en: But they did not offer it as a fundamental contribution to the development of transport, rather as an object of recreation.
vi: They did not introduce it as a fundamental contribution to transportation development but presented it as a toy.
tr: But they presented it not as a fundamental contribution to the development of transportation, but as an entertainment device.
es: But they did not offer it as a fundamental contribution to the development of transportation, but as a recreational object.

en: The people at once dug up their last gold pieces to take advantage of a quick flight over the houses of the village.
vi: Of course, the villagers dug out their last bits of gold to enjoy a swift flight over the rooftops in the village.
tr: The people dug up their last gold coins from the ground just to take a quick flight over the village.
es: The people, of course, unearthed their last bits of gold to enjoy a fleeting flight over the village houses.

en: Protected by the delightful cover of collective disorder, José Arcadio and Pilar passed many relaxing hours.
vi: Taking advantage of the public's noisy and fascinating forgiveness, José Arcadio and Pilar Ternera lived hours of freedom.
tr: Taking advantage of the chaos that everyone was participating in, Jose Arcadio and Pilar mingled with the crowd and had fun for hours.
es: Taking advantage of the delightful impunity of collective disorder, José Arcadio and Pilar experienced hours of relief.

en: They were two happy lovers among the crowd, and they even came to suspect that love could be a feeling that was more relaxing and deep than the happiness, wild but momentary, of their secret nights.
vi: They were two lovers blissfully happy amidst the crowd, to the point of believing that their love was deeper and more profound than the ultimate and immediate pleasure they experienced during their secret nights.
tr: Among all those people, they were two newly in love, flying with happiness, and they almost believed that love was a much deeper and more comforting feeling than the ecstatic but fleeting happiness of the nights they secretly met.
es: They were two happy lovers among the crowd, and they even began to suspect that love could be a more serene and profound feeling than the wild but momentary happiness of their secret nights.

en: Pilar, however, broke the spell.
vi: However, Pilar Ternera shattered that joy.
tr: However, Pilar broke the spell.
es: Pilar, however, broke the spell.

en: Stimulated by the enthusiasm that José Arcadio showed in her companionship, she confused the form and the occasion, and all of a sudden she threw the whole world on top of him.
vi: Elated by José Arcadio's passion while enjoying their couple's happiness, she confused the manner and timing of her words, suddenly placing a heavy responsibility on his shoulders as vast as the globe.
tr: Jose Arcadio, caught up in the joy of being with her, forgot the time and place and brought the world crashing down on the boy's head.
es: Encouraged by the enthusiasm with which José Arcadio enjoyed her company, she mistook the form and the occasion, and in one fell swoop, she threw the world upon him.

en: “Now you really are a man,” she told him.
vi: "Now, you are a man," she told him.
tr: She said, "Now you have truly become a man."
es: “Now you are a man,” she said to him.

en: And since he did not understand what she meant, she spelled it out to him.
vi: And because he did not understand what she had just said, she calmly explained it in detail:
tr: When the young man couldn't understand what she meant, she said it plainly:
es: And since he did not understand what she wanted to tell him, she explained it to him letter by letter:

en: “You’re going to be a father.”
vi: - It means you will have a son.
tr: -You're going to be a father.
es: —You are going to have a child.

en: José Arcadio did not dare leave the house for several days.
vi: For several days in a row, José Arcadio did not dare to leave the house.
tr: Jose Arcadio couldn't step out of the house for a few days.
es: José Arcadio did not dare to leave his house for several days.

en: It was enough for him to hear the rocking laughter of Pilar in the kitchen to run and take refuge in the laboratory, where the artifacts of alchemy had come alive again with Úrsula’s blessing.
vi: Just hearing the giggling of Pilar Ternera was enough to make him hide in the laboratory, where the handicrafts, the fruits of alchemy, were coming to life thanks to Úrsula's charity.
tr: As soon as he heard Pilar's cheerful laughter from the kitchen, he would take refuge in the laboratory where, with Ursula's permission, the alchemy experiments had regained momentum.
es: It was enough for him to hear Pilar's boisterous laughter in the kitchen to run and take refuge in the laboratory, where the alchemy artifacts had come back to life with Úrsula's blessing.

en: José Arcadio Buendía received his errant son with joy and initiated him in the search for the philosopher’s stone, which he had finally undertaken.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía warmly welcomed the wayward son and guided him as an apprentice in the alchemical work that he had thoroughly understood.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia welcomed his wayward son with joy and included him in the alchemical stone research he had finally decided to undertake.
es: José Arcadio Buendía welcomed the lost son with joy and initiated him into the search for the philosopher's stone, which he had finally undertaken.

en: One afternoon the boys grew enthusiastic over the flying carpet that went swiftly by the laboratory at window level carrying the gypsy who was driving it and several children from the village who were merrily waving their hands, but José Arcadio Buendía did not even look at it.
vi: One afternoon, the two brothers were very excited by the sight of a flying carpet passing by the laboratory window, carrying the gypsy driver and several village children who were happily waving, and José Arcadio Buendía did not even glance at the flying carpet.
tr: One evening, when a gypsy, who had seated the village children waving happily behind him, flew the carpet past the laboratory window, the boys' minds were captivated by the flying carpet, but Jose Arcadio Buendia didn't even turn his head to look.
es: One afternoon, the boys got excited about the flying carpet that swiftly passed by the laboratory window, carrying the gypsy driver and several village children who were cheerfully waving, and José Arcadio Buendía didn't even look at it.

en: “Let them dream,” he said.
vi: "Let them dream," he said, "we will fly higher than them with scientific means far superior to this pathetic flying carpet.
tr: Let them think they are flying, he said.
es: "Let them dream," he said.

en: “We’ll do better flying than they are doing, and with more scientific resources than a miserable bedspread.”
tr: We will fly better than them, and not with a tattered blanket, but with scientific tools.
es: "We will fly better than they do with more scientific resources than that miserable bedspread."

en: In spite of his feigned interest, José Arcadio must understood the powers of the philosopher’s egg, which to him looked like a poorly blown bottle.
vi: Even though he had to pretend to be interested in the work, José Arcadio could never understand the grand possibilities of the alchemical furnace, which to him was simply a poorly made glass jar.
tr: Although Jose Arcadio seemed interested, he couldn't fathom the mystery of the alchemist's egg, which resembled a clumsily blown, crooked bottle.
es: Despite his feigned interest, José Arcadio never understood the powers of the philosophical egg, which simply seemed to him like a poorly made flask.

en: He did not succeed in escaping from his worries.
vi: He lost his appetite, suffered from insomnia, became irritable, just like his father when he faced failures in some tasks, and his erratic state forced his father to take over all the work in the alchemical furnace, thinking that the work was too exhausting for him.
tr: He couldn't rid himself of his worries.
es: He couldn't escape his worry.

en: He lost his appetite and he could not sleep.
vi: He lost his appetite, suffered from insomnia, became irritable, just like his father when he faced failures in some tasks, and his erratic state forced his father to take over all the work in the alchemical furnace, thinking that the work was too exhausting for him.
tr: He stopped eating and drinking, and couldn't sleep.
es: He lost his appetite and sleep, succumbed to bad temper, just like his father when one of his ventures failed, and his distress was so great that José Arcadio Buendía himself relieved him of his duties in the laboratory, believing he had taken alchemy too seriously.

en: He fell into an ill humor, the same as his father’s over the failure of his undertakings, and such was his upset that José Arcadio Buendía himself relieved him of his duties in the laboratory, thinking that he had taken alchemy too much to heart.
vi: He lost his appetite, suffered from insomnia, became irritable, just like his father when he faced failures in some tasks, and his erratic state forced his father to take over all the work in the alchemical furnace, thinking that the work was too exhausting for him.
tr: Just as his father would become sullen when his experiments failed, Jose Arcadio's face would also fall into a thousand pieces, so much so that Jose Arcadio Buendia thought the boy was too obsessed with this alchemy business and removed him from his duties in the laboratory.
es: He lost his appetite and sleep, succumbed to bad temper, just like his father when one of his ventures failed, and his distress was so great that José Arcadio Buendía himself relieved him of his duties in the laboratory, believing he had taken alchemy too seriously.

en: Aureliano, of course, understood that his brother’s affliction did not have its source in the search for the philosopher’s stone but he could not get into his confidence.
vi: Aureliano, of course, understood that his brother's suffering had nothing to do with the alchemical furnace, but he could not get him to reveal the deeper issue.
tr: Aureliano knew that his brother's problem did not stem from searching for the philosopher's stone, but he couldn't get a word out of him.
es: Aureliano, of course, understood that his brother's distress did not originate from the search for the philosopher's stone, but he couldn't get him to confide in him.

en: He had lost his former spontaneity.
vi: José Arcadio was no longer as lively as before.
tr: Jose Arcadio's former sincerity was gone; he had ceased to be someone who shared his secrets and talked, becoming instead a withdrawn, rude person.
es: He had lost his former spontaneity.

en: From an accomplice and a communicative person he had become withdrawn and hostile.
vi: From being witty and open, he became secretive and difficult.
tr: He harbored a bitter resentment against the whole world and avoided everyone.
es: From being a communicative accomplice, he became secretive and hostile.

en: Anxious for solitude, bitten by a virulent rancor against the world, one night he left his bed as usual, but he did not go to Pilar Ternera’s house, but to mingle is the tumult of the fair.
vi: Too fond of solitude, always angry at everything around him, one night, as usual, he left his bed empty and went out, but instead of going to Pilar Ternera's house, he went straight to the fair.
tr: One night, as usual, he slipped out of bed, but instead of going to Pilar Ternera's house, he mingled with the noisy crowd of the fair.
es: Anxious for solitude, bitten by a virulent resentment against the world, one night he left his bed as usual, but instead of going to Pilar Ternera's house, he mingled with the tumult of the fair.

en: After wandering about among all kinds of contraptions with out becoming interested in any of them, he spotted something that was not a part of it all: a very young gypsy girl, almost a child, who was weighted down by beads and was the most beautiful woman that José Arcadio had ever seen in his life.
vi: After wandering through all the amusements, uninterested in any of them, he noticed someone not performing, a very young gypsy girl, almost still a child, wearing a necklace full of fake crystal gems. She was the most beautiful woman he had ever seen until then.
tr: Among the myriad of shows, after wandering without turning his head to any of them, something unrelated to the exhibited skills caught his eye: It was a very young gypsy girl, almost a child, whose neck was weighed down by the beads she wore, and she was the most beautiful woman Jose Arcadio had ever seen in his life.
es: After wandering among all sorts of contraptions without being interested in any, he focused on something that wasn't part of the show: a very young gypsy girl, almost a child, laden with trinkets, the most beautiful woman José Arcadio had ever seen in his life.

en: She was in the crowd that was witnessing the sad spectacle of the man who had been turned into a snake for having disobeyed his parents.
vi: He was in the middle of a crowd engrossed in watching a man turn into a snake for not obeying his parents.
tr: The girl was standing among the crowd watching the tragic adventure of the man who turned into a snake for not obeying his parents.
es: She was among the crowd watching the sad spectacle of the man who turned into a snake for disobeying his parents.

en: José Arcadio paid no attention.
vi: Hôsê Accađiô didn't pay attention.
tr: Jose Arcadio showed no interest in the performance.
es: José Arcadio paid no attention.

en: While the sad interrogation of the snake-man was taking place, he made his way through the crowd up to the front row, where the gypsy girl was, and he stooped behind her.
vi: While the interrogation of the snake-man was taking place, he weaved through the crowd to reach the first place where he met the gypsy girl, stopping behind her.
tr: While the pitiful interrogation of the snake man continued, he pushed through the crowd to the front row where the girl was standing, walked up, and stood right behind her.
es: While the sad interrogation of the snake-man was taking place, he had made his way through the crowd to the front row where the gypsy girl was, and had stopped behind her.

en: He pressed against her back.
vi: From behind, he wrapped his arms around her waist.
tr: He pressed closely against the girl's back.
es: He pressed against her back.

en: The girl tried to separate herself, but José Arcadio pressed more strongly against her back.
vi: She tried to break free, but Hôsê Accađiô held her tighter.
tr: When the girl tried to pull away, Jose Arcadio leaned in even more.
es: The girl tried to move away, but José Arcadio pressed harder against her back.

en: Then she felt him.
vi: So she was moved, standing still but still turning her back to him, trembling with surprise and fear, unable to believe it was real; finally, she turned her face, looking at him with a trembling smile.
tr: It was then that the girl felt him completely.
es: Then she felt it.

en: She remained motionless against him, trembling with surprise and fear, unable to believe the evidence, and finally she turned her head and looked at him with a tremulous smile.
vi: So she was moved, standing still but still turning her back to him, trembling with surprise and fear, unable to believe it was real; finally, she turned her face, looking at him with a trembling smile.
tr: Unable to believe this was real, she leaned against the young man in shock and fear without moving, and finally, unable to resist, she turned her head and gave a timid smile.
es: She remained motionless against him, trembling with surprise and fear, unable to believe the evidence, and finally turned her head and looked at him with a trembling smile.

en: At that instant two gypsies put the snake-man into his cage and carried him into the tent.
vi: Meanwhile, two gypsy men shoved the snake-man into a bag and carried him inside the shop.
tr: At that moment, two gypsies locked the snake man in his cage and took him to the tent.
es: At that moment, two gypsies put the snake-man into his cage and took him inside the tent.

en: The gypsy who was conducting the show announced:
vi: A gypsy ringleader turned to the audience and said:
tr: The gypsy running the show addressed the audience: Ladies and gentlemen, now we will show you the chilling ordeal of the woman who, as punishment for seeing something she shouldn't have, is beheaded every night at this exact hour for the past one hundred and fifty years.
es: The gypsy who was directing the show announced:

en: “And now, ladies and gentlemen, we are going to show the terrible test of the woman who must have her head chopped off every night at this time for one hundred and fifty years as punishment for having seen what she should not have.”
vi: - Ladies and gentlemen, now we would like to present a thrilling act about a woman who, every night just like tonight, has been beheaded at this exact hour for one hundred and fifty years for daring to look at what she shouldn't have.
tr: The gypsy running the show addressed the audience: Ladies and gentlemen, now we will show you the chilling ordeal of the woman who, as punishment for seeing something she shouldn't have, is beheaded every night at this exact hour for the past one hundred and fifty years.
es: —And now, ladies and gentlemen, we are going to show the terrible ordeal of the woman who will have to be decapitated every night at this hour for one hundred and fifty years, as punishment for having seen what she should not have.

en: José Arcadio and the gypsy girl did not witness the decapitation.
vi: Hôsê Accađiô and the girl did not watch the beheading act.
tr: Jose Arcadio and the gypsy girl did not watch the beheading scene.
es: José Arcadio and the girl did not witness the decapitation.

en: They went to her tent, where they kissed each other with a desperate anxiety while they took off their clothes.
vi: They went to her place, where in desperate longing they indulged in kissing while undressing.
tr: They went to the girl's tent, and while undressing, they began to kiss each other with frantic passion.
es: They went to her tent, where they kissed with desperate anxiety while they took off their clothes.

en: The gypsy girl removed the starched lace corsets she had on and there she was, changed into practically nothing.
vi: The gypsy girl took off all her outer garments, petticoats, heavily padded corset, and fake crystal pearl necklace, and suddenly her once full breasts and wide hips disappeared.
tr: When the gypsy girl took off her starched lace corset, she was left completely naked.
es: The gypsy girl got rid of her overlapping bodices, her numerous starched lace petticoats, her useless wired corset, her load of trinkets, and was practically reduced to nothing.

en: She was a languid little frog, with incipient breasts and legs so thin that they did not even match the size of José Arcadio’s arms, but she had a decision and a warmth that compensated for her fragility.
vi: In reality, her body was like a dry branch, with a flat chest and thin thighs that were not even as big as Hôsê Accađiô's arms, but she had a bold demeanor and a warm scent that compensated.
tr: Her newly budding breasts and her spindly legs, which were not even as thick as Jose Arcadio's arms, made her resemble a frail frog, but she had a boldness and warmth that made one forget her frailty.
es: She was a languid little frog, with budding breasts and legs so thin that they did not surpass José Arcadio's arms in diameter, but she had a determination and warmth that compensated for her fragility.

en: Nevertheless, José Arcadio could not respond to her because they were in a kind of public tent where the gypsies passed through with their circus things and did their business, and would even tarry by the bed for a game of dice.
vi: However, Hôsê Accađiô couldn't immediately respond to her fervor because they were in a public place, where gypsies frequently passed by, sometimes carrying circus equipment, sometimes in costume, and occasionally gathering beside the bed to play a game of dice.
tr: However, Jose Arcadio could not respond to the girl's advances, because the tent they entered was a busy place where the gypsies constantly came and went to take their circus equipment and do their work, and sometimes even stood by the bed to play dice.
es: However, José Arcadio could not respond to her because they were in a sort of public tent, where the gypsies passed by with their circus things and took care of their affairs, and even lingered by the bed to play a game of dice.

en: The lamp hanging from the center pole lighted the whole place up.
vi: A lamp hanging from a pole in the middle of the yard illuminated the surroundings.
tr: The lantern hanging from the central pole illuminated everything.
es: The lamp hanging from the central pole illuminated the entire space.

en: During a pause in the caresses, José Arcadio stretched out naked on the bed without knowing what to do, while the girl tried to inspire him.
vi: When they stopped caressing each other, Hôsê Accađiô lay naked, stretched out on the bed, not knowing what else to do, while the girl tried to seduce him.
tr: When they paused their foreplay, as the girl, not knowing what to do, tried to arouse the completely naked Jose Arcadio lying on the bed, a gypsy woman with marvelous skin, followed by a man who was neither from the camp nor the villagers, entered the tent and started undressing by the bed.
es: In a pause of the caresses, José Arcadio stretched out naked on the bed, not knowing what to do, while the girl tried to encourage him.

en: A gypsy woman with splendid flesh came in a short time after accompanied by a man who was not of the caravan but who was not from the village either, and they both began to undress in front of the bed.
vi: Later, a sleek-skinned gypsy woman walked in, followed by a man who was neither part of the circus troupe nor from the village. Then both of them undressed right in front of the bed where Hôsê Accađiô was lying.
tr: When they paused their foreplay, as the girl, not knowing what to do, tried to arouse the completely naked Jose Arcadio lying on the bed, a gypsy woman with marvelous skin, followed by a man who was neither from the camp nor the villagers, entered the tent and started undressing by the bed.
es: A gypsy woman of splendid flesh entered shortly after, accompanied by a man who was not part of the troupe, but who was also not from the village, and they both began to undress in front of the bed.

en: Without meaning to, the woman looked at José Arcadio and examined his magnificent animal in repose with a kind of pathetic fervor.
vi: Without intending to tease him, the woman looked at Hôsê Accađiô, filled with desire, eagerly admiring his magnificent resting organ. - Oh, my friend?
tr: At one point, the woman's eyes fell on Jose Arcadio, and she examined his fallen, beastly sign from head to toe with fiery excitement.
es: Unintentionally, the woman looked at José Arcadio and examined with a kind of pathetic fervor his magnificent animal at rest.

en: “My boy,” she exclaimed, “may God preserve you just as you are.”
vi: - She exclaimed. - May God protect your sister for you, my friend.
tr: "Oh my boy," he exclaimed, "I hope you stay just the way you are."
es: —Boy —he exclaimed—, may God preserve it for you.

en: José Arcadio’s companion asked them to leave them alone, and the couple lay down on the ground, close to the bed.
vi: The girlfriend of José Arcadio requested to be left alone and the couple lay down on the floor right next to the bed.
tr: The girl next to Jose Arcadio snapped, Leave us alone, and the newcomers knelt down on the floor beside the bed.
es: José Arcadio's companion asked them to leave them alone, and the couple lay down on the floor, very close to the bed.

en: The passion of the others woke up José Arcadio’s fervor.
vi: The passion of the others awakened José Arcadio's fervor.
tr: Their passionate caressing also fueled Jose Arcadio's desire.
es: The passion of the others awakened José Arcadio's fever.

en: On the first contact the bones of the girl seemed to become disjointed with a disorderly crunch like the sound of a box of dominoes, and her skin broke out into a pale sweat and her eyes filled with tears as her whole body exhaled a lugubrious lament and a vague smell of mud.
vi: From the very first moment, the girl's bones seemed to come loose, cracking like dominoes touching each other, her skin slick with a yellowish sweat, her eyes brimming with tears, her whole body emitting a moaning sound and a persistent smell of mud lingering around.
tr: At the first thrust, the girl's bones cracked as if a box of dominoes had scattered around, a light sweat broke out on her skin, a mournful moan and a faint smell of mud rose from her entire body as her eyes filled with tears.
es: At the first contact, the girl's bones seemed to disarticulate with a disordered crackle like that of a domino file, and her skin dissolved into a pale sweat and her eyes filled with tears and her whole body exhaled a mournful lament and a vague smell of mud.

en: But she bore the impact with a firmness of character and a bravery that were admirable.
vi: But the resilient girl endured the encounter with a steadfast character and an admirable courage.
tr: But he endured this blow with an admirable will and bravery.
es: But she endured the impact with admirable firmness of character and bravery.

en: José Arcadio felt himself lifted up into the air toward a state of seraphic inspiration, where his heart burst forth with an outpouring of tender obscenities that entered the girl through her ears and came out of her mouth translated into her language.
vi: At that moment, José Arcadio felt himself being lifted to a breathless state where his heart melted into a well of gentle sensuality flowing into the girl through her ears and coming out through her mouth, transformed into words translated into her language.
tr: Arcadio felt as if he were ascending to the realm of angels, and the love-filled, explicit words that overflowed from his heart entered the girl's ears and began to spill from her mouth in the gypsy language.
es: José Arcadio then felt lifted into a state of seraphic inspiration, where his heart unraveled into a spring of tender obscenities that entered the girl through her ears and came out of her mouth translated into her language.

en: It was Thursday.
vi: It was Thursday.
tr: It was a Thursday.
es: It was Thursday.

en: On Saturday night, José Arcadio wrapped a red cloth around his head and left with the gypsies.
vi: On Saturday night, with a red scarf on his head, José Arcadio left home with the gypsies.
tr: On Saturday night, Jose Arcadio wrapped a red scarf around his head and left with the gypsies.
es: On Saturday night, José Arcadio tied a red cloth around his head and left with the gypsies.

en: When Úrsula discovered his absence she searched for him all through the village.
vi: When Úrsula noticed his absence, she hurriedly went around the village looking for him.
tr: Ursula, upon realizing that he had disappeared, turned the village upside down.
es: When Úrsula discovered his absence, she looked for him all over the village.

en: In the remains of the gypsy camp there was nothing but a garbage pit among the still smoking ashes of the extinguished campfires.
vi: At the desolate camp, there was nothing more than a stream of dirty water amidst the still-hot ashes in the extinguished hearths.
tr: At the place where the tribe had camped, there was nothing but a trash can among the extinguished fires that were still smoldering.
es: In the dismantled camp of the gypsies, there was nothing but a trail of waste among the still-smoldering ashes of the extinguished fires.

en: Someone who was there looking for beads among the trash told Úrsula that the night before he had seen her son in the tumult of the caravan pushing the snake-man’s cage on a cart.
vi: A person searching for fake crystal beads in the garbage told Úrsula that last night they had seen her son mingling with the noisy gypsies, pushing a cage cart with the snake-man inside.
tr: Someone searching for trinkets among the debris told Ursula that they had seen her son the night before, being taken away in a wheelbarrow with the snake man's cage in the middle of the gypsy caravan.
es: Someone who was rummaging through the trash for trinkets told Úrsula that the night before, they had seen her son in the tumult of the carnival, pushing a wheelbarrow with the cage of the snake-man.

en: “He’s become a gypsy” she shouted to her husband, who had not shown the slightest sign of alarm over the disappearance.
vi: "So he has gone off with the gypsies," she screamed into his ear, showing no sign of worry at the news of their son's disappearance.
tr: To her husband, who didn't care in the slightest about the boy's disappearance; "The boy has turned into a gypsy!" Ursula exclaimed.
es: “He joined the gypsies!” she shouted to her husband, who had shown no sign of alarm at the disappearance.

en: “I hope it’s true,” José Arcadio Buendía said, grinding in his mortar the material that had been ground a thousand times and reheated and ground again.
vi: - God willing, it will be so, - José Arcadio Buendía said as he continued to grind the material that had been ground a thousand times in the mortar, fired, and then ground again.
tr: After being beaten a thousand times and reheated a thousand times, Jose Arcadio Buendia, who was pounding the mortar in the mortar, said, "I wish it were so.
es: —I wish it were true —said José Arcadio Buendía, pounding in the mortar the substance that had been pounded a thousand times, reheated, and pounded again—.

en: “That way he’ll learn to be a man.”
vi: - That way, it will learn to be human.
tr: He would learn to be a man that way."
es: That way he will learn to be a man.

en: Úrsula asked where the gypsies had gone.
vi: Ursula asked everyone which direction the gypsies had gone.
tr: Ursula asked around to find out where the gypsies had gone.
es: Úrsula asked where the gypsies had gone.

en: She went along asking and following the road she had been shown, thinking that she still had time to catch up to them.
vi: On the way, she kept asking, and people kept pointing her in the direction, so she continued on, thinking there was still time to catch up with her son.
tr: With the hope of catching up to them, she set off on the indicated path and began walking, asking as she went.
es: She continued asking along the path they indicated, and believing she still had time to catch up with them, she kept moving away from the village until she realized she was so far away that she no longer thought of returning.

en: She kept getting farther away from the village until she felt so far away that she did not think about returning.
vi: In this manner, she went farther and farther from the village until she realized she had gone so far that she didn't think she could return.
tr: She got farther and farther from the village, and eventually, thinking she had completely lost touch with the village, she dismissed the idea of returning.
es: She continued asking along the path they indicated, and believing she still had time to catch up with them, she kept moving away from the village until she realized she was so far away that she no longer thought of returning.

en: José Arcadio Buendía did not discover that his wife was missing until eight o’clock at night, when he left the material warming in a bed of manure and went to see what was wrong with little Amaranta, who was getting hoarse from crying.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía only noticed his wife's absence at eight o'clock in the evening, when he placed the remelted alloy on a layer of mulch and went to see why baby Amaranta was crying hoarsely.
tr: At eight in the evening, after burying the prepared materials in warm manure to prevent them from freezing, Jose Arcadio Buendia entered the house, curious about what had happened to Amaranta, who had turned purple from crying, and noticed that Ursula was nowhere to be seen.
es: José Arcadio Buendía did not notice his wife's absence until eight o'clock at night, when he left the substance reheating in a bed of manure and went to see what was wrong with little Amaranta, who was hoarse from crying.

en: In a few hours he gathered a group of well-equipped men, put Amaranta in the hands of a woman who offered to nurse her, and was lost on invisible paths in pursuit of Úrsula.
vi: A few hours later, he gathered a group of men, equipped them neatly, placed baby Amaranta in the hands of a woman who agreed to nurse her, and then went to look for Ursula.
tr: Within a few hours, he gathered a fully armed group, entrusted Amaranta to a woman who volunteered to nurse her, and set off on the invisible paths in search of Ursula.
es: In a few hours, he gathered a group of well-equipped men, placed Amaranta in the care of a woman who offered to nurse her, and disappeared down invisible paths in search of Úrsula.

en: Aureliano went with them.
vi: Aureliano also went with them.
tr: Aureliano went with them.
es: Aureliano accompanied them.

en: Some Indian fishermen, whose language they could not understand, told them with signs that they had not seen anyone pass.
vi: The indigenous fishermen, through gestures, indicated to them that they hadn't seen anyone pass by since early morning.
tr: Indian fishermen, whose language they did not understand, tried to explain through gestures that they had not seen anyone pass by.
es: Some indigenous fishermen, whose language they did not understand, indicated by signs at dawn that they had not seen anyone pass by.

en: After three days of useless searching they returned to the village.
vi: After three days of futile searching, the search party returned to the village.
tr: After searching in vain for three days, they returned to the village.
es: After three days of futile searching, they returned to the village.

en: For several weeks José Arcadio Buendía let himself be overcome by consternation.
vi: In a few weeks, José Arcadio Buendía was completely disheartened.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia agonized for weeks out of curiosity.
es: For several weeks, José Arcadio Buendía succumbed to consternation.

en: He took care of little Amaranta like a mother.
vi: He took care of baby Amaranta like a mother.
tr: He took care of Amaranta, washed and cleaned her, swaddled her, carried her to the wet nurse four times a day, and even sang lullabies at night that Ursula could never manage.
es: He took care of little Amaranta like a mother.

en: He bathed and dressed her, took her to be nursed four times a day, and even sang to her at night the songs that Úrsula never knew how to sing.
vi: He bathed and changed the baby's clothes, and during the day, he took the baby to nurse four times, and at night he sang lullabies to put the baby to sleep, something Úrsula had never done.
tr: He took care of Amaranta, washed and cleaned her, swaddled her, carried her to the wet nurse four times a day, and even sang lullabies at night that Ursula could never manage.
es: He bathed her and changed her clothes, took her to be nursed four times a day, and even sang to her at night the songs that Úrsula never knew how to sing.

en: On a certain occasion Pilar Ternera volunteered to do the household chores until Úrsula came back.
vi: Once, Pilar Ternera volunteered to help with the household chores until Úrsula returned.
tr: At one point, Pilar Ternera volunteered to take care of the household chores until Ursula returned.
es: On one occasion, Pilar Ternera offered to do the household chores while Úrsula returned.

en: Aureliano, whose mysterious intuition had become sharpened with the misfortune, felt a glow of clairvoyance when he saw her come in.
vi: Aureliano, whose strange intuition had already sensed that she was the culprit behind this misfortune, glared at her as she entered.
tr: Aureliano, whose instincts had become even sharper due to the disaster that had befallen them, immediately sensed upon seeing the woman that she was responsible for his brother's escape and his mother's subsequent disappearance.
es: Aureliano, whose mysterious intuition had become sensitized in misfortune, experienced a flash of clairvoyance upon seeing her enter.

en: Then he knew that in some inexplicable way she was to blame for his brother’s flight and the consequent disappearance of his mother, and he harassed her with a silent and implacable hostility in such a way that the woman did not return to the house.
vi: Thus, he knew that in whatever form, she was guilty of his brother's departure and his mother's disappearance, and in this way, he silently and resolutely condemned her, causing the woman to no longer dare to set foot in the house.
tr: He greeted the suggestion so silently and sullenly that the woman never set foot in the house again.
es: Then he knew that in some inexplicable way she was to blame for his brother's flight and his mother's subsequent disappearance, and he harassed her so much, with a silent and implacable hostility, that the woman never returned to the house.

en: Time put things in their place.
vi: As time passed, everything fell back into place.
tr: Time set everything right.
es: Time put things in their place.

en: José Arcadio Buendía and his son did not know exactly when they returned to the laboratory, dusting things, lighting the water pipe, involved once more in the patient manipulation of the material that had been sleeping for several months in its bed of manure.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía and his son did not realize when they resumed working in the laboratory, dusting, heating the test tubes, and then becoming engrossed in the preparation of alloys that had lain dormant under a layer of dust for several months.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia and his son found themselves at work without even realizing when they had returned to the laboratory, dusted off the place, set the still on the fire, and patiently started processing the materials that had been lying in manure for months.
es: José Arcadio Buendía and his son did not know at what moment they were back in the laboratory, shaking off the dust, lighting the fire in the athanor, once again dedicated to the patient manipulation of the matter that had been dormant for several months in its bed of manure.

en: Even Amaranta, lying in a wicker basket, observed with curiosity the absorbing work of her father and her brother in the small room where the air was rarefied by mercury vapors.
vi: Even little Amaranta, snug in her wicker cradle, curiously observed the silent work of her father and brother in the room that had become strange due to the mercury fumes.
tr: Even Amaranta, lying in her wicker basket, watched with curiosity as her father and brother worked diligently in the small room, which had become heavy with mercury vapors.
es: Even Amaranta, lying in a wicker basket, observed with curiosity the absorbing work of her father and brother in the little room made rarefied by mercury vapors.

en: On a certain occasion, months after Úrsula’s departure, strange things began to happen.
vi: After several months of Úrsula's disappearance, some strange events occurred one day.
tr: Months after Ursula's departure, strange things began to happen.
es: On one occasion, months after Úrsula's departure, strange things began to happen.

en: An empty flask that had been forgotten in a cupboard for a long time became so heavy that it could not be moved.
vi: An empty glass jar that had been forgotten on a shelf for a long time suddenly became so heavy that it could not be moved.
tr: An empty bottle that had been forgotten in a corner of the cupboard for a long time suddenly became too heavy to lift.
es: An empty jar that had been forgotten in a cupboard for a long time became so heavy that it was impossible to move.

en: A pan of water on the worktable boiled without any fire under it for a half hour until it completely evaporated.
vi: A pot of filtered water placed on the work table, without any fire underneath, suddenly started boiling and within half an hour, all the water had evaporated.
tr: A pot of water on the workbench started boiling vigorously without any fire underneath it and continued to boil for half an hour until all the water had evaporated.
es: A pot of water placed on the work table boiled without fire for half an hour until it completely evaporated.

en: José Arcadio Buendía and his son observed those phenomena with startled excitement, unable to explain them but interpreting them as predictions of the material.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía and his son were startled by these phenomena and could not explain them, but they insisted that they were omens of the alloy that was about to be created.
tr: Unable to explain these occurrences but attributing them to the maturation of the philosopher's stone, Jose Arcadio Buendia and his son watched what was happening with astonishment and excitement.
es: José Arcadio Buendía and his son observed those phenomena with frightened joy, unable to explain them, but interpreting them as signs from the matter.

en: One day Amaranta’s basket began to move by itself and made a complete turn about the room, to the consternation of Auerliano, who hurried to stop it.
vi: One day, little Amaranta's cradle started spinning on its own and moved around the room, much to the alarm of Aureliano, who rushed to stop it.
tr: One day, Amaranta's basket suddenly started moving, spinning around the room until Aureliano rushed in and caught it.
es: One day, Amaranta's basket began to move on its own and made a complete turn in the room, to the consternation of Aureliano, who hurried to stop it.

en: But his father did not get upset.
vi: But his father remained calm and unperturbed.
tr: But his father did not panic at all.
es: But his father was not disturbed.

en: He put the basket in its place and tied it to the leg of a table, convinced that the long-awaited event was imminent.
vi: He placed the cradle back in its original spot and tied it to a table leg, convinced that the long-awaited event was imminent.
tr: Firmly believing that the miracle they had been waiting for was imminent, he put the basket back in its place and tied it securely to the leg of the table.
es: He put the basket back in its place and tied it to the leg of a table, convinced that the awaited event was imminent.

en: It was on that occasion that Auerliano heard him say:
vi: At that moment, Aureliano heard his father say:
tr: It was after this incident that Aureliano heard these words from his father's mouth:
es: It was on that occasion that Aureliano heard him say:

en: “If you don’t fear God, fear him through the metals.
vi: - If you do not fear God, then fear metal instead!
tr: -If you do not fear God, at least let the miracle of the mines instill the fear of God in you.
es: —If you do not fear God, fear the metals.

en: Suddenly, almost five months after her disappearance, Úrsula came back.
vi: Suddenly, Úrsula returned after nearly five months of being missing.
tr: Ursula suddenly reappeared about five months after her mysterious disappearance.
es: Suddenly, almost five months after her disappearance, Úrsula returned.

en: She arrived exalted, rejuvenated, with new clothes in a style that was unknown in the village.
vi: She came back looking cheerful, youthful, wearing a dress that was unfamiliar to the villagers.
tr: She had undergone a transformation, becoming elevated, rejuvenated, and dressed in a manner unfamiliar to the villagers.
es: She arrived excited, rejuvenated, with new clothes of a style unknown in the village.

en: José Arcadio Buendía could barely stand up under the impact.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía, overwhelmed with joy and sorrow, could hardly resist hugging and kissing her.
tr: When Jose Arcadio Buendia saw her like this in front of him, his knees gave way.
es: José Arcadio Buendía could barely withstand the impact.

en: “That was it!” he shouted.
vi: "Oh my, so that's how it is!", he exclaimed: "I knew it would happen" and he truly believed it, because during his solitary sessions in the room while concocting compounds, from the depths of his heart he had prayed for the eagerly awaited event to occur—not as the perfect result of alchemy, not as liberation from the furnace blowing fire to melt metals, not as the magic to turn the hinges and locks of the house into gold, but as the event that had just happened: Úrsula's return.
tr: That's it!
es: “This was it!” he shouted.

en: “I knew it was going to happen.”
vi: "Oh my, so that's how it is!", he exclaimed: "I knew it would happen" and he truly believed it, because during his solitary sessions in the room while concocting compounds, from the depths of his heart he had prayed for the eagerly awaited event to occur—not as the perfect result of alchemy, not as liberation from the furnace blowing fire to melt metals, not as the magic to turn the hinges and locks of the house into gold, but as the event that had just happened: Úrsula's return.
tr: he shouted, I knew this would happen.
es: “I knew it was going to happen.”

en: And he really believed it, for during his prolonged imprisonment as he manipulated the material, he begged in the depth of his heart that the longed-for miracle should not be the discovery of the philosopher’s stone, or the freeing of the breath that makes metals live, or the faculty to convert the hinges and the locks of the house into gold, but what had just happened: Úrsula’s return.
vi: "Oh my, so that's how it is!", he exclaimed: "I knew it would happen" and he truly believed it, because during his solitary sessions in the room while concocting compounds, from the depths of his heart he had prayed for the eagerly awaited event to occur—not as the perfect result of alchemy, not as liberation from the furnace blowing fire to melt metals, not as the magic to turn the hinges and locks of the house into gold, but as the event that had just happened: Úrsula's return.
tr: Indeed, while he had been secluded all that time preparing the materials for the alchemist's stone, he had prayed from the depths of his heart, yearning for the awaited miracle, not the discovery of the philosopher's stone or the release of the breath that would animate metals, or the ability to turn the hinges and locks in the house into gold, but for the event of that very moment to happen, for Ursula to return.
es: And he truly believed it, because in his prolonged seclusions, while manipulating matter, he prayed deep in his heart that the awaited miracle would not be the discovery of the philosopher's stone, nor the liberation of the breath that gives life to metals, nor the ability to turn the house's hinges and locks into gold, but what had now occurred: Úrsula's return.

en: But she did not share his excitement.
vi: But she did not share her husband's noisy joy.
tr: But Ursula paid no attention to his excitement.
es: But she did not share his joy.

en: She gave him a conventional kiss, as if she had been away only an hour, and she told him:
vi: She kissed him out of habit as if she had been away for no more than an hour, then told him:
tr: After giving her husband a perfunctory kiss as if she had been gone for just an hour, she said, Look outside.
es: She gave him a conventional kiss, as if she had not been absent for more than an hour, and said to him:

en: “Look out the door.”
vi: - Let's go outside!
tr: After giving her husband a perfunctory kiss as if she had been gone for just an hour, she said, Look outside.
es: —Take a look at the door.

en: José Arcadio Buendía took a long time to get out of his perplexity when he went out into the street and saw the crowd.
vi: When he went out and looked at the crowd, José Arcadio Buendía took a long time to come to his senses.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia, when he went out into the street and saw the crowd, was unable to recover from his astonishment for a long time and couldn't figure out what was happening.
es: José Arcadio Buendía took a long time to recover from his bewilderment when he went out into the street and saw the crowd.

en: They were not gypsies.
vi: They were not gypsies.
tr: These people were not gypsies.
es: They were not gypsies.

en: They were men and women like them, with straight hair and dark skin, who spoke the same language and complained of the same pains.
vi: They were men and women just like the villagers, with the same soft hair and brown skin, speaking the same language as him and lamenting the same sorrows.
tr: They were people with straight hair like theirs, dark-skinned, speaking the same language, complaining about the same things.
es: They were men and women like them, with straight hair and brown skin, who spoke the same language and lamented the same pains.

en: They had mules loaded down with things to eat, oxcarts with furniture and domestic utensils, pure and simple earthly accessories put on sale without any fuss by peddlers of everyday reality.
vi: They brought with them donkeys laden with food, ox carts carrying tables and cooking utensils, which were simple and essential goods sold by vendors without any advertisement.
tr: They had mules loaded with food, carts filled with household and kitchen items, in short, the pure and simple goods sold without embellishment by traveling vendors within the daily reality.
es: They brought mules loaded with food, ox carts with furniture and household utensils, pure and simple earthly accessories put up for sale without fuss by the peddlers of everyday reality.

en: They came from the other side of the swamp, only two days away, where there were towns that received mail every month in the year and where they were familiar with the implements of good living.
vi: They had come from the other side of the swamp, about two days' journey from Macondo, where villages regularly received mail from the post office and were familiar with machines that produced many benefits.
tr: They came from a place just two days' journey beyond the swamp, where the mail arrived every month of the year and where people knew the blessings of life.
es: They came from the other side of the swamp, only two days' journey away, where there were towns that received mail every month and knew the machines of well-being.

en: Úrsula had not caught up with the gypsies, but she had found the route that her husband had been unable to discover in his frustrated search for the great inventions.
vi: Úrsula did not catch up with the gypsies, but she found the road that her husband had failed to discover in his unsuccessful quest for great inventions.
tr: Ursula had not been able to find the gypsies, but she had found the road that her husband, due to his obsession with great inventions, had failed to discover.
es: Úrsula had not caught up with the gypsies, but she found the route that her husband could not discover in his frustrated search for great inventions.

en: Chapter 3
vi: Chapter 3
tr: Ursula had not been able to find the gypsies, but she had found the road that her husband, due to his obsession with great inventions, had failed to discover.
es: Úrsula had not caught up with the gypsies, but she found the route that her husband could not discover in his frustrated search for great inventions.

en: PILAR TERNERA’S son was brought to his grand parents’ house two weeks after he was born.
vi: Pila Tecnêra's son was brought to his grandparents' home two weeks after he was born.
tr: Pilar Ternera's son was brought to his grandfather's house two weeks after he was born.
es: Pilar Ternera's son was taken to his grandparents' house two weeks after he was born.

en: Úrsula admitted him grudgingly, conquered once more by the obstinacy of her husband, who could not tolerate the idea that an offshoot of his blood should be adrift, but he imposed the condition that the child should never know his true identity.
vi: Ursula reluctantly accepted him, as once again she had to yield to her husband's eccentricity, who persistently held the belief that his descendants should not be left to fend for themselves in life. However, she set the condition that the child would never know his true origins.
tr: Ursula reluctantly took the child into the house, yielding to her husband's insistence that a child of their own blood should not be left out in the cold, but on the condition that the child would not learn his true identity.
es: Úrsula reluctantly admitted him, once again defeated by her husband's stubbornness, who could not tolerate the idea of a child of his blood being left adrift, but she imposed the condition that the child's true identity be kept secret.

en: Although he was given the name José Arcadio, they ended up calling him simply Arcadio so as to avoid confusion.
vi: Although the child was named José Arcadio, the grandparents decided to avoid confusion by calling him simply Arcadio.
tr: They named the boy Jose Arcadio, but to avoid confusion later, they started calling him simply Arcadio.
es: Although he was given the name José Arcadio, they ended up calling him simply Arcadio to avoid confusion.

en: At that time there was so much activity in the town and so much bustle in the house that the care of the children was relegated to a secondary level.
vi: At that time, there were many social activities outside the village and a lot of work inside the house, so child care became a secondary concern.
tr: At that time, there was such activity in the village and such hustle and bustle in the house that the care of the children was relegated to the background.
es: At that time, there was so much activity in the town and so much hustle and bustle in the house that the care of the children was relegated to a secondary level.

en: They were put in the care of Visitación, a Guajiro Indian woman who had arrived in town with a brother in flight from a plague of insomnia that had been scourging their tribe for several years.
vi: The children were entrusted to Visitación, an indigenous girl who had come to the village with her brother, fleeing a plague of insomnia that had been ravaging their tribe for several years.
tr: The children were entrusted to a woman named Visitacion, one of the Guajiro Indians, who had come to the village with her brother, fleeing the insomnia plague that had ravaged their tribe for years.
es: They were entrusted to Visitación, a Guajira Indian who came to the town with a brother, fleeing from a plague of insomnia that had been afflicting their tribe for several years.

en: They were both so docile and willing to help that Úrsula took them on to help her with her household chores.
vi: Both siblings were gentle, well-behaved, and hardworking, so Ursula trusted them to help with household chores.
tr: The Indian siblings were so meek and so willing to be subservient that Ursula had taken them in to help with the household chores.
es: Both were so docile and helpful that Úrsula took charge of them to help her with household chores.

en: That was how Arcadio and Amaranta came to speak the Guajiro language before Spanish, and they learned to drink lizard broth and eat spider eggs without Úrsula’s knowing it, for she was too busy with a promising business in candy animals.
vi: Thus, Arcadio and Amaranta spoke the indigenous language before they knew how to speak Spanish, learned to sip lizard soup, and ate spider eggs without Ursula's knowledge, as she was busy with her promising candy animal business.
tr: Thus, Arcadio and Amaranta began speaking the Guajiro language fluently before they even mastered Spanish, learning to eat lizard soup and spider eggs without Ursula's knowledge, who was absorbed in making and selling animal-shaped candies.
es: Thus, Arcadio and Amaranta spoke the Guajira language before Spanish, and learned to drink lizard broth and eat spider eggs without Úrsula noticing, because she was too busy with a promising business of candy animals.

en: Macondo had changed.
vi: Macondo had completely changed.
tr: Macondo had changed.
es: Macondo was transformed.

en: The people who had come with Úrsula spread the news of the good quality of its soil and its privileged position with respect to the swamp, so that from the narrow village of past times it changed into an active town with stores and workshops and a permanent commercial route over which the first Arabs arrived with their baggy pants and rings in their ears, swapping glass beads for macaws.
vi: Those who came with Ursula had learned to exploit the fertile land and the advantageous geographical position of Macondo compared to the swampy region. Consequently, the once desolate village quickly became a bustling town with shops, craft workshops, and a regular marketplace where the first Arabs, wearing pantoufles and earrings, came to trade fake crystal beads for long-tailed parrots.
tr: Those who came with Ursula spread the word so enthusiastically about how much better this place was compared to the swamp, praising its fertile soil, that the once isolated village transformed into a bustling town with shops, workshops, and a constantly busy caravan route. The first to arrive via this route were Arabs with baggy trousers and earrings, who bartered large parrots for glass beads.
es: The people who arrived with Úrsula spread the word about the good quality of its soil and its privileged position with respect to the swamp, so that the once sparse village soon became an active town, with shops and craft workshops, and a permanent trade route through which the first Arabs arrived, wearing slippers and earrings, trading glass necklaces for macaws.

en: José Arcadio Buendía did not have a moment’s rest.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía did not have a moment of rest.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia had no time to scratch his head.
es: José Arcadio Buendía did not have a moment's rest.

en: Fascinated by an immediate reality that came to be more fantastic than the vast universe of his imagination, he lost all interest in the alchemist’s laboratory, put to rest the material that had become attenuated with months of manipulation, and went back to being the enterprising man of earlier days when he had decided upon the layout of the streets and the location of the new houses so that no one would enjoy privileges that everyone did not have.
vi: Excited by a reality that at this moment seemed more mystical to him than the vast world within his imagination, he lost all interest in his work at the alchemy lab, abandoning the metal substance that had been repeatedly heated and cooled for months to return to his energetic self who once decided to chart roads and build houses so that no one would enjoy more benefits than others.
tr: Enchanted by the tangible reality that seemed even more fantastical than the boundless universe created by his imagination, Jose Arcadio Buendia stopped paying attention to his alchemy laboratory, set aside the materials he had painstakingly prepared over months, and became as proactive as he was in the days when he decided where the streets would lead and where the houses would be built to ensure no one was wronged.
es: Fascinated by an immediate reality that then seemed more fantastic than the vast universe of his imagination, he lost all interest in the alchemy laboratory, let the matter exhausted by long months of manipulation rest, and returned to being the enterprising man of the early days who decided the layout of the streets and the position of the new houses, so that no one enjoyed privileges that everyone did not have.

en: He acquired such authority among the new arrivals that foundations were not laid or walls built without his being consulted, and it was decided that he should be the one in charge of the distribution of the land.
vi: He had high prestige among the newcomers to the village, to the extent that those who wanted to dig foundations for houses or fence their gardens had to seek his advice first, and he was elected by everyone as the first person to decide on the redistribution of the village's land.
tr: He established such dominance over the newcomers that no foundation was laid, nor any wall built without consulting him, and eventually, they decided to put him in charge of land distribution.
es: He acquired so much authority among the newcomers that no foundations were laid nor fences erected without consulting him, and it was determined that he should be the one to direct the distribution of the land.

en: When the acrobat gypsies returned, with their vagabond carnival transformed now into a gigantic organization of games of luck and chance, they were received with great joy, for it was thought that José Arcadio would be coming back with them.
vi: When the gypsies returned with their magic tricks, this time their mobile stall had become a huge shop with games of chance, they were warmly welcomed because people thought that José Arcadio would return with them.
tr: When the acrobat gypsies, who had turned the old travelers' fair into a huge casino of fortune and gambling games, returned, they were greeted with great fanfare, thinking that Jose Arcadio had returned with them.
es: When the gypsy acrobats returned, now with their traveling fair transformed into a gigantic establishment of games of chance, they were received with joy because it was thought that José Arcadio was returning with them.

en: But José Arcadio did not return, nor did they come with the snake-man, who, according to what Úrsula thought, was the only one who could tell them about their son, so the gypsies were not allowed to camp in town or set foot in it in the future, for they were considered the bearers of concupiscence and perversion.
vi: But José Arcadio did not return, and these gypsies did not bring the snake-man, whom Úrsula thought would be the only one who could tell her the truth about her son, so she did not allow the gypsies to stop and open their shop, and in the future, they would not be allowed to set foot in the village because they were condemned as messengers of debauchery and corruption.
tr: However, Jose Arcadio did not return, and according to Ursula, the snake man, the only person who could tell where her son was, was also not there. As a result, the gypsies were not allowed to stay in the town because they were said to spread lust and perversion wherever they went, and they were warned never to set foot there again.
es: But José Arcadio did not return, nor did they bring the snake-man who Úrsula thought was the only one who could give them news of her son, so the gypsies were not allowed to settle in the town or return in the future, as they were considered messengers of lust and perversion.

en: José Arcadio Buendía, however, was explicit in maintaining that the old tribe of Melquíades, who had contributed so much to the growth of the village with his age-old wisdom and his fabulous inventions, would always find the gates open.
vi: However, José Arcadio Buendía showed great insight in thinking that the tribe of Melquíades, with their ancient knowledge and marvelous inventions that had greatly contributed to the growth of Macondo, should always be welcomed with open arms.
tr: However, Jose Arcadio Buendia did not forget to say that the doors of the town were always open to the tribe of Melquiades, who had greatly contributed to the development of the town with his infinite wisdom and unique inventions.
es: José Arcadio Buendía, however, was explicit in stating that Melquíades' old tribe, which had contributed so much to the village's growth with their ancient wisdom and fabulous inventions, would always find the doors open.

en: But Melquíades’ tribe, according to what the wanderers said, had been wiped off the face of the earth because they had gone beyond the limits of human knowledge.
vi: But the tribe of Melquíades, according to the words of the wanderers, had been wiped off the face of the earth for daring to surpass the limits of knowledge that God had decreed for mankind.
tr: Nevertheless, according to what the nomads said, Melquiades' tribe had been wiped off the face of the earth because it had surpassed the limits of human comprehension.
es: But Melquíades' tribe, according to the wanderers, had been wiped off the face of the earth for having surpassed the limits of human knowledge.

en: Emancipated for the moment at least from the torment of fantasy, José Arcadio Buendía in a short time set up a system of order and work which allowed for only one bit of license: the freeing of the birds, which, since the time of the founding, had made time merry with their flutes, and installing in their place musical clocks in every house.
vi: Escaping the torment of illusory desires, at least for the time being, José Arcadio Buendía managed to stabilize the village's way of life with discipline and labor, and allowed the birds that had enlivened the atmosphere with their songs since the village's founding to be released, replacing them with musical clocks installed in homes.
tr: At least for now, freed from the torment of his imagination, Jose Arcadio Buendia established such an order and work system in a short time that only one thing was free: the permission to release the birds, which had been bringing joy to life with their chirping since the founding days of the village, and replace them with a clock in every house.
es: Emancipated at least for the moment from the tortures of fantasy, José Arcadio Buendía quickly imposed a state of order and work, within which he allowed only one indulgence: the release of the birds that had cheered the time with their flutes since the founding, and the installation in their place of musical clocks in all the houses.

en: They were wondrous clocks made of carved wood, which the Arabs had traded for macaws and which José Arcadio Buendía had synchronized with such precision that every half hour the town grew merry with the progressive chords of the same song until it reached the climax of a noontime that was as exact and unanimous as a complete waltz.
vi: These were precious clocks made of smoothly planed wood that the Arabs exchanged with the villagers for long-tailed parrots, and José Arcadio Buendía orchestrated them to run so precisely in unison that every half hour, the villagers were cheered by harmonious music that seemed to emanate from a single clock.
tr: These were wooden clocks traded by the Arabs for parrots. Jose Arcadio Buendia set the clocks so perfectly that the town was enlivened every half hour by the successive chorus of the same tune, and when noon arrived, the sounds of a waltz rising uninterruptedly and in unison filled everywhere.
es: They were precious carved wooden clocks that the Arabs exchanged for macaws, and which José Arcadio Buendía synchronized with such precision that every half hour the town was cheered by the progressive chords of the same piece, culminating in an exact and unanimous midday with the complete waltz.

en: It was also José Arcadio Buendía who decided during those years that they should plant almond trees instead of acacias on the streets, and who discovered, without ever revealing it, a way to make them live forever.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía was the one who, during those years, decided to plant almond trees along the roads instead of acacias, and he was also the one who discovered but never revealed the methods to make them thrive.
tr: It was also Jose Arcadio Buendia who decided to plant almond trees instead of acacias in the streets during those years and found a way to make the almonds immortal without ever revealing his secret.
es: It was also José Arcadio Buendía who decided in those years that almond trees should be planted in the town's streets instead of acacias, and who discovered, without ever revealing them, the methods to make them eternal.

en: Many years later, when Macondo was a field of wooden houses with zinc roofs, the broken and dusty almond trees still stood on the oldest streets, although no one knew who had planted them.
vi: Many years later, when the village of Macondo had become a settlement of wooden houses with tin roofs, the old almond trees still lined the ancient roads, covered in road dust, though by then no one knew who had planted them.
tr: Years later, when Macondo was filled with wooden houses with zinc roofs, the almond trees, with their broken and dusty branches, stood in the oldest streets, long forgotten who had planted them.
es: Many years later, when Macondo was a camp of wooden houses with zinc roofs, the broken and dusty almond trees still endured in the oldest streets, although no one then knew who had planted them.

en: While his father was putting the town in order and his mother was increasing their wealth with her marvelous business of candied little roosters and fish, which left the house twice a day strung along sticks of balsa wood, Aureliano spent interminable hours in the abandoned laboratory, learning the art of silverwork by his own experimentation.
vi: While the father was busy organizing the communal affairs of the village and the mother was making chicken-shaped candies on sticks to sell at the market twice a day to supplement the family income, Aureliano was passionately absorbed in the abandoned laboratory, studying the craft of goldsmithing. He did it purely out of personal interest.
tr: While his father was busy organizing the town and his mother was making money from the business of distributing rooster and fish-shaped candies attached to sandalwood sticks twice a day, Aureliano would lock himself in the abandoned laboratory for hours, teaching himself the art of silverwork.
es: While his father was putting the town in order and his mother was consolidating the domestic patrimony with her marvelous industry of sugar roosters and fish that twice a day left the house strung on balsa wood sticks, Aureliano spent endless hours in the abandoned laboratory, learning the art of silversmithing through pure investigation.

en: He had shot up so fast that in a short time the clothing left behind by his brother no longer fit him and he began to wear his father’s, but Visitación had to sew pleats in the shirt and darts in the pants, because Aureliano had not sequined the corpulence of the others.
vi: In a short time, Aureliano grew so much that he could no longer fit into his older brother's clothes and had to wear his father's, but Visitación had to take in the sleeves and narrow the pant legs because he still did not have the robust build of his father and brother.
tr: He had grown so quickly that, soon after, when his older brother's clothes no longer fit him, he started wearing his father's, but since he was not as stocky as the others, Visitacion would pleat the shirts and put darts in the pants.
es: He had grown so much that in a short time the clothes abandoned by his brother no longer fit him, and he began to wear his father's, but it was necessary for Visitación to sew tucks into the shirts and gussets into the pants because Aureliano had not inherited the corpulence of the others.

en: Adolescence had taken away the softness of his voice and had made him silent and definitely solitary, but, on the other hand, it had restored the intense expression that he had had in his eyes when he was born.
vi: Adolescence had taken away Aureliano's sweet voice and made him sullen, quiet, and solitary, but conversely, it had also returned to him the intense expressiveness that he had possessed since birth in his eyes.
tr: Puberty had taken away the softness of his voice, making the young man silent and introverted, but at the same time, it had restored the intense expression in his eyes that he had at birth.
es: Adolescence had taken away the sweetness of his voice and made him silent and definitively solitary, but in return, it had restored the intense expression he had in his eyes at birth.

en: He concentrated so much on his experiments in silverwork that he scarcely left the laboratory to eat.
vi: Aureliano was so intensely focused on his goldsmithing experiments that he hardly left the laboratory to eat.
tr: He had devoted himself to silverwork so much that he rarely left the laboratory, even to eat.
es: He was so concentrated on his silversmithing experiments that he barely left the laboratory to eat.

en: Worried ever his inner withdrawal, José Arcadio Buendía gave him the keys to the house and a little money, thinking that perhaps he needed a woman.
vi: Worried about his son's extreme intellectual concentration, José Arcadio Buendía gave him the key to the door and some money, thinking that perhaps his son needed the company of a woman.
tr: Thinking that he might need a woman, Jose Arcadio Buendia gave him the keys to the house and some money.
es: Concerned about his self-absorption, José Arcadio Buendía gave him keys to the house and a little money, thinking that perhaps he needed a woman.

en: But Aureliano spent the money on muriatic acid to prepare some aqua regia and he beautified the keys by plating them with gold.
vi: But Aureliano used the money to buy hydrochloric acid to create a solution, and he made the keys shine with a layer of gold plating.
tr: But Aureliano used the money to buy hydrochloric acid to make a solution for melting gold and decorated the keys with gold plating.
es: But Aureliano spent the money on muriatic acid to prepare aqua regia and embellished the keys with a gold plating.

en: His excesses were hardly comparable to those of Arcadio and Amaranta, who had already begun to get their second teeth and still went about all day clutching at the Indians’ cloaks, stubborn in their decision not to speak Spanish but the Guajiro language.
vi: Aureliano's peculiar traits were in harmony with Arcadio and Amaranta, who, though they had lost their baby teeth, still clung to the skirts of the Indian women and stubbornly refused to give up their native language for Spanish.
tr: Aureliano's excesses paled in comparison to what Amaranta and Arcadio did, who, despite starting to grow their seven-year molars, still clung to the Indian woman's skirt and stubbornly spoke in the Guajiro language instead of Spanish.
es: His exaggerations were only comparable to those of Arcadio and Amaranta, who had already started to lose their teeth and still clung all day to the Indian blankets, stubborn in their decision not to speak Spanish but the Guajiro language.

en: “You shouldn’t complain.”
vi: "I have nothing more to complain about," Úrsula said to her husband.
tr: Ursula would say to her husband, "You have no right to complain; they take after their lineage, what can you do.
es: "You have nothing to complain about," Úrsula told her husband.

en: Úrsula told her husband.
vi: "I have nothing more to complain about," Úrsula said to her husband.
tr: Ursula would say to her husband, "You have no right to complain; they take after their lineage, what can you do.
es: "You have nothing to complain about," Úrsula told her husband.

en: “Children inherit their parents’ madness.”
vi: "Our children have inherited their parents' madness."
es: "Children inherit the madness of their parents."

en: And as she was lamenting her misfortune, convinced that the wild behavior of her children was something as fearful as a pig’s tail, Aureliano gave her a look that wrapped her in an atmosphere of uncertainty.
vi: While she lamented her unfortunate fate, feeling that her sons' eccentricities were indeed as terrifying as a pig's tail, Aureliano dreamily watched her:
tr: While Ursula cursed her misfortune, believing that her children's wildness was as terrible as a pig's tail, Aureliano gave her such a look that she froze, not knowing what to do.
es: And while she lamented her bad luck, convinced that her children's extravagances were something as dreadful as a pig's tail, Aureliano fixed on her a gaze that enveloped her in an aura of uncertainty.

en: “Somebody is coming,” he told her.
vi: - Someone will come to our house! - he told his mother.
tr: "Someone is coming," said the young man.
es: —Someone is going to come —he told her.

en: Úrsula, as she did whenever he made a prediction, tried to break it down with her housewifely logic.
vi: Because you have often talked about omens, Ucsula, with her common sense, intended to dampen your spirits.
tr: Ursula, as she did with every prophecy of her son, tried to interpret this one with the logic of a housewife.
es: Úrsula, as always when he expressed a prediction, tried to discourage him with her homespun logic.

en: It was normal for someone to be coming.
vi: Visitors to the house are a normal occurrence.
tr: It could happen, someone might come.
es: It was normal for someone to arrive.

en: Dozens of strangers came through Macondo every day without arousing suspicion or secret ideas.
vi: Dozens of strangers pass through the village of Macondo without surprising anyone or announcing any secret.
tr: Every day, a bunch of strangers came to Macondo, none of whom aroused suspicion or became the subject of prophecy.
es: Dozens of strangers passed through Macondo daily without arousing concerns or foretelling secret announcements.

en: Nevertheless, beyond all logic, Aureliano was sure of his prediction.
vi: However, despite those common sense arguments, Aureliano still insisted on his prediction:
tr: However, Aureliano was too convinced of the accuracy of his prophecy to heed this logic.
es: However, beyond all logic, Aureliano was certain of his premonition.

en: “I don’t know who it will be,” he insisted, “but whoever it is is already on the way.”
vi: - I don't know who it is? - he said, - but the person coming here is currently on their way.
tr: "I don't know who it is," he said, "but whoever it is, they have already set off."
es: —I don't know who it will be —he insisted—, but whoever it is, they are already on their way.

en: That Sunday, in fact, Rebeca arrived.
vi: Indeed, Rebecca arrived on a Sunday.
tr: Indeed, that Sunday arrived, Rebeca.
es: On Sunday, indeed, Rebeca arrived.

en: She was only eleven years old.
vi: The little girl was not yet eleven years old.
tr: She was only eleven years old.
es: She was no more than eleven years old.

en: She had made the difficult trip from Manaure with some hide dealers who had taken on the task of delivering her along with a letter to José Arcadio Buendía, but they could not explain precisely who the person was who had asked the favor.
vi: She had to struggle to travel from Manaure to here with the fur traders who were tasked with delivering her and the letter to José Arcadio Buendía's house, but even these traders could not clearly explain who had asked them to do so.
tr: She had made a strenuous journey from Manaure to Macondo with leather merchants who had taken on the task of bringing the girl along with a letter addressed to Jose Arcadio Buendia, but who could not for the life of them remember who had entrusted the child to them.
es: She had made the arduous journey from Manaure with some fur traders who were tasked with delivering her along with a letter to the house of José Arcadio Buendía, but they could not precisely explain who had asked them to do the favor.

en: Her entire baggage consisted of a small trunk, a little rocking chair with small hand-painted flowers, and a canvas sack which kept making a cloc-cloc-cloc sound, where she carried her parents’ bones.
vi: All of her belongings consisted of a small trunk containing clothes, a wooden rocking chair, and a burlap sack in which her parents' bones were kept, which would often clatter, clatter, clatter when they bumped into each other.
