vi: By a strange reversal of habits, it was Úrsula who had planted this idea in his mind, and she, who had forgotten her previous discomforts, agreed to let Melquíades stay in their house, although she never allowed him to photograph her because (as she said) she did not want to exist in such a way to mock her grandchildren.
tr: This time, contrary to the usual, it was Ursula who calmed him down and erased this thought from his mind, deciding to let Melquiades stay in the house, having forgotten her old grudge, but she never agreed to have her photograph taken, as she (in her own words) did not want to become a source of amusement for her grandchildren.
es: By a curious inversion of custom, it was Úrsula who got that idea out of his head, as it was also she who forgot her old resentments and decided that Melquíades should stay living in the house, although she never allowed them to take a daguerreotype of her because (in her own exact words) she did not want to be a laughingstock for her grandchildren.

en: That morning she dressed the children in their best clothes, powdered their faces, and gave a spoonful of marrow syrup to each one so that they would all remain absolutely motionless during the nearly two minutes in front of Melquíades fantastic camera.
vi: That morning, she dressed beautifully to visit the children, applied powder to them, and then gave each one a spoonful of marrow porridge so they could stand still for two minutes in front of Menkyadet's camera.
tr: That morning, she dressed the children in their holiday clothes, powdered their faces, and gave each of them a spoonful of marrow broth so they could stand still for about two minutes in front of Melquiades' incredible machine without moving a muscle.
es: That morning, she dressed the children in their best clothes, powdered their faces, and gave each of them a spoonful of marrow syrup so they could remain absolutely still for almost two minutes in front of Melquíades' cumbersome camera.

en: In the family daguerreotype, the only one that ever existed, Aureliano appeared dressed in black velvet between Amaranta and Rebeca.
vi: In the photograph of the long-lost family, Aureliano, dressed in black wool, stood between Amaranta and Rebeca.
tr: In that unique family photograph, Aureliano, dressed in black velvet, was standing between Amaranta and Rebeca.
es: In the family daguerreotype, the only one that ever existed, Aureliano appeared dressed in black velvet, between Amaranta and Rebeca.

en: He had the same languor and the same clairvoyant look that he would have years later as he faced the firing squad.
vi: He bore a melancholic look and sharp eyes that, many years later, remained unchanged when he faced the firing squad; at that time, he still had no premonition of his fate.
tr: On his face was that reluctant expression, reflecting his clairvoyant sensitivity, which he would have years later when he faced the firing squad.
es: He had the same languor and the same clairvoyant look that he would have years later in front of the firing squad, but he had not yet felt the premonition of his destiny.

en: But he still had not sensed the premonition of his fate.
vi: He bore a melancholic look and sharp eyes that, many years later, remained unchanged when he faced the firing squad; at that time, he still had no premonition of his fate.
tr: But he had not yet foreseen what would happen to him.
es: He had the same languor and the same clairvoyant look that he would have years later in front of the firing squad, but he had not yet felt the premonition of his destiny.

en: He was an expert silversmith, praised all over the swampland for the delicacy of his work.
vi: He had become a skilled jeweler admired throughout the region.
tr: He was a master silversmith, renowned throughout the swampy region for the delicacy of his work.
es: He was an expert goldsmith, esteemed throughout the swamp for the meticulousness of his work.

en: In the workshop, which he shared with Melquíades’ mad laboratory, he could barely be heard breathing.
vi: In the workshop, which was set up alongside Menkyadet's noisy laboratory, it seemed as if he had escaped into another era to work to the point where he could no longer hear himself breathe; meanwhile, his father and Menkyadet loudly debated Nostradamus's prophecies.
tr: He worked silently in the workshop he shared with Melquiades.
es: In the workshop he shared with Melquíades' chaotic laboratory, he was barely heard breathing.

en: He seemed to be taking refuge in some other time, while his father and the gypsy with shouts interpreted the predictions of Nostradamus amidst a noise of flasks and trays and the disaster of spilled acids and silver bromide that was lost in the twists and turns it gave at every instant.
vi: The words echoed amidst the clinking of bottles and cups containing solutions, and the misfortune of spilled acid and scattered silver spoons caused by occasional elbow bumps and slips.
tr: While his father and the gypsy, amidst the clinking of bottles and trays, the spilling acids, and the constant shimmer of silver bromide appearing and disappearing on the photographic plate, loudly tried to decipher Nostradamus' prophecies, Aureliano seemed to escape and take refuge in another time.
es: He seemed to be sheltered in another time, while his father and the gypsy loudly interpreted Nostradamus' predictions, amid a clatter of bottles and tubs, and the disaster of spilled acids and lost silver bromide due to the constant jostling and stumbling.

en: That dedication to his work, the good judgment with which he directed his attention, had allowed Aureliano to earn in a short time more money than Úrsula had with her delicious candy fauna, but everybody thought it strange that he was now a full-grown man and had not known a woman.
vi: The wholehearted dedication to work, the correct concept guiding all his interests, had allowed him in a short time to earn a sum of money larger than what Ursula had earned from her delicious animal-shaped candies, but everyone was surprised that although he was already a grown man, he still hadn't known a woman.
tr: Due to his dedication and meticulousness in his work, Aureliano soon earned more money than Ursula did from her sweets, but everyone found it strange that, despite being a grown man, he had no relationships with any women.
es: That dedication to work, the good judgment with which he managed his interests, had allowed Aureliano to earn more money in a short time than Úrsula with her delightful candy animals, but everyone was surprised that he was already a grown man and had not been known to have a woman.

en: It was true that he had never had one.
vi: In truth, he had never been with anyone.
tr: Indeed, he had not yet touched a woman's hand.
es: In reality, he had never had one.

en: Several months later saw the return of Francisco the Man, as ancient vagabond who was almost two hundred years old and who frequently passed through Macondo distributing songs that he composed himself.
vi: A few months later, old Francisco - The Man, a nearly two-hundred-year-old wanderer who often passed through Macondo to spread songs he composed himself, returned to the village.
tr: A few months later, Francisco the Devil-Breaker showed up. This two-hundred-year-old vagabond would come and go to Macondo every now and then, spreading the folk songs he wrote and composed himself.
es: Months later, Francisco the Man returned, an elderly wanderer of almost 200 years who frequently passed through Macondo, spreading the songs he composed himself.

en: In them Francisco the Man told in great detail the things that had happened in the towns along his route, from Manaure to the edge of the swamp, so that if anyone had a message to send or an event to make public, he would pay him two cents to include it in his repertory.
vi: In these songs, old Francisco - The Man recounted in detail the events that happened along his journeys, from the village of Manaure to the remotest corners of the swampy regions, so if anyone wanted to send a message or announce an event, they could pay him two cents to include it in his program.
tr: In these songs, Francisco the Devil-Breaker would recount the events that happened in the towns along the road from Manaure to the edge of the swamp. Therefore, anyone who wanted to convey a message or announce something from one town to another would slip two coins into Francisco's palm, and he would include the news in his song.
es: In them, Francisco the Man recounted with meticulous details the news that occurred in the towns along his route, from Manaure to the edges of the swamp, so that if someone had a message to send or an event to publicize, they paid him two cents to include it in his repertoire.

en: That was how Úrsula learned of the death of her mother, as a simple consequence of listening to the songs in the hope that they would say something about her son José Arcadio.
vi: Thanks to this, one night Úrsula listened to his songs with the hope that they would mention José Arcadio, and she accidentally learned of her mother's passing.
tr: Listening to these songs in the hope of hearing news from her son Jose Arcadio, Ursula learned of her mother's death in this way.
es: This was how Úrsula learned of her mother's death, purely by chance, one night when she was listening to the songs hoping they would say something about her son José Arcadio.

en: Francisco the Man, called that because he had once defeated the devil in a duel of improvisation, and whose real name no one knew, disappeared from Macondo during the insomnia plague and one night he appeared suddenly in Catarino’s store.
vi: He was called Francisco - The Man because in a singing contest he had defeated the devil, and besides, no one knew his real name. During the insomnia epidemic that plagued the village of Macondo, he quietly disappeared, and now, without any prior notice, he was back in Catarino's store.
tr: Francisco, who became famous as Francisco the Devil-Breaker for defeating the devil in an impromptu folk song contest and whose real name no one knew, had slipped away from Macondo during the insomnia plague. One night, just as suddenly as he had left, he appeared in Catarino's shop.
es: Francisco the Man, so called because he defeated the devil in a duel of improvised songs, and whose real name no one knew, disappeared from Macondo during the insomnia plague and one night reappeared without any announcement in Catarino's store.

en: The whole town went to listen to him to find out what had happened in the world.
vi: The whole village flocked to hear him to see what new things had happened in the world.
tr: When he arrived this time, there was a woman with him who was so fat that she couldn't lift herself up and walk.
es: The whole town went to listen to him to find out what had happened in the world.

en: On that occasion there arrived with him a woman who was so fat that four Indians had to carry her in a rocking chair, and an adolescent mulatto girl with a forlorn look who protected her from the sun with an umbrella.
vi: On this occasion, accompanying him was a fat woman sitting on a rocking chair carried by four Indian porters, with a lonely-looking mixed-race girl holding an umbrella to shade her.
tr: Four Native Americans were carrying the woman from place to place with a rocking chair that they could barely move, and a melancholy-faced young mestizo girl was staying by the woman's side with an umbrella to keep the sun off her head.
es: On this occasion, he arrived with a woman so fat that four Indians had to carry her in a rocker, and a teenage mulatto girl with a helpless appearance who protected her from the sun with an umbrella.

en: Aureliano went to Catarino’s store that night.
vi: That night, Aureliano went to Catarino's store.
tr: That night, Aureliano went to Cacarino's shop.
es: Aureliano went to Catarino's store that night.

en: He found Francisco the Man, like a monolithic chameleon, sitting in the midst of a circle of bystanders.
vi: He saw old Francisco - The Man, like a petrified chameleon, sitting among the curious crowd listening to his tales...
tr: Francisco was sitting in the middle of a circle of listeners, like a chameleon carved from a single piece of stone, playing that same old accordion given to him by Sir Walter Raleigh in Guiana, tapping the rhythm with his feet, which were cracked from saltpeter and accustomed to stomping, and singing news with his familiar, raspy voice.
es: He found Francisco the Man, like a monolithic chameleon, sitting in the middle of a circle of curious onlookers.

en: He was singing the news with his old, out-of-tune voice, accompanying himself with the same archaic accordion that Sir Walter Raleigh had given him in the Guianas and keeping time with his great walking feet that were cracked from saltpeter.
vi: With a wheezing voice accompanied by an old accordion, which had been given to him by Mr. Oante Rahch on the island of Goadana. He sang to tell the news, while his large, rough, cracked feet from walking through sulfur mines kept stomping to keep the rhythm.
tr: Francisco was sitting in the middle of a circle of listeners, like a chameleon carved from a single piece of stone, playing that same old accordion given to him by Sir Walter Raleigh in Guiana, tapping the rhythm with his feet, which were cracked from saltpeter and accustomed to stomping, and singing news with his familiar, raspy voice.
es: He sang the news with his old, hoarse voice, accompanying himself with the same archaic accordion that Sir Walter Raleigh had given him in Guiana, while he kept the rhythm with his large, salt-cracked walking feet.

en: In front of a door at the rear through which men were going and coming, the matron of the rocking chair was sitting and fanning herself in silence.
vi: The madam sat on a rocking chair, fanning herself at the back door where some men were coming and going.
tr: In front of the large door at the back, where people were constantly coming and going, the owner of the rocking chair sat silently, fanning herself.
es: In front of a back door through which some men were entering and leaving, the matron of the rocker was sitting and fanning herself in silence.

en: Catarino, with a felt rose behind his ear, was selling the gathering mugs of fermented cane juice, and he took advantage of the occasion to go over to the men and put his hand on them where he should not have.
vi: With a felt rose tucked behind his ear, Catarino sold glasses of guarapo - nearly everyone placed their hands on him right where they shouldn't.
tr: Catarino, with an artificial rose tucked behind his ear, was selling pitcher after pitcher of sugarcane juice to the gathered crowd, while also taking the opportunity to grope the men here and there.
es: Catarino, with a felt rose in his ear, was selling bowls of fermented guarapo to the crowd, and took the opportunity to approach the men and put his hand where he shouldn't.

en: Toward midnight the heat was unbearable.
vi: As the night wore on, the heat became unbearable.
tr: By midnight, the heat became unbearable.
es: By midnight, the heat was unbearable.

en: Aureliano listened to the news to the end without hearing anything that was of interest to his family.
vi: Aureliano sat and listened to the news until the end of the program but found nothing useful for his family.
tr: Aureliano listened to the news until the end, but heard nothing that concerned his family.
es: Aureliano listened to the news until the end without finding any that interested his family.

en: He was getting ready to go home when the matron signaled him with her hand.
vi: As he was preparing to go home, the madam pointed her finger, signaling to him:
tr: Just as he was about to head home, a fat woman gestured and called him over.
es: He was about to return home when the matron signaled to him with her hand.

en: “You go in too.” she told him.
vi: - You should come in too, - she said, - it only costs two hào!
tr: "Why don't you come inside too," he said.
es: —You come in too —he said to him—.

en: “It only costs twenty cents.”
vi: - You should come in too, - she said, - it only costs two hào!
tr: "It's only twenty cents."
es: It only costs twenty cents.

en: Aureliano threw a coin into the hopper that the matron had in her lap and went into the room without knowing why.
vi: Aureliano put two dimes into the dish the woman held at her side and then stepped into the room without knowing what to do.
tr: Aureliano, without understanding why, threw the money into the bowl on the woman's lap and entered the room.
es: Aureliano tossed a coin into the piggy bank that the matron had on her lap and entered the room without knowing why.

en: The adolescent mulatto girl, with her small bitch’s teats, was naked on the bed.
vi: The mixed-race girl was lying naked on the bed with breasts that looked like a dog's.
tr: The young mestizo girl was lying completely naked with tiny dog-like breasts.
es: The teenage mulatto girl, with her little dog-like breasts, was naked on the bed.

en: Before Aureliano sixty-three men had passed through the room that night.
vi: That night, before Aureliano entered, sixty-three men had already passed through this room.
tr: That night, sixty-three men had been with her before Aureliano.
es: Before Aureliano, that night, sixty-three men had passed through the room.

en: From being used so much, kneaded with sweat and sighs, the air in the room had begun to turn to mud.
vi: The air in the room, thickened by the sweat and breath of so many people, had started to condense into a muddy substance.
tr: The air in the room had started to thicken with sweat and breath, becoming almost muddy.
es: From so much use, and kneaded in sweat and sighs, the air in the room was beginning to turn into mud.

en: The girl took off the soaked sheet and asked Aureliano to hold it by one side.
vi: The girl stripped the soaking wet bed sheet and asked Aureliano to hold one end.
tr: The girl pulled the soaking sheet and handed one end to Aureliano.
es: The girl removed the soaked sheet and asked Aureliano to hold it on one side.

en: It was as heavy as a piece of canvas.
vi: It was extremely heavy.
tr: The sheet had become as heavy as a sailcloth.
es: It was as heavy as a canvas.

en: They squeezed it, twisting it at the ends until it regained its natural weight.
vi: The two of them twisted the ends of the sheet until it was wrung dry.
tr: They twisted it from both ends, wringing out the water until it returned to its normal weight.
es: They wrung it out, twisting it by the ends, until it regained its natural weight.

en: They turned over the mat and the sweat came out of the other side.
vi: They tilted the bed, and sweat streamed down the tilted side, dripping onto the floor.
tr: They flipped the mattress over, but the sweat had soaked through to the other side as well.
es: They turned the mat over, and the sweat came out the other side.

en: Aureliano was anxious for that operation never to end.
vi: Aureliano fervently wished that this task would never end.
tr: Aureliano was hoping these tasks would never end.
es: Aureliano longed for that operation to never end.

en: He knew the theoretical mechanics of love, but he could not stay on his feet because of the weakness of his knees, and although he had goose pimples on his burning skin he could not resist the urgent need to expel the weight of his bowels.
vi: In theory, he knew the art of lovemaking, but his knees were weak, and despite his skin being covered in goosebumps and feeling feverish, he couldn't suppress the urgent need to pass gas.
tr: Although he knew about love games from hearsay, his legs were so weak that he could barely stand, and despite being in his adolescence, his face was burning like fire and he was almost about to wet himself out of fear.
es: He knew the theoretical mechanics of love, but he couldn't stand up due to the discouragement in his knees, and although his skin was bristling and burning, he couldn't resist the urge to expel the weight from his guts.

en: When the girl finished fixing up the bed and told him to get undressed, he gave her a confused explanation: “They made me come in.
vi: When the bed was made, the girl ordered him to undress, and he clumsily explained, "They told me to come in.
tr: When the girl made the bed and told him to undress, Aureliano started to stammer: They forced me in here.
es: When the girl finished fixing the bed and ordered him to undress, he gave her a flustered explanation: "They made me come in.

en: They told me to throw twenty cents into the hopper and hurry up.”
vi: They told me to put two dimes in the money dish and not to delay."
tr: They said, throw twenty cents into the bowl and be quick about it.
es: They told me to toss twenty cents into the piggy bank and not to take too long.

en: The girl understood his confusion.
vi: The girl understood his anxiety.
tr: The girl understood his confusion.
es: " The girl understood his confusion.

en: “If you throw in twenty cents more when you go out, you can stay a little longer,” she said softly.
vi: "If you put two more dimes at the exit, you can stay a few more minutes," she said gently.
tr: In a soft voice, she said, if you throw another twenty cents when you leave, you can stay inside longer.
es: "If you toss another twenty cents on your way out, you can take a little longer," she said softly.

en: Aureliano got undressed, tormented by shame, unable to get rid of the idea that-his nakedness could not stand comparison with that of his brother.
vi: Aureliano undressed, looking miserable with shame, unable to shake off the thought that his naked body could not compare to his brother's robust physique.
tr: Aureliano, comparing his own naked state with his brother's, undressed, sinking into the ground with shame.
es: Aureliano undressed, tormented by shame, unable to shake the idea that his nakedness couldn't compare to his brother's.

en: In spite of the girl’s efforts he felt more and more indifferent and terribly alone.
vi: Despite the girl's attempts to be seductive, he still felt lonely, terribly lonely.
tr: No matter how much effort the girl put in, Aureliano became increasingly indifferent, increasingly withdrawn.
es: Despite the girl's efforts, he felt increasingly indifferent and terribly alone.

en: “I’ll throw in other twenty cents,” he said with a desolate voice.
vi: "I'll add two more cents," he said in a dejected voice.
tr: In a miserable voice, he muttered, I'll throw in another twenty cents.
es: "I'll toss another twenty cents," he said in a desolate voice.

en: The girl thanked him in silence.
vi: The girl quietly thanked him.
tr: The girl thanked him quietly.
es: The girl thanked him in silence.

en: Her back was raw.
vi: Her back was bright red.
tr: Her back was peeling from lying down so much.
es: Her back was raw.

en: Her skin was stuck to her ribs and her breathing was forced because of an immeasurable exhaustion.
vi: Her skin clung to her bones, revealing each rib, and her breath was rapid and erratic, full of exhaustion.
tr: Her skin clung to her ribs, and she was breathless from deadly exhaustion.
es: Her skin clung to her ribs and her breathing was altered by an unfathomable exhaustion.

en: Two years before, far away from there, she had fallen asleep without putting out the candle and had awakened surrounded by flames.
vi: Two years ago, in a distant village, the girl had fallen asleep without extinguishing a candle, and when she awoke, she was right next to the fire.
tr: Two years ago, in a place far away, he had fallen asleep without extinguishing the candle and woke up surrounded by flames.
es: Two years earlier, far from there, she had fallen asleep without extinguishing the candle and had woken up surrounded by fire.

en: The house where she lived with the grandmother who had raised her was reduced to ashes.
vi: The house where she lived with her grandmother, who had raised her since she was a baby, had turned to ashes.
tr: The house he lived in with his grandmother had burned down to ashes.
es: The house where she lived with the grandmother who had raised her was reduced to ashes.

en: Since then her grandmother carried her from town to town, putting her to bed for twenty cents in order to make up the value of the burned house.
vi: Since then, her grandmother had taken her from village to village, forcing her to sleep with men for two cents each time to save up enough to compensate for the value of the burned house.
tr: After that, his grandmother started taking him from town to town, and to make up for the burned house, she had him sleep with anyone who could pay twenty cents.
es: Since then, her grandmother had taken her from town to town, laying her down for twenty cents, to pay for the value of the burned house.

en: According to the girl’s calculations, she still had ten years of seventy men per night, because she also had to pay the expenses of the trip and food for both of them as well as the pay of the Indians who carried the rocking chair.
vi: According to the girl's calculations, she still had more than ten years to go, offering herself every night to seventy men, because besides paying her grandmother, she also had to earn enough to cover travel expenses, food for both of them, and wages for the Indians who carried the rocking chair.
tr: According to the girl's calculations, she needed to sleep with seventy people a night for another ten years, because she had to cover the travel and food expenses not only for herself and her grandmother but also for the Indians carrying the rocking chair.
es: According to the girl's calculations, she still had about ten years of seventy men per night left, because she also had to pay for the travel and food expenses for both of them and the wages of the Indians who carried the rocker.

en: When the matron knocked on the door the second time, Aureliano left the room without having done anything, troubled by a desire to weep.
vi: When the madam knocked on the door for the second time, Aureliano left the room without having done anything, feeling so pained he wanted to cry.
tr: When Mama knocked on the door for the second time, Aureliano, unable to accomplish anything, left the room on the verge of tears.
es: When the matron knocked on the door for the second time, Aureliano left the room without having done anything, dazed by the desire to cry.

en: That night he could not sleep, thinking about the girl, with a mixture of desire and pity.
vi: That night, he did not sleep, only thinking about the girl with a mix of love and pity.
tr: That night, he spent thinking about the girl, on one hand with desire, on the other with pity, until morning.
es: That night he couldn't sleep thinking about the girl, with a mixture of desire and pity.

en: He felt an irresistible need to love her and protect her.
vi: He felt both love and a desire to protect the girl. It was an intense feeling that could not be stopped.
tr: He felt an irresistible urge to love and protect her.
es: He felt an irresistible need to love and protect her.

en: At dawn, worn out by insomnia and fever, he made the calm decision to marry her in order to free her from the despotism of her grandmother and to enjoy all the nights of satisfaction that she would give the seventy men.
vi: At dawn, exhausted from lack of sleep and fever, he made a healthy decision: he would marry the girl to free her from her grandmother's control and to enjoy with her the nights of pleasure she had to share with seventy men.
tr: At dawn, exhausted from sleeplessness and the fire of desire, he made his decision: He would marry her to save her from her tyrannical grandmother and to savor those fulfilling nights shared by seventy men alone.
es: At dawn, exhausted by insomnia and fever, he made the serene decision to marry her to free her from the grandmother's despotism and enjoy every night the satisfaction she gave to seventy men.

en: But at ten o’clock in the morning, when he reached Catarino’s store, the girl had left town.
vi: But at ten in the morning, when he arrived at Catarino's store, the girl had already left the village.
tr: However, when he arrived at Catarino's shop at ten in the morning, the girl had already left town.
es: But at ten in the morning, when he arrived at Catarino's store, the girl had left town.

en: Time mitigated his mad proposal, but it aggravated his feelings of frustration.
vi: Time gradually soothed Auréliano's naive intentions, but it deepened his sense of failure.
tr: As time extinguished this mad desire to marry, it also increased his sense of emptiness.
es: The passage of time calmed his reckless purpose, but aggravated his sense of frustration.

en: He took refuge in work.
vi: He buried himself in work.
tr: He threw himself into his work with all his might.
es: He took refuge in work.

en: He resigned himself to being a womanless man for all his life in order to hide the shame of his uselessness.
vi: He resolved to remain single for life, to bury the shameful thought of considering himself useless.
tr: To hide the shame of his uselessness, he vowed to remain without a woman for life.
es: He resigned himself to being a man without a woman for his entire life to hide the shame of his uselessness.

en: In the meantime, Melquíades had printed on his plates everything that was printable in Macondo, and he left the daguerreotype laboratory to the fantasies of José Arcadio Buendía who had resolved to use it to obtain scientific proof of the existence of God.
vi: Meanwhile, Melquíades had finished recording on his films everything that could be captured in the village of Macondo and had left the darkroom to the passions of José Arcadio Buendía, who had decided to use it for a scientific experiment to prove the existence of God.
tr: Meanwhile, Melquiades had printed everything in Macondo that could be photographed onto zinc plates and had left the photo lab to Jose Arcadio Buendia, who had decided to use it to scientifically prove the existence of God.
es: Meanwhile, Melquíades finished capturing everything that could be captured in Macondo on his plates, and abandoned the daguerreotype laboratory to the delusions of José Arcadio Buendía, who had resolved to use it to obtain scientific proof of the existence of God.

en: Through a complicated process of superimposed exposures taken in different parts of the house, he was sure that sooner or later he would get a daguerreotype of God, if He existed, or put an end once and for all to the supposition of His existence.
vi: Through a complex process of presenting photographs taken at different locations in the house, he was convinced that sooner or later there would be a photograph of God, if God indeed existed, and at the same time, it would end all speculation about His existence.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia was convinced that by taking overlapping photographs in different parts of the house, he would eventually capture an image of God, if He existed, or put an end to the claims about God's existence.
es: Through a complicated process of superimposed exposures taken in different parts of the house, he was sure he would sooner or later make a daguerreotype of God, if He existed, or put an end once and for all to the supposition of His existence.

en: Melquíades got deeper into his interpretations of Nostradamus.
vi: Melquíades delved deeper into the teachings of Nostradamus.
tr: Melquiades devoted himself entirely to interpreting Nostradamus's prophecies.
es: Melquíades delved into the interpretations of Nostradamus.

en: He would stay up until very late, suffocating in his faded velvet vest, scribbling with his tiny sparrow hands, whose rings had lost the glow of former times.
vi: He worked until dusk, suffocating in his faded felt coat, with his tiny sparrow-like hands, the rings on his fingers having lost their luster from times past, scribbling on sheets of paper.
tr: He would sit until late hours, gasping for breath in his faded velvet vest, scribbling with his sparrow-like hands adorned with rings that had lost their former brilliance.
es: He stayed up very late, suffocating in his faded velvet vest, scribbling papers with his tiny sparrow-like hands, whose rings had lost the luster of another era.

en: One night he thought he had found a prediction of the future of Macondo.
vi: One night, he thought he had found a prophecy about the future of Macondo.
tr: One night, he thought he had found a prophecy foretelling the future of Macondo.
es: One night he thought he found a prediction about the future of Macondo.

en: It was to be a luminous city with great glass houses where there was no trace remaining of the race of the Buendía.
vi: It could become a radiant city, with enormous crystal buildings, where there would be no trace of the Buendía lineage.
tr: Macondo will be a town full of glittering large houses made of glass, and there will be no trace left of the Buendia lineage.
es: It would be a luminous city, with large glass houses, where no trace of the Buendía lineage remained.

en: “It’s a mistake,” José Arcadio Buendía thundered.
vi: " That is a mistake," José Arcadio Buendía angrily said. "
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia roared, "That's wrong, the houses will be made of ice as I saw in my dream, not glass, and the Buendia lineage will endure as long as the world exists, per omnia secula seculorum."
es: “It’s a mistake,” thundered José Arcadio Buendía.

en: “They won’t be houses of glass but of ice, as I dreamed, and there will always be a Buendía, per omnia secula seculorum.”
vi: Those are not crystal buildings, but ice buildings, as I have seen in my dreams, and no matter how many centuries pass, there will always be a Buendía. "
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia roared, "That's wrong, the houses will be made of ice as I saw in my dream, not glass, and the Buendia lineage will endure as long as the world exists, per omnia secula seculorum."
es: “They won’t be glass houses but ice houses, as I dreamed, and there will always be a Buendía, for centuries and centuries.”

en: Úrsula fought to preserve common sense in that extravagant house, having broadened her business of little candy animals with an oven that went all night turning out baskets and more baskets of bread and a prodigious variety of puddings, meringues, and cookies, which disappeared in a few hours on the roads winding through the swamp.
vi: In that bizarre house, Úrsula was the one trying to maintain a normal atmosphere by expanding the business of making candy figurines, with an oven that in one night produced baskets and baskets of bread, and batches of puddings, cakes, and biscuits that within a few hours spread throughout the paths of the swampy region.
tr: Ursula was doing her best to maintain common sense in this house full of excesses. Meanwhile, she had expanded her candy-making business, establishing a large bakery. The bakery worked all night, producing baskets of bread, buns, and cookies, and the goods from the oven were transported and sold out within hours along the roads winding through the swamp.
es: In that extravagant house, Úrsula struggled to preserve common sense, having expanded the candy animal business with an oven that produced baskets and baskets of bread all night and a prodigious variety of puddings, meringues, and sponge cakes, which vanished in a few hours through the swamp’s pathways.

en: She had reached an age where she had a right to rest, but she was nonetheless more and more active.
vi: Though she was of an age to rest, she became even more active.
tr: Ursula had reached the age where she could sit back and rest, yet she was working harder with each passing day.
es: She had reached an age where she had the right to rest, but was, however, increasingly active.

en: So busy was she in her prosperous enterprises that one afternoon she looked distractedly toward the courtyard while the Indian woman helped her sweeten the dough and she saw two unknown and beautiful adolescent girls doing frame embroidery in the light of the sunset.
vi: So busy with these profitable tasks, that one afternoon, while the Indian girl helping her mixed honey into the dough, she looked out into the yard and saw two beautiful, unfamiliar young women sitting and embroidering under the sunset light.
tr: She was so engrossed in her money-making ventures that one day, while adding sugar to the dough with the Indian woman, her eyes drifted to the garden, where she saw two beautiful girls she didn't recognize, sitting under the sun and working on embroidery.
es: She was so busy with her prosperous enterprises that one afternoon she looked distractedly towards the patio while the Indian woman helped her sweeten the dough, and saw two unknown and beautiful adolescents embroidering in a hoop by the twilight light.

en: They were Rebeca and Amaranta.
vi: They were Rebeca and Amaranta.
tr: These were Rebeca and Amaranta.
es: They were Rebeca and Amaranta.

en: As soon as they had taken off the mourning clothes for their grandmother, which they wore with inflexible rigor for three years, their bright clothes seemed to have given them a new place in the world.
vi: They had just finished mourning their grandmother, a mourning they had persistently observed for three long years, and now their colorful clothes seemed to place them in a new phase of life.
tr: As soon as they discarded the mourning clothes they had stubbornly worn for three years after their grandmother's death, the colorful clothes they wore seemed to have earned them a whole new place in the world.
es: They had just taken off their grandmother’s mourning clothes, which they had kept with inflexible rigor for three years, and the colored clothes seemed to have given them a new place in the world.

en: Rebeca, contrary to what might have been expected, was the more beautiful.
vi: Completely contrary to what might await her in the future, Rebecca was the most beautiful girl.
tr: Contrary to expectations, the more beautiful of the girls was Rebeca.
es: Rebeca, contrary to what might have been expected, was the most beautiful.

en: She had a light complexion, large and peaceful eyes, and magical hands that seemed to work out the design of the embroidery with invisible threads.
vi: She had skin as white as celery, large and deep eyes, and dexterous hands that seemed to be weaving invisible threads on an embroidered tapestry.
tr: She was a fair-skinned girl with large, calming eyes, and skillful hands that seemed to embroider patterns with invisible threads.
es: She had a clear complexion, large and calm eyes, and magical hands that seemed to weave the embroidery’s pattern with invisible threads.

en: Amaranta, the younger, was somewhat graceless, but she had the natural distinction, the inner tightness of her dead grandmother.
vi: Amaranta, the younger girl, though slightly less graceful, had a natural elegance, an inner tranquility inherited from her late grandmother.
tr: The younger Amaranta was a bit rough, but she had inherited her late grandmother's natural charm and resilience.
es: Amaranta, the younger one, was a bit graceless, but she had the natural distinction, the inner poise of the dead grandmother.

en: Next to them, although he was already revealing the physical drive of his father, Arcadio looked like a child.
vi: Beside the two girls was Arcadio. Despite having inherited his father's stature, Arcadio was still just a little boy.
tr: Although it was clear she would be as tall and imposing as her father, Arcadio looked like a child next to them.
es: Next to them, although already revealing his father’s physical drive, Arcadio seemed like a child.

en: He set about learning the art of silverwork with Aureliano, who had also taught him how to read and write.
vi: He decided to learn the trade of a jeweler under the guidance of Aureliano, who, besides teaching the trade, also taught the boy to read and write.
tr: Arcadio had learned to read and write from Aureliano and was now trying to master silverwork.
es: He had dedicated himself to learning the art of silversmithing with Aureliano, who had also taught him to read and write.

en: Úrsula suddenly realized that the house had become full of people, that her children were on the point of marrying and having children, and that they would be obliged to scatter for lack of space.
vi: Immediately, Ursula realized that her house would soon be cramped, that her children were of marriageable age and would have children of their own, and due to lack of space, they would be forced to scatter.
tr: It suddenly dawned on Úrsula that the house was filled with grown-ups, and she realized that her children were almost old enough to get married and start their own families, and that they would scatter due to the lack of space in the house.
es: Úrsula suddenly realized that the house was filled with people, that her children were about to marry and have children, and that they would be forced to disperse due to lack of space.

en: Then she took out the money she had accumulated over long years of hard labor, made some arrangements with her customers, and undertook the enlargement of the house.
vi: So she took the money she had saved over many years of hard work, made contracts with her clients, and began expanding the house.
tr: So, she took out the money she had saved up over the years, collected a bit more from her customers, and set about expanding the house.
es: Then she took out the money accumulated over long years of hard work, made commitments with her clients, and undertook the expansion of the house.

en: She had a formal parlor for visits built, another one that was more comfortable and cool for daily use, a dining room with a table with twelve places where the family could sit with all of their guests, nine bedrooms with windows on the courtyard and a long porch protected from the heat of noon by a rose garden with a railing on which to place pots of ferns and begonias.
vi: She decided to build two living rooms, one of which would be fully equipped and more airy for daily use, and a dining room large enough to accommodate a big dining table with twelve seats for family and guests to dine together, nine bedrooms all with windows opening to the yard, and a long corridor with balconies holding pots of ferns and begonias, outside of which was a rose garden shielding from the harsh midday sun.
tr: She added a guest room for occasional visitors, a daily sitting room, a dining room with a table that could seat twelve people, nine bedrooms overlooking the garden, and a terrace that would be shaded by the rose garden in the afternoon heat, with ferns and begonia pots lined up along its railings.
es: She arranged for the construction of a formal living room for visitors, another more comfortable and cool for daily use, a dining room for a table with twelve places where the family could sit with all their guests; nine bedrooms with windows facing the patio and a long corridor protected from the midday glare by a rose garden, with a handrail for placing fern pots and begonia planters.

en: She had the kitchen enlarged to hold two ovens.
vi: She also decided to demolish the old kitchen to build two ovens; to dismantle the old corn warehouse where Pila Tecnêra had read José Arcadio's fortune through the cards, to construct a new warehouse twice as large, sufficient to store food supplies for many years.
tr: She also enlarged the kitchen to fit two stoves.
es: She arranged to expand the kitchen to build two ovens, to destroy the old barn where Pilar Ternera had read José Arcadio’s future, and to build another twice as large so that food would never be lacking in the house.

en: The granary where Pilar Ternera had read José Arcadio’s future was torn down and another twice as large built so that there would never be a lack of food in the house.
vi: She also decided to demolish the old kitchen to build two ovens; to dismantle the old corn warehouse where Pila Tecnêra had read José Arcadio's fortune through the cards, to construct a new warehouse twice as large, sufficient to store food supplies for many years.
tr: The pantry where Pilar Ternera had read José Arcadio's fortune was demolished and replaced with a new pantry twice its size to ensure there would never be a shortage of food in the house.
es: She arranged to expand the kitchen to build two ovens, to destroy the old barn where Pilar Ternera had read José Arcadio’s future, and to build another twice as large so that food would never be lacking in the house.

en: She had baths built is the courtyard in the shade of the chestnut tree, one for the women and another for the men, and in the rear a large stable, a fenced-in chicken yard, a shed for the milk cows, and an aviary open to the four winds so that wandering birds could roost there at their pleasure.
vi: She decided to erect a male bathhouse and a female bathhouse, and at the end of the yard, a large stable, a chicken coop with wire mesh, a milking barn, and an aviary with open doors to welcome birds that could freely come and go.
tr: Ursula had two outhouses built under the shade of the chestnut tree in the garden, one for women and the other for men, a large barn in the back garden, a chicken coop surrounded by wire mesh, a shed for the milk-giving cows, and an aviary open to the wind from all sides so that the passing birds could perch as they pleased.
es: She arranged to build in the patio, under the shade of the chestnut tree, a bathroom for women and another for men, and at the back a large stable, a wired chicken coop, a milking stable, and an aviary open to the four winds so that the aimless birds could settle as they pleased.

en: Followed by dozens of masons and carpenters, as if she had contracted her husband’s hallucinating fever, Úrsula fixed the position of light and heat and distributed space without the least sense of its limitations.
vi: Followed by dozens of carpenters and masons, as if she had caught her husband's gold fever, Úrsula arranged the positions for light and ventilation, dividing the spaces without forgetting their boundaries.
tr: Just like her husband, who seemed to be in a feverish delirium, Ursula would follow with a troop of masons and carpenters, deciding where the light and heat would come from, and without worrying about keeping the job small, she was creating a spacious place.
es: Followed by dozens of masons and carpenters, as if she had contracted her husband’s hallucinatory fever, Úrsula ordered the positioning of the light and the conduct of the heat, and distributed the space without the slightest sense of its limits.

en: The primitive building of the founders became filled with tools and materials, of workmen exhausted by sweat, who asked everybody please not to molest them, exasperated by the sack of bones that followed them everywhere with its dull rattle.
vi: The house, originally built by the pioneering ancestors, suddenly became crowded with saws, chisels, and construction materials, and the tired, sweaty workers were asking everyone else not to disturb the objects, unaware that they themselves were the ones causing all the disruption. They went mad because of the bag of human bones that rattled, clattering everywhere they went.
tr: The primitive structure built by the village founders was filled with tools, materials, and workers who, tired of the clattering bone sack that followed them wherever they went, would tell anyone who would listen not to be a hindrance.
es: The primitive construction of the founders was filled with tools and materials, with workers overwhelmed by sweat, who asked everyone to please not get in the way, without realizing that it was they who were in the way, exasperated by the bag of human bones that followed them everywhere with its dull rattling.

en: In that discomfort, breathing quicklime and tar, no one could see very well how from the bowels of the earth there was rising not only the largest house is the town, but the most hospitable and cool house that had ever existed in the region of the swamp.
vi: In the unpleasant scene of having to breathe the strong smell of lime and tar, no one understood why a house was rising from the ground, not only larger than any seen in the village but also the most hospitable and coolest ever in the entire swamp region.
tr: In the chaos where the smell of quicklime and tar filled the entire town and everyone's lungs, no one noticed how not only the largest structure in the town but also the coolest house ever built in the swampy region, with its doors always open to guests, suddenly rose as if it had sprouted from the ground.
es: In that discomfort, breathing quicklime and tar molasses, no one quite understood how from the bowels of the earth emerged not only the largest house that would ever be in the town, but the most hospitable and cool that there ever was in the swamp’s domain.

en: José Buendía, trying to surprise Divine Providence in the midst of the cataclysm, was the one who least understood it.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía, who thought he would astonish the Almighty with the great changes, was the one who understood it the least.
tr: In the chaos, Jose Arcadio Buendia, who tried to catch God off guard and take His picture, was the person who understood the least about how the house was built and completed.
es: José Arcadio Buendía, trying to surprise Divine Providence in the midst of the cataclysm, was the one who understood it the least.

en: The new house was almost finished when Úrsula drew him out of his chimerical world in order to inform him that she had an order to paint the front blue and not white as they had wanted.
vi: When the house was nearly complete, Úrsula pulled him out of his dream world to inform him that there was an order requiring the front walls of all houses to be painted blue instead of white, as the villagers preferred.
tr: As the house neared completion, Ursula informed her husband, pulling him out of his dream world, that she had received orders to paint the facade blue instead of white as they wanted.
es: The new house was almost finished when Úrsula pulled him out of his chimerical world to inform him that there was an order to paint the facade blue, not white as they wanted.

en: She showed him the official document.
vi: She showed him the paper with the official order written on it.
tr: She showed the official document.
es: She showed him the official order written on a piece of paper.

en: José Arcadio Buendía, without understanding what his wife was talking about, deciphered the signature.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía, still not understanding what his wife was saying, was trying to read the signature:
tr: Not understanding what his wife was talking about, Jose Arcadio Buendia read the signature at the bottom of the paper.
es: José Arcadio Buendía, without understanding what his wife was saying, deciphered the signature.

en: “Who is this fellow?” he asked:
vi: - Who is this person? - He asked.
tr: "Who is this man?" he asked.
es: —Who is this guy? —he asked.

en: “The magistrate,” Úrsula answered disconsolately.
vi: - That's the inspector, - Ursula replied sadly.
tr: -He was a justice of the peace, Ursula replied with sadness.
es: —The magistrate —said Úrsula disconsolately—.

en: They say he’s an authority sent by the government.”
vi: - People say that he is a new official sent by the government.
tr: -He was an official sent by the government.
es: They say he is an authority sent by the government.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote, the magistrate, had arrived in Macondo very quietly.
vi: Apollinar Moscote, the magistrate, quietly arrived in the village of Macondo.
tr: The magistrate Don Apolinar Moscote had arrived in Macondo quietly and unobtrusively.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote, the magistrate, had arrived in Macondo without making any noise.

en: He put up at the Hotel Jacob—built by one of the first Arabs who came to swap knickknacks for macaws—and on the following day he rented a small room with a door on the street two blocks away from the Buendía house.
vi: He got off the vehicle and stayed at the Jacob Hotel, established by one of the first Arabs who came here to trade goods for long-tailed parrots. The next day, he rented a room that opened onto the street, just two blocks away from Buendía's house.
tr: He stayed at the Jacob Hotel, built by one of the first Arabs who bartered parrots and knick-knacks, and the next day rented a one-room house with a door opening onto the street, two blocks away from the Buendia's house.
es: He got off at Jacob's Hotel —established by one of the first Arabs who arrived bartering trinkets for macaws— and the next day he rented a small room with a door to the street, two blocks from the Buendía house.

en: He set up a table and a chair that he had bought from Jacob, nailed up on the wall the shield of the republic that he had brought with him, and on the door he painted the sign: Magistrate.
vi: He set up a table and a chair bought from Jacob, hung the national emblem he had brought with him on the wall, and placed a sign on the door that read: Magistrate.
tr: He placed a table and a chair he got from Jacob in the room, hung the state emblem he had brought with him on the wall, and wrote "Magistrate" on the door.
es: He set up a table and a chair that he bought from Jacob, nailed a republic shield he had brought with him to the wall, and painted the sign on the door: Magistrate.

en: His first order was for all the houses to be painted blue in celebration of the anniversary of national independence.
vi: His first order of business was to instruct the houses in the village to be whitewashed in celebration of Independence Day.
tr: The first order he issued was that all houses be painted blue in celebration of the anniversary of national independence.
es: His first order was to have all the houses painted blue to celebrate the anniversary of national independence.

en: José Arcadio Buendía, with the copy of the order in his hand, found him taking his nap in a hammock he had set up in the narrow office.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía, holding a copy of the order, found him napping in a hammock strung up in a sparsely furnished and decorated room.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia, who grabbed the decree and rushed to the magistrate's house, found him lying in a hammock he had set up in the room, taking a nap.
es: José Arcadio Buendía, with a copy of the order in hand, found him taking a nap in a hammock he had hung in the sparse office.

en: “Did you write this paper?” he asked him.
vi: "Are you the one who wrote this paper?" he asked.
tr: Did you write this? he asked.
es: “Did you write this paper?” he asked him.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote, a mature man, timid, with a ruddy complexion, said yes.
vi: Apollinar Moscote, a mature man with a timid demeanor and a flushed face, replied that he was.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote, a middle-aged, red-faced, timid man, replied, Yes.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote, a mature, timid man of sanguine complexion, answered yes.

en: “By what right?” José Arcadio Buendía asked again.
vi: "In the name of what did you write this?" José Arcadio Buendía continued to ask.
tr: On what authority? Jose Arcadio Buendia pressed.
es: “With what right?” José Arcadio Buendía asked again.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote picked up a paper from the drawer of the table and showed it to him.
vi: Đông Apôlina
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote took a paper out of the desk drawer and showed it.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote searched for a paper in the desk drawer and showed it to him: “I have been appointed magistrate of this town.”

en: “I have been named magistrate of this town.”
vi: Môscôtê found a piece of paper stored in the desk drawer and showed it to him: "I have just been appointed as the Inspector of this village".
tr: I was appointed as the magistrate of this town.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote searched for a paper in the desk drawer and showed it to him: “I have been appointed magistrate of this town.”

en: José Arcadio Buendía did not even look at the appointment.
vi: Hôsê Accađiô Buênđya didn't bother to look at the appointment letter, and said:
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia didn't even look at the appointment document.
es: José Arcadio Buendía didn't even look at the appointment.

en: “In this town we do not give orders with pieces of paper,” he said without losing his calm.
vi: - In this village, we do not issue orders with paperwork - he said calmly, - and just so you know, we do not need any Inspector, because there is nothing here that needs inspecting.
tr: Without losing his composure, he said, In this town, we don't issue orders on written paper.
es: —In this town, we don't rule with papers —he said without losing his calm—.

en: “And so that you know it once and for all, we don’t need any judge here because there’s nothing that needs judging.”
vi: - In this village, we do not issue orders with paperwork - he said calmly, - and just so you know, we do not need any Inspector, because there is nothing here that needs inspecting.
tr: And get this straight, we don't need a magistrate, because we never have any need for one.
es: And just so you know once and for all, we don't need any magistrate because there's nothing to correct here.

en: Facing Don Apolinar Moscote, still without raising his voice, he gave a detailed account of how they had founded the village, of how they had distributed the land, opened the roads, and introduced the improvements that necessity required without having bothered the government and without anyone having bothered them.
vi: Faced with the firm attitude of Don Apolinar Moscote, who never raised his voice, José Arcadio Buendía recounted in detail how they had built the village, how they had divided the land, how they had opened roads, and how they had developed the necessary and profitable trades for life, without ever bothering the government and without anyone ever bothering the villagers.
tr: Standing in front of Don Apolinar Moscote without raising his voice, he explained one by one how they founded the village, how they distributed the land, how they opened the roads, and how they did everything necessary without bothering the government and without allowing anyone to disturb them.
es: In the face of Don Apolinar Moscote's impassiveness, always without raising his voice, he gave a detailed account of how they had founded the village, how they had divided the land, opened the roads, and introduced the improvements that necessity had demanded, without bothering any government and without anyone bothering them.

en: “We are so peaceful that none of us has died even of a natural death,” he said.
vi: "We live so peacefully that our village has never had anyone die from illness or old age," he said.
tr: "We live in such peace that not even one of us has met their end yet," he said.
es: "We are so peaceful that we haven't even died of natural causes," he said.

en: “You can see that we still don’t have any cemetery.”
vi: "You see, our village doesn't even have a cemetery yet!"
tr: "As you can see, we don't even have a cemetery."
es: "You see, we still don't have a cemetery."

en: No once was upset that the government had not helped them.
vi: He was not at all distressed that the government had not helped the villagers.
tr: No one was upset because they didn't receive help from the government.
es: He did not complain that the government had not helped them.

en: On the contrary, they were happy that up until then it had let them grow in peace, and he hoped that it would continue leaving them that way, because they had not founded a town so that the first upstart who came along would tell them what to do.
vi: On the contrary, he was pleased to see that up to this point, the government had allowed the villagers to continue living that way, because they did not waste their efforts establishing the village only for others to come and tell them what to do.
tr: On the contrary, everyone was pleased with their situation because the government hadn't disturbed their peace so far, and they wanted it to continue this way; they hadn't founded this town for any upstart to come and give orders.
es: On the contrary, he was glad that until then it had let them grow in peace, and he hoped it would continue to do so, because they had not founded a town for the first newcomer to come and tell them what they should do.

en: Don Apolinar had put on his denim jacket, white like his trousers, without losing at any moment the elegance of his gestures.
vi: Don Apolinar Moscote, wearing a twill fabric coat as white as his trousers, never lost his calm demeanor.
tr: While he was explaining these things, Don Apolinar Moscote, without losing his grace for a moment, had put on his jacket made of the same white cotton as his trousers.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote had put on a drill jacket, as white as his pants, without losing the purity of his gestures at any moment.

en: “So that if you want to stay here like any other ordinary citizen, you’re quite welcome,” José Arcadio Buendía concluded.
vi: - So if you want to stay here, like other ordinary residents, you will be warmly welcomed, - José Arcadio Buendía concluded, - otherwise, if you have come to cause trouble and force the villagers to whitewash their walls, you can pack your bags and go back to where you came from.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia finished his words by saying, "If you intend to sit here like one of us, you are more than welcome, but if you are going to cause trouble by painting people's houses blue, you better pack up and go back to where you came from."
es: —So if you want to stay here, like any other ordinary citizen, you are very welcome —concluded José Arcadio Buendía—.

en: “But if you’ve come to cause disorder by making the people paint their houses blue, you can pick up your junk and go back where you came from.
vi: - So if you want to stay here, like other ordinary residents, you will be warmly welcomed, - José Arcadio Buendía concluded, - otherwise, if you have come to cause trouble and force the villagers to whitewash their walls, you can pack your bags and go back to where you came from.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia finished his words by saying, "If you intend to sit here like one of us, you are more than welcome, but if you are going to cause trouble by painting people's houses blue, you better pack up and go back to where you came from."
es: But if you come to create disorder by forcing people to paint their houses blue, you can pack your things and leave the way you came.

en: Because my house is going to be white, white, like a dove.”
vi: Because my house must be as white as a dove.
tr: "Because my house will be as white as a dove."
es: Because my house must be white like a dove.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote turned pale.
vi: Don Apolinar Moscote turned pale.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote turned pale.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote turned pale.

en: He took a step backward and tightened his jaws as he said with a certain affliction:
vi: He took a step back, gritting his teeth with an embarrassed look, and said:
tr: He took a step back, clenched his teeth, and spoke with a somewhat sorrowful demeanor:
es: He took a step back and clenched his jaws to say with a certain distress:

en: “I must warn you that I’m armed.”
vi: - I inform you that I have a weapon.
tr: -Know that I am armed.
es: —I want to warn you that I am armed.

en: José Arcadio Buendía did not know exactly when his hands regained the useful strength with which he used to pull down horses.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía did not know since when the strength of a young man capable of breaking a bull's horn had concentrated entirely in his hands.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia, without understanding how his hands, which once knocked down horses with a single blow, regained the same strength, grabbed Don Apolinar Moscote by the collar, lifted him into the air, and held him at eye level.
es: José Arcadio Buendía did not know at what moment the youthful strength with which he could knock down a horse came into his hands.

en: He grabbed Don Apolinar Moscote by the lapels and lifted him up to the level of his eyes.
vi: Grabbing Apolinar Moscote by the lapels of his cotton jacket, he lifted him to eye level and said:
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia, without understanding how his hands, which once knocked down horses with a single blow, regained the same strength, grabbed Don Apolinar Moscote by the collar, lifted him into the air, and held him at eye level.
es: He grabbed Don Apolinar Moscote by the lapel and lifted him to the height of his eyes.

en: “I’m doing this,” he said, “because I would rather carry you around alive and not have to keep carrying you around dead for the rest of my life.”
vi: - I'll do this, - he said, - because I want to carry it alive and not have to regret for the rest of my life carrying a dead body.
tr: "I am doing this because I prefer to carry you around alive rather than dead for the rest of my life," he said.
es: —I do this —he told him— because I prefer to carry him alive and not have to keep carrying him dead for the rest of my life.

en: In that way he carried him through the middle of the street, suspended by the lapels, until he put him down on his two feet on the swamp road.
vi: He kept carrying him along the main road until his hand got tired and he let go of the lapel, then he set him down. At that moment, the Inspector was already on the road outside the marsh.
tr: Then he grabbed the man by his collar, lifted him into the air, and carried him out to the street, taking him all the way to the start of the swamp road before setting him down on his feet.
es: He carried him down the middle of the street, suspended by his lapels, until he set him on his two feet on the path to the swamp.

en: A week later he was back with six barefoot and ragged soldiers, armed with shotguns, and an oxcart in which his wife and seven daughters were traveling.
vi: A week later, he returned with six barefoot soldiers, all dressed in rags, each carrying a musket, and an ox cart carrying his wife and seven daughters.
tr: A week later, the man returned, accompanied by six barefoot, bald-headed soldiers armed with shotguns, and with his wife and seven daughters crammed into an ox cart.
es: A week later, he was back with six barefoot and ragged soldiers, armed with shotguns, and an ox cart in which his wife and seven daughters traveled.

en: Two other carts arrived later with the furniture, the baggage, and the household utensils.
vi: After that, two more ox carts arrived carrying beds, chairs, tables, cabinets, trunks, and kitchen utensils.
tr: Two more carts loaded with household items, suitcases, and kitchen utensils followed.
es: Later, two more carts arrived with the furniture, trunks, and household utensils.

en: He settled his family in the Hotel Jacob, while he looked for a house, and he went back to open his office under the protection of the soldiers.
vi: He lodged his family at the Jacob Hotel while looking to buy a house and resumed his office with guards outside.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote settled his family into the Jacob Hotel and began searching for a house. In the meantime, he reopened his office under the protection of the soldiers.
es: He installed the family in the Hotel de Jacob while he found a house, and reopened the office protected by the soldiers.

en: The founders of Macondo, resolving to expel the invaders, went with their older sons to put themselves at the disposal of José Arcadio Buendía.
vi: The founders of the village of Macondo were ready to expel the invaders. Together with their grown sons, they came to support the determination of José Arcadio Buendía.
tr: The founders of Macondo, determined to drive out the invaders from the town, took their eldest sons with them and went to Jose Arcadio Buendia, saying they were at his command. But Jose Arcadio Buendia objected, saying that humiliating a man in front of his family was not manly.
es: The founders of Macondo, determined to expel the invaders, went with their eldest sons to offer their services to José Arcadio Buendía.

en: But he was against it, as he explained, because it was not manly to make trouble for someone in front of his family, and Don Apolinar had returned with his wife and daughters.
vi: But he objected because, as he explained, Apôhna Môscôtê had returned here with his wife and daughters, and as a man, one should not embarrass another in front of their family.
tr: He explained that Don Apolinar had brought his wife and daughters with him.
es: But he opposed it, as he explained, because Don Apolinar Moscote had returned with his wife and daughters, and it was not a man's thing to humiliate others in front of their family.

en: So he decided to resolve the situation in a pleasant way.
vi: So he decided to handle the matter in a more amicable manner.
tr: Therefore, he decided to resolve the matter amicably.
es: So he decided to resolve the situation amicably.

en: Aureliano went with him.
vi: Aureliano went with him.
tr: Aureliano went with him.
es: Aureliano accompanied him.

en: About that time he had begun to cultivate the black mustache with waxed tips and the somewhat stentorian voice that would characterize him in the war.
vi: At this time, he had a black mustache that curled up at the ends and a booming voice, which later became distinguishing features that made him stand out in the war.
tr: At that time, he had just started to grow out the black mustache he used to twist with paraffin at the ends, and his voice, which was one of his greatest assets on the battlefield, was approaching a thunderous boom.
es: By then, he had already started to grow a black mustache with waxed tips, and he had the slightly stentorian voice that would characterize him in the war.

en: Unarmed, without paying any attention to the guards, they went into the magistrate’s office.
vi: Without carrying any weapons and not obeying the guards' orders, the father and son walked straight into the Inspector's office.
tr: Without even taking a pocketknife with them and paying no heed to the soldiers at the door, they burst into the magistrate's office.
es: Unarmed, ignoring the guard, they entered the corregidor's office.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote did not lose his calm.
vi: Don Apolinar Moscote remained calm.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote did not lose his composure.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote did not lose his composure.

en: He introduced them to two of his daughters who happened to be there: Amparo, sixteen, dark like her mother, and Remedios, only nine, a pretty little girl with lily-colored skin and green eyes.
vi: He introduced to them his two daughters who happened to be there. Amparo, sixteen years old, with tanned skin like her mother's, and Remedios, approximately nine years old, a charming little girl with ivory skin and blue eyes.
tr: He introduced them to his two daughters who were in the office at the time: sixteen-year-old Amparo, who was dark like her mother, and nine-year-old Remedios, who had lily-white skin and beautiful green eyes.
es: He introduced them to two of his daughters who happened to be there by chance: Amparo, sixteen years old, dark-skinned like her mother, and Remedios, barely nine years old, a beautiful girl with lily-white skin and green eyes.

en: They were gracious and well-mannered.
vi: Both were graceful and well-mannered.
tr: The girls were graceful and well-mannered.
es: They were graceful and well-mannered.

en: As soon as the men came in, before being introduced, they gave them chairs to sit on.
vi: As swiftly as they had entered, before being introduced by their father, the girls had already brought chairs for the guests to sit on.
tr: As soon as the men entered, without waiting to be introduced, they ran to fetch chairs.
es: As soon as they entered, before being introduced, the girls brought them chairs to sit down.

en: But they both remained standing.
vi: But both father and daughters remained standing. - Very well?
tr: But they themselves remained standing.
es: But both remained standing.

en: “Very well, my friend,” José Arcadio Buendía said, “you may stay here, not because you have those bandits with shotguns at the door, but out of consideration for your wife and daughters.”
vi: - José Arcadio Buendía said. - You will stay here, but not because you have those guards with muskets, but because of the villagers' respect for your wife and these young ladies.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia said, "Alright, my friend, you can stay here, but don't think that we are afraid of the armed bandits you posted at the door. We are keeping quiet out of respect for your wife and daughters."
es: —Very well, my friend —said José Arcadio Buendía—, you will stay here, but not because you have those blunderbuss bandits at the door, rather out of consideration for your wife and daughters.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote was upset, but José Arcadio Buendía did not give him time to reply.
vi: Apollinar Moscote was bewildered, but José Arcadio Buendía did not give him time to respond: "We only ask two things of you," he said.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote was taken aback, but Jose Arcadio Buendia did not give him a chance to speak.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote was taken aback, but José Arcadio Buendía did not give him time to reply.

en: “We only make two conditions,” he went on.
vi: Apollinar Moscote was bewildered, but José Arcadio Buendía did not give him time to respond: "We only ask two things of you," he said.
tr: We have only two conditions, he continued, first, everyone will paint their house in the color they want.
es: “We only have two conditions,” he added.

en: “The first: that everyone can paint his house the color he feels like.
vi: "First, let each person paint their house as they wish.
tr: We have only two conditions, he continued, first, everyone will paint their house in the color they want.
es: “The first: that everyone paints their house whatever color they want.

en: The second: that the soldiers leave at once.
vi: Second, let the soldiers leave the village immediately.
tr: Second, the soldiers will leave immediately.
es: The second: that the soldiers leave immediately.

en: We will guarantee order for you.”
vi: We will ensure your safety."
tr: We will ensure public order.
es: We guarantee the order.”

en: The magistrate raised his right hand with all the fingers extended.
vi: The inspector spread out his right hand and raised it:
tr: The magistrate raised his right hand, spreading all five fingers.
es: The magistrate raised his right hand with all his fingers extended.

en: “Your word of honor?”
vi: - A promise of honor?
tr: -Word of honor?
es: —Word of honor?

en: “The word of your enemy,” José Arcadio Buendía said.
vi: - Those are the words of an enemy, - José Arcadio Buendía said.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia said, "Enemy words."
es: —Word of an enemy —said José Arcadio Buendía.

en: And he added in a bitter tone: “Because I must tell you one thing: you and I are still enemies.”
vi: But with a bitter tone, he clarified: - Because I want to make it clear for you to know: You and I will continue to be enemies.
tr: And he added in a bitter tone: "Because never forget this: You and I are enemies."
es: And he added in a bitter tone—: Because there's one thing I want to tell you: you and I are still enemies.

en: The soldiers left that same afternoon.
vi: That very afternoon, the soldiers had to leave in a hurry.
tr: The soldiers left before evening.
es: That same afternoon the soldiers left.

en: A few days later José Arcadio Buendía found a house for the magistrate’s family.
vi: A few days later, José Arcadio Buendía found a house for the Inspector's family.
tr: A few days later, Jose Arcadio Buendia found a house for the judge's family.
es: A few days later, José Arcadio Buendía found a house for the corregidor's family.

en: Everybody was at peace except Aureliano.
vi: Everyone lived peacefully, except for Aureliano.
tr: Everyone except Aureliano was content with their life.
es: Everyone was at peace, except Aureliano.

en: The image of Remedios, the magistrate’s younger daughter, who, because of her age, could have been his daughter, kept paining him in some part of his body.
vi: The image of Remedios, the Inspector's youngest daughter, who by age could have been his own child, lingered painfully in his mind.
tr: The thought of Remedios, the judge's young daughter who was almost young enough to be his own daughter, had left an unending ache in his heart.
es: The image of Remedios, the corregidor's youngest daughter, who could have been his own daughter due to her age, remained aching somewhere in his body.

en: It was a physical sensation that almost bothered him when he walked, like a pebble in his shoe.
vi: It was a mechanical sensation, like a pebble in a shoe that hurts the foot with every step.
tr: This was a tangible pain, like having a stone in your shoe that hurts as you walk.
es: It was a physical sensation that almost bothered him when walking, like a small stone in his shoe.

en: Chapter 4
vi: Chapter 4
tr: The completion of the new house, as white as a dove's wing, was celebrated with a dance party.
es: The new house, white as a dove, was inaugurated with a dance.

en: THE NEW HOUSE, white, like a dove, was inaugurated with a dance.
vi: A dance party was organized to celebrate the new house, white as a dove.
tr: The completion of the new house, as white as a dove's wing, was celebrated with a dance party.
es: The new house, white as a dove, was inaugurated with a dance.

en: Úrsula had got that idea from the afternoon when she saw Rebeca and Amaranta changed into adolescents, and it could almost have been said that the main reason behind the construction was a desire to have a proper place for the girls to receive visitors.
vi: Ursula had cherished that idea ever since the afternoon she saw Rebeca and Amaranta had become young ladies, and it could almost be said that the main reason for building the new house was the desire to provide the girls with a worthy place to receive guests.
tr: Ursula had thought of doing this on the day she first noticed that Hebeca and Amaranta had grown up and blossomed. The reconstruction of the house was actually intended to properly accommodate the suitors who would come and go for the girls.
es: Úrsula had conceived that idea since the afternoon she saw Rebeca and Amaranta turned into teenagers, and it can almost be said that the main reason for the construction was the desire to provide the girls with a worthy place to receive visitors.

en: In order that nothing would be lacking in splendor she worked like a galley slave as the repairs were under way, so that before they were finished she had ordered costly necessities for the decorations, the table service, and the marvelous invention that was to arouse the astonishment of the town and the jubilation of the young people: the pianola.
vi: While carrying out the reconstruction of the house, Ursula toiled like a convict so that no obstacle could extinguish that brilliant, radiant purpose. Therefore, before these tasks were completed, she had already sent for the purchase of decorations and food containers, all of which were expensive items. Among them was a marvelous object that had astonished the entire village and delighted the youth, which was the automatic piano.
tr: So that nothing would be lacking, she gathered her skirt at her waist and worked hard like a laborer in the house's renovation. Even before the craftsmen had finished their work, Ursula spared no expense to furnish the house from top to bottom, ordering a heap of items, bringing in tableware, and acquiring a new invention that left the entire village in awe and thrilled the young people: the Laterna.
