tr: The next day, which was Wednesday, Jose Arcadio Buendia entered the workshop again.
es: The next day, Wednesday, José Arcadio Buendía returned to the workshop.

en: “This is a disaster,” he said.
vi: "This is a disaster," he said, "Look at the wind, listen to the buzzing of the sun, just like yesterday, and the day before."
tr: This is a disaster, he said.
es: “This is a disaster,” he said.

en: “Look at the air, listen to the buzzing of the sun, the same as yesterday and the day before.
vi: "This is a disaster," he said, "Look at the wind, listen to the buzzing of the sun, just like yesterday, and the day before."
tr: Look at the weather, listen to the buzzing of the sun, everything is just like yesterday and the day before.
es: “Look at the air, hear the hum of the sun, just like yesterday and the day before.

en: Today is Monday too.”
vi: That night, Pietro Crespi found him in the hallway, crying with the dry sobs of an old man, crying for Prudencio Aguilar, crying for Melquíades, crying for Rebeca's parents, crying for his own parents, crying for everyone he could remember who was now lonely in death.
tr: Today is also Monday.
es: Today is also Monday.”

en: That night Pietro Crespi found him on the porch, weeping for Prudencio Aguilar, for Melquíades, for Rebeca’s parents, for his mother and father, for all of those he could remember and who were now alone in death.
vi: That night, Pietro Crespi found him in the hallway, crying with the dry sobs of an old man, crying for Prudencio Aguilar, crying for Melquíades, crying for Rebeca's parents, crying for his own parents, crying for everyone he could remember who was now lonely in death.
tr: That night, Pietro Crespi found him on the terrace, crying for Prudencio Aguilar, for Melquiades, for Rebeca's parents, for his own parents, for everyone he knew who was now facing death.
es: That night, Pietro Crespi found him in the corridor, crying with the graceless sob of the old, crying for Prudencio Aguilar, for Melquíades, for Rebeca's parents, for his father and mother, for all those he could remember who were then alone in death.

en: He gave him a mechanical bear that walked on its hind legs on a tightrope, but he could not distract him from his obsession.
vi: Pietro Crespi gave him a wind-up bear that walked on two legs on a wire, but even this gift did not cheer him up.
tr: Even though Crespi gave him a toy bear that walked on its hind legs and performed tricks on a rope, he couldn't free Jose Arcadio Buendia from his obsession:
es: He gave him a wind-up bear that walked on two legs on a wire, but he couldn't distract him from his obsession.

en: He asked him what had happened to the project he had explained to him a few days before about the possibility of building a pendulum machine that would help men to fly and he answered that it was impossible because a pendulum could lift anything into the air but it could not lift itself.
vi: He asked Pietro about the plan he had given him days before, which was about the possibility of building a machine based on the principle of a clock pendulum that could lift any object into the air, allowing humans to fly. And Pietro replied that it was impossible because a clock pendulum could lift any object into the air but could not lift itself.
tr: He asked about the status of the pendulum mechanism he had described a few days ago, which was supposed to help people fly. Buendia said it couldn't be done because the pendulum could lift everything into the air, but there was no way it could lift itself.
es: He asked him what had happened to the project he had explained to him days before, about the possibility of building a pendulum machine that would allow man to fly, and he replied that it was impossible because the pendulum could lift anything into the air but could not lift itself.

en: On Thursday he appeared in the workshop again with the painful look of plowed ground.
vi: On the hundredth day, he was back in the jewelry workshop with the miserable look of the earth being scraped.
tr: On Thursday, with a face wrinkled from pain like freshly plowed soil, he went back to the workshop. He would cry if someone touched him.
es: On Thursday he reappeared in the workshop with a painful look of scorched earth.

en: “The time machine has broken,” he almost sobbed, “and Úrsula and Amaranta so far away!”
vi: "The time machine is broken," he sobbed, "and Úrsula and Amaranta are very far away."
tr: "The time machine is broken," he said, almost sobbing. And Ursula and Amaranta are so far away!
es: “The time machine has broken down,” he almost sobbed, “and Úrsula and Amaranta are so far away!”

en: Aureliano scolded him like a child and he adopted a contrite air.
vi: Aureliano scolded his father like a child, and he obediently listened.
tr: Aureliano scolded him as if reprimanding a child. Upon this, Buendia adopted an attitude as if he regretted what he had done.
es: Aureliano scolded him like a child, and he adopted a submissive air.

en: He spent six hours examining things, trying to find a difference from their appearance on the previous day in the hope of discovering in them some change that would reveal the passage of time.
vi: For six continuous hours, he inspected objects, trying to find some difference from the previous day to prove that time was still flowing sequentially.
tr: He examined his surroundings for six hours without rest; he struggled to find a change that would prove the passage of time.
es: He spent six hours examining things, trying to find a difference from the way they looked the day before, eager to discover in them some change that would reveal the passage of time.

en: He spent the whole night in bed with his eyes open, calling to Prudencio Aguilar, to Melquíades, to all the dead, so that they would share his distress.
vi: All night, he lay in bed with his eyes wide open, calling out to Prudencio Aguilar, calling out to Melquíades, calling out to all the dead to come and share his desolation.
tr: He spent the whole night in his bed without blinking, calling out to Prudencio Aguilar, Melquiades, and all the dead, inviting them to share his pain.
es: He spent the whole night in bed with his eyes open, calling out to Prudencio Aguilar, to Melquíades, to all the dead, to come and share his unease.

en: But no one came.
vi: But no one came.
tr: But no one came.
es: But no one came.

en: On Friday.
vi: On the sixth day, just before everyone woke up, he observed all the external signs of nature, watching until he was sure that it was still Monday.
tr: On Friday, he went outside before anyone woke up; he watched nature until he was completely convinced that it was Monday.
es: On Friday, before anyone got up, he went back to watch the appearance of nature until he had no doubt that it was still Monday.

en: before anyone arose, he watched the appearance of nature again until he did not have the slightest doubt but that it was Monday.
vi: On the sixth day, just before everyone woke up, he observed all the external signs of nature, watching until he was sure that it was still Monday.
tr: On Friday, he went outside before anyone woke up; he watched nature until he was completely convinced that it was Monday.
es: On Friday, before anyone got up, he went back to watch the appearance of nature until he had no doubt that it was still Monday.

en: Then he grabbed the bar from a door and with the savage violence of his uncommon strength he smashed to dust the equipment in the alchemy laboratory, the daguerreotype room, the silver workshop, shouting like a man possessed in some high-sounding and fluent but completely incomprehensible language.
vi: So he grabbed the wooden bar used to block the door and with his inherent brutal strength, he smashed to pieces the alchemical laboratory equipment, the goldsmith's workshop, and the camera. Then, like a demon, he screamed in a language that was both resonant and incessant, yet utterly incomprehensible.
tr: Then, grabbing the iron door handle, with the full crushing force of his unprecedented strength, he smashed everything in the alchemy laboratory, the photo studio, and the silver workshop to pieces. On the one hand, he was shouting something in a high-pitched and incomprehensible language.
es: Then he grabbed a door bar and with the wild violence of his immense strength, he smashed the alchemy apparatus, the daguerreotype cabinet, the goldsmith's workshop into dust, shouting like a madman in a high-sounding and fluent but completely incomprehensible language.

en: He was about to finish off the rest of the house when Aureliano asked the neighbors for help.
vi: He was ready to destroy the entire house when fortunately, Aureliano had called the neighbors for help.
tr: Aureliano saw that things were getting out of hand and that if he let it go, his father would destroy the house, so he asked for help from the neighbors.
es: He was about to finish off the rest of the house when Aureliano asked the neighbors for help.

en: Ten men were needed to get him down, fourteen to tie him up, twenty to drag him to the chestnut tree in the courtyard, where they left him tied up, barking in the strange language and giving off a green froth at the mouth.
vi: It took ten strong men to bring him down, fourteen to tie him up, and twenty to drag him to the chestnut tree in the middle of the yard, where they left him tied up, free to bark out strange words and spit out green phlegm.
tr: It took ten people to bring Jose Arcadio to the ground, fourteen people to tie his hands and feet, and twenty people to drag him to the chestnut tree in the garden. When they tied him to the tree and left him, he was shouting something in an unknown language, and green foam was coming out of his mouth.
es: It took ten men to knock him down, fourteen to tie him up, twenty to drag him to the chestnut tree in the yard, where they left him tied up, barking in a strange language and foaming green at the mouth.

en: When Úrsula and Amaranta returned he was still tied to the trunk of the chestnut tree by his hands and feet, soaked with rain and in a state of total innocence.
vi: When Ursula and Amaranta returned, he was still tightly bound to the tree, soaked and completely deranged.
tr: When Ursula and Amaranta returned, Jose Arcadio Buendia was tied to the chestnut tree by his hands and feet: he was soaking wet from the rain and had completely lost his mind. Ursula and Amaranta tried to talk to him.
es: When Úrsula and Amaranta arrived, he was still tied hand and foot to the trunk of the chestnut tree, soaked by the rain and in a state of total innocence.

en: They spoke to him and he looked at them without recognizing them, saying things they did not understand.
vi: The mother and daughter spoke to him, but he did not recognize his own kin. He spoke to them about something incomprehensible.
tr: He did not recognize them and said something in a language they did not understand.
es: They spoke to him, and he looked at them without recognizing them and said something incomprehensible.

en: Úrsula untied his wrists and ankles, lacerated by the pressure of the rope, and left him tied only by the waist.
vi: Ursula untied the ropes around his wrists and ankles, where the flesh had become calloused from the tight bindings, leaving him only tied at the waist.
tr: Ursula untied his wrists and feet, which had been cut by the ropes. She left only his waist tied.
es: Úrsula untied his wrists and ankles, ulcerated by the pressure of the ropes, and left him tied only by the waist.

en: Later on they built him a shelter of palm brandies to protect him from the sun and the rain.
vi: After that, they set up a makeshift palm leaf hut to shield him from the rain and sun.
tr: Later on, they made a shelter out of palm leaves to protect him from the sun and rain.
es: Later they built him a palm shelter to protect him from the sun and rain.

en: Chapter 5
vi: Chapter 5
tr: Aureliano Buendia and Remedios Moscote entered into matrimony on a Sunday in March, in front of the altar set up in the guest room by Father Nicanor Reyna.
es: Aureliano Buendía and Remedios Moscote were married on a Sunday in March before the altar that Father Nicanor Reyna had built in the visitors' room.

en: AURELIANO BUENDÍA and Remedios Moscote were married one Sunday in March before the altar Father Nicanor Reyna had set up in the parlor.
vi: One Sunday in March, Aureliano Buendía and Remedios Moscote were married before the altar of God, which Father Nicanor Reyna had set up right in the Buendía family's living room.
tr: Aureliano Buendia and Remedios Moscote entered into matrimony on a Sunday in March, in front of the altar set up in the guest room by Father Nicanor Reyna.
es: Aureliano Buendía and Remedios Moscote were married on a Sunday in March before the altar that Father Nicanor Reyna had built in the visitors' room.

en: It was the culmination of four weeks of shocks in the Moscote household because little Remedios had reached puberty before getting over the habits of childhood.
vi: It was a period of intense activity lasting four consecutive weeks in the Moscote household, because little Remedios reached puberty before she had abandoned her childhood habits.
tr: Thus concluded the stormy four weeks that had turned the Moscote family upside down due to Remedios' transition to adolescence without abandoning her childhood habits.
es: It was the culmination of four weeks of upheavals in the Moscote household, as little Remedios reached puberty before outgrowing the habits of childhood.

en: In spite of the fact that her mother had taught her about the changes of adolescence, one February afternoon she burst shouting into the living room, where her sisters were chatting with Aureliano, and showed them her panties, smeared with a chocolate-colored paste.
vi: Although her mother had explained the sudden changes of puberty to her, one February afternoon she suddenly panicked and cried out, showing her sisters, who were sitting and embroidering, a slip stained with a slimy chocolate-colored substance.
tr: Her mother had sat her down and explained at length how to transition to young womanhood, but still, one day in February, while Aureliano was sitting and chatting with his sisters-in-law, Remedios had burst into the room, showing her underwear stained with a chocolate-colored liquid.
es: Despite her mother's lessons about the changes of adolescence, one February afternoon she burst into the room where her sisters were talking with Aureliano, shouting in alarm, and showed them her underwear smeared with a chocolaty paste.

en: A month for the wedding was agreed upon.
vi: The wedding date was set for a month later.
tr: It was decided that the wedding would take place one month from that date.
es: A month was set for the wedding.

en: There was barely enough time to teach her how to wash herself, get dressed by herself, and understand the fundamental business of a home.
vi: There was hardly enough time to teach the girl how to wash herself, dress herself, and understand the essential tasks of family life.
tr: During this time, the household was at their wits' end trying to teach Remedios to bathe herself, dress herself, and manage some basic household chores.
es: There was barely enough time to teach her to wash herself, dress herself, and understand the basic matters of running a household.

en: They made her urinate over hot bricks in order to cure her of the habit of wetting her bed.
vi: They made her urinate on heated bricks to cure her bedwetting.
tr: They heated up bricks and placed them under him to make him stop wetting his pants.
es: They made her urinate on hot bricks to correct her bed-wetting habit.

en: It took a good deal of work to convince her of the inviolability of the marital secret, for Remedios was so confused and at the same time so amazed at the revelation that she wanted to talk to everybody about the details of the wedding night.
vi: It was very difficult to convince her of the inviolability of the bridal chamber, because Remedios was both very frightened and very excited by the instructions to the point that she wanted everyone to talk about the wedding night in all its details.
tr: It took a lot of effort to make her understand that she shouldn't talk to anyone about the privacy of a married couple, because Remedios was so bewildered and confused by what her mother had taught her that she wanted to tell everyone about what would happen on her wedding night. Preparing the girl for marriage was not a task that just anyone could handle.
es: It was hard to convince her of the inviolability of marital secrets, because Remedios was so bewildered and at the same time so amazed by the revelation that she wanted to share the details of the wedding night with everyone.

en: It was a fatiguing effort, but on the date set for the ceremony the child was as adept in the ways of the world as any of her sisters.
vi: It was a tremendous effort, but on the day chosen for the wedding, the girl appeared as worldly-wise as any of her older sisters.
tr: Still, by the time the wedding day arrived, the girl had become at least as aware as her older sisters.
es: It was an exhausting effort, but by the date set for the ceremony, the girl was as skilled in worldly matters as any of her sisters.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote escorted her by the arm down the street that was decorated with flowers and wreaths amidst the explosion of rockets and the music of several bands, and she waved with her hand and gave her thanks with a smile to those who wished her good luck from the windows.
vi: Mr. Apolina Moscote took his daughter by the arm and led her through the village streets adorned with flowers, resonating with the sound of firecrackers and joyful cranes. The little girl waved and smiled in thanks to those who wished her luck and happiness from their windows.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote took his daughter by the arm and began to walk down the street adorned with flowers and wreaths, where several brass bands were lined up along the way, amidst the noise of fireworks being set off here and there.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote walked her down the flower-adorned street, amidst the sound of fireworks and the music of several bands, and she waved and thanked with a smile those who wished her good luck from the windows.

en: Aureliano, dressed in black, wearing the same patent leather boots with metal fasteners that he would have on a few years later as he faced the firing squad, had an intense paleness and a hard lump in his throat when he met the bride at the door of the house and led her to the altar.
vi: Aureliano, dressed in a black wool suit, wearing dark brown boots with spurs, the same boots he would wear years later when facing the firing squad, with a pale, ashen face and a throat tight with emotion, greeted his bride at the door and led her to the altar.
tr: Gelin, pencerelerden sarkan, kendisine iyi dileklerde bulunan konu komşuya gülümseyerek el sallıyordu.
es: Aureliano, dressed in black cloth, with the same patent leather boots with metal hooks that he would wear a few years later before the firing squad, was intensely pale and had a hard lump in his throat when he received his bride at the door of the house and led her to the altar.

en: She behaved as naturally, with such discretion, that she did not lose her composure, not even when Aureliano dropped the ring as he tried to put it on her finger.
vi: The young girl behaved so naturally and appropriately that she maintained her composure even when Aureliano, while placing the ring on her finger, dropped it.
tr: Tepeden tırnağa siyahlar giyinmiş, ayaklarına da birkaç yıl sonra idam mangasının önüne çıkarken de giyeceği parlak deri çizmeleri çekmiş olan Aureliano'nun benzi, kül gibiydi.
es: She behaved with such naturalness and discretion that she did not lose her composure even when Aureliano dropped the ring while trying to put it on her.

en: In the midst of the.
vi: In the noisy atmosphere filled with whispers and in the initial moments of confusion among the guests, the bride held up her hand, wearing a stocking that left her toes exposed, and kept her ring finger extended, waiting until the groom, with his booted foot, stopped the ring from rolling out the door and picked it up, his face flushed as he returned to the altar.
tr: Evin kapısında gelini karşılayıp mihrabın önüne götürürken boğazına bir düğüm takıldı.
es: Amidst the murmur and the beginning of confusion among the guests, she kept her arm raised with the lace mitten and remained with her ring finger ready, until her groom managed to stop the ring with his boot so it wouldn't roll to the door, and returned blushing to the altar.

en: murmurs and confusion of the guests, she kept her arm with the fingerless lace glove held up and remained like that with her ring finger ready until the bridegroom managed to stop the ring with his foot before it rolled to the door, and came back blushing to the altar.
vi: In the noisy atmosphere filled with whispers and in the initial moments of confusion among the guests, the bride held up her hand, wearing a stocking that left her toes exposed, and kept her ring finger extended, waiting until the groom, with his booted foot, stopped the ring from rolling out the door and picked it up, his face flushed as he returned to the altar.
tr: Remedios öyle kendine güvenli bir tavırdaydı ki, Aureliano yüzüğü parmağına takayım derken düşürünce bile hiç istifini bozmadı. Konukların şaşkınlığına, salonu bir anda dolduran fısıltılara aldırmadan, damat bey, yüzüğü tam kapıdan dışarı yuvarlanacağı sırada ayağıyla durdurup kan ter içinde mihrabın önüne gelinceye dek, Remedios, dantel eldivenli yüzüksüz elini havada hazır bekletti.
es: Amidst the murmur and the beginning of confusion among the guests, she kept her arm raised with the lace mitten and remained with her ring finger ready, until her groom managed to stop the ring with his boot so it wouldn't roll to the door, and returned blushing to the altar.

en: Her mother and sisters suffered so much from the fear that the child would do something wrong during the ceremony that in the end they were the ones who committed the impertinence of picking her up to kiss her.
vi: Her mother and sisters were anxiously worried that the girl might make a mistake, even a small gesture, during the ceremony, and when the ceremony concluded, they were the ones who rushed over, despite the presence of all the guests, to lift her up and shower her with passionate kisses.
tr: Annesiyle ablaları tören sırasında kızın bir densizlik yapmasından öylesine korkuyorlardı ki, gelin bu işin içinden yüzünün akıyla çıkınca, kendilerini tutamayıp kucakladıkları gibi öpücüklere boğdular onu.
es: Her mother and sisters were so anxious that the girl might make a mistake during the ceremony that in the end, they were the ones who committed the impropriety of lifting her up to give her a kiss.

en: From that day on the sense of responsibility, the natural grace, the calm control that Remedios would have in the face of adverse circumstances was revealed.
vi: From that day on, she demonstrated that she was a person of submissive, tactful, and calm nature in the face of family conflicts.
tr: Remedios's sense of responsibility, grace, delicacy, and ability to remain calm in difficult situations showed itself even from that day.
es: From that day on, Remedios revealed the sense of responsibility, natural grace, and calm control that she would always have in the face of adverse circumstances.

en: It was she who, on her own initiative, put aside the largest piece that she had cut from the wedding cake and took it on a plate with a fork to José Arcadio Buendía.
vi: She was the one who initiated the wedding feast and took the best piece of the wedding cake, placed it on a plate with a fork, and brought it to José Arcadio Buendía.
tr: It was she who thought on her own to put the largest slice of the wedding cake on a plate and bring it along with a fork to Jose Arcadio Buendia.
es: It was she who, on her own initiative, set aside the best portion of the wedding cake and took it on a plate with a fork to José Arcadio Buendía.

en: Tied to the trunk of the chestnut tree, huddled on a wooden stool underneath the palm shelter, the enormous old man, discolored by the sun and rain, made a vague smile of gratitude and at the piece of cake with his fingers, mumbling an unintelligible psalm.
vi: Tied to the chestnut tree, hunched over on a wooden chair in the palm-thatched hut, the old, fat man with skin bleached by the sun and rain gave a distracted, grateful smile, took the piece of cake, and began to hum an incomprehensible hymn.
tr: The large man, tied to the trunk of the chestnut tree, huddled on the wooden bench under the palm shade, his color faded from the sun and rain, smiled faintly as if to thank her and mumbled an incomprehensible prayer while gobbling down the cake with his hands.
es: Tied to the trunk of the chestnut tree, hunched on a wooden stool under the palm shelter, the enormous old man, discolored by the sun and rain, gave a vague smile of gratitude and ate the cake with his fingers, chewing an unintelligible psalm.

en: The only unhappy person in that noisy celebration, which lasted until dawn on Monday, was Rebeca Buendía.
vi: The only person not happy at the grand wedding that lasted until the early hours of the second day was Rebeca Buendía.
tr: The only hopeless person at the wedding, which lasted with music and dancing until Monday morning, was Rebeca Buendia.
es: The only unhappy person at that boisterous celebration that lasted until dawn on Monday was Rebeca Buendía.

en: It was her own frustrated party.
vi: Her joyous day did not come to pass.
tr: It was her darkest day.
es: It was her frustrated party.

en: By an arrangement of Úrsula’s, her marriage was to be celebrated on the same day, but that Friday Pietro Crespi received a letter with the news of his mother’s imminent death.
vi: According to an agreement with Úrsula, her wedding was also to be held on the same day as Aureliano's, but on Friday, Pietro Crespi received a letter informing him that his mother was dying.
tr: Ursula had planned to marry her off on the same day. However, on Friday, a letter arrived for Pietro Crespi, informing him that his mother was on her deathbed.
es: By agreement with Úrsula, her wedding was to be celebrated on the same date, but Pietro Crespi received a letter on Friday announcing the imminent death of his mother.

en: The wedding was postponed.
vi: Their wedding was postponed.
tr: As a result, the wedding was postponed.
es: The wedding was postponed.

en: Pietro Crespi left for the capital of the province an hour after receiving the letter, and on the road he missed his mother, who arrived punctually Saturday night and at Aureliano’s wedding sang the sad aria that she had prepared for the wedding of her son.
vi: An hour after receiving the letter, Pietro Crespi left for the city immediately, and on his way, he did not meet his mother, who was also on her way to the village of Macondo to arrive in time for Saturday night. At Aureliano's wedding, she sang a sad song she had composed specifically for her son's wedding.
tr: Pietro Crespi departed for the capital one hour after receiving the news of the death. Mother and son passed by each other in opposite directions without noticing, the woman arrived home at the expected hour on Saturday evening and sang the sorrowful aria she had prepared for her son's wedding at Aureliano's wedding.
es: Pietro Crespi left for the provincial capital an hour after receiving the letter, and on the way, he crossed paths with his mother who arrived punctually on Saturday night and sang at Aureliano's wedding the sad aria she had prepared for her son's wedding.

en: Pietro Crespi returned on Sunday midnight to sweep up the ashes of the party, after having worn out five horses on the road in an attempt to be in time for his wedding.
vi: Piêtrô Crêspi returned at midnight on Sunday to clean up the cigarette butts from the party after he had raced like the wind, causing five horses to collapse along the way, trying to make it back in time for his own wedding.
tr: Having exhausted five horses to make it to his own wedding on time, Pietro Crespi found, upon his return on Sunday night, that the wedding festivities had ended, leaving only remnants behind.
es: Pietro Crespi returned at midnight on Sunday to sweep up the ashes of the party, after having exhausted five horses on the way trying to be on time for his wedding.

en: It was never discovered who wrote the letter.
vi: The letter writer would never be discovered.
tr: It was never discovered who wrote the letter.
es: It was never discovered who wrote the letter.

en: Tormented by Úrsula, Amaranta wept with indignation and swore her innocence in front of the altar, which the carpenters had not finished dismantling.
vi: Scolded by Úrsula, Amaranta wept bitterly, swearing on her life and before the altar of God, which the carpenters had not yet removed.
tr: Ursula cornered Amaranta, but the girl swore her innocence in front of the altar that the carpenters had yet to dismantle.
es: Tormented by Úrsula, Amaranta cried in indignation and swore her innocence in front of the altar that the carpenters had not yet finished dismantling.

en: Father Nicanor Reyna—whom Don Apolinar Moscote had brought from the swamp to officiate at the wedding—was an old man hardened by the ingratitude of his ministry.
vi: Father Nicanor Reyna - the person brought here by Apolinar Moscote to perform the wedding ceremony - was a patient man in his exceedingly dull and monotonous work.
tr: Father Nicanor Reyna, whom Don Apolinar Moscote brought from the swamp to conduct his wedding ceremony, was an old man hardened by the ingratitude of his profession.
es: Father Nicanor Reyna —whom Don Apolinar Moscote had brought from the swamp to officiate the wedding— was an old man hardened by the ingratitude of his ministry.

en: His skin was sad, with the bones almost exposed, and he had a pronounced round stomach and the expression of an old angel, which came more from, simplicity than from goodness.
vi: He had a sorrowful complexion that clung to his bones, a round, protruding belly, and the overly gentle, almost foolish demeanor of an old deity.
tr: His skin was so pale it seemed as if his bones were about to burst out from within. He had a round belly and an angelic expression on his face that stemmed more from simplicity than goodness.
es: He had sad skin, almost just bones, a pronounced and round belly, and an expression of an old angel that was more of innocence than of kindness.

en: He had planned to return to his pariah after the wedding, but he was appalled at the hardness of the inhabitants of Macondo, who were prospering in the midst of scandal, subject to the natural law, without baptizing their children or sanctifying their festivals.
vi: He intended to return to his parish immediately after the wedding, but he was astonished by the excessively rustic and uncouth nature of the people of Macondo, who had proliferated abundantly, living blindly according to natural laws, refusing to baptize their children or give them saint names for the holidays.
tr: After the wedding, he intended to return to his homeland. However, when he saw that the people of Macondo had shelved both virtue and sin, forgotten what baptism and feast days were, his heart could not bear such depravity.
es: He intended to return to his parish after the wedding, but he was appalled by the aridity of the inhabitants of Macondo, who thrived on scandal, adhered to natural law, without baptizing their children or sanctifying the holidays.

en: Thinking that no land needed the seed of God so much, he decided to stay on for another week to Christianize both circumcised and gentile, legalize concubinage, and give the sacraments to the dying.
vi: Believing that this land needed God's seeds more than anywhere else, the priest decided to stay another week to convert this village into a village of the Lord, to conduct weddings for couples living together as they pleased, and to baptize those who were gravely ill.
tr: Believing that there could be no place more in need of God's love and fear, and that no more virgin soil could be found to sow God's seed, he decided to stay another week, to baptize anyone circumcised or uncircumcised, to marry long-time couples before God, and to pray over the dead.
es: Thinking that no land needed the seed of God as much, he decided to stay one more week to Christianize the circumcised and the gentiles, legalize concubinaries, and sacrament the dying.

en: But no one paid any attention to him.
vi: But no one listened to the priest.
tr: But no one paid any attention.
es: But no one paid him any attention.

en: They would answer him that they had been many years without a priest, arranging the business of their souls directly with God, and that they had lost the evil of original sin.
vi: They told the priest that for many years they had lived without the guidance of a pastor, that they resolved their spiritual issues directly with God, and that they had completely abandoned their sinful habits.
tr: Whoever he approached, they said that they had managed just fine without a priest for all these years, and that they conducted their affairs with God without any intermediaries for their souls.
es: They replied that for many years they had been without a priest, dealing with the matters of the soul directly with God, and had lost the malice of mortal sin.

en: Tired of preaching in the open, Father Nicanor decided to undertake the building of a church, the largest in the world, with life-size saints and stained-glass windows on the sides, so that people would come from Rome to honor God in the center of impiety.
vi: Weary of preaching in the wilderness, Father Nicanô decided to build the largest church in the world, with life-sized statues and walls inlaid with colorful glass. Such a grand church would attract believers from as far as Rome, bringing glory to God right in the heart of this godless land.
tr: When Father Nicanor grew tired of going from street to street preaching, he thought of building a church. This was going to be a church like no other in the world, adorned with stained glass on both sides, featuring life-sized depictions of saints, and people would travel all the way from Rome to this land of non-believers to find their God.
es: Tired of preaching in the desert, Father Nicanor set out to build a temple, the largest in the world, with life-sized saints and colored glass in the walls, so that people would come from Rome to honor God in the center of impiety.

en: He went everywhere begging alms with a copper dish.
vi: The priest went around the village with a brass plate in hand to collect donations.
tr: He took a copper bowl in his hand and went out to collect donations. Everyone was giving generously from their hearts, and what was given was not insignificant at all, but it was impossible to satisfy the holy father's greed.
es: He went everywhere begging for alms with a copper dish.

en: They gave him a large amount, but he wanted more, because the church had to have a bell that would raise the drowned up to the surface of the water.
vi: The villagers gave a lot, but the priest wanted more, because the church needed a bell whose sound could make the bodies of drowned people rise to the surface.
tr: He said it had to be a bell strong enough to bring the drowned to the surface and loud enough to make an impact wherever it struck.
es: They gave him a lot, but he wanted more, because the temple had to have a bell whose toll would bring the drowned to the surface.

en: He pleaded so much that he lost his voice.
vi: The priest pleaded so much that he became hoarse.
tr: His voice became hoarse from pleading, and he could no longer speak.
es: He pleaded so much that he lost his voice.

en: His bones began to fill with sounds.
vi: His bones ached as if ants were crawling inside them.
tr: When he couldn't express his voice outwardly, it spread inwardly, and his bones and marrow began to resonate.
es: His bones began to fill with noises.

en: One Saturday, not even having collected the price of the doors, he fell into a desperate confusion.
vi: One Saturday, unable to get anything, not even fruits or food left at the door, the priest became fearful out of despair.
tr: On a Saturday when he couldn't even gather enough money for the doors, he went mad with despair, not knowing what to do, he set up a pulpit in the middle of the village, and on Sunday, like in the days of his insomnia, he took a rattle in his hand and called everyone, whether they heard or not, to an open-air mass.
es: One Saturday, not having collected even the value of the doors, he let himself be overcome by despair.

en: He improvised an altar in the square and on Sunday he went through the town with a small bell, as in the days of insomnia, calling people to an open-air mass.
vi: He hastily set up an altar in the middle of the square, and on Sunday, ringing a bell as if during a time of rampant insomnia, he went around the village urging everyone to attend the rustic mass.
tr: On a Saturday when he couldn't even gather enough money for the doors, he went mad with despair, not knowing what to do, he set up a pulpit in the middle of the village, and on Sunday, like in the days of his insomnia, he took a rattle in his hand and called everyone, whether they heard or not, to an open-air mass.
es: He improvised an altar in the square and on Sunday went around the town with a small bell, as in the times of insomnia, calling for an open-air mass.

en: Many went out of curiosity.
vi: Many people came out of curiosity.
tr: Most went out of curiosity.
es: Many went out of curiosity.

en: Others from nostalgia.
vi: Others came out of longing.
tr: Most went out of curiosity.
es: Others out of nostalgia.

en: Others so that God would not take the disdain for His intermediary as a personal insult.
vi: Some attended the mass to avoid having God see their neutral stance as personal opposition.
tr: Some went out of longing for the old days, and some so that God wouldn't consider ignoring His messenger an insult to Himself.
es: Others so that God would not take their disregard for his intermediary as a personal offense.

en: So that at eight in the morning half the town was in the square, where Father Nicanor chanted the gospels in a voice that had been lacerated by his pleading.
vi: So at eight in the morning, half the village had gathered in the square to watch Father Nicanô, hoarse from pleading, reciting the Gospel.
tr: Thus, at eight in the morning, half the village gathered in the square and listened to the sermon given by Father Nicanor, whose voice was hoarse from begging.
es: So at eight in the morning, half the town was in the square, where Father Nicanor sang the gospels with a voice lacerated by supplication.

en: At the end, when the congregation began to break up, he raised his arms signaling for attention.
vi: At the end of the mass, as the attendees began to disperse, the priest raised his hands high to signal everyone to listen:
tr: Finally, as the gathered crowd began to slowly disperse, Father Nicanor raised his arms as if to indicate he was about to say something important.
es: At the end, when the attendees began to disperse, he raised his arms as a sign of attention.

en: “Just a moment,” he said.
vi: - Wait? Wait? - father said.
tr: "Wait a minute," he said.
es: —One moment —he said—.

en: “Now we shall witness an undeniable proof of the infinite power of God.”
vi: - Now we will see an indisputable proof of the infinite power of God.
tr: "Now we will witness an indisputable proof of God's infinite power."
es: Now we are going to witness irrefutable proof of the infinite power of God.

en: The boy who had helped him with the mass brought him a cup of thick and steaming chocolate, which he drank without pausing to breathe.
vi: The little boy who earlier helped the priest conduct the mass now brought him a cup of thick, steaming hot chocolate, which the priest drank in one continuous gulp.
tr: During the ceremony, the child who was helping him brought a cup of dark cocoa with steam rising from it. Father Nicanor finished the cocoa in one gulp.
es: The boy who had assisted at mass brought him a cup of thick, steaming chocolate which he drank without pausing for breath.

en: Then he wiped his lips with a handkerchief that he drew from his sleeve, extended his arms, and closed his eyes.
vi: After that, the priest took the handkerchief tucked in his wide sleeve to wipe his mouth, spread his arms wide, and closed his eyes tightly.
tr: He wiped his mouth with the handkerchief he took out from the sleeve of his robe, opened his arms wide, and closed his eyes.
es: Then he wiped his lips with a handkerchief he took from his sleeve, stretched out his arms, and closed his eyes.

en: Thereupon Father Nicanor rose six inches above the level of the ground.
vi: Thus, Father Nicanô lifted himself twelve centimeters off the ground.
tr: And Father Nicanor suddenly rose about fifteen centimeters off the ground.
es: Then Father Nicanor rose twelve centimeters above the ground.

en: It was a convincing measure.
vi: It was an easily acceptable trick.
tr: There could be no more convincing proof of God's greatness.
es: It was a convincing demonstration.

en: He went among the houses for several days repeating the demonstration of levitation by means of chocolate while the acolyte collected so much money in a bag that in less than a month he began the construction of the church.
vi: In a few days, the priest went to every house to remind people of the experiment of lifting oneself off the ground through the neural stimulation power of chocolate. Meanwhile, the altar boy had collected so much money in the sack that in less than a month, the construction of the church had begun.
tr: After going door to door for a few more days and downing hot cocoa, he repeated this flying trick. When the bag in the sacristan boy's hand was stuffed full, he started the construction of the church within a month.
es: He spent several days going from house to house, repeating the levitation test through the stimulus of chocolate, while the altar boy collected so much money in a sack that in less than a month he began the construction of the temple.

en: No one doubted the divine origin of the demonstration except José Arcadio Buendía, who without changing expression watched the troop of people who gathered around the chestnut tree one morning to witness the revelation once more.
vi: No one doubted the divine origin of that demonstration, except for José Arcadio Buendía, who, without moving, observed the chaotic crowd surrounding the chestnut tree one morning to once again see the priest lift himself off the ground.
tr: No one doubted that God's hand was in the priest's flying, except for Jose Arcadio Buendia, who watched the crowd gathered around the chestnut tree to see the flying demonstration again without moving a muscle.
es: No one doubted the divine origin of the demonstration, except for José Arcadio Buendía, who observed without flinching the crowd that one morning gathered around the chestnut tree to witness the revelation once more.

en: He merely stretched on his stool a little and shrugged his shoulders when Father Nicanor began to rise up from the ground along with the chair he was sitting on.
vi: He almost just slightly stretched his legs on the chair and shrugged when Father Nicanor began to lift himself off the ground along with the chair he was sitting on.
tr: When Father Nicanor began to lift his feet off the ground along with the chair he was sitting on, Jose Arcadio Buendia did nothing but spread out a little more on the wooden bench and shrug his shoulders.
es: He barely stretched a little on the bench and shrugged when Father Nicanor began to rise from the ground along with the chair he was sitting on.

en: “Hoc est simplicissimus,” José Arcadio Buendía said.
vi: - This is the simplest - said José Arcadio Buendía - this man has discovered the fourth state of matter
tr: Then I said, "Hoc est simplicissimus."
es: —This is the simplest thing —said José Arcadio Buendía—: this man has discovered the fourth state of matter.

en: “Homo iste statum quartum materiae invenit.”
vi: - This is the simplest - said José Arcadio Buendía - this man has discovered the fourth state of matter
tr: This man discovered the fourth state of matter.
es: —This is the simplest thing —said José Arcadio Buendía—: this man has discovered the fourth state of matter.

en: Father Nicanor raised his hands and the four legs of the chair all landed on the ground at the same time.
vi: Father Nicanor raised his hand and immediately the four legs of the chair lowered to stand on the ground.
tr: Peder Nicanor raised his hands in the air and the four legs of the chair touched the ground at the same time.
es: Father Nicanor raised his hand and the four legs of the chair touched the ground at the same time.

en: “Nego,” he said.
vi: - I deny it - he said.
tr: "No," he replied.
es: —I deny it —he said—.

en: “Factum hoc existentiam Dei probat sine dubio.”
vi: - In fact, this proves the existence of God without a doubt.
tr: "This fact undoubtedly proves the existence of God."
es: This fact undoubtedly proves the existence of God.

en: Thus it was discovered that José Arcadio Buendía’s devilish jargon was Latin.
vi: Thus it was known that the incomprehensible demonic language of José Arcadio Buendía was Latin.
tr: Thus, it was understood that the hocus-pocus spoken by Jose Arcadio Buendia was Latin.
es: That was how it was discovered that the devilish jargon of José Arcadio Buendía was Latin.

en: Father Nicanor took advantage of the circumstance of his being the only person who had been able to communicate with him to try to inject the faith into his twisted mind.
vi: Father Nicanor took advantage of the opportunity, being the only one who could communicate with José Arcadio Buendía, to instill Christian faith into his deranged mind.
tr: Father Nicanor, taking advantage of being the only person who could communicate with him, tried to inject the belief in God into his deranged mind:
es: Father Nicanor took advantage of being the only person who had been able to communicate with him to try to instill faith in his disturbed mind.

en: Every afternoon he would sit by the chestnut tree preaching in Latin, but José Arcadio Buendía insisted on rejecting rhetorical tricks and the transmutation of chocolate, and he demanded the daguerreotype of God as the only proof.
vi: Every afternoon, the priest would sit by the chestnut tree and preach in Latin, but José Arcadio Buendía, delighted, would not acknowledge the old worn paths nor the changing color of chocolate and demanded to see a picture of God, considering it as the ultimate proof.
tr: Now, he went to the chestnut tree every day, preaching in Latin. However, Jose Arcadio Buendia paid no attention to the babble, did not care about the cocoa miracle, and insisted that he wanted a photograph of God as the only proof.
es: Every afternoon he would sit next to the chestnut tree, preaching in Latin, but José Arcadio Buendía stubbornly refused to accept rhetorical twists or chocolate transmutations, and demanded as the only proof the daguerreotype of God.

en: Father Nicanor then brought him medals and pictures and even a reproduction of the Veronica, but José Arcadio Buendía rejected them as artistic objects without any scientific basis.
vi: So Father Nicanor brought him badges and pictures and even a reproduction of a cloth embroidered with the image of Saint Veronica, but José Arcadio dismissed them as handicrafts without scientific basis.
tr: Upon this, Father Nicanor brought medallions, icons, and even a Veronica handkerchief. But Jose Arcadio Buendia did not accept them, saying they were artistic things without a scientific basis.
es: Father Nicanor then brought him medals and holy cards and even a reproduction of Veronica's veil, but José Arcadio Buendía rejected them as artisanal objects without scientific basis.

en: He was so stubborn that Father Nicanor gave up his attempts at evangelization and continued visiting him out of humanitarian feelings.
vi: He was so stubborn that Father Nicanor had to abandon his intention of converting him to Christianity. However, in terms of personal affection, the priest still visited him regularly.
tr: He was so adamant that in the end, Father Nicanor gave up trying to call him to the righteous path and continued to visit him purely out of human compassion.
es: He was so stubborn that Father Nicanor gave up his evangelization efforts and continued visiting him out of humanitarian feelings.

en: But then it was José Arcadio Buendía who took the lead and tried to break down the priest’s faith with rationalist tricks.
vi: But at that time, José Arcadio Buendía took the initiative to attack and intended to break the priest's faith with rational arguments.
tr: But then Jose Arcadio Buendia rolled up his sleeves and tried to undermine the priest's faith by trapping him in logical dilemmas.
es: But then it was José Arcadio Buendía who took the initiative and tried to break the priest's faith with rationalist tricks.

en: On a certain occasion when Father Nicanor brought a checker set to the chestnut tree and invited him to a game, José Arcadio Buendía would not accept, because according to him he could never understand the sense of a contest in which the two adversaries have agreed upon the rules.
vi: There were times when Father Nicanor brought a chessboard with all the pieces to the chestnut tree to invite him to play checkers. José Arcadio Buendía did not play, as he could never understand the meaning of a contest in which the two opponents had agreed on the principles.
tr: One day, Father Nicanor brought a chess set under the chestnut tree and invited Jose Arcadio to play. Jose Arcadio Buendia did not respond to this invitation, saying that there was no point in playing a game according to pre-agreed rules.
es: On one occasion, when Father Nicanor brought a board and a box of pieces to the chestnut tree to invite him to play checkers, José Arcadio Buendía did not accept, saying that he could never understand the point of a contest between two opponents who agreed on the principles.

en: Father Nicanor, who had never seen checkers played that way, could not play it again.
vi: Father Nicanor, who had never seen anyone play chess in such a manner, also did not return to play checkers.
tr: Having never seen chess played without rules, Father Nicanor never mentioned chess again.
es: Father Nicanor, who had never seen the game of checkers in that way, could not play it again.

en: Ever more startled at José Arcadio Buendía’s lucidity, he asked him how it was possible that they had him tied to a tree.
vi: Day by day, Father Nicanor admired José Arcadio Buendía's intelligence more and more. He asked him how he could be tied to the tree like that.
tr: Astonished by Jose Arcadio Buendia's rational conversation, he asked how they had managed to tie him to the tree.
es: Increasingly astonished by José Arcadio Buendía's lucidity, he asked him how it was possible that they had him tied to a tree.

en: “Hoc est simplicissimus,” he replied.
vi: - This is very simple, - he replied - because I am mad.
tr: This is the simplest, replied Jose Arcadio Buendia, I'm crazy, that's why.
es: —That is the simplest —he replied—: because I am crazy.

en: “Because I’m Crazy.”
vi: - This is very simple, - he replied - because I am mad.
tr: This is the simplest, replied Jose Arcadio Buendia, I'm crazy, that's why.
es: —That is the simplest —he replied—: because I am crazy.

en: From then on, concerned about his own faith, the priest did not come back to visit him and dedicated himself to hurrying along the building of the church.
vi: From that point on, taking care of his faith, the pastor no longer visited him, resolutely starting the construction of the church immediately.
tr: After that day, the priest, who began to doubt his own faith, never went to him again and dedicated himself to the construction of the church.
es: Since then, worried about his own faith, the priest did not visit him again, and devoted himself entirely to hastening the construction of the temple.

en: Rebeca felt her hopes being reborn.
vi: Rebecca felt her hope rekindling.
tr: Rebeca's hopes were rekindled.
es: Rebeca felt hope revive.

en: Her future was predicated on the completion of the work, for one Sunday when Father Nicanor was lunching at the house and the whole family sitting at the table spoke of the solemnity and splendor that religious ceremonies would acquire when the church was built, Amaranta said: “The luckiest one will be Rebeca.”
vi: Her future depended on the completion of this work. She thought so because since that Sunday when Pastor Nicano had lunch at their house and the whole family gathered around the dining table to talk about the solemn and grand ceremonies in religious activities once the church was completed. "The luckiest person here is Rebecca," Amaranta said.
tr: The future now depended on the construction of the church. Because one Sunday, when Father Nicanor came to eat with them and the family sat down at the table, while they were talking about the magnificent masses and ceremonies that would be held after the church was built, Amaranta said, "The luckiest of us will be Rebeca."
es: Her future was conditioned on the completion of the work, ever since a Sunday when Father Nicanor was having lunch at the house and the whole family, seated at the table, spoke of the solemnity and splendor that the religious ceremonies would have once the temple was built. “The most fortunate will be Rebeca,” said Amaranta.

en: And since Rebeca did not understand what she meant, she explained it to her with an innocent smile:
vi: And seeing that Rebecca did not understand what she meant, she explained with an innocent smile:
tr: When Rebeca didn't understand what she meant, she explained with a naive smile:
es: And since Rebeca did not understand what she meant, she explained it with an innocent smile:

en: “You’re going to be the one who will inaugurate the church with your wedding.”
vi: - Oh, it's because your wedding will coincide with the inauguration of the church.
tr: -You are the one who will celebrate the completion of the church with your wedding.
es: —You're going to have to inaugurate the church with your wedding.

en: Rebeca tried to forestall any comments.
vi: Rebecca hurriedly blocked any comments about this matter.
tr: Rebeca wanted to close the subject immediately.
es: Rebeca tried to anticipate any comment.

en: The way the construction was going the church would not be built before another ten years.
vi: According to the construction progress, the church cannot be completed before ten years.
tr: At this rate, the church wouldn't be finished for another ten years.
es: At the pace the construction was going, the temple would not be finished for another ten years.

en: Father Nicanor did not agree: the growing generosity of the faithful permitted him to make more optimistic calculations.
vi: Father Nicanor disagreed because he believed that with the newfound generosity of the faithful, he could make the optimists even more hopeful.
tr: However, Father Nicanor didn't think so at all. The generosity of charitable citizens led him to optimistic calculations.
es: Father Nicanor did not agree: the growing generosity of the faithful allowed for more optimistic calculations.

en: To the mute Indignation of Rebeca, who could not finish her lunch, Úrsula celebrated Amaranta’s idea and contributed a considerable sum for the work to move faster.
vi: In response to Rebecca's silent sulking, who had to leave her meal unfinished, Ursula agreed with Amaranta's idea and contributed a significant portion of her wealth to accelerate the construction progress.
tr: Despite Rebeca's silent anger, who had a lump in her throat, Ursula found Amaranta's idea quite reasonable and made a considerable donation to speed up the construction.
es: In the face of Rebeca's silent indignation, who could not finish her lunch, Úrsula celebrated Amaranta's idea and contributed a considerable amount to hasten the work.

en: Father Nicanor felt that with another contribution like that the church would be ready within three years.
vi: Father Nicanor believed that with another contribution like this, the house would be completed in less than three years.
tr: According to Father Nicanor, if there were another donation like this, the church would be finished in less than three years.
es: Father Nicanor considered that with another aid like that, the temple would be ready in three years.

en: From then on Rebeca did not say another word to Amaranta, convinced that her initiative had not the innocence that she attempted to give it.
vi: From that moment on, Rebeca refused to speak to Amaranta, telling herself that Amaranta's provocative attitude was not as innocent as she had thought.
tr: Believing that Amaranta's intentions were not as pure as they seemed, Rebeca never spoke to her again.
es: From then on, Rebeca did not speak to Amaranta again, convinced that her initiative had not had the innocence she had managed to appear.

en: “That was the least serious thing I could have done,” Amaranta answered her during the violent argument they had that night.
vi: "That is the least serious thing that could happen," Amaranta retorted to Rebeca in the fierce argument that took place that night.
tr: That night, while they were arguing, Amaranta said, This was the mildest, most harmless thing I could do.
es: "It was the least serious thing I could do," Amaranta replied in the virulent argument they had that night.

en: “In that way I won’t have to kill you for three years.”
vi: "So, for the next three years, I won't need to kill you."
tr: At least this way, I won't have to kill you for another three years.
es: "This way I won't have to kill you in the next three years."

en: Rebeca accepted the challenge.
vi: Rebeca accepted that challenge.
tr: Rebeca accepted this challenge of hers.
es: Rebeca accepted the challenge.

en: When Pietro Crespi found out about the new postponement, he went through a crisis of disappointment, but Rebeca gave him a final proof of her loyalty.
vi: When Pietro Crespi learned that his wedding was postponed again, he fell into a state of despair. In contrast, Rebeca demonstrated her loyalty.
tr: Pietro Crespi was devastated when he heard that their wedding had been postponed again. Rebeca encouraged him by proving her loyalty once more.
es: When Pietro Crespi learned of the new postponement, he suffered a crisis of disappointment, but Rebeca gave him a definitive proof of loyalty.

en: “We’ll elope whenever you say,” she told him.
vi: "We will elope whenever you decide," she said.
tr: "If you want, we can elope," she said.
es: "We will elope whenever you decide," she said to him.

en: Pietro Crespi, however, was not a man of adventure.
vi: However, Pietro Crespi was not one to take risks.
tr: But Pietro Crespi was not the kind of man to jump into an adventure with his eyes closed.
es: However, Pietro Crespi was not a man of adventures.

en: He lacked the impulsive character of his fiancée and he considered respect for one’s given word as a wealth that should not be squandered.
vi: He lacked the passionate nature of a lover and was overly scrupulous, treating promises as treasures that could not be squandered.
tr: He didn't have a trace of his fiancée's boldness. Respecting a given word was his most valuable treasure.
es: He lacked the impulsive character of his fiancée, and considered respect for one's word as a capital that could not be squandered.

en: Then Rebeca turned to more audacious methods.
vi: So Rebeca resorted to bolder tactics.
tr: Upon this, Rebeca began to employ bolder methods.
es: Then Rebeca resorted to bolder methods.

en: A mysterious wind blew out the lamps in the parlor and Úrsula surprised the lovers kissing in the dark.
vi: A strange wind blew out the lamp in the living room, and Úrsula caught the two of them kissing in the dark.
tr: Once, when a gust of wind from an unknown source extinguished the lamps in the guest room, Ursula caught the two lovers kissing in the dark.
es: A mysterious wind would extinguish the lamps in the visiting room, and Úrsula would catch the couple kissing in the dark.

en: Pietro Crespi gave her some confused explanations about the poor quality of modern pitch lamps and he even helped her install a more secure system of illumination for the room.
vi: Pietro Crespi clumsily explained to her about the poor quality of modern candles that burned with tar and helped her set up a more reliable lighting system in the living room.
tr: Pietro Crespi was flustered, complained that these newfangled lamps were useless, and even helped Ursula to equip the room with a more reliable lighting system.
es: Pietro Crespi gave clumsy explanations about the poor quality of modern tar lamps and even helped install safer lighting systems in the room.

en: But the fuel failed again or the wicks became clogged and Úrsula found Rebeca sitting on her fiancé’s lap.
vi: But another time, the lamp was either filled with the wrong oil or the wick slipped. Úrsula caught Rebeca sitting on her lover's lap again.
tr: But whether it was due to the poor quality of the kerosene or defective wicks, the lamps went out again, and this time Ursula caught Rebeca in her fiancé's lap.
es: But again, the fuel would fail or the wicks would get stuck, and Úrsula would find Rebeca sitting on her fiancé's lap.

en: This time she would accept no explanation.
vi: So she refused to listen to any more excuses.
tr: There was no more room for excuses.
es: She ended up not accepting any explanation.

en: She turned the responsibility of the bakery over to the Indian woman and sat in a rocking chair to watch over the young people during the visits, ready to win out over maneuvers that had already been old when she was a girl.
vi: She assigned the Indian girl to watch over the candy store and sat in the rocking chair herself to supervise the lovers' conversations, determined not to be outdone by the old tricks she was familiar with from her own youth.
tr: She dumped the bakery work on the Indian woman and, to prevent the usual tricks she herself had once played on her own mother, sat in the rocking chair and watched them until Crespi left.
es: She entrusted the responsibility of the bakery to the Indian woman and sat in a rocking chair to supervise the couple's visits, determined not to be defeated by maneuvers that were already old in her youth.

en: “Poor Mama,” Rebeca would say with mock indignation, seeing Úrsula yawn during the boredom of the visits.
vi: "Poor mother!", Rebecca said with all the resentment mixed with a bit of humor as she watched Ursula yawning in the tense atmosphere of the visit.
tr: Seeing Ursula yawn from boredom, Rebeca would pretend to be angry and say, "Poor mother, she'll go to heaven with this rocking chair when she dies."
es: "Poor mom," Rebeca would say with mocking indignation, seeing Úrsula yawn in the drowsiness of the visits. "

en: “When she dies she’ll go off to her reward in that rocking chair.”
vi: "When I die, I might just go on this rocking chair."
tr: Seeing Ursula yawn from boredom, Rebeca would pretend to be angry and say, "Poor mother, she'll go to heaven with this rocking chair when she dies."
es: When she dies, she'll haunt that rocking chair. "

en: After three months of supervised love, fatigued by the slow progress of the construction, which he went to inspect every day, Pietro Crespi decided to give Father Nicanor the money he needed to finish the church.
vi: After three months of living in a love that was closely monitored, disheartened by the delays in the construction work that he visited every day, Pietro Crespi agreed to contribute the money Father Nicanor needed to complete the church building.
tr: In the third month of their supervised courtship, tired of the lack of progress in the construction, Pietro Crespi decided to give Father Nicanor the money needed to complete the church.
es: After three months of supervised love, bored with the slow construction that he inspected every day, Pietro Crespi decided to give Father Nicanor the money he needed to finish the temple.

en: Amaranta did not grow impatient.
vi: Amaranta did not lose heart.
tr: Amaranta was not worried at all.
es: Amaranta did not grow impatient.

en: As she conversed with her girl friends every afternoon when they came to embroider on the porch, she tried to think of new subterfuges.
vi: While sitting and chatting with the sisters who often came to the house in the afternoons to embroider or knit on the porch, she tried to come up with new schemes.
tr: Every day, she sat on the terrace with her friends, embroidering, talking with them, and devising new tricks.
es: While conversing with the friends who came every afternoon to embroider or knit in the corridor, she tried to conceive new tricks.

en: A mistake in calculation spoiled the one she considered the most effective: removing the mothballs that Rebeca had put in her wedding dress before she put it away in the bedroom dresser.
vi: A mistake ruined the scheme she thought was the most effective. It was the plan to steal the mothballs that Rebecca had placed in her bridal gown before storing it in the chest in the bedroom.
tr: The trick she thought would be most effective was foiled by a miscalculation: Amaranta removed the mothballs from Rebeca's wedding dress, which was stored in the console in her bedroom.
es: A miscalculation ruined what she considered the most effective: removing the mothballs that Rebeca had placed on her wedding dress before storing it in the bedroom dresser.

en: She did it when two months were left for the completion of the church.
vi: Amaranta would do it when there were less than two months left until the church construction was completed.
tr: There were two months left until the church was completed.
es: She did it when there were less than two months left for the temple's completion.

en: But Rebeca was so impatient with the approach of the wedding that she wanted to get the dress ready earlier than Amaranta had foreseen.
vi: But Rebecca was so eager for her wedding day to come that she wanted to prepare her bridal gown earlier than Amaranta had planned.
tr: However, the plan didn't go as expected, and with the wedding approaching, an increasingly impatient Rebeca decided to start preparing her wedding dress earlier than Amaranta had anticipated.
es: But Rebeca was so impatient with the proximity of the wedding that she wanted to prepare the dress earlier than Amaranta had anticipated.

en: When she opened the dresser and unfolded first the papers and then the protective cloth, she found the fabric of the dress and the stitches of the veil and even the crown of orange blossoms perforated by moths.
vi: When she opened the chest, then the wrapping paper, and finally the silk covering, she found the satin wedding dress, a veil, and an orange blossom crown, all eaten to dust by moths.
tr: When she pulled out the drawer and opened the papers and then the bundle, she saw that moths had riddled the dress, the veil's threads, and even the bridal crown made of orange blossoms with holes.
es: When she opened the dresser and first unwrapped the papers and then the protective cloth, she found the satin of the dress, the lace of the veil, and even the orange blossom crown pulverized by moths.

en: Although she was sure that she had put a handful of mothballs in the wrappings, the disaster seemed so natural that she did not dare blame Amaranta.
vi: Although she was sure she had placed two packets of mothballs wrapped in handkerchiefs in the dress, the misfortune seemed entirely accidental, so she did not dare blame Amaranta.
tr: She had no doubt that she had put handfuls of mothballs into the bundle, but this disaster was so typical that she couldn't bring herself to blame Amaranta.
es: Although she was sure she had put two handfuls of mothballs in the wrapping, the disaster seemed so accidental that she did not dare to blame Amaranta.

en: There was less than a month until the wedding, but Amparo Moscote promised to sew a new dress within a week.
vi: With less than a month until the wedding, it was no problem because she had Amparo Moscote who could sew the bridal gown in just a week.
tr: There was less than a month left until the wedding. Fortunately, Amparo Moscote promised to have a new wedding dress ready within a week.
es: There was less than a month left for the wedding, but Amparo Moscote committed to sewing a new dress in a week.

en: Amaranta felt faint that rainy noontime when Amparo came to the house wrapped in the froth of needlework for Rebeca to have the final fitting of the dress.
vi: One rainy afternoon, Amparo, wearing a raincoat, entered the house to give the final fitting of the bridal gown for Rebecca, and Amaranta felt so furious she wanted to die.
tr: On that rainy afternoon when Amparo came to do Rebeca's final fitting, Amaranta almost fainted.
es: Amaranta felt faint on the rainy noon when Amparo entered the house wrapped in a froth of lace to give Rebeca the final fitting of the dress.

en: She lost her voice and a thread of cold sweat ran down the path of her spine.
vi: Her voice faltered, and a cold sweat ran down her spine.
tr: Her breath was cut off, and cold sweat ran down her back.
es: She lost her voice, and a thread of cold sweat ran down the channel of her spine.

en: For long months she had trembled with fright waiting for that hour, because if she had not been able to conceive the ultimate obstacle to Rebeca’s wedding, she was sure that at the last moment, when all the resources of her imagination had failed, she would have the courage to poison her.
vi: For many months she had lived in anxious anticipation of that moment. Because if she did not successfully create a decisive obstacle to prevent Rebecca's wedding, she was certain that, in the final moment when all other schemes had failed, she would have the courage to poison Rebecca.
tr: For months, she had been waiting in fear for that moment to arrive. Because if the last resort to prevent Rebeca from getting married failed, she had no doubt that she would dare to poison her at the last moment.
es: For long months, she had trembled with fear awaiting that hour, because if she did not conceive the definitive obstacle to Rebeca's wedding, she was sure that at the last moment, when all the resources of her imagination had failed, she would have the courage to poison her.

en: That afternoon, while Rebeca was suffocating with heat inside the armor of thread that Amparo Moscote was putting about her body with thousands of pins and infinite patience, Amaranta made several mistakes in her crocheting and pricked her finger with the needle, but she decided with frightful coldness that the date would be the last Friday before the wedding and the method would be a dose of laudanum in her coffee.
vi: That afternoon, while Rebecca was suffocating from the heat in the satin dress being fitted by Amparo, who was calmly pinning it to fit her body, Amaranta had pricked her fingers several times with the crochet hook. But with terrifying coldness, she decided that the day to poison Rebecca would be the Friday closest to the wedding day, and the method would be a drop of opium dissolved in coffee.
tr: That day, while Rebeca, wrapped in the fabric armor that Amparo had wound around her body with thousands of pins and infinite patience, stood breathless from the heat, Amaranta lost track of her work, embroidered incorrectly, pricked her finger with a needle, but with a terrifying calmness decided that the last day would be the Friday before the wedding. She would poison Rebeca with the spirit of opium she would add to her coffee.
es: That afternoon, while Rebeca suffocated from the heat inside the satin armor that Amparo Moscote was fitting to her body with a thousand pins and infinite patience, Amaranta made several mistakes in her crochet stitches and pricked her finger with the needle, but she decided with dreadful coldness that the date would be the last Friday before the wedding, and the method would be a dose of laudanum in the coffee.

en: A greater obstacle, as impassable as it was unforeseen, obliged a new and indefinite postponement.
vi: A major obstacle, very brutal and also very unexpected, came crashing down, forcing the wedding to be postponed once again, with no idea of when it would finally take place.
tr: An unexpected and unsolvable new obstacle postponed the wedding once more and indefinitely.
es: A major obstacle, as insurmountable as it was unforeseen, forced a new and indefinite postponement.

en: One week before the date set for the wedding, little Remedios woke up in the middle of the night soaked in a hot broth which had exploded in her insides with a kind of tearing belch, and she died three days later, poisoned by her own blood, with a pair of twins crossed in her stomach.
vi: Just one week before the wedding, suddenly at midnight, Remedios woke up vomiting and having diarrhea, her body drenched in the hot, foul-smelling contents from her stomach, and after three days, she died from poisoning by her own blood, carrying a twin fetus in her womb.
tr: A week before the wedding day, little bride Remedios woke up in the middle of the night, submerged in the warmth of water that burst with a pain as if something was being torn from inside her. Three days later, she passed away from blood poisoning along with the twins lying head to toe in her womb.
es: A week before the scheduled wedding date, little Remedios woke up at midnight drenched in a hot broth that exploded in her insides with a kind of tearing burp, and died three days later poisoned by her own blood with a pair of twins lodged in her belly.

en: Amarante suffered a crisis of conscience.
vi: Amaranta tormented herself with guilt.
tr: Amaranta was writhing in guilt.
es: Amaranta suffered a crisis of conscience.

en: She had begged God with such fervor for something fearful to happen so that she would not have to poison Rebeca that she felt guilty of Remedios’ death.
vi: She had fervently prayed to God for something terrible to happen so that she wouldn't have to poison Rebeca, and thus she felt guilty for Remedios's death.
tr: She had prayed so fervently for a terrible event to occur so that she wouldn't have to poison Rebeca, that she blamed herself for Remedios' death.
es: She had prayed to God with such fervor for something dreadful to happen so she wouldn't have to poison Rebeca, that she felt guilty for Remedios' death.

en: That was not the obstacle that she had begged for so much.
vi: This was not the obstacle she had prayed for.
tr: This was not the obstacle she had desperately awaited.
es: That was not the obstacle she had prayed so much for.

en: Remedios had brought a breath of merriment to the house.
vi: Remedios had brought a new, joyful breeze into the house.
tr: Remedios had brought joy to the house.
es: Remedios had brought a breath of joy to the house.

en: She had settled down with her husband in a room near the workshop, which she decorated with the dolls and toys of her recent childhood, and her merry vitality overflowed the four walls of the bedroom and went like a whirlwind of good health along the porch with the begonias:
vi: She and her husband moved into the room next to the jewelry workshop, and she decorated their living space with all her childhood dolls and toys. Her youthful vitality spread beyond the four walls, like a refreshing breeze blowing through the corridors adorned with pots of begonias.
tr: She had decorated a room near the workshop with dolls and toys from her recent childhood and settled there with her husband. Her cheerful and lively spirit transcended the four walls of the bedroom and had become like a breeze of health on the begonia terrace.
es: She had settled with her husband in a room near the workshop, which she decorated with the dolls and toys of her recent childhood, and her cheerful vitality overflowed the four walls of the room and swept like a gust of good health through the begonia corridor.

en: She would start singing at dawn.
vi: From the moment she woke up, she would sing.
tr: She would start singing at dawn.
es: She sang from dawn.

en: She was the only person who dared intervene in the arguments between Rebeca and Amaranta.
vi: She was the only one in the house who dared to intervene in the arguments between Rebeca and Amaranta.
tr: She was the only one who dared to intervene in the fights between Rebeca and Amaranta.
es: She was the only person who dared to mediate in the disputes between Rebeca and Amaranta.

en: She plunged into the fatiguing chore of taking care of José Arcadio Buendía.
vi: She took on the responsibility of caring for José Arcadio Buendía.
tr: He had also taken care of Jose Arcadio Buendia.
es: She took on the costly task of attending to José Arcadio Buendía.

en: She would bring him his food, she would help him with his daily necessities, wash him with soap and a scrubbing brush, keep his hair and beard free of lice and nits, keep the palm shelter in good condition and reinforce it with waterproof canvas in stormy weather.
vi: She brought food to her father-in-law, diligently attended to him during his bathroom needs, bathed him with soap and scrubbing pads, kept his beard and hair free from lice, and maintained and repaired his palm-leaf hut during stormy seasons.
tr: He would bring him his food, help him with his daily needs, wash and brush his hands and face, pick out the lice and fleas from his hair and beard, and if the weather turned bad, he would reinforce the shelter made of palm leaves with a canvas.
es: She brought him food, assisted him in his daily needs, washed him with soap and scrub, kept his hair and beard free of lice and nits, maintained the palm shed in good condition, and reinforced it with waterproof tarps during stormy times.

en: In her last months she had succeeded in communicating with him in phrases of rudimentary Latin.
vi: In the final months of her life, she communicated with him using simple Latin phrases.
tr: In recent months, he had picked up Latin and had even started to speak broken Latin with Jose Arcadio.
es: In her last months, she had managed to communicate with him in rudimentary Latin phrases.

en: When the son of Aureliano and Pilar Ternera was born and brought to the house and baptized in an intimate ceremony with the name Aureliano José, Remedios decided that he would be considered their oldest child.
vi: When Aureliano's son with Pilar Ternera was born, brought home, and named Aureliano José, Remedios decided to acknowledge the boy as her own firstborn.
tr: When Pilar Ternera's son, born of Aureliano, was brought home and baptized with the name Aureliano Jose in a ceremony held among the family, Remedios decided to embrace him as her first child.
es: When the son of Aureliano and Pilar Ternera was born and brought to the house and baptized in an intimate ceremony with the name Aureliano José, Remedios decided he should be considered her eldest son.

en: Her maternal instinct surprised Úrsula.
vi: Her maternal affection greatly surprised Úrsula.
tr: Her maternal instinct surprised Ursula.
es: Her maternal instinct surprised Úrsula.
