en: Aureliano, for his part, found in her the justification that he needed to live.
vi: For his part, Aureliano found in her the essential justification for his life.
tr: As for Aureliano, the sole meaning and purpose of his life had become his wife:
es: Aureliano, for his part, found in her the justification he needed to live.

en: He worked all day in his workshop and Remedios would bring him a cup of black coffee in the middle of the morning.
vi: He worked all day in the workshop, and Remedios would bring him a cup of unsweetened coffee in the middle of the morning.
tr: He worked in his workshop all day, and around noon, Remedios would bring him his coffee.
es: He worked all day in the workshop and Remedios brought him a bowl of unsweetened coffee mid-morning.

en: They would both visit the Moscotes every night.
vi: Every night, they would visit the Moscotes.
tr: Every evening, they would go together to the Moscotes' house.
es: They both visited the Moscotes every night.

en: Aureliano would play endless games of dominoes with his father-in-law while Remedios chatted with her sisters or talked to her mother about more important things.
vi: Aureliano would engross himself in playing dominoes with his father-in-law while Remedios chatted cheerfully with her sisters-in-law and discussed adult matters with her mother.
tr: Aureliano would engage in endless domino games with his father-in-law, while Remedios would chat with her sisters or consult her mother on more important matters.
es: Aureliano played endless games of dominoes with his father-in-law, while Remedios conversed with her sisters or dealt with adult matters with her mother.

en: The link with the Buendías consolidated Don Apolinar Moscote’s authority in the town.
vi: The close relationship with the Buendía family strengthened Don Apolinar Moscote's authority in the village.
tr: Becoming related to the Buendia family had solidified Don Apolinar Moscote's respectability in the village.
es: The bond with the Buendía family consolidated the authority of don Apolinar Moscote in the town.

en: On frequent trips to the capital of the province he succeeded in getting the government to build a school so that Arcadio, who had inherited the educational enthusiasm of his grandfather, could take charge of it.
vi: During his frequent trips to the provincial capital, he had secured government approval to open a school, which was managed by Arcadio, who had inherited his grandfather's passion for teaching.
tr: By frequently traveling to the capital, he managed to get the government to take action and succeeded in having a school built, which would be headed by Arcadio, who had inherited his grandfather's passion for teaching.
es: In frequent trips to the provincial capital, he managed to get the government to build a school for Arcadio to run, who had inherited his grandfather's educational enthusiasm.

en: Through persuasion he managed to get the majority of houses painted blue in time for the date of national independence.
vi: Through persuasive measures, he managed to get most of the houses in the village painted blue to celebrate Independence Day.
tr: With sweet talk, he persuaded the villagers to paint most of the houses blue for the national independence day.
es: He persuaded most of the houses to be painted blue for the national independence celebration.

en: At the urging of Father Nicanor, he arranged for the transfer of Catarino’s store to a back street and he closed down several scandalous establishments that prospered in the center of town.
vi: In response to Father Nicanor's suggestions, he decided to relocate Catarino's eatery to a secluded street and shut down several noisy establishments that had sprung up in the village center.
tr: Under the pressure of Father Nicanor, he had Catarino's shop moved to a back street and closed down the dens of iniquity that had opened in the heart of the village.
es: At the urging of Father Nicanor, he arranged for Catarino's shop to be moved to a remote street and closed several scandalous places that thrived in the town center.

en: Once he returned with six policemen armed with rifles to whom he entrusted the maintenance of order, and no one remembered the original agreement not to have armed men in the town.
vi: On one of his trips back from the provincial capital, he brought along six armed policemen. These were the men he entrusted with maintaining order. However, no one reminded him of his promise to José Arcadio Buendía that he would not use armed police in the village.
tr: On his trips to the capital, he brought armed mounted police to ensure security; no one even remembered the initial agreement not to allow armed men into the village.
es: Once he returned with six policemen armed with rifles to maintain order, without anyone remembering the original commitment not to have armed people in the town.

en: Aureliano enjoyed his father-in-law’s efficiency.
vi: Aureliano was very fond of his resourceful father-in-law.
tr: Aureliano was pleased with his father-in-law's dominance.
es: Aureliano was pleased with his father-in-law's efficiency.

en: “You’re going to get as fat as he is,” his friends would say to him.
vi: "You'll end up as plump as he is," his friends told him.
tr: His friends teased him, saying, "You'll get as fat as he is."
es: " You're going to get as fat as he is," his friends told him.

en: But his sedentary life, which accentuated his cheekbones and concentrated the sparkle of his eyes, did not increase his weight or alter the parsimony of his character, but, on the contrary, it hardened on his lips the straight line of solitary meditation and implacable decision.
vi: But the leisure that had once puffed up his cheeks and concentrated the light in his eyes did not increase his body weight nor did it disrupt his pride; on the contrary, it only accentuated the lines on his lips, a sign of deep thought and unshakable determination.
tr: However, the monotonous life that made his cheekbones more prominent and intensified the sparkle in his eyes did not make him gain weight; instead, it deepened the thoughtful line at the corner of his lips and the expression of determination.
es: But the sedentary lifestyle, which accentuated his cheekbones and concentrated the glow in his eyes, did not increase his weight nor alter the calmness of his character, and on the contrary, it hardened the straight line of solitary meditation and implacable decision on his lips.

en: So deep was the affection that he and his wife had succeeded in arousing in both their families that when Remedios announced that she was going to have a child.
vi: The deep affection between him and his wife awakened the feelings of both families to such an extent that when Remedios announced she was pregnant, even Rebeca and Amaranta reconciled to weave a blue linen if it was a boy and a pink linen if it was a girl.
tr: They had endeared themselves so much to both the boy's and the girl's side that when Remedios announced she was going to have a child, even Rebeca and Amaranta set aside their quarrels and grievances and took up knitting, blue if it was a boy and pink if it was a girl.
es: So deep was the affection that he and his wife had managed to awaken in both families, that when Remedios announced she was going to have a child, even Rebeca and Amaranta made a truce to knit in blue wool, in case it was a boy, and in pink wool, in case it was a girl.

en: even Rebeca and Amaranta declared a truce in order to knit items in blue wool if it was to be a boy and in pink wool in case it was a girl.
vi: The deep affection between him and his wife awakened the feelings of both families to such an extent that when Remedios announced she was pregnant, even Rebeca and Amaranta reconciled to weave a blue linen if it was a boy and a pink linen if it was a girl.
tr: They had endeared themselves so much to both the boy's and the girl's side that when Remedios announced she was going to have a child, even Rebeca and Amaranta set aside their quarrels and grievances and took up knitting, blue if it was a boy and pink if it was a girl.
es: So deep was the affection that he and his wife had managed to awaken in both families, that when Remedios announced she was going to have a child, even Rebeca and Amaranta made a truce to knit in blue wool, in case it was a boy, and in pink wool, in case it was a girl.

en: She was the last person Arcadio thought about a few years later when he faced the firing squad.
vi: She was the last person Arcadio thought of a few years later when he stood before the firing squad.
tr: A few years later, while standing before the firing squad, the last person to cross Arcadio's mind was Remedios.
es: She was the last person Arcadio thought of, a few years later, in front of the firing squad.

en: Úrsula ordered a mourning period of closed doors and windows, with no one entering or leaving except on matters of utmost necessity.
vi: Ursula decided to mourn her for a year.
tr: Ursula declared mourning by locking the windows and doors, and she did not allow anyone to enter or leave the house unless it was very important.
es: Úrsula arranged a mourning period with doors and windows closed, no entry or exit for anyone except for indispensable matters; she forbade speaking out loud for a year, and placed the daguerreotype of Remedios in the spot where the body was laid out, with a black ribbon across it and an oil lamp lit forever.

en: She prohibited any talking aloud for a year and she put Remedios’ daguerreotype in the place where her body had been laid out, with a black ribbon around it and an oil lamp that was always kept lighted.
vi: She ordered all the doors to be closed, no one to enter or leave except in unavoidable circumstances, forbade loud talking, and personally hung Remedios' picture at the place where her body was laid out, placing an oil lamp that would burn continuously in front of the picture.
tr: She banned speaking loudly for a year and placed a photograph of Remedios, tied with a black ribbon, and an oil lamp that was never extinguished at the head of her bed.
es: Úrsula arranged a mourning period with doors and windows closed, no entry or exit for anyone except for indispensable matters; she forbade speaking out loud for a year, and placed the daguerreotype of Remedios in the spot where the body was laid out, with a black ribbon across it and an oil lamp lit forever.

en: Future generations, who never let the lamp go out, would be puzzled at that girl in a pleated skirt, white boots, and with an organdy band around her head, and they were never able to connect her with the standard image of a great-grandmother.
vi: Future generations, who never let the oil lamp go out, were puzzled by the picture of the girl in a puffed dress, white boots, and a bow in her hair, unable to reconcile that image with their own imagination of an aunt.
tr: The later generations who kept the lamp burning without ever extinguishing it would look long and hard at the picture of this girl in a pleated skirt, white boots, and an organza ribbon in her hair, unable to reconcile it with the image of a typical great-great-grandmother.
es: Future generations, who never let the lamp go out, would be puzzled by that girl with ruffled skirts, white boots, and an organdy bow in her hair, whom they could not reconcile with the academic image of a great-grandmother.

en: Amaranta took charge of Aureliano José.
vi: Amaranta took in Aureliano José and raised him as her own son.
tr: Amaranta took on the care of Aureliano Jose.
es: Amaranta took charge of Aureliano José.

en: She adopted him as a son who would share her solitude and relieve her from the involutary laudanum that her mad beseeching had thrown into Remedios’ coffee.
vi: He would be the one to share her loneliness and console her from the torment of her fervent prayers that had inadvertently caused the opium to fall into Remedios' coffee.
tr: She embraced him like a son who would share her loneliness and save her from the torment of having caused Remedios' death with her frantic prayers.
es: She adopted him as a son who would share her solitude and relieve her of the involuntary laudanum that her frantic supplications had poured into Remedios' coffee.

en: Pietro Crespi would tiptoe in at dusk, with a black ribbon on his hat, and he would pay a silent visit to Rebeca, who seemed to be bleeding to death inside the black dress with sleeves down to her wrists.
vi: In the evenings, Pietro Crespi, wearing a mourning band on his hat, would tiptoe into the house to quietly visit Rebeca, a Rebeca who seemed to be bleeding out in her black dress with sleeves that covered the backs of her hands.
tr: In the afternoons, Pietro Crespi would come, tiptoeing in his black ribboned hat, to check on Rebeca, whose heart was bleeding in her long-sleeved black dress.
es: Pietro Crespi would tiptoe in at dusk, with a black ribbon on his hat, and pay a silent visit to a Rebeca who seemed to be bleeding out inside the black dress with sleeves down to her wrists.

en: Just the idea of thinking about a new date for the wedding would have been so irreverent that the engagement turned into an eternal relationship, a fatigued love that no one worried about again, as if the lovers, who in other days had sabotaged the lamps in order to kiss, had been abandoned to the free will of death.
vi: The mere thought of rescheduling the wedding was already considered highly improper, thus their romantic relationship became an eternal one, a weary love that no one wanted to tend to, as if the lovers who had turned off the lights to kiss in the dark had drifted apart by the will of death.
tr: Even thinking about setting a new date for the wedding seemed like such a great disrespect that their engagement turned into an endless relationship. The days when they played various games to turn off the lamps just to kiss were long gone; their love had now been abandoned to death, a breathless romance that no one cared about anymore.
es: The mere idea of thinking about a new date for the wedding would have been so irreverent that the engagement turned into an eternal relationship, a love of exhaustion that no one cared for anymore, as if the lovers who once disassembled lamps to kiss had been abandoned to the whim of death.

en: Having lost her bearings, completely demoralized, Rebeca began eating earth again.
vi: Completely disoriented and having lost her sanity, Rebeca began eating earth again.
tr: Having lost all her hope and all her supports, Rebeca started eating soil again.
es: Lost and completely demoralized, Rebeca went back to eating earth.

en: Suddenly—when the mourning had gone on so long that the needlepoint sessions began again—someone pushed open the street door at two in the afternoon in the mortal silence of the heat and the braces in the foundation shook with such force that Amaranta and her friends sewing on the porch, Rebeca sucking her finger in her bedroom, Úrsula in the kitchen, Aureliano in the workshop, and even José Arcadio Buendía under the solitary chestnut tree had the impression that an earthquake was breaking up the house.
vi: The mourning had been going on for quite some time, to the point where the family had to reorganize the prayer sessions at home. At two in the afternoon on a quiet, unbearably hot day, someone suddenly pushed open the door leading to the main road, causing the doors to creak with such force that it shook the entire house where Amaranta and her friends were sitting and embroidering in the hallway, Rebeca was sucking her thumb in the bedroom, Úrsula was busy in the kitchen, Aureliano was diligently working in the goldsmith's workshop, and José Arcadio Buendía was sitting alone under the chestnut tree; everyone felt a shiver as if there was an earthquake.
tr: One completely unexpected day -the mourning had lasted so long that the lacework sessions had started again- at noon, when the heat descended with a deadly fervor, someone slammed the street door wide open, and the house shook to its very foundations. Amaranta, who was embroidering with her friends on the terrace, Rebeca, who was sucking her finger in the bedroom, Ursula in the kitchen, Aureliano in his workshop, and even Jose Arcadio Buendia under the chestnut tree, all thought there was an earthquake and the house was collapsing on top of them.
es: Suddenly —when the mourning had lasted so long that the cross-stitch sessions had already resumed— someone pushed the street door at two in the afternoon, in the deadly silence of the heat, and the beams trembled with such force in the foundations that Amaranta and her friends embroidering in the corridor, Rebeca sucking her thumb in the bedroom, Úrsula in the kitchen, Aureliano in the workshop, and even José Arcadio Buendía under the solitary chestnut tree, had the impression that an earthquake was unsettling the house.

en: A huge man had arrived.
vi: A burly man came to the house.
tr: A burly man had arrived.
es: A colossal man was arriving.

en: His square shoulders barely fitted through the doorways.
vi: His broad back seemed too large to fit through the door.
tr: His broad shoulders couldn't fit through the doors.
es: His square shoulders barely fit through the doors.

en: He was wearing a medal of Our Lady of Help around his bison neck, his arms and chest were completely covered with cryptic tattooing, and on his right wrist was the tight copper bracelet of the niños-en-cruz amulet.
vi: Around his neck, he wore a chain with a medallion of Saint Remedios the Virgin. His chest and arms were covered in tattoos of cemetery images. On his wrist, he wore a bronze statue of the crucified Jesus.
tr: On his thick neck, reminiscent of wild bulls, hung a Madonna medallion for good luck. His arms and chest were covered with indistinguishable tattoos. On his right wrist, there was a copper bracelet with a ninos-en-cruz amulet hanging from it.
es: He had a small medallion of the Virgin of Remedies hanging on his bison neck, his arms and chest completely embroidered with cryptic tattoos, and on his right wrist the tight copper bracelet of the children-on-the-cross.

en: His skin was tanned by the salt of the open air, his hair was short and straight like the mane of a mule, his jaws were of iron, and he wore a sad smile.
vi: He had weather-beaten dark skin, short and shaggy hair like a mule's mane, a strong, protruding jaw, and sad eyes.
tr: His skin was tanned from being outdoors. His hair was very short and smooth like a mule's mane. He had a strong and large chin. He was smiling sadly.
es: His skin was tanned by the salt of the outdoors, his hair short and cropped like a mule's mane, his jaws ironclad, and his gaze sad.

en: He had a belt on that was twice as thick as the cinch of a horse, boots with leggings and spurs and iron on the heels, and his presence gave the quaking impression of a seismic tremor.
vi: His belt was twice as thick as a horse's rein. His short boots had spurs and were reinforced with iron. And his presence gave everyone the shiver of an impending earthquake.
tr: The belt around his waist was twice as thick as a horse's girth. He wore boots with knee pads and iron-tipped spurs. He made the ground shake with his steps, as if the earth trembled when he walked.
es: He had a belt twice as thick as a horse's girth, boots with gaiters and spurs, and with ironed heels, and his presence gave the tremulous impression of a seismic shake.

en: He went through the parlor and the living room, carrying some half-worn saddlebags in his hand, and he appeared like a thunderclap on the porch with the begonias where Amaranta and her friends were paralyzed, their needles in the air.
vi: He walked through the living room, then the waiting room, carrying old bags in his hands. Then, like a thunderclap, he appeared in the hallway where the begonias were placed, where Amaranta and her friends, who were sewing, were so startled that they raised their hands holding the needles.
tr: He swung his worn-out saddlebags as he walked across the living room and the sitting room. He burst into the begonia terrace where Amaranta and her friends froze with needles in hand, as if struck by lightning.
es: He crossed the living room and the sitting room, carrying in his hand some half-destroyed saddlebags, and appeared like thunder in the corridor of begonias, where Amaranta and her friends were paralyzed with their needles in the air.

en: “Hello,” he said to them in a tired voice, threw the saddlebags on a worktable, and went by on his way to the back of the house.
vi: "Hello," he said to the girls in a tired voice, then threw the bags onto the desk. After that, he hurriedly walked into the inner house.
tr: In a tired voice, he said hello to the girls, placed the saddlebags on the table, and walked towards the back of the house.
es: “Hello,” he said to them with a tired voice, and threw the saddlebags on the work table and passed by towards the back of the house.

en: “Hello,” he said to the startled Rebecca, who saw him pass by the door of her bedroom.
vi: "Hello," he said to Rebeca, who was looking at him in panic as he passed by the bedroom window.
tr: He also said hello to Rebeca, who was surprised to see him passing by her bedroom.
es: “Hello,” he said to the frightened Rebeca who saw him pass by her bedroom door.

en: “Hello,” he said to Aureliano, who was at his silversmith’s bench with all five senses alert.
vi: "Hello," he said to Aureliano in the jewelry workshop, who was straining all five senses to listen.
tr: He waved a hello to Aurelio, who was sitting on pins and needles in the silver workshop.
es: “Hello,” he said to Aureliano, who was with all five senses alert at the goldsmith's bench.

en: He did not linger with anyone.
vi: He went straight into the kitchen, and here for the first time, he paused at the end of a journey around the world.
tr: He didn't linger with anyone.
es: He did not linger with anyone.

en: He went directly to the kitchen and there he stopped for the first time at the end of a trip that had begun of the other side of the world.
vi: He went straight into the kitchen, and here for the first time, he paused at the end of a journey around the world.
tr: He went straight to the kitchen and, for the first time since the beginning of his journey from the other end of the world, took a break.
es: He went directly to the kitchen, and there he stopped for the first time at the end of a journey that had started on the other side of the world.

en: “Hello,” he said.
vi: "Hello," he said.
tr: Hello, he said.
es: “Hello,” he said.

en: Úrsula stood for a fraction of a second with her mouth open, looked into his eyes, gave a cry, and flung her arms around his neck, shouting and weeping with joy.
vi: Ursula stood still for a second, her mouth agape, staring straight into his eyes. She let out a cry and then jumped up to hug his neck, crying and shouting with joy.
tr: Ursula stood there for a moment with her mouth open, looked into his eyes, screamed, and then hugged him around the neck, crying with joy.
es: Úrsula stayed with her mouth open for a fraction of a second, looked him in the eyes, screamed and jumped to his neck, shouting and crying with joy.

en: It was José Arcadio.
vi: It was José Arcadio.
tr: It was Jose Arcadio.
es: It was José Arcadio.

en: He was returning as poor as when he had left, to such an extreme that Úrsula had to give him two pesos to pay for the rental of his horse.
vi: He returned as poor as when he left, to the point that Ursula had to give him two pesos to pay for the horse rental.
tr: He had returned penniless, just as he had left. Ursula even had to pay for the horse he had rented.
es: He returned as poor as he had left, to the extent that Úrsula had to give him two pesos to pay for the horse's rental.

en: He spoke a Spanish that was larded with sailor slang.
vi: He spoke Spanish mixed with sailor slang.
tr: He spoke Spanish mixed with sailor's slang.
es: He spoke Spanish mixed with sailor's jargon.

en: They asked where he had been and he answered: “Out there.”
vi: When people asked him where he had been, he answered, "Over there."
tr: When they asked him where he had been, he replied, "Way over there. "
es: They asked him where he had been, and he answered: “Around.

en: He hung his hammock in the room they assigned him and slept for three days.
vi: He hung a hammock in the room reserved for him and slept for three days straight.
tr: He set up his hammock in the room given to him and slept for three days and three nights.
es: ”He hung the hammock in the room they assigned to him and slept for three days.

en: When he woke up, after eating sixteen raw eggs, he went directly to Catarino’s store, where his monumental size provoked a panic of curiosity among the women.
vi: When he woke up, after eating sixteen boiled eggs, he went straight to Catarino's eatery. There, his massive body sparked lively and curious discussions among the women.
tr: When he woke up, after swallowing sixteen raw eggs one after another, he headed straight to Catarino's shop. The women who saw his gigantic figure were instantly filled with curiosity.
es: When he woke up, and after drinking sixteen raw eggs, he went straight to Catarino's store, where his monumental bulk provoked a panic of curiosity among the women.

en: He called for music and cane liquor for everyone, to be put on his bill.
vi: He organized a party with music and strong liquor for everyone.
tr: Jose Arcadio ordered music to be played and treated everyone to cane liquor.
es: He ordered music and liquor for everyone at his expense.

en: He would Indian-wrestle with five men at the same time.
vi: He challenged five men to arm wrestle him simultaneously.
tr: He was also saying that he would wrestle with five people at once.
es: He arm-wrestled five men at the same time.

en: “It can’t be done,” they said, convinced that they would not be able to move his arm.
vi: "No way," they said when they realized they couldn't budge his arm, "because you have the crucified Jesus helping you"...
tr: The people there, realizing that they couldn't even bend his arm, let alone bring him down, dismissed it saying, "No way."
es: “It's impossible,” they said, convinced that they couldn't move his arm.

en: “He has niños-en-cruz.”
vi: Catarino, who still didn't believe in his strength, bet him twelve pesos if he could lift his counter.
tr: He was wearing a Ninos-en-cruz amulet.
es: “He has children-on-the-cross.

en: Catarino, who did not believe in magical tricks of strength, bet him twelve pesos that he could not move the counter.
vi: Catarino, who still didn't believe in his strength, bet him twelve pesos if he could lift his counter.
tr: Catarino, who didn't believe in gaining strength through amulets or magic, bet twelve pesos that he couldn't move the counter.
es: ”Catarino, who didn't believe in feats of strength, bet twelve pesos that he couldn't move the counter.

en: José Arcadio pulled it out of its place, lifted it over his head, and put it in the street.
vi: José Arcadio lifted the counter, balanced it on his head, and carried it out to the middle of the street.
tr: Jose Arcadio lifted the counter, carried it over his head, and placed it in the middle of the street.
es: José Arcadio ripped it from its place, lifted it over his head, and put it out on the street.

en: It took eleven men to put it back.
vi: It took eleven strong men to carry it back to its original place.
tr: It took eleven people, sweating profusely, to put the counter back in its place.
es: It took eleven men to bring it back in.

en: In the heat of the party he exhibited his unusual masculinity on the bar, completely covered with tattoos of words in several languages intertwined in blue and red.
vi: In the lively, festive atmosphere, José Arcadio stood on the counter, showing off his muscular body covered in tattoos with blue and red writing in various languages.
tr: Just as the fun was reaching its peak, Jose Arcadio revealed and displayed his unprecedented mark, covered in red and blue tattoos in various languages.
es: In the heat of the party, he displayed on the counter his unbelievable masculinity, entirely tattooed with a blue and red tangle of inscriptions in various languages.

en: To the women who were besieging him and coveting him he put the question as to who would pay the most.
vi: Turning to the women surrounding him, with insatiable greed, he asked who would pay more.
tr: He told the women clinging to him that he would stay with whoever gave him the most money.
es: To the women who besieged him with their greed, he asked who paid more.

en: The one who had the most money offered him twenty pesos.
vi: The wealthiest woman gave him several dozen pesos.
tr: The wealthiest among them gave twenty pesos.
es: The one who had the most offered twenty pesos.

en: Then he proposed raffling himself off among them at ten pesos a chance.
vi: So he organized a raffle with tickets costing ten pesos each.
tr: Upon this, Jose Arcadio suggested that the women each give ten pesos and draw lots for him.
es: Then he proposed to raffle himself among all at ten pesos a number.

en: It was a fantastic price because the most sought-after woman earned eight pesos a night, but they all accepted.
vi: It was an exorbitant price because the most popular woman could only earn eight pesos a night. But all the women accepted the price.
tr: This was an unprecedented fee, because even the most successful woman would earn at most eight pesos a night. Nevertheless, they accepted the proposal.
es: It was an exorbitant price, because the most sought-after woman earned eight pesos in a night, but they all accepted.

en: They wrote their names on fourteen pieces of paper which they put into a hat and each woman took one out.
vi: They wrote their names on fourteen tickets, mixed them up, put them all in a hat, and then each woman drew a ticket.
tr: They wrote their names on fourteen pieces of paper and put them into a hat. Each woman drew a lot.
es: They wrote their names on fourteen slips of paper that they put in a hat, and each woman drew one.

en: When there were only two pieces left to draw, it was established to whom they belonged.
vi: When only two tickets were left, he approached the women who were about to draw.
tr: When only two pieces of paper remained, it was already clear to whom they belonged.
es: When only two slips were left to draw, it was established to whom they belonged.

en: “Five pesos more from each one,” José Arcadio proposed, “and I’ll share myself with both.
vi: - Pay an extra five dollars per ticket, - José Arcadio urged, - and then I'll split it between the two of you.
tr: Jose Arcadio, "Both of you cough up another five each, and I'll stay with both of you," he said.
es: —Five more pesos each —proposed José Arcadio— and I'll split myself between both of you.

en: He made his living that way.
vi: He lived that way.
tr: He was earning his bread in this way.
es: That was how he made a living.

en: He had been around the world sixty-five times, enlisted in a crew of sailors without a country.
vi: He had circled the earth sixty-five times, living with exiled sailors.
tr: He had mingled with homeless sailors and had circled the globe exactly sixty-five times.
es: He had circled the globe sixty-five times, enlisted in a crew of stateless sailors.

en: The women who went to bed with him that night in Catarino’s store brought him naked into the dance salon so that people could see that there was not a square inch of his body that was not tattooed, front and back, and from his neck to his toes.
vi: The women who slept with him that night in Catarino's shop had taken him stark naked to the dance hall so everyone could see his body, not a single millimeter without a tattoo: tattoos in the front, tattoos in the back, tattoos from his neck down to his toes.
tr: That night, the women he slept with at Catarino's shop stripped him naked in the middle of the night and took him down to the dance hall, showing that from his neck to his toes, both front and back, he was covered in tattoos with no space left for even a pin to prick.
es: The women who slept with him that night in Catarino's tent took him naked to the dance hall so that everyone could see that he didn't have a millimeter of his body without a tattoo, front and back, from his neck to his toes.

en: He did not succeed in becoming incorporated into the family.
vi: He could not integrate into family life.
tr: Jose Arcadio could not mix with the family.
es: He couldn't integrate into the family.

en: He slept all day and spent the night in the red-light district, making bets on his strength.
vi: He slept all day, and at night he stayed up gambling and testing his strength in the poor worker's neighborhood.
tr: He would sleep soundly all day and go to the red-light district at night, betting on his strength.
es: He slept all day and spent the night in the red-light district performing feats of strength.

en: On the rare occasions when Úrsula got him to sit down at the table, he gave signs of radiant good humor, especially when he told about his adventures in remote countries.
vi: On rare occasions, Úrsula managed to get him to sit at the dinner table. He came across as a likable person, especially when recounting his adventurous tales in distant lands.
tr: On the days when Ursula could coax him to sit at the table, he would cheerfully recount his adventures in distant lands.
es: On the rare occasions when Úrsula managed to get him to sit at the table, he showed a radiant charm, especially when recounting his adventures in distant lands.

en: He had been shipwrecked and spent two weeks adrift in the Sea of Japan, feeding on the body of a comrade who had succumbed to sunstroke and whose extremely salty flesh as it cooked in the sun had a sweet and granular taste.
vi: He had been shipwrecked and drifted for several weeks on the Japanese sea, surviving by eating the salted and sun-cooked flesh of a friend who had died of sunstroke, which had turned into a sweet-tasting jerky.
tr: Once, their ship had wrecked, and they had stayed on a raft in the Sea of Japan for two weeks, surviving by eating their friends who had died from sunstroke and whose flesh, cooked by the sun, tasted somewhat bitter and somewhat sweet.
es: He had shipwrecked and spent two weeks adrift in the Sea of Japan, feeding on the body of a companion who succumbed to sunstroke, whose salted and re-salted flesh, cooked in the sun, had a grainy and sweet taste.

en: Under a bright noonday sun in the Gulf of Bengal his ship had killed a sea dragon, in the stomach of which they found the helmet, the buckles, and the weapons of a Crusader.
vi: One scorching afternoon in the Bay of Bengal, his ship defeated a sea dragon, inside which they found a helmet, belt buckles, and the weapons of an ocean explorer.
tr: On a hot afternoon in the Bay of Bengal, their boat struck and killed a sea dragon, and when they cut open the dragon's belly, they found a crusader's helmet, metal buckles, and weapons.
es: On a radiant midday in the Bay of Bengal, his ship had defeated a sea dragon in whose belly they found the helmet, buckles, and weapons of a crusader.

en: In the Caribbean he had seen the ghost of the pirate ship of Victor Hugues, with its sails torn by the winds of death, the masts chewed by sea worms, and still looking for the course to Guadeloupe.
vi: In the Caribbean Sea, he had seen the ghost of the pirate Victor Hugo's ship, with its tattered sail and worm-eaten hull, forever lost on its way to the island of Guadeloupe.
tr: In the Caribbean Sea, he had seen Victor Hugues' ghost ship, whose sails had been torn by death, whose masts had been gnawed by worms, still trying to find its way to Guadeloupe.
es: He had seen in the Caribbean the ghost of Victor Hugues' corsair ship, with sails torn by the winds of death, the rigging gnawed by sea cockroaches, and forever lost on the course to Guadeloupe.

en: Úrsula would weep at the table as if she were reading the letters that had never arrived and in which José Arcadio told about his deeds and misadventures.
vi: Sitting at the table, Úrsula sobbed as if she were reading letters never sent to her, in which José Arcadio recounted his triumphs and failures.
tr: As Jose Arcadio recounted these tales, Ursula would cry as if reading letters from her son in exile that had never arrived, saying, "Here you had a place above our heads, my son."
es: Úrsula cried at the table as if she were reading the letters that never arrived, in which José Arcadio recounted his exploits and misadventures.

en: “And there was so much of a home here for you, my son,” she would sob, “and so much food thrown to the hogs!”
vi: "Here, the houses are so spacious, my child," she wept, "and there's so much food that we have to throw it to the pigs. But you're never home for me to rely on..."
tr: She would lament, "I always gave the meals I set aside for you to the pigs!"
es: “And so much house here, my son,” she sobbed. “And so much food thrown to the pigs!

en: But underneath it an she could not conceive that the boy the gypsies took away was the same lout who would eat half a suckling pig for lunch and whose flatulence withered the flowers.
vi: Yet deep down, she couldn't accept that the boy taken away by the gypsies had become this crude man who devoured half a suckling pig at lunch and whose hot breath withered the plants.
tr: Yet she could not wholeheartedly believe that this giant of a man, who could devour half a pig in one sitting and still seem unfazed, was the same person as the young man kidnapped by the gypsies.
es: ”But deep down, she couldn't conceive that the boy taken by the gypsies was the same brute who ate half a piglet at lunch and whose flatulence withered the flowers.

en: Something similar took place with the rest of the family.
vi: The other family members thought similarly of him.
tr: The other family members shared more or less the same feelings.
es: Something similar happened to the rest of the family.

en: Amaranta could not conceal the repugnance that she felt at the table because of his bestial belching.
vi: Amaranta couldn't hide her disgust whenever he burped at the table.
tr: Amaranta did not hide her disgust at his animal-like belching at the table.
es: Amaranta couldn't hide the disgust his bestial belches caused her at the table.

en: Arcadio, who never knew the secret of their relationship, scarcely answered the questions that he asked with the obvious idea of gaining his affection.
vi: Arcadio, who never knew of his father-son relationship with José Arcadio, barely responded to his attempts to win his son's affection.
tr: Arcadio, who knew nothing of the true nature of their bond, would dismissively answer his questions, which were meant to win his affection.
es: Arcadio, who never knew the secret of his parentage, barely answered the questions he asked with the evident purpose of winning his affections.

en: Aureliano tried to relive the times when they slept in the same room, tried to revive the complicity of childhood, but José Arcadio had forgotten about it, because life at sea had saturated his memory with too many things to remember.
vi: Aureliano tried to revive the old days when they shared a room and reminisced about their childhood pranks, but José Arcadio had forgotten everything, as his sailor's life, filled with countless memories, had saturated his mind.
tr: Aureliano was trying to relive the days when they slept in the same room, to recall childhood memories. However, Jose Arcadio, whose mind was filled with a multitude of memories from his days at sea, had long forgotten his childhood.
es: Aureliano tried to revive the times when they slept in the same room, tried to restore the complicity of childhood, but José Arcadio had forgotten them because the life at sea had saturated his memory with too many things to remember.

en: Only Rebeca succumbed to the first impact.
vi: Only Rebeca submitted to him from the very first moment.
tr: The only one who couldn't shake off the impact of seeing him for the first time was Rebeca.
es: Only Rebeca succumbed to the first impact.

en: The day that she saw him pass by her bedroom she thought that Pietro Crespi was a sugary dandy next to that protomale whose volcanic breathing could be heard all over the house.
vi: That afternoon, seeing him pass by her window, she thought Pietro Crespi was just a plump man compared to the extremely robust José Arcadio, whose volcanic breath filled the house.
tr: The day Rebeca saw him passing by the bedroom, she thought that next to this symbol of masculinity, whose presence was felt in every corner of the house like a volcano about to erupt, Pietro Crespi seemed like a delicate dandy.
es: The afternoon she saw him pass in front of her bedroom, she thought Pietro Crespi was a dandy weakling compared to that prime male whose volcanic breath was felt throughout the house.

en: She tried to get near him under any pretext.
vi: She found excuses to be near him.
tr: She tried to get close to Jose Arcadio at every opportunity.
es: She sought his proximity with any excuse.

en: On a certain occasion José Arcadio looked at her body with shameless attention and said to her “You’re a woman, little sister.”
vi: There were times when José Arcadio shamelessly ogled her body and said, "You are very womanly, my dear."
tr: Once, Jose Arcadio looked her up and down with a brazen gaze and said, "You've become quite a woman, sister.
es: On one occasion, José Arcadio looked at her body with blatant attention and said, “You are very much a woman, little sister.

en: Rebeca lost control of herself.
vi: Rebeca could no longer control herself.
tr: "Rebeca couldn't control herself anymore.
es: ”Rebeca lost control of herself.

en: She went back to eating earth and the whitewash on the walls with the avidity of previous days, and she sucked her finger with so much anxiety that she developed a callus on her thumb.
vi: She resumed eating earth and wall lime with the same craving as before and sucked her thumb until it became calloused.
tr: With the fervor of old days, she started eating dirt again, tearing off and swallowing the plaster from the walls. She sucked her finger so persistently that it eventually became calloused.
es: She went back to eating earth and lime from the walls with the avidity of old days, and sucked her thumb with such anxiety that a callus formed on it.

en: She vomited up a green liquid with dead leeches in it.
vi: She vomited a green liquid mixed with clotted blood.
tr: She was bringing up a green bile in which leech larvae swam.
es: She vomited a green liquid with dead leeches.

en: She spent nights awake shaking with fever, fighting against delirium, waiting until the house shook with the return of José Arcadio at dawn.
vi: All night she lay awake, trembling with fever, battling her longing, waiting for dawn; the whole house shook with José Arcadio's footsteps as he returned.
tr: Burning with fever throughout the nights, she tried to stay conscious while waiting for Jose Arcadio's return, which shook the house at dawn.
es: She spent sleepless nights shivering with fever, fighting delirium, waiting until the house trembled with José Arcadio's return at dawn.

en: One afternoon, when everyone was having a siesta, she could no longer resist and went to his bedroom.
vi: One afternoon, while the whole family was taking a nap, she couldn't bear it any longer and sneaked into José Arcadio's bedroom.
tr: One afternoon, when everyone was taking a siesta, she couldn't stand it any longer and went to Jose Arcadio's room.
es: One afternoon, when everyone was napping, she couldn't resist any longer and went to his bedroom.

en: She found him in his shorts, lying in the hammock that he had hung from the beams with a ship’s hawser.
vi: She saw him awake, wearing shorts, lying on a hammock tied with large iron rings and ship ropes.
tr: She found him lying in his hammock, which was tied to the ceiling beams with ship moorings, wearing only his underwear.
es: She found him in his underwear, awake, lying in the hammock he had hung from the beams with ship mooring cables.

en: She was so impressed by his enormous motley nakedness that she felt an impulse to retreat.
vi: His muscular bare body moved her so much that she instinctively stopped and intended to leave.
tr: Rebeca, affected by Jose Arcadio's impressive nakedness, suddenly wanted to flee.
es: His enormous tattooed nakedness impressed her so much that she felt the urge to retreat.

en: “Excuse me,” she said, “I didn’t know you were here.”
vi: "Sorry"… she stammered, "I didn't know you were here".
tr: I'm sorry.
es: “Excuse me,” she apologized. “I didn't know you were here.

en: But she lowered her voice so as not to wake anyone up.
vi: But she lowered her voice immediately so as not to wake anyone else.
tr: I didn't know you were here, she said, lowering her voice so no one would wake up.
es: ”But she lowered her voice so as not to wake anyone.

en: “Come here,” he said.
vi: "Come in," he said.
tr: Jose Arcadio said, Come here.
es: “Come here,” he said.

en: Rebeca obeyed.
vi: Rebeca obediently complied.
tr: Rebeca went and stood by the hammock.
es: Rebeca obeyed.

en: She stopped beside the hammock in an icy sweat, feeling knots forming in her intestines, while José Arcadio stroked her ankles with the tips of his fingers, then her calves, then her thighs, murmuring: “Oh, little sister, little sister.”
vi: She stood right next to the hammock, sweating coldly, feeling her stomach knotting up, while José Arcadio caressed her wrist with his five fingers, then her groin, then her buttocks, whispering: "Oh, little one. Oh, little one."
tr: As Jose Arcadio murmured, My little one, my little one, while caressing her ankles, then her legs, then her calves with his fingertips, cold sweat poured down Rebeca's body, and a knot of pain twisted in her intestines.
es: She stopped next to the hammock, sweating ice, feeling knots form in her stomach, while José Arcadio caressed her ankles with his fingertips, then her calves, and then her thighs, murmuring, “Oh, little sister; oh, little sister.

en: She had to make a supernatural effort not to die when a startlingly regulated cyclonic power lifted her up by the waist and despoiled her of her intimacy with three clashes of its claws and quartered her like a little bird.
vi: The girl had to muster all her strength to avoid dying when a storm-like but very gentle force lifted her by the waist, undressed her, and laid her down like a small bird.
tr: When an unimaginable force grabbed her by the waist and tore her clothes to shreds in three swift moves, seating her on him like a fledgling bird, Rebeca exerted supernatural strength not to die.
es: ”She had to make a supernatural effort not to die when an astonishingly regulated cyclonic force lifted her by the waist, stripped her of her intimacy with three claw swipes, and dismembered her like a little bird.

en: She managed to thank God for having been born before she lost herself in the inconceivable pleasure of that unbearable pain, splashing in the steaming marsh of the hammock which absorbed the explosion of blood like a blotter.
vi: She only had time to thank God for her existence before her consciousness was submerged in the soft, ecstatic pleasure that overwhelmed the pain, making her writhe in the steaming hammock. The hammock, like a blotting paper, immediately absorbed the blood from her virginity.
tr: Before she lost herself in the unbearable pleasure of that excruciating pain and sank into the mist of the hammock that absorbed the gushing blood like a sponge, she thanked God for being born.
es: She managed to thank God for being born before losing consciousness in the inconceivable pleasure of that unbearable pain, splashing in the steaming swamp of the hammock that absorbed the explosion of her blood like blotting paper.

en: Three days later they were married during the five-o’clock mass.
vi: Three days later, they held the wedding ceremony during the mass at five in the afternoon.
tr: They got married three days later during the afternoon service.
es: Three days later they got married at the five o'clock mass.

en: José Arcadio had gone to Pietro Crespi’s store the day before.
vi: The day before that, Arcadio had gone to Pietro Crespi's shop.
tr: Jose Arcadio went to Pietro Crespi's shop the day before.
es: José Arcadio had gone to Pietro Crespi's shop the day before.

en: He found him giving a zither lesson and did not draw him aside to speak to him.
vi: He found Pietro Crespi teaching a student to play the guitar and did not discreetly call him aside to talk.
tr: Crespi was teaching music to his students.
es: He had found him giving a zither lesson and did not take him aside to talk to him.

en: “I’m going to marry Rebeca,” he told him.
vi: "I'm marrying Rebeca," he said.
tr: Without feeling the need to pull him aside and whisper, Jose Arcadio openly said, I'm marrying Rebeca.
es: "I'm marrying Rebeca," he said to him.

en: Pietro Crespi turned pale, gave the zither to one of his pupils, and dismissed the class.
vi: Pietro Crespi turned pale, handed the guitar to a student, and dismissed the class in the middle of the lesson.
tr: Pietro Crespi's face turned ashen. He handed the instrument to one of the students and stopped the lesson.
es: Pietro Crespi turned pale, handed the zither to one of his students, and ended the class.

en: When they were alone in the room that was crowded with musical instruments and mechanical toys, Pietro Crespi said:
vi: When only the two of them were left in the room filled with musical instruments and wind-up toys, Pietro Crespi said:
tr: When they were alone in the room filled with musical instruments and mechanical toys, Pietro Crespi said, She's your sister.
es: When they were alone in the room crowded with musical instruments and clockwork toys, Pietro Crespi said:

en: “She’s your sister.”
vi: - Rebecca is your sister!
tr: When they were alone in the room filled with musical instruments and mechanical toys, Pietro Crespi said, She's your sister.
es: —It's his sister.

en: “I don’t care,” José Arcadio replied.
vi: - To me, that doesn't matter, - José Arcadio replied.
tr: Jose Arcadio replied, "So what?"
es: —I don't care —replied José Arcadio.

en: Pietro Crespi mopped his brow with the handkerchief that was soaked in lavender.
vi: Piêtrô Crêspi took out a lavender-scented handkerchief to wipe the sweat from his forehead.
tr: Pietro Crespi wiped his forehead with a handkerchief soaked in coca.
es: Pietro Crespi wiped his forehead with a lavender-scented handkerchief.

en: “It’s against nature,” he explained, “and besides, it’s against the law.”
vi: - Taking it that way is against the laws of nature, he explained, - besides, the law strictly prohibits such a marriage.
tr: "It would be against nature," he tried to explain. "It is also against the laws."
es: —It is against nature —he explained— and, moreover, the law prohibits it.

en: José Arcadio grew impatient, not so much at the argument as over Pietro Crespi’s paleness.
vi: - Oh, I don't care about your so-called natural order, - said José Arcadio.
tr: Although Jose Arcadio did not mind the prolongation of the argument, Pietro Crespi's temper flared as he looked at the ash-colored face.
es: José Arcadio grew impatient not so much with the argument as with Pietro Crespi's paleness.

en: “Fuck nature two times over,” he said.
vi: - Oh, I don't care about your so-called natural order, - said José Arcadio.
tr: "I'll even read nature itself," he said.
es: —I shit twice on nature —he said—.

en: “And I’ve come to tell you not to bother going to ask Rebeca anything.”
vi: - I'm here to let you know so you won't bother Rebeca with questions.
tr: "I came to tell you not to ask Rebeca anything, no matter how tempted you are."
es: And I'm telling you this so you don't bother going to ask Rebeca anything.

en: But his brutal deportment broke down when he saw Pietro Crespi’s eyes grow moist.
vi: Although his rude behavior had to disappear when he saw Pietro Crespi with tears in his eyes.
tr: When she saw that Pietro Crespi's eyes were filling with tears, she stopped scolding him.
es: But his brutal behavior was shattered upon seeing Pietro Crespi's eyes fill with tears.

en: “Now,” he said to him in a different tone, “if you really like the family, there’s Amaranta for you.”
vi: "Now, here's the deal," he changed his tone, "if you still have feelings for my family, then Amaranta will be yours."
tr: In a different voice; -If you truly love family, there's the lovely Amaranta for you, he said.
es: —Now —he said to him in a different tone—, if what you like is family, then there's Amaranta for you.

en: Father Nicanor revealed in his Sunday sermon that José Arcadio and Rebeca were not brother and sister.
vi: In the Sunday sermon, Father Nicanor demonstrated that José Arcadio and Rebeca were not biological siblings.
tr: Peder Nicanor announced during the Sunday mass that Jose Arcadio and Rebeca were not siblings.
es: Father Nicanor revealed in the Sunday sermon that José Arcadio and Rebeca were not siblings.

en: Úrsula never forgave what she considered an inconceivable lack of respect and when they came back from church she forbade the newlyweds to set foot in the house again.
vi: Ursula never forgave what she considered to be excessive rudeness, and when they returned from the church, she barred the newlyweds from entering the house.
tr: Ursula never forgave this event, which she deemed an incredible disrespect, and banned the newlyweds from ever setting foot in the house again.
es: Úrsula never forgave what she considered an inconceivable lack of respect, and when they returned from church, she forbade the newlyweds from ever setting foot in the house again.

en: For her it was as if they were dead.
vi: To her, they were now like the dead.
tr: She considered them as good as dead.
es: To her, it was as if they had died.

en: So they rented a house across from the cemetery and established themselves there with no other furniture but José Arcadio’s hammock.
vi: So they bought a small house in front of the cemetery and moved to their new home without taking any furniture except for José Arcadio's hammock.
tr: They rented a house across from the cemetery and settled in by setting up Jose Arcadio's hammock, their only piece of furniture.
es: So they rented a small house in front of the cemetery and settled in it with no more furniture than José Arcadio's hammock.

en: On their wedding night a scorpion that had got into her slipper bit Rebeca on the foot.
vi: On their wedding night, Rebecca was bitten on the foot by a scorpion that had somehow gotten into her slipper.
tr: On their wedding night, a scorpion that had crawled into her slipper stung Rebeca's foot.
es: On their wedding night, Rebeca was bitten on the foot by a scorpion that had crawled into her slipper.

en: Her tongue went to sleep, but that did not stop them from spending a scandalous honeymoon.
vi: She was left speechless, but that didn't make their honeymoon any less enjoyable.
tr: The girl's tongue went numb. Nevertheless, this incident did not prevent them from having a honeymoon that caused quite a stir.
es: Her tongue went numb, but that did not prevent them from having a scandalous honeymoon.

en: The neighbors were startled by the cries that woke up the whole district as many as eight times in a single night and three times during siesta, and they prayed that such wild passion would not disturb the peace of the dead.
vi: The neighbors were startled by the screams that woke the entire neighborhood up to eight times in one night and three times in one afternoon, and they prayed that this excessive frenzy wouldn't disturb the dead resting peacefully in the tranquil cemetery nearby.
tr: The neighbors were astonished by the screams that woke the neighborhood eight times a night and three times during the siesta, and they began to pray that this wildness would not disturb the peace of the dead.
es: The neighbors were frightened by the screams that woke up the entire neighborhood up to eight times in one night, and up to three times during the siesta, and they prayed that such an unbridled passion would not disturb the peace of the dead.

en: Aureliano was the only one who was concerned about them.
vi: Aureliano was the only one worried about them.
tr: Aureliano was the only one who thought about and cared for them.
es: Aureliano was the only one who cared about them.

en: He bought them some furniture and gave them some money until José Arcadio recovered his sense of reality and began to work the no-man’s-land that bordered the courtyard of the house.
vi: He bought some supplies and provided them with financial assistance until José Arcadio took a more realistic view of life and began to clear the unclaimed land adjacent to the yard.
tr: He brought them a few pieces of furniture and gave them money until Jose Arcadio came to his senses and started working the abandoned land adjacent to the garden.
es: He bought them some furniture and provided them with money until José Arcadio regained his sense of reality and began to work the no-man's land that bordered the house's yard.

en: Amaranta, on the other hand, never did overcome her rancor against Rebeca, even though life offered her a satisfaction of which she had not dreamed: at the initiative of Úrsula, who did not know how to repair the shame, Pietro Crespi continued having lunch at the house on Tuesdays, rising above his defeat with a serene dignity.
vi: In contrast, Amaranta never ceased to hold a grudge against Rebeca, even though life had brought her unexpected joy. That joy was Pietro Crespi, who, with a calm and noble demeanor hiding his heartbreak, continued to have lunch with the family every Tuesday at Ursula's suggestion, as she still didn't know how to ease her embarrassment.
tr: On the other hand, although life's twist had brought her an unexpected joy, Amaranta's hatred for Rebeca never faded. At Ursula's request, who didn't know how to make people forget the disgrace, Pietro Crespi continued to come for dinner on Tuesdays.
es: Amaranta, on the other hand, never managed to overcome her resentment towards Rebeca, although life offered her a satisfaction she had never dreamed of: on Úrsula's initiative, who did not know how to repair the shame, Pietro Crespi continued to have lunch at the house on Tuesdays, overcoming the failure with serene dignity.

en: He still wore the black ribbon on his hat as a sign of respect for the family, and he took pleasure in showing his affection for Úrsula by bringing her exotic gifts:
vi: Still wearing the black ribbon on his hat as a sign of his closeness to the family, he enjoyed expressing his admiration for Ursula by bringing her exotic gifts:
tr: Crespi, who bore his great ruin with dignified composure, still wore a black mourning band on his hat as a sign of respect for the family and demonstrated his affection for Ursula with various gifts.
es: He kept the black ribbon on his hat as a sign of appreciation for the family, and he delighted in showing his affection to Úrsula by bringing her exotic gifts:

en: Portuguese sardines, Turkish rose marmalade, and on one occasion a lovely Manila shawl.
vi: Portuguese sardines, Turkish delight, and on special occasions, even a precious Manila shawl.
tr: He brought sardines from Portugal and rose jams made by the Turks. Once, he had brought a very beautiful Manila shawl.
es: Portuguese sardines, Turkish rose jam, and on one occasion, a beautiful Manila shawl.

en: Amaranta looked after him with a loving diligence.
vi: Amaranta, with affectionate feelings, pampered him.
tr: Amaranta served him kindly, mending the frayed cuffs of his shirt.
es: Amaranta attended to him with affectionate diligence.

en: She anticipated his wants, pulled out the threads on the cuffs of his shirt, and embroidered a dozen handkerchiefs with his initials for his birthday.
vi: She guessed his preferences, meticulously mended every loose thread on his sleeves, and to celebrate his birthday, she hemmed and embroidered their initials on a dozen handkerchiefs.
tr: As a birthday gift, she embroidered a dozen handkerchiefs with his initials in the corner.
es: She guessed his tastes, removed the loose threads from the cuffs of his shirt, and embroidered a dozen handkerchiefs with his initials for his birthday.

en: On Tuesdays, after lunch, while she would embroider on the porch, he would keep her happy company.
vi: On Tuesdays, after lunch, while Amaranta sat in the hallway, he always stayed by her side, chatting cheerfully.
tr: On Tuesdays, after lunch, while Amaranta sat on the terrace doing embroidery, Pietro Crespi, who kept her company, began to see this woman, whom he had always regarded as a child, as a gift from God.
es: On Tuesdays, after lunch, while she embroidered in the corridor, he kept her cheerful company.

en: For Pietro Crespi, that woman whom he always had considered and treated as a child was a revelation.
vi: One Tuesday afternoon, when no one suspected what was about to happen, it happened: Pietro Crespi proposed to her.
tr: On Tuesdays, after lunch, while Amaranta sat on the terrace doing embroidery, Pietro Crespi, who kept her company, began to see this woman, whom he had always regarded as a child, as a gift from God.
es: For Pietro Crespi, that woman whom he always considered and treated as a child, was a revelation.

en: Although her temperament lacked grace, she had a rare sensibility for appreciating the things of the world and had a secret tenderness.
vi: One Tuesday afternoon, when no one suspected what was about to happen, it happened: Pietro Crespi proposed to her.
tr: Amaranta was wild and carefree, but there was nothing she didn't understand. When she was treated well, she would become gentle and affectionate.
es: Although her type lacked grace, she had a rare sensitivity to appreciate the things of the world, and a secret tenderness.

en: One Tuesday, when no one doubted that sooner or later it had to happen, Pietro Crespi asked her to marry him.

tr: Everyone believed that they would eventually get married. Indeed, one Tuesday, Pietro Crespi proposed marriage to Amaranta.
es: One Tuesday, when no one doubted that sooner or later it had to happen, Pietro Crespi asked her to marry him.

en: She did not stop her work.
vi: The girl continued to embroider calmly.
tr: Amaranta did not put down her work.
es: She did not interrupt her work.

en: She waited for the hot blush to leave her ears and gave her voice a serene stress of maturity.

es: She waited for the hot blush of her ears to pass and gave her voice a serene emphasis of maturity.

en: “Of course, Crespi,” she said.

en: It’s never good to be hasty in things.”

en: In spite of the esteem she had for Pietro Crespi, she could not tell whether his decision was good or bad from the moral point of view after his prolonged and famous engagement to Rebeca.

tr: She respected Pietro Crespi, but she couldn't determine whether his decision to marry Amaranta after his legendary engagement to Rebeca was morally consistent.
es: Despite the affection she had for Pietro Crespi, she couldn't determine whether his decision was good or bad from a moral standpoint, after the prolonged and noisy courtship with Rebeca.

en: But she finally accepted it as an unqualified fact because no one shared her doubts.

es: But she ended up accepting it as an unqualified fact, because no one shared her doubts.

en: Aureliano, who was the man of the house, confused her further with his enigmatic and final opinion:

en: “These are not times to go around thinking about weddings.”
vi: - Now is not the time to discuss marriage.

es: —These are not the hours to be thinking about marriages.

en: That opinion, which Úrsula understood only some months later, was the only sincere one that Aureliano could express at that moment, not only with respect to marriage, but to anything that was not war.
vi: In the following months, Úrsula finally understood that the statement was the only sincere answer that Aureliano could have given at that moment. It was not only a response to the matter of marriage but also to any issue unrelated to the war.
tr: These words, which Ursula could only understand a month later, were the only ones Aureliano could sincerely utter at that moment. What he said encompassed not only the topic of marriage but everything unrelated to the war.
es: That opinion, which Úrsula only understood some months later, was the only sincere one that Aureliano could express at that moment, not only regarding marriage but any matter that wasn't war.

en: He himself, facing a firing squad, would not understand too well the concatenation of the series of subtle but irrevocable accidents that brought him to that point.
vi: When facing the execution squad's rifles, even he did not fully understand why a series of ironic coincidences had led him to that situation.
tr: Even he couldn't fully comprehend the series of insignificant but irreversible events that led him to that point when he stood before the firing squad.
es: He himself, in front of the firing squad, did not quite understand how the series of subtle but irrevocable coincidences that led him to that point had unfolded.

en: The death of Remedios had not produced the despair that he had feared.
vi: The death of Remedios did not lead him to a terrifying agitation.
tr: Remedios's death had not caused the devastation in Aureliano that he had feared.
es: Remedios' death did not produce the shock he feared.

en: It was, rather, a dull feeling of rage that grades ally dissolved in a solitary and passive frustration similar to the one he had felt during the time he was resigned to living without a woman.
vi: Rather, it was merely a silent anger that gradually seeped into a quiet and lonely despondency, similar to the despondency he felt during the days he resolved to remain single.
tr: He felt a silent rage that gradually turned into an inward resentment during the period he lived without a woman.
es: It was rather a dull feeling of rage that gradually dissolved into a solitary and passive frustration, similar to what he experienced in the times when he was resigned to living without a woman.

en: He plunged into his work again, but he kept up the custom of playing dominoes with his father-in-law.
vi: He immersed himself in work again but still kept the habit of visiting his father-in-law to play dominoes: "Aureliano, get married," his father-in-law told him.
tr: He had returned to his work but had not given up his habit of playing dominoes with his father-in-law.
es: He plunged back into work, but kept the habit of playing dominoes with his father-in-law.

en: In a house bound up in mourning, the nightly conversations consolidated the friendship between the two men.
vi: He immersed himself in work again but still kept the habit of visiting his father-in-law to play dominoes: "Aureliano, get married," his father-in-law told him.
tr: The conversations held in the mourning house from evening to evening brought the two men closer together and strengthened their friendship.
es: In a house silenced by mourning, the nightly conversations consolidated the friendship between the two men.

en: “Get married again.
vi: He immersed himself in work again but still kept the habit of visiting his father-in-law to play dominoes: "Aureliano, get married," his father-in-law told him.
tr: His father-in-law would say, "Remarry, Aurelito."
es: "Remarry, Aurelito," his father-in-law would say.

en: Aurelito,” his father-in-law would tell him.
vi: He immersed himself in work again but still kept the habit of visiting his father-in-law to play dominoes: "Aureliano, get married," his father-in-law told him.
tr: His father-in-law would say, "Remarry, Aurelito."
es: "Remarry, Aurelito," his father-in-law would say.

en: “I have six daughters for you to choose from.”
vi: "I have six daughters for you to choose from."
tr: "Look, I have six more daughters." "Choose the one you like and take her."
es: "I have six daughters to choose from. "

en: On one occasion on the eve of the elections, Don Apolinar Moscote returned from one of his frequent trips worried about the political situation in the country.
vi: Once, perhaps the event occurred before the election day, Don Apolinar Moscote returned to the village from the province, full of anxiety about the political situation of the country.
tr: The night of the elections, Don Apolinar Moscote, who had just returned from one of his frequent trips, was quite pessimistic about the political situation in the country.
es: On one occasion, on the eve of the elections, Don Apolinar Moscote returned from one of his frequent trips, worried about the country's political situation.

en: The Liberals were determined to go to war.
vi: The Liberals were ready to plunge into the fight.
tr: The Liberals were determined to fight.
es: The liberals were determined to go to war.

en: Since Aureliano at that time had very confused notions about the difference between Conservatives and Liberals, his father-in-law gave him some schematic lessons.
vi: Since Aureliano still had vague notions about the differences between the Conservatives and the Liberals at that time, his father-in-law explained the general outlines to him.
tr: At that time, since Aureliano did not have sufficient knowledge about the distinction between Conservatives and Liberals, his father-in-law briefly explained to him what was what.
es: Since Aureliano had very confused notions at that time about the differences between conservatives and liberals, his father-in-law gave him schematic lessons.

en: The Liberals, he said, were Freemasons, bad people, wanting to hang priests, to institute civil marriage and divorce, to recognize the rights of illegitimate children as equal to those of legitimate ones, and to cut the country up into a federal system that would take power away from the supreme authority.
vi: Free men, he said, are Masons, wicked people who support hanging priests, advocate equal marriage and divorce, recognize the equality of illegitimate and legitimate children, and favor dividing the country into states that are federated to strip local powers and concentrate them in the supreme government.
tr: According to Moscote, the Liberals were Freemasons, bad people, who would hang and strangle priests, disregard religious rules, come up with new inventions like civil marriage and divorce, grant the same rights to illegitimate children as to other children, and weaken the power of the state by dividing the country with a federal system.
es: The liberals, he said, were masons; people of bad character, supporters of hanging priests, implementing civil marriage and divorce, recognizing equal rights for natural children as for legitimate ones, and tearing the country apart into a federal system that stripped the supreme authority of its powers.

en: The Conservatives, on the other hand, who had received their power directly from God, proposed the establishment of public order and family morality.
vi: In contrast, the Royalists, who have received power directly from God, protect the established public order and family morals, are the defenders of Christ, protect the foundations of power, and do not allow the country to be divided into free states.
tr: However, the Conservatives, who derived their power directly from God, wanted to defend the established order, ensure public order, and protect the sanctity and morality of the family institution.
es: The conservatives, on the other hand, who had received power directly from God, advocated for the stability of public order and family morals; they were the defenders of the faith of Christ, the principle of authority, and were not willing to allow the country to be dismembered into autonomous entities.

en: They were the defenders of the faith of Christ, of the principle of authority, and were not prepared to permit the country to be broken down into autonomous entities.
vi: In contrast, the Royalists, who have received power directly from God, protect the established public order and family morals, are the defenders of Christ, protect the foundations of power, and do not allow the country to be divided into free states.
tr: They were the guardians of our Lord Jesus' religion, the defenders of the principle of sovereignty, and they would not allow the country to be divided into autonomous administrative regions; they would ensure the integrity of the homeland.
es: The conservatives, on the other hand, who had received power directly from God, advocated for the stability of public order and family morals; they were the defenders of the faith of Christ, the principle of authority, and were not willing to allow the country to be dismembered into autonomous entities.

en: Because of his humanitarian feelings Aureliano sympathized with the Liberal attitude with respect to the rights of natural children, but in any case, he could not understand how people arrived at the extreme of waging war over things that could not be touched with the hand.
vi: Due to humanitarian sentiments, Aureliano sympathized with the liberal attitude of recognizing the rights of illegitimate children, but in any case, he could not understand why people had to go to war over intangible matters.
tr: Aureliano, influenced by his humane feelings, sided with the Liberals because of their stance on illegitimate children. But he could never understand how discussions about intangible matters could bring the parties to the brink of war.
es: Out of humanitarian sentiments, Aureliano sympathized with the liberal stance regarding the rights of natural children, but still did not understand how it came to the point of waging a war over things that could not be touched with hands.

en: It seemed an exaggeration to him that for the elections his father-in-law had them send six soldiers armed with rifles under the command of a sergeant to a town with no political passions.
vi: He felt his father-in-law was being extreme when he requested his superiors to send six soldiers under the command of a sergeant to Macondo, a village without political passions, to protect the election.
tr: He also attributed the arrival of six armed soldiers, led by a sergeant, to a village where no one had any political passion, during election time, to his father-in-law's meddling. When the soldiers arrived in the village, they did not remain idle.
es: It seemed an exaggeration to him that his father-in-law had six soldiers armed with rifles, led by a sergeant, sent for the elections in a town without political passions.

en: They not only arrived, but they went from house to house confiscating hunting weapons, machetes, and even kitchen knives before they distributed among males over twenty-one the blue ballots with the names of the Conservative candidates and the red ballots with the names of the Liberal candidates.
vi: The soldiers not only came to the village, but they also went house to house, confiscating hunting weapons, machetes, and even kitchen knives, before distributing to men aged twenty-one and over a green ballot with the names of the Royalist candidates and a pink ballot with the names of the Liberal candidates.
tr: They went from house to house and collected all the weapons they could find. They even took bread knives along with cane knives. Then they distributed blue ballots with the names of Conservative candidates and red ballots for the Liberals to men over twenty-one years old.
es: Not only did they arrive, but they went from house to house confiscating hunting weapons, machetes, and even kitchen knives, before distributing the blue ballots with the names of the conservative candidates and the red ballots with the names of the liberal candidates among men over twenty-one years old.

en: On the eve of the elections Don Apolinar Moscote himself read a decree that prohibited the sale of alcoholic beverages and the gathering together of more than three people who were not of the same family.
vi: Before the election day, Apolinar Moscote himself read a decree prohibiting the sale of liquor and gatherings of more than three people unless they were from the same household for forty-eight hours starting from midnight on Saturday.
tr: On the evening before the elections, Don Apolinar Moscote read a proclamation banning the sale of alcoholic beverages and the gathering of more than three people from different families.
es: On the eve of the elections, Don Apolinar Moscote himself read an edict that prohibited, from midnight on Saturday and for forty-eight hours, the sale of alcoholic beverages and the gathering of more than three people who were not from the same family.

en: The elections took place without incident.
vi: The election proceeded smoothly.
tr: The elections passed without incident.
es: The elections passed without incident.

en: At eight o’clock on Sunday morning a wooden ballot box was set up in the square, which was watched over by the six soldiers.
vi: As early as eight o'clock on Sunday morning, a wooden box guarded by six soldiers was placed in the square.
tr: At eight on Sunday morning, a ballot box was placed in the square. Six soldiers stood guard at the ballot box.
es: From eight o'clock on Sunday morning, the wooden ballot box was set up in the square, guarded by the six soldiers.

en: The voting was absolutely free, as Aureliano himself was able to attest since he spent almost the entire day with his father-in-law seeing that no one voted more than once.
vi: People voted freely, just as Aureliano could see for himself when he, along with his father-in-law, stood guard all day to ensure that no one could vote more than once.
tr: The election was conducted in an atmosphere of great freedom and maturity. Aureliano, since he was with his father-in-law who did not leave the ballot box to ensure no one voted more than once, witnessed these free and mature elections with his own eyes.
es: Voting took place with complete freedom, as Aureliano himself could verify, who spent almost the entire day with his father-in-law ensuring that no one voted more than once.

en: At four in the afternoon a roll of drums in the square announced the closing of the polls and Don Apolinar Moscote sealed the ballot box with a label crossed by his signature.
vi: At four in the afternoon, a drum roll in the square signaled the end of the election day, and Apolinar Moscote sealed the ballot box with a cross-marked tape bearing his signature.
tr: At four in the afternoon, the end of voting was announced with a drum played in the square. Don Apolinar Moscote sealed the ballot box, labeled it, and signed the label.
es: At four in the afternoon, a drum roll in the square announced the end of the day, and Don Apolinar Moscote sealed the ballot box with a label crossed with his signature.

en: That night, while he played dominoes with Aureliano, he ordered the sergeant to break the seal in order to count the votes.
vi: That night, while playing dominoes with Aureliano, he ordered the sergeant to open the box and count the votes.
tr: That night, while playing dominoes with Aureliano, Moscote told the sergeant to break the seal of the ballot box and count the votes.
es: That night, while playing dominoes with Aureliano, he ordered the sergeant to break the label to count the votes.

en: There were almost as many red ballots as blue, but the sergeant left only ten red ones and made up the difference with blue ones.
