vi: The number of pink and green ballots was roughly equal, but the sergeant left only ten pink ballots and replaced the rest with green ones to make up the difference.
tr: From the box came an equal number of blue and red ballots, but the sergeant left only ten red ballots in the box and filled the difference with blue ones.
es: There were almost as many red ballots as blue ones, but the sergeant left only ten red ones and made up the difference with blue ones.

en: Then they sealed the box again with a new label and the first thing on the following day it was taken to the capital of the province.
vi: Then the sergeant resealed the ballot box with a new label, and the next morning it was hurriedly taken to the provincial capital.
tr: Then they sealed the box again and sent it to the capital without delay the next morning.
es: Then they resealed the ballot box with a new label and the next day, first thing in the morning, they took it to the provincial capital.

en: “The Liberals will go to war,” Aureliano said.
vi: " The Liberals will rise up in civil war," Aureliano said.
tr: The Liberals will declare war, said Aureliano.
es: " The liberals will go to war," said Aureliano.

en: Don Apolinar concentrated on his domino pieces.
vi: Apolinar did not take his eyes off his domino tiles.
tr: Don Apolinar was completely focused on the domino tiles.
es: Don Apolinar did not take his eyes off his domino pieces.

en: “If you’re saying that because of the switch in ballots, they won’t,” he said.
vi: "If you mean because of the ballot change, they won't rise up," he said, "some pink ballots were left to keep them from complaining.
tr: If you're saying this because we changed the votes, don't worry, they won't start a war, he said.
es: "If you say it because of the ballot changes, they won't," he said. "

en: “We left a few red ones in so there won’t be any complaints.”
vi: "If you mean because of the ballot change, they won't rise up," he said, "some pink ballots were left to keep them from complaining.
tr: We left a few red ballots so that no one would have anything to say.
es: Some red ones are left so there are no complaints.

en: Aureliano understood the disadvantages of being in the opposition.
vi: "Aureliano understood the disadvantages of the opposing side.
tr: Aureliano was slowly understanding the disadvantages of being in opposition.
es: "Aureliano understood the disadvantages of the opposition.

en: “If I were a Liberal,” he said, “I’d go to war because of those ballots.”
vi: "If I were a Liberal," he said, "I would rise up precisely because of this ballot change."
tr: If I were a liberal, I would go to war over these votes; he said.
es: "If I were a liberal," he said, "I would go to war over this ballot issue. "

en: His father-in-law looked at him over his glasses.
vi: His father-in-law looked at him over his glasses.
tr: His father-in-law scrutinized him over his glasses.
es: His father-in-law looked at him over the rim of his glasses.

en: “Come now, Aurelito,” he said, “if you were a Liberal, even though you’re my son-in-law, you wouldn’t have seen the switching of the ballots.”
vi: - Oh Aureliano, - he said, - if you belong to the Liberal party, even if you are my son-in-law, you will never be able to witness the changing of the vote here.
tr: "What else, Aurelito," she said. "If you were a Liberal, you wouldn't even know that the ballots were changed, even though you're my son-in-law."
es: —Oh, Aurelito —he said—, if you were a liberal, even if you were my son-in-law, you wouldn't have seen the ballot change.

en: What really caused indignation in the town was.
vi: In reality, what caused public outrage was not the election results but the fact that the soldiers did not return the weapons.
tr: It wasn't the election results that stirred up the village, but the soldiers' refusal to return the weapons they had collected from the houses.
es: What actually caused indignation among the people was not the election results, but the fact that the soldiers had not returned the weapons.

en: not the results of the elections but the fact that the soldiers had not returned the weapons.
vi: In reality, what caused public outrage was not the election results but the fact that the soldiers did not return the weapons.
tr: It wasn't the election results that stirred up the village, but the soldiers' refusal to return the weapons they had collected from the houses.
es: What actually caused indignation among the people was not the election results, but the fact that the soldiers had not returned the weapons.

en: A group of women spoke with Aureliano so that he could obtain the return of their kitchen knives from his father-in-law.
vi: A group of women spoke with Aureliano, asking him to request his father-in-law to return their kitchen knives.
tr: A group of women gathered and went to Aureliano, asking him to request the bread knives from his father-in-law.
es: A group of women spoke with Aureliano to get his father-in-law to return the kitchen knives.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote explained to him, in strictest confidence, that the soldiers had taken the weapons off as proof that the Liberals were preparing for war.
vi: Don Apolinar Moscote, with utmost caution, explained to him that the soldiers had taken the confiscated weapons as evidence that the Liberals were preparing for war.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote, as if revealing a state secret to his son-in-law, said that the soldiers had taken the knives to the capital as evidence of the Liberals' war preparations.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote explained to him, in strict confidence, that the soldiers had taken the confiscated weapons as proof that the liberals were preparing for war.

en: The cynicism of the remark alarmed him.
vi: The brazenness of that response shocked him.
tr: This deceitful, treacherous attitude horrified Aureliano.
es: The cynicism of the statement alarmed him.

en: He said nothing, but on a certain night when Gerineldo Márquez and Magnífico Visbal were speaking with some other friends about the incident of the knives, they asked him if he was a Liberal or a Conservative.
vi: He did not comment, but one night, when Hernando Márquez and Magnífico Visbal were discussing the trouble over the knives with some friends, they asked him which side he belonged to: Liberal or Royalist.
tr: He said nothing to his father-in-law. One evening, while Gerineldo Marquez and Magnifico Visbal were sitting with their friends discussing the matter of the knives, they turned to Aureliano and asked if he was a Liberal or a Conservative.
es: He made no comment, but one night when Gerineldo Márquez and Magnífico Visbal were talking with other friends about the knife incident, they asked him if he was a liberal or a conservative.

en: Aureliano did not hesitate.
vi: Without hesitation, he replied:
tr: He did not hesitate.
es: Aureliano did not hesitate:

en: “If I have to be something I’ll be a Liberal,” he said, “because the Conservatives are tricky.”
vi: - If I have to choose between the two factions, I will side with the Liberals, - he said, - because the Royalists are swindlers.
tr: If I absolutely had to take a side, I would be a Liberal, he said. Conservatives are deceitful, scheming.
es: —If I had to be something, I would be a liberal —he said—, because conservatives are cheaters.

en: On the following day, at the urging of his friends, he went to see dr Alirio Noguera to be treated for a supposed pain in his liver.
vi: The very next day, at the request of his friends, he went to see Dr. Alirio Noguera to have him examine his liver pain.
tr: The next day, upon the insistence of his friends, he went to Dr. Alirio Noguera, supposedly to cure the pain in his liver.
es: The next day, at the insistence of his friends, he went to visit Dr. Alirio Noguera to treat a supposed liver pain.

en: He did not even understand the meaning of the subterfuge.
vi: He didn't even know why he was doing it.
tr: He couldn't understand why he needed to lie about being sick.
es: He didn't even know what the point of the ruse was.

en: dr Alirio Noguera had arrived in Macondo a few years before with a medicine chest of tasteless pills and a medical motto that convinced no one:
vi: Dr. Alino Noguera had come to the village of Macondo a few years ago, bringing with him a cabinet of tasteless pills and an unconvincing advertisement sign: Fight poison with poison.
tr: Dr. Alirio Noguera had come to Macondo a few years earlier with a box of unpleasant pills and a saying that no one could make sense of: "A nail drives out another nail," he said.
es: Dr. Alirio Noguera had arrived in Macondo a few years earlier with a kit of tasteless globules and a medical motto that convinced no one:

en: One nail draws another.
vi: Dr. Alino Noguera had come to the village of Macondo a few years ago, bringing with him a cabinet of tasteless pills and an unconvincing advertisement sign: Fight poison with poison.
tr: Dr. Alirio Noguera had come to Macondo a few years earlier with a box of unpleasant pills and a saying that no one could make sense of: "A nail drives out another nail," he said.
es: One nail drives out another.

en: In reality he was a charlatan.
vi: In reality, it was a joke.
tr: In fact, he was a charlatan.
es: In reality, he was a fraud.

en: Behind his innocent façade of a doctor without prestige there was hidden a terrorist who with his short legged boots covered the scars that five years in the stocks had left on his legs.
vi: Behind the mild exterior of a mediocre doctor was the face of a terrorist who wore knee-high boots to cover the scars on his ankles, marks from five years in prison.
tr: Behind the guise of a doctor with no respectability, a terrorist was hidden. The short boots he always wore covered the marks left on his legs by five years of shackles.
es: Behind his innocent facade of an unprestigious doctor hid a terrorist who covered the scars on his ankles from five years in stocks with half-leg gaiters.

en: Taken prisoner during the first federalist adventure, he managed to escape to Curaçao disguised in the garment he detested most in this world: a cassock.
vi: From the very first federalist adventure, he had been arrested, escaped to Curaçao disguised in the clothes he hated most in the world: a priest's cassock.
tr: He had been arrested during the first actions of the Federalists, had to disguise himself in the form he most opposed in the world, and managed to escape to Curaçao by wearing a priest's robe.
es: Captured in the first federalist adventure, he managed to escape to Curaçao disguised in the outfit he most detested in this world: a cassock.

en: At the end of a prolonged exile, stirred up by the exciting news that exiles from all over the Caribbean brought to Curaçao, he set out in a smuggler’s schooner and appeared in Riohacha with the bottles of pills that were nothing but refined sugar and a diploma from the University of Leipzig that he had forged himself.
vi: After a long exile, filled with excitement by the news brought by exiles from all over the Caribbean to Curaçao, he sneaked onto a smuggling ship and then appeared in Riohacha with a cabinet of pills, which were actually just refined sugar tablets, and a fake medical degree from the University of Leipzig that he had forged himself:
tr: After living in exile for many years, he could no longer stay put upon hearing news from fellow exiles spread across the Caribbean coming to Curaçao, and he took a smuggler's boat to Riohacha. He had nothing but pills made of powdered sugar and a fake diploma from Leipzig University.
es: After a prolonged exile, spurred on by the exalted news brought to Curaçao by exiles from all over the Caribbean, he boarded a smugglers' schooner and appeared in Riohacha with the vials of globules that were nothing more than refined sugar, and a diploma from the University of Leipzig forged by himself.

en: He wept with disappointment.
vi: He wept bitterly.
tr: He cried in disappointment at what he saw.
es: He cried in disappointment.

en: The federalist fervor, which the exiles had pictured as a powder keg about to explode, had dissolved into a vague electoral illusion.
vi: The revolutionary fervor of the federalists, defined by the exiles as a powder keg about to explode, gradually cooled in the illusion of futile elections.
tr: The federalist force, which the smugglers had endlessly described as a boiling cauldron ready to explode, had dissipated in an obscure election frenzy.
es: The federalist fervor, which the exiles described as a powder keg about to explode, had dissolved into a vague electoral illusion.

en: Embittered by failure, yearning for a safe place where he could await old age, the false homeopath took refuge in Macondo.
vi: Bitter from that failure, longing for a safe place to spend his old age, the doctor who treated illness with illness fled to the village of Macondo.
tr: The fake doctor, devastated by the defeat and seeking a place to spend the rest of his life in peace, took refuge in Macondo.
es: Bitter from the failure, anxious for a safe place to await old age, the fake homeopath took refuge in Macondo.

en: In the narrow bottle-crowded room that he rented on one side of the square, he lived several years off the hopelessly ill who, after having tried everything, consoled themselves with sugar pills.
vi: In a cramped room filled with empty bottles, rented from across the square, he lived for several years with an incurable disease, convincing himself that he could be consoled with sugar pills.
tr: In a room filled with rented bottles of pills in a corner of the area, he lived off the desperate patients who, after trying every remedy, consoled themselves with sugar pills for a few years.
es: In the narrow room crammed with empty bottles that he rented beside the plaza, he lived for several years off hopeless patients who, after trying everything, consoled themselves with sugar globules.

en: His instincts of an agitator remained dormant as long as Don Apolinar Moscote was a figurehead.
vi: His rebellious spirit had settled as Apolinar Moscote became more of a puppet authority.
tr: During the years when Don Apolinar Moscote supposedly governed, there was no sign of incitement from the doctor.
es: His agitator instincts remained dormant while Don Apolinar Moscote was a decorative authority.

en: He passed the time remembering and fighting against asthma.
vi: Time passed, and he lived in reminiscence, treating asthma.
tr: He spent his time reminiscing about the old days and battling asthma.
es: His time was spent remembering and fighting asthma.

en: The approach of the elections was the thread that led him once more to the skein of subversion.
vi: The upcoming election was the trigger for him to find a way to act rebelliously again.
tr: With the approach of the elections, things got out of hand, and the doctor found himself once again in the role of an agitator.
es: The proximity of the elections was the thread that allowed him to find the skein of subversion again.

en: He made contact with the young people in the town, who lacked political knowledge, and he embarked on a stealthy campaign of instigation.
vi: He had close relations with the village youth, who were very politically unaware, and threw himself into secret rebellious activities.
tr: He established relationships with the village youths who were completely unaware of politics and continuously ran an incitement campaign.
es: He established contact with the young people of the town, who lacked political training, and embarked on a stealthy campaign of instigation.

en: The numerous red ballots that appeared is the box and that were attributed by Don Apolinar Moscote to the curiosity that came from youth were part of his plan: he made his disciples vote in order to show them that elections were a farce.
vi: The majority of the pink ballots in the box were from the enthusiastic youth. This was part of his plan: to force his disciples to vote to show them that elections were a farce.
tr: The red votes that came out of the ballot box, which Don Apolinar Moscote interpreted as a youthful whim, were part of the doctor's plan. He had made the young people vote to prove that the elections were nothing but a sham.
es: The numerous red ballots that appeared in the ballot box, which Don Apolinar Moscote attributed to the novelty-seeking nature of youth, were part of his plan: he forced his disciples to vote to convince them that elections were a farce.

en: “The only effective thing,” he would say, “is violence.”
vi: "The only thing that works," he said, "is violence. "
tr: The only thing that has an effect is acts of violence, he would say.
es: "The only effective thing," he said, "is violence."

en: The majority of Aureliano’s friends were enthusiastic over the idea of liquidating the Conservative establishment, but no one had dared include him in the plans, not only because of his ties with the magistrate, but because of his solitary and elusive character.
vi: Most of Aureliano's friends were eager to sweep away the royalist regime, but none dared to involve him in the plan, not only because of his relationship with his father-in-law but also because of his solitary and indifferent nature.
tr: Most of Aureliano's friends intended to overthrow the Conservative government. However, no one dared to reveal their plans to him. They couldn't open up to him not only because he was the son-in-law of the justice of the peace, but also because he was a reserved person.
es: Most of Aureliano's friends were enthusiastic about the idea of overthrowing the conservative order, but no one had dared to include him in the plans, not only because of his ties to the magistrate but also because of his solitary and evasive nature.

en: It was known, furthermore, that he had voted blue at his father-in-law’s direction.
vi: Moreover, they knew he had voted green as directed by his father-in-law.
tr: Moreover, it was known that he voted blue just because his father-in-law wanted him to.
es: It was also known that he had voted blue at his father-in-law's suggestion.

en: So it was a simple matter of chance that he revealed his political sentiments, and it was purely a matter of curiosity, a caprice, that brought him to visit the doctor for the treatment of a pain that he did not have.
vi: So it was merely a coincidence that revealed his political thoughts, and it was a completely curious impulse that led him to the absurd idea of visiting the doctor to treat a non-existent ailment.
tr: In short, Aureliano's political stance was revealed purely by chance. Although he was perfectly healthy, he went to the doctor out of sheer curiosity.
es: So it was a simple coincidence that revealed his political feelings, and it was pure curiosity that got him involved in the whim of visiting the doctor to treat a pain he didn't have.

en: In the den that smelled of camphorated cobwebs he found himself facing a kind of dusty iguana whose lungs whistled when he breathed.
vi: In the cramped room reeking of cheap camphor, there was a man who looked exactly like a moldy iguana wheezing.
tr: When Aureliano entered the room that smelled of camphor and was covered in cobwebs, he found himself in front of someone who resembled a dusty lizard, wheezing with every breath.
es: In the cubbyhole smelling of camphorated cobwebs, he found a sort of dusty iguana whose lungs whistled as he breathed.

en: Before asking him any questions the doctor took him to the window and examined the inside of his lower eyelid.
vi: Before he could ask anything, the doctor pulled him to the window and examined his lower eyelid.
tr: Without asking him anything, the doctor took him to the window and looked inside his lower eyelid.
es: Before asking him any questions, the doctor took him to the window and examined the inside of his lower eyelid.

en: “It’s not there,” Aureliano said, following what they told him.
vi: "It's not there," Aureliano said, following his friends' instructions.
tr: Aureliano said, "My problem isn't there." They had advised him to say it that way.
es: "It's not there," said Aureliano, as he had been instructed.

en: He pushed the tips of his fingers into his liver and added: “Here’s where I have the pain that won’t let me sleep.”
vi: Pressing his finger on his abdomen where his liver was, he said, "This is where it hurts so much I can't sleep. "
tr: Pressing the tips of his fingers against his liver, he added, The pain that keeps me awake at night is right here.
es: He pressed his liver with his fingertips and added, "It's here where I have the pain that won't let me sleep."

en: Then dr Noguera closed the window with the pretext that there was too much sun, and explained to him in simple terms that it was a patriotic duty to assassinate Conservatives.
vi: So Dr. Noguera closed the window, claiming it was too bright, and in simple terms explained to him why eliminating the royalists was a patriot's duty.
tr: Upon this, Dr. Noguera, pretending to be bothered by the sun, closed the curtain and explained to Aureliano in simple terms that he could understand that killing the Conservatives was an act of patriotism.
es: Then Dr. Noguera closed the window under the pretext that there was too much sun and explained in simple terms why it was a patriotic duty to kill the conservatives.

en: For several days Aureliano carried a small bottle of pills in his shirt pocket.
vi: For several days, Aureliano carried a tube of pills in his shirt pocket.
tr: Aureliano carried a bottle of medicine in his shirt pocket for several days.
es: For several days, Aureliano carried a small vial in his shirt pocket.

en: He would take it out every two hours, put three pills in the palm of his hand, and pop them into his mouth for them to be slowly dissolved on his tongue.
vi: Every two hours, he would take out the tube, pour three pills into his palm, and pop them all into his mouth, letting them dissolve slowly on his tongue.
tr: Every two hours, he would take out the bottle, take three pills into his palm, and slowly suck on them.
es: He would take it out every two hours, put three globules in the palm of his hand, and throw them into his mouth to dissolve slowly on his tongue.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote made fun of his faith in homeopathy, but those who were in on the plot recognized another one of their people in him.
vi: Apolinar Moscote mocked his faith in the method of treating illness with illness, but those plotting rebellion recognized him as one of their own.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote mocked him for believing in old wives' remedies, but those involved in the assassination plot considered him one of their own.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote mocked his faith in homeopathy, but those in the plot recognized him as one of their own.

en: Almost all of the sons of the founders were implicated, although none of them knew concretely what action they were plotting.
vi: Almost all the sons of Macondo's founders were in the secret organization, but none knew exactly how the actions they were preparing would unfold.
tr: Although none of them knew exactly what action would be taken, almost all the sons of the village founders had joined the organization.
es: Almost all the children of the founders were involved, although none knew concretely what the action they were plotting consisted of.

en: Nevertheless, the day the doctor revealed the secret to Aureliano, the latter elicited the whole plan of the conspiracy.
vi: However, on the day the doctor revealed the secret to Aureliano, he volunteered to join the uprising.
tr: However, the day the doctor hinted at what was to be done, Aureliano understood the plan.
es: However, the day the doctor revealed the secret to Aureliano, he backed out of the conspiracy.

en: Although he was convinced at that time of the urgency of liquidating the Conservative regime, the plot horrified him.
vi: Although he agreed at the time that the royalist regime had to be quickly destroyed, the doctor's plan of action disgusted him.
tr: Although he believed that the Conservative regime needed to be overthrown, he was frightened by what was being planned.
es: Although he was then convinced of the urgency of overthrowing the conservative regime, the plan horrified him.

en: dr Noguera had a mystique of personal assassination.
vi: Dr. Noguera was a great fan of individual terrorism.
tr: Dr. Noguera was fixated on assassinations.
es: Dr. Noguera was a mystic of personal attack.

en: His system was reduced to coordinating a series of individual actions which in one master stroke covering the whole nation would liquidate the functionaries of the regime along with their respective families, especially the children, in order to exterminate Conservatism at its roots.
vi: His method of action involved coordinating a series of individual acts so that in a large-scale national uprising, the royalist officials and their entire families, especially their children, would be exterminated to eradicate the royalist lineage.
tr: These actions, which would be triggered at the push of a button, would plan the killing of individuals one by one, ultimately leading to the elimination of those running the regime along with their families, especially their children, thereby eradicating Conservatism throughout the country.
es: His system was reduced to coordinating a series of individual actions that, in a masterstroke of national scope, would eliminate the regime's officials along with their respective families, especially the children, to exterminate conservatism at its root.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote, his wife, and his six daughters, needless to say, were on the list.
vi: Of course, Apolinar Moscote, his wife, and daughters were all on the terrorist list.
tr: Needless to say, Don Apolinar Moscote, his wife, and his six daughters were also on this list.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote, his wife, and their six daughters were, of course, on the list.

en: “You’re no Liberal or anything else,” Aureliano told him without getting excited.
vi: - You are neither a Liberal nor anything else - Aureliano said calmly, - you are a murderer, nothing more, nothing less.
tr: Aureliano, without losing his composure, said to the doctor, "You are not a liberal at all."
es: —You are neither a liberal nor anything —Aureliano told him without getting upset—.

en: “You’re nothing but a butcher.”
vi: - You are neither a Liberal nor anything else - Aureliano said calmly, - you are a murderer, nothing more, nothing less.
tr: "You can be nothing but a butcher."
es: You are nothing but a butcher.

en: “In that case,” the doctor replied with equal calm, “give me back the bottle.
vi: - In that case, - the doctor said calmly, - please return the tube of medicine to me.
tr: The doctor responded with the same calmness. Then give the bottle back.
es: —In that case —replied the doctor with equal calm— give me back the little bottle.

en: You don’t need it any more.”
vi: You don't need it anymore.
tr: You don't need it anymore.
es: You don't need it anymore.

en: Only six months later did Aureliano learn that the doctor had given up on him as a man of action because he was a sentimental person with no future, with a passive character, and a definite solitary vocation.
vi: Six months later, Aureliano learned that the doctor did not believe he was a man of action, had no hope for him, considering him a sentimental person, overly gentle and lonely.
tr: Aureliano only learned six months later that the doctor had looked at his emotional, introverted, solitary nature and concluded that he could not be a man of action.
es: Only six months later did Aureliano learn that the doctor had written him off as a man of action, deeming him a sentimentalist with no future, a passive character, and a defined solitary vocation.

en: They tried to keep him surrounded, fearing that he would betray the conspiracy.
vi: They tried to monitor him because they feared he would reveal the rebellion plans.
tr: His friends did not leave Aureliano's side, fearing he might reveal their plans, so they did not leave him alone.
es: They tried to corner him, fearing he would denounce the conspiracy.

en: Aureliano calmed them down: he would not say a word, but on the night they went to murder the Moscote family they would find him guarding the door.
vi: To put them at ease, Aureliano promised not to say a word. But the night they came to assassinate the Moscote family, they found him standing guard at the entrance.
tr: Aureliano reassured them. He would not let a single word slip, but on the night they came to kill Moscote and his family, they would find him standing guard at the door.
es: Aureliano reassured them: he wouldn't say a word, but the night they went to kill the Moscote family, they would find him defending the door.

en: He showed such a convincing decision that the plan was postponed for an indefinite date.
vi: He showed such a decisive attitude that the assassination plan had to be postponed indefinitely.
tr: He was so determined in this matter that the assassination plan was postponed to an indefinite date.
es: He demonstrated such a convincing resolve that the plan was postponed indefinitely.

en: It was during those days that Úrsula asked his opinion about the marriage between Pietro Crespi and Amaranta, and he answered that these were not times to be thinking about such a thing.
vi: It was during these days that Úrsula asked his opinion about the marriage of Pietro Crespi and Amaranta, and he replied that now was not the time to think about it.
tr: It was precisely during those days that Ursula asked what he thought about Pietro Crespi and Amaranta getting married, and Aureliano said it was not the time to worry about their marriage.
es: It was around that time that Úrsula sought his opinion on the marriage of Pietro Crespi and Amaranta, and he replied that the times were not right for thinking about that.

en: For a week he had been carrying an old-fashioned pistol under his shirt.
vi: For more than a week, he had been hiding an old-fashioned revolver under his shirt, always on guard against his friends.
tr: For a week, he had been carrying an old model pistol under his shirt; he did not take his eyes off his friends.
es: For a week, he had been carrying an archaic pistol under his shirt.

en: He kept his eyes on his friends.
vi: For more than a week, he had been hiding an old-fashioned revolver under his shirt, always on guard against his friends.
tr: For a week, he had been carrying an old model pistol under his shirt; he did not take his eyes off his friends.
es: He was watching his friends.

en: In the afternoon he would go have coffee with José Arcadio and Rebeca, who had begun to put their house in order, and from seven o’clock on he would play dominoes with his father-in-law.
vi: In the afternoon, he would go to drink coffee with José Arcadio and Rebeca, who were now starting to decorate their house, and then from seven in the evening, he would play dominoes with his father-in-law.
tr: In the evenings, he would go to visit Jose Arcadio and Rebeca, who had started tidying up their house, and after seven o'clock, he would play dominoes with his father-in-law.
es: In the afternoons, he would go for coffee with José Arcadio and Rebeca, who were starting to organize their house, and from seven o'clock, he played dominoes with his father-in-law.

en: At lunchtime he was chatting with Arcadio, who was already a huge adolescent, and he found him more and more excited over the imminence of war.
vi: At lunchtime, he talked with Arcadio, who was now a robust young man, and noticed that the young man increasingly showed eager enthusiasm for the impending civil war.
tr: At lunch, he would chat with Arcadio, who was now a grown young man, and he saw that Arcadio was very excited about the outbreak of war.
es: At lunchtime, he conversed with Arcadio, who was already a monumental adolescent, and found him increasingly excited about the imminence of war.

en: In school, where Arcadio had pupils older than himself mixed in with children who were barely beginning to talk, the Liberal fever had caught on.
vi: Arcadio had kindled a fervent admiration for the idea of freedom in the school, where he had gathered not only older students but also young children who could barely speak.
tr: In the school where Arcadio taught, there were students older than him. Those who had just learned to speak and those with hair and beard intertwined were together. The fire of liberalism had also engulfed the school.
es: At school, where Arcadio had students older than him mixed with children who were just beginning to speak, the liberal fever had taken hold.

en: There was talk of shooting Father Nicanor, of turning the church into a school, of instituting free love.
vi: The young man spoke about shooting Father Nicanor, turning the church into a school, and recognizing sexual freedom.
tr: There was talk of Father Nicanor being shot, the church being turned into a school, and free love being recognized.
es: There was talk of executing Father Nicanor, converting the temple into a school, and implementing free love.

en: Aureliano tried to calm down his drive.
vi: Aureliano was worried about his nephew's violent ideas.
tr: Aureliano tried to calm Arcadio's outbursts.
es: Aureliano tried to temper his impulses.

en: He recommended discretion and prudence to him.
vi: He advised him to be cautious and discreet.
tr: He advised him to be sensible and moderate.
es: He recommended discretion and prudence.

en: Deaf to his calm reasoning, to his sense of reality, Arcadio reproached him in public for his weakness of character.
vi: Ignoring his uncle's sensible arguments and practical thoughts, Arcadio openly criticized his uncle's cowardice.
tr: However, Arcadio ignored his rational views and realism, and accused him of being unprincipled in front of everyone.
es: Deaf to his calm reasoning and sense of reality, Arcadio publicly reproached him for his weakness of character.

en: Aureliano waited.
vi: Aureliano waited and waited.
tr: Aureliano waited.
es: Aureliano waited.

en: Finally, in the beginning of December, Úrsula burst into the workshop all upset.
vi: Finally, at the beginning of December, Úrsula suddenly rushed into the goldsmith's workshop in a panic:
tr: Finally, one day in early December, Ursula, trembling all over, burst into the workshop.
es: Finally, at the beginning of December, Úrsula burst into the workshop, distraught.

en: “War’s broken out!”
vi: - Civil war has broken out!
tr: -The war has broken out!
es: —The war has broken out!

en: War, in fact, had broken out three months before.
vi: Indeed, the civil war had been raging for three months.
tr: In fact, it had been three months since the war broke out.
es: Indeed, it had broken out three months ago.

en: Martial law was in effect in the whole country.
vi: The curfew law was enforced nationwide.
tr: Martial law had been declared throughout the country.
es: Martial law prevailed throughout the country.

en: The only one who knew it immediately was Don Apolinar Moscote, but he did not give the news even to his wife while the army platoon that was to occupy the town by surprise was on its way.
vi: Don Apolinar Moscote was the only one who knew in time that the fighting had broken out, but he didn't reveal it even to his wife, while a platoon of soldiers had rushed in to occupy the village and set up a garrison.
tr: The only one who received news of the events immediately was Don Apolinar Moscote. But even though the army unit that occupied the village had set out, he hadn't even told his wife about it.
es: The only one who knew in time was Don Apolinar Moscote, but he did not give the news even to his wife, while the army platoon that was to occupy the town by surprise was arriving.

en: They entered noiselessly before dawn, with two pieces of light artillery drawn by mules, and they set up their headquarters in the school.
vi: The soldiers quietly entered the village before dawn, bringing with them two light cannons pulled by mules, and established a garrison right at the school.
tr: The soldiers entered the village before dawn with two light cannons pulled by mules and set up headquarters in the school.
es: They entered silently before dawn, with two pieces of light artillery pulled by mules, and established the barracks in the school.

en: A 6 P. M. curfew was established.
vi: They blew the curfew horn as early as six in the evening.
tr: A curfew was imposed after six in the evening.
es: A curfew was imposed at six in the evening.

en: A more drastic search than the previous one was undertaken, house by house, and this time they even took farm implements.
vi: This time, they searched each house more terrifyingly than before, confiscating everything from sickles onwards.
tr: A much more meticulous investigation was conducted than the previous one, all the houses were searched thoroughly, and even agricultural tools were confiscated.
es: A more drastic search than the previous one was carried out, house by house, and this time they even took the farming tools.

en: They dragged out dr Noguera, tied him to a tree in the square, and shot him without any due process of law.
vi: They dragged Dr. Noguera away, tied him to a tree, and shot him without trial.
tr: They dragged Dr. Noguera to the square, tied him to a tree, and shot him without any questioning.
es: They dragged out Dr. Noguera, tied him to a tree in the square, and executed him without trial.

en: Father Nicanor tried to impress the military authorities with the miracle of levitation and had his head split open by the butt of a soldier’s rifle.
vi: Father Nicanor wanted to awe the military authorities with his mystical ability to levitate, but a soldier struck him on the head with the butt of his rifle, causing it to bleed.
tr: Father Nicanor tried to impress the military authorities with the miracle of flying, but one of the soldiers brought down the butt of his rifle, splitting his head in two.
es: Father Nicanor tried to impress the military authorities with the miracle of levitation, and a soldier smashed his head with a rifle butt.

en: The Liberal exaltation had been extinguished into a silent terror.
vi: The excitement of the Liberals was extinguished in silent anxiety.
tr: The enthusiasm of the Liberals turned into this silent horror.
es: The liberal exaltation faded into a silent terror.

en: Aureliano, pale, mysterious, continued playing dominoes with his father-in-law.
vi: Aureliano, pale and inscrutable, continued to play dominoes with his father-in-law.
tr: The sallow-faced, silent Aureliano continued his domino games with his father-in-law.
es: Aureliano, pale and inscrutable, continued playing dominoes with his father-in-law.

en: He understood that in spite of his present title of civil and military leader of the town, Don Apolinar Moscote was once more a figurehead.
vi: He understood that although Don Apolinar Moscote was nominally the leader of civil and military affairs in the village, he was once again just a puppet official.
tr: Although he held the title of the so-called civilian and military leader of the village, Don Apolinar Moscote had once again lost his respect.
es: He understood that despite his current title of civil and military chief of the town, Don Apolinar Moscote was once again a decorative authority.

en: The decisions were made by the army captain, who each morning collected an extraordinary levy for the defense of public order.
vi: All matters in the village were decided by an army captain. Every morning, this captain personally collected extraneous taxes to fund the maintenance of public security.
tr: The decisions were made by the captain, and extraordinary meetings were held every morning to maintain order.
es: The decisions were made by an army captain who every morning collected an extraordinary levy for the defense of public order.

en: Four soldiers under his command snatched a woman who had been bitten by a mad dog from her family and killed her with their rifle butts.
vi: Four soldiers under his command looted the home of a woman bitten by a rabid dog and beat her to death with rifle butts right in the middle of the street.
tr: One day, four of the soldiers under his command forcibly took a woman who had been bitten by a rabid dog from her family and beat her to death with their rifle butts.
es: Four soldiers under his command took a woman who had been bitten by a rabid dog from her family and killed her with rifle butts in the middle of the street.

en: One Sunday, two weeks after the occupation, Aureliano entered Gerineldo Márquez’s house and with his usual terseness asked for a mug of coffee without sugar.
vi: Two weeks after the soldiers occupied the village, one Sunday, Aureliano walked into Herinendo Marquez's house with his usual dazed look and asked for a cup of coffee without sugar.
tr: Two weeks after the occupation, on a Sunday, Aureliano went to Gerineldo Marquez's house and, in his usual taciturn manner, asked for a cup of plain coffee.
es: One Sunday, two weeks after the occupation, Aureliano entered Gerineldo Márquez's house and with his usual calm asked for a bowl of coffee without sugar.

en: When the two of them were alone in the kitchen, Aureliano gave his voice an authority that had never been heard before.
vi: When they were alone, unlike on other days, Aureliano authoritatively said, "Prepare the boys, we are going to war."
tr: When the two were alone in the kitchen, Aureliano spoke in a tone of authority that had been unfamiliar until that day.
es: When the two were alone in the kitchen, Aureliano gave his voice an authority that had never been known in him.

en: “Get the boys ready,” he said.
vi: When they were alone, unlike on other days, Aureliano authoritatively said, "Prepare the boys, we are going to war."
tr: Prepare the boys, he said.
es: “Prepare the boys,” he said.

en: “We’re going to war.”
vi: When they were alone, unlike on other days, Aureliano authoritatively said, "Prepare the boys, we are going to war."
tr: We are going to war.
es: “We are going to war.”

en: Gerineldo Márquez did not believe him.
vi: Herinendo Marquez, still in disbelief, asked:
tr: Gerineldo Marquez couldn't believe his ears.
es: Gerineldo Márquez did not believe him.

en: “With what weapons?” he asked.
vi: - Where do we get weapons from?
tr: "With which weapons?" he asked.
es: —With what weapons? —he asked.

en: “With theirs,” Aureliano replied.
vi: - Take it from them, - Aureliano replied.
tr: Aureliano replied, With their weapons.
es: —With theirs —Aureliano replied.

en: Tuesday at midnight in a mad operation, twenty-one men under the age of thirty commanded by Aureliano Buendía, armed with table knives and sharpened tools, took the garrison by surprise, seized the weapons, and in the courtyard executed the captain and the four soldiers who had killed the woman.
vi: At midnight on the third day, during a fierce battle, twenty-one men under thirty years old, under the command of Aureliano, all armed with kitchen knives and pointed iron bars, suddenly ambushed the guards, seized their weapons, and shot dead the captain and four soldiers who had killed the innocent woman right in the yard.
tr: In a reckless move made at midnight on Tuesday, twenty-one men under the command of Aureliano Buendia, none of whom were over thirty years old, armed with kitchen knives and sharpened tools, stormed the garrison, seized the weapons, and executed the captain and the four soldiers who had killed the woman in the garden.
es: On Tuesday at midnight, in a reckless operation, twenty-one men under thirty years old led by Aureliano Buendía, armed with table knives and sharpened irons, took the garrison by surprise, seized the weapons, and executed in the courtyard the captain and the four soldiers who had murdered the woman.

en: That same night, while the sound of the firing squad could be heard, Arcadio was named civil and military leader of the town.
vi: That night, as the order to disarm the execution squad echoed, Accadio was appointed as the commander of military and civil affairs of the village.
tr: That night, before the sound of the firing squad's bullets had even died down, Arcadio was declared the military and civil leader of the village.
es: That same night, while the firing squad's volleys were heard, Arcadio was named the civil and military chief of the town.

en: The married rebels barely had time to take leave of their wives, whom they left to their our devices.
vi: The militia members who had wives barely had time to bid farewell to their spouses before leaving, leaving the women to fend for themselves.
tr: Those among the insurgents who were married only had enough time to bid farewell to their wives.
es: The married rebels barely had time to say goodbye to their wives, whom they left to fend for themselves.

en: They left at dawn, cheered by the people who had been liberated from the terror, to join the forces of the revolutionary general Victorio Medina, who, according to the latest reports, was on his way to Manaure.
vi: They left at dawn, cheered on by the entire village, having escaped the horrors, to join the armed forces of General Victorio Medina, a revolutionary. According to the latest news, he is operating in the Manaure area.
tr: Leaving them behind, they set out at dawn amidst the enthusiastic demonstrations of the people liberated from terror. According to the latest news, they were heading to join the forces of the revolutionary General Victoria Medina, who had set out towards Manaure.
es: They left at dawn, acclaimed by the population freed from terror, to join the forces of the revolutionary general Victorio Medina, who according to the latest news was in the vicinity of Manaure.

en: Before leaving, Aureliano brought Don Apolinar Moscote out of a closet.
vi: Before leaving, Aureliano released old Apolinar Moscote from the iron cage.
tr: Before leaving, Aureliano brought Don Apolinar Moscote out from the closet where he had been hiding.
es: Before leaving, Aureliano pulled Don Apolinar Moscote out of a wardrobe.

en: “Rest easy, father-in-law,” he told him.
vi: "Please stay calm," he said to his father-in-law, "the new government, with their word of honor, will ensure the safety of you and the entire family."
tr: Don't be afraid, father, he said.
es: "You stay calm, father-in-law," he said to him.

en: “The new government guarantees on its word of honor your personal safety and that of your family.”
vi: "Please stay calm," he said to his father-in-law, "the new government, with their word of honor, will ensure the safety of you and the entire family."
tr: The new government promises to protect your and your family's personal safety.
es: "The new government guarantees, on its word of honor, your personal safety and that of your family."

en: Don Apolinar Moscote had trouble identifying that conspirator in high boots and with a rifle slung over his shoulder with the person he had played dominoes with until nine in the evening.
vi: It was very difficult for Don Apolinar Moscote to recognize the revolutionary, wearing high boots and a gun at his hip, as the same person who used to play dominoes with him until nine in the evening.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote couldn't determine whether this rebel, wearing long boots and carrying a rifle over his shoulder, was the same person he used to play dominoes with in the evenings.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote had difficulty identifying that conspirator with high boots and a rifle slung over his back with the man he had played dominoes with until nine o'clock at night.

en: “This is madness, Aurelito,” he exclaimed.
vi: - Is this a joke, Aureliano?
tr: This is madness, Aurelito, he shouted.
es: —This is nonsense, Aurelito —he exclaimed.

en: “Not madness,” Aureliano said.
vi: - Is this a joke, Aureliano?
tr: Aureliano said, It's not madness, it's war.
es: —No nonsense —said Aureliano—.

en: “War.
vi: - he exclaimed.
tr: Aureliano said, It's not madness, it's war.
es: It's war.

en: And don’t call me Aurelito any more.
vi: - I'm not joking, - Aureliano said, - this is a real war.
tr: And don't call me Aurelito anymore.
es: And don't call me Aurelito anymore, I am now Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: Now I’m Colonel Aureliano Buendía.”
vi: Please don't call me just Aureliano anymore, because I am now Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: I'm now Colonel Aureliano Buendia.
es: And don't call me Aurelito anymore, I am now Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: Chapter 6
vi: Chapter 6
tr: I'm now Colonel Aureliano Buendia.
es: And don't call me Aurelito anymore, I am now Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: COLONEL AURELIANO BUENDÍA organized thirty-two armed uprisings and he lost them all.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía launched thirty-two armed uprisings and failed completely.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia organized thirty-two armed uprisings, and he was defeated in all of them.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía promoted thirty-two armed uprisings and lost them all.

en: He had seventeen male children by seventeen different women and they were exterminated one after the other on a single night before the oldest one had reached the age of thirty-five.
vi: Having relations with seventeen girls in different villages, he fathered seventeen sons, all of whom were killed one by one in a single night before the eldest turned thirty-five.
tr: He had seventeen sons by seventeen different women, and before the oldest reached thirty-five, all seventeen were killed in one night.
es: He had seventeen male children by seventeen different women, who were exterminated one by one in a single night, before the oldest turned thirty-five years old.

en: He survived fourteen attempts on his life, seventy-three ambushes, and a firing squad.
vi: He survived fourteen assassination attempts, seventy-three ambushes, and a firing squad.
tr: He survived fourteen assassination attempts, seventy-three ambushes, and a firing squad.
es: He escaped fourteen assassination attempts, seventy-three ambushes, and a firing squad.

en: He lived through a dose of strychnine in his coffee that was enough to kill a horse.
vi: He survived poisoning by strychnine powder mixed in his coffee in a dose sufficient to kill a horse.
tr: He drank strychnine-laced coffee strong enough to knock out a big horse and still managed to save his skin.
es: He survived a dose of strychnine in his coffee that would have been enough to kill a horse.

en: He refused the Order of Merit, which the President of the Republic awarded him.
vi: He refused the Order of Merit awarded by the President of the Republic.
tr: He refused the medal of merit given by the President.
es: He rejected the Order of Merit that the president of the republic awarded him.

en: He rose to be Commander in Chief of the revolutionary forces, with jurisdiction and command from one border to the other, and the man most feared by the government, but he never let himself be photographed.
vi: He became the Commander-in-Chief of the revolutionary armed forces, wielding authority from one country to another, and made the government wary, but he never allowed anyone to photograph him.
tr: He rose to the command of the revolutionary forces, his fame spread from one border to the other throughout the country, he became the person the government feared the most, and he never allowed his picture to be taken.
es: He became the general commander of the revolutionary forces, with jurisdiction and command from one border to the other, and the most feared man by the government, but he never allowed a photograph to be taken of him.

en: He declined the lifetime pension offered him after the war and until old age he made his living from the little gold fishes that he manufactured in his workshop in Macondo.
vi: He declined the pension due to him after the war and lived to old age thanks to the goldfish he produced in his jewelry workshop in the village of Macondo.
tr: After the war, he refused the lifelong pension that was offered to him and even in his old age, he earned his living by making silver fish in his workshop in Macondo.
es: He declined the lifetime pension offered to him after the war and lived to old age on the goldfish he made in his workshop in Macondo.

en: Although he always fought at the head of his men, the only wound that he received was the one he gave himself after signing the Treaty of Neerlandia, which put an end to almost twenty years of civil war.
vi: Although he always led his army in battle, the only wound on his body was self-inflicted after signing the Neclandia truce, ending twenty years of civil war.
tr: Despite leading his men into battle in every skirmish, the only wound he received was by his own hand.
es: Although he always fought at the front of his men, the only wound he received was self-inflicted after signing the capitulation of Neerlandia, which ended almost twenty years of civil wars.

en: He shot himself in the chest with a pistol and the bullet came out through his back without damaging any vital organ.
vi: He shot himself in the chest with a revolver, and the bullet exited through his back without harming any vital organs.
tr: After signing the Neerlandia Treaty, which ended the twenty-year-long civil war, he shot himself in the chest, but the bullet missed all vital organs and exited through his back as smoothly as pulling a hair from butter.
es: He shot himself in the chest with a pistol, and the bullet exited through his back without injuring any vital organs.

en: The only thing left of all that was a street that bore his name in Macondo.
vi: The only thing that remained from twenty years of civil war was a street in Macondo named after him.
tr: The only thing that remained from all this was a street in Macondo that bore his name.
es: The only thing that remained from all of that was a street with his name in Macondo.

en: And yet, as he declared a few years before he died of old age, he had not expected any of that on the dawn he left with his twenty-one men to join the forces of General Victorio Medina.
vi: However, according to his declaration a few years before dying of old age, even that was not what he had hoped for on the morning he and twenty-one strong young men set out to join the armed forces of General Victoriano Medina.
tr: However, a few years before he died of old age, as he himself said, at dawn when he set out with twenty-one companions to join General Victorio Medina's forces, he did not expect any of this.
es: However, as he declared a few years before dying of old age, he did not even expect that on the morning he left with his twenty-one men to join the forces of General Victorio Medina.

en: “We leave Macondo in your care.” was all that he said to Arcadio before leaving.
vi: - We are leaving Macondo to you, - that is all he said to Arcadio before setting off.
tr: All he said to Arcadio before leaving was, "We are leaving Macondo to you."
es: —We leave Macondo to you —was all he said to Arcadio before leaving—.

en: “We leave it to you in good shape, try to have it in better shape when we return.”
vi: - we are pleased to leave it to you. So try to take care of it so that when we return, we find it better.
tr: "We are leaving it in good condition; let us find it in better condition when we return."
es: We leave it in good shape, make sure we find it better.

en: Arcadio gave a very personal interpretation to the instructions.
vi: Accadio responded to that advice in his own way.
tr: Arcadio interpreted these words as it suited him.
es: Arcadio gave a very personal interpretation to the recommendation.

en: He invented a uniform with the braid and epaulets of a marshal, inspired by the prints in one of Melquíades’ books, and around his waist he buckled the saber with gold tassels that had belonged to the executed captain.
vi: He tailored a military uniform with marshal's epaulets and fringes, modeled after the illustrations in Menkyadet's book, and strapped to his waist the gold-inlaid sword of the executed captain.
tr: He fashioned a uniform for himself. He rummaged through Melquiades' books from cover to cover and acquired a jacket with braids and epaulettes, like a marshal's uniform. He secured the sword at his waist with gold-embroidered buckles he had stripped from the captain who was executed by firing squad.
es: He invented a uniform with marshal's stripes and epaulets, inspired by the illustrations in one of Melquíades' books, and hung the saber with golden tassels of the executed captain at his waist.

en: He set up the two artillery pieces at the entrance to town, put uniforms on his former pupils, who had been amused by his fiery proclamations, and let them wander through the streets armed in order to give outsiders an impression of invulnerability.
vi: He placed two cannons right at the village gate, dressed his former students—who had been driven mad by his fiery proclamations—in uniforms, and had them swagger around the village armed, giving strangers the impression that this was an impregnable military position.
tr: He positioned the cannons at the entrance of the village, outfitted his former students who had risen up with uniforms, and sent them out into the streets with fiery speeches.
es: He placed the two artillery pieces at the entrance of the town, uniformed his former students, exacerbated by his incendiary proclamations, and let them wander armed through the streets to give outsiders an impression of invulnerability.

en: It was a double-edged deception, for the government did not dare attack the place for ten months, but when it did it unleashed such a large force against it that resistance was liquidated in a half hour.
vi: It was a double-edged game because it prevented the government from daring to attack the square for ten months, but it also meant that when the government did order an attack, the military used such overwhelming force that they crushed the resistance within half an hour.
tr: In this way, he wanted to create the impression among outsiders that the village was defended by invincible forces. This was a double-edged deception. Because the government did not dare to attack the village for ten months; and when they finally did, they attacked with such overwhelming force that the village's resistance crumbled within half an hour.
es: It was a double-edged trick because the government did not dare attack the plaza for ten months, but when it did, it unleashed such a disproportionate force that it crushed the resistance in half an hour.

en: From the first day of his rule Arcadio revealed his predilection for decrees.
vi: From the very first day of exercising his power, Accadio revealed himself to be an arrogant person.
tr: Arcadio revealed his keen interest in proclamations from the very first day of his administration.
es: From the first day of his mandate, Arcadio revealed his fondness for decrees.

en: He would read as many as four a day in order to decree and institute everything that came into his head.
vi: Every day, he would read orders until four in the afternoon to command and arrange everything according to his will.
tr: He would announce everything that came to his mind through a proclamation, sometimes issuing four decrees in a single day.
es: He read up to four daily to order and arrange everything that crossed his mind.

en: He imposed obligatory military service for men over eighteen, declared to be public property any animals walking the streets after six in the evening, and made men who were overage wear red armbands.
vi: He enforced military conscription on those aged eighteen and above, declared the requisition of any animals still wandering the streets after six in the evening, and required elderly men to wear a red armband.
tr: He mandated compulsory military service for those over eighteen, declared that animals wandering aimlessly after six in the evening would be considered public property, and required the elderly to wear a red armband.
es: He implemented mandatory military service from the age of eighteen, declared animals that roamed the streets after six in the evening to be of public utility, and imposed on adult men the obligation to wear a red armband.

en: He sequestered Father Nicanor in the parish house under pain of execution and prohibited him from saying mass or ringing the bells unless it was for a Liberal victory.
vi: Imprisoning Father Nicanor in the monastery with the threat of shooting him and forbidding him from performing mass and ringing the bells unless it was to celebrate the victory of the Liberal faction.
tr: He had cornered Peder Nicanor, threatened him with torture, and forbidden him from holding services and ringing the bell unless it was for the victory of the Liberals.
es: He confined Father Nicanor in the parish house under threat of execution and forbade him from saying mass or ringing the bells except to celebrate liberal victories.

en: In order that no one would doubt the severity of his aims, he ordered a firing squad organized in the square and had it shoot at a scarecrow.
vi: To ensure that no one doubted the seriousness of his policies, he ordered a firing squad to practice shooting at a scarecrow in the square right in front of the public.
tr: To ensure that no one doubted the decisiveness of his orders, he lined up a firing squad in the village square and had a scarecrow shot.
es: To ensure no one doubted the severity of his intentions, he ordered a firing squad to train in the public square by shooting at a scarecrow.

en: At first no one took him seriously.
vi: At first, no one took it seriously.
tr: At first, no one took him seriously.
es: At first, no one took him seriously.

en: They were, after all, schoolchildren playing at being grown-ups.
vi: It was just the students playing at being adults.
tr: After all, they were all just children pretending to be important.
es: After all, they were just schoolboys playing at being grown-ups.

en: But one night, when Arcadio went into Catarino’s store, the trumpeter in the group greeted him with a fanfare that made the customers laugh and Arcadio had him shot for disrespect for the authorities.
vi: But one night, when Arcadio entered Catarino's restaurant, the trumpet player greeted him with a mocking fanfare that made the crowd burst into laughter, so he ordered the man to be shot for disrespecting authority.
tr: But one night, Arcadio went to Catarino's shop. When the drummer saw him, he greeted him with a tremolo. The people there started to laugh. Arcadio, losing his temper, had the drummer shot for disrespecting the authorities.
es: But one night, when Arcadio entered Catarino's store, the band's trumpeter greeted him with a fanfare that provoked the laughter of the customers, and Arcadio had him executed for disrespecting authority.

en: People who protested were put on bread and water with their ankles in a set of stocks that he had set up in a schoolroom.
vi: For those who dared to oppose him, he ordered them to be handcuffed and locked in a jail that was once a classroom, feeding them only bland bread and water.
tr: He also imprisoned those who opposed this by locking their ankles between two logs and giving them nothing but bread and water.
es: Those who protested were put on bread and water with their ankles in a stock he installed in a room of the school.

en: “You murderer!” Úrsula would shout at him every time she learned of some new arbitrary act.
vi: "You are a murderer," Ursula scolded him whenever she learned of a new act of cruelty by her grandson.
tr: When Ursula learned of his arbitrary actions, she would shout in his face, Murderer!
es: "You are a murderer!" Úrsula would shout at him every time she learned of a new atrocity.

en: “When Aureliano finds out he’s going to shoot you and I’ll be the first one to be glad.”
vi: "If Aureliano knew, he would kill you, and I would be the first in this village to feel satisfied."
tr: When Aureliano hears about what you've done, he'll have you shot, and I'll be the first to cheer.
es: "When Aureliano finds out, he will have you executed, and I will be the first to rejoice."

en: But it was of no use.
vi: But her scoldings were in vain.
tr: But what was the use of her wishes?
es: But it was all in vain.

en: Arcadio continued tightening the tourniquet with unnecessary rigor until he became the cruelest ruler that Macondo had ever known.
vi: Arcadio continued to tighten the screws of his oppressive machine until he became the bloodiest authority Macondo had ever seen.
tr: Arcadio increased the pressure more and more, squeezing the people tighter and tighter. In the end, he became the most ruthless ruler Macondo had ever seen.
es: Arcadio continued tightening the screws of unnecessary rigor until he became the cruelest ruler Macondo had ever known.

en: “Now let them suffer the difference,” Don Apolinar Moscote said on one occasion.
vi: "Now we suffer from the struggle," Don Apolinar Moscote said on several occasions: "This is the Paradise of the Liberals."
tr: One day, Don Apolinar Moscote made a mistake, saying they should beat their heads against the wall to understand the difference.
es: "Now suffer the difference," said Don Apolinar Moscote on one occasion.

en: “This is the Liberal paradise.”
vi: "Now we suffer from the struggle," Don Apolinar Moscote said on several occasions: "This is the Paradise of the Liberals."
tr: This is what they call the Liberal paradise, he said.
es: "This is the liberal paradise."

en: Arcadio found out about it.
vi: Arcadio knew.
tr: These words reached Arcadio's ears.
es: Arcadio found out.

en: At the head of a patrol he assaulted the house, destroyed the furniture, flogged the daughters, and dragged out Don Apolinar Moscote.
vi: Leading a squad of soldiers, he broke into houses, smashed furniture, beat the daughters, and dragged Don Apolinar Moscote along.
tr: He led the patrols to raid Moscote's house, smashed his belongings, and had his daughters whipped. He dragged Don Apolinar Moscote outside.
es: Leading a patrol, he stormed the house, destroyed the furniture, beat the daughters, and dragged Don Apolinar Moscote away.

en: When Úrsula burst into the courtyard of headquarters, after having gone through the town shouting shame and brandishing with rage a pitch-covered whip, Arcadio himself was preparing to give the squad the command to fire.
vi: Just as Arcadio was about to personally order the firing squad to shoot Don Apolinar Moscote, Ursula, after angrily shouting and waving a tarred leather whip to part the crowd, made a commotion in the barracks yard: "You scoundrel, have some respect!"
tr: When Ursula heard what had happened, she went mad with rage. Grabbing the whip, she ran to the headquarters, shouting and cursing. As Ursula burst into the courtyard, Arcadio was about to give the order to fire.
es: When Úrsula burst into the barracks courtyard, after crossing the town clamoring with shame and brandishing a tarred whip in rage, Arcadio himself was about to give the order to fire to the firing squad.

en: “I dare you to, bastard!”
vi: Just as Arcadio was about to personally order the firing squad to shoot Don Apolinar Moscote, Ursula, after angrily shouting and waving a tarred leather whip to part the crowd, made a commotion in the barracks yard: "You scoundrel, have some respect!"
tr: "Hit me if you dare, you son of a bitch!" he shouted.
es: —Dare, bastard!

en: Úrsula shouted.
vi: Just as Arcadio was about to personally order the firing squad to shoot Don Apolinar Moscote, Ursula, after angrily shouting and waving a tarred leather whip to part the crowd, made a commotion in the barracks yard: "You scoundrel, have some respect!"
tr: Without giving Arcadio a chance to open his mouth, she shouted, "Alright, you murderer!" and brought down the whip.
es: —shouted Úrsula.

en: Before Arcadio had time to read she let go with the first blow of the lash.
vi: Before Arcadio could react, she lashed him with the whip, "You murderer.
tr: Without giving Arcadio a chance to open his mouth, she shouted, "Alright, you murderer!" and brought down the whip.
es: Before Arcadio had time to react, she delivered the first lash.

en: “I dare you to, murderer!” she shouted.
vi: You are too insolent," she screamed.
tr: Without giving Arcadio a chance to open his mouth, she shouted, "Alright, you murderer!" and brought down the whip.
es: "Dare, murderer," she shouted.

en: “And kill me too, son of an evil mother.
vi: "You might as well kill me too, you scoundrel.
tr: "Kill me too, son of a devilish mother."
es: "And kill me too, you son of a bad mother.

en: That way I won’t have the eyes to weep for the shame of having raised a monster.”
vi: That way, I won't have to cry in shame for having raised a traitor."
tr: "Kill me so I don't have to shed tears for raising a monster."
es: That way I won't have eyes to cry over the shame of having raised a monster."

en: Whipping him without mercy, she chased him to the back of the courtyard, where Arcadio curled up like a snail in its shell.
vi: She continued to whip him mercilessly, chasing him to the end of the yard, making him squirm like a snail.
tr: Ursula was bringing down the whip mercilessly. Whipping and whipping, she chased Arcadio to the back yard. Arcadio shrank into a corner like a snail retreating into its shell.
es: Whipping him mercilessly, she chased him to the back of the yard, where Arcadio curled up like a snail.

en: Don Apolinar Moscote was unconscious, tied to the post where previously they had had the scarecrow that had been cut to pieces by shots fired in fun.
vi: Don Apolinar Moscote stood petrified, tied to the post where the scarecrows had previously been blown to bits by the firing squad's bullets.
tr: Don Apolinar Moscote, who was tied to the place where the scarecrow they had previously shot and shattered for fun stood, had passed out.
es: Don Apolinar Moscote was unconscious, tied to the post where they had previously kept the scarecrow, torn apart by training shots.

en: The boys in the squad scattered, fearful that Úrsula would go after them too.
vi: The boys of the execution squad scattered because they were afraid Ursula would beat them to death.
tr: The children in the firing squad scattered like chicks out of fear that Ursula might beat them too.
es: The boys of the platoon scattered, fearful that Úrsula would end up venting her anger on them.

en: But she did not even look at them.
vi: But she didn't even look at them.
tr: However, Ursula didn't even look at them.
es: But she didn't even look at them.

en: She left Arcadio with his uniform torn, roaring with pain and rage, and she untied Don Apolinar Moscote and took him home.
vi: Leaving Arcadio in his disheveled, ragged military uniform, groaning in pain and anger, she went to untie Don Apolinar Moscote and led him home.
tr: She left Arcadio, whose collar and cuffs were torn, screaming in pain and anger; she went and untied Don Apolinar Moscote and took him home.
es: She left Arcadio with his uniform dragging, roaring in pain and rage, and untied Don Apolinar Moscote to take him to his house.

en: Before leaving the headquarters she released the prisoners from the stocks.
vi: Before leaving the barracks, she also released the political prisoners.
tr: Before leaving the headquarters, she also freed the prisoners who were tied to the log.
es: Before leaving the barracks, she released the prisoners from the stocks.

en: From that time on she was the one who ruled in the town.
vi: Since that time, she has been the ruler of Macondo village.
tr: From that day on, Ursula was the one who governed the village.
es: From then on, it was she who ruled the town.

en: She reestablished Sunday masses, suspended the use of red armbands, and abrogated the harebrained decrees.
vi: She restored the Sunday mass, abolished the wearing of red armbands, and disbanded the violent patrols.
tr: She reinstated the Sunday masses, opposed the wearing of red armbands, and repealed the absurd decrees.
es: She reinstated Sunday mass, suspended the use of red armbands, and disqualified the arbitrary edicts.

en: But in spite of her strength, she still wept over her unfortunate fate.
vi: But during her moments of rest, she still lamented her unfortunate fate.
tr: Despite all her strength, she couldn't help but cry over the misfortunes that befell her.
es: But despite her strength, she continued to mourn the misfortune of her fate.

en: She felt so much alone that she sought the useless company of her husband, who had been forgotten under the chestnut tree.
vi: She felt so lonely that she had to seek out her forgotten husband under the chestnut tree.
tr: She felt such great loneliness that she even sought solace in chatting with her husband forgotten under the chestnut tree.
es: She felt so alone that she sought the useless company of her husband forgotten under the chestnut tree.

en: “Look what we’ve come to,” she would tell him as the June rains threatened to knock the shelter down.
vi: "My dear, look at our plight, isn't it tragic," she said to him as the July downpours threatened to topple the palm-leaf hut.
tr: On days when the June rains poured as if they would destroy the arbor, she would say, Look at what we've come to.
es: "Look at what we've come to," she would say, while the June rains threatened to bring down the palm shelter.

en: “Look at the empty house, our children scattered all over the world, and the two of us alone again, the same as in the beginning.”
vi: "Look at the deserted house, our children scattered across the world, and once again it's just the two of us together like in the beginning."
tr: Look at this house, it's deserted. Our children have scattered in all directions. It's just you and me left alone. Just like in the beginning.
es: "Look at the empty house, our children scattered around the world, and the two of us alone again like at the beginning."

en: José Arcadio Buendía, sunk in an abyss of unawareness, was deaf to her lamentations.
vi: José Arcadio Buendía was perpetually lost in a deep unconscious state, unresponsive as stone to her laments.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia, who had already fallen into the abyss of unconsciousness, couldn't even hear what his wife was saying.
es: José Arcadio Buendía, sunk in an abyss of unconsciousness, was deaf to her laments.

en: At the beginning of his madness he would announce his daily needs with urgent Latin phrases.
vi: In the early days of his madness, he would use incomprehensible Latin phrases to communicate his daily essential needs to everyone.
tr: In the early days of his madness, he would express his daily needs in Latin words.
es: At the onset of his madness, he would announce his daily urgencies with pressing Latin phrases.

en: In fleeting clear spells of lucidity, when Amaranta would bring him his meals he would tell her what bothered him most and would accept her sucking glasses and mustard plasters in a docile way.
vi: During brief moments of lucidity, when Amaranta brought him food, he would inform her of his greatest discomforts, and he obediently took mustard seed medicine and allowed her to perform bloodletting.
tr: When the clouds enveloping his mind parted, even if only for short periods, he spoke sensibly, and when Amaranta brought his meal, he would tell her what was bothering him and did not object to her applying a mustard plaster or using a cupping glass on his back.
es: In fleeting moments of lucidity, when Amaranta brought him food, he would communicate his most bothersome grievances and would submit docilely to her cupping and mustard plasters.

en: But at the time when Úrsula went to lament by his side he had lost all contact with reality.
vi: But during the period when Úrsula lamented beside him, he had completely lost the ability to interact with reality.
tr: When Ama Ursula started to lament to him, Jose Arcadio Buendia had already severed all ties with reality.
es: But by the time Úrsula went to lament by his side, he had lost all contact with reality.

en: She would bathe him bit by bit as he sat on his stool while she gave him news of the family.
vi: He sat in the chair while she bathed him, one part at a time. As she bathed him, she told him stories about the household.
tr: Ursula would slowly clean him without moving him from his place, while also informing him about what was happening within the family.
es: She would bathe him in parts while he sat on the little stool, giving him news of the family.

en: “Aureliano went to war more than four months ago and we haven’t heard anything about him,” she would say, scrubbing his back with a soaped brush.
vi: "Aureliano has been at war for four months now, and we still haven't received any news about him," she said while scrubbing him with soap.
tr: As she scrubbed her husband's back with soap, she would say, "It's been four months since Aureliano went to war, and we haven't heard a word from him.""Jose Arcadio has grown into a big man and returned.""Even you would look small next to him.""He has tattoos all over his body.""Unfortunately, he does nothing but bring us disgrace.
es: "Aureliano has gone to war, it's been more than four months now, and we haven't heard from him," she would say, scrubbing his back with a soapy sponge.

en: “José Arcadio came back a big man, taller than you, and all covered with needle-work, but he only brought shame to our house.”
vi: "José Arcadio has returned; he is a real man, taller than even you, and covered in tattoos." "He came back only to bring shame to our family."
es: "José Arcadio came back, a big man taller than you and all embroidered in cross-stitch, but he only came to bring shame to our house."

en: She thought she noticed, however, that her husband would grow sad with the bad news.
vi: However, she noticed that her husband seemed saddened by the bad news.
tr: Upon hearing the bad news, Ursula felt as if her husband was saddened.
es: She thought she observed, however, that her husband grew sad with the bad news.

en: Then she decided to lie to him.
vi: So she changed her tone and began to lie to him, "Don't believe what I just said," she said, while sprinkling ashes over his excrement to scoop it up.
tr: So she decided to lie to him.
es: So she opted to lie to him.

en: ‘Rou won’t believe what I’m going to tell you,” she said as she threw ashes over his excrement in order to pick it up with the shovel.
vi: So she changed her tone and began to lie to him, "Don't believe what I just said," she said, while sprinkling ashes over his excrement to scoop it up.
tr: While sprinkling ash over her husband's filth before scooping it up with a shovel, she said, "Look, I'll tell you something you won't believe.""God wanted Jose Arcadio and Rebeca to get married, and now there's no end to their happiness."
es: "Don't believe what I'm telling you," she would say, while sprinkling ashes over his excrement to collect it with the shovel.

en: “God willed that José Arcadio and Rebeca should get married, and now they’re very happy.”
vi: "God wants José Arcadio and Rebeca to marry, and now they are living very happily."
tr: While sprinkling ash over her husband's filth before scooping it up with a shovel, she said, "Look, I'll tell you something you won't believe.""God wanted Jose Arcadio and Rebeca to get married, and now there's no end to their happiness."
es: "God wanted José Arcadio and Rebeca to get married, and now they are very happy."

en: She got to be so sincere in the deception that she ended up by consoling herself with her own lies.
vi: Then she became so sincere in her lies that she herself felt comforted by her own deceptions.
