tr: He narrated these deceptions so sincerely that in the end, he began to console himself with his own lies.
es: She became so sincere in the deceit that she herself ended up consoling herself with her own lies.

en: “Arcadio is a serious man now,” she said, “and very brave, and a fine-looking young man with his uniform and saber.”
vi: "Arcadio has become a respectable young man," she said, "very brave and very handsome in his uniform with a sword at his side."
tr: Arcadio has become a dignified man now, he would say. Brave, oh so brave. Handsome, oh so handsome. You should see him when he puts on his uniform and straps on his sword.
es: "Arcadio is already a serious man," she would say, "and very brave, and very handsome in his uniform and with his saber."

en: It was like speaking to a dead man, for José Arcadio Buendía was already beyond the reach of any worry.
vi: All these words were spoken as if to a dead person, for José Arcadio Buendía was serene, very serene, beyond all worries and concerns.
tr: Yet, talking to him was no different than talking to a dead man, indistinguishable.
es: It was like talking to a dead man, because José Arcadio Buendía was already beyond the reach of any concern.

en: But she insisted.
vi: But she did not stop.
tr: Yet, talking to him was no different than talking to a dead man, indistinguishable.
es: But she insisted.

en: He seemed so peaceful, so indifferent to everything that she decided to release him.
vi: She found him so gentle, so much like everyone else, that she untied him.
tr: Because Jose Arcadio Buendia seemed so harmless, so withdrawn from the world, that Ursula decided to unravel him.
es: She saw him so meek, so indifferent to everything, that she decided to untie him.

en: He did not even move from his stool.
vi: He remained in the chair, as if the restraints were no longer necessary, because it seemed that a force stronger than any visible bonds had tied him to the chestnut tree.
tr: After being unraveled, Jose Arcadio Buendia did not move from his place.
es: He didn't even move from the little stool.

en: He stayed there, exposed to the sun and the rain, as if the thongs were unnecessary, for a dominion superior to any visible bond kept him tied to the trunk of the chestnut tree.
vi: He remained in the chair, as if the restraints were no longer necessary, because it seemed that a force stronger than any visible bonds had tied him to the chestnut tree.
tr: As if bound to the trunk of the chestnut tree by invisible bonds stronger than any rope, he sat there, come rain or shine.
es: He remained exposed to the sun and the rain, as if the ropes were unnecessary, because a force superior to any visible tie kept him bound to the trunk of the chestnut tree.

en: Toward August, when winter began to last forever, Úrsula was finally able to give him a piece of news that sounded like the truth.
vi: Around August, when the winter began to drag on, Úrsula was able to give him some news:
tr: Towards August, when it seemed like winter would never end, Ursula was able to give him news that resembled reality:
es: By the month of August, when the winter began to seem eternal, Úrsula was finally able to give him news that seemed true.

en: “Would you believe it that good luck is still pouring down on us?” she told him.
vi: - Hey, luck is still with us, - she told him, - Amaranta and that Italian guy who fixed the automatic piano are going to get married.
tr: "Do you still believe our luck is holding?" he began.
es: —Notice that good luck keeps hounding us —he said to her—.

en: “Amaranta and the pianola Italian are going to get married.”
vi: - Hey, luck is still with us, - she told him, - Amaranta and that Italian guy who fixed the automatic piano are going to get married.
tr: Amaranta and the Italian lantern maker are getting married.
es: Amaranta and the Italian from the pianola are going to get married.

en: Amaranta and Pietro Crespi had, in fact, deepened their friendship, protected by Úrsula, who this time did not think it necessary to watch over the visits.
vi: Indeed, Amaranta and Pietro Crespi had a deep friendship. Both were lovingly cared for by Úrsula. This time she felt it was unnecessary to sit and watch over the young couple as they conversed.
tr: Indeed, Amaranta and Pietro Crespi had advanced their friendship. Ursula, who no longer saw it necessary to watch over them, also supported this friendship.
es: Amaranta and Pietro Crespi, indeed, had deepened their friendship, sheltered by Úrsula's trust, who this time did not find it necessary to monitor the visits.

en: It was a twilight engagement.
vi: It was a love in the twilight.
tr: Everyone considered them as engaged.
es: It was a twilight courtship.

en: The Italian would arrive at dusk, with a gardenia in his buttonhole, and he would translate Petrarch’s sonnets for Amaranta.
vi: The Italian man, with an ivory white gardenia flower standing out on his lapel, would come to the house in the afternoon and translate Petrarch's sonnets into Spanish for Amaranta.
tr: The Italian, arriving at dusk with a daffodil pinned to his jacket collar, would translate Petrarch's poems for Amaranta.
es: The Italian would arrive at dusk, with a gardenia in his buttonhole, and translate Petrarch's sonnets for Amaranta.

en: They would sit on the porch, suffocated by the oregano and the roses, he reading and she sewing lace cuffs, indifferent to the shocks and bad news of the war, until the mosquitoes made them take refuge in the parlor.
vi: The two of them would sit in the hallway, thick with the scent of roses and begonias. He read poetry, she wove lace, unaware of the shocking events and bad news from the front, until the mosquitoes bit them so fiercely that they had to run into the living room.
tr: They would sit on the terrace, breathless from the scent of hydrangeas and roses, -without caring whether there was a war or bad news- one reading poetry, the other sewing lace cuffs, until the mosquitoes made the terrace uninhabitable and drove them inside.
es: They would stay in the corridor suffocated by oregano and roses, he reading and she weaving bobbin lace, indifferent to the shocks and bad news of the war, until the mosquitoes forced them to take refuge in the living room.

en: Amaranta’s sensibility, her discreet but enveloping tenderness had been wearing an invisible web about her fiancé, which he had to push aside materially with his pale and ringless fingers in order to leave the house at eight o’clock.
vi: Amaranta's gentle affection, with her subtly tender words, was like an invisible spider web that gradually enveloped her beloved, so much so that by eight o'clock in the evening, he had to use his pale, ringed fingers to untangle himself and go home.
tr: Amaranta's sensible and modest demeanor, her measured but sincere closeness, had woven an invisible net around her fiancé. When Pietro Crespi reluctantly left the house at eight in the evening, it was as if he was pushing aside this net with his ringless fingers to make his way.
es: Amaranta's sensitivity, her discreet but enveloping tenderness, had woven around the suitor an invisible web that he had to physically push aside with his pale, ringless fingers to leave the house at eight.

en: They had put together a delightful album with the postcards that Pietro Crespi received from Italy.
vi: The two of them had made a wonderful album with postcards sent from Italy to Pietro Crespi.
tr: They had placed the postcards sent to Pietro Crespi from Italy into an album.
es: They had made a precious album with the postcards that Pietro Crespi received from Italy.

en: They were pictures of lovers in lonely parks, with vignettes of hearts pierced with arrows and golden ribbons held by doves.
vi: These were photographs of lovers in secluded gardens, decorated with drawings of hearts pierced by arrows and golden ribbons entwining pairs of doves.
tr: The cards had pictures of lovers holding hands in deserted parks. In the corners, there were hearts pierced by arrows and golden ribbons in the beaks of doves.
es: They were images of lovers in solitary parks, with vignettes of pierced hearts and golden ribbons held by doves.

en: “I’ve been to this park in Florence,” Pietro Crespi would say, going through the cards.
vi: "I know this park in Florence," he said, as he flipped through the postcards."
tr: While looking at the cards, Pietro Crespi would say, I went to this park when I was in Florence.
es: "I know this park in Florence," Pietro Crespi would say, going through the postcards. "

en: “A person can put out his hand and the birds will come to feed.”
vi: As soon as one extends a hand, the birds immediately swoop down to eat.
tr: In that park, you take some feed in your hand, open your palm, and feed the birds.
es: One extends a hand and the birds come down to eat.

en: Sometimes, over a watercolor of Venice, nostalgia would transform the smell of mud and putrefying shellfish of the canals into the warm aroma of flowers.
vi: "Sometimes, in front of a nursery, nostalgia transformed the smell of mud and rotten fish in the canals of Venice into a gentle floral fragrance.
tr: Sometimes, while looking at a watercolor painting of Venice, homesickness would turn the slimy mud of the canals, the acrid smell of sticky jellyfish, into the scent of flowers in the Italian's nose.
es: "Sometimes, before a watercolor of Venice, nostalgia would transform the smell of mud and rotten seafood from the canals into the warm aromas of flowers.

en: Amaranta would sigh, laugh, and dream of a second homeland of handsome men and beautiful women who spoke a childlike language with ancient cities of whose past grandeur only the cats among the rubble remained.
vi: Amaranta sighed, laughed, and dreamed of a second homeland filled with magnificent young men and women speaking the language of children, in ancient cities whose former glory now only lingered in the form of cats prowling among the ruins.
tr: Amaranta would sigh, laugh, and dream of a second homeland filled with old cities where handsome men and beautiful women speaking a childlike language lived, and where only cats roamed the garbage dumps of its former glory.
es: Amaranta would sigh, laugh, dream of a second homeland of beautiful men and women who spoke a child's language, with ancient cities whose past grandeur was only evidenced by the cats among the ruins.

en: After crossing the ocean in search of it, after having confused passion with the vehement stroking of Rebeca, Pietro Crespi had found love.
vi: After crossing the vast ocean in his quest, after mistaking it for the passionate moments with Rebeca, Pietro Crespi had now found love.
tr: After crossing oceans to find this second homeland and confusing passion with love through Rebeca's fiery embraces, Pietro Crespi had found true love.
es: After crossing the ocean in search of it, after confusing it with passion in Rebeca's vehement caresses, Pietro Crespi had found love.

en: Happiness was accompanied by prosperity.
vi: Joy brought with it wealth, and now his shop occupied nearly an entire block.
tr: Alongside happiness, he had also attained wealth.
es: Happiness brought prosperity with it.

en: His warehouse at that time occupied almost a whole block and it was a hothouse of fantasy, with reproductions of the bell tower of Florence that told time with a concert of carillons, and music boxes from Sorrento and compacts from China that sang five-note melodies when they were opened, and all the musical instruments imaginable and all the mechanical toys that could be conceived.
vi: It was a gigantic, magical display case that restored Florentine alarm clocks, which, each time they struck the hour, would ring out a chorus of bells, sold Chinese powder boxes that delighted the fingers when opened, and offered every imaginable musical instrument and wind-up toy one could dream of.
tr: At that time, his shop and warehouse extended from one street to the next. From a model of the bell tower in Florence, which rang tiny bells every hour, to musical boxes from Sorrento, to cabinets from China that played music when opened, the shop had everything imaginable, from every kind of musical instrument to every conceivable type of mechanical toy.
es: His store then occupied almost an entire block, and it was a fantasy greenhouse, with reproductions of the Florence bell tower that chimed the hour with a carillon concert, and musical boxes from Sorrento, and Chinese powder boxes that sang five-note tunes when opened, and all the musical instruments one could imagine and all the mechanical devices one could conceive.

en: Bruno Crespi, his younger brother, was in charge of the store because Pietro Crespi barely had enough time to take care of the music school.
vi: Bruno Crespi, his youngest son, sat watching over the store because he was not yet capable of handling the music class.
tr: Since Pietro Crespi could only spare time to give music lessons, the shop was run by his brother, Bruna Crespi.
es: Bruno Crespi, his younger brother, was in charge of the store, because he couldn't keep up with the demands of the music school.

en: Thanks to him the Street of the Turks, with its dazzling display of knickknacks, became a melodic oasis where one could forget Arcadio’s arbitrary acts and the distant nightmare of the war.
vi: Thanks to Pietro Crespi, the Turkish street quickly transformed the splendid display of precious goods into a serene and melodious place to forget the brutal actions of Arcadio and the perpetual gloom of war.
tr: Thanks to Pietro Crespi, Turkish Street turned into an oasis of melodies that made people forget Arcadio's whimsical behavior and the nightmare of the distant war.
es: Thanks to him, the Street of the Turks, with its dazzling display of trinkets, became a melodic haven to forget Arcadio's arbitrariness and the distant nightmare of the war.

en: When Úrsula ordered the revival of Sunday mass, Pietro Crespi donated a German harmonium to the church, organized a children’s chorus, and prepared a Gregorian repertory that added a note of splendor to Father Nicanor’s quiet rite.
vi: When Úrsula decided to restore the Sunday mass ceremonies, Pietro Crespi donated a children's organ to the church and prepared a song that would brighten Father Nicanor's somber mass.
tr: When Ursula resumed the Sunday services, Pietro Crespi donated a small German organ to the church. He formed a children's choir and prepared a Gregorian repertoire that added grandeur to Father Nicanor's silent mass.
es: When Úrsula arranged for the resumption of Sunday mass, Pietro Crespi donated a German harmonium to the church, organized a children's choir, and prepared a Gregorian repertoire that added a splendid note to Father Nicanor's taciturn ritual.

en: No one doubted that he would make Amaranta a fortunate mate.
vi: No one doubted anymore that Amaranta would be a happy wife.
tr: There was no doubt that Amaranta was his perfect match.
es: No one doubted that he would make Amaranta a happy wife.

en: Not pushing their feelings, letting themselves be borne along by the natural flow of their hearth they reached a point where all that was left to do was set a wedding date.
vi: Allowing the feelings of the couple to naturally blossom from their hearts, without any urging, they reached the peak of love with only the wedding date left to be set.
tr: Without forcing their emotions, letting themselves flow naturally, they reached a point where there was nothing left to do but set the wedding date.
es: Without rushing their feelings, letting themselves be carried by the natural flow of the heart, they reached a point where all that was left was to set the wedding date.

en: They did not encounter any obstacles.
vi: They did not encounter any obstacles.
tr: There were no obstacles in their way.
es: They would find no obstacles.

en: Úrsula accused herself inwardly of having twisted Rebecca’s destiny with repeated postponements and she was not about to add more remorse.
vi: Úrsula silently blamed herself for the indefinite postponement of the wedding, which had altered Rebeca's fate. To this day, she had not yet overcome the shame.
tr: Ursula, feeling guilty for having altered Rebeca's fate by continually postponing her marriage, was now careful to avoid creating new sorrows.
es: Úrsula privately blamed herself for having twisted Rebeca's fate with repeated postponements, and she was not willing to accumulate more remorse.

en: The rigor of the mourning for Remedios had been relegated to the background by the mortifications of the war, Aureliano’s absence, Arcadio’s brutality, and the expulsion of José Arcadio and Rebeca.
vi: The serious mourning for Remedios had to take a back seat due to the deaths caused by the war, Aureliano's absence, Arcadio's brutality, and the expulsion of José Arcadio and Rebeca from the house.
tr: The progression of the war, Aureliano's absence, Arcadio's cruelty, and the expulsion of Jose Arcadio and Rebeca from the house had pushed the mourning for Remedios into the background.
es: The rigor of mourning for Remedios' death had been relegated to a secondary place by the mortification of the war, Aureliano's absence, Arcadio's brutality, and the expulsion of José Arcadio and Rebeca.

en: With the imminence of the wedding, Pietro Crespi had hinted that Aureliano José, in whom he had stirred up a love that was almost filial, would be considered their oldest child.
vi: Before the upcoming wedding, it was Pietro Crespi who earnestly requested to consider Aureliano José, whom he cherished like his own child, as his firstborn.
tr: In those days leading up to the wedding, Pietro Crespi had begun to accept Aureliano Jose, who was as attached to him as a son, as his first child.
es: In the face of the imminent wedding, Pietro Crespi himself had suggested that Aureliano José, in whom he had fostered an almost paternal affection, be considered his eldest son.

en: Everything made Amaranta think that she was heading toward a smooth happiness.
vi: Everything made everyone think that Amaranta was heading towards an easy happiness.
tr: All the events around her seemed to herald a carefree, perfect happiness for Amaranta.
es: Everything suggested that Amaranta was heading towards an untroubled happiness.

en: But unlike Rebeca, she did not reveal the slightest anxiety.
vi: But, unlike Rebeca, she did not reveal the desires of her heart.
tr: However, unlike Rebeca, Amaranta showed no signs of excitement.
es: But unlike Rebeca, she did not show the slightest anxiety.

en: With the same patience with which she dyed tablecloths, sewed lace masterpieces, and embroidered needlepoint peacocks, she waited for Pietro Crespi to be unable to bear the urges of his heart and more.
vi: With the same feeling she had while weaving tablecloths, lace trims, and embroidering peacocks on the cross, she waited for Pietro Crespi, unable to suppress the urgent demands of his heart.
tr: Just as she patiently dyes the tablecloths, quietly knits the unique lace, and embroiders peacocks from needlework, she was eagerly awaiting the moment when Pietro Crespi could no longer ignore the voice of his heart.
es: With the same patience with which she adorned tablecloths and wove exquisite trimmings and embroidered peacocks in cross-stitch, she waited for Pietro Crespi to no longer bear the urgencies of the heart.

en: Her day came with the ill-fated October rains.
vi: His fateful hour came during the unfortunate rainy days of October.
tr: The day she had been waiting for came with the autumn rains at the beginning of October.
es: Her moment came with the ominous rains of October.

en: Pietro Crespi took the sewing basket from her lap and he told her, “We’ll get married next month.”
vi: Pietro Crespi removed her hand from the embroidery frame and held her hand in his for a long time. "I can't wait any longer," he told her. "Let's get married next month."
tr: Pietro Crespi took the sewing box from her lap and said, "We are getting married next month."
es: Pietro Crespi took the embroidery basket from her lap and clasped her hand between his. "I can't bear this wait any longer," he said to her. "We'll get married next month.

en: Amaranta did not tremble at the contact with his icy hands.
vi: Amaranta did not tremble when her hand touched his cold hand.
tr: When his ice-cold hands touched hers, Amaranta did not shiver at all.
es: "Amaranta did not tremble at the touch of his icy hands.

en: She withdrew hers like a timid little animal and went back to her work.
vi: She slowly withdrew her hand from his. Like an evasive animal, she resumed her work.
tr: Like a docile animal, she withdrew her hands and continued her work.
es: She withdrew hers, like a slippery little animal, and returned to her work.

en: “Don’t be simple, Crespi.”
vi: - Stop being so naive, Crespi, - she laughed.
tr: "Simplification," Crespi said, smiling.
es: —Don't be naive, Crespi —she smiled—, not even dead would I marry you.

en: She smiled.
vi: - Stop being so naive, Crespi, - she laughed.
tr: "Simplification," Crespi said, smiling.
es: —Don't be naive, Crespi —she smiled—, not even dead would I marry you.

en: “I wouldn’t marry you even if I were dead.”
vi: - Even if I die, I won't marry you.
tr: "I wouldn't marry you even if I died."
es: —Don't be naive, Crespi —she smiled—, not even dead would I marry you.

en: Pietro Crespi lost control of himself.
vi: Piêtrô Crêspi could not control himself.
tr: Pietro Crespi could no longer hold himself back.
es: Pietro Crespi lost control of himself.

en: He wept shamelessly, almost breaking his fingers with desperation, but he could not break her down.
vi: He cried uncontrollably, no longer feeling any shame, nearly crushing his fingers out of frustration. But he still could not sway her.
tr: Without any shame, he was sobbing uncontrollably, rubbing his hands in despair as if he would break his fingers.
es: He cried shamelessly, almost breaking his fingers in desperation, but he could not break her.

en: “Don’t waste your time,” was all that Amaranta said.
vi: "Don't waste any more time hesitating," that was all Amaranta could say.
tr: But he couldn't soften Amaranta. -Don't waste your time.
es: “Don't waste your time,” was all Amaranta said.

en: “If you really love me so much, don’t set foot in this house again.”
vi: "If you truly love me deeply, then please do not come to this house anymore."
tr: If you really love me, you will never set foot in this house again, she said, and no other words came out of the girl's mouth.
es: “If you really love me that much, don't set foot in this house again.”

en: Úrsula thought she would go mad with shame.
vi: Ursula felt as if she were going mad with shame.
tr: Ursula was dying of shame.
es: Úrsula thought she would go mad with shame.

en: Pietro Crespi exhausted all manner of pleas.
vi: Piêtrô Crêspi used all his skills to plead, lowering himself to unimaginable levels.
tr: Pietro Crespi did not tire of begging and pleading.
es: Pietro Crespi exhausted the resources of supplication.

en: He went through incredible extremes of humiliation.
vi: Piêtrô Crêspi used all his skills to plead, lowering himself to unimaginable levels.
tr: He was willing to endure all kinds of disgrace and humiliation.
es: He reached incredible extremes of humiliation.

en: He wept one whole afternoon in Úrsula’s lap and she would have sold her soul in order to comfort him.
vi: He cried like a child on Ursula's chest all night, who might have had to sell her soul to comfort him.
tr: He spent an entire day with his head resting on Ursula's lap, crying. Ursula was ready to give her life if it would console him.
es: He cried all afternoon in Úrsula's lap, who would have sold her soul to console him.

en: On rainy nights he could be seen prowling about the house with an umbrella, waiting for a light in Amaranta’s bedroom.
vi: On rainy nights, people would find him wandering around the house with a silk umbrella, hoping to catch a glimpse of the light in Amaranta's room.
tr: On rainy nights, Crespi would open his umbrella and circle around the house to see the light in Amaranta's room.
es: On rainy nights he was seen lurking around the house with a silk umbrella, trying to catch a glimpse of light in Amaranta's bedroom.

en: He was never better dressed than at that time.
vi: He had never dressed as elegantly as he did then.
tr: He had never dressed as well as he did in those days.
es: He was never better dressed than during that time.

en: His august head of a tormented emperor had acquired a strange air of grandeur.
vi: His magnificent hair, like that of an emperor after a storm of emotions, had taken on a strange appearance.
tr: He held his head, reminiscent of an emperor who had lost his throne and crown, with a peculiar dignity and nobility.
es: His august head of a tormented emperor acquired a strange air of grandeur.

en: He begged Amaranta’s friends, the ones who sewed with her on the porch, to try to persuade her.
vi: He intercepted Amaranta's friends, the girls who usually came to embroider on the porch, to ask them to persuade Amaranta.
tr: He went to the friends who sat on the terrace with Amaranta, doing embroidery. He left no stone unturned to persuade Amaranta.
es: He pestered Amaranta's friends, those who came to embroider in the corridor, to try to persuade her.

en: He neglected his business.
vi: He no longer had the heart to take care of the shop.
tr: He neglected his work.
es: He neglected his business.

en: He would spend the day in the rear of the store writing wild notes, which he would send to Amaranta with flower petals and dried butterflies, and which she would return unopened.
vi: All day long, he stayed at home writing tedious letters to send to Amaranta along with dried flowers and butterflies. But she returned them unopened.
tr: He would lock himself in the room at the back of the shop from morning till night, writing passionate letters and sending them to Amaranta with dried flower petals and butterflies. But Amaranta would send the letters back unopened.
es: He spent the day in the back room, writing insane notes, which he sent to Amaranta with membranes of petals and dried butterflies, and which she returned unopened.

en: He would shut himself up for hours on end to play the zither.
vi: Shutting himself in his room, he sat for days on end playing the lute.
tr: Crespi would retreat to a corner and play the lute for hours.
es: He locked himself up for hours and hours to play the zither.

en: One night he sang.
vi: One night, he sang.
tr: One night, he even sang.
es: One night he sang.

en: Macondo woke up in a kind of angelic stupor that was caused by a zither that deserved more than this world and a voice that led one to believe that no other person on earth could feel such love.
vi: Macondo awoke in a special kind of astonishment, feeling chosen by the gods, as the sound of the lute resonated mournfully, not from this world, accompanied by a voice filled with such love that it seemed impossible to exist on this earth.
tr: The divine melodies from the strings of the lute, resembling a qanun, and the soulful voice that could serve as proof that no one in the world could love this much, awakened the entire Macondo.
es: Macondo awoke in a kind of stupor, angelized by a zither that did not deserve to be of this world and a voice that one could not conceive there could be another on earth with so much love.

en: Pietro Crespi then saw the lights go on in every window in town except that of Amaranta.
vi: It was then that Pietro Crespi saw light coming from the windows of every house in the village except Amaranta's room.
tr: All the lights in the village were lit one by one, except for Amaranta's.
es: Pietro Crespi then saw the light in all the windows of the town, except in Amaranta's.

en: On November second, All Souls’ Day, his brother opened the store and found all the lamps lighted, all the music boxes opened, and all the docks striking an interminable hour, and in the midst of that mad concert he found Pietro Crespi at the desk in the rear with his wrists cut by a razor and his hands thrust into a basin of benzoin.
vi: On November second, All Souls' Day, his younger brother opened the shop and found all the lights on, all the music boxes open, all the clocks stopped at an eternal hour, and amidst this chaotic scene, he saw Pietro Crespi sitting at the writing table in the back room with his fingers cut and soaked in a basin of cochineal dye.
tr: On the second of November, All Saints' Day, Crespi's brother opened the shop. All the lights were on. All the musical boxes were open. All the clocks were striking an endless hour. And amidst this crazy music, they found Pietro Crespi at the back of the shop, having slit his wrists with a razor and dipped his hands in a bowl of basil.
es: On November second, the Day of the Dead, his brother opened the store and found all the lamps lit and all the music boxes open and all the clocks stopped at an endless hour, and in the midst of that crazy concert he found Pietro Crespi in the back room's desk, with his wrists cut by a razor and both hands dipped in a basin of benzoin.

en: Úrsula decreed that the wake would be in her house.
vi: Ursula decided to keep her brother's body in her house for the funeral rites.
tr: Ursula announced that the deceased would stay in their house that night, a vigil would be held, and the traditional funeral meal would be eaten.
es: Úrsula arranged for him to be laid out in the house.

en: Father Nicanor was against a religious ceremony and burial in consecrated ground.
vi: Father Nicanor refused to perform the baptism and bury him in the holy ground.
tr: Father Nicanor opposed holding a religious ceremony and burying the deceased in consecrated ground.
es: Father Nicanor opposed religious services and burial in sacred ground.

en: Úrsula stood up to him.
vi: Ursula confronted the priest.
tr: Ursula confronted him.
es: Úrsula confronted him.

en: “In a way that neither you nor I can understand, that man was a saint,” she said.
vi: "Neither you nor I can understand that this man is a saint," she said. "
tr: He was a holy man in a way that neither you nor I can comprehend, she said.
es: "In a way that neither you nor I can understand, that man was a saint," she said.

en: “So I am going to bury him, against your wishes, beside Melquíades’ grave.”
vi: Against your wishes, I will bury him right next to Melquiades' grave. "
tr: Therefore, whether you like it or not, I will bury him next to Melquiades.
es: "So I am going to bury him, against your will, next to Melquíades' grave."

en: She did it with the support of the whole town and with a magnificent funeral.
vi: She did exactly what she said. With the support of the entire village, she organized a solemn funeral for him.
tr: And she did; with the support of the entire village and a grand funeral ceremony.
es: She did so, with the support of the entire town, in magnificent funerals.

en: Amaranta did not leave her bedroom.
vi: Amaranta did not step out of her room.
tr: Amaranta did not leave her bedroom.
es: Amaranta did not leave the bedroom.

en: From her bed she heard Úrsula’s weeping, the steps and whispers of the multitude that invaded the house, the wailing of the mourners, and then a deep silence that smelled of trampled flowers.
vi: Lying on her bed, she clearly heard Ursula's crying, the footsteps and the sobbing murmurs of the crowd, the eerie wails of the hired mourners echoing into the house, and then the quiet, solemn scene laden with the scent of trampled flowers.
tr: From where she lay, she could hear Ursula crying, the footsteps and whispers of the crowd filling the house, and the lamentations of the mourners. Then a silence began that smelled of crushed flowers.
es: From her bed, she heard Úrsula's weeping, the footsteps and murmurs of the crowd that invaded the house, the wails of the mourners, and then a deep silence smelling of trampled flowers.

en: For a long time she kept on smelling Pietro Crespi’s lavender breath at dusk, but she had the strength not to succumb to delirium.
vi: Lying on her bed, she clearly heard Ursula's crying, the footsteps and the sobbing murmurs of the crowd, the eerie wails of the hired mourners echoing into the house, and then the quiet, solemn scene laden with the scent of trampled flowers.
tr: For a long time, as evening fell, Amaranta continued to smell the lavender scent of Pietro Crespi. But she was strong enough not to lose herself.
es: For a long time, she continued to feel the lavender breath of Pietro Crespi at dusk, but she had the strength not to succumb to delirium.

en: Úrsula abandoned her.
vi: Ursula abandoned her.
tr: Ursula had left her to her own devices and had stopped caring.
es: Úrsula abandoned her.

en: She did not even raise her eyes to pity her on the afternoon when Amaranta went into the kitchen and put her hand into the coals of the stove until it hurt her so much that she felt no more pain but instead smelled the pestilence of her own singed flesh.
vi: That very afternoon, Amaranta went into the kitchen, thrust her hand into the glowing embers, and left it there until she no longer felt pain but only the acrid smell of her own flesh burning, yet her mother did not even lift her eyes to pity her daughter.
tr: Even when one afternoon, Amaranta went to the kitchen, plunged her hand into the coals in the stove, and burned her hand until she felt a pain beyond the smell of her burning flesh, Ursula did not turn her head to look.
es: She did not even lift her eyes to pity her, the afternoon when Amaranta entered the kitchen and put her hand in the embers of the stove, until it hurt so much that she felt no more pain, only the stench of her own scorched flesh.

en: It was a stupid cure for her remorse.
vi: It was an effective remedy for the torment of remorse.
tr: Remorse could not be alleviated this way.
es: It was a donkey's cure for remorse.

en: For several days she went about the house with her hand in a pot of egg whites, and when the burns healed it appeared as if the whites had also scarred over the sores on her heart.
vi: For several days, with her burnt hand soaking in a bowl of egg whites, she walked around the house, and as the egg whites healed the burns, it seemed they also healed the burns in her heart.
tr: For a few days, Amaranta walked around the house with her hand wrapped in an egg white poultice. It was as if the egg white had seared not only the burn on her hand but also the wounds in her heart.
es: For several days she walked around the house with her hand in a bowl of egg whites, and when the burns healed, it seemed as if the egg whites had also healed the ulcers of her heart.

en: The only external trace that the tragedy left was the bandage of black gauze that she put on her burned hand and that she wore until her death.
vi: The only external trace left of the tragedy was the black bandage on her burnt hand, which she had to wear until her death.
tr: The only visible trace left from this tragedy was the black cloth wrapped around Amaranta's burned hand, which she never removed until her death.
es: The only external mark the tragedy left on her was the black gauze bandage she wore on her burned hand, which she would wear until her death.

en: Arcadio gave a rare display of generosity by decreeing official mourning for Pietro Crespi.
vi: Through the official order to mourn Pietro Crespi, Arcadio particularly showed himself to be a noble person.
tr: Arcadio showed an unexpected act of humanity by declaring official mourning for Pietro Crespi.
es: Arcadio gave a rare display of generosity by proclaiming an official mourning for the death of Pietro Crespi.

en: Úrsula interpreted it as the return of the strayed lamb.
vi: Úrsula explained this phenomenon as the return of a lost sheep.
tr: Ursula interpreted this behavior as the return of the lamb that had strayed from the flock.
es: Úrsula interpreted it as the return of the lost lamb.

en: But she was mistaken.
vi: But she was greatly mistaken.
tr: However, she was mistaken.
es: But she was mistaken.

en: She had lost Arcadio, not when he had put on his military uniform, but from the beginning.
vi: She had lost Arcadio not just since he wore the military uniform but long before that.
tr: She had lost Arcadio not on the day he donned the uniform, but from the very beginning.
es: She had lost Arcadio, not since he donned the military uniform, but since always.

en: She thought she had raised him as a son, as she had raised Rebeca, with no privileges or discrimination.
vi: She thought she was raising him like a son, like she raised Rebeca, neither too indulgently nor too harshly.
tr: She thought she had raised Arcadio just as she had raised Rebeca, without any difference, treating him no differently than her own children.
es: She believed she had raised him like a son, as she had raised Rebeca, without privileges or discrimination.

en: Nevertheless, Arcadio was a solitary and frightened child during the insomnia plague, in the midst of Úrsula’s utilitarian fervor, during the delirium of José Arcadio Buendía, the hermetism of Aureliano, and the mortal rivalry between Amaranta and Rebeca.
vi: However, Arcadio was a lonely and frightened child during the time of the insomnia plague, in the circumstances where Úrsula was busy getting rich, José Arcadio Buendía was insane, Aureliano was taciturn, and Amaranta and Rebeca were hostile to each other.
tr: However, during the insomnia plague, amidst Ursula's efforts to repair the house, when Jose Arcadio Buendia lost his mind, during Aureliano's days of seclusion, and throughout the deadly feud between Amaranta and Rebeca, Arcadio had always lived a lonely and timid childhood.
es: However, Arcadio was a lonely and frightened child during the insomnia plague, amidst Úrsula's utilitarian fever, José Arcadio Buendía's delusions, Aureliano's hermeticism, and the deadly rivalry between Amaranta and Rebeca.

en: Aureliano had taught him to read and write, thinking about other things, as he would have done with a stranger.
vi: Aureliano taught him to read and write, but his mind was elsewhere, as if he was turning him into a stranger.
tr: Indeed, Aureliano had taught him to read and write. But he did so as if teaching a stranger, without genuine interest, his mind always elsewhere.
es: Aureliano taught him to read and write, thinking of something else, as a stranger would have done.

en: He gave him his clothing so that Visitación could take it in when it was ready to be thrown away.
vi: He gave him clothes that were about to tear for Visitación to mend to fit.
tr: He also gave his clothes that had become unwearable to Arcadio, and Visitacion would alter and shorten them to fit the child.
es: He gave him his clothes, for Visitación to alter, when they were already about to be discarded.

en: Arcadio suffered from shoes that were too large, from his patched pants, from his female buttocks.
vi: Arcadio suffered with shoes that were too big, with mended pants, and with his womanly hips.
tr: Throughout his childhood, Arcadio suffered the discomfort of wearing oversized shoes, patched pants, and feminine hips.
es: Arcadio suffered with his oversized shoes, his patched pants, and his womanly buttocks.

en: He never succeeded in communicating with anyone better than he did with Visitación and Cataure in their language.
vi: He never confided in anyone except Visitación and Cataure in their language.
tr: He spoke with Visitacion and Cataure in their language, unable to communicate with anyone else as he did with them.
es: He never managed to communicate with anyone better than he did with Visitación and Cataure in their language.

en: Melquíades was the only one who really was concerned with him as he made him listen to his incomprehensible texts and gave him lessons in the art of daguerreotype.
vi: In fact, Melquíades was the only one who cared about him. He recited incomprehensible elegies to him and explained the art of photography to him.
tr: The only person who truly cared for him was Melquiades, who read him his incomprehensible writings and taught him the art of photography.
es: Melquíades was the only one who truly cared for him, making him listen to his incomprehensible texts and giving him instructions on the art of daguerreotype.

en: No one imagined how much he wept in secret and the desperation with which he tried to revive Melquíades with the useless study of his papers.
vi: No one knew how he cried silently over Melquíades' death and tried to revive him by studying his writings without success.
tr: Nobody knew that when Melquiades died, Arcadio secretly shed tears and tried to revive him by futilely examining his writings.
es: No one imagined how much he cried in secret over his death, and with what desperation he tried to revive him through the futile study of his papers.

en: The school, where they paid attention to him and respected him, and then power, with his endless decrees and his glorious uniform, freed him from the weight of an old bitterness.
vi: The school, where he worked diligently and was respected by everyone, and later the authority given to him with decisive orders and the glorious military uniform, those things freed him from his previous bitterness.
tr: The period when he was a respected and beloved teacher, followed by his time in power with endless decrees and a mottled uniform, freed him from the weight of an old sorrow.
es: The school, where he was given attention and respect, and later power, with its decisive edicts and his uniform of glory, freed him from the weight of an old bitterness.

en: One night in Catarino’s store someone dared tell him, “you don’t deserve the last name you carry.”
vi: One night, right in Catarino's store, someone dared to say to him: "You are not worthy of your name!".
tr: One night in Catarino's shop, someone dared to say, "You are not worthy of the surname you carry."
es: One night, in Catarino's store, someone dared to say to him: "You don't deserve the surname you bear."

en: Contrary to what everyone expected, Arcadio did not have him shot.
vi: Contrary to what everyone expected, Arcadio did not order that person to be shot: - Very pleased, - he said.
tr: Contrary to what was expected, Arcadio did not have the man executed by firing squad.
es: Contrary to what everyone expected, Arcadio did not have him shot.

en: “To my great honor,” he said, “I am not a Buendía.”
vi: - Fortunately, I'm not a Buendía.
tr: -Not being a Buendia is the greatest honor for me, he said.
es: —With great pride —he said—, I am not a Buendía.

en: Those who knew the secret of his parentage thought that the answer meant that he too was aware of it, but he had really never been.
vi: Those who knew his origins through this argument all thought that he had understood. In reality, he still had no idea about his origins.
tr: Those who knew the secret about Arcadio's parents thought, upon hearing these words, that he also knew the truth.
es: Those who knew the secret of his parentage thought from that reply that he was also aware, but in reality, he never was.

en: Pilar Ternera, his mother, who had made his blood boil in the darkroom, was as much an irresistible obsession for him as she had been first for José Arcadio and then for Aureliano.
vi: Pila Tecnêra, his mother, who had once aroused his lust in the darkroom, was an irresistible craving for him, just as she had been initially for José Arcadio and later for Aureliano.
tr: But Arcadio had never learned this truth. In the dark room, Pilar Ternera, who had once been an irresistible passion first for Jose Arcadio and then for Aureliano, was now the same for Arcadio:
es: Pilar Ternera, his mother, who had made his blood boil in the daguerreotype room, was for him an obsession as irresistible as she was first for José Arcadio and then for Aureliano.

en: In spite of her having lost her charms and the splendor of her laugh, he sought her out and found her by the trail of her smell of smoke.
vi: Although she had lost her former charm and infectious laughter, he still sought her out and found her in the acrid smoke emanating from her body.
tr: Even though her former beauty was gone and her laughter no longer echoed as it used to, Arcadio always sought her out and found her by the scent of smoky mist.
es: Despite having lost her charms and the splendor of her laughter, he sought her out and found her in the trail of her smoky scent.

en: A short time before the war, one noon when she was later than usual in coming for her younger son at school, Arcadio was waiting for her in the room where he was accustomed to take his siesta and where he later set up the stocks.
vi: But before the outbreak of hostilities, one afternoon when she came to the school later than usual to find her youngest son, Arcadio was waiting for her in the lounge, which later became a prison cell.
tr: Shortly before the war, when Pilar Ternera came a little later than usual to pick up her young son from school, she found Arcadio waiting for her in the room where he took his afternoon naps and later shackled the prisoners to the log.
es: Shortly before the war, one midday when she went later than usual to pick up her youngest son from school, Arcadio was waiting for her in the room where he used to take his siesta, and where he later installed the stocks.

en: While the child played in the courtyard, he waited in his hammock, trembling with anxiety, knowing that Pillar Ternera would have to pass through there.
vi: While the child was playing outside in the yard, he lay in the hammock waiting for her, trembling with renewed desire and knowing that she would come.
tr: The child was playing in the garden, and Arcadio, knowing that Pilar Ternera had to pass through that room, lay in his hammock, trembling as he waited.
es: While the child played in the yard, he waited in the hammock, trembling with anxiety, knowing that Pilar Ternera had to pass by there.

en: She arrived.
vi: She did come.
tr: The woman arrived.
es: She arrived.

en: Arcadio grabbed her by the wrist and tried to pull her into the hammock.
vi: Arcadio grabbed her wrist, intending to pull her into the hammock with him.
tr: Arcadio grabbed her by the wrist and tried to pull her into the hammock.
es: Arcadio grabbed her by the wrist and tried to pull her into the hammock.

en: “I can’t, I can’t,” Pilar Ternera said in horror.
vi: "I give up! I give up!", Pila Tecnêra said, trembling with fear.
tr: Pilar Ternera was horrified. No! No! she was saying.
es: “I can't, I can't,” said Pilar Ternera, horrified.

en: “You can’t imagine how much I would like to make you happy, but as God is my witness I can’t.”
vi: "You don't know that I also want to please you very much. But with God as my witness: I cannot satisfy you."
tr: You can't know how much I want to make you happy, but God knows, I can't do it.
es: “You can't imagine how much I would like to please you, but God is my witness that I can't.”

en: Arcadio took her by the waist with his tremendous hereditary strength and he felt the world disappear with the contact of her skin.
vi: With inherited strength, Accadio wrapped his arms around her waist and felt the world tilt when he touched her skin.
tr: Arcadio, with the strength inherited from his ancestors, grabbed the woman by the waist, and the moment he touched her skin, the world vanished from his sight.
es: Arcadio grabbed her by the waist with his tremendous hereditary strength, and felt the world fade away at the touch of her skin.

en: “Don’t play the saint,” he said.
vi: "Stop it, don't pretend to be all high and mighty...", he said.
tr: Don't try to put on an act of decency, he said.
es: “Don't play the saint,” he said.

en: “After all, everybody knows that you’re a whore.”
vi: "In the end, everyone knows I'm a prostitute."
tr: Who doesn't know about her promiscuity?
es: “After all, everyone knows you're a whore.”

en: Pilar overcame the disgust that her miserable fate inspired in her.
vi: Pila Tecnera could not overcome the shame that the tragic fate had bestowed upon her.
tr: Pilar cursed her bad fate inwardly.
es: Pilar overcame the disgust that her miserable fate inspired in her.

en: “The children will find out,” she murmured.
vi: - The children will disappear, - she said.
tr: "The children might see," he whispered.
es: —The children will notice —he murmured—.

en: “It will be better if you leave the bar off the door tonight.”
vi: - It's best if you leave the door open tonight.
tr: "It's best not to bolt the door tonight."
es: It's better if you leave the door unlatched tonight.

en: Arcadio waited for her that night trembling with fever in his hammock.
vi: That night, lying on the hammock, his body burning as if on fire, Arcadio waited for her.
tr: That night Arcadio waited for her in his hammock, trembling with fever.
es: Arcadio waited for her that night, shivering with fever in the hammock.

en: He waited without sleeping, listening to the aroused crickets in the endless hours of early morning and the implacable telling of time by the curlews, more and more convinced that he had been deceived.
vi: He did not sleep, waiting and listening to the sounds of the late night and the cries of the night heron.
tr: He couldn't sleep, listening intently. In the endless hours of the approaching dawn, as he heard the sound of crickets and the merciless cries of curlews heralding the new day, he became increasingly convinced that he had been deceived.
es: He waited without sleeping, listening to the restless crickets of the endless dawn and the relentless schedule of the curlews, increasingly convinced that he had been deceived.

en: Suddenly, when anxiety had broken down into rage, the door opened.
vi: The longer he waited, the more hopeless he felt, thinking he had been "fooled."Just as his desire began to cool and his anger flared up, the door suddenly opened.
tr: Just as his excitement turned to anger, the door suddenly opened.
es: Suddenly, when his anxiety had turned into rage, the door opened.

en: A few months later, facing the firing squad, Arcadio would relive the wandering steps in the classroom, the stumbling against benches, and finally the bulk of a body in the shadows of the room and the breathing of air that was pumped by a heart that was not his.
vi: Months later, standing before the firing squad, Arcadio recalled the staggering footsteps in the classroom, the collisions with the benches, and finally, a shadowy figure emerging in the dim room and the pounding heart that was not his own.
tr: Months later, as Arcadio stood before the firing squad, he would remember the footsteps in the classroom, the slamming of desks, the weight of a body leaning against his in the darkness of the room, and the breath from another heart mingling with his own.
es: A few months later, in front of the firing squad, Arcadio would relive the lost steps in the classroom, the stumbles against the benches, and finally the density of a body in the darkness of the room and the beats of the air pumped by a heart that was not his own.

en: He stretched out his hand and found another hand with two rings on the same finger about to go astray in the darkness.
vi: He reached out his hand and encountered another hand wearing two rings on the same finger of a person about to drown in darkness.
tr: Arcadio reached out his hand and in the darkness caught another hand with two rings on two fingers, just as it was about to slip away.
es: He extended his hand and found another hand with two rings on the same finger, which was about to sink into the darkness.

en: He felt the structure of the veins, the pulse of its misfortune, and felt the damp palm with a lifeline cut off at the base of the thumb by the claws of death.
vi: He felt his blood pulsing through his veins, his misfortune beating erratically, and his hand, with a lifeline cut short by death on the thumb mound, was damp with sweat.
tr: He felt the veins on the hand, sensed the heartbeat of an ill-fated heart in the wrist, and touched the palm where the lifeline was cut by the claw of death at the base of the thumb.
es: He felt the veins' texture, the pulse of his misfortune, and felt the moist palm with the lifeline cut at the base of the thumb by the claw of death.

en: Then he realized that this was not the woman he was waiting for, because she did not smell of smoke but of flower lotion, and she had inflated, blind breasts with nipples like.
vi: Thus, he immediately understood that this woman was not the one he had been waiting for, because she did not emit the expected burnt smell but rather the scent of brigantine, because she had wrinkled breasts, a firm and round navel like a grape seed, and a body trembling with the fear of someone inexperienced in life.
tr: Then, he realized that she was not the woman he was expecting, because she smelled of flowers, not smoky steam, and she had tiny, unseen breasts like a man's chest, a crotch as hard and round as a walnut, and a tenderness tinged with the excitement of inexperience.
es: Then he understood that this was not the woman he was waiting for, because she did not smell of smoke but of little flower pomade, and she had inflated and blind breasts with male nipples, and a stone-like and round sex like a nut, and the chaotic tenderness of exalted inexperience.

en: a man’s, a sex as stony and round as a nut, and the chaotic tenderness of excited inexperience.
vi: Thus, he immediately understood that this woman was not the one he had been waiting for, because she did not emit the expected burnt smell but rather the scent of brigantine, because she had wrinkled breasts, a firm and round navel like a grape seed, and a body trembling with the fear of someone inexperienced in life.
tr: Then, he realized that she was not the woman he was expecting, because she smelled of flowers, not smoky steam, and she had tiny, unseen breasts like a man's chest, a crotch as hard and round as a walnut, and a tenderness tinged with the excitement of inexperience.
es: Then he understood that this was not the woman he was waiting for, because she did not smell of smoke but of little flower pomade, and she had inflated and blind breasts with male nipples, and a stone-like and round sex like a nut, and the chaotic tenderness of exalted inexperience.

en: She was a virgin and she had the unlikely name of Santa Sofía de la Piedad.
vi: She was a virgin and had an almost unbelievable name: Santa Sofía de la Piedad.
tr: She was a virgin girl and her name was Santa Sofia de la Piedad.
es: She was a virgin and had the unbelievable name of Santa Sofía de la Piedad.

en: Pilar Ternera had paid her fifty pesos, half of her life savings, to do what she was doing.
vi: Pilar Ternera paid her fifty pesos, half of the money she had saved all her life, to do what she was doing.
tr: Pilar Ternera had given her half of the money she had saved and set aside all her life, exactly fifty pesos, to do what she did to him.
es: Pilar Ternera had paid her fifty pesos, half of her lifetime savings, to do what she was doing.

en: Arcadio, had seen her many times working in her parents’ small food store but he had never taken a good look at her because she had that rare virtue of never existing completely except at the opportune moment.
vi: Arcadio had seen her many times while tending his parents' grocery store, and he had never paid attention to her because she was not yet in her prime.
tr: Arcadio had seen her many times while she worked at his father's small cookshop, but he had never looked at her with interest; because the girl had the rare virtue of not making her presence felt to those around her except when necessary.
es: Arcadio had seen her many times, tending her parents' small grocery store, and had never noticed her, because she had the rare virtue of not fully existing except at the opportune moment.

en: But from that day on he huddled like a cat in the warmth of her armpit
vi: But from that day on, he clung to her like a cat.
tr: But after that day, Arcadio couldn't help but snuggle up to the warmth of her armpits like a cat.
es: But from that day on, she curled up like a cat in the warmth of his armpit.

en: She would go to the school at siesta time with the consent of her parents, to whom Pilar Ternera hid paid the other half of her savings.
vi: She came to the school during lunch breaks with the complicity of her parents, who had received the rest of Pilar Ternera's savings.
tr: When it was time for her siesta, she went to school. Her parents knew and didn't say anything. Pilar Ternera had given them the other half of her life savings as well.
es: She would go to the school at siesta time, with her parents' consent, to whom Pilar Ternera had paid the other half of her savings.

en: Later on, when the government troops dislodged them from the place where they had made love, they did it among the cans of lard and sacks of corn in the back of the store.
vi: Later, when the government troops expelled them from the school, the two made love among the butter barrels and corn sacks in the warehouse.
tr: Later, when the government troops evicted them from their love nests, they began to make love between the lard cans and corn sacks at the back of the shop.
es: Later, when the government troops evicted them from the premises, they made love among the tins of lard and sacks of corn in the back room.

en: About the time that Arcadio was named civil and military leader they had a daughter.
vi: During the time Arcadio was appointed Military and Civil Governor of Macondo, they had a daughter together.
tr: At the time Arcadio was appointed as the civil and military leader of the village, they had a daughter.
es: By the time Arcadio was appointed civil and military chief, they had a daughter.

en: The only relatives who knew about it were José Arcadio and Rebeca, with whom Arcadio maintained close relations at that time, based not so much on kinship as on complicity.
vi: The only close relatives who knew about it were José Arcadio and Rebeca. They were the ones with whom Arcadio at that time maintained intimate relations not only based on kinship but also on complicity.
tr: The only relatives who knew about this situation were Jose Arcadio and Rebeca. During that period, Arcadio was close to them more out of a sense of complicity than kinship.
es: The only relatives who found out were José Arcadio and Rebeca, with whom Arcadio maintained intimate relations, based not so much on kinship as on complicity.

en: José Arcadio had put his neck into the marital yoke.
vi: The marital yoke completely subdued José Arcadio.
tr: Jose Arcadio had surrendered himself to the yoke of marriage.
es: José Arcadio had bowed his head to the matrimonial yoke.

en: Rebeca’s firm character, the voracity of her stomach, her tenacious ambition absorbed the tremendous energy of her husband, who had been changed from a lazy, woman-chasing man into an enormous work animal.
vi: Rebeca's strong character, her gluttonous appetite, and her insatiable greed drained the robust strength of her husband, forcing him, who was lazy and a playboy, to become a hardworking giant.
tr: Rebeca's strong personality, insatiable appetite, and relentless ambition were draining all the strength from her husband, who had transformed from a woman-chasing idler into a beast of burden.
es: Rebeca's firm character, the voracity of her womb, her tenacious ambition, absorbed the husband's colossal energy, who from a lazy womanizer turned into a huge work animal.

en: They kept a clean and neat house.
vi: He has a clean and tidy house.
tr: They had a neat and tidy house.
es: They had a clean and orderly house.

en: Rebeca would open it wide at dawn and the wind from the graveyard would come in through the windows and go out through the doors to the yard and leave the whitewashed walls and furniture tanned by the saltpeter of the dead.
vi: Every morning, Rebecca opens the doors wide, and the wind from the cemetery rushes through the windows and then sweeps out through the side door, leaving behind the sulfurous smell of the dead, causing the walls to turn pale and the tables, cabinets, and beds to darken.
tr: At sunrise, Rebeca would open up the entire house, and as the wind from the cemetery blew in through the windows and out through the doors into the garden, it would infuse the walls and furniture with the scent of graveyard saltpeter.
es: Rebeca would open it wide at dawn, and the wind from the graves would enter through the windows and exit through the patio doors, leaving the walls whitewashed and the furniture tanned by the saltpeter of the dead.

en: Her hunger for earth, the cloc-cloc of her parents’ bones, the impatience of her blood as it faced Pietro Crespi’s passivity were relegated to the attic of her memory.
vi: The hunger for land, the clattering sound of the bones of her parents, and her impatience with Pietro Crespi's overly calm demeanor had faded into the past.
tr: Rebeca's craving for eating earth, the rattling of her parents' bones, and the boiling of her blood in the face of Pietro Crespi's ineptitude were all things of the distant past.
es: The hunger for land, the cloc cloc of her parents' bones, the impatience of her blood in the face of Pietro Crespi's passivity were relegated to the attic of memory.

en: All day long she would embroider beside the window, withdrawn from the uneasiness of the war, until the ceramic pots would begin to vibrate in the cupboard and she would get up to warm the meal, much before the appearance, first, of the mangy hounds, and then of the colossus in leggings and spurs with a double-barreled shotgun, who sometimes carried a deer on his shoulder and almost always a string of rabbits or wild ducks.
vi: All day, she sat embroidering by the window, indifferent to the echoes of war. Only when the earthenware pots began to rattle in the cupboard did she get up to reheat the food. She did this before the appearance of the mud-splattered, sniffing dogs and the burly man in spurred boots, carrying a double-barreled musket: "This man sometimes carried a deer on his shoulders, but almost always brought back a string of rabbits or wild ducks…
tr: Rebeca would sit by the window all day, embroidering, far removed from the anxieties of the war. When the dishes in the cupboard began to clink against each other, she would get up and start cooking. Long before the giant with boots, spurs, and a shotgun, sometimes with a deer slung over his shoulder, but more often with strings of wild ducks and rabbits dangling from his hands, appeared in the distance, Rebeca would have the meal ready.
es: All day she would embroider by the window, oblivious to the turmoil of the war, until the ceramic pots started to vibrate in the cupboard and she would get up to heat the food, long before the scrawny tracking dogs appeared and then the colossus with gaiters and spurs and a double-barreled shotgun, who sometimes carried a deer on his shoulder and almost always a string of rabbits or wild ducks.

en: One afternoon, at the beginning of his rule, Arcadio paid them a surprise visit.
vi: One afternoon, right when he took power, Arcadio suddenly came to visit them.
tr: One afternoon, during the early days of his administration, Arcadio showed up.
es: One afternoon, at the beginning of his rule, Arcadio went to visit them unexpectedly.

en: They had not seen him since they had left the house, but he seemed so friendly and familiar that they invited him to share the stew.
vi: When they left the house, they did not see him, but he had shown such warmth and friendliness that the couple invited him to stay and taste the freshly cooked game meat.
tr: They had not seen him since they left home, but he had such a sincere and friendly demeanor that Rebeca and Jose Arcadio did not hesitate to invite him to their table.
es: They hadn't seen him since they left the house, but he was so affectionate and familiar that they invited him to share the stew.

en: Only when they were having coffee did Arcadio reveal the motive behind his visit: he had received a complaint against José Arcadio.
vi: It was only when drinking coffee that Arcadio clearly stated the purpose of his visit: he had received a complaint against José Arcadio.
tr: While they were eating their meals and drinking their coffee, Arcadio explained the reason for his visit. There was a complaint about Jose Arcadio.
es: Only when they were having coffee did Arcadio reveal the reason for his visit: he had received a complaint against José Arcadio.

en: It was said that he had begun by plowing his own yard and had gone straight ahead into neighboring lands, knocking down fences and buildings with his oxen until he took forcible possession of the best plots of land around.
vi: The complaint alleged that José Arcadio plowed his own field and encroached on neighboring lands, broke down fences, herded his cattle into others' pens, and used force to seize the most fertile farms around.
tr: It was said that Jose Arcadio had started by plowing his own field, then driving the oxen forward, crushing fences and demolishing structures, he forcibly took over the most fertile lands in the area.
es: It was said that he started by plowing his yard and continued straight through the adjoining lands, knocking down fences and destroying ranches with his oxen, until he forcibly took over the best plots in the area.

en: On the peasants whom he had not despoiled because he was not interested in their lands, he levied a contribution which he collected every Saturday with his hunting dogs and his double-barreled shotgun.
vi: For those farmers who were not dispossessed because their lands were poor, he forced them to pay taxes. Every Saturday, he used hunting dogs and a double-barreled musket to collect taxes.
tr: He had also imposed a tribute on the owners of the lands he did not find appealing. Every Saturday, he would take his hunting dogs, sling his shotgun over his shoulder, and go out to collect the tribute.
es: To the peasants he had not dispossessed, because he was not interested in their lands, he imposed a tax that he collected every Saturday with his hunting dogs and double-barreled shotgun.

en: He did not deny it.
vi: He did not deny these accusations.
tr: Jose Arcadio did not deny his actions.
es: He did not deny it.

en: He based his right on the fact that the usurped lands had been distributed by José Arcadio Buendía at the time of the founding, and he thought it possible to prove that his father had been crazy ever since that time, for he had disposed of a patrimony that really belonged to the family.
vi: He asserted his rights over the lands he had seized, which had been distributed by José Arcadio Buendía during the village's founding, and he believed he could prove that his father had been insane since that time because he had given away wealth that rightfully belonged to his family.
tr: -These lands were distributed by Jose Arcadio Buendia during the establishment of the village. In fact, it is said that his madness began at that time because he squandered this inheritance, which actually belonged to the family, and for this reason, he saw himself justified in seizing those lands.
es: He based his right on the fact that the usurped lands had been distributed by José Arcadio Buendía at the time of the founding, and he believed it possible to prove that his father had been crazy since then, as he had disposed of an estate that actually belonged to the family.

en: It was an unnecessary allegation, because Arcadio had not come to do justice.
vi: It was an unnecessary argument because Arcadio had not come to adjudicate right or wrong but merely to negotiate.
tr: Such a defense was actually unnecessary, because Arcadio had not come to see justice served. He had come to negotiate with Jose Arcadio.
es: It was an unnecessary argument because Arcadio had not come to seek justice.

en: He simply offered to set up a registry office so that José Arcadio could legalize his title to the usurped land, under the condition that he delegate to the local government the right to collect the contributions.
vi: As for himself, he established a law office to oversee private property, which would provide José Arcadio with the documents to legalize the lands he had seized, and in return, he had to allow the local government the right to collect taxes.
tr: In order for the title deeds of the seized lands to be transferred to Jose Arcadio, Arcadio would establish a cadastral office, and in return, Jose Arcadio would agree to let the local government representatives collect the tribute.
es: He simply offered to create a property registry office so that José Arcadio could legalize the titles of the usurped land, on the condition that he delegated to the local government the right to collect the taxes.

en: They made an agreement.
vi: The two agreed with each other.
tr: They reached an agreement.
es: They came to an agreement.

en: Years later, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía examined the titles to property, he found registered in his brother’s name all of the land between the hill where his yard was on up to the horizon, including the cemetery, and discovered that during the eleven months of his rule, Arcadio had collected not only the money of the contributions, but had also collected fees from people for the right to bury their dead in José Arcadio’s land.
vi: In later years, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía examined the land deeds, he found that all the land from José Arcadio's yard to the horizon, including the village cemetery, belonged to his brother; and that during the eleven months of his rule, Arcadio had collected not only taxes but also money from people who wanted to bury their loved ones on José Arcadio's estate.
tr: Years later, while Colonel Aureliano Buendia was examining the title records, he saw that all the lands, including the cemetery, from the hill where Jose Arcadio's garden was located to as far as the eye could see, were registered in his brother's name. And he learned that during Arcadio's eleven-month rule, not only had he collected the tributes, but he had also taken money from the families of the deceased so they could bury their dead on Jose Arcadio's land. Ursula learned about these events, which were the talk of the entire village, only a few months later.
es: Years later, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía examined the property titles, he found that all the lands visible from the hill of his yard to the horizon, including the cemetery, were registered in his brother's name, and that in the eleven months of his mandate, Arcadio had taken not only the tax money but also the money he charged the town for the right to bury the dead in José Arcadio's plots.

en: It took Úrsula several months to find out what was already public knowledge because people hid it from her so as not to increase her suffering.
vi: A few months later, Úrsula finally learned about the matter that had become public knowledge, because the townspeople had hidden it from her to spare her further distress.
tr: Everyone was hiding what had happened to avoid adding to her sorrow.
es: Úrsula took several months to learn what was already public knowledge, because people hid it from her to avoid increasing her suffering.

en: At first she suspected it.
vi: She began to suspect him.
tr: At first, Ursula was suspicious.
es: She began to suspect it.

en: “Arcadio is building a house,” she confided with feigned pride to her husband as she tried to put a spoonful of calabash syrup into his mouth.
vi: "Arcadio is building a house," she proudly asserted to her husband while trying to shove a spoonful of pumpkin soup into his mouth.
tr: While she was giving her husband spoonfuls of pumpkin syrup, she said, supposedly with a puffed-up chest, Arcadio is building a house.
es: "Arcadio is building a house," she confided to her husband with feigned pride, while trying to put a spoonful of totumo syrup into his mouth.

en: Nevertheless, she involuntarily sighed and said, “I don’t know why, but all this has a bad smell to me.”
vi: However, she unconsciously sighed: "I don't know why, but I feel uneasy about all these things."
tr: She said it, but then she couldn't help but sigh and added, I don't know, but I have a feeling something is going to come out of this.
es: However, she sighed involuntarily: "I don't know why all this smells bad to me."

en: Later on, when she found out that Arcadio had not only built a house but had ordered some Viennese furniture, she confirmed her suspicion that he was using public funds.
vi: And later, when she found out that not only had Arcadio finished building the house but had also bought furniture made in Vienna, she became even more convinced that he was embezzling public funds, something she had previously suspected.
tr: Later, when she learned that Arcadio was not only building a house but also ordering furniture from Vienna, she became convinced that he was spending the money he had collected for public services.
es: Later, when she found out that Arcadio had not only finished the house but had also ordered Viennese furniture, she confirmed her suspicion that he was using public funds.

en: “You’re the shame of our family name,” she shouted at him one Sunday after mass when she saw him in his new house playing cards with his officers.
vi: "You are the disgrace of our family," she scolded him like that at the end of the Sunday mass, when she saw him playing cards in the new house.
tr: After a Sunday mass, when she saw Arcadio sitting in his new house playing cards with his officials, she shouted, You are the disgrace of our family!
es: "You are the shame of our family name," she shouted at him one Sunday after mass, when she saw him in the new house playing cards with his officers.

en: Arcadio paid no attention to her.
vi: Arcadio ignored her words.
tr: Arcadio paid her no mind.
es: Arcadio paid no attention to her.

en: Only then did Úrsula know that he had a six-month-old daughter and that Santa Sofía de la Piedad, with whom he was living outside of marriage, was pregnant again.
vi: It was only then that Úrsula learned he had a six-month-old daughter and that Santa Sofía de la Piedad, the woman he was living with without being married, was pregnant again.
tr: It was only then that Ursula learned he had a six-month-old daughter and that Santa Sofia de la Piedad, with whom he was living, was pregnant again.
es: Only then did Úrsula learn that he had a six-month-old daughter, and that Santa Sofía de la Piedad, with whom he was living without being married, was pregnant again.

en: She decided to write to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, wherever he was, to bring him up to date on the situation.
vi: Ursula intended to write a letter to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, no matter where he was, to inform him of everything happening at home and in the neighborhood.
tr: Upon this, she decided to find Colonel Aureliano Buendia wherever he was and write him a letter to inform him of what had happened.
es: She resolved to write to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, wherever he might be, to inform him of the situation.

en: But the fast-moving events of those days not only prevented her plans from being carried out, they made her regret having conceived them.
vi: But the tumultuous events at that time not only hindered all her intentions but also made her regret having gathered them.
tr: However, the rapidly unfolding events of the days not only prevented Ursula from implementing her plans but also made her regret even thinking about them.
es: But the events that unfolded in those days not only thwarted her plans but made her regret having conceived them.

en: The war, which until then had been only a word to designate a vague and remote circumstance, became a concrete and dramatic reality.
vi: War, which until then had been just a word to describe an empty and stagnant situation, had materialized into a tragic reality.
tr: Until then, the word war, which served only to describe a vague and distant event, suddenly became a concrete and dramatic reality.
es: The war, which until then had been just a word to designate a vague and remote circumstance, became a dramatic reality.

en: Around the end of February an old woman with an ashen look arrived in Macondo riding a donkey loaded down with brooms.
vi: At the end of February, an old woman with white hair riding a broomstick horse arrived in the village of Macondo.
tr: Towards the end of February, an old woman with an ashen face, riding a donkey loaded with brooms, arrived in Macondo.
es: At the end of February, an elderly woman with an ashen appearance arrived in Macondo, riding a donkey loaded with brooms.

en: She seemed so inoffensive that the sentries let her pass without any questions as another vendor, one of the many who often arrived from the towns in the swamp.
vi: She looked so gentle that the patrols let her into the village without questioning her, just as they had not questioned the peddlers who often passed through the villages around the swamp.
tr: She had such a harmless appearance that the guards, thinking she was one of the vendors from the swamp villages, let her into the village without any questioning.
es: She seemed so harmless that the patrols let her pass without questions, like one of the many vendors who often came from the swamp villages.

en: She went directly to the barracks.
vi: She went straight to the barracks, where Arcadio received her right in what used to be the classroom and was now the soldiers' resting place, where hammocks were rolled up and hung on hooks, backpacks were piled up in corners, and rifles, carbines, and hunting guns were scattered all over the floor.
tr: The woman went straight to the barracks.
es: She went directly to the barracks.

en: Arcadio received her in the place where the classroom used to be and which at that time had been transformed into a kind of rearguard encampment, with roiled hammocks hanging on hooks and mats piled up in the corners, and rifles and carbines and even hunting shotguns scattered on the floor.
vi: She went straight to the barracks, where Arcadio received her right in what used to be the classroom and was now the soldiers' resting place, where hammocks were rolled up and hung on hooks, backpacks were piled up in corners, and rifles, carbines, and hunting guns were scattered all over the floor.
tr: Arcadio received her in the room that had once been a classroom. Now it had been turned into a sort of rear headquarters, with hammocks coiled and folded on hooks, beds piled in the corners, and rifles, carbines, and even hunting shotguns spread out on the floor.
es: Arcadio received her in the room that had once been the classroom, which had since been transformed into a sort of rear-guard camp, with hammocks rolled up and hung on the rings, and bedrolls piled in the corners, and rifles and carbines and even hunting shotguns scattered on the floor.

en: The old woman stiffened into a military salute before identifying herself:
vi: The old woman saluted in a military manner before introducing herself:
tr: Before the old woman introduced herself, she straightened up, stood at attention, and gave a military salute.
es: The elderly woman stood at attention in a military salute before identifying herself:

en: “I am Colonel Gregorio Stevenson.”
vi: - I am Colonel Gregory Stevenson.
tr: -Lieutenant Colonel Gregorio Stevenson.
es: —I am Colonel Gregorio Stevenson.

en: He brought bad news.
vi: He brings bad news.
tr: He had brought bad news.
es: He brought bad news.
