en: The last centers of Liberal resistance, according to what he said, were being wiped out.
vi: The last strongholds of the Liberal forces, according to him, are being destroyed.
tr: According to him, the last strongholds of the Liberals had also begun to fall.
es: The last pockets of liberal resistance, he said, were being exterminated.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, whom he had left fighting in retreat near Riohacha, had given him a message for Arcadio.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, who is being pursued by the Royalist army on the outskirts of the city of Riohacha, has entrusted him with the mission to speak with Arcadio, advising him to surrender the square to the government forces under the condition that they honorably promise to ensure the safety and property of the Liberals.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, whom he had left fighting while retreating near Riohacha, had sent a message to Arcadio.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, whom he had left retreating around the Riohacha area, entrusted him with the mission of speaking to Arcadio.

en: He should surrender the town without resistance on the condition that the lives and property of Liberals would be respected.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, who is being pursued by the Royalist army on the outskirts of the city of Riohacha, has entrusted him with the mission to speak with Arcadio, advising him to surrender the square to the government forces under the condition that they honorably promise to ensure the safety and property of the Liberals.
tr: He would surrender the village without resistance, on the condition that the lives and property of the Liberals would be protected.
es: He was to surrender the town without resistance, on the condition that the lives and properties of the liberals would be respected under a word of honor.

en: Arcadio examined that strange messenger who could have been a fugitive grandmother with a look of pity.
vi: Accađiô looked with suspicious eyes at the strange messenger, who could be mistaken for a frightened old woman fleeing. - So may I ask if you have any documents with you?
tr: Arcadio looked pityingly at this strange messenger who resembled lost grandmothers.
es: Arcadio examined with a look of pity that strange messenger who could have been mistaken for a runaway grandmother.

en: “You have brought something in writing, naturally,” he said.
vi: - he asked.
tr: "Of course, you brought something written," he said.
es: —You, of course, bring some written paper —he said.

en: “Naturally,” the emissary answered, “I have brought nothing of the sort.
vi: - Unfortunately, - the messenger replied, - I didn't bring it with me.
tr: "Of course, I didn't bring anything like that," said the messenger.
es: —Of course —replied the emissary—, I don't have it with me.

en: It’s easy to understand that under the present circumstances a person can’t carry anything that would compromise him.”
vi: It is understandable that under the current conditions, it is really difficult to carry anything on one's person that might arouse suspicion.
tr: "You should know that under these circumstances, one cannot carry anything that would give them away."
es: It is easy to understand that under the current circumstances, one does not carry anything compromising.

en: As he was speaking he reached into his bodice and took out a small gold fish.
vi: While speaking, he took a goldfish out of his chest pocket and placed it on the table.
tr: While speaking, he reached into his bosom and took out a small fish made of silver.
es: While he was speaking, he took out from his bodice and placed on the table a little gold fish.

en: “I think that this will be sufficient,” he said.
vi: "I believe this will be more than sufficient," he said.
tr: I think this is enough, he said.
es: “I think this will be enough,” he said.

en: Arcadio could see that indeed it was one of the little fishes made by Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: Accadio confirmed that it was one of the goldfish made by Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: Arcadio recognized the fish as soon as he saw it, knowing it had come from Colonel Aureliano Buendía's hand.
es: Arcadio verified that it was indeed one of the little fish made by Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: But anyone could have bought it before the war or stolen it, and it had no merit as a safe-conduct pass.
vi: But someone had either bought it before the war broke out or had stolen it, and thus it no longer held the value of a transit pass.
tr: However, someone could have taken or stolen it before the war.
es: But someone could have bought it before the war, or stolen it, and therefore it had no merit as a safe-conduct.

en: The messenger even went to the extreme of violating a military secret so that they would believe his identity.
vi: At this point, the messenger was forced to violate military secrecy to reveal his true identity.
tr: A man could not be trusted blindly just because he had a silver fish in his bosom. The messenger went so far as to reveal a military secret to prove his identity.
es: The messenger went so far as to violate a war secret to prove his identity.

en: He revealed that he was on a mission to Curaçao, where he hoped to recruit exiles from all over the Caribbean and acquire arms and supplies sufficient to attempt a landing at the end of the year.
vi: He recounted that his mission was to go to Curaçao to recruit all the exiles from the entire Caribbean region, purchase enough weapons and military supplies to plan a landing by the end of the year.
tr: He explained that he had gone to Curaçao on duty, would gather all the exiles in the Caribbean region, and would find enough weapons and ammunition to launch an assault by the end of the year.
es: He revealed that he was on a mission to Curaçao, where he hoped to recruit exiles from all over the Caribbean and acquire enough weapons and supplies to attempt a landing by the end of the year.

en: With faith in that plan, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was not in favor of any useless sacrifices at that time.
vi: Although he trusted the plan, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not agree that it was the right time to carry out such futile sacrificial activities.
tr: Since Colonel Aureliano Buendía believed that this plan would succeed, he was against unnecessary loss of life at that moment.
es: Trusting in that plan, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was not in favor of making useless sacrifices at that moment.

en: But Arcadio was inflexible.
vi: But Accadio was ruthless.
tr: But Arcadio was adamant and unyielding.
es: But Arcadio was inflexible.

en: He had the prisoner put into the stocks until he could prove his identity and he resolved to defend the town to the death.
vi: He imprisoned the messenger to verify his background and decided to defend the square to the last breath.
tr: He arrested the messenger and had him shackled until he could prove his identity, deciding to defend the village to the last drop of his blood.
es: He had the messenger imprisoned while verifying his identity, and resolved to defend the place to the death.

en: He did not have long to wait.
vi: No need to wait long.
tr: He didn't have to wait long.
es: He did not have to wait long.

en: The news of the Liberal defeat was more and more concrete.
vi: News of the Liberal faction's failure became more and more certain.
tr: News of the Liberals' defeat was increasing day by day.
es: The news of the liberal failure became increasingly concrete.

en: Toward the end of March, before a dawn of premature rain, the tense calm of the previous weeks was abruptly broken by the desperate sounds of a cornet and a cannon shot that knocked down the steeple of the church.
vi: In the early hours of a late March night, amidst early downpours, the heavy, quiet atmosphere of the previous weeks suddenly dissipated with the eerie sound of a cornet and the violent explosion of a cannon that brought down the church bell tower.
tr: Towards the end of March, at dawn when untimely rains were pouring down, the tense silence of the past weeks was broken by the bitter sound of a trumpet and the cannon noise that destroyed the church's tower.
es: At the end of March, in the early hours of a premature rainy morning, the tense calm of the previous weeks was abruptly shattered by a desperate bugle call, followed by a cannon shot that destroyed the temple tower.

en: Actually, Arcadio’s decision to resist was madness.
vi: In reality, Arcadio's resolve to resist was a mad idea.
tr: In fact, Arcadio's decision to resist was sheer madness.
es: In reality, Arcadio's will to resist was madness.

en: He had only fifty poorly armed men with a ration of twenty cartridges apiece.
vi: He had no more than fifty poorly armed men with no more than twenty bullets per gun.
tr: Supposedly, he had fifty armed men, and each man had twenty bullets.
es: He had no more than fifty poorly armed men, each with a maximum supply of twenty cartridges.

en: But among them, his former pupils, excited by the high-sounding proclamations, the determination reigned to sacrifice their skins for a lost cause.
vi: But among the resistance fighters, his former students, who were once eager with his grand declarations, were determined to fight to the last moment for a lost cause.
tr: Even so, former students, spurred on by Arcadio's boasts, had committed themselves wholeheartedly to the lost cause.
es: But among them, his former students, excited by high-sounding proclamations, were determined to sacrifice their skins for a lost cause.

en: In the midst of the tramping of boots, contradictory commands, cannon shots that made the earth tremble, wild shooting, and the senseless sound of cornets, the supposed Colonel Stevenson managed to speak to Arcadio.
vi: In the midst of the chaotic sounds of running boots, conflicting orders, earth-shaking cannon blasts, random gunfire, and meaningless cornet calls, the imprisoned Colonel Stevenson requested to speak with Arcadio.
tr: Amid the sounds of boots on the roads, clashing commands, earth-shaking cannons, whizzing bullets, and the harsh sounds of bugles, a man called Colonel Stevenson found an opportunity to speak with Arcadio.
es: Amid the clatter of boots, contradictory orders, cannon shots that made the ground tremble, hasty gunfire, and senseless bugle calls, the supposed Colonel Stevenson managed to speak with Arcadio.

en: “Don’t let me undergo the indignity of dying in the stocks in these women’s clothes,” he said to him.
vi: "Spare me the shame of dying in prison dressed in women's clothes," he said to him.
tr: "Don't humiliate me by making me die in women's clothing," he said.
es: “Spare me the indignity of dying in the stocks with these women's rags,” he said.

en: “If I have to die, let me die fighting.”
vi: "If I must die, I will die fighting.
tr: "If I'm going to die, let me die fighting."
es: “If I am to die, let it be fighting.”

en: He succeeded in convincing him.
vi: "Arcadio ordered a gun with twenty bullets to be given to him and allowed him, along with five others, to defend the barracks, while he and his command went to the front line of the resistance.
tr: In the end, he managed to convince Arcadio.
es: He managed to convince him.

en: Arcadio ordered them to give him a weapon and twenty cartridges, and he left him with five men to defend headquarters while he went off with his staff to head up the resistance.
vi: "Arcadio ordered a gun with twenty bullets to be given to him and allowed him, along with five others, to defend the barracks, while he and his command went to the front line of the resistance.
tr: Arcadio ordered that he be given a weapon and twenty bullets, left five men with him to defend the headquarters, and went out with his men to lead the resistance.
es: Arcadio ordered that he be given a weapon with twenty cartridges and left him with five men defending the barracks while he went with his staff to lead the resistance.

en: He did not get to the road to the swamp.
vi: "Arcadio ordered a gun with twenty bullets to be given to him and allowed him, along with five others, to defend the barracks, while he and his command went to the front line of the resistance.
tr: However, he couldn't reach the main road leading to the swamp.
es: He did not reach the swamp road.

en: The barricades had been broken and the defenders were openly fighting in the streets, first until they used up their ration of rifle bullets, then with pistols against rifles, and finally hand to hand.
vi: The barricades were broken, and the village defenders had to fight an uneven gun battle in the streets. First, they fought with rifles until they ran out of bullets, then with pistols against rifles, and finally in hand-to-hand combat.
tr: The barricades had been destroyed. The defenders of the village were fighting in the streets. They fought with their rifles until they ran out of bullets, then drew their pistols against the rifles, and finally came to hand-to-hand combat, grappling throat to throat.
es: The barricades had been torn apart and the defenders were fighting in the open in the streets, first as far as their rifle supplies would last, then with pistols against rifles, and finally hand to hand.

en: With the imminence of defeat, some women went into the street armed with sticks and kitchen knives.
vi: Facing imminent defeat, some women, wielding sticks and butcher knives, poured into the streets.
tr: Seeing the rout, some of the women took to the streets with sticks and bread knives they had grabbed.
es: Faced with imminent defeat, some women took to the streets armed with sticks and kitchen knives.

en: In that confusion Arcadio found Amaranta, who was looking for him like a madwoman, in her nightgown and with two old pistols that had belonged to José Arcadio Buendía.
vi: In that chaotic scene, Arcadio encountered Amaranta in her nightgown, holding two old pistols of José Arcadio Buendía, frantically searching for him.
tr: In that chaos, Arcadio, in his nightshirt and with José Arcadio Buendía's two old pistols in hand, encountered Amaranta, who was frantically searching for him.
es: In that confusion, Arcadio found Amaranta who was looking for him like a madwoman, in her nightgown, with two old pistols of José Arcadio Buendía.

en: He gave his rifle to an officer who had been disarmed in the fight and escaped with Amaranta through a nearby street to take her home.
vi: Arcadio handed his gun to an officer who had lost his weapon in the battle, then slipped into a nearby alley with Amaranta to take her home.
tr: Arcadio gave his rifle to an officer who had lost his weapon in the fight and turned into a side street to take Amaranta home.
es: He gave his rifle to an officer who had been disarmed in the skirmish, and escaped with Amaranta down an adjacent street to take her home.

en: Úrsula was, in the doorway waiting, indifferent to the cannon shots that had opened up a hole in the front of the house next door.
vi: Ursula stood at the doorway, waiting, despite the gunfire and a stray bullet that punched a hole in the front wall of the neighboring house.
tr: Ursula was standing at the door, waiting for them, indifferent to the cannon fire that had made a huge breach in the adjoining house.
es: Úrsula was at the door, waiting, indifferent to the gunfire that had opened a breach in the facade of the neighboring house.

en: The rain was letting up, but the streets were as slippery and as smooth as melted soap, and one had to guess distances in the darkness.
vi: The rain had stopped, but the main road was muddy like soap foam, and people had to feel their way in the darkness.
tr: The rain was letting up, but the streets were as slippery as if soap had been spilled on them, and in the darkness, distance could only be judged by eye.
es: The rain was letting up, but the streets were slippery and soft like melted soap, and distances had to be guessed in the darkness.

en: Arcadio left Amaranta with Úrsula and made an attempt to face two soldiers who had opened up with heavy firing from the corner.
vi: Arcadio left Amaranta with Ursula and intended to face two government soldiers coming down the street to search.
tr: Arcadio left Amaranta with Ursula and tried to confront two soldiers who were firing from the corner.
es: Arcadio left Amaranta with Úrsula and tried to confront two soldiers who fired a blind volley from the corner.

en: The old pistols that had been kept for many years in the bureau did not work.
vi: The pistols, having been in the drawer for too long without oil, did not fire.
tr: The old pistols, forgotten for years at the bottom of a drawer, did not fire.
es: The old pistols, stored for many years in a wardrobe, did not work.

en: Protecting Arcadio with her body, Úrsula tried to drag him toward the house.
vi: Shielding Arcadio with her body, Ursula tried to pull him back to her house.
tr: Ursula tried to pull Arcadio into the house, shielding him with her body.
es: Protecting Arcadio with her body, Úrsula tried to drag him to the house.

en: “Come along in the name of God,” she shouted at him.
vi: - Come back immediately! For God's sake, come back home immediately - she shouted at him.
tr: "For God's sake, come!" he shouted.
es: —Come on, for God's sake —he shouted at him—.

en: “There’s been enough madness!”
vi: - Stop this madness.
tr: "This madness is enough!"
es: Enough of this madness!

en: The soldiers aimed at them.
vi: The soldiers fired bullets at them.
tr: The soldiers took aim at them.
es: The soldiers aimed at them.

en: “Let go of that man, ma’am,” one of them shouted, “or we won’t be responsible!”
vi: - Old woman, let go of that person, - a soldier shouted, - or we will not be responsible for your death.
tr: Someone shouted, "Leave that man alone, lady." Or else we won't intervene!
es: —Let go of that man, ma'am —shouted one of them—, or we won't be responsible for what happens!

en: Arcadio pushed Úrsula toward the house and surrendered.
vi: Accadio pushed Ursula towards the house, while he raised his hands in surrender.
tr: Arcadio pushed Ursula towards the house, then surrendered.
es: Arcadio pushed Úrsula towards the house and surrendered.

en: A short time later the shooting stopped and the bells began to toll.
vi: Shortly thereafter, the gunfire ceased abruptly and the church bells began to toll.
tr: Soon after, the gunfire ceased, and the bells began to ring.
es: Shortly after, the shooting stopped and the bells began to ring.

en: The resistance had been wiped out in less than half an hour.
vi: The resistance was crushed in less than half an hour.
tr: The resistance was broken in less than half an hour.
es: The resistance had been annihilated in less than half an hour.

en: Not a single one of Arcadio’s men had survived the attack, but before dying they had killed three hundred soldiers.
vi: Not a single person from Akkad survived the attack, but before dying, they were all paraded in front of three hundred government soldiers.
tr: Not a single one of Arcadio's men survived, but they had killed three hundred soldiers from the opposing side.
es: Not a single one of Arcadio's men survived the assault, but before dying they took down three hundred soldiers.

en: The last stronghold was the barracks.
vi: The last fortress to be destroyed was the military camp.
tr: The last point of resistance was the headquarters.
es: The last stronghold was the barracks.

en: Before being attacked, the supposed Colonel Gregorio Stevenson had freed the prisoners and ordered his men to go out and fight in the street.
vi: Before it was attacked, Colonel Gregory Stevenson, who was imprisoned, released all the prisoners and ordered his subordinates to go out and fight on the streets.
tr: Before the attack, a man named Colonel Gregorio Stevenson had released the prisoners in the headquarters and ordered his men to go out and fight in the streets.
es: Before being attacked, the supposed Colonel Gregorio Stevenson set the prisoners free and ordered his men to go out and fight in the street.

en: The extraordinary mobility and accurate aim with which he placed his twenty cartridges gave the impression that the barracks was well-defended, and the attackers blew it to pieces with cannon fire.
vi: The change in the combat position was as flexible as his, and the precise trajectory of the twenty bullets he fired from different windows gave the impression that the barracks were well-defended, forcing the attackers to use cannons to bring it down.
tr: His extraordinary agility and his ability to hit all twenty of his shots without missing gave the impression that the headquarters was defended by a multitude of people, causing the attackers to bombard the headquarters with cannonballs.
es: The extraordinary mobility and accurate aim with which he fired his twenty cartridges from different windows gave the impression that the barracks was well guarded, and the attackers blew it to pieces with cannon fire.

en: The captain who directed the operation was startled to find the rubble deserted and a single dead man in his undershorts with an empty rifle still clutched in an arm that had been blown completely off.
vi: The captain commanding the battle was astonished by the sight of the collapsed walls, with only one man, wearing nothing but shorts, dead, and a gun with no bullets being held by a severed arm.
tr: The captain leading the attack was surprised when he saw no one among the ruins except a single dead body with a shattered arm, holding an empty rifle, and wearing nothing but underwear.
es: The captain who led the operation was astonished to find the rubble deserted, and a single man in his underwear, dead, with an unloaded rifle still clutched by an arm that had been torn off.

en: He had a woman’s full head of hair held at the neck with a comb and on his neck a chain with a small gold fish.
vi: That man had thick, curly hair resting on his shoulders and wore a necklace with a goldfish pendant around his neck.
tr: The dead man's long hair, like that of a woman, was held at the nape of his neck with a comb, and there was a small fish pendant hanging from a chain around his neck.
es: He had a thick mane of a woman's hair coiled at the nape with a comb, and around his neck a scapular with a little gold fish.

en: When he turned him over with the tip of his boot and put the light on his face, the captain was perplexed.
vi: When the captain used his boot to turn the man's face up for a clearer look, he was startled and exclaimed, "Holy crap," he said.
tr: When the captain turned the corpse over onto its back with the toe of his boot and shone a light on its face, his astonishment grew even more.
es: When he turned him over with the tip of his boot to light up his face, the captain was perplexed.

en: “Jesus Christ,” he exclaimed.
vi: When the captain used his boot to turn the man's face up for a clearer look, he was startled and exclaimed, "Holy crap," he said.
tr: "Oh my God!" he cried out.
es: “Shit,” he exclaimed.

en: Other officers came over.
vi: Several other officers also rushed over.
tr: The other officers rushed to his side.
es: Other officers approached.

en: “Look where this fellow turned up,” the captain said.
vi: - Look, where does this man come from? - the captain said to them.
tr: The captain said, "Look, who would have thought!"
es: —Look where this man turned up —the captain told them—.

en: “It’s Gregorio Stevenson.”
vi: - That is Gregorio Stevenson.
tr: Gregorio Stevenson.
es: It's Gregorio Stevenson.

en: At dawn, after a summary court martial, Arcadio was shot against the wall of the cemetery.
vi: At dawn, Accadio was shot in front of the cemetery wall after the military council held an emergency meeting.
tr: At dawn, by the decision of the hastily convened military court, Arcadio was executed by firing squad at the foot of the cemetery wall.
es: At dawn, after a summary court-martial, Arcadio was executed by firing squad against the cemetery wall.

en: In the last two hours of his life he did not manage to understand why the fear that had tormented him since childhood had disappeared.
vi: In the last two hours of his life, he still couldn't understand why the fear of death that had tormented him since childhood had vanished.
tr: He himself could not understand why the fear that had poisoned his life since childhood suddenly vanished in the last two hours of his life.
es: In the last two hours of his life, he could not understand why the fear that had tormented him since childhood had disappeared.

en: Impassive.
vi: With a cold, calm demeanor, not at all concerned with proving his newly found courage, he listened to the lengthy accusations.
tr: Without attempting to show the courage he had displayed moments before, he listened indifferently to the accusations directed at him by the court.
es: Impassive, without even bothering to demonstrate his newfound courage, he listened to the endless charges of the accusation.

en: without even worrying about making a show of his recent bravery, he listened to the interminable charges of the accusation.
vi: With a cold, calm demeanor, not at all concerned with proving his newly found courage, he listened to the lengthy accusations.
tr: Without attempting to show the courage he had displayed moments before, he listened indifferently to the accusations directed at him by the court.
es: Impassive, without even bothering to demonstrate his newfound courage, he listened to the endless charges of the accusation.

en: He thought about Úrsula, who at that hour must have been under the chestnut tree having coffee with José Arcadio Buendía.
vi: He thought of Úrsula, who at this hour was probably drinking coffee with José Arcadio Buendía under the chestnut tree.
tr: He remembered Ursula. He thought that at this hour she must be having her morning coffee with Jose Arcadio Buendia under the chestnut tree.
es: He thought of Úrsula, who at that hour must be under the chestnut tree having coffee with José Arcadio Buendía.

en: He thought about his eight-month-old daughter, who still had no name, and about the child who was going to be born in August.
vi: He thought of the eight-month-old daughter who still had no name and the child that would be born in the coming August.
tr: He thought of his eight-month-old daughter, who had not yet been named, and the child that would be born in August.
es: He thought of his eight-month-old daughter, who still did not have a name, and of the one who was to be born in August.

en: He thought about Santa Sofía de la Piedad, whom he had left the night before salting down a deer for next day’s lunch, and he missed her hair pouring over her shoulders and her eyelashes, which looked as if they were artificial.
vi: He thought of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, who had marinated a deer last night for Saturday's lunch, remembered her long hair falling over her shoulders, and her long eyelashes that looked like they were fake.
tr: He thought of Santa Sofia de la Piedad, whom he had left the evening before while salting the venison for the next day's meal; he missed her hair falling on her shoulders and her eyelashes that looked artificial.
es: He thought of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, whom he had left the night before salting a deer for Saturday's lunch, and he longed for her hair streaming over her shoulders and her eyelashes that seemed artificial.

en: He thought about his people without sentimentality, with a strict dosing of his accounts with life, beginning to understand how much he really loved the people he hated most.
vi: He thought of his people without the slightest regret. In the fairness that life demanded, he began to understand how much he actually loved those he had once hated.
tr: As he was definitively settling his account with life, he wasn't getting emotional thinking about his own people; he was beginning to understand how he had actually loved the people he hated the most.
es: He thought of his people without sentimentality, in a severe reckoning with life, beginning to understand how much he really loved the people he had most hated.

en: The president of the court-martial began his final speech when Arcadio realized that two hours had passed.
vi: The president of the military council began his final speech just as Arcadio suddenly remembered that two hours had already passed.
tr: When the president of the military court finished his speech, Arcadio realized that two hours had passed.
es: The president of the court-martial began his final speech, before Arcadio realized that two hours had passed.

en: “Even if the proven charges did not have merit enough,” the president was saying, “the irresponsible and criminal boldness with which the accused drove his subordinates on to a useless death would be enough to deserve capital punishment.”
vi: "Although the positions assigned to him were insignificant," the president said, "his aggressive, irresponsible, and cruel attitude led his subordinates to useless deaths, which is enough to sentence him to death."...
tr: Although we do not have sufficient evidence to substantiate the charges, said the president, the defendant's irresponsible rashness, which led those under his command to unnecessary death, is enough to warrant the heaviest penalty.
es: "Although the proven charges may not have had sufficient merit," said the president, "the irresponsible and criminal recklessness with which the accused pushed his subordinates to a useless death would be enough to deserve the death penalty."

en: In the shattered schoolhouse where for the first time he had felt the security of power, a few feet from the room where he had come to know the uncertainty of love, Arcadio found the formality of death ridiculous.
vi: At the cracked school where he first felt the certainty of power, just a few meters from the classroom where he first experienced bewildering love, Arcadio encountered the ridiculous form of death.
tr: Arcadio found it absurd that he was preparing for his death a few steps away from the room where he first felt the anxiety of love, in the ruined classroom where he first tasted the security of power.
es: In the dilapidated school where he first experienced the security of power, a few meters from the room where he knew the uncertainty of love, Arcadio found the formality of death ridiculous.

en: Death really did not matter to him but life did, and therefore the sensation he felt when they gave their decision was not a feeling of fear but of nostalgia.
vi: In reality, what mattered to him now was not death but life, and thus, the feeling he experienced when sentenced to death was not fear but longing.
tr: He didn't care about death, but life meant a lot. Therefore, his feeling at the moment the death sentence was pronounced was not fear, but longing.
es: In reality, it was not death that mattered to him but life, and that is why the sensation he experienced when the sentence was pronounced was not one of fear but of nostalgia.

en: He did not speak until they asked him for his last request.
vi: He remained silent until asked what his final wish was.
tr: He did not open his mouth until he was asked what his last wish was.
es: He did not speak until he was asked what his last wish was.

en: “Tell my wife,” he answered in a well-modulated voice, “to give the girl the name of Úrsula.”
vi: - Tell my wife, - he replied in a loud voice, - to name our daughter Ucsula, - he thought and confirmed: yes, Ucsula, the name of her grandmother.
tr: In a soft voice, he said, Tell my wife to name the girl Ursula.
es: —Tell my wife —he replied with a well-modulated voice— to name the girl Úrsula.

en: He paused and said it again: “Úrsula, like her grandmother.
vi: - Tell my wife, - he replied in a loud voice, - to name our daughter Ucsula, - he thought and confirmed: yes, Ucsula, the name of her grandmother.
tr: After pausing for a moment, he repeated: Like her grandmother's, Ursula.
es: —He paused and confirmed—: Úrsula, like the grandmother.

en: And tell her also that if the child that is to be born is a boy, they should name him José Arcadio, not for his uncle, but for his grandfather.”
vi: And tell my wife that if the child to be born is a boy, name him José Arcadio, but not after his uncle, rather after his grandfather.
tr: Then say that if the child to be born is a boy, they should name him Jose Arcadio, not to resemble his uncle, but to resemble his grandfather.
es: And also tell her that if the one to be born is a boy, to name him José Arcadio, but not after the uncle, rather after the grandfather.

en: Before they took him to the execution wall Father Nicanor tried to attend him.
vi: Before they took him to the wall at the cemetery, Father Nicanor intended to baptize him.
tr: Before they took him to the wall where he would be executed by firing squad, Father Nicanor came to hear his confession.
es: Before they took him to the wall, Father Nicanor tried to assist him.

en: “I have nothing to repent,” Arcadio said, and he put himself under the orders of the squad after drinking a cup of black coffee.
vi: "I have no regrets," Arcadio said, and followed the execution squad's orders after drinking a cup of black coffee.
tr: Arcadio said, I am not sorry for what I have done. And after drinking a cup of black coffee, he followed the command of the execution squad and set off.
es: “I have nothing to repent for,” said Arcadio, and he put himself at the orders of the squad after having a cup of black coffee.

en: The leader of the squad, a specialist in summary executions, had a name that had much more about it than chance: Captain Roque Carnicero, which meant butcher.
vi: The commander of the execution squad, a man who specialized in carrying out death sentences, had a name very fitting for his profession: Captain Roque Carnicero.
tr: The name of the commander, who was unmatched in hasty executions, suited him well: Captain Roque Carnicero, which meant butcher.
es: The leader of the squad, a specialist in summary executions, had a name that was much more than a coincidence: Captain Roque Carnicero.

en: On the way to the cemetery, under the persistent drizzle, Arcadio saw that a radiant Wednesday was breaking out on the horizon.
vi: On the way to the cemetery, under a light drizzle, Arcadio noticed that a dawn Wednesday was beginning to glow on the horizon.
tr: As they were heading to the cemetery, under the constant drizzle, Arcadio saw that a bright Wednesday was about to dawn on the horizon.
es: On the way to the cemetery, under the persistent drizzle, Arcadio noticed that a radiant Wednesday was dawning on the horizon.

en: His nostalgia disappeared with the mist and left an immense curiosity in its place.
vi: Nostalgia dissolved in the mist and left behind a terrible curiosity.
tr: With the dawn, the pain of longing within him also dissipated and was replaced by curiosity.
es: Nostalgia faded with the fog and left in its place an immense curiosity.

en: Only when they ordered him to put his back to the wall did Arcadio see Rebeca, with wet hair and a pink flowered dress, opening wide the door.
vi: Only when he was ordered to lean against the wall did Arcadio see Rebeca with her wet hair, wearing a pink floral dress, opening the door of the house wide.
tr: When they told him to lean against the wall, Arcadio saw Rebeca opening the door with her wet hair and pink nightgown.
es: Only when he was ordered to turn his back to the wall did Arcadio see Rebeca with wet hair and a dress of pink flowers, opening the house wide open.

en: He made an effort to get her to recognize him.
vi: He silently prayed that Rebeca would recognize him.
tr: He tried to introduce himself.
es: He made an effort for her to recognize him.

en: And Rebeca did take a casual look toward the wall and was paralyzed with stupor, barely able to react and wave good-bye to Arcadio.
vi: Indeed, at that moment, Rebeca looked towards the cemetery wall and suddenly stood there, stunned and horrified. She barely had time to signal a farewell to Arcadio.
tr: Rebeca glanced at the wall and froze in astonishment. She barely had time to wave to Arcadio.
es: Indeed, Rebeca casually looked towards the wall and was paralyzed with astonishment, and could barely react to wave goodbye to Arcadio with her hand.

en: Arcadio answered her the same way.
vi: Arcadio responded with a similar gesture.
tr: Arcadio waved back at her.
es: Arcadio responded in the same way.

en: At that instant the smoking mouths of the rifles were aimed at him and letter by letter he heard the encyclicals that Melquíades had chanted and he heard the lost steps of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, a virgin, in the classroom, and in his nose he felt the same icy hardness that had drawn his attention in the nostrils of the corpse of Remedios.
vi: At that moment, the smoking barrels of the guns fired at Arcadio, and he clearly heard each word of the chant recited by old Melquíades and felt the staggering footsteps of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, the virgin maiden, echoing in the classroom, and felt the cold hardness of ice on his nose, which he had noticed in the nostrils of Remedios' corpse.
tr: At that moment, the smoking barrels of the rifles were aimed at him, and Arcadio heard Melquiades' words verbatim, the footsteps of untouched Santa Sofia de la Piedad in the dark classroom echoed in his ears, and he felt the icy stiffness he saw in Remedios' nostrils when she died in his own nose.
es: At that moment, the smoky barrels of the rifles aimed at him, and he heard letter by letter the encyclicals sung by Melquíades, and felt the lost steps of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, virgin, in the classroom, and experienced in his nose the same icy hardness that had caught his attention in the nostrils of Remedios' corpse.

en: “Oh, God damn it!” he managed to think.
vi: "Ah, the b... - he just had time to think, - I forgot to say that if it's a girl, name her Remedios."
tr: Damn it! he had just enough time to think.
es: “Ah, damn! —he managed to think—, I forgot to say that if it was a girl, they should name her Remedios.”

en: “I forgot to say that if it was a girl they should name her Remedios.”
vi: "Ah, the b... - he just had time to think, - I forgot to say that if it's a girl, name her Remedios."
tr: I forgot to tell them to name the child Remedios if it’s a girl.
es: “Ah, damn! —he managed to think—, I forgot to say that if it was a girl, they should name her Remedios.”

en: Then, all accumulated in the rip of a claw, he felt again all the terror that had tormented him in his life.
vi: At that moment, he felt the fear that had tormented him his entire life.
tr: Then, all the fear that had poisoned his entire life pierced his heart at once.
es: Then, accumulated in a tearing claw, he felt again all the terror that had tormented him in life.

en: The captain gave the order to fire.
vi: The captain ordered the guns to fire.
tr: The captain gave the order to fire: Arcadio barely had time to puff out his chest and lift his head, and he couldn't understand where the hot liquid scorching his groin was coming from.
es: The captain gave the order to fire.

en: Arcadio barely had time to put out his chest and raise his head, not understanding where the hot liquid that burned his thighs was pouring from.
vi: Almost at the same time, Arcadio managed to puff out his chest and lift his head, not understanding where the stream of hot, thick liquid that was burning his muscles was coming from:
tr: The captain gave the order to fire: Arcadio barely had time to puff out his chest and lift his head, and he couldn't understand where the hot liquid scorching his groin was coming from.
es: Arcadio barely had time to puff out his chest and lift his head, without understanding where the burning liquid that was scorching his thighs was flowing from.

en: “Bastards!” he shouted.
vi: - You old goat, - he shouted - Long live the Liberal Party!
tr: "You sons of bitches!" he shouted.
es: —Bastards! —he shouted—.

en: “Long live the Liberal Party!”
vi: - You old goat, - he shouted - Long live the Liberal Party!
tr: "Long live the Liberals!"
es: Long live the liberal party!

en: Chapter 7
vi: Chapter 7
tr: "Long live the Liberals!"
es: Long live the liberal party!

en: THE WAR was over in May.
vi: The war ended in May.
tr: The war ended in May.
es: The war ended in May.

en: Two weeks before the government made the official announcement in a high-sounding proclamation, which promised merciless punishment for those who had started the rebellion, Colonel Aureliano Buendía fell prisoner just as he was about to reach the western frontier disguised as an Indian witch doctor.
vi: Two weeks before the government issued an official announcement, in a boastful statement, they promised to mercilessly punish the leaders of the uprising. It was at that moment that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was captured while disguised as an Indian shaman, just as he was about to cross the western border of the country.
tr: Two weeks before the government announcement declaring that those who initiated the uprising would be ruthlessly punished, Colonel Aureliano Buendia was arrested while trying to cross the western border disguised as an Indian witch doctor.
es: Two weeks before the government made the official announcement, in a high-sounding proclamation that promised ruthless punishment for the promoters of the rebellion, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was captured when he was about to reach the western border disguised as an indigenous sorcerer.

en: Of the twenty-one men who had followed him to war, fourteen fell in combat, six were wounded, and only one accompanied him at the moment of final defeat: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.
vi: Of the twenty-one men who followed him in the war, fourteen died in battle, six were wounded, and only one remained with him in the final defeat. That person was Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.
tr: Of the twenty-one people who went to war following him, fourteen had died in combat, and six were wounded. At the moment of the final defeat, only one person remained by his side: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez.
es: Of the twenty-one men who followed him to war, fourteen died in combat, six were wounded, and only one accompanied him at the moment of final defeat: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.

en: The news of his capture was announced in Macondo with a special proclamation.
vi: Through a special decree, the news of his capture was announced in the village of Macondo.
tr: The news of Aureliano's capture was announced in Macondo through a special bulletin.
es: The news of the capture was announced in Macondo with an extraordinary decree.

en: “He’s alive,” Úrsula told her husband.
vi: "He is still alive… - Úrsula informed her husband.
tr: Ursula ran to her husband's side. He's alive, she said.
es: “He is alive,” Úrsula informed her husband.

en: “Let’s pray to God for his enemies to show him clemency.”
vi: "Let us hope that his enemies have mercy."
tr: Let us pray to God to instill a sense of mercy in the hearts of his enemies.
es: “Let us pray to God that his enemies have mercy.”

en: After three days of weeping, one afternoon as she was stirring some sweet milk candy in the kitchen she heard her son’s voice clearly in her ear.
vi: After three days of crying, one afternoon while stirring a pot of milk candy over the fire, she clearly heard her son's voice right next to her ear.
tr: After crying her heart out for three days and three nights, Ursula heard her son's voice while making caramel in the kitchen.
es: After three days of weeping, one afternoon while she was stirring a milk candy in the kitchen, she clearly heard her son's voice very close to her ear.

en: “It was Aureliano, “ she shouted, running toward the chestnut tree to tell her husband the news.
vi: "It's Aureliano," she screamed as she ran to the chestnut tree to inform her husband: "I don't know what kind of omen this is, but he is alive and we will see him soon."
tr: Running to the chestnut tree to inform her husband, she shouted, It was Aureliano's voice!
es: “It was Aureliano,” she shouted, running towards the chestnut tree to give the news to her husband.

en: “I don’t know how the miracle took place, but he’s alive and we’re going to see him very soon.”
vi: "It's Aureliano," she screamed as she ran to the chestnut tree to inform her husband: "I don't know what kind of omen this is, but he is alive and we will see him soon."
tr: I don't know what kind of miracle this is, but our son is alive, and we will see him in a few days.
es: “I don't know how the miracle happened, but he is alive and we will see him very soon.”

en: She took it for granted.
vi: She believed that omen to be true.
tr: Ursula was absolutely certain that she would see Aureliano.
es: She took it for granted.

en: She had the floors of the house scrubbed and changed the position of the furniture.
vi: She ordered the floor to be cleaned and the furniture to be rearranged.
tr: She had the floors scrubbed and rearranged the furniture.
es: She had the floors of the house washed and the furniture rearranged.

en: One week later a rumor from somewhere that was not supported by any proclamation gave dramatic confirmation to the prediction.
vi: A week later, a source without origin, not based on any decree, heartbreakingly confirmed that omen.
tr: A week later, a rumor that was not confirmed by any official statement supported Ursula's prophecy.
es: A few weeks later, a rumor without origin that would not be supported by the decree dramatically confirmed the omen.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been condemned to death and the sentence would be carried out in Macondo as a lesson to the population.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was sentenced to death, and the sentence would be carried out in the village of Macondo to intimidate the populace.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been sentenced to death, and his execution was to be carried out in Macondo as a lesson to the public.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been sentenced to death, and the sentence would be carried out in Macondo, as a warning to the population.

en: On Monday, at ten-thirty in the morning, Amaranta was dressing Aureliano José when she heard the sound of a distant troop and the blast of a cornet one second before Úrsula burst into the room with the shout: “They’re bringing him now!”
vi: At seven twenty on a Monday morning, Amaranta was dressing Aureliano José when she heard a distant commotion and a chilling cornet blast, and a minute later Úrsula burst into the room. "They are bringing him back," she said.
tr: One Monday morning at ten-thirty, while Amaranta was dressing Aureliano José, she heard the distant sound of soldiers marching and the blare of a bugle. One second later, Ursula burst into the room, shouting, They're bringing him!
es: One Monday, at twenty past ten in the morning, Amaranta was dressing Aureliano José when she perceived a distant commotion and a trumpet call, a second before Úrsula burst into the room with a shout: "They're bringing him."

en: The troop struggled to subdue the overflowing crowd with their rifle butts.
vi: The soldiers had to struggle, using their rifle butts to push through the chaotic crowd.
tr: The soldiers tried to disperse the gathered crowd by hitting them with their rifle butts.
es: The troops struggled to subdue the overflowing crowd with rifle butts.

en: Úrsula and Amaranta ran to the corner, pushing their way through, and then they saw him.
vi: Úrsula and Amaranta ran to the end of the street, pushed through the crowd, and there they saw Aureliano Buendía.
tr: Ursula and Amaranta pushed those around them aside, making their way to the corner, and they saw him.
es: Úrsula and Amaranta ran to the corner, pushing their way through, and then they saw him.

en: He looked like a beggar.
vi: He looked like a beggar: his clothes were in tatters, his hair and beard were unkempt, he was barefoot, his hands were tied behind his back with a rope attached to the saddle of the officer's horse.
tr: He looked like a beggar.
es: He looked like a beggar.

en: His clothing was torn, his hair and beard were tangled, and he was barefoot.
vi: He looked like a beggar: his clothes were in tatters, his hair and beard were unkempt, he was barefoot, his hands were tied behind his back with a rope attached to the saddle of the officer's horse.
tr: His clothes were torn, and his hair was tangled with his beard. He was barefoot.
es: His clothes were torn, his hair and beard tangled, and he was barefoot.

en: He was walking without feeling the burning dust, his hands tied behind his back with a rope that a mounted officer had attached to the head of his horse.
vi: He looked like a beggar: his clothes were in tatters, his hair and beard were unkempt, he was barefoot, his hands were tied behind his back with a rope attached to the saddle of the officer's horse.
tr: He walked without feeling the heat of the scorching ground. His hands were tied behind his back with a rope. One of the mounted officers had tied the end of the rope to his horse's head.
es: He walked without feeling the scorching dust, his hands tied behind his back with a rope held by a mounted officer.

en: Along with him, also ragged and defeated, they were bringing Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.
vi: Along with him, the soldiers were also escorting Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, who was just as ragged and miserable as he was.
tr: Along with him, they had also brought Colonel Gerineldo Marquez, who looked just as ragged and worn out.
es: Next to him, equally shabby and defeated, they were bringing Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.

en: They were not sad.
vi: The two men were not sad at all.
tr: Neither of them was sad.
es: They were not sad.

en: They seemed more disturbed by the crowd that was shouting all kinds of insults at the troops.
vi: They seemed to be excited in front of the crowd that was shouting and cursing the most depraved soldiers.
tr: The soldiers seemed uneasy with the cursing crowd.
es: They seemed rather disturbed by the crowd that shouted all kinds of insults at the troops.

en: “My son!” Úrsula shouted in the midst of the uproar, and she slapped the soldier who tried to hold her back.
vi: - Oh my child! - in the noisy scene filled with screams, Ursula called out to her child and slapped the soldier who was trying to stop her.
tr: Ursula, shouting "My son!" as she rushed forward through the crowd, slapped the soldier who tried to stop her.
es: —My son! —shouted Úrsula amidst the commotion, and she slapped the soldier who tried to stop her.

en: The officer’s horse reared.
vi: The officer's horse jumped up.
tr: The officer's horse reared back in fright.
es: The officer's horse reared up.

en: Then Colonel Aureliano Buendía stopped, tremulous, avoided the arms of his mother, and fixed a stern look on her eyes.
vi: At this moment, Colonel Aureliano Buendía stopped, trembling, and avoided his mother's outstretched arms that were about to embrace him, giving her a stern look:
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia stopped. He was trembling with anger. Without approaching his mother who wanted to embrace him, he stared directly into her eyes.
es: Then Colonel Aureliano Buendía stopped, trembling, dodged his mother's arms, and fixed a hard gaze on her eyes.

en: “Go home, Mama,” he said.
vi: - Mother, please go home, - he said.
tr: Go home, mother, he said.
es: —Go home, mom —he said—.

en: “Get permission from the authorities to come see me in jail.”
vi: - Please ask the authorities for permission to visit me in prison.
tr: Get permission from the authorities to see me in prison.
es: Ask the authorities for permission and come see me in jail.

en: He looked at Amaranta, who stood indecisively two steps behind Úrsula, and he smiled as he asked her, “What happened to your hand?” Amaranta raised the hand with the black bandage.
vi: He looked at Amaranta standing two steps behind Ucsula, smiled at her, and asked, "What happened to your hand?". Amaranta raised her bandaged hand.
tr: Then, he looked at Amaranta, who was standing hesitantly two steps behind Ursula, and smiled, "What happened to your hand?" he asked. Amaranta raised her hand wrapped in a black bandage.
es: He looked at Amaranta, who remained undecided two steps behind Úrsula, and smiled as he asked her: "What happened to your hand?". Amaranta raised her hand with the black bandage.

en: “A burn,” she said, and took Úrsula away so that the horses would not run her down.
vi: "Burned," she replied and pulled Ucsula back to avoid being trampled by the horse.
tr: "It got burned," she said. He pulled Ursula back so the horses wouldn't trample her.
es: "A burn," she said, and moved Úrsula aside so she wouldn't be trampled by the horses.

en: The troop took off.
vi: The soldiers fired their guns into the air.
tr: The soldiers walked past.
es: The troop fired.

en: A special guard surrounded the prisoners and took them to the jail at a trot.
vi: The special guard unit surrounded the two prisoners and rode off, dragging them back to the military camp.
tr: The prisoners were surrounded by special guards. These guards trotted their horses and took the prisoners to the prison.
es: A special guard surrounded the prisoners and trotted them to the barracks.

en: At dusk Úrsula visited Colonel Aureliano Buendía in jail.
vi: That afternoon, Úrsula went to the prison to visit Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: In the late afternoon, Ursula went to see Colonel Aureliano Buendia.
es: In the evening, Úrsula visited Colonel Aureliano Buendía in jail.

en: She had tried to get permission through Don Apolinar Moscote, but he had lost all authority in the face of the military omnipotence.
vi: She had intended to go through Don Apolinar Moscote to get permission to visit, but he had been stripped of all his power by the dictatorial soldiers.
tr: She had tried to obtain permission to visit through Don Apolinar Moscote. However, the soldiers' control over the situation had tied Moscote's hands.
es: She had tried to obtain permission through Don Apolinar Moscote, but he had lost all authority in the face of the omnipotence of the military.

en: Father Nicanor was in bed with hepatic fever.
vi: Father Nicanor was being laid low by a liver fever.
tr: Father Nicanor was writhing in pain because his liver was acting up.
es: Father Nicanor was bedridden with a hepatic fever.

en: The parents of Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, who had not been condemned to death, had tried to see him and were driven off with rifle butts.
vi: The parents of Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, who had not been sentenced to death, tried to visit their son but were beaten with rifle butts by the soldiers and driven away.
tr: The family of Colonel Gerinaldo Marquez, who had not been sentenced to death, also tried to see their son, but the soldiers drove them away with rifle butts.
es: The parents of Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, who was not condemned to death, had tried to see him and were turned away with rifle butts.

en: Facing the impossibility of finding anyone to intervene, convinced that her son would be shot at dawn, Úrsula wrapped up the things she wanted to bring him and went to the jail alone.
vi: In the face of the hopelessness of finding intermediaries to help her, and moreover convincing herself that her son would be shot at dawn the next day, Úrsula wrapped up a bundle of supplies to bring to him, and went straight to the barracks by herself.
tr: When Ursula couldn't find anyone to take charge of the situation, she became convinced that her son would be executed at dawn, so she packed what she wanted to bring him and went to the prison alone.
es: Faced with the impossibility of finding intermediaries, convinced that her son would be executed at dawn, Úrsula made a bundle with the things she wanted to take him and went alone to the barracks.

en: “I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendía,” she announced.
vi: - I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, - she introduced herself.
tr: She said to those at the door, "I am Colonel Aureliano Buendia's mother."
es: —I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendía —she announced.

en: The sentries blocked her way.
vi: The guards stopped her.
tr: The guards blocked her way.
es: The sentinels blocked her way.

en: “I’m going in in any case,” Úrsula warned them.
vi: "Whatever you want, I'm going in," Ursula told them.
tr: Ursula insisted, "No matter what, I will get inside."
es: “I’m going in anyway,” Úrsula warned them.

en: “So if you have orders to shoot, start right in.”
vi: "If you have orders to shoot, then go ahead and start all at once."
tr: She said, "If you have orders to shoot anyone who comes to the door, then fire without wasting any time," and pushed one of the guards aside, rushing into the room that used to be a classroom.
es: “So if you have orders to shoot, start right now.”

en: She pushed one of them aside and went into the former classroom, where a group of half-dressed soldiers were oiling their weapons.
vi: She pushed one of the soldiers aside and stepped into the old classroom where a group of shirtless soldiers were busily cleaning their guns.
tr: In the room, a group of half-naked soldiers were sitting and cleaning their weapons.
es: She pushed one aside and entered the old classroom, where a group of naked soldiers were greasing their weapons.

en: An officer in a field uniform, ruddy-faced, with very thick glasses and ceremonious manners, signaled to the sentries to withdraw.
vi: An officer in field uniform, with rosy skin and glasses as thick as bottle bottoms, moving leisurely, ordered the guards to withdraw.
tr: A red-cheeked officer with maneuver uniform, very thick glasses, and affected manners signaled the guards to step aside.
es: An officer in campaign uniform, rosy-cheeked, with very thick glasses and ceremonious gestures, signaled the sentinels to withdraw.

en: “I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendía,” Úrsula repeated.
vi: - I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, - Úrsula repeated.
tr: Ursula said again, "I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendia."
es: —I am the mother of Colonel Aureliano Buendía —Úrsula repeated.

en: “You must mean,” the officer corrected with a friendly smile, “that you are the mother of Mister Aureliano Buendía.”
vi: - You mean to say, - the officer, correcting her with a charming smile, - you are the mother who gave birth to Mr. Aureliano Buendía.
tr: The officer, with a friendly-looking smile, corrected her: "You mean to say that you are the mother of Señor Aureliano Buendia."
es: —You mean to say —corrected the officer with a kind smile— that she is the mother of Mr. Aureliano Buendía.

en: Úrsula recognized in his affected way of speaking the languid cadence of the stuck-up people from the highlands.
vi: In the gentle speech of the officer, Úrsula recognized the soft intonation of the highland people, the dandies.
tr: Ursula, "Whatever you say, whether it's señor or colonel, as long as I can see him," she conceded.
es: Úrsula recognized in his affected way of speaking the languid cadence of the people from the highlands, the cachacos.

en: “As you say, mister,” she accepted, “just as long as I can see him.”
vi: - Sir, just as you said. - She sincerely admits it. -
tr: Ursula, "Whatever you say, whether it's señor or colonel, as long as I can see him," she conceded.
es: —As you say, sir —he admitted—, as long as you allow me to see it.

en: There were superior orders that prohibited visits to prisoners condemned to death, but the officer assumed the responsibility of letting her have a fifteen-minute stay.
vi: Are you willing to let me visit it? There was an order from the higher-ups not to allow anyone to visit the prisoners sentenced to death. But this officer dared to take responsibility for letting her visit her son for fifteen minutes.
tr: There were higher authority orders prohibiting visitors for those sentenced to death, but the officer took responsibility and granted Ursula a fifteen-minute visit.
es: There were higher orders not to allow visits to those condemned to death, but the officer took responsibility for granting a fifteen-minute interview.

en: Úrsula showed him what she had in the bundle: a change of clean clothing, the short boots that her son had worn at his wedding, and the sweet milk candy that she had kept for him since the day she had sensed his return.
vi: Ursula showed the officer the items she had in her package: a clean set of clothes to change into, the boots her son wore on his wedding day, and milk candies she had set aside from the day she received the omen.
tr: Ursula showed the officer what she had brought: A set of clean clothes, the short boots her son wore at his wedding, and the clotted cream candy she had been saving since she sensed his arrival.
es: Úrsula showed him what she carried in the bundle: a change of clean clothes, the boots her son wore for the wedding, and the dulce de leche she had saved for him since the day she sensed his return.

en: She found Colonel Aureliano Buendía in the room that was used as a cell, lying on a cot with his arms spread out because his armpits were paved with sores.
vi: She met Colonel Aureliano Buendía in the cell, lying on a single bed, with his arms spread wide because his armpits were swollen.
tr: Ursula found Colonel Aureliano Buendia lying on a mattress spread out in the room used as a cell. Because his armpits were sore, he lay with his arms spread out to the sides.
es: She found Colonel Aureliano Buendía in the stocks room, lying on a cot with his arms open, because his armpits were studded with boils.

en: They had allowed him to shave.
vi: He had been allowed to shave.
tr: They had allowed him to shave.
es: They had allowed him to shave.

en: The thick mustache with twisted ends accentuated the sharp angles of his cheekbones.
vi: His thick, curled mustache accentuated his high cheekbones even more.
tr: His thick mustache, with drooping ends, made his prominent cheekbones even more noticeable.
es: The dense mustache with twisted ends accentuated the angularity of his cheekbones.

en: He looked paler to Úrsula than when he had left, a little taller, and more solitary than ever.
vi: It seemed to Ursula that her son looked paler than when he left, taller, and lonelier than ever.
tr: To Ursula, Aureliano seemed paler, thinner, and more withdrawn than ever.
es: To Úrsula, he seemed paler than when he left, a bit taller, and more solitary than ever.

en: He knew all about the details of the house: Pietro Crespi’s suicide, Arcadio’s arbitrary acts and execution.
vi: He knew all the details of what had happened at home: Pietro Crespi's suicide, Arcadio's arrogance and execution, José Arcadio Buendía growing weaker under the chestnut tree.
tr: He was aware of everything that had happened at home: Pietro Crespi's suicide, Arcadio's arbitrary behavior and execution, and Jose Arcadio Buendia's fearless life under the chestnut tree.
es: He was aware of the details of the house: Pietro Crespi's suicide, the arbitrariness and execution of Arcadio, José Arcadio Buendía's impassiveness under the chestnut tree.

en: the dauntlessness of José Arcadio Buendía underneath the chestnut tree.
vi: He knew all the details of what had happened at home: Pietro Crespi's suicide, Arcadio's arrogance and execution, José Arcadio Buendía growing weaker under the chestnut tree.
tr: He was aware of everything that had happened at home: Pietro Crespi's suicide, Arcadio's arbitrary behavior and execution, and Jose Arcadio Buendia's fearless life under the chestnut tree.
es: He was aware of the details of the house: Pietro Crespi's suicide, the arbitrariness and execution of Arcadio, José Arcadio Buendía's impassiveness under the chestnut tree.

en: He knew that Amaranta had consecrated her virginal widowhood to the rearing of Aureliano José and that the latter was beginning to show signs of quite good judgment and that he had learned to read and write at the same time he had learned to speak.
vi: He knew that Amaranta had decided to remain single for life to raise Aureliano José and that the child was very well-behaved, moreover intelligent, learning to read and write as soon as he learned to speak.
tr: He knew that Amaranta's virgin widowhood, her dedication to raising Aureliano Jose, Aureliano Jose learning to read and write while learning to speak, and that he was a smart child.
es: He knew that Amaranta had dedicated her virgin widowhood to raising Aureliano José, and that he was beginning to show very good judgment and could read and write at the same time he was learning to speak.

en: From the moment
vi: From the moment she stepped into the cell, Ursula felt overwhelmed by her son's maturity, his sense of command, and the aura of authority radiating from his skin.
tr: From the moment Ursula entered the room, she felt a sense of shyness in the face of her son's maturity, his commanding demeanor, and the aura of superiority that seemed to emanate from his very skin.
es: From the moment she entered the room, Úrsula felt intimidated by her son's maturity, by his aura of dominance, by the glow of authority that radiated from his skin.

en: In which she entered the room Úrsula felt inhibited by the maturity of her son, by his aura of command, by the glow of authority that radiated from his skin.
vi: From the moment she stepped into the cell, Ursula felt overwhelmed by her son's maturity, his sense of command, and the aura of authority radiating from his skin.
tr: From the moment Ursula entered the room, she felt a sense of shyness in the face of her son's maturity, his commanding demeanor, and the aura of superiority that seemed to emanate from his very skin.
es: From the moment she entered the room, Úrsula felt intimidated by her son's maturity, by his aura of dominance, by the glow of authority that radiated from his skin.

en: She was surprised that he was so well-informed.
vi: She was surprised to see him know everything.
tr: She was astonished at how he knew everything so well.
es: She was surprised that he was so well-informed.

en: “You knew all along that I was a wizard,” he joked.
vi: "You already know, mother, I'm very good at guessing," he joked.
tr: Aureliano teased his mother, "Haven't you always known that I'm a sorcerer?"
es: "You know I'm a fortune teller," he joked.

en: And he added in a serious tone, “This morning, when they brought me here, I had the impression that I had already been through all that before.”
vi: Then, with a serious demeanor, he added, "This morning, when they took me away, I had the feeling that all of this had already happened."
tr: Then, in a serious tone, he continued, "This morning, as they were bringing me here, I had the feeling that I had lived through all this before."
es: And he added seriously: "This morning, when they brought me, I had the impression that I had already gone through all this."

en: In fact, while the crowd was roaring alongside him, he had been concentrating his thoughts, startled at how the town had aged.
vi: Indeed, while the people were angrily shouting around him, he concentrated his thoughts and was surprised at the village's aged appearance over the past year.
tr: Indeed, amidst the noise of the crowd, Aureliano had concentrated his thoughts and memories, surprised at how the village had deteriorated.
es: In truth, while the crowd thundered as he passed, he was lost in his thoughts, amazed at how the town had aged in a year.

en: The leaves of the almond trees were broken.
vi: The almond trees spread out their tattered leaves.
tr: The branches of the almond trees were broken.
es: The almond trees had broken leaves.

en: The houses, painted blue, then painted red, had ended up with an indefinable coloration.
vi: The houses, once painted green, then red, and then green again, began to take on an indescribable color.
tr: The houses, first painted blue, then red, had finally turned mottled.
es: The houses painted blue, then painted red, and then painted blue again, had ended up acquiring an indefinable color.

en: “What did you expect?” Úrsula sighed.
vi: - What are you waiting for? - Ucsula sighed.
tr: Ursula sighed, "You didn't know how?"
es: —What did you expect? —sighed Úrsula—.

en: “Time passes.”
vi: - Time is passing by.
tr: Time passes in the blink of an eye.
es: Time passes.

en: “That’s how it goes,” Aureliano admitted, “but not so much.”
vi: - That's right, - Aureliano admitted, - but not much, mother.
tr: -It's true that it is so, he confirmed. But it can't be like this.
es: —That's right —admitted Aureliano—, but not so much.

en: In that way the long-awaited visit, for which both had prepared questions and had even anticipated answers, was once more the usual everyday conversation.
vi: In this form, the long-awaited visit, for which both had prepared questions and anticipated answers, once again became an everyday conversation.
tr: The long-awaited meeting, where both were prepared to ask questions and receive answers, thus turned into their usual daily conversations.
es: In this way, the long-awaited visit, for which both had prepared questions and even anticipated the answers, turned out to be the same everyday conversation as always.

en: When the guard announced the end of the visit, Aureliano took out a roll of sweaty papers from under the cot.
vi: When the guard announced that the permitted time for the conversation was over, Aureliano lifted the mat and took out a sweat-stained notebook.
tr: When the guard came and announced that the meeting was over, Aureliano took out a bundle of yellowed papers from under the cushion.
es: When the sentinel announced the end of the interview, Aureliano pulled a roll of sweaty papers from under the mat of the cot.

en: They were his poetry, the poems inspired by Remedios, which he had taken with him when he left, and those he had written later on during chance pauses in the war.
vi: It contained his poems. Some were poems he had written when he loved Remedios and had taken with him when he left, and some were poems he had written during moments of rest after battles, filled with confusion.
tr: These were the poems he had written. Poems born out of his love for Remedios. Aureliano had written some of these in the past and had taken them with him when he left. He had written some of them on the battlefield, between two skirmishes.
es: They were his verses. The ones inspired by Remedios, which he had taken with him when he left, and the ones written afterwards, in the hazardous pauses of the war.

en: “Promise me that no one will read them,” he said.
vi: "Promise me you won't let anyone read them," he said, "burn them in the oven tonight."
tr: -Promise me you won't show these to anyone, he said.
es: “Promise me that no one will read them,” he said.

en: “Light the oven with them this very night.”
vi: "Promise me you won't let anyone read them," he said, "burn them in the oven tonight."
tr: -By tonight, burn them all in the oven.
es: “Tonight, burn them in the oven.”

en: Úrsula promised and stood up to kiss him good-bye.
vi: Úrsula promised him, then she prepared to bid him farewell with a kiss.
tr: After Ursula promised her son, she stood on her tiptoes to kiss him one last time.
es: Úrsula promised and stood up to give him a farewell kiss.

en: “I brought you a revolver,” she murmured.
vi: - Mom brought you a revolver, - she whispered.
tr: "I brought you a gun," he murmured.
es: —I brought you a revolver —he murmured.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía saw that the sentry could not see.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía looked around and saw that the guard was not there.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, watching to see if the guard was looking at them, said, "It won't be of much use to me."
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía confirmed that the sentry was not in sight.

en: “It won’t do me any good,” he said in a low voice, “but give it to me in case they search you on the way out.”
vi: "It won't do you any good, mother," he whispered. "Alright, just leave it here, or else they'll search you when you leave."
tr: "But you should give it to me anyway, just in case they search you on the way out."
es: “It's no use to me,” he replied in a low voice. “But give it to me, just in case they search you on the way out.”

en: Úrsula took the revolver out of her bodice and put it under the mattress of the cot.
vi: Ursula took a pistol out from her chest pocket and he hid it under the mat.
tr: Ursula took the gun out from her bosom and quietly placed it under the cushion.
es: Úrsula took the revolver out of her bodice and he placed it under the cot's mat.

en: “And don’t say good-bye,” he concluded with emphatic calmness.
vi: "Now there's no need for farewells," he calmly said.
tr: Aureliano finished his words with absolute composure: -Don't you dare try to say goodbye to me.
es: “And now, don't say goodbye,” he concluded with calm emphasis.

en: “Don’t beg or bow down to anyone.
vi: "Mother, you don't need to beg anyone and you don't need to lower yourself before anyone.
tr: Neither bow to anyone, nor plead with anyone.
es: “Don't beg anyone or lower yourself before anyone.

en: Pretend that they shot me a long time ago.”
vi: Just consider that they have already shot me dead a long time ago."
tr: Act as if they had shot me a long time ago.
es: Consider that I was executed a long time ago.”

en: Úrsula bit her lip so as not to cry.
vi: Ursula bit her lip to keep from crying out.
tr: Ursula bit her lip to keep from crying.
es: Úrsula bit her lips to keep from crying.

en: “Put some hot stones on those sores,” she said.
vi: - Apply hot bricks to the swollen areas under your arms, - she said.
tr: Pointing to her armpits, she said, -Press hot stones on your wounds.
es: —Put hot stones on the boils —he said.

en: She turned halfway around and left the room.
vi: She turned halfway around and then left the cell.
tr: Then he turned and left the room.
es: He turned around and left the room.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía remained standing, thoughtful, until the door closed.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía stood still, looking pensive, until the door closed.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia stood until the door closed. He was pensive.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía remained standing, thoughtful, until the door closed.

en: Then he lay down again with his arms open.
vi: Then he lay down on the bed, spreading his arms wide:
tr: Then he lay down again, spreading his arms out to the sides.
es: Then he lay back down with his arms spread out.

en: Since the beginning of adolescence, when he had begun to be aware of his premonitions, he thought that death would be announced with a definite, unequivocal, irrevocable signal, but there were only a few hours left before he would die and the signal had not come.
vi: Ever since he entered adolescence, when he began to perceive his own omens, he had thought that death must be heralded by a definitive, unmistakable sign, one that could not be altered, but with only a few hours left before he was to die, no such sign had come to him.
tr: Since the time he began to realize the power of his intuition in his teenage years, he believed that his death would be preceded by an indisputable, absolute sign. Yet, although only a few hours remained until his death, there was no such sign.
es: Since the beginning of adolescence, when he began to be aware of his premonitions, he thought that death had to announce itself with a definite, unequivocal, irrevocable sign, but he was only a few hours away from dying, and the sign had not come.

en: On a certain occasion a very beautiful woman had come into his camp in Tucurinca and asked the sentries’ permission to see him.
vi: One day, a stunningly beautiful woman entered the Tucurinca barracks, asking the guards for permission to visit him.
tr: Once, a very beautiful woman came to his camp in Tucurinca and asked the guards at the door for permission to see him.
es: On one occasion, a very beautiful woman entered his camp in Tucurinca and asked the sentries to let her see him.

en: They let her through because they were aware of the fanaticism of mothers, who sent their daughters to the bedrooms of the most famous warriors, according to what they said, to improve the breed.
vi: They allowed her to enter because they were accustomed to the fanaticism of some mothers who often sent their daughters to the bedrooms of the most famous warriors, as these men claimed, to improve the breed.
tr: The guards, knowing that some mothers sent their daughters to the beds of famous warriors to improve and strengthen the lineage, let the woman in.
es: They let her pass because they knew the fanaticism of some mothers who sent their daughters to the bedrooms of the most notable warriors, as they themselves said, to improve the race.

en: That night Colonel Aureliano Buendía was finishing the poem about the man who is lost in the rain when the girl came into his room.
vi: That night, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had just finished writing a poem about a man lost in the rain when the girl entered the room.
tr: That night, when the girl entered his room, Colonel Aureliano Buendia was writing a poem about a man lost in the rain.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was that night finishing the poem of the man who had gotten lost in the rain when the girl entered the room.

en: He turned his back to her to put the sheet of paper into the locked drawer where he kept his poetry.
vi: He turned his back to her to place the paper in a locked drawer where he kept his poems.
tr: He turned his back to the girl to put away the papers in front of him into the drawer where he kept his poems.
es: He turned his back to her to put the sheet in the locked drawer where he kept his verses.

en: And then he sensed it.
vi: And then he felt the presence of death.
tr: And at that moment, he sensed it.
es: And then he felt it.

en: He grasped the pistol in the drawer without turning his head.
vi: He grabbed the gun from the drawer without turning around.
tr: Without turning his head, he took the gun from the drawer.
es: He grabbed the pistol in the drawer without turning his face.

en: “Please don’t shoot,” he said.
vi: - Please, don't shoot! - He said.
tr: "Please don't shoot," he said.
es: —Don't despair, please —he said.

en: When he turned around holding his Pistol, the girl had lowered hers and did not know what to do.
vi: When he turned back, with a gun in hand ready to fire, the girl had already lowered her gun, flustered and unsure of what to do.
tr: When he turned back after pointing his gun, the girl had lowered her own gun and was standing there, not knowing what to do.
es: When he turned with the gun cocked, the girl had lowered hers and didn't know what to do.

en: In that way he had avoided four out of eleven traps.
vi: In this way, he had escaped four out of eleven ambushes.
tr: Aureliano Buendia had thwarted four out of the eleven traps set for him in this manner.
es: That was how he had managed to evade four out of eleven ambushes.

en: On the other hand, someone who was never caught entered the revolutionary headquarters one night in Manaure and stabbed to death his close friend Colonel Magnífico Visbal, to whom he had given his cot so that he could sweat out a fever.
vi: On the contrary, there was one person who could never be caught, who infiltrated the revolutionary camp and stabbed Colonel Macgriffico Visban, his closest friend, to death while he was lying shivering on the bed waiting for the fever to break.
tr: However, someone unknown and uncaptured had entered the revolutionary headquarters in Manaure one night and had stabbed and killed his close friend Colonel Magnifico Visbal. That night, Aureliano had given his bed to Magnifico, claiming he was ill.
