vi: In sleepless nights lying on the hammock hung in the very room that used to be a death row cell, he recalled the images of lawyers dressed in black with collars turned up to cover their ears and sleeves hanging down to cover their hands, stepping out of the President's mansion in the freezing cold of the night towards dawn, shivering, quickly slipping into the mournful coffee gardens at dawn to ponder over what the President meant when he said yes, or perhaps what he meant when he said no, and to search for what the President was thinking when he said something entirely different. Meanwhile, he swatted mosquitoes, endured the sweltering heat of thirty-five degrees, and felt increasingly closer to the dreadful morning when he would have to order his soldiers to plunge into the sea.
tr: Once upon a time, he would lie down in the hammock in the room where he awaited death, thinking without blinking until dawn; he would imagine the lawyers dressed in black leaving the presidential palace in the morning chill, lifting their collars to their ears and rubbing their hands as they made their way to the all-night cafes; he would construct in his mind their debates about what the president meant when he said yes, what he meant when he said no, and even what he might be thinking when he said something else. Meanwhile, he was struggling with the overwhelming heat and mosquitoes, and he sensed that the dreadful dawn hour when he would have to give the command to his men to jump into the sea was approaching.
es: On sleepless nights, lying on his back in the hammock that hung in the same room where he had been condemned to death, he evoked the image of the lawyers dressed in black who left the presidential palace in the icy early morning with their coat collars turned up to their ears, rubbing their hands, whispering, taking refuge in the gloomy cafes of dawn, to speculate on what the president meant when he said yes, or what he meant when he said no, and even to suppose what the president was thinking when he said something entirely different, while he swatted mosquitoes at thirty-five degrees of temperature, feeling the dreadful dawn approaching when he would have to give his men the order to throw themselves into the sea.

en: One night of uncertainty, when Pilar Ternera was singing in the courtyard with the soldiers, he asked her to read the future in her cards.
vi: One restless night, Pila Tecnêra sang with the soldiers in the courtyard. He asked her to predict his future through the cards.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, on a night when he was once again mired in doubts and anxieties, summoned Pilar Ternera, who was singing in the garden with the soldiers, to read his fortune.
es: One night of uncertainty when Pilar Ternera was singing in the courtyard with the troop, he asked her to read his future in the cards.

en: “Watch out for your mouth,” was all that Pilar Ternera brought out after spreading and picking up the cards three times.
vi: "Keep your mouth shut," that was all Pila Tecnêra clearly saw after arranging the cards and gathering them back.
tr: Pilar Ternera, after spreading and gathering the cards three times, simply said, "Watch your mouth."
es: "Take care of your mouth," was all that Pilar Ternera could make out after spreading and gathering the cards three times.

en: “I don’t know what it means, but the sign is very clear.
vi: "I don't know what that means, but the omen is very clear: keep your mouth shut"…
tr: "I don't know what it means, but it's clear."
es: "I don't know what it means, but the sign is very clear: take care of your mouth."

en: Watch out for your mouth.”
vi: "I don't know what that means, but the omen is very clear: keep your mouth shut"…
tr: "Watch your mouth."
es: "I don't know what it means, but the sign is very clear: take care of your mouth."

en: Two days later someone gave an orderly a mug of black coffee and the orderly passed it on to someone else and that one to someone else until, hand to hand, it reached Colonel Aureliano Buendía office.
vi: Two days later, someone replaced him and ordered an orderly to prepare a cup of coffee without sugar, then this orderly passed the order to another person, who then passed it to another until the cup of coffee without sugar, having gone through many hands, was brought to Colonel Aureliano Buendía's residence.
tr: Two days later, someone gave a cup of coffee to one of the sentry soldiers, who passed the cup to another, and that one to another, and so on. The cup made its way from hand to hand until it reached Colonel Aureliano Buendia's room.
es: Two days later, someone gave an orderly a bowl of coffee without sugar, and the orderly passed it to another, and this one to another, until it went from hand to hand to Colonel Aureliano Buendía's office.

en: He had not asked for any coffee, but since it was there the colonel drank it.
vi: Although he hadn't called for coffee, since it was already there, the colonel drank it.
tr: The Colonel hadn't asked for coffee, but since it was there, he drank it.
es: He hadn't asked for coffee, but since it was there, the colonel drank it.

en: It had a dose of nux vomica strong enough to kill a horse.
vi: That cup of coffee contained enough strychnine to kill a stallion.
tr: Inside the coffee was a dose of poisonous black nightshade seeds strong enough to kill a large stallion.
es: It had enough nux vomica to kill a horse.

en: When they took him home he was stiff and arched and his tongue was sticking out between his teeth.
vi: When they brought him home, he was stiff, convulsed, with his tongue sticking out between his teeth.
tr: When they carried him home, Aureliano was stiff as a board, his tongue hanging out between his teeth.
es: When they took him home, he was stiff and arched, and his tongue was split between his teeth.

en: Úrsula fought against death over him.
vi: Úrsula fought with death to save him.
tr: Ursula waged a battle against death on his body.
es: Úrsula wrestled him from death.

en: After cleaning out his stomach with emetics, she wrapped him in hot blankets and fed him egg whites for two days until his harrowed body recovered its normal temperature.
vi: After making him vomit to cleanse his stomach, she covered him with heated bed sheets and gave him egg whites to drink for two days until his weak body regained its normal temperature.
tr: She made him drink purgative medicines and washed his stomach. Then she wrapped him in thick blankets and fed him egg whites for two days until Aureliano's fever returned to normal.
es: After cleaning his stomach with emetics, she wrapped him in warm blankets and gave him egg whites for two days, until his ravaged body regained its normal temperature.

en: On the fourth day he was out of danger.
vi: On the fourth day, he was out of danger.
tr: On the fourth day, Aureliano tore off the shroud.
es: On the fourth day, he was out of danger.

en: Against his will, pressured by Úrsula and his officers, he stayed in bed for another week.
vi: Contrary to his wishes, due to Úrsula and his officers' insistence, he stayed in bed for another week.
tr: With the insistence of Ursula and her officers, he stayed in bed for another week.
es: Against his will, pressured by Úrsula and the officers, he stayed in bed for another week.

en: Only then did he learn that his verses had not been burned.
vi: Only then did he learn that his poems had not been burned.
tr: During that time, he learned that his poems had not been burned.
es: Only then did he learn that his verses had not been burned.

en: “I didn’t want to be hasty,” Úrsula explained to him.
vi: "That night, mother didn't want to rush," Úrsula explained to him.
tr: Ursula explained, "I said, let me not rush."
es: "I didn't want to rush," Úrsula explained to him.

en: “That night when I went to light the oven I said to myself that it would be better to wait until they brought the body.”
vi: "That night, when I went to light the stove, I thought it best to wait until your corpse was brought home."
tr: "When I went to light the oven that night, I said, let them bring the body first, for now, let it be."
es: "That night, when I was about to light the oven, I told myself it was better to wait until they brought the corpse."

en: In the haze of convalescence, surrounded by Remedios’ dusty dolls, Colonel Aureliano Buendía, brought back the decisive periods of his existence by reading his poetry.
vi: Living among Remedios' dolls surrounding him, in the condition of gradually recovering health, Colonel Aureliano Buendía, through his poems, reminisced about the most vibrant periods of his life.
tr: In the lethargy of the recovery days spent among Remedios's dusty dolls, Colonel Aureliano Buendia recalled the days that had shaped the course of his life by reading his poems.
es: In the haze of convalescence, surrounded by Remedios's dusty dolls, Colonel Aureliano Buendía evoked in the reading of his verses the decisive moments of his existence.

en: He started writing again.
vi: He began writing poetry again.
tr: He started writing poetry again.
es: He began to write again.

en: For many hours, balancing on the edge of the surprises of a war with no future, in rhymed verse he resolved his experience on the shores of death.
vi: For many hours, on the sidelines of the prominent events of a war with no future, he affirmed his experiences right at the brink of death.
tr: He would sit for hours, writing poems, trying not to stumble in the face of the unexpected developments of a war with no future.
es: For many hours, apart from the shocks of a war without a future, he resolved his experiences on the brink of death into rhymed verses.

en: Then his thoughts became so clear that he was able to examine them forward and backward.
vi: Thus, his mind became increasingly clearer to the point where he could turn it inside out to examine it.
tr: In this way, he went back and forth to the other world. Eventually, his thoughts became so clear that he could see the front and back of everything.
es: Then his thoughts became so clear that he could examine them inside out.

en: One night he asked Colonel Gerineldo Márquez:
vi: One night, he asked Colonel Gerineldo Márquez:
tr: One night to Colonel Gerineldo Marquez,
es: One night he asked Colonel Gerineldo Márquez:

en: “Tell me something, old friend: why are you fighting?”
vi: - Tell me, why do you fight, my friend?
tr: -I will ask you something, friend, he said. -Why are you fighting?
es: —Tell me something, buddy: why are you fighting?

en: “What other reason could there be?” Colonel Gerineldo Márquez answered.
vi: - Why are you asking me that, - Colonel Hêrinênđô Mackêt replied.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez,
es: —Why should it be, compadre —answered Colonel Gerineldo Márquez—: for the great Liberal Party.

en: “For the great liberal party.”
vi: - Because of the great Liberal party.
tr: "Why, of course?" he replied, "for the great Liberal Party, naturally."
es: —Why should it be, compadre —answered Colonel Gerineldo Márquez—: for the great Liberal Party.

en: “You’re lucky because you know why,” he answered.
vi: - I'm really happy because I know my goal in fighting, - he replied.
tr: -You're lucky because you know why you're fighting.
es: —Lucky you who knows it —he replied—.

en: “As far as I’m concerned, I’ve come to realize only just now that I’m fighting because of pride.”
vi: - As for myself, until now I have only known that I fight for pride.
tr: As for me, it just dawned on me: I'm fighting to not tarnish bravery.
es: As for me, I am just now realizing that I am fighting out of pride.

en: “That’s bad,” Colonel Gerineldo Márquez said.
vi: - That's terrible, - Colonel Hêrinênđô Mackêt replied.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez said, "This is a bad business."
es: —That is bad —said Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was amused at his alarm.
vi: The warning from Hernando Márquez delighted Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia had liked his attitude.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was amused by his alarm.

en: “Naturally,” he said.
vi: "Of course," he said.
tr: "True," he said.
es: "Naturally," he said.

en: “But in any case, it’s better than not knowing why you’re fighting.”
vi: "But in any case, it's better not to know why you're fighting."
tr: "But still, it's better than not knowing why you're fighting."
es: "But in any case, it's better than not knowing why one fights."

en: He looked him in the eyes and added with a smile:
vi: He looked into his friend's eyes, smiled, and clarified:
tr: He looked into his friend's eyes and completed his sentence with a smile: "Or like you, fighting for something that means nothing to anyone."
es: He looked him in the eyes and added, smiling:

en: “Or fighting, like you, for something that doesn’t have any meaning for anyone.”
vi: - Or as if you had fought for something that meant nothing to anyone.
tr: He looked into his friend's eyes and completed his sentence with a smile: "Or like you, fighting for something that means nothing to anyone."
es: —What is it to fight like you for something that means nothing to anyone.

en: His pride had prevented him from making contact with the armed groups in the interior of the country until the leaders of the party publicly rectified their declaration that he was a bandit.
vi: It was precisely that pride that prevented him from contacting the armed groups in the interior, while the leaders of the Liberal Party did not publicly make statements to dispel the notion that he was a bandit leader.
tr: Until the party leaders openly declared him an outlaw, Aureliano could not bring himself to associate with armed gangs in the interior of the country.
es: His pride had prevented him from making contact with the armed groups in the interior of the country, as long as the party leaders did not publicly retract their statement that he was a bandit.

en: He knew, however, that as soon as he put those scruples aside he would break the vicious circle of the war.
vi: However, he knew that if he could overcome those obstacles, he would immediately break the dangerous siege of war.
tr: But as soon as he shed this reluctance, he knew he would break the vicious cycle of war.
es: He knew, however, that as soon as he set aside those scruples, he would break the vicious circle of war.

en: Convalescence gave him time to reflect.
vi: His recovered health allowed him to think.
tr: His illness gave him the opportunity to think.
es: Convalescence allowed him to reflect.

en: Then he succeeded in getting Úrsula to give him the rest of her buried inheritance and her substantial savings.
vi: So he asked Ursula not only for the remaining gold but also for the considerable capital she had accumulated.
tr: Then he deceived Ursula and took the gold she had buried and the money she had saved.
es: Then he managed to get Úrsula to give him the rest of the buried inheritance and her substantial savings; he appointed Colonel Gerineldo Márquez as the civil and military chief of Macondo, and went to establish contact with the rebel groups in the interior.

en: He named Colonel Gerineldo Márquez civil and military leader of Macondo and he went off to make contact with the rebel groups in the interior.
vi: He appointed Colonel Gerineldo Márquez as the Governor in charge of military and civil matters in Macondo, and then he set out to establish relations with the insurgent groups in the interior.
tr: He appointed Colonel Gerineldo Marquez as the civil and military leader of Macondo and went to establish connections with the gangs in the interior.
es: Then he managed to get Úrsula to give him the rest of the buried inheritance and her substantial savings; he appointed Colonel Gerineldo Márquez as the civil and military chief of Macondo, and went to establish contact with the rebel groups in the interior.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was not only the man closest to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, but Úrsula received him as a member of the family.
vi: Colonel Herinendo Marquez was not only Colonel Aureliano Buendía's closest confidant but also someone Ursula considered part of the family.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez was not only a close friend of Colonel Aureliano Buendia; Ursula treated him like a member of the family.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was not only Colonel Aureliano Buendía's most trusted man, but Úrsula also received him as a member of the family.

en: Fragile, timid, with natural good manners, he was, however, better suited for war than for government.
vi: Though he was elegant, shy, and well-mannered, he was more suited for battle than for leadership.
tr: Despite his frail build, innate elegance, and delicacy, he was still more inclined towards war than government affairs.
es: Fragile, timid, with a natural good education, he was nevertheless better suited for war than for governance.

en: His political advisers easily entangled him in theoretical labyrinths, But he succeeded in giving Macondo the atmosphere of rural peace that Colonel Aureliano, Buendía dreamed of so that he could die of old age making little gold fishes.
vi: His political advisors easily led him into theoretical mazes. However, he managed to establish a peaceful, rustic atmosphere in Macondo, which was what Colonel Aureliano Buendía dreamed of for his old age, living by making goldfish.
tr: His political advisors would lead him into theoretical dead ends and confuse him. Nevertheless, it was Marquez who ensured the peace and tranquility in Macondo that Colonel Aureliano Buendia dreamed of for his twilight years, which he would spend making silver fish.
es: His political advisors easily entangled him in theoretical labyrinths. But he managed to impose in Macondo the rural peace environment that Colonel Aureliano Buendía dreamed of to die old making little gold fishes.

en: Although he lived in his parents’ house he would have lunch at Úrsula’s two or three times a week.
vi: Although he lived with his parents, he had lunch at Ursula's house two or three times a week.
tr: Although Marquez lived with his own parents, he would come to Ursula's for meals several times a week.
es: Although he lived in his parents' house, he had lunch at Úrsula's two or three times a week.

en: He initiated Aureliano José in the use of firearms, gave him early military instruction, and for several months took him to live in the barracks, with Úrsula’s consent, so that he could become a man.
vi: He taught Aureliano José how to use weapons, imparted basic military knowledge, and with Ursula's consent, took him to live in the barracks to train him.
tr: He taught Aureliano José how to handle a weapon and gave him his first military lessons. So that he could grow up and mature properly, with Úrsula's consent, he had the boy stay at the barracks for a few months.
es: He initiated Aureliano José in the handling of firearms, gave him premature military instruction, and for several months took him to live in the barracks, with Úrsula's consent, so that he would become a man.

en: Many years before, when he was still almost a child, Gerineldo Márquez had declared his love for Amaranta.
vi: Many years ago, when he was still a child, Herinendo Marquez once expressed his feelings to Amaranta.
tr: Years ago, when he was still a child, Gerineldo Márquez had told Amaranta that he loved her.
es: Many years before, almost a child, Gerineldo Márquez had declared his love to Amaranta.

en: At that time she was so illusioned with her lonely passion for Pietro Crespi that she laughed at him.
vi: At that time, Amaranta was secretly in love with Pietro Crespi, so she mocked him.
tr: At that time, Amaranta was so infatuated with Pietro Crespi that she just laughed it off.
es: She was then so infatuated with her solitary passion for Pietro Crespi that she laughed at him.

en: Gerineldo Márquez waited.
vi: Herinendo Marquez waited patiently.
tr: Gerineldo Márquez did not give up; he waited.
es: Gerineldo Márquez waited.

en: On a certain occasion he sent Amaranta a note from jail asking her to embroider a dozen batiste handkerchiefs with his father’s initials on them.
vi: Once, from prison, he sent Amaranta a letter asking her to embroider the initials of his father's name on a dozen handkerchiefs.
tr: Once, he wrote a letter to Amaranta from prison, asking for a dozen linen handkerchiefs with his father's initials embroidered on them.
es: On one occasion, he sent Amaranta a note from jail, asking her the favor of embroidering a dozen batiste handkerchiefs with his father's initials.

en: He sent her the money.
vi: He also sent her money.
tr: He also sent the money.
es: He sent her the money.

en: A week later Amaranta, brought the dozen handkerchiefs to him in jail along with the money and they spent several hours talking about the past.
vi: Within a week, Amaranta brought him a dozen embroidered handkerchiefs along with the money, and she stayed for several hours to talk about the past.
tr: A week later, Amaranta brought the handkerchiefs along with the money to the prison. They sat for a few hours reminiscing about old times.
es: A week later, Amaranta brought him the dozen embroidered handkerchiefs to the jail, along with the money, and they spent several hours talking about the past.

en: “When I get out of here I’m going to marry you,” Gerineldo Márquez told her when she left.
vi: "When I get out of here, I will marry you," Herinendo Marquez said as he bid her farewell.
tr: As Amaranta was about to leave, Gerineldo Márquez said, "When I get out of here, I will marry you."
es: “When I get out of here, I will marry you,” Gerineldo Márquez said to her as he bid farewell.

en: Amaranta laughed but she kept on thinking about him while she taught the children to read and she tried to revive her juvenile passion for Pietro Crespi.
vi: Amaranta laughed but still thought of him while "teaching the children to read and trying to revive in her heart the passionate love of her youth, which had been her obsession with Pietro Crespi, to dedicate it to him.
tr: Amaranta laughed it off, but while teaching the children to read and write, she found herself thinking about Márquez and trying to rekindle the love she had felt for Pietro Crespi in her youth.
es: Amaranta laughed, but she continued thinking about him while teaching the children to read, and wished to revive for him her youthful passion for Pietro Crespi.

en: On Saturday, visiting days for the prisoners, she would stop by the house of Gerineldo Márquez’s parents and accompany them to the jail.
vi: On Saturdays, visiting days, she would go to Herinendo Marquez's parents' house and then accompany them to the prison.
tr: On Saturdays, the visiting day at the prison, they would stop by Gerineldo Marquez's house and go to see him with his parents.
es: On Saturdays, the day for visiting prisoners, she would stop by Gerineldo Márquez’s parents' house and accompany them to the jail.

en: On one of those Saturdays Úrsula was surprised to see her in the kitchen, waiting for the biscuits to come out of the oven so that she could pick the best ones and cap them in a napkin that she had embroidered for the occasion.
vi: One Saturday, Ursula was surprised to find her in the kitchen waiting for the biscuits to come out of the oven so she could choose the best ones to put in a pre-embroidered bag for the occasion.
tr: One of those Saturdays, Ursula was surprised to find him waiting by the oven for the fresh buns to come out. Amaranta was going to wrap the freshly baked bun in a napkin she had embroidered just for that purpose and take it to the prison.
es: One of those Saturdays, Úrsula was surprised to see her in the kitchen, waiting for the biscuits to come out of the oven so she could choose the best ones and wrap them in a napkin she had embroidered for the occasion.

en: “Marry him,” she told her.
vi: - Take him, my dear! - she said to her.
tr: Ursula said, "Marry him."
es: —Marry him —he said to her—.

en: “You’ll have a hard time finding another man like him.”
vi: - It's very rare to find a man like him.
tr: "You won't find another like him."
es: You'll hardly find another man like him.

en: Amaranta feigned a reaction of displeasure.
vi: Amaranta pretended to be annoyed:
tr: Amaranta, indicating that she did not welcome this remark, replied, -I am not going to chase after men.
es: Amaranta pretended a reaction of disgust.

en: “I don’t have to go around hunting for men,” she answered.
vi: - I don't need to entice anyone - she argued with her mother.
tr: Amaranta, indicating that she did not welcome this remark, replied, -I am not going to chase after men.
es: —I don't need to go around hunting men —she replied—.

en: “I’m taking these biscuits to Gerineldo because I’m sorry that sooner or later they’re going to shoot him.”
vi: - I brought these cookies to Herinendo simply because I care about him and sooner or later, he will be shot dead.
tr: -If I am taking these pastries to Gerineldo, it is only because I pity him for eventually being executed by firing squad.
es: I'm taking these biscuits to Gerineldo because I feel sorry for him; sooner or later they're going to shoot him.

en: She said it without thinking, but that was the time that the government had announced its threat to shoot Colonel Gerineldo Márquez if the rebel forces did not surrender Riohacha.
vi: Without any hesitation, she blurted it out. But at that time, the government openly threatened to shoot Colonel Gerineldo Márquez if the insurgent forces did not surrender Riohacha.
tr: Amaranta had spoken those words without thinking. Yet, at that very time, the government had threatened that Colonel Gerineldo Marquez would be executed if the rebels did not surrender Riohacha.
es: He said it without thinking, but it was around that time that the government made public the threat to execute Colonel Gerineldo Márquez if the rebel forces did not surrender Riohacha.

en: The visits stopped.
vi: Visits to the prisoner were suspended.
tr: Visits to the prison were cut off.
es: The visits were suspended.

en: Amaranta shut herself up to weep, overwhelmed by a feeling of guilt similar to the one that had tormented her when Remedios died, as if once more her careless words had been responsible for a death.
vi: Amaranta shut herself in, crying and tormenting herself with the thought that she was guilty, just as she had been tormented when Remedios died, and just as another time, her careless words had been responsible for another death, the death of Pietro Crespi.
tr: Amaranta locked herself in her room. She cried day and night. She once again felt the guilt she had experienced when Remedios died, believing once more that her words had led to death.
es: Amaranta locked herself up to cry, overwhelmed by a feeling of guilt similar to the one that tormented her when Remedios died, as if once again her thoughtless words were responsible for a death.

en: Her mother consoled her.
vi: Úrsula comforted her.
tr: Her mother tried to comfort and calm her.
es: Her mother consoled her.

en: She inured her that Colonel Aureliano Buendía would do something to prevent the execution and promised that she would take charge of attracting Gerineldo Márquez herself when the war was over.
vi: She assured her that Colonel Aureliano Buendía would take strong practical action to prevent the execution, and she promised that she herself would welcome Gerineldo Márquez home when the war ended.
tr: She said that Colonel Aureliano Buendia would absolutely do something to prevent the execution, and promised that she herself would try to win over Gerineldo Marquez once the war was over.
es: She assured her that Colonel Aureliano Buendía would do something to prevent the execution, and promised that she herself would take care of attracting Gerineldo Márquez, once the war was over.

en: She fulfilled her promise before the imagined time.
vi: She fulfilled her promise ahead of schedule.
tr: She fulfilled her promise sooner than she had planned.
es: She fulfilled the promise before the expected time.

en: When Gerineldo Márquez returned to the house, invested with his new dignity of civil and military leader, she received him as a son, thought of delightful bits of flattery to hold him there, and prayed with all her soul that he would remember his plan to marry Amaranta.
vi: When Gerineldo Márquez arrived at the house with the responsibility of overseeing military and civil matters as the Provincial Governor, she welcomed him like a son, pampered him to stay, and from the bottom of her heart, she implored him to remember his intention to marry Amaranta.
tr: When Gerineldo Marquez arrived, having added honor to his honor as both a civil and military leader, Ursula embraced him like a son, did a lot of things to make him feel at home, and prayed with all her might for Marquez to remind Amaranta of his marriage proposal.
es: When Gerineldo Márquez returned to the house invested with his new dignity as civil and military chief, she received him like a son, conceived exquisite flattery to retain him, and prayed with all her heart that he would remember his intention to marry Amaranta.

en: Her pleas seemed to be answered.
vi: Her pleas seemed to be effective.
tr: Her prayers seemed to have been answered.
es: Her pleas seemed certain.

en: On the days that he would have lunch at the house, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez would linger on the begonia porch playing Chinese checkers with Amaranta.
vi: On the days he came to the house for lunch, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez stayed the entire afternoon to play checkers with Amaranta on the veranda adorned with begonia pots.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez, on the days he came to eat, did not leave immediately; he would sit with Amaranta on the terrace with begonias and play Chinese checkers.
es: The days when he went to have lunch at the house, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez would stay the afternoon in the begonia corridor playing Chinese checkers with Amaranta.

en: Úrsula would bring them coffee and milk and biscuits and would take over the children so that they would not bother them.
vi: Úrsula brought the young couple coffee with milk and biscuits, and kept an eye on the children to prevent them from disturbing the two.
tr: Ursula would bring them coffee, milk, and buns, and take the children away so they wouldn't disturb them.
es: Úrsula would bring them coffee with milk and biscuits and take care of the children so they wouldn't be disturbed.

en: Amaranta was really making an effort to kindle in her heart the forgotten ashes of her youthful passion.
vi: In reality, Amaranta tried to rekindle the passionate love of her youth, which now felt like a forgotten heap of cold ashes in her heart.
tr: Amaranta was genuinely making an effort to rekindle the embers of her youthful love in her heart.
es: Amaranta, in reality, made an effort to rekindle in her heart the forgotten ashes of her youthful passion.

en: With an anxiety that came to be intolerable, she waited for the lunch days, the afternoons of Chinese checkers, and time flew by in the company of the warrior with a nostalgic name whose fingers trembled imperceptibly as he moved the pieces.
vi: With a longing that had reached an unchangeable intensity, she awaited the days he would come to her house for lunch, the afternoons of playing checkers, and the passing of time while she sat beside a warrior whose name evoked so many memories, and whose fingers trembled as he moved the pieces.
tr: With unbearable excitement, she eagerly awaited the days Gerineldo would come for dinner and the hours they would play Chinese checkers. As she moved the checkers pieces, her hands constantly trembled, and hours flew by next to the warrior whose name reminded her of the homeland of his ancestors.
es: With an anxiety that became intolerable, she awaited the lunch days, the afternoons of Chinese checkers, and time flew by in the company of that warrior with a nostalgic name whose fingers trembled imperceptibly when moving the pieces.

en: But the day on which Colonel Gerineldo Márquez repeated his wish to marry her, she rejected him.
vi: But on the day Colonel Gerineldo Márquez reiterated his heartfelt desire to marry Amaranta, she refused:
tr: Nevertheless, on the day Colonel Gerineldo Marquez repeated his marriage proposal, Amaranta turned him down.
es: But the day Colonel Gerineldo Márquez reiterated his intention to marry her, she rejected him.

en: “I’m not going to marry anyone,” she told him, “much less you.
vi: - I won't marry anyone, - she said, - and I won't marry you either.
tr: "I will not marry anyone," she said. "Especially not you."
es: —I will not marry anyone —she told him—, but least of all you.

en: You love Aureliano so much that you want to marry me because you can’t marry him.”
vi: You love Aureliano so much that you will marry me because you can't marry him.
tr: "You are in love with Aureliano, and since you cannot marry him, you are trying to marry me."
es: You love Aureliano so much that you are going to marry me because you cannot marry him.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was a patient man.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was a calm person.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez was a patient man.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was a patient man.

en: “I’ll keep on insisting,” he said.
vi: "You will wait patiently," he said.
tr: "I will continue to resist."
es: “I will insist again,” he said.

en: “Sooner or later I’ll convince you.”
vi: "Sooner or later, you will marry me."
tr: "Sooner or later, I will bring you to your senses," he said.
es: “Sooner or later I will convince you.”

en: He kept on visiting the house.
vi: He continued to visit the house.
tr: He was still coming and going to the house.
es: He continued visiting the house.

en: Shut up in her bedroom biting back her secret tears, Amaranta put her fingers in her ears so as not to bear the voice of the suitor as he gave Úrsula the latest war news, and in spite of the fact that she was dying to see him she had the strength not to go out and meet him.
vi: Locking herself in the bedroom to cry in secret, Amaranta covered her ears with her fingertips to avoid hearing the suitor telling Úrsula the latest war news, and although she longed to see him to the point of death, she had enough strength not to go out and meet him.
tr: Amaranta would lock herself in her room, biting her lips to keep from crying, pressing her fingers to her ears to avoid hearing the voice of the man who wanted her, giving war news to Ursula. And although she longed to see him, she could never find the strength to face him.
es: Locked in the bedroom, biting back secret tears, Amaranta put her fingers in her ears to avoid hearing the voice of the suitor who was telling Úrsula the latest news of the war, and despite dying to see him, she found the strength not to go out to meet him.

en: At that time Colonel Aureliano Buendía took the time to send a detailed account to Macondo every two weeks.
vi: At that time, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had arranged to send a detailed report about Macondo every two weeks.
tr: At that time, Colonel Aureliano Buendia was sending a detailed report to Macondo every fifteen days.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía then had time to send a detailed report to Macondo every two weeks.

en: But only once, almost eight months after he had left, did he write to Úrsula.
vi: But only once, after nearly eight months away, did he write a private letter to Úrsula.
tr: But he wrote to Ursula only once, and that was almost eight months after his departure.
es: But only once, almost eight months after he had left, did he write to Úrsula.

en: A special messenger brought a sealed envelope to the house with a sheet of paper inside bearing the colonel’s delicate hand:
vi: A special messenger brought to the house a letter written in the colonel's beautiful handwriting: "Take good care of father because he is going to die."
tr: A special messenger brought the sealed envelope to the house.
es: A special emissary brought a sealed envelope to the house, inside of which was a paper written in the colonel's meticulous handwriting:

en: Take good care of Papa because he is going to die.
vi: A special messenger brought to the house a letter written in the colonel's beautiful handwriting: "Take good care of father because he is going to die."
tr: In the paper inside the envelope, the colonel, with his pearl-like handwriting, said, -Take good care of my father, because he is going to die.
es: Take good care of father because he is going to die.

en: Úrsula became alarmed.
vi: Úrsula was startled.
tr: Ursula became alarmed.
es: Úrsula was alarmed.

en: “If Aureliano says so it’s because Aureliano knows,” she said.
vi: "If Aureliano says so, then Aureliano knows," Úrsula said, and asked someone to carry José Arcadio Buendía into the bedroom.
tr: -If Aureliano says so, then it is so, she said.
es: "If Aureliano says so, Aureliano knows," she said.

en: And she had them help her take José Arcadio Buendía to his bedroom.
vi: "If Aureliano says so, then Aureliano knows," Úrsula said, and asked someone to carry José Arcadio Buendía into the bedroom.
tr: And Jose Arcadio Buendia, as if being heavy wasn't enough, had learned to make himself even heavier whenever he wanted during the long time he spent under the chestnut tree.
es: And she asked for help to take José Arcadio Buendía to his bedroom.

en: Not only was he as heavy as ever, but during his prolonged stay under the chestnut tree he had developed the faculty of being able to increase his weight at will, to such a degree that seven men were unable to lift him and they had to drag him to the bed.
vi: He was not only as heavy as he had been before but had grown even heavier during the time he lay under the chestnut tree, to the point that seven strong men could not lift him, forcing them to drag him into the house.
tr: Seven people barely managed to lift him, and they had to drag him to his bed.
es: Not only was he as heavy as ever, but during his prolonged stay under the chestnut tree, he had developed the ability to increase his weight voluntarily, to the point that seven men could not lift him and had to drag him to the bed.

en: A smell of tender mushrooms, of wood-flower fungus, of old and concentrated outdoors impregnated the air of the bedroom as it was breathed by the colossal old man weather-beaten by the sun and the rain.
vi: The smell of fresh moss mixed with the scent of wood ear mushrooms, the odor of long-standing and dense humidity, filled the room when the robust old man, who had weathered rain and sun for a long time, began to breathe.
tr: The large, elderly man, sunburned and soaked by rains, filled the bedroom air with the scent of soft fungus, tree moss, and condensed open air as he breathed.
es: A stench of tender mushrooms, wood flower, and ancient, concentrated exposure to the elements filled the air of the bedroom when the colossal old man, macerated by the sun and rain, began to breathe it.

en: The next morning he was not in his bed.
vi: The next day, he did not wake up in the bed placed in the room. After searching all the rooms, Úrsula once again found him lying under the chestnut tree. So they tied him to the bed.
tr: The next morning, the old man was not in his bed.
es: The next day he was not in bed at dawn. After searching all the rooms, Úrsula found him again under the chestnut tree. Then they tied him to the bed.

en: In spite of his undiminished strength, José Arcadio Buendía was in no condition to resist.
vi: Though strong, José Arcadio Buendía had been rendered out of action...
tr: Despite his inexhaustible strength, Jose Arcadio Buendia was in no condition to resist.
es: Despite his intact strength, José Arcadio Buendía was not in a condition to fight.

en: It was all the same to him.
vi: He accepted everything, no longer distinguishing anything.
tr: It was all the same to him.
es: Everything was the same to him.

en: If he went back to the chestnut tree it was not because he wanted to but because of a habit of his body.
vi: If he returned to lie under the chestnut tree, it was not out of desire but out of habit.
tr: If he had gone back under the chestnut tree, it wasn't because he wanted to, but because his body had the habit of doing so.
es: If he returned to the chestnut tree, it was not by his will but by a habit of the body.

en: Úrsula took care of him, fed him, brought him news of Aureliano.
vi: Úrsula took care of him, fed him, and told him news about Aureliano.
tr: Ursula looked after him, fed him, and brought news from Aureliano.
es: Úrsula took care of him, fed him, and brought him news of Aureliano.

en: But actually, the only person with whom he was able to have contact for a long time was Prudencio Aguilar.
vi: But in reality, the only person he had been in contact with for a long time was Prudencio Aguilar.
tr: However, the only person Jose Arcadio Buendia could communicate with for a long time was Prudencio Aguilar.
es: But in reality, the only person he could have contact with for a long time was Prudencio Aguilar.

en: Almost pulverized at that time by the decrepitude of death, Prudencio Aguilar would come twice a day to chat with him.
vi: With a haggard appearance due to old age in the underworld, Prudencio Aguilar would come to the house twice a day to talk with him.
tr: Prudencio Aguilar, who had aged considerably in the realm of the dead, would come twice a day, walking shakily, to chat with him.
es: Almost pulverized by the profound decrepitude of death, Prudencio Aguilar went twice a day to talk with him.

en: They talked about fighting cocks.
vi: The two of them talked about fighting cocks.
tr: They would talk about cockfights.
es: They talked about roosters.

en: They promised each other to set up a breeding farm for magnificent birds, not so much to enjoy their victories, which they would not need then, as to have something to do on the tedious Sundays of death.
vi: They promised each other to build a coop for magnificent fighting cocks, not just for the joy of winning some matches but also to pass the time on the melancholic Sunday afternoons in the underworld.
tr: They would make plans to establish a large farm and raise purebred roosters. They had no intention of fighting them; the glory of cockfighting victories was long behind them. Their main goal was to create a pastime to while away the endless markets of death.
es: They promised to establish a breeding farm of magnificent animals, not so much to enjoy victories that they would no longer need, but to have something to distract themselves with on the tedious Sundays of death.

en: It was Prudencio Aguilar who cleaned him fed him and brought him splendid news of an unknown person called Aureliano who was a colonel in the war.
vi: Prudencio Aguilar was the one who bathed him, fed him, and told him about the glorious victories of a completely unknown man called Aureliano, who was a colonel in battle.
tr: It was always Prudencio Aguilar who brought good news about an unknown person named Aureliano, who had cleaned and fed Jose Arcadio Buendia and had been promoted to colonel in the war.
es: It was Prudencio Aguilar who cleaned him, fed him, and brought him splendid news of an unknown man named Aureliano who was a colonel in the war.

en: When he was alone, José Arcadio Buendía consoled himself with the dream of the infinite rooms.
vi: When alone, José Arcadio Buendía found some solace in dreams within the infinite room.
tr: Jose Arcadio Buendia would amuse himself with the fantasy of endless rooms when he was alone.
es: When he was alone, José Arcadio Buendía consoled himself with the dream of infinite rooms.

en: He dreamed that he was getting out of bed, opening the door and going into an identical room with the same bed with a wrought-iron head, the same wicker chair, and the same small picture of the Virgin of Help on the back wall.
vi: He dreamed of getting up from bed, opening the main door, and walking into the next room, which had a bed with a steel headboard, a wicker rocking chair, and a portrait of the Virgin of Remedies hanging on the far wall.
tr: He would imagine getting out of bed, opening the door, and entering a second room with the same wrought-iron bed, the same rocking chair, and the same image of the Holy Virgin on the wall.
es: He dreamed that he got out of bed, opened the door, and passed into another identical room, with the same wrought-iron headboard bed, the same wicker chair, and the same little picture of the Virgin of Remedies on the back wall.

en: From that room he would go into another that was just the same, the door of which would open into another that was just the same, the door of which would open into another one just the same, and then into another exactly alike, and so on to infinity.
vi: From this room, he would go into another identical room, whose door opened into yet another identical room, and so on endlessly.
tr: He would open the door of that room and enter another identical one, and from there another identical one, and so on.
es: From that room, he passed into another exactly the same, whose door he opened to pass into another exactly the same, and then another exactly the same, to infinity.

en: He liked to go from room to room.
vi: From this room, he would go into another identical room, whose door opened into yet another identical room, and so on endlessly.
tr: Once Jose Arcadio Buendia entered these interconnected rooms that resembled the mirrored hall at the fair, he would wander around until Prudencio Aguilar came and touched his shoulder.
es: He liked to go from room to room, as in a gallery of parallel mirrors, until Prudencio Aguilar touched his shoulder.

en: As in a gallery of parallel mirrors, until Prudencio Aguilar would touch him on the shoulder.
vi: He enjoyed walking from room to room, as if walking in a corridor with mirrored walls on both sides, until Prudencio Aguilar patted him on the shoulder.
tr: Once Jose Arcadio Buendia entered these interconnected rooms that resembled the mirrored hall at the fair, he would wander around until Prudencio Aguilar came and touched his shoulder.
es: He liked to go from room to room, as in a gallery of parallel mirrors, until Prudencio Aguilar touched his shoulder.

en: Then he would go back from room to room, walking in reverse, going back over his trail, and he would find Prudencio Aguilar in the room of reality.
vi: Then he would return, passing through the rooms one by one, gradually waking up as he retraced his steps, only to meet Prudencio Aguilar again in the backdrop of reality.
tr: Then he would return the way he came, passing from room to room, from room to room, until he came to the real room to find Prudencio Aguilar.
es: Then he would return from room to room, waking backward, retracing his steps, and finding Prudencio Aguilar in the room of reality.

en: But one night, two weeks after they took him to his bed, Prudencio Aguilar touched his shoulder in an intermediate room and he stayed there forever, thinking that it was the real room.
vi: But then one night, two weeks after Úrsula had brought him into the house, Prudencio Aguilar patted him on the shoulder right in the intermediate room between reality and dreams, and he stayed there forever, thinking it was the room of reality.
tr: But one night, two weeks after they had moved him to the bed, Jose Arcadio Buendia, while in one of the intermediate rooms, felt Prudencio Aguilar touch his shoulder, and Buendia, thinking he was in the real room, stayed there forever.
es: But one night, two weeks after they took him to bed, Prudencio Aguilar touched his shoulder in an intermediate room, and he stayed there forever, believing it was the real room.

en: On the following morning Úrsula was bringing him his breakfast when she saw a man coming along the hall.
vi: The very next morning, when bringing him breakfast, Úrsula encountered a man walking towards her from the hallway.
tr: The next morning, as Ursula was bringing his breakfast, she encountered a man in the corridor.
es: The next morning, Úrsula was bringing him breakfast when she saw a man approaching down the corridor.

en: He was short and stocky, with a black suit on and a hat that was also black, enormous, pulled down to his taciturn eyes.
vi: The man was short and stout, dressed in black clothes, wearing a wide-brimmed black hat that almost covered his sad eyes.
tr: He was a short, stocky man. He was dressed in black, with a large black hat pulled down over his eyes.
es: He was small and stocky, with a black wool suit and an enormous black hat, sunk down to his taciturn eyes.

en: “Good Lord,” Úrsula thought, “I could have sworn it was Melquíades.”
vi: "Oh my God," Úrsula thought. "He looks like Melquiades...
tr: Ursula thought to herself, -My God, I could swear this is almost Melquiades.
es: " My God," thought Úrsula. "I would have sworn it was Melquíades. "

tr: On one occasion, he approached within twenty kilometers of Macondo and had to retreat to the mountains after encountering government reconnaissance patrols. He was very close to the place where his father had found the remains of the Spanish galleon years before.
es: On one occasion, he was less than twenty kilometers from Macondo, and was forced by government patrols to retreat into the mountains very close to the enchanted region where his father had found the fossil of a Spanish galleon many years before.

en: Visitación died around that time.
vi: During this time, Visitacion also passed away.
tr: Visitacion died around that time.
es: During that time, Visitación died.

en: She had the pleasure of dying a natural death after having renounced a throne out of fear of insomnia, and her last wish was that they should dig up the wages she had saved for more than twenty years under her bed and send the money to Colonel Aureliano Buendía so that he could go on with the war.
vi: After giving up the throne due to fear of the insomnia epidemic, she wished to die of old age, and her final wish was for people to dig up the savings she had accumulated over several decades buried under her bed and send it to Colonel Aureliano Buendía so he could continue fighting.
tr: She had given up being a princess in her own tribe out of fear of the insomnia plague, and had attained the happiness of dying a natural death. She bequeathed that the monthly savings she had accumulated for over twenty years under her bed be unearthed and sent to Colonel Aureliano Buendia so he could continue the war.
es: She had the pleasure of dying a natural death, after having renounced a throne for fear of insomnia, and her last wish was for the salary she had saved for more than twenty years to be dug up from under her bed and sent to Colonel Aureliano Buendía so he could continue the war.

en: But Úrsula did not bother to dig it up because it was rumored in those days that Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been killed in a landing near the provincial capital.
vi: But Úrsula did not allow the money to be dug up, because at that time there were rumors that Colonel Aureliano Buendía had died in a landing operation on the outskirts of the provincial capital.
tr: However, since news arrived that Colonel Aureliano Buendia had been killed while stationed near the provincial capital, Ursula did not bother to unearth the money.
es: But Úrsula did not bother to retrieve that money, because at that time there were rumors that Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been killed in a landing near the provincial capital.

en: The official announcement—the fourth in less than two years—was considered true for almost six months because nothing further was heard of him.
vi: The official announcement, the fourth in less than two years, indicated that this was evident because for nearly six months, there had been no news about him.
tr: The government communiqué announcing the colonel's death - the fourth such announcement in the last two years - was taken as fact for up to six months, as there was no news from the colonel.
es: The official announcement—the fourth in less than two years—was believed to be true for almost six months, as nothing more was heard of him.

en: Suddenly, when Úrsula and Amaranta had added new mourning to the past period, unexpected news arrived.
vi: Suddenly, while Úrsula and Amaranta were mourning their ancestors anew, a strange piece of news arrived.
tr: Just as Ursula and Amaranta were about to add a new mourning to the past ones, unexpected news arrived.
es: Suddenly, when Úrsula and Amaranta had already added a new mourning to the previous ones, an unusual piece of news arrived.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was alive, but apparently he had stopped harassing the government of his country and had joined with the victorious federalism of other republics of the Caribbean.
vi: Colonel Aureliano was still alive, but it was clear he was not siding with his own government, as he had joined the federal forces that were prevailing in several other Caribbean countries.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia was alive. However, he had given up dealing with his own country's government and had joined those working for the federation of other republics in the Caribbean.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was alive, but apparently he had given up harassing the government of his country and had joined the triumphant federalism in other Caribbean republics.

en: He would show up under different names farther and farther away from his own country.
vi: He went to lands with different names, increasingly unfamiliar compared to the name of his homeland.
tr: Each time, he appeared under different names and each time in a place a little farther from his country.
es: He appeared under different names, each time farther from his homeland.

en: Later it would be learned that the idea that was working on him at the time was the unification of the federalist forms of Central America in order to wipe out conservative regimes from Alaska to Patagonia.
vi: It was later learned that the idea inspiring him at that moment was the idea of uniting the federal forces of Central America to sweep away the royalist regimes from Alaska to Patagonia.
tr: It was later learned that his idea at the time was to unite the federalist forces in Central America and to sweep away all conservative regimes from Alaska to Patagonia.
es: It was later learned that the idea that then motivated him was the unification of the federalist forces of Central America, to sweep away the conservative regimes from Alaska to Patagonia.

en: The first direct news that Úrsula received from him, several years after his departure, was a wrinkled and faded letter that had arrived, passing through various hands, from Santiago, Cuba.
vi: After a few years he left, the first letter that Úrsula received from him was a crumpled and smudged letter passed hand-to-hand from the city of Santiago de Cuba.
tr: The first direct news Ursula received from him was a letter sent from the city of Santiago in Cuba a few years after his departure, which reached his mother after passing from hand to hand, yellowing and crumpling along the way.
es: The first direct news Úrsula received from him, several years after he had left, was a crumpled and blurry letter that reached her hand to hand from Santiago de Cuba.

en: “We’ve lost him forever,” Úrsula exclaimed on reading it.
vi: - We have lost it forever, - Ursula exclaimed when reading the letter because Christmas on the day of the apocalypse will appear on that road.
tr: When Ursula read the letter, she exclaimed, "We have completely lost him."
es: —We have lost him forever —exclaimed Úrsula upon reading it—.

en: “If he follows this path he’ll spend Christmas at the ends of the earth.”
vi: - We have lost it forever, - Ursula exclaimed when reading the letter because Christmas on the day of the apocalypse will appear on that road.
tr: "At this rate, he will spend Christmas on the other side of the world."
es: Christmas will pass that way at the end of the world.

en: The person to whom she said it, who was the first to whom she showed the letter, was the Conservative general José Raquel Moncada, mayor of Macondo since the end of the war.

tr: The person to whom Ursula said these words and first showed the letter was Conservative General Jose Raquel Moncada, who had been the mayor of Macondo since the end of the war.
es: The person to whom he said it, who was the first to whom he showed the letter, was the conservative general José Raquel Moncada, mayor of Macondo since the war ended."This Aureliano," commented General Moncada, "it's a pity he's not a conservative.

en: “This Aureliano,” General Moncada commented, “what a pity that he’s not a Conservative.”
vi: "It's a pity," General Moncada commented, "that this Aureliano is not a Royalist. "
tr: General Moncada expressed his opinion, "It's a pity that this Aureliano is not a Conservative."

en: He really admired him.
vi: He genuinely admired him.
tr: He truly admired her.
es: He truly admired him.

en: Like many Conservative civilians, José Raquel Moncada had waged war in defense of his party and had earned the title of general on the field of battle, even though he was not a military man by profession.
vi: Like many Royalist civil officials, José Raquén Moncada had fought to defend his party and had risen to the rank of general in combat, despite not having strategic talent.
tr: Like most conservative civilians, Jose Raquel Moncada had joined the war to defend his party and, despite not being a professional officer, he had earned the title of general due to his usefulness on the battlefield.
es: Like many conservative civilians, José Raquel Moncada had fought the war in defense of his party and had achieved the title of general on the battlefield, although he lacked a military vocation.

en: On the contrary, like so many of his fellow party members, he was an antimilitarist.
vi: On the contrary, like many in his party, he was opposed to the militaristic regime.
tr: However, like most of his colleagues in the party, he was against the war.
es: On the contrary, also like many of his fellow party members, he was anti-militarist.

en: He considered military men unprincipled loafers, ambitious plotters, experts in facing down civilians in order to prosper during times of disorder.
vi: He viewed the military class as a group of undisciplined, lazy, adventurous, and greedy individuals with experience in opposing civil officials to enrich themselves in chaotic situations.
tr: He viewed soldiers as idle individuals with no principles, greedy schemers, and experts at intimidating civilians to live in luxury during times of chaos.
es: He considered military people to be lazy, unprincipled, intriguing, and ambitious, experts in pitting civilians against each other to thrive in disorder.

en: Intelligent, pleasant, ruddy-faced, a man who liked to eat and watch cockfights, he had been at one time the most feared adversary of Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: Intelligent, courteous, with a rosy complexion, a lover of good food and cockfighting, he had once been the most formidable enemy of Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: Moncada, cultured, intelligent, pleasant, rosy-cheeked, and fond of food and cockfights, was once considered Colonel Aureliano Buendia's most feared rival.
es: Intelligent, likable, sanguine, a man of good appetite and a fan of cockfights, he had at one point been the most formidable adversary of Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: He succeeded in imposing his authority over the career officers in a wide sector along the coast.
vi: He had established his command over professional military personnel throughout this vast coastal region.
tr: He had managed to establish his own authority over professional officers in the vast region along the coast.
es: He managed to impose his authority over career military officers in a large sector of the coast.

en: One time when he was forced by strategic circumstances to abandon a stronghold to the forces of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, he left two letters for him.
vi: Once, due to strategic agreements, he had to withdraw his troops from a town to hand it over to Colonel Aureliano Buendía's forces, leaving two letters for him.
tr: On one occasion, when he was forced to withdraw from a region they held due to strategic circumstances, he left two letters for Colonel Aureliano Buendia.
es: Once, when he was forced by strategic conveniences to abandon a position to the forces of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, he left him two letters.

en: In one of them quite long, he invited him to join in a campaign to make war more humane.
vi: In a long letter to the colonel, he invited him to join a joint campaign to make the war less brutal.
tr: In one of the rather long letters, he was calling on the colonel to join the campaign to conduct the war under more humane conditions.
es: In one of them, very extensive, he invited him to a joint campaign to humanize the war.

en: The other letter was for his wife, who lived in Liberal territory, and he left it with a plea to see that it reached its destination.
vi: The other letter he asked the colonel to deliver to his wife, who lived in an area controlled by the Liberal forces.
tr: He had written the second letter to his wife, who was in the region dominated by the Liberals, and placed it next to the colonel's letter with the hope that it would be delivered.
es: The other letter was for his wife, who lived in liberal territory, and he left it with the plea to ensure it reached its destination.

en: From then on, even in the bloodiest periods of the war, the two commanders would arrange truces to exchange prisoners.
vi: Since then, even during the fiercest battles, the two commanders had agreed to ceasefires to exchange prisoners.
tr: From that day on, even during the bloodiest periods of the war, the two commanders would occasionally cease fire and exchange war prisoners.
es: Since then, even during the most intense periods of the war, the two commanders arranged truces to exchange prisoners.

en: They were pauses with a certain festive atmosphere, which General Moncada took advantage of to teach Colonel Aureliano Buendía how to play chess.
vi: These were truce moments so cheerful that General Moncada took advantage of the time to teach Colonel Aureliano Buendía how to play checkers.
tr: These ceasefire periods became breathers that brought a certain festive atmosphere, and General Moncada took advantage of these opportunities to teach Colonel Aureliano Buendia how to play chess.
es: They were pauses with a certain festive atmosphere that General Moncada used to teach Colonel Aureliano Buendía how to play chess.

en: They became great friends.
vi: There were times when both men considered the possibility of combining the popular elements within both parties to eliminate the influence of professional military and political figures and establish a humane regime by fully exploiting the advantages of each doctrine.
tr: They became good friends.
es: They became great friends.

en: They even came to think about the possibility of coordinating the popular elements of both parties, doing away with the influence of the military men and professional politicians, and setting up a humanitarian regime that would take the best from each doctrine.
vi: There were times when both men considered the possibility of combining the popular elements within both parties to eliminate the influence of professional military and political figures and establish a humane regime by fully exploiting the advantages of each doctrine.
tr: Gradually, they even planned to unite the beloved and respected elements of both parties, to free the soldiers from the influence of professional politicians, and to establish a humane order that encompassed the best aspects of each doctrine.
es: They even came to consider the possibility of coordinating the popular elements of both parties to eliminate the influence of the military and professional politicians, and to establish a humanitarian regime that would take the best from each doctrine.

en: When the war was over, while Colonel Aureliano, Buendía was sneaking about through the narrow trails of permanent sub.
vi: When the war ended, while Colonel Aureliano Buendía frequently faced defeat and had to flee through ravines, General Moncada was appointed Inspector General in the village of Macondo.
tr: After the war, while Colonel Aureliano Buendia was trying to navigate the harsh paths of successive defeats, General Moncada was appointed as a justice of the peace.
es: When the war ended, while Colonel Aureliano Buendía was slipping through the ravines of permanent subversion, General Moncada was appointed corregidor of Macondo.

en: version, General Moncada was named magistrate of Macondo.
vi: When the war ended, while Colonel Aureliano Buendía frequently faced defeat and had to flee through ravines, General Moncada was appointed Inspector General in the village of Macondo.
tr: After the war, while Colonel Aureliano Buendia was trying to navigate the harsh paths of successive defeats, General Moncada was appointed as a justice of the peace.
es: When the war ended, while Colonel Aureliano Buendía was slipping through the ravines of permanent subversion, General Moncada was appointed corregidor of Macondo.

en: He wore civilian clothes, replaced the soldiers with unarmed policemen, enforced the amnesty laws, and helped a few families of Liberals who had been killed in the war.
vi: He dressed in civilian clothes, used unarmed police instead of the militia, enforced respect for all amnesty regulations, and assisted families of fallen Liberals.
tr: He took off his uniform and put on civilian clothes, replaced the soldiers with unarmed police officers, implemented amnesty laws, and helped the families of a few Liberals who died in the war.
es: He donned his civilian suit, replaced the military with unarmed police agents, enforced the amnesty laws, and assisted some families of liberals who had died in the campaign.

en: He succeeded in having Macondo raised to the status of a municipality and he was therefore its first mayor, and he created an atmosphere of confidence that made people think of the war as an absurd nightmare of the past.
vi: He did everything he could to have Macondo chosen as a county town, and thus he was appointed mayor and cultivated an atmosphere of mutual trust among the populace, making them think of the war as a meaningless hardship of the past.
tr: He ensured that Macondo became a district and thus became its first mayor. And he brought security, peace, and order to the people to such an extent that they thought the war was a meaningless nightmare of the past.
es: He managed to have Macondo established as a municipality and thus became its first mayor, creating an atmosphere of trust that made people think of the war as an absurd nightmare of the past.

en: Father Nicanor, consumed by hepatic fever, was replaced by Father Coronel, whom they called “The Pup,” a veteran of the first federalist war.
vi: Father Nicanor, emaciated by liver fever, was replaced by Father Coronel, nicknamed El Cachorro, a veteran of the Federalist wars.
tr: Father Coronel, who had participated in the first federalist war and was nicknamed Bear Fish, replaced Father Nicanor, who died of liver disease.
es: Father Nicanor, consumed by hepatic fevers, was replaced by Father Coronel, known as El Cachorro, a veteran of the first federalist war.

en: Bruno Crespi, who was married to Amparo Mos. cote, and whose shop of toys and musical instruments continued to prosper, built a theater which Spanish companies included in their Itineraries.
vi: Bruno Crespi had married Amparo Moscote. Thanks to his ever-prospering toy and musical instrument store, he built a theater that Spanish touring companies included in their itineraries.
tr: Bruno Crespi, who married Amparo Moscote and developed his music instruments and toy shop day by day, had a theater built. Spanish theater companies on tour began to give performances there.
es: Bruno Crespi, married to Amparo Moscote, whose toy and musical instrument store continued to prosper, built a theater, which Spanish companies included in their itineraries.

en: It was a vast open-air hall with wooden benches, a velvet curtain with Greek masks, and three box offices in the shape of lions’ heads, through whose mouths the tickets were sold.
vi: It was an open-air salon with long wooden benches, a felt backdrop adorned with Greek masks, and three ticket booths shaped like lion heads through whose open mouths tickets were sold to customers.
tr: The open-air theater consisted of wooden benches, a stage with velvet curtains adorned with Greek masks, and three ticket booths shaped like lion heads. Tickets were obtained from the lion's mouth.
es: It was a vast open-air hall, with wooden benches, a velvet curtain with Greek masks, and three ticket booths shaped like lion heads through whose open mouths tickets were sold.

en: It was also about that time that the school was rebuilt.
vi: During this period, the school was also built.
tr: At around this time, the school was also rebuilt.
es: It was also around this time that the school building was restored.

en: It was put under the charge of Don Melchor Escalona, an old teacher brought from the swamp, who made his lazy students walk on their knees in the lime-coated courtyard and made the students who talked in class eat hot chili with the approval of their parents.
vi: Don Mencho Escalona, an old teacher, was sent from the swamps to oversee the school. With the consent of the parents, he made the unruly boys kneel and walk on the gravelly yard and forced the talkative children to eat hot peppers.
tr: Don Melchor Escalona, who was brought in from the swampy region, was put in charge of the school. Escalona made lazy students walk on their knees in the lime-plastered courtyard and filled the mouths of those who talked during class with hot pepper. The children's parents did not object to these actions.
es: It was taken over by Don Melchor Escalona, an old teacher sent from the swamp, who made undisciplined students walk on their knees in the caliche yard and made the talkative ones eat hot chili peppers, with the parents' approval.

en: Aureliano Segundo and José Arcadio Segundo, the willful twins of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, were the first to sit in the classroom, with their slates, their chalk, and their aluminum jugs with their names on them.
vi: Aureliano Segundo and José Arcadio Segundo, the twin sons of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, were the first students to sit in the classroom with a blackboard, chalk, and aluminum cups engraved with their names.
tr: The mischievous twins of Santa Sofia de la Piedad, Aureliano Segundo and Jose Arcadio Segundo, were the first students to arrive in class with their slate boards, chalks, and aluminum canteens with their names written on them.
es: Aureliano Segundo and José Arcadio Segundo, the determined twins of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, were the first to sit in the classroom with their slates, chalks, and aluminum mugs marked with their names.

en: Remedios, who inherited her mother’s pure beauty, began to be known as Remedios the Beauty.
vi: Remedios inherited her mother's true beauty and began to be known by the name Remedios the Beauty.
tr: Remedios, who had inherited her mother's unique beauty, became known as Beautiful Remedios.
es: Remedios, inheritor of her mother's pure beauty, was beginning to be known as Remedios the Beautiful.

en: In spite of time, of the superimposed Periods of mourning, and her accumulated afflictions, Úrsula resisted growing old.
vi: Despite her old age, despite having endured many bereavements and numerous hardships, Úrsula remained as vigorous as ever.
tr: Despite time, successive periods of mourning, and a heap of sorrows, Ursula resisted aging.
es: Despite the time, the overlapping mourning periods, and accumulated afflictions, Úrsula resisted aging.

en: Aided by Santa Sofía de la Piedad, she gave a new drive to her pastry business and in a few years not only recovered the fortune that her son had spent in the war, but she once more stuffed with pure gold the gourds buried in the bedroom.
vi: With the help of Santa Sofía de la Piedad, she resumed her candy business and in a short time, not only recovered the wealth her son had squandered during the war, but also filled dried gourds with pure gold and buried them in her bedroom.
tr: With the help of Santa Sofia de la Piedad, Ursula accelerated her pastry-making again, and within a few years, not only did she rebuild the fortune her son had squandered in the war, but she also refilled the jars buried in the bedroom with glittering gold.
es: Helped by Santa Sofía de la Piedad, she had given a new impetus to her pastry business, and not only recovered in a few years the fortune her son had spent in the war, but also refilled the pure gold gourds buried in the bedroom.

en: “As long as God gives me life,” she would say, “there will always be money in this madhouse.”
vi: "As long as God lets me live," - the old man often said, - "there will never be a shortage of money in this house of lunatics."
tr: "As long as God gives me life, there will be no shortage of money in this madhouse," she said.
es: " As long as God gives me life," she used to say, "there will be no lack of money in this house of madness. "

en: That was how things were when Aureliano José deserted the federal troops in Nicaragua, signed on as a crewman on a German ship, and appeared in the kitchen of the house, sturdy as a horse, as dark and long-haired as an Indian, and with a secret determination to marry Amaranta.
vi: Everything was going smoothly like that, when suddenly Auréliano José deserted the ranks of the federal army of Nicaragua, escaped onto a German ship, and then appeared right in his own kitchen. He returned healthy as a horse, tanned and with thick hair like an Indian, with the secret intention of marrying Amaranta.
tr: It was during this time that Aureliano Jose, having fled the federal troops in Nicaragua and signed on as a crew member of a German ship, appeared in the kitchen of the house. Aureliano Jose was as strong as a horse, as dark-skinned as a native, and had long hair, and he had secretly decided to marry Amaranta.
es: That was how things were when Aureliano José deserted from the federalist troops of Nicaragua, enlisted in the crew of a German ship, and appeared in the kitchen of the house, solid as a horse, dark and hairy like an Indian, with the secret determination to marry Amaranta.

en: When Amaranta, saw him come in, even though he said nothing she knew immediately why he had come back.
vi: When Amaranta saw him walk in, even though he hadn't said anything, she immediately knew why he had returned.
tr: When Amaranta saw him come in, she understood why he had come, even though he hadn't said anything yet.
es: When Amaranta saw him enter, without him having said anything, she immediately knew why he had returned.

en: At the table they did not dare look each other in the face.
vi: They sat at the same table but didn't dare look each other in the face.
tr: They couldn't look each other in the face at the table.
es: At the table, they did not dare to look each other in the face.

en: But two weeks after his return, in the presence of Úrsula, he set his eyes on hers and said to her, “I always thought a lot about you.”
vi: But after two weeks of being back, even with Ursula present, he still looked her straight in the eyes and said, "I always think of you, my dear.
tr: However, two weeks after his arrival, Aureliano Jose, in front of Ursula, staring into Amaranta's eyes, suddenly said, "I've always thought of you."
es: But two weeks after his return, with Úrsula present, he fixed his eyes on hers and said, "I always thought a lot about you.

en: Amaranta avoided him.
vi: "Amaranta fled from him.
tr: Amaranta kept her distance from him, avoided unexpected encounters, and tried to keep Beautiful Remedios by her side.
es: "Amaranta avoided him.

en: She guarded against chance meetings.
vi: She guessed and maneuvered to avoid encountering him in unexpected places and times.
tr: Amaranta kept her distance from him, avoided unexpected encounters, and tried to keep Beautiful Remedios by her side.
es: She guarded against casual encounters.

en: She tried not to become separated from Remedios the Beauty.
vi: She clung to Remedios the Beauty, not leaving her side for a moment.
tr: Amaranta kept her distance from him, avoided unexpected encounters, and tried to keep Beautiful Remedios by her side.
es: She tried not to separate from Remedios, the beautiful.

en: She was ashamed of the blush that covered her cheeks on the day her nephew asked her how long she intended wearing the black bandage on her hand, for she interpreted it as an allusion to her virginity.
vi: She blushed with shame the day her nephew asked how long she would keep wearing the black ribbon on her arm, because she understood the question as a hint about her chastity.
tr: When her nephew asked her how long she intended to keep the black bandage on her hand, she blushed with shame. Because she saw this bandage as a symbol of her virginity.
es: She was outraged by the blush that gilded her cheeks the day her nephew asked her how long she planned to wear the black bandage on her hand, because she interpreted the question as an allusion to her virginity.

en: When he arrived, she barred the door of her bedroom, but she heard his peaceful snoring in the next room for so many nights that she forgot about the precaution.
vi: When he returned home, she immediately locked her bedroom door. But for many nights, hearing his gentle, steady snoring from the next room, she felt so reassured that she let her guard down.
tr: After Aureliano Jose arrived, Amaranta began to bolt the door of her bedroom. However, hearing the comfortable snores coming from the adjacent room every night, she eventually forgot to bolt the door.
es: When he arrived, she bolted her bedroom door, but after so many nights of hearing his peaceful snores in the next room, she neglected that precaution.

en: Early one morning, almost two months after his return, she heard him come into the bedroom.
vi: Nearly two months after Aureliano José returned, one night towards dawn, she felt him enter her room.
tr: About two months after Aureliano Jose's arrival, one morning Amaranta heard him enter the room.
es: One early morning, almost two months after his return, she felt him enter the bedroom.

en: Then, instead of fleeing, instead of shouting as she had thought she would, she let herself be saturated with a soft feeling of relaxation.
vi: Instead of fleeing or screaming as she had planned, she surrendered herself to a light feeling of rest and satisfaction.
tr: Then, instead of screaming or running away as she had previously thought she would, she sank into a soft comfort.
es: Then, instead of fleeing, instead of screaming as she had planned, she let herself be saturated by a soft sensation of rest.

en: She felt him slip in under the mosquito netting as he had done when he was a child, as he had always done, and she could not repress her cold sweat and the chattering of her teeth when she realized that he was completely naked.
vi: She felt him crawling into the bed, just as he had since he was a child, as he always had, and she couldn't stop the cold sweat and chattering teeth when she realized he was completely naked.
