tr: He heard Aureliano José slip under the mosquito net as he always did when he was a child, and when he realized the young man was completely naked, he couldn't stop himself from breaking out in a cold sweat and his teeth chattering.
es: She felt him slip under the mosquito net, as he had done when he was a child, as he had always done, and she couldn't suppress the cold sweat and the chattering of her teeth when she realized he was completely naked.

en: “Go away,” she whispered, suffocating with curiosity.
vi: "Get out!" she whispered, feeling like she was suffocating from curiosity.
tr: Breathless with curiosity, he whispered, -Go away, or I'll scream.
es: "Go away," she murmured, choking with curiosity.

en: “Go away or I’ll scream.”
vi: "Get out or I'll scream.
tr: Breathless with curiosity, he whispered, -Go away, or I'll scream.
es: "Go away or I'll start screaming.

en: But Aureliano José knew then what he had to do, because he was no longer a child but a barracks animal.
vi: "But Aureliano José knew exactly what he needed to do, because he was no longer a boy afraid of the dark but a seasoned soldier.
tr: However, Aureliano José knew exactly what he had to do. Because he was no longer a child; he had become a barracks stallion.
es: "But Aureliano José then knew what he had to do, because he was no longer a child afraid of the dark but a camp animal.

en: Starting with that night the dull, inconsequential battles began again and would go on until dawn.
vi: From that night on, they continued their silent struggles until dawn.
tr: That night, the silent and noisy struggles began again and lasted until dawn.
es: From that night on, the silent battles without consequences resumed and lasted until dawn.

en: “I’m your aunt,” Amaranta murmured, spent.
vi: "I am your aunt," Amaranta whispered wearily.
tr: Amaranta, losing herself, said, -I am your aunt.
es: "I am your aunt," Amaranta murmured, exhausted. "

en: “It’s almost as if I were your mother, not just because of my age but because the only thing I didn’t do for you was nurse you.”
vi: "I am almost like your mother, not just because of my age but because I raised you and taught you everything, except breastfeeding you.
tr: -I am practically your mother, not just because I am older, but because the only thing I didn't do was breastfeed you; beyond that, I mothered you, she said.
es: It's almost as if I were your mother, not only because of the age difference, but because the only thing I didn't do was nurse you.

en: Aureliano would escape at dawn and come back early in the morning on the next day, each time more excited by the proof that she had not barred the door.
vi: "At dawn, Aureliano slipped away, and the next night towards dawn, he returned to her room, increasingly pleased to find her door still unlocked.
tr: Aureliano would leave at dawn, come back the next morning, and each time he came, he was even more excited by the fact that Amaranta didn't bolt the door.
es: "Aureliano escaped at dawn and returned the next morning, increasingly excited by the realization that she did not bolt the door.

en: He had nit stopped desiring her for a single instant.
vi: There was never a moment when he didn't love his aunt intensely.
tr: His desire for her had not diminished for a moment.
es: He had not stopped desiring her for a single moment.

en: He found her in the dark bedrooms of captured towns, especially in the most abject ones, and he would make her materialize in the smell of dry blood on the bandages of the wounded, in the instantaneous terror of the danger of death, at all times and in all places.
vi: He often saw her image in the dark rooms of occupied villages, especially the most squalid ones, and recognized her physically through the smell of dried blood on the bandages of the wounded, in the sudden fear of death. He saw his aunt everywhere and at all times.
tr: In the dark bedrooms of the occupied cities, in the most wretched of bedrooms, he had found Amaranta, sensed Amaranta in the dried blood smell of the bandages of the wounded, lived Amaranta in the momentary terror of the danger of death, dreamed of her everywhere, all the time.
es: He found her in the dark bedrooms of the defeated towns, especially in the most abject ones, and materialized her in the stench of dried blood on the bandages of the wounded, in the instant fear of death, at all hours and in all places.

en: He had fled from her in an attempt to wipe out her memory, not only through distance but by means of a muddled fury that his companions at arms took to be boldness, but the more her image wallowed in the dunghill of the war, the more the war resembled Amaranta.
vi: He had fled from his aunt by deliberately erasing his memories, not only through the vast distance but also through the blood-curdling battles that his comrades had ranked among the most terrifying. However, the more he tried to erase his aunt's image in the horrors of war, the more the war resembled Amaranta.
tr: He had fled from her to forget her; not only going far away but also throwing himself forward with a fury that his comrades called recklessness, yet the more he tried to bury Amaranta's image in the filth of war, the more the war resembled Amaranta. During his time in hiding, Aureliano Jose had writhed in these pains, seeking ways to kill himself and thus kill the image of Amaranta.
es: He had fled from her, trying to annihilate her memory not only with distance but with a dazed ferocity that his comrades in arms described as recklessness, but the more he wallowed her image in the filth of war, the more the war resembled Amaranta.

en: That was how he suffered in exile, looking for a way of killing her with, his own death, until he heard some old man tell the tale of the man who had married his aunt, who was also his cousin, and whose son ended up being his own grandfather.
vi: Thus, he painfully lived in exile, trying to kill his aunt by his own death until he heard a soldier tell a fairy tale about a man who married his own aunt, who was also his niece, and whose son was his own great-uncle.
tr: One day, he had listened to a tale from an old man.
es: Thus he endured exile, seeking a way to kill her with his own death, until he heard her tell someone the old story of the man who married an aunt who was also his cousin, and whose son ended up being his own grandfather.

en: “Can a person marry his own aunt?” he asked, startled.
vi: - Can't one marry their own aunt? - he asked, looking horrified.
tr: In the tale, the man marries his aunt, who is also his uncle's daughter, and in the end, his son becomes his own grandfather.
es: —Can one marry an aunt? —he asked, astonished.

en: “He not only can do that, a soldier answered him.
vi: - Not only can it be taken, - a soldier answered him, - but even more than that.
tr: In the tale, the man marries his aunt, who is also his uncle's daughter, and in the end, his son becomes his own grandfather.
es: —Not only is it possible —a soldier replied to him— but we are fighting this war against the priests so that one can marry his own mother.

en: “but we’re fighting this war against the priests so that a person can marry his own mother.”
vi: We are waging this war against these priests so that people can take their own mothers.
tr: In the tale, the man marries his aunt, who is also his uncle's daughter, and in the end, his son becomes his own grandfather.
es: —Not only is it possible —a soldier replied to him— but we are fighting this war against the priests so that one can marry his own mother.

en: Two weeks later he deserted.
vi: Fifteen days later, he deserted.
tr: Aureliano Jose had escaped from the barracks and come back two weeks after this incident.
es: Fifteen days later he deserted.

en: He found Amaranta more withered than in his memory, more melancholy and shy, and now really turning the last corner of maturity, but more feverish than ever in the darkness of her bedroom and more challenging than ever in the aggressiveness of her resistance.
vi: He found the real-life Amaranta more captivating than the Amaranta in his memory, saw her as sadder and more graceful, and although in reality she was past her prime, she was more passionate than ever in the darkness of the bedroom, more than ever she abandoned herself to the frenzy of denial.
tr: He found Amaranta more worn out, more withdrawn, more timid, and curled up at the last corner of maturity than he had imagined, but in the darkness of the bedroom, more passionate than ever, more aggressively defiant in her resistance than ever.
es: He found Amaranta more withered than in his memory, more melancholic and prudish, and already truly rounding the last bend of maturity, but more feverish than ever in the darkness of the bedroom and more defiant than ever in the aggressiveness of her resistance: "You are a brute," Amaranta would say, harassed by her watchdogs.

en: “You’re a brute,” Amaranta would tell him as she was harried by his hounds.
vi: "You are a scoundrel," Amaranta told him when he pursued her.
tr: As Amaranta undressed in his hand caresses, she said, "You are a monster."
es: He found Amaranta more withered than in his memory, more melancholic and prudish, and already truly rounding the last bend of maturity, but more feverish than ever in the darkness of the bedroom and more defiant than ever in the aggressiveness of her resistance: "You are a brute," Amaranta would say, harassed by her watchdogs.

en: “You can’t do that to a poor aunt unless you have a special dispensation from the Pope.”
vi: "What you are doing to your poor aunt is improper, even if the Pope himself granted absolution."
tr: "You can't do these things to your poor aunt unless you get special permission from the Pope."
es: "It's not true that one can do this to a poor aunt, unless with a special dispensation from the Pope."

en: Aureliano, José promised to go to Rome, he promised to go across Europe on his knees to kiss the sandals of the Pontiff just so that she would lower her drawbridge.
vi: Aureliano José promised to go to Rome, promised to crawl on his knees across Europe kissing the Pope's feet just to beg his aunt to "grant him entry."
tr: Aureliano Jose promised to go to Rome; Amaranta said she would walk across Europe on her knees to kiss the Pope's sandals so that he would lower the drawbridge of the castle.
es: Aureliano José promised to go to Rome, promised to travel across Europe on his knees, and kiss the sandals of the Supreme Pontiff just so she would lower her drawbridges.

en: “It’s not just that,” Amaranta retorted.
vi: - Not just because of that, - Amaranta tried to resist, - but also because they will give birth to children with pig tails.
tr: Amaranta was protesting, "This doesn't end here."
es: —It's not just that —Amaranta argued—.

en: “Any children will be born with the tail of a pig.”
vi: - Not just because of that, - Amaranta tried to resist, - but also because they will give birth to children with pig tails.
tr: "If we have a child, it will have a tail like a pig."
es: It's that children are born with pig tails.

en: Aureliano José was deaf to all arguments.
vi: Aureliano José deliberately ignored all reasoning.
tr: Aureliano Jose paid no attention to these words.
es: Aureliano José was deaf to all arguments.

en: “I don’t care if they’re born as armadillos,” he begged.
vi: - Even if I have to give birth to pangolins, I am willing, - he pleaded.
tr: "Even if you give birth to a thorny lizard, it wouldn't matter," he was saying.
es: —Even if armadillos are born —he pleaded.

en: Early one morning, vanquished by the unbearable pain of repressed virility, he went to Catarino’s.
vi: One early morning, he went to Mr. Catarinô's shop after he could no longer endure the pain of repressed lust.
tr: Aureliano Jose, in the early morning, unable to bear the pain of unrelieved manhood, went to Catarino's shop.
es: One early morning, overcome by the unbearable pain of repressed manhood, he went to Catarino's store.

en: He found a woman with flaccid breasts, affectionate and cheap, who calmed his stomach for some time.
vi: There, he had an affair with a woman with sagging breasts, who was friendly and easygoing, and who satisfied his hunger for a while.
tr: He found a woman with sagging breasts, affectionate and vulgar. The woman temporarily quenched his hunger.
es: He found a woman with flaccid breasts, affectionate and cheap, who soothed his belly for a while.

en: He tried to apply the treatment of disdain to Amaranta.
vi: He intended to treat Amaranta badly.
tr: He also began to try the tactic of disdain towards Amaranta.
es: He tried to apply the treatment of disdain to Amaranta.

en: He would see her on the porch working at the sewing machine, which she had learned to operate with admirable skill, and he would not even speak to her.
vi: He saw her sitting in the hallway, working on a sewing machine—a skill she had learned very quickly—and he did not greet his aunt.
tr: He would see Amaranta sitting on the terrace, working at the sewing machine she had quickly mastered, and wouldn't even greet her.
es: He saw her in the corridor, sewing on a hand-crank machine that she had learned to operate with admirable skill, and he didn't even speak to her.

en: Amaranta felt freed of a reef, and she herself did not understand why she started thinking again at that time about Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, why she remembered with such nostalgia the afternoons of Chinese checkers, and why she even desired him as the man in her bedroom.
vi: Amaranta felt a weight lifted off her shoulders and she herself did not understand why she now thought of Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, why she longed for the afternoons playing checkers, and why she wanted him to be her husband.
tr: Amaranta compared herself to a boat narrowly escaping crashing into the rocks and couldn't understand why she started thinking about Colonel Gerineldo Marquez, why she nostalgically remembered the days they played Chinese checkers, and why she imagined Gerineldo as the man in her bedroom.
es: Amaranta felt liberated from a burden, and she herself didn't understand why she then began to think of Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, why she nostalgically recalled the afternoons of Chinese checkers, and why she even came to desire him as a bedroom man.

en: Aureliano, José did not realize how much ground he had lost on, the night he could no longer bear the farce of indifference and went back to Amaranta’s room.
vi: Aureliano José still did not know that he had lost his place in his aunt's heart, so one night, unable to control his desire, he sneaked into Amaranta's bedroom again.
tr: Aureliano Jose, however, did not realize the great defeat he faced the night he could no longer endure the comedy of indifference and returned to Amaranta's room.
es: Aureliano José did not realize how much ground he had lost, the night he could no longer resist the pretense of indifference, and returned to Amaranta's room.

en: She rejected him with an inflexible and unmistakable determination, and she barred the door of her bedroom forever.
vi: This time she firmly and resolutely rejected him. From then on, she locked her bedroom door tightly every night.
tr: Amaranta, with unshakable and unwavering determination, turned him away and bolted her door for life.
es: She rejected him with inflexible, unequivocal determination, and forever bolted the bedroom door.

en: A few months after the return of Aureliano José an exuberant woman perfumed with jasmine appeared at the house with a boy of five.
vi: A few months after Aureliano José returned, a woman with an open demeanor, smelling of jasmine, brought a five-year-old child to the house.
tr: A few months after Aureliano Jose's return, a flamboyant woman, smelling of jasmine, arrived at the door holding the hand of a five-year-old boy.
es: A few months after Aureliano José's return, an exuberant woman, scented with jasmine, arrived at the house with a child of about five years old.

en: She stated that he was the son of Colonel Aureliano Buendía and that she had brought him to Úrsula to be baptized.
vi: She said that the child was the son of Colonel Aureliano Buendía and that she had brought him for Úrsula to name.
tr: She said that the boy was the son of Colonel Aureliano Buendia and that she had brought him to Ursula to be baptized.
es: She claimed that he was the son of Colonel Aureliano Buendía and had brought him for Úrsula to baptize.

en: No one doubted the origins of that nameless child: he looked exactly like the colonel at the time he was taken to see ice for the first time.
vi: No one doubted the origin of the unnamed child: he resembled the Colonel exactly as he did when his father took him to see the ice.
tr: No one doubted the lineage of the unnamed child: He was the spitting image of the colonel. It was exactly like the time when Aureliano first saw ice. The woman described how the child was born:
es: No one doubted the origin of that nameless child: he was just like the colonel when they took him to see the ice.

en: The woman said that he had been born with his eyes open, looking at people with the judgment of an adult, and that she was frightened by his way of staring at things without blinking.
vi: The woman recounted that the boy was born with his eyes wide open, scrutinizing those around him with the inquisitiveness of an adult, and that she herself was startled by his unblinking, intense gaze.
tr: He was born with his eyes wide open. As soon as he was born, he fixed his eyes, which looked like those of a grown man, on the people around him, as if he were judging them. His unblinking stare frightened his mother.
es: The woman said that he was born with his eyes open, looking at people with the judgment of an adult, and that his way of staring at things without blinking frightened her.

en: “He’s identical,” Úrsula said.
vi: "Exactly," said Ursula.
tr: Ursula, "Just like him," she said.
es: "He is identical," said Úrsula.

en: “The only thing missing is for him to make chairs rock by simply looking at them.”
vi: "The only thing missing is for the chair to spin around when he looks at it."
tr: "The only thing missing is that he can't move the chairs with a glance."
es: "The only thing missing is for him to make the chairs move just by looking at them."

en: They christened him Aureliano and with his mother’s last name, since the law did not permit a person to bear his father’s name until he had recognized him.
vi: She named him with Aureliano's first name and his mother's last name, because the law did not allow a child to bear the father's last name if the father had not acknowledged him.
tr: They gave the child the name Aureliano and his mother's surname. Because according to the laws, until his father officially recognized him, the child could not take his father's surname.
es: They baptized him with the name Aureliano, and with his mother's surname, because the law did not allow him to carry his father's surname unless he recognized him.

en: General Moncada was the godfather.
vi: Colonel Moncada agreed to be his godfather.
tr: General Moncada became his godfather.
es: General Moncada served as godfather.

en: Although Amaranta insisted that he be left so that she could take over his upbringing, his mother was against it.
vi: Although Amaranta requested that the boy stay with the girl's family, the mother did not agree.
tr: Amaranta insisted a lot that she stay with them to take on the child's upbringing, but the child's mother opposed this.
es: Although Amaranta insisted on keeping him to finish raising him, the mother refused.

en: Úrsula at that time did not know about the custom of sending virgins to the bedrooms of soldiers in the same way that hens are turned loose with fine roosters, but in the course of that year she found out: nine more sons of Colonel Aureliano Buendía were brought to the house to be baptized.
vi: At that time, Úrsula still did not know the custom of parents sending their virgin daughters to the bedrooms of warriors as if they were letting hens into the coop of handsome roosters. But after a whole year, she learned: nine more sons of Colonel Aureliano Buendía were brought to the house to be named by her.
tr: Ursula had not yet heard of the custom of sending virgins into the arms of soldiers, just as hens are let loose among roosters. But she learned it well within that year. Colonel Aureliano Buendia's nine sons were brought home to be baptized.
es: Úrsula was unaware at the time of the custom of sending maidens to the bedrooms of warriors, much like fine roosters are given hens, but over the course of that year, she found out: nine more sons of Colonel Aureliano Buendía were brought to the house to be baptized.

en: The oldest, a strange dark boy with green eyes, who was not at all like his father’s family, was over ten years old.
vi: The oldest, brown-skinned with blue eyes, did not resemble his paternal side at all, and was already ten years old.
tr: The eldest, a dark-skinned, green-eyed boy who did not resemble his father at all, was no more than ten years old.
es: The eldest, a strange dark-skinned boy with green eyes who bore no resemblance to the paternal family, was over ten years old.

en: They brought children of all ages, all colors, but all males and all with a look of solitude that left no doubt as to the relationship.
vi: They brought children of all ages to the house, with all skin colors, but all were boys, and all seemed lonely—a characteristic that forced people to acknowledge their origins.
tr: They kept bringing children of every age and color, but all of them were boys and left no doubt about their paternity.
es: They brought children of all ages, of all colors, but all boys, and all with an air of solitude that left no doubt about their kinship.

en: Only two stood out in the group.
vi: They brought children of all ages to the house, with all skin colors, but all were boys, and all seemed lonely—a characteristic that forced people to acknowledge their origins.
tr: Among those who came, only two showed distinct characteristics.
es: Only two stood out from the crowd.

en: One, large for his age, made smithereens out of the flowerpots and china because his hands seemed to have the property of breaking everything they touched.
vi: One child, who was very mature for his age, broke several vases and some cups, as it seemed that whatever his clumsy hands touched, he broke.
tr: One was large for his age and broke every piece of crockery and every pot in the house. It was as if his hands had the ability to break everything they touched.
es: One, too big for his age, who shattered vases and several pieces of crockery because his hands seemed to have the property of breaking everything they touched.

en: The other was a blond boy with the same light eyes as his mother, whose hair had been left to grow long and curly like that of a woman.
vi: Another had red hair, with snail-like eyes just like his mother's, and wore his long hair tied up in bunches just like a woman's.
tr: The other was a fair-haired boy with light-colored eyes like his mother. His hair was grown long and curled like a girl's.
es: The other was a blond boy with the same hazel eyes as his mother, whose hair had been left long and curly, like a girl's.

en: He entered the house with a great deal of familiarity, as if he had been raised there, and he went directly to a chest in Úrsula’s bedroom and demanded, “I want the mechanical ballerina.”
vi: This boy walked into the house very naturally, as if he had been raised there, and then went straight to the old cabinet in Úrsula's room and demanded, "Give me the wind-up dancer."
tr: He entered the house with a familiarity as if he had been raised there, went straight to the console in Ursula's room, and said, "I want the wind-up ballerina."
es: He entered the house with great familiarity, as if he had been raised there, and went directly to a chest in Úrsula's bedroom, demanding: "I want the wind-up dancer."

en: Úrsula was startled.
vi: Úrsula was startled.
tr: Ursula was taken aback.
es: Úrsula was frightened.

en: She opened the chest, searched among the ancient and dusty articles left from the days of Melquíades, and wrapped in a pair of stockings she found the mechanical ballerina that Pietro Crespi had brought to the house once and that everyone had forgotten about.
vi: She opened the cabinet. After finding the dancer wrapped in a pair of stockings. It was a gift from Pietro Crespi and no one had remembered it.
tr: She opened the drawer, rummaged through the old, dusty knick-knacks from Melquiades' time, and found the wind-up ballerina wrapped in a pair of socks. Pietro Crespi had brought it to the house, and then everyone had forgotten about it.
es: She opened the chest, rummaged through the old and dusty objects from Melquíades' time, and found the wind-up dancer wrapped in a pair of stockings, which Pietro Crespi had once brought to the house and which no one had remembered since.

en: In less than twelve years they baptized with the name Aureliano and the last name of the mother all the sons that the colonel had implanted up and down his theater of war: seventeen.
vi: In less than twelve years, seventeen children, fathered by the colonel and scattered across the regions he passed through during the war, were named Aureliano along with their mothers' surnames.
tr: Within less than twelve years, the seventeen sons that the colonel had fathered on his battlefield were baptized with the name Aureliano and their mothers' surnames.
es: In less than two years, all the children that the colonel had scattered across his war territories were baptized with the name Aureliano and their mother's surname: seventeen in total.

en: At first Úrsula would fill their pockets with money and Amaranta tried to have them stay.
vi: At first, Úrsula stuffed their pockets with money, and Amaranta wanted to keep them to raise.
tr: At first, Ursula would fill the pockets of those who came with money, and Amaranta would try to keep them at home.
es: At first, Úrsula filled their pockets with money, and Amaranta tried to keep them.

en: But they finally limited themselves to giving them presents and serving as godmothers.
vi: But both concluded that it was best to give each child a commemorative gift and accept to be their godmothers.
tr: But eventually, they started to be content with giving them gifts and becoming their godmothers.
es: But they ended up limiting themselves to giving them a gift and serving as their godmothers.

en: “We’ve done our duty by baptizing them,” Úrsula would say, jotting down in a ledger the name and address of the mother and the place and date of birth of the child.
vi: "We will just name them," Úrsula said as she recorded the names and addresses of the mothers, and the places and dates of the children's births in a notebook.
tr: Ursula would record the mother's name, address, and the child's place and date of birth in a large ledger, saying, "By baptizing them, we have done our part."
es: "We fulfilled our duty by baptizing them," Úrsula said, noting in a notebook the name and address of the mothers and the place and date of birth of the children.

en: “Aureliano needs well-kept accounts so that he can decide things when he comes back.”
vi: "Surely Aureliano has planned this, so he will decide everything when he returns."
tr: She would say, "We need to keep the records well so that when Aureliano comes, he can make a decision easily."
es: "Aureliano must keep good records, so he will be the one to make decisions when he returns."

en: During lunch, commenting with General Moncada about that disconcerting proliferation, she expressed the desire for Colonel Aureliano Buendía to come back someday and gather all of his sons together in the house.
vi: During lunch, while commenting with General Moncada about this "proliferation," she expressed her wish that Colonel Aureliano Buendía would have the opportunity to return and reunite with his children in his own home.
tr: While Ursula was discussing this surprising reproduction issue with General Moncada at dinner one day, she hinted that Colonel Aureliano Buendia deeply wished to return one day and gather all his sons at home.
es: During a lunch, commenting with General Moncada on that bewildering proliferation, she expressed the wish that Colonel Aureliano Buendía would someday return to gather all his children in the house.

en: “Don’t worry, dear friend,” General Moncada said enigmatically.
vi: - Please don't worry, - General Moncada said mysteriously, - the Colonel will return sooner than you think.
tr: General Moncada said, "Do not worry, my dear friend, Aureliano will return sooner than you think."
es: —Don't worry, comadre —said General Moncada enigmatically—.

en: “He’ll come sooner than you suspect.”
vi: - Please don't worry, - General Moncada said mysteriously, - the Colonel will return sooner than you think.
tr: General Moncada said, "Do not worry, my dear friend, Aureliano will return sooner than you think."
es: He will come sooner than you imagine.

en: What General Moncada knew and what he did not wish to reveal at lunch was that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was already on his way to head up the most prolonged, radical, and bloody rebellion of all those he had started up till then.
vi: What Colonel Moncada knew well and did not want to reveal during lunch was that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was preparing for the longest, most thorough, and bloodiest uprising compared to any of the uprisings he had planned until now.
tr: The truth that General Moncada knew at that moment and did not want to explain was that Colonel Aureliano Buendia was on his way to lead the longest, most relentless, and bloodiest uprising he had ever undertaken until that day.
es: What General Moncada knew, and did not want to reveal at lunch, was that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was already on his way to lead the longest, most radical, and bloodiest rebellion attempted until then.

en: The situation again became as tense as it had been during the months that preceded the first war.
vi: The political atmosphere became tense again, just like the political atmosphere of the months before the outbreak of the first war.
tr: The situation became tense again, just like in the months before the first war.
es: The situation became as tense as it was in the months leading up to the first war.

en: The cockfights, instituted by the mayor himself, were suspended.
vi: The cockfights that were once encouraged by the mayor had been abolished.
tr: The cockfights, which were held under the protection of the mayor, were suspended.
es: The cockfights, encouraged by the mayor himself, were suspended.

en: Captain Aquiles Ricardo, the commander of the garrison, took over the exercise of municipal power.
vi: Captain Aquiles Ricardo, the commanding officer of the troops stationed in Macondo, took power and managed all affairs in the town.
tr: Captain Aquiles Ricardo, the Garrison Commander, took over the mayoral duties.
es: Captain Aquiles Ricardo, commander of the garrison, practically assumed municipal power.

en: The Liberals looked upon him as a provocateur.
vi: The Liberals accused him of being a provocateur.
tr: The Liberals viewed him as a provocateur.
es: The liberals pointed to him as a provocateur.

en: “Something terrible is going to happen,” Úrsula would say to Aureliano José.
vi: "A terrible event will happen," Úrsula told Aureliano José.
tr: Ursula said to Aureliano Jose, "Bad things are going to happen."
es: “Something terrible is going to happen,” Úrsula told Aureliano José.

en: “Don’t go out into the street after six o’clock.”
vi: "Do not go out after six in the evening, do you hear me?"
tr: "Don't go out after six in the evening."
es: “Don’t go out after six in the evening.”

en: The entreaties were useless.
vi: Her warnings all became useless.
tr: However, no matter how much Ursula pleaded, she couldn't make him listen.
es: They were useless pleas.

en: Aureliano José, just like Arcadio in other times, had ceased to belong to her.
vi: Aureliano José, just like Arcadio in the previous period, did not listen to his grandmother.
tr: Just as Arcadio once did, Aureliano Jose had also ceased to belong to her.
es: Aureliano José, like Arcadio in another era, had ceased to belong to her.

en: It was as if his return home, the possibility of existing without concerning himself with everyday necessities, had awakened in him the lewd and lazy leanings of his uncle José Arcadio.
vi: It seems that this is the result of your return home, the result of an indifferent lifestyle towards the daily pressing tasks. It was these things that awakened in you the talent for womanizing and laziness of your uncle José Arcadio.
tr: It seemed that the possibility of living without worrying about daily subsistence, upon returning home, had awakened in him the lazy and profligate tendencies of his uncle, Jose Arcadio.
es: It was as if returning home, the possibility of existing without worrying about daily urgencies, had awakened in him the lustful and idle vocation of his uncle José Arcadio.

en: His passion for Amaranta had been extinguished without leaving any scars.
vi: Your wave of feelings for Amaranta had completely subsided, leaving no trace of injury.
tr: His passion for Amaranta had passed without leaving a trace.
es: His passion for Amaranta extinguished without leaving scars.

en: He would drift around, playing pool, easing his solitude with occasional women, sacking the hiding places where Úrsula had forgotten her money.
vi: You indulged in somewhat debauched activities, sometimes playing billiards, sometimes relieving boredom with random women you encountered, sometimes embezzling money that Úrsula had forgotten in the desk drawer.
tr: He wandered aimlessly, played billiards, passed his loneliness with transient women, and plundered the money Ursula had hidden and forgotten.
es: He wandered a bit aimlessly, playing billiards, coping with his loneliness with occasional women, looting the nooks where Úrsula forgot the misplaced money.

en: He ended up coming home only to change his clothes.
vi: You only returned home to change clothes, "Children of this house, all of them are the same," Úrsula lamented.
tr: Eventually, he only stopped by the house to change his clothes.
es: He ended up only returning home to change clothes.

en: “They’re all alike,” Úrsula lamented.
tr: Ursula complained, "They are all the same."
es: “They are all the same,” Úrsula lamented.

en: “At first they behave very well, they’re obedient and prompt and they don’t seem capable of killing a fly, but as soon as their beards appear they go to ruin.”
vi: At first, they are raised very carefully, so they are all obedient, virtuous, and gentle, seemingly not even daring to kill a fly. Yet as soon as they start to grow a bit of a beard, they become wayward and unruly.
tr: "At first, their manners and gentlemanliness are impeccable." "They listen, do whatever they are told, and seem incapable of hurting even an ant." "But as soon as their beards grow, their morals deteriorate," she grumbled.
es: “At first they are raised very well, they are obedient and formal and seem incapable of killing a fly, and as soon as they grow a beard they throw themselves into perdition.”

en: Unlike Arcadio, who had never known his real origins, he found out that he was the son of Pilar Ternera, who had hung up a hammock so that he could take his siesta in her house.
vi: "Unlike Arcadio, who never knew his origins, you knew that you were the son of Pilar Ternera, who had hung a hammock for you to nap in right at her house.
tr: Unlike Arcadio, who never learned who his real parents were, Aureliano Jose found out that he was the son of Pilar Ternera. The woman had prepared a hammock for him to take his afternoon naps in her house.
es: Unlike Arcadio, who never knew his true origin, he found out that he was the son of Pilar Ternera, who had hung a hammock for him to take a nap in her house.

en: More than mother and son, they were accomplices in solitude.
vi: In their loneliness, they went beyond a mother-son relationship to have an affair with each other.
tr: Beyond being mother and son, they shared their loneliness.
es: They were, more than mother and son, accomplices in solitude.

en: Pilar Ternera had lost the trail of all hope.
vi: Pilar Ternera was completely desperate.
tr: Pilar Ternera had lost all her hopes.
es: Pilar Ternera had lost the trace of all hope.

en: Her laugh had taken on the tones of an organ, her breasts had succumbed to the tedium of endless caressing, her stomach and her thighs had been the victims of her irrevocable fate as a shared woman, but her heart grew old without bitterness.
vi: Her laughter was hoarse like the sound of a frog's croak. Her breasts had sagged, her belly and thighs had become flabby from being the victim of her inescapable fate as a promiscuous woman. But her heart resigned to aging without a hint of bitterness.
tr: She had forgotten the resonance of her laughter, which had turned into the heavy strokes of an organ, her breasts had been ruined by endless squeezes, and she had fallen victim to the inevitable fate of a woman whose belly and hips were shared. Yet, her heart had aged without hardening.
es: Her laughter had acquired organ-like tones, her breasts had succumbed to the tedium of occasional caresses, her belly and thighs had been victims of her irrevocable destiny as a shared woman, but her heart aged without bitterness.

en: Fat, talkative, with the airs of a matron in disgrace, she renounced the sterile illusions of her cards and found peace and consolation in other people’s loves.
vi: She was a fat, talkative woman. With the emptiness of an unfortunate Madam, she had given up the hopeless illusion that the cards brought her, and she found solace in the love of others.
tr: She had become like a plump, talkative, self-indulgent maternal housewife, had cast aside the empty dreams of the cards, and had begun to find peace and solace in the loves of others.
es: Fat, talkative, with airs of a matron in disgrace, she renounced the sterile illusion of the cards and found a haven of consolation in the loves of others.

en: In the house where Aureliano José took his siesta, the girls from the neighborhood would receive their casual lovers.
vi: In the house where Aureliano José napped, the neighboring girls entertained random lovers.
tr: In the house where Aureliano Jose took his afternoon naps, the neighboring girls would meet with their lovers.
es: In the house where Aureliano José took his nap, the neighborhood girls received their casual lovers.

en: “Lend me your room, Pilar,” they would simply say when they were already inside.
vi: "Aunt Pilar, can I borrow a room?" they would easily say to her once they were inside the house.
tr: After entering without question, they would say, -Pilar, can we use your room for a while?
es: “Can I borrow the room, Pilar,” they would simply say when they were already inside.

en: “Of course,” Pilar would answer.
vi: "Whatever," Pilar replied.
tr: Pilar would respond to them, "Of course, by all means," and if there was someone else at home, she would turn to them and explain, "I too am happy to know that people are happy in bed."
es: “Of course,” Pilar would say.

en: And if anyone was present she would explain:
vi: And if anyone was standing there, she would explain:
tr: Pilar would respond to them, "Of course, by all means," and if there was someone else at home, she would turn to them and explain, "I too am happy to know that people are happy in bed."
es: And if someone was present, she would explain:

en: “I’m happy knowing that people are happy in bed.”
vi: - I would be happy to know that others are in ecstasy on the bed.
tr: Pilar would respond to them, "Of course, by all means," and if there was someone else at home, she would turn to them and explain, "I too am happy to know that people are happy in bed."
es: —I am happy knowing that people are happy in bed.

en: She never charged for the service.
vi: She never took money for renting rooms.
tr: He wouldn't take any money in return for this service.
es: She never charged for the service.

en: She never refused the favor, just as she never refused the countless men who sought her out, even in the twilight of her maturity, without giving her money or love and only occasionally pleasure.
vi: She never refused to do favors for others, nor did she ever turn away the many men who sought her out, even when she was well past her prime. She indulged them not for money or love, but simply for the occasional pleasure, that's all.
tr: Even in her old age, she never turned away men who came looking for her, without giving money, without giving love, and always without giving pleasure, nor did she ever turn away girls who wanted her room.
es: She never refused a favor, just as she did not refuse it to the countless men who sought her even in the twilight of her maturity, without providing her with money or love, and only sometimes pleasure.

en: Her five daughters, who inherited a burning seed, had been lost on the byways of life since adolescence.
vi: Her five daughters, who inherited her passionate nature, wandered the thorny paths of life from their adolescence.
tr: All five of her daughters, each a legacy of a passionate seed, had grown up and gotten lost in the intricate paths of life.
es: Her five daughters, inheritors of a burning seed, lost themselves in the twists and turns of life since adolescence.

en: Of the two sons she managed to raise, one died fighting in the forces of Colonel Aureliano Buendía and the other was wounded and captured at the age of fourteen when he tried to steal a crate of chickens in a town in the swamp.
vi: Of the two sons she raised, one joined Colonel Aureliano Buendía's army and died in combat, while the other was crippled and imprisoned at fourteen when he tried to steal a henhouse in a village in the marshlands.
tr: One of the two sons Pilar had raised and brought up had died fighting after joining Colonel Aureliano Buendia's forces, while the other had been caught and injured at the age of fourteen while trying to steal a crate of chicks from a village in the swamp.
es: Of the two sons she managed to raise, one died fighting in the ranks of Colonel Aureliano Buendía and the other was wounded and captured at fourteen, when he tried to steal a crate of chickens in a swamp village.

en: In a certain way, Aureliano José was the tall, dark man who had been promised her for half a century by the king of hearts, and like all men sent by the cards he reached her heart when he was already stamped with the mark of death.
vi: In appearance, Aureliano José was tall and robust, with a rosy brown complexion, and for half a century, the "cards" had foretold his arrival to her, just as they had for all the men the cards had predicted, Aureliano José came to her marked by death.
tr: In a way, Aureliano Jose was the tall, dark man that the tarot priest had foretold for her half a century ago, and like all the men brought by the cards, he reached Pilar's heart after being marked by death on his forehead.
es: In a way, Aureliano José was the tall, dark man who for half a century announced the king of cups to her, and like all the messengers of the cards, he reached her heart when it was already marked by the sign of death.

en: She saw it in the cards.
vi: She saw it in the cards.
tr: The woman saw in the cards that he was destined for death.
es: She saw him in the cards.

en: “Don’t go out tonight,” she told him.
vi: - Don't go out tonight, - she said, - stay here and sleep because Carmelita Montiel keeps insisting that I take her to your room.
tr: "Don't go out tonight," he said. "Stay here."
es: —Don't go out tonight —he told her—.

en: “Stay and sleep here because Carmelita Montiel is getting tired of asking me to put her in your room.”
vi: - Don't go out tonight, - she said, - stay here and sleep because Carmelita Montiel keeps insisting that I take her to your room.
tr: "Besides, Carmelita Montiel keeps begging me to put her in your arms."
es: Stay here and sleep, because Carmelita Montiel has been begging me to let her into your room.

en: Aureliano José did not catch the deep feeling of begging that was in the offer.
vi: Aureliano Jose did not grasp the deep meaning hidden in that pleading invitation.
tr: Aureliano Jose could not grasp the hidden plea in those words.
es: Aureliano José did not grasp the profound sense of supplication that offer had.

en: “Tell her to wait for me at midnight” he said.
vi: - Tell her to wait for me until midnight! - he said.
tr: -Tell her to wait for me at midnight, he said.
es: —Tell him to wait for me at midnight —he said.

en: He went to the theater, where a Spanish company was putting on The Dagger of the Fox, which was really Zorzilla’s play with the title changed by order of Captain Aquiles Ricardo, because the Liberals called the Conservatives Goths.
vi: You went to the theater. There, a Spanish troupe advertised a play called The Fox's Dagger, which was actually a script by Xôrida but had to be renamed by order of Captain Akilêt Ricacđô, because the Liberals called the Royalists "the strong ones.
tr: He went to the theater. A Spanish troupe was performing 'The Dagger of the Fox'. In fact, it was Zorrilla's play called The Dagger of the Goths. However, since the Liberals had nicknamed the Conservatives as Goths, Captain Aquiles Ricardo had changed the name of the play.
es: He went to the theater where a Spanish company was announcing The Dagger of the Fox, which was actually Zorrilla's play with the name changed by order of Captain Aquiles Ricardo, because the liberals called the conservatives "goths."

en: Only when he handed in his ticket at the door did Aureliano José realize that Captain Aquiles Ricardo and two soldiers armed with rifles were searching the audience.
vi: " It wasn't until presenting the ticket at the entrance that Aurêlianô Hôsê realized that Captain Akilêt Ricacđô, along with two soldiers carrying long guns, was controlling the crowd.
tr: Aureliano Jose only noticed that Captain Aquiles Ricardo and two soldiers with rifles were searching the audience after he went to the door and got his ticket.
es: Only at the moment of handing over the ticket at the door did Aureliano José realize that Captain Aquiles Ricardo, with two soldiers armed with rifles, was frisking the attendees.

en: “Be careful, captain,” Aureliano José warned him.
vi: "Watch out, Captain," Aurêlianô warned him. "
tr: Aureliano Jose, "Take it easy, captain."
es: "Careful, captain," Aureliano José warned him.

en: “The man hasn’t been born yet who can lay hands on me.”
vi: The one who will make me raise my hands hasn't appeared yet. "
tr: "No man born of a woman has dared to lay a hand on me," he said.
es: "The man who can lay hands on me has not yet been born."

en: The captain tried to search him forcibly and Aureliano José, who was unarmed, began to run.
vi: The captain tried to use force to control him, but Aurêlianô Hôsê, not carrying any weapons at the time, ran away.
tr: The captain tried to search him by force, and the unarmed Aureliano Jose began to flee.
es: The captain tried to frisk him by force, and Aureliano José, who was unarmed, started to run.

en: The soldiers disobeyed the order to shoot.
vi: The captain ordered to shoot, but the soldiers did not obey."That's a Buendía," one of them said to the captain.
tr: The soldiers did not obey the order to shoot.
es: The soldiers disobeyed the order to shoot.

en: “He’s a Buendía,” one of them explained.
vi: The captain ordered to shoot, but the soldiers did not obey."That's a Buendía," one of them said to the captain.
tr: One of them tried to explain, "He is a Buendia."
es: "He's a Buendía," explained one of them.

en: Blind with rage, the captain then snatched away the rifle, stepped into the center of the street, and took aim.”
vi: Furious, the captain grabbed a gun, ran into the middle of the street, and fired.
tr: Blinded by rage, the captain snatched the rifle from the soldier's hands, stood in the middle of the street, and took aim.
es: Blinded by fury, the captain then snatched the rifle, stepped into the middle of the street, and aimed.

en: “Cowards!” he shouted.
vi: - You old goat!
tr: "Cowards!" he shouted.
es: —Bastards! —he managed to shout—.

en: “I only wish it was Colonel Aureliano Buendía.”
vi: - the captain still managed to shout. - God willing, he is Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: "I wish it were Colonel Aureliano Buendia himself!"
es: I wish I were Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: Carmelita Montiel, a twenty-year-old virgin, had just bathed in orange-blossom water and was strewing rosemary leaves on Pilar Ternera’s bed when the shot rang out.
vi: Cacmêlita Môntiên, a young girl in her early twenties, had just finished bathing with orange leaf water and was laying rosemary leaves on Pila Tecnêra's bed when she heard the sound of gunfire.
tr: As the gunshot echoed, twenty-year-old untouched Carmelita Montiel, freshly bathed in orange blossom-scented water, was sprinkling rosemary leaves on Pilar Ternera's bed.
es: Carmelita Montiel, a twenty-year-old virgin, had just bathed with orange blossom water and was sprinkling rosemary leaves on Pilar Ternera's bed when the shot rang out.

en: Aureliano José had been destined to find with her the happiness that Amaranta had denied him, to have seven children, and to die in her arms of old age, but the bullet that entered his back and shattered his chest had been directed by a wrong interpretation of the cards.
vi: Aurêlianô Hôsê was ready to share the happiness with Cacmêlita Môntiên that Amaranta had denied him, ready to have seven children with her and be faithful to her until he died in her arms, but the bullet pierced his back and shattered his chest. It was a bullet guided by a misinterpretation of the cards.
tr: If it were up to Aureliano Jose, he would find the happiness Amaranta denied him in her. They would have exactly seven beautiful children. Aureliano Jose would spend many years with her and die of natural causes in her arms in his old age. However, the bullet that buried itself in his back and shattered his chest must have been fired due to a misinterpretation of the cards.
es: Aureliano José was destined to find with her the happiness that Amaranta had denied him, to have seven children, and to die of old age in her arms, but the rifle bullet that entered through his back and shattered his chest was directed by a misinterpretation of the cards.

en: Captain Aquiles Ricardo, who was really the one destined to die that night, did indeed die, four hours before Aureliano José.
vi: Captain Akilêt Ricacđô, who was supposed to die that night, indeed died four hours before Aurêlianô Hôsê.
tr: According to the fortune, the one who was supposed to die that night was Captain Aquiles Ricardo, who indeed died four hours before Aureliano Jose.
es: Captain Aquiles Ricardo, who was actually the one destined to die that night, indeed died four hours before Aureliano José.

en: As won as the shot was heard he was brought down by two simultaneous bullets whose origin was never established and a shout of many voices shook the night.
vi: Almost as soon as the sound of his own gunshot echoed, he was struck down by two bullets simultaneously, and the origin of those bullets was never discovered. Following that was a rumbling shout that shook the entire night sky:
tr: As soon as the gunshot was heard, the captain fell to the ground, hit by two bullets fired simultaneously from an unknown direction, and the night was interrupted by loud voices: "Long live the Liberal Party!" "Long live Colonel Aureliano Buendia!"
es: As soon as the shot rang out, he was struck down by two simultaneous bullets, the origin of which was never established, and a multitude of cries shook the night.

en: “Long live the Liberal party!
vi: - Long live the Liberal Party?
tr: As soon as the gunshot was heard, the captain fell to the ground, hit by two bullets fired simultaneously from an unknown direction, and the night was interrupted by loud voices: "Long live the Liberal Party!" "Long live Colonel Aureliano Buendia!"
es: —Long live the Liberal Party!

en: Long live Colonel Aureliano Buendía!”
vi: Long live Colonel Aureliano Buendía!
tr: As soon as the gunshot was heard, the captain fell to the ground, hit by two bullets fired simultaneously from an unknown direction, and the night was interrupted by loud voices: "Long live the Liberal Party!" "Long live Colonel Aureliano Buendia!"
es: Long live Colonel Aureliano Buendía!

en: At twelve o’clock, when Aureliano, José had bled to death and Carmelita Montiel found that the cards showing her future were blank, more than four hundred men had filed past the theater and discharged their revolvers into the abandoned body of Captain Aquiles Ricardo.
vi: At midnight, when Aureliano José breathed his last due to blood loss, and Carmelita Montiel saw her murky future in the cards, more than four hundred men had marched past the theater door and fired pistol shots at the abandoned corpse of Captain Aquiles Ricardo.
tr: At midnight, when Aureliano Jose died from blood loss and the fortune read for Carmelita Montiel proved false, a crowd of over four hundred gathered in front of the theater and emptied their pistols into the corpse of Captain Aquiles Ricardo, left in the middle of the street.
es: At twelve o'clock, when Aureliano José had finished bleeding out and Carmelita Montiel found the cards of her future blank, more than four hundred men had marched in front of the theater and had unloaded their revolvers into the abandoned corpse of Captain Aquiles Ricardo.

en: A patrol had to use a wheelbarrow to carry the body, which was heavy with lead and fell apart like a water-soaked loaf of bread.
vi: It took a new patrol team to carry the bullet-riddled and soggy corpse of the captain, which was as mushy as bread soaked in soup, onto a wheelbarrow to be taken away.
tr: His body, weighed down by the bullets and crumbling like soaked bread, was carried away by a patrolman with a wheelbarrow.
es: A patrol was needed to put the lead-laden body, which was falling apart like a soaked loaf of bread, into a wheelbarrow.

en: Annoyed by the outrages of the regular army, General José Raquel Moncada used his political influence, put on his uniform again, and assumed the civil and military leadership of Macondo.
vi: Contrary to the wrongful actions of the government troops, General José Raquén Moncada used his political influence, donned his uniform again, and took full control in Macondo.
tr: Annoyed by the excesses of career soldiers, General Jose Raquel Moncada used his political influence, donned his uniform again, and took control of the military and civil administration of Macondo.
es: Upset by the impertinences of the regular army, General José Raquel Moncada mobilized his political influences, donned the uniform again, and assumed the civil and military leadership of Macondo.

en: He did not expect, however, that his conciliatory attitude would be able to prevent the inevitable.
vi: However, he did not hope that his conciliatory attitude could avoid the inevitable.
tr: However, he hoped that his conciliatory attitude would prevent the inevitable.
es: He did not expect, however, that his conciliatory attitude could prevent the inevitable.

en: The news in September was contradictory.
vi: The news in September was full of contradictions.
tr: In September, various reports came in.
es: The news in September was contradictory.

en: While the government announced that it was maintaining control throughout the country, the Liberals were receiving secret news of armed uprisings in the interior.
vi: While the government declared that it had control over the entire country, the Liberals received secret notifications about armed uprisings in the interior regions.
tr: While the government claimed to have control of the situation throughout the country, secret reports to the Liberals indicated armed uprisings in the interior.
es: While the government announced that it maintained control throughout the country, the liberals received secret reports of armed uprisings in the interior.

en: The regime would not admit a state of war until it was proclaimed in a decree that had followed a court-martial which had condemned Colonel Aureliano Buendía to death in absentia.
vi: The current regime did not acknowledge that the country was in a state of war, and thus, in an official bulletin, it did not dare to declare that the military court continued to try Colonel Aureliano Buendía in absentia and had sentenced him to death in absentia.
tr: Those in power were reluctant to declare a state of war. However, following the court-martial decision that sentenced Colonel Aureliano Buendia to death in absentia, the situation was announced in a government communiqué.
es: The regime did not admit the state of war until it was proclaimed in a decree that Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been court-martialed in absentia and sentenced to death.

en: The first unit that captured him was ordered to carry the sentence out.
vi: They ordered the sentence to be carried out by whichever military unit first captured him.
tr: The first unit to capture the Colonel was ordered to execute the sentence.
es: The order was to carry out the sentence by the first garrison that captured him.

en: “This means he’s come back,” Úrsula said joyfully to General Moncada.
vi: "This means he is still alive," Úrsula declared in front of General Moncada.
tr: Ursula joyfully said to General Moncada, "This means he has returned."
es: "This means he has returned," Úrsula rejoiced before General Moncada.

en: But he himself knew nothing about it.
vi: But even he did not know for sure.
tr: However, Moncada had no knowledge of this matter.
es: But he himself was unaware of it.

en: Actually, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been in the country for more than a month.
vi: In reality, it shows that Colonel Aureliano Buendía had already been in the country for more than a month.
tr: In fact, Colonel Aureliano Buendia had returned to the country more than a month ago.
es: In reality, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been in the country for more than a month.

en: He was preceded by conflicting rumors, supposed to be in the most distant places at the same time, and even General Moncada did not believe in his return until it was officially announced that he had seized two states on the coast.
vi: Confused by conflicting sources of information and deceived by the supernatural actions of Colonel Aureliano Buendía in remote regions of the country, General Moncada still did not believe the colonel had returned to the country until he was officially informed that the colonel had taken control of two coastal provinces.
tr: Before his arrival, various rumors had spread, claiming that the colonel was in several distant places at the same time, and even General Moncada did not believe he had returned until it was officially announced that he had captured two towns in the coastal region.
es: Preceded by contradictory rumors, supposedly in the most remote places at the same time, General Moncada himself did not believe in his return until it was officially announced that he had taken over two coastal states.

en: “Congratulations, dear friend,” he told Úrsula, showing her the telegram.
vi: "Sir, I sincerely congratulate you," he said to Úrsula while showing her the telegram.
tr: Showing the telegram containing the official statement to Ursula, -Congratulations, dear friend.
es: “I congratulate you, comadre,” he said to Úrsula, showing her the telegram.

en: “You’ll soon have him here.”
vi: "Your son will be here soon."
tr: He will be here soon, he said.
es: “You will have him here very soon.”

en: Úrsula was worried then for the first time.
vi: For the first time in her life, Úrsula became worried.
tr: At that moment, Ursula became anxious for the first time.
es: Úrsula then became worried for the first time.

en: “And what will you do?” she asked.
vi: "And what will you do?" she asked.
tr: -What will you do? she asked.
es: “And what will you do, compadre?” she asked.

en: General Moncada had asked himself that same question many times.
vi: General Moncada had also asked himself that question many times.
tr: General Moncada had asked himself the same question many times.
es: General Moncada had asked himself that question many times.

en: “The same as he, my friend,” he answered.
vi: - I will remain silent about what your son did, sir!
tr: -I will do what he does, my friend, he said.
es: —The same as him, comadre —he replied—: to fulfill my duty.

en: “I’ll do my duty.”
vi: - he replied, - that is fulfilling one's duty.
tr: I will fulfill my duty.
es: —The same as him, comadre —he replied—: to fulfill my duty.

en: At dawn on the first of October Colonel Aureliano Buendía attacked Macondo with a thousand well-armed men and the garrison received orders to resist to the end.
vi: At dawn on the first of October, Colonel Aureliano Buendía, with a thousand heavily armed soldiers, attacked Macondo, and the army was ordered to resist to the end.
tr: On the first of October, at dawn, Colonel Aureliano Buendia marched on Macondo with a thousand men, armed from head to toe. The garrison was ordered to hold out to the end.
es: On the first of October, at dawn, Colonel Aureliano Buendía with a thousand well-armed men attacked Macondo, and the garrison received the order to resist until the end.

en: At noon, while General Moncada was lunching with Úrsula, a rebel cannon shot that echoed in the whole town blew the front of the municipal treasury to dust.
vi: By noon, when General Moncada was having lunch with Ursula, the cannon fire from the revolutionary forces shook the entire town and shattered the front wall of the town's treasury.
tr: At noon, while General Moncada was having lunch with Ursula, a cannonball, whose rumble echoed throughout the town, shattered the facade of the treasury.
es: At noon, while General Moncada was having lunch with Úrsula, a rebel cannon shot that echoed throughout the town pulverized the facade of the municipal treasury.

en: “They’re as well armed as we are,” General Moncada sighed, “but besides that they’re fighting because they want to.”
vi: "They are as heavily armed as we are," General Moncada sighed, "but they fight more fiercely than we do."
tr: General Moncada sighed, "They are as well-armed as we are." "Moreover, they are fighting willingly and with conviction."
es: «They are as well-armed as we are,» sighed General Moncada, «but they also fight with more determination.»

en: At two o’clock in the afternoon, while the earth trembled with the artillery fire from both sides, he took leave of Úrsula with the certainty that he was fighting a losing battle.
vi: By two in the afternoon, as the sky and earth trembled under the roaring cannon fire from both sides of the battle, he bid farewell to Ursula with the feeling that he was being defeated.
tr: At two in the afternoon, when the earth shook with the mutual artillery fire of both sides, General Moncada, certain that he was continuing a battle he believed lost from the start, asked Ursula for permission to leave.
es: At two in the afternoon, while the ground trembled with cannon shots from both sides, he said goodbye to Úrsula with the certainty that he was fighting a lost battle.

en: “I pray to God that you won’t have Aureliano in the house tonight,” he said.
vi: "May God grant that you do not welcome Aureliano into this house tonight," he said, "if not, please embrace him for me, because I do not expect to see him again."
tr: "I pray to God that Aureliano is not at home tonight."
es: —I pray to God that Aureliano is not in the house tonight —he said—.

en: “If it does happen that way, give him an embrace for me, because I don’t expect ever to see him again.”
vi: "May God grant that you do not welcome Aureliano into this house tonight," he said, "if not, please embrace him for me, because I do not expect to see him again."
tr: "If that happens, embrace him in my place." "Because I don't think I will see him again," he said.
es: If he is, give him a hug from me, because I do not expect to see him ever again.

en: That night he was captured when he tried to escape from Macondo, after writing a long letter to Colonel Aureliano Buendía in which he reminded him of their common aim to humanize the war and he wished him a final victory over the corruption of the militarists and the ambitions of the politicians in both parties.
vi: That night he was captured while trying to flee Macondo after writing a long letter to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, reminding him of their shared plans to make the war less brutal and wishing him decisive victory against the corrupt officers and greedy politicians of both parties.
tr: That night, after writing a long letter to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, reminding him of their common goal to humanize the war and wishing for the complete defeat of the army's corruptions and the passions of politicians on both sides, General Moncada was captured while trying to escape from Macondo.
es: That night he was captured while trying to escape from Macondo, after writing an extensive letter to Colonel Aureliano Buendía, in which he reminded him of their common goals of humanizing the war, and wished him a definitive victory against the corruption of the military and the ambitions of politicians from both parties.

en: On the following day Colonel Aureliano Buendía had lunch with him in Úrsula’s house, where he was being held until a revolutionary court-martial decided his fate.
vi: The next day, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had lunch with him at Úrsula's house, where he was being detained until the revolutionary military court decided his fate.
tr: The next day, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had a meal with the general at Ursula's house. He would stay there until the court-martial made a decision about him.
es: The next day, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had lunch with him at Úrsula's house, where he was confined until a revolutionary war council decided his fate.

en: It was a friendly gathering.
vi: It was a family gathering.
tr: They were sitting in a great atmosphere of friendship.
es: It was a family gathering.

en: But while the adversaries forgot the war to remember things of the past, Úrsula had the gloomy feeling that her son was an intruder.
vi: But while the two adversaries forgot the war to reminisce about old memories, Úrsula had a sorrowful feeling that her son had become a completely different person.
tr: However, while they reminisced about the old days and forgot the war, Ursula kept feeling a bitter emotion, repeatedly telling herself that her son was like an uninvited guest and didn't belong there.
es: But while the adversaries forgot the war to recall memories of the past, Úrsula had the grim impression that her son was an intruder.

en: She had felt it ever since she saw him come in protected by a noisy military retinue, which turned the bedrooms inside out until they were convinced there was no danger.
vi: She had that feeling from the moment he entered the house, protected by a noisy squad of guards. This squad had searched all the rooms until they ensured there was no danger.
tr: Ursula had felt this way the moment she saw her son being escorted inside by a noisy group of soldiers. The soldiers had turned the whole house upside down, even reaching the bedrooms, to ensure there was no danger for the colonel.
es: She had had it since she saw him enter protected by a noisy military apparatus that turned the bedrooms upside down until they were convinced there was no risk.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía not only accepted it but he gave strict orders that no one should come closer than ten feet, not even Úrsula, while the members of his escort finished placing guards about the house.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía not only acknowledged this rude and intrusive action but also issued a firm order, forbidding anyone, including Úrsula, from approaching him within three meters until the guards had finished positioning themselves around the house.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia not only accepted their behavior but also ordered that no one, including Ursula, be allowed to come within three meters of him. Meanwhile, guards were posted at various points around the house.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía not only accepted him but also issued orders with a decisive severity, and did not allow anyone to approach him within three meters, not even Úrsula, until the members of his escort finished setting up the guards around the house.

en: He was wearing an ordinary denim uniform with no insignia of any kind and high boots with spurs that were caked with mud and dried blood.
vi: He wore a common coarse fiber military uniform, without any rank or insignia, and high boots with spurs caked in mud and dried blood.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia was wearing a coarse fabric uniform without insignia or epaulets, and his boots were smeared with mud and dried blood on the spurs.
es: He wore an ordinary drill uniform, without any insignia, and high boots smeared with mud and dried blood.

en: On his waist he wore a holster with the flap open and his hand, which was always on the butt of the pistol, revealed the same watchful and resolute tension as his look.
vi: On his belt, he carried a pistol in a worn leather holster, his hand always resting on the grip, a gesture that perfectly matched the high alertness and determination in his eyes.
tr: A holster with an open flap was hanging at his waist. His hand, which never left the grip of his pistol, was as alert and tense as his gaze.
es: He carried a pistol at his waist with the holster unbuttoned, and his hand always resting on the grip revealed the same vigilant and resolute tension as his gaze.

en: His head, with deep recessions in the hairline now, seemed to have been baked in a slow oven.
vi: His head, now with tightly curled hair, seemed to have been dried.
tr: The head that had now significantly receded at the forehead looked as if it had been baked in a kiln without glaze.
es: His head, now with deep receding hairlines, seemed slow-cooked.

en: His face, tanned by the salt of the Caribbean, had acquired a metallic hardness.
vi: His face, once tanned by the Caribbean sun and wind, now bore a cold, steely expression.
tr: His face, scorched by the salt of the Caribbean Sea, had taken on a metallic hardness.
es: His face, cracked by the Caribbean salt, had acquired a metallic hardness.

en: He was preserved against imminent old age by a vitality that had something to do with the coldness of his insides.
vi: With a hidden coldness, he was ready to face the inevitable onset of old age.
tr: A kind of vitality connected to his inner coldness had protected him from aging and deteriorating.
es: He was preserved against imminent old age by a vitality that had something to do with the coldness of his insides.

en: He was taller than when he had left, paler and bonier, and he showed the first symptoms of resistance to nostalgia.
vi: Compared to when he left, he was taller, thinner, and paler, and showed the first signs of an unending melancholy.
tr: He was taller, paler, and bonier than when he had left, and had begun to show the first signs of resisting homesickness.
es: He was taller than when he left, paler and bonier, and showed the first symptoms of resistance to nostalgia.

en: “Good Lord,” Úrsula said to herself.
vi: "My God," Úrsula said to herself in alarm.
tr: Ursula thought to herself, -My God, he looks like someone who can do anything now, she said.
es: " My God," Úrsula said to herself, alarmed.

en: “Now he looks like a man capable of anything.”
vi: "Now he is capable of anything."
tr: Ursula thought to herself, -My God, he looks like someone who can do anything now, she said.
es: "Now he seems like a man capable of anything.

en: He was.
vi: Indeed, he was such a person.
tr: Indeed, Aureliano Buendia had reached a point where he could do anything.
es: "He was.

en: The Aztec shawl that he brought Amaranta, the remembrances he spoke of at lunch, the funny stories her told were simple leftovers from his humor of a different time.
vi: Not content with ordering the burial of battlefield corpses in a common grave, he also tasked Colonel Roque Carnicero with urgently convening military tribunals, while he personally took on the heavy burden of implementing thorough land reforms to eradicate the royalist regime.
tr: The Aztec shawl he brought to Amaranta, the memories he recounted at dinner, the funny stories, were remnants of his former playful self.
es: The Aztec shawl he brought to Amaranta, the recollections he made at lunch, the amusing anecdotes he told were mere embers of his humor from another era.

en: As soon as the order to bury the dead in a common grave was carried out, he assigned Colonel Roque Carnicero the minion of setting up courts-martial and he went ahead with the exhausting task of imposing radical reforms which would not leave a stone of the reestablished Conservative regime in place.
vi: Not content with ordering the burial of battlefield corpses in a common grave, he also tasked Colonel Roque Carnicero with urgently convening military tribunals, while he personally took on the heavy burden of implementing thorough land reforms to eradicate the royalist regime.
tr: After the order to bury the dead in a common grave was carried out, Colonel Aureliano Buendia assigned Colonel Roque Carnicero to establish the court-martial. He himself embarked on implementing radical reforms that would change the newly established Conservative regime in a way that would leave no stone unturned.
es: No sooner had the order to bury the dead in the common grave been carried out, he assigned Colonel Roque Carnicero the mission of expediting the war trials, and he undertook the exhausting task of imposing radical reforms that would leave no stone unturned in the crumbling structure of the conservative regime.

en: “We have to get ahead of the politicians in the party,” he said to his aides.
vi: "We must stay one step ahead of the party politicians," he told his advisors.
tr: He told his aides, -We must act faster than the politicians in the party.
es: "We have to get ahead of the party politicians," he told his advisors. "

en: “When they open their eyes to reality they’ll find accomplished facts.”
vi: "When they open their eyes to reality, they will be faced with accomplished facts."
tr: When they open their eyes to the facts, they will be faced with accomplished deeds, he said.
es: When they open their eyes to reality, they will find the accomplished facts. "

en: It was then that he decided to review the titles to land that went back a hundred years and he discovered the legalized outrages of his brother, José Arcadio.
vi: It was then that he decided to review the land deeds, even those made a hundred years ago, and thus discovered the forged deeds legalized by his brother José Arcadio.
tr: At that moment, he decided to examine the land registry records dating back a hundred years and learned about his brother Jose Arcadio's legitimized scandals.
es: It was then that he decided to review the land ownership titles, going back a hundred years, and discovered the legalized outrages of his brother José Arcadio.

en: He annulled the registrations with a stroke of the pen.
vi: With a single stroke, he invalidated those deeds.
tr: He defaced and erased the land records.
es: He annulled the records with a stroke of the pen.

en: As a last gesture of courtesy, he left his affairs for an hour and visited Rebeca to bring her up to date on what he was determined to do.
vi: In a final courteous gesture, he pondered for an hour and then visited Rebeca to inform her of his decision.
tr: To make one last gesture of courtesy, he took an hour's break from his work and went to Rebeca to explain his decisions to her.
es: In a final gesture of courtesy, he neglected his affairs for an hour and visited Rebeca to inform her of his determination.

en: In the shadows of her house, the solitary widow who at one time had been the confidante of his repressed loves and whose persistence had saved his life was a specter out of the past.
vi: In the dimly lit thatched house, there was only the lonely widow who had once been the confidante to whom he poured out his secret affections and who had persistently watched from her home for the soldiers to come and execute him, ultimately saving him from death. Now she was merely a shadow of the past.
tr: Once upon a time, this widow, who was buried in solitude and had been the confidante of Aureliano Buendia's secret loves and had saved his life with her stubbornness, seemed like an image from the past in the dimness of her home.
es: In the dim light of the house, the lonely widow who was once the confidante of his repressed loves, and whose obstinacy saved his life, was a specter of the past.

en: Encased in black down to her knuckles, with her heart turned to ash, she scarcely knew anything about the war.
vi: She hid herself in black mourning clothes that covered her from head to toe, and with a cold heart, she was almost oblivious to the war.
tr: The woman, whose heart had turned to ashes and who wore black clothes that reached down to her ankles, knew almost nothing about the war.
es: Clad in black up to her wrists, with a heart turned to ashes, she barely had any news of the war.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had the impression that the phosphorescence of her bones was showing through her skin and that she moved in an atmosphere of Saint Elmo’s fire, in a stagnant air where one could still note a hidden smell of gunpowder.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía felt as if the sulfur from her bones was seeping through her skin, and that she flickered like a ghostly flame in the stagnant air that still reeked of gunpowder.
tr: To Colonel Aureliano Buendia, it seemed as if the phosphorus in her bones was visible under her skin, as if the woman was moving within an electrically charged cloud, in an aged atmosphere where the smell of gunpowder could still be sensed.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had the impression that the phosphorescence of her bones pierced her skin, and that she moved through an atmosphere of will-o'-the-wisps, in stagnant air where a faint smell of gunpowder still lingered.

en: He began by advising her to moderate the rigor of her mourning, to ventilate the house, to forgive the world for the death of José Arcadio.
vi: He began to advise her to grieve less for her husband and to open the windows to let fresh air into the house, and to forgive the world for the death of José Arcadio.
tr: Colonel Buendia began by advising Rebeca not to mourn endlessly, to air out the house, and not to turn her back on the world just because Jose Arcadio had died.
es: He began by advising her to moderate the rigor of her mourning, to air out the house, to forgive the world for the death of José Arcadio.

en: But Rebeca was already beyond any vanity.
vi: But Rebeca was beyond all worldly temptations.
tr: However, nothing said to Rebeca mattered anymore.
es: But Rebeca was already beyond all vanity.
