en: After searching for it uselessly in the taste of earth, in, the perfumed letters from Pietro Crespi, in the tempestuous bed of her husband, she had found peace in that house where memories materialized through the strength of implacable evocation and walked like human beings through the cloistered rooms, Leaning back in her wicker rocking chair, looking at Colonel Aureliano Buendía as if he were the one who looked like a ghost out of the past, Rebeca was not even upset by the news that the lands usurped by José Arcadio would be returned to their rightful owners.
vi: After having futilely sought them in the taste of earth, in the scented letters of Pietro Crespi, on the bed that shook under the wild passion of her husband, she had found a serene atmosphere in that house, where unending memories brought past recollections to life, wandering through the closed rooms like real people. Lying on the wicker rocking chair, looking at Colonel Aureliano Buendía as if he were a figure from the past, Rebeca showed no sign of distress when she learned that the lands José Arcadio had illegally seized would now be returned to their rightful owners.
tr: After seeking peace in eating soil, in the scented letters of Pietro Crespi, and in the stormy bed of her husband to no avail, Rebeca had found peace and tranquility in this house where memories had materialized and floated from room to room like people. Rebeca, sitting in her rocking chair, looked at him as if it was not herself, who appeared like a ghost from the past, but Colonel Aureliano Buendia. He wasn't even surprised by the news that the lands Jose Arcadio had taken by force would be returned to their rightful owners.
es: After searching for her in vain in the taste of the earth, in the perfumed letters of Pietro Crespi, in the tempestuous bed of her husband, she had found peace in that house where memories materialized by the force of relentless evocation, and wandered like human beings through the closed rooms. Stretched out in her wicker rocker, looking at Colonel Aureliano Buendía as if he were the one who seemed like a specter of the past, Rebeca was not even moved by the news that the lands usurped by José Arcadio would be returned to their rightful owners.

en: “Whatever you decide will be done, Aureliano,” she sighed.
vi: - Aureliano, let people do what you have decided.
tr: "As you see fit, Aureliano," she sighed.
es: —It will be done as you decide, Aureliano —she sighed—.

en: “I always thought and now I have the proof that you’re a renegade.”
vi: She always thought, and now she is even more convinced, that you are a despicable man.
tr: "I have always thought you were a traitor, and now it is fully proven."
es: I always believed, and I confirm it now, that you are a renegade.

en: The revision of the deeds took place at the same time as the summary courts-martial presided over by Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, which ended with the execution of all officers of the regular army who had been taken prisoner by the revolutionaries.
vi: The examination of land documents was concluded simultaneously with the emergency trials conducted by Colonel Herinendo Marquez, and these trials all ended with the execution of all the government army officers captured as prisoners by the revolutionaries.
tr: The process of correcting land records coincided with the work of the court presided over by General Gerineldo Marquez. At the end of the trials, all the regular army officers captured by the revolutionaries were sentenced to death.
es: The review of property titles was completed at the same time as the summary trials, presided over by Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, which concluded with the execution by firing squad of all the regular army officers who were prisoners of the revolutionaries.

en: The last court-martial was that of José Raquel Moncada.
vi: The final military trial was the trial of General Jose Raquen Moncada.
tr: Finally, Jose Raquel Moncada was tried.
es: The last court-martial was that of General José Raquel Moncada.

en: Úrsula intervened.
vi: Ursula intervened.
tr: Ursula intervened.
es: Úrsula intervened.

en: ‘”His government was the best we’ve ever had in Macondo,” she told Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: "He is the best authority among the authorities in Macondo," she told Colonel Aureliano Buendia: "I don't even need to mention his kindness and the respectful attitude he has shown us, because you, more than anyone, understand him well."
tr: Reproaching Colonel Aureliano Buendia, she said, -During his time, Macondo had the best administration it ever had.
es: “He is the best ruler we have had in Macondo,” she told Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: “I don’t have to tell you anything about his good heart, about his affection for us, because you know better than anyone.”
vi: "He is the best authority among the authorities in Macondo," she told Colonel Aureliano Buendia: "I don't even need to mention his kindness and the respectful attitude he has shown us, because you, more than anyone, understand him well."
tr: I don't need to tell you how kind-hearted he was, how much he loved us, you know it better than any of us, she said.
es: “I don’t even need to tell you about his good heart, about the affection he has for us, because you know him better than anyone.”

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía gave her a disapproving look.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendia gave her a scrutinizing look:
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia glared at his mother.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía fixed a reproachful gaze on her:

en: “I can’t take over the job of administering justice,” he replied.
vi: - I cannot violate the court's rules of procedure, - he argued with his mother -
tr: "I cannot take on the duty of dispensing justice," he said.
es: —I cannot arrogate to myself the faculty of administering justice —he replied—.

en: “If you have something to say, tell it to the court-martial.”
vi: If you feel the need to say something, please go before the military court and say it.
tr: "If you have something to say, you will say it in court."
es: If you have something to say, say it before the court-martial.

en: Úrsula not only did that she also brought all of the mothers of the revolutionary officers who lived in Macondo to testify.
vi: Ursula not only spoke by herself but also mobilized all the mothers of revolutionary military officers currently living in Macondo.
tr: Ursula did not stop at going to court; she also brought all the mothers of the revolutionary officers in Macondo as witnesses.
es: Úrsula not only did it, but she also brought in all the mothers of the revolutionary officers living in Macondo to testify.

en: One by one the old women who had been founders of the town, several of whom had taken part in the daring crossing of the mountains, praised the virtues of General Moncada.
vi: The elders, who were the founders of the village of Macondo, among them the women who participated in the adventurous journey through the jungle to find a place to settle, took turns praising the virtues of General Moncada.
tr: The elderly women, some of whom were among the town's first founders and had bravely crossed the mountains, each spoke of General Moncada's virtues.
es: One by one, the old founders of the town, several of whom had participated in the daring crossing of the mountains, extolled the virtues of General Moncada.

en: Úrsula was the last in line.
vi: Ursula was the last among them.
tr: Ursula spoke last.
es: Úrsula was the last in the parade.

en: Her gloomy dignity, the weight of her name, the convincing vehemence of her declaration made the scale of justice hesitate for a moment.
vi: Her honor, her prestige, her commanding and persuasive demeanor in her declaration, all of these at some point made the judges feel embarrassed.
tr: Her heart-wrenching honor, the weight of her name, and the credibility of her words momentarily swayed the scales of justice.
es: Her mournful dignity, the weight of her name, the convincing vehemence of her statement momentarily shook the balance of justice.

en: “You have taken this horrible game very seriously and you have done well because you are doing your duty,” she told the members of the court.
vi: "You have played this terrifying game very seriously and you have done it right because you are fulfilling your duty," she said to the judges.
tr: Ursula said to the panel of judges, "You have taken this terrible game very seriously and are executing it successfully. Because you are doing your duty," she said.
es: “You have taken this dreadful game very seriously, and you have done well, because you are fulfilling your duty,” she said to the members of the tribunal.

en: “But don’t forget that as long as God gives us life we will still be mothers and no matter how revolutionary you may be, we have the right to pull down your pants and give you a whipping at the first sign of disrespect.”
vi: "But please remember that as long as God allows us to live, we are still your mothers, and even if you are very revolutionary, we still have the right to strip you and give you a few lashes if you do not listen."
tr: "Just remember that as long as God grants us life, we will remain mothers, and no matter how great revolutionaries you become, the moment you attempt to show disrespect, it is our right to pull down your pants and give you a good spanking."
es: “But do not forget that as long as God gives us life, we will continue to be mothers, and no matter how revolutionary you are, we have the right to pull down your pants and give you a whipping at the first sign of disrespect.”

en: The court retired to deliberate as those words still echoed in the school that had been turned into a barracks.
vi: As those words still echoed in the school turned military camp, the court withdrew to deliberate.
tr: As Ursula's words continued to echo in the school turned barracks, the panel of judges adjourned for deliberation.
es: The jury withdrew to deliberate while these words still echoed in the converted school-turned-barracks.

en: At midnight General José Raquel Moncada was sentenced to death.
vi: By midnight, General José Raquén Moncada was sentenced to death.
tr: At midnight, Jose Raquel Moncada was sentenced to death.
es: At midnight, General José Raquel Moncada was sentenced to death.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, in spite of the violent recriminations of Úrsula, refused to commute the sentence.
vi: Despite Ursula's fervent plea for clemency, Colonel Aureliano Buendía refused to reduce the sentence.
tr: Despite all of Ursula's pressing, urging, and resistance, Colonel Aureliano Buendia refused to change the decision.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, despite Úrsula's violent recriminations, refused to commute the sentence.

en: A short while before dawn he visited the condemned man in the room used as a cell.
vi: Just before dawn, he went to visit the condemned man in his cell.
tr: Just before dawn, he went to see the convict in the room used as a cell.
es: Shortly before dawn, he visited the condemned man in the stockade room.

en: “Remember, old friend,” he told him.
vi: - Remember, - he said to him, - that I am not the one shooting you.
tr: "Don't forget, my friend," he said.
es: —Remember, compadre —he said to him—, that it is not I who am executing you.

en: “I’m not shooting you.
vi: The revolution is shooting you.
tr: "I'm not the one killing you."
es: —Remember, compadre —he said to him—, that it is not I who am executing you.

en: It’s the revolution that’s shooting you.”
vi: The revolution is shooting you.
tr: "The revolution is killing you."
es: The revolution is executing you.

en: General Moncada did not even get up from the cot when he saw him come in.
vi: General Moncada, upon seeing him enter the cell, did not even bother to get up.
tr: General Moncada; he didn't even get out of bed when he saw him coming.
es: The general Moncada didn't even get up from the cot when he saw him enter.

en: “Go to hell, friend,” he answered.
vi: - Get lost, buddy, - he said.
tr: "You have a long road to hell, just go away, my friend," he said.
es: —Go to hell, buddy —he replied.

en: Until that moment, ever since his return.
vi: Since returning until that moment, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had not found the opportunity to visit General Moncada with all his heart.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia had not looked at his friend sincerely until that moment of his arrival.
es: Until that moment, since his return, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had not allowed himself the opportunity to see him with his heart.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had not given himself the opportunity to see him with his heart.
vi: Since returning until that moment, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had not found the opportunity to visit General Moncada with all his heart.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia had not looked at his friend sincerely until that moment of his arrival.
es: Until that moment, since his return, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had not allowed himself the opportunity to see him with his heart.

en: He was startled to see how much he had aged, how his hands shook, and the rather punctilious conformity with which he awaited death, and then he felt a great disgust with himself, which he mingled with the beginnings of pity.
vi: He was so surprised to see how much the general had aged, to see his hands trembling, to see him resigned to death, and thus at that moment he felt such self-contempt that he could mistake it for pity:
tr: He was surprised and disgusted with himself when he saw how his friend had deteriorated, how his hands trembled, and how he accepted death with an almost ceremonial formality. This feeling was mixed with a bit of pity.
es: He was astonished at how much he had aged, at the tremor in his hands, at the somewhat routine acceptance with which he awaited death, and then he experienced a deep contempt for himself that he confused with a beginning of mercy.

en: “You know better than I,” he said, “that all courts-martial are farces and that you’re really paying for the crimes of other people, because this time we’re going to win the war at any price.
vi: - You must know better than I do, - he said, - that all military courts are a joke, because in reality you have to pay for the crimes of others, because this time we will win by all means.
tr: "You know better than I do that all court-martial trials are a ridiculous farce," he said. "In fact, you are atoning for the crimes committed by others." "Because this time, we will win the war at any cost."
es: —You know better than I do —he said— that every court-martial is a farce, and that you truly have to pay for the crimes of others, because this time we are going to win the war at any cost.

en: Wouldn’t you have done the same in my place?”
vi: If you were in my position right now, wouldn't you do the same?
tr: "If you were in my place, wouldn't you do the same?"
es: If you were in my place, wouldn't you have done the same?

en: General Moncada, got up to clean his thick horn-rimmed glasses on his shirttail.
vi: General Moncada sat up and used his shirt tail to clean his tortoiseshell-framed glasses.
tr: General Moncada stood up to wipe his thick-rimmed glasses on the hem of his shirt.
es: The general Moncada stood up to clean his thick tortoiseshell glasses with the tail of his shirt.

en: “Probably,” he said.
vi: "It could be," he said, "but what I have to worry about is not you shooting me, because in any case, for people like us, this kind of death is inevitable."
tr: It could be, he said.
es: "Probably," he said.

en: “But what worries me is not your shooting me, because after all, for people like us it’s a natural death.”
vi: "It could be," he said, "but what I have to worry about is not you shooting me, because in any case, for people like us, this kind of death is inevitable."
tr: -What saddens me is not that you are going to kill me, because for people like us, being executed is in a way like dying of natural causes.
es: "But what worries me is not that you will shoot me, because after all, for people like us this is the natural death."

en: He laid his glasses on the bed and took off his watch and chain.
vi: He placed the glasses on the bed and then took off his pocket watch.
tr: He placed his glasses on the bed. He took off his watch and chain.
es: He placed the glasses on the bed and took off his pocket watch.

en: “What worries me,” he went on, “is that out of so much hatred for the military, out of fighting them so much and thinking about them so much, you’ve ended up as bad as they are.
vi: "What I worry about," he continued, "is that from someone who hated professional generals, who tirelessly fought against them, who pondered about them, now you are no different from them.
tr: -What really saddens me, he continued, -is that after hating the military so much, after fighting them so much, and after thinking so much about them, in the end, you have become worse than them.
es: "What worries me," he added, "is that from hating the military so much, from fighting them so much, from thinking about them so much, you have ended up being just like them.

en: And no ideal in life is worth that much baseness.”
vi: In life, there is no type of person who represents the baseness of humanity as much as you."
tr: And no ideal in the world is worth such degradation.
es: And there is no ideal in life that deserves such abjection."

en: He took off his wedding ring and the medal of the Virgin of Help and put them alongside his glasses and watch.
vi: He took off his wedding ring and the medal of Saint Remedios the Virgin, and placed them beside the watch and the glasses.
tr: He took off his wedding ring and the Holy Mary medallion, and placed them next to his glasses and watch. Then he finished his words:
es: He took off his wedding ring and the medal of the Virgin of Remedies and placed them along with the glasses and the watch.

en: “At this rate,” he concluded, “you’ll not only be the most despotic and bloody dictator in our history, but you’ll shoot my dear friend Úrsula in an attempt to pacify your conscience.”
vi: - At this point, - he concluded, - you are not only the most typical bloodthirsty dictator in the history of our country, but you will also shoot old Ucsula just to put your conscience at ease.
tr: After reaching this point, not only do you become the most despotic and bloody dictator of our latest history, but you also have my dear friend Ursula shot to silence your conscience.
es: —At this rate —he concluded— not only will you become the most despotic and bloodthirsty dictator in our history, but you will also execute my friend Úrsula in an attempt to appease your conscience.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía stood there impassively.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía stood there like a statue.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia stood motionless.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía remained impassive.

en: General Moncada then gave him the glasses, medal, watch, and ring and he changed his tone.
vi: General Moncada handed him glasses, medals, a watch, a wedding ring, and then changed his tone:
tr: General Moncada gave him his glasses, medallion, watch, and ring.
es: General Moncada then handed him the glasses, the medal, the watch, and the ring, and changed his tone.

en: “But I didn’t send for you to scold you,” he said.
vi: - But never mind, I did not want you to come just to scold you, - he said.
tr: Then, changing the tone of his voice, he said, "I didn't call you here to scold you."
es: —But I didn't make you come to scold you —he said—.

en: “I wanted to ask you the favor of sending these things to my wife.”
vi: - I want to ask you to deliver these things to my wife.
tr: "I wanted to ask you to send these to my wife."
es: I wanted to beg you the favor of sending these things to my wife.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía put them in his pockets.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía received the items and put them in his pocket.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia put what the general gave him into his pockets.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía put them in his pockets.

en: “Is she still in Manaure?”
vi: - Does she still live in Manaurê? - Still in Manaurê?
tr: -Is your wife still in Manaure? -She's still in Manaure.
es: —Is he still in Manaure?

en: “She’s still in Manaure,” General Moncada confirmed, “in the same house behind the church where you sent the letter.”
vi: - General Moncada confirmed, - still the house behind the church where you went to send that letter.
tr: At the address where you sent the letter, in the house behind the church again.
es: —He is still in Manaure —confirmed General Moncada—, in the same house behind the church where you sent that letter.

en: “I’ll be glad to, José Raquel,” Colonel Aureliano Buendía said.
vi: - I'm willing to do it. José Raquén? - Colonel Aureliano Buendía said.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, "I will send it willingly, Jose Raquel," he said.
es: —I will do it with great pleasure, José Raquel —said Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: When he went out into the blue air of the mist his face grew damp as on some other dawn in the past and only then did he realize that -he had ordered the sentence to be carried out in the courtyard and not at the cemetery wall.
vi: When he stepped outside into the damp green wind, his face was wet and blurred as it had been at dawn before, and only then did he understand why he had decided that the sentence had to be carried out right in the prison yard and not next to the cemetery wall.
tr: When Colonel Aureliano Buendia stepped into the blue air of dawn, his face became moist as it had at a dawn in the past, and it was only then that he realized he had ordered the execution to be carried out in the courtyard rather than against the cemetery wall.
es: When he stepped into the blue misty air, his face became moist as it had in another dawn of the past, and only then did he understand why he had arranged for the sentence to be carried out in the courtyard, and not at the cemetery wall.

en: The firing squad, drawn up opposite the door, paid him the honors of a head of state.
vi: The firing squad lined up right in front of the door, presenting arms to him, their commander.
tr: The firing squad lined up opposite the door saluted him in a manner befitting heads of state.
es: The squad, formed up in front of the door, gave him the honors of a head of state.

en: “They can bring him out now,” he ordered.
vi: - You can take him away now, - the colonel ordered.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia said, "They can bring him out now."
es: —You can bring him now —he ordered.

en: Chapter 9
vi: Chapter 9
tr: The first to grasp the futility of the war was Colonel Gerineldo Marquez.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was the first to perceive the emptiness of the war.

en: COLONEL GERINELDO MÁRQUEZ was the first to perceive the emptiness of the war.
vi: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was the first to perceive the futility of war.
tr: The first to grasp the futility of the war was Colonel Gerineldo Marquez.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was the first to perceive the emptiness of the war.

en: In his position as civil and military leader of Macondo he would have telegraphic conversations twice a week with Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: As the supreme commander in Macondo, he maintained regular telegraphic conversations twice a week with Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: By virtue of being in charge of the civil and military administration of Macondo, he communicated with Colonel Aureliano Buendia twice a week via telegraph.
es: In his capacity as the civil and military chief of Macondo, he held telegraphic conversations twice a week with Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: At first those exchanges would determine the course of a flesh-and-blood war, the perfectly defined outlines of which told them at any moment the exact spot -where it was and the prediction of its future direction.
vi: Initially, these exchanges confirmed the flow of the bloody conflict, where at any given moment its contours allowed for the establishment of a destination point and the projection of future directions.
tr: Initially, these communications served to determine the course of a life-and-death struggle, to report where the war was being fought at any given moment and in which direction it was progressing.
es: At the beginning, those interviews determined the course of a flesh-and-blood war whose perfectly defined contours allowed one to establish at any moment the exact point it was at, and to foresee its future directions.

en: Although he never let himself be pulled into the area of confidences, not even by his closest friends, Colonel Aureliano Buendía still had at that time the familiar tone that made it possible to identify him at the other end of the wire.
vi: Although he never allowed himself to become entangled in intimate emotional matters, even with his closest comrades, Colonel Aureliano Buendía now maintained a familiar manner of speaking that allowed the person on the other end of the line to recognize him.
tr: Although Aureliano Buendia never opened up to even his closest friends and kept his distance, he still imbued his words with a friendly meaning that identified him as the one at the other end of the wire at that time.
es: Although he never allowed himself to be drawn into confidences, not even by his closest friends, Colonel Aureliano Buendía then maintained the familiar tone that allowed him to be identified at the other end of the line.

en: Many times he would prolong the talk beyond the expected limit and let them drift into comments of a domestic nature.
vi: Many times, he extended these telegraphic conversations beyond the allotted time, letting them drift into idle chatter.
tr: He often prolonged the conversation more than necessary and maintained it in the atmosphere of a family chat.
es: Many times he prolonged the conversations beyond the scheduled end and let them drift into comments of a domestic nature.

en: Little by little, however, and as the war became more intense and widespread, his image was fading away into a universe of unreality.
vi: However, as the war expanded and intensified, his image gradually faded into a nebulous and unreal world.
tr: However, as the war intensified and spread, Colonel Aureliano Buendia's presence at the other end of the wire began to shift increasingly into an unreal realm.
es: Little by little, however, and as the war intensified and spread, his image began to fade into a universe of unreality.

en: The characteristics of his speech were more and more uncertain, and they cam together and combined to form words that were gradually losing all meaning.
vi: The clicks and clacks of his telegraph key became increasingly distant and vague, and they coalesced into words that gradually lost all meaning.
tr: The distinctive qualities of his speech became blurred, gradually turning into forms of words that had completely lost their meanings.
es: The dots and dashes of his voice became increasingly remote and uncertain, and they joined and combined to form words that gradually lost all meaning.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez limited himself then to just listening, burdened by the impression that he was in telegraphic contact with a stranger from another world.
vi: At this point, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez merely listened, feeling uncomfortable with the sensation that he was communicating via telegraph with a stranger from another world.
tr: At that point, Colonel Gerineldo Marquez began to be content with just listening, and as he listened, he felt the discomfort of talking to a stranger from another world.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez then limited himself to listening, overwhelmed by the impression of being in telegraphic contact with a stranger from another world.

en: “I understand, Aureliano,” he would conclude on the key.
vi: - I understand now, Aureliano! -
tr: Listening, listening, then clicking the manipulator, -I understand, Aureliano.
es: —Understood, Aureliano —he concluded on the manipulator—.

en: “Long live the Liberal party!”
vi: He gently pressed the manip to finish - Long live the Liberal Party!
tr: Long live the Liberal Party!
es: Long live the Liberal Party!

en: He finally lost all contact with the war.
vi: Colonel Herinendo Marquez had completely lost touch with the war.
tr: he concluded. In the end, he lost all connection to the war.
es: He ended up losing all contact with the war.

en: What in other times had been a real activity, an irresistible passion of his youth, became a remote point of reference for him: an emptiness.
vi: What had once been a practical action, an uncontrollable passion of youth, had now become for him an old story, an empty void.
tr: Once a real action, an irresistible passion of his youth, the war became a distant memory, a void for him.
es: What had once been a real activity, an irresistible passion of his youth, became for him a remote reference: a void.

en: His only refuge was Amaranta’s sewing room.
vi: The only place for him to escape that loneliness was Amaranta's sewing room.
tr: To escape this meaninglessness, he often sought refuge in Amaranta's sewing room.
es: His only refuge was Amaranta's sewing room.

en: He would visit her every afternoon.
vi: Every afternoon he would visit her.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez went to Amaranta every day.
es: He visited her every afternoon.

en: He liked to watch her hands as she curled frothy petticoat cloth in the machine that was kept in motion by Remedios the Beauty.
vi: He liked to watch her hands as she folded the fabric on the sewing machine table, while Remedios the Beauty turned the crank.
tr: Gerineldo enjoyed watching Amaranta slide the fabric for her puffy, foam-like petticoat under the foot of the sewing machine operated by Beautiful Remedios, and her hands turning and twisting the fabric.
es: He liked to watch her hands while she curled foam lace on the hand-cranked machine that Remedios the Beauty would turn.

en: They spent many hours without speaking, content with their reciprocal company, but while Amaranta was inwardly pleased in keeping the fire of his devotion alive, he was unaware of the secret designs of that indecipherable heart.
vi: For hours and hours they would be together, not saying a word. While Amaranta was content with maintaining the intense flame of his love, he could not understand the purpose of that heart.
tr: They would sit for hours without speaking, content just to be in each other's presence. However, while Amaranta secretly took pleasure in keeping Gerineldo's love aflame, Gerineldo was unaware of the hidden games in her inscrutable heart.
es: They would spend many hours without speaking, content with each other's company, but while Amaranta secretly delighted in keeping the fire of his devotion alive, he was unaware of the secret designs of that inscrutable heart.

en: When the news of his return reached her, Amaranta had been smothered by anxiety.
vi: When she learned that he would return, Amaranta felt a breathless joy.
tr: When Amaranta heard that Gerineldo had returned, she was breathless with excitement.
es: When the news of his return became known, Amaranta had been overwhelmed with anxiety.

en: But when she saw him enter the house in the middle of Colonel Aureliano Buendía’s noisy escort and she saw how he had been mistreated by the rigors of exile, made old by age and oblivion, dirty with sweat and dust, smelling like a herd, ugly, with his left arm in a sling, she felt faint with disillusionment.
vi: But when she saw him mingling with Colonel Aureliano Buendia's noisy guard as they entered the house, saw him worn out from his overseas struggles, saw him aged by time and neglect, saw him sticky with sweat mixed with road dust, smelling of animal odor, saw him unattractive with his arm immobilized in a sling, she was so disappointed she wanted to die.
tr: Yet, the moment he entered the house amidst the noisy crowd around Colonel Aureliano Buendia, and she saw how the period of exile had worn him down, aged and weakened him, made him smell foul with dirt and grime, and how his suspended left arm made him look even more unattractive, Amaranta was so disappointed that she nearly fainted.
es: But when she saw him enter the house, mingled with the noisy escort of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, and saw him battered by the harshness of exile, aged by time and forgetfulness, dirty with sweat and dust, smelling of livestock, ugly, with his left arm in a sling, she felt faint with disappointment.

en: “My God,” she thought.
vi: "Oh my God," she said, "this is not the man I had been waiting for."
tr: "Oh my God, the man I've been waiting for all this time wasn't him," she thought.
es: "My God," she thought, "this is not the one I was waiting for."

en: “This wasn’t the person I was waiting for.”
vi: "Oh my God," she said, "this is not the man I had been waiting for."
tr: "Oh my God, the man I've been waiting for all this time wasn't him," she thought.
es: "My God," she thought, "this is not the one I was waiting for."

en: On the following day, however, he came back to the house shaved and clean, with his mustache perfumed with lavender water and without the bloody sling.
vi: However, the next day, he came to the house looking more dapper: shaved and bathed, his mustache smelling of lavender, and his arm no longer in a sling.
tr: But the next day, Colonel Gerineldo Marquez came home washed and shaved, with lavender water on his mustache, and that bloody bandage removed from his arm.
es: The next day, however, he returned to the house shaved and clean, with his mustache scented with lavender water and without the bloodstained sling.

en: He brought her a prayerbook bound in mother-of-pearl.
vi: He brought her a prayer book bound in hard cover inlaid with mother-of-pearl.
tr: He also brought Amaranta a prayer book with mother-of-pearl inlay.
es: He brought her a breviary with mother-of-pearl covers.

en: “How strange men are,” she said, because she could not think of anything else to say.
vi: - Oh, how strange men are, - she said because she didn't know what else to say. -
tr: Amaranta said, "These men are so strange." She couldn't find anything else to say.
es: —How strange men are —she said, because she couldn't find anything else to say—.

en: “They spend their lives fighting against priests and then give prayerbooks as gifts.”
vi: Their whole life is a struggle against the priests, yet they go and give away religious books.
tr: They fight against priests and give their lives, and then they bring a prayer book as a gift.
es: They spend their lives fighting against priests and give away prayer books.

en: From that time on, even during the most critical days of the war, he visited her every afternoon.
vi: Since that day, even during the fiercest days of the war, he would visit her every afternoon.
tr: Gerineldo, from that day on, came to check on Amaranta every day, even during the most intense times of the war.
es: Since then, even on the most critical days of the war, he visited her every afternoon.

en: Many times, when Remedios the Beauty was not present, it was he who turned the wheel on the sewing machine.
vi: Many times he turned the wheel of the sewing machine when Remedios the Beauty was not present.
tr: When Beautiful Remedios was not around, Gerineldo would turn the machine's handle.
es: Many times, when Remedios the Beauty was not present, it was he who turned the wheel of the sewing machine.

en: Amaranta felt upset by the perseverance, the loyalty, the submissiveness of that man who was invested with so much authority and who nevertheless took off his sidearm in the living room so that he could go into the sewing room without weapons, But for four years he kept repeating his love and she would always find a way to reject him without hurting him, for even though she had not succeeded in loving him she could no longer live without him.
vi: Amaranta felt awkward in the face of his unwavering loyalty, his dedicated spirit, and the fact that this man, entrusted with many powers by her brother, would still leave his weapons in the living room when entering the sewing room. However, for four long years, he had confessed his love to her, and she had found ways to decline without causing him pain, because she did not love him, but also felt she could not live without him.
tr: Despite being granted such extraordinary privileges, the dedication, patience, and resilience of this man, who never forgot to leave his weapons in the living room to enter the sewing room unarmed, astonished Amaranta. For four years, Gerineldo tirelessly repeated that he loved her, and Amaranta always found a way to gently turn him down without hurting him. She did not want to hurt him, because even though she could not manage to love Gerineldo, she had become unable to do without him.
es: Amaranta felt disturbed by the perseverance, loyalty, and submission of that man vested with so much authority, who nevertheless disarmed himself in the living room to enter defenseless into the sewing room. But for four years he reiterated his love, and she always found a way to reject him without hurting him, because although she couldn't love him, she could no longer live without him.

en: Remedios the Beauty, who seemed indifferent to everything and who was thought to be mentally retarded, was not insensitive to so much devotion and she intervened in Colonel Gerineldo Márquez’s favor.
vi: Remedios the Beauty, who seemed indifferent to everything in life and was considered intellectually underdeveloped, did not appear so indifferent after all and showed some affection for Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.
tr: Even Beautiful Remedios, who seemed indifferent to everything and was thought to be mentally slow, could not remain indifferent in the face of such devotion and took the side of Colonel Gerineldo Marquez.
es: Remedios the Beauty, who seemed indifferent to everything and was thought to be mentally retarded, was not insensitive to such devotion and intervened in favor of Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.

en: Amaranta suddenly discovered that the girl she had raised, who was just entering adolescence, was already the most beautiful creature that had even been seen in Macondo.
vi: Amaranta immediately realized that the girl she had raised, though not yet at puberty, was already the most beautiful girl in Macondo.
tr: Amaranta suddenly realized that this girl, whom she had raised with her own hands and who had just entered her teenage years, was the most beautiful creature that had ever existed in Macondo.
es: Amaranta suddenly discovered that the girl she had raised, who was just entering adolescence, was already the most beautiful creature ever seen in Macondo.

en: She felt reborn in her heart the rancor that she had felt in other days for Rebeca, and begging God not to impel her into the extreme state of wishing her dead, she banished her from the sewing room.
vi: In her heart, she felt a resurgence of the hatred she had once harbored for Rebeca and prayed to God not to let her wish for the girl's death, so she banished her from the sewing room.
tr: He sensed that the jealousy and anger he once felt towards Rebeca were rekindling in his heart, and to prevent this feeling from escalating to the extreme of wishing for the girl's death, he prayed to God and forbade Beautiful Remedios from entering the sewing room.
es: She felt the resurgence in her heart of the resentment she once felt against Rebeca, and praying to God not to be driven to the extent of wishing her death, she banished her from the sewing room.

en: It was around that time that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez began to feel the boredom of the war.
vi: That was the period when Colonel Gerineldo Márquez began to feel a deep aversion to war.
tr: At that time, Colonel Gerineldo Marquez had begun to feel the meaninglessness and tedium of the war.
es: It was around that time that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez began to feel the weariness of the war.

en: He summoned his reserves of persuasion, his broad and repressed tenderness, ready to give up for Amaranta a glory that had cost him the sacrifice of his best years.
vi: He employed his caution, his gentle nature, ready to forsake the glory he had exchanged for the best years of his life, just to win Amaranta's heart.
tr: Ready to sacrifice the glory and honor that had cost him the best years of his youth for Amaranta's sake, he unleashed the love he had suppressed for years like a flood and tried with all his might to win over Amaranta.
es: He appealed to his reserves of persuasion, to his immense and repressed tenderness, willing to renounce for Amaranta a glory that had cost him the sacrifice of his best years.

en: But he could not succeed in convincing her.
vi: But he could not persuade her.
tr: He failed.
es: But he could not convince her.

en: One August afternoon, overcome by the unbearable weight of her own obstinacy, Amaranta locked herself in her bedroom to weep over her solitude unto death after giving her final answer to her tenacious suitor:
vi: On an August afternoon, suffering from his persistent attitude, Amaranta stayed in her bedroom to cry for the loneliness of her fate, after having resolutely rejected his steadfast heart:
tr: One August day, Amaranta gave her patient suitor her final and definitive answer, -Let's forget about each other.
es: One August afternoon, overwhelmed by the unbearable weight of her own obstinacy, Amaranta locked herself in the bedroom to cry her loneliness to death, after giving her persistent suitor the final answer.

en: “Let’s forget about each other forever,” she told him.
vi: - Let's forget each other forever, - she said to him, - because we have missed our chance.
tr: One August day, Amaranta gave her patient suitor her final and definitive answer, -Let's forget about each other.
es: —Let's forget about each other forever —he said to her—, we are too old for these things now.

en: “We’re too old for this sort of thing now.”
vi: - Let's forget each other forever, - she said to him, - because we have missed our chance.
tr: Such things are beyond us now, she said, and after giving her final and definitive answer, she shut herself in her room to be crushed under the unbearable weight of her own stubbornness and to weep for the loneliness that would last until her death.
es: —Let's forget about each other forever —he said to her—, we are too old for these things now.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez had a telegraphic call from Colonel Aureliano Buendía that afternoon.
vi: That afternoon, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez hurriedly came in response to Colonel Aureliano Buendía's telegram.
tr: That day Colonel Aureliano Buendia contacted Colonel Gerineldo Marquez by telegraph.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez attended that afternoon to a telegraphic call from Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: It was a routine conversation which was not going to bring about any break in the stagnant war.
vi: It was a routine conversation that did not alter the stagnant war.
tr: It was one of those daily conversations that wouldn't affect the ongoing war.
es: It was a routine conversation that would not open any breach in the stagnant war.

en: At the end, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez looked at the desolate streets, the crystal water on the almond trees, and he found himself lost in solitude.
vi: At the end, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez gazed at the desolate streets, the crystal-like drops of water on the almond tree leaves, and then he lost himself in loneliness.
tr: At the end of the conversation, Colonel Gerineldo Marquez looked at the deserted streets, the crystallized roofs of the almond tree, and saw himself lost in loneliness.
es: At the end, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez contemplated the desolate streets, the crystallized water on the almond trees, and found himself lost in solitude.

en: “Aureliano,” he said sadly on the key, “it’s raining in Macondo.”
vi: - Aureliano, - he said sadly through the telegraph - it's raining in Macondo!
tr: Pressing the manipulator, -Aureliano said. -It's raining in Macondo.
es: —Aureliano —he said sadly on the manipulator—, it's raining in Macondo.

en: There was a long silence on the line.
vi: There was a long silence on the line.
tr: There was no response for a long time.
es: There was a long silence on the line.

en: Suddenly the apparatus jumped with the pitiless letters from Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: Suddenly, the machine emitted the irritated clicks and clacks of Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
tr: Then the ruthless words of Colonel Aureliano Buendia began to shake the machine.
es: Suddenly, the devices jumped with the ruthless signs of Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: “Don’t be a jackass, Gerineldo,” the signals said.
vi: - Don't be so absent-minded, Herinendo, - the signals said.
tr: "Don't be foolish, Gerineldo," said the walrus, "What could be more natural than rain in August!"
es: —Don't be an idiot, Gerineldo —said the signs—.

en: “It’s natural for it to be raining in August.”
vi: - Of course it rains in August.
tr: "Don't be foolish, Gerineldo," said the walrus, "What could be more natural than rain in August!"
es: It's natural for it to be raining in August.

en: They had not seen each other for such a long time that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was upset by the aggressiveness of the reaction.
vi: It had been a long time since the two had seen each other, to the point that Colonel Herinendo Márquez was surprised by such a provocative reaction.
tr: It had been so long since they had seen each other that Colonel Gerineldo Marquez was surprised by the severity of Aureliano's reaction.
es: They had gone so long without seeing each other that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was taken aback by the aggressiveness of that reaction.

en: Two months later, however, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía returned to Macondo, his upset was changed to stupefaction.
vi: However, two months later, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía returned to Macondo, that surprise turned into a joy that left him stunned.
tr: When Colonel Aureliano Buendia returned to Macondo two months later, Gerineldo's surprise turned into bewilderment. The change in Aureliano even astonished Ursula.
es: However, two months later, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía returned to Macondo, the bewilderment turned into astonishment.

en: Even Úrsula was surprised at how much he had changed.
vi: Even Úrsula was astonished to see how much he had changed.
tr: He came quietly, without any mockery or ceremony.
es: Even Úrsula was surprised at how much he had changed.

en: He came with no noise, no escort, wrapped in a cloak in spite of the heat, and with three mistresses, whom he installed in the same house, where he spent most of his time lying in a hammock.
vi: Hiding himself in an overcoat despite the sweltering heat, he quietly returned without any bodyguards, bringing along three female spirits. He let them stay with him in one house, while he lay on a hammock almost all day.
tr: Despite the heat, he was tightly wrapped in his cloak. He had three mistresses with him. He placed all three women in the same house, and he himself rarely left the hammock.
es: He arrived quietly, without an escort, wrapped in a blanket despite the heat, and with three lovers whom he installed in the same house, where he spent most of his time lying in a hammock.

en: He scarcely read the telegraphic dispatches that reported routine operations.
vi: He hardly read the daily telegrams reporting the war situation.
tr: He wasn't even properly reading the telegrams reporting the daily operations.
es: He barely read the telegraphic dispatches that reported routine operations.

en: On one occasion Colonel Gerineldo Márquez asked him for instructions for the evacuation of a spot on the border where there was a danger that the conflict would become an international affair.
vi: Once, Colonel Herinendo Marquez asked him for instructions to resolve an issue that was becoming increasingly troublesome in international relations at a border location, and he replied:
tr: One day, Colonel Gerineldo Marquez requested orders about whether to withdraw from a border region, which could lead to the conflict taking on an international dimension.
es: On one occasion, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez asked him for instructions on the evacuation of a border town that threatened to become an international conflict.

en: “Don’t bother me with trifles,” he ordered him.
vi: - Do not bother me with these trivial matters, - he ordered the colonel.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia commanded, "Do not bother me with trivial matters."
es: —Don't bother me with trivialities —he ordered—.

en: “Consult Divine Providence.”
vi: - Go ask that Almighty.
tr: "Ask God what you should do."
es: Consult it with Divine Providence.

en: It was perhaps the most critical moment of the war.
vi: Perhaps that was the most stressful phase of the war.
tr: This was perhaps the most critical moment of the war.
es: It was perhaps the most critical moment of the war.

en: The Liberal landowners, who had supported the revolution in the beginning, had made secret alliances with the Conservative landowners in order to stop the revision of property titles.
vi: The landlords of the Liberal faction, who had supported the revolution from the beginning, secretly allied with the Royalist landlords to halt the land reform.
tr: The Liberal landowners, who had initially supported the revolution, had made secret agreements with the Conservative landowners to prevent the re-examination of land registry records.
es: The liberal landowners, who initially supported the revolution, had entered into secret alliances with the conservative landowners to prevent the review of property titles.

en: The politicians who supplied funds for the war from exile had Publicly repudiated the drastic aims of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, but even that withdrawal of authorization did not seem to bother him.
vi: The politicians who had funded the war, even from abroad, openly opposed his bold decisions. But he ignored everything, even this deposition of power.
tr: The exiled politicians who provided financial aid to the fighters announced to the public that all of Colonel Aureliano Buendia's powers had been taken away. But the colonel didn't care about authority at all.
es: The politicians who were capitalizing on the war from exile had publicly repudiated the drastic determinations of Colonel Aureliano Buendía, but even that disavowal seemed not to concern him.

en: He had not returned to reading his poetry, which filled more than five volumes and lay forgotten at the bottom of his trunk.
vi: He did not reread his poems, now five volumes thick and often forgotten at the bottom of a trunk.
tr: He never even picked up his poems, which filled five large notebooks and had been forgotten at the bottom of a chest.
es: He had not returned to reading his verses, which occupied more than five volumes and remained forgotten at the bottom of the trunk.

en: At night or at siesta time he would call one of his women to his hammock and obtain a rudimentary satisfaction from her, and then he would sleep like a stone that was not concerned by the slightest indication of worry.
vi: At night or during siesta time, as usual, he would call a mistress to the hammock to frolic with her and then fall asleep like a dead ox, oblivious to the world.
tr: At night or when he took a nap, he would call one of the women to his hammock, and after reaching a superficial, primal satisfaction with her, he would collapse like a log and sleep. He was like a stone that neither sorrow nor worry ever touched.
es: At night, or during siesta time, he would call one of his women to the hammock and obtain from her a rudimentary satisfaction, and then he would sleep with a stone-like slumber that was not disturbed by the slightest hint of worry.

en: Only he knew at that time that his confused heart was condemned to uncertainty forever.
vi: At that moment, only he understood that his passionate heart had been permanently exiled to chaos.
tr: Only in those days did he know that he was doomed to struggle to the end with his heart turned into a tangled mess.
es: Only he knew then that his bewildered heart was forever condemned to uncertainty.

en: At first, intoxicated by the glory of his return, by his remarkable victories, he had peeped into the abyss of greatness.
vi: Initially, intoxicated by the victories, returning amidst such obvious triumphs, he had ascended to the pinnacle of glory.
tr: Initially, he had been dizzy with the glorious air of his return and the considerable victories he had won, coming right to the edge of the abyss of greatness.
es: At the beginning, intoxicated by the glory of his return, by the unbelievable victories, he had peered into the abyss of greatness.

en: He took pleasure in keeping by his right hand the Duke of Marlborough, his great teacher in the art of war, whose attire of skins and tiger claws aroused the respect of adults and the awe of children.
vi: He was content to cling tightly to Duke Marlborough, his great master in the art of war, who wore a tiger-skin coat with intact sharp claws that commanded respect from adults and fear from children.
tr: With his animal hide clothing and tiger claw ornaments, the Duke of Marlborough, a great master of the art of war who terrified the young and was feared by the old, was Aureliano's right-hand man. He enjoyed having him constantly by his side.
es: He took pleasure in keeping the Duke of Marlborough, his great master in the arts of war, at his right hand, whose attire of furs and tiger claws elicited the respect of adults and the astonishment of children.

en: It was then that he decided that no human being, not even Úrsula, could come closer to him than ten feet.
vi: That was when he decided that no one, not even Ursula, could come within three meters of him.
tr: At that time, Ursula decided that no human being, including herself, should come closer than three meters to him.
es: It was then that he decided that no human being, not even Úrsula, should approach him within three meters.

en: In the center of the chalk circle that his aides would draw wherever he stopped, and which only he could enter, he would decide with brief orders that had no appeal the fate of the world.
vi: With short and decisive commands, he determined the fate of the world from the center of a circle drawn with white chalk by his attendants wherever he went, and only he stepped inside.
tr: Wherever he stood, those around him would immediately run and draw a circle with chalk, and Colonel Aureliano Buendia would step into the center of this circle, which no one else could enter, and issue commands that led nowhere regarding the fate of the world.
es: In the center of the chalk circle that his aides would draw wherever he arrived, and into which only he could enter, he would decide the fate of the world with brief and unappealable orders.

en: The first time that he was in Manaure after the shooting of General Moncada, he hastened to fulfill his victim’s last wish and the widow took the glasses, the medal, the watch, and the ring, but she would not let him in the door.
vi: For the first time in Manaure, after executing General Moncada, he hastily fulfilled his victim's last wish. The widow accepted the glasses, medals, watch, and wedding ring but did not allow him to step through the door.
tr: After the execution of General Moncada, during his first visit to Manaure, Aureliano had rushed to the general's house to fulfill his will. The general's widow took his glasses, medal, watch, and ring, but did not let Aureliano step inside the threshold.
es: The first time he was in Manaure after the execution of General Moncada, he hastened to fulfill his victim's last wish, and the widow received the glasses, the medal, the watch, and the ring, but she did not allow him to go beyond the door.

en: “You can’t come in, colonel,” she told him.
vi: - Colonel, you shouldn't enter the house, - she said.
tr: "You cannot enter, Colonel," he said.
es: —Don't come in, Colonel —he said to him—.

en: “You may be in command of your war, but I’m in command of my house.”
vi: - You manage the battlefield, and I, I manage my own home.
tr: "Maybe you command in the war, but in my house, my word is law."
es: You may command in your war, but I command in my house.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not show any sign of anger, but his spirit only calmed down when his bodyguard had sacked the widow’s house and reduced it to ashes.
vi: Although Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not show his anger outwardly, his mind was only at ease when he knew that his entourage had looted and burned the widow's house to ashes.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia never showed his anger, but his rage only subsided after the guards looted the house and turned it into a heap of ashes.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía showed no signs of resentment, but his spirit only found peace when his personal guard looted and burned the widow's house to ashes.

en: “Watch out for your heart, Aureliano,” Colonel Gerineldo Márquez would say to him then.
vi: "Please take care of your heart, Aureliano," Colonel Gerineldo Márquez said to him at that time.
tr: Colonel Marquez said, "Watch your heart, Aureliano, you're decaying before you die."
es: "Take care of your heart, Aureliano," Colonel Gerineldo Márquez would say to him then.

en: “You’re rotting alive.”
vi: "You are rotting while still alive."
tr: Colonel Marquez said, "Watch your heart, Aureliano, you're decaying before you die."
es: "You're rotting alive."

en: About that time he called together a second assembly of the principal rebel commanders.
vi: At this time, he organized the second conference of the rebel generals ready to die.
tr: In those days, Colonel Aureliano Buendia called a second meeting of the leading rebel commanders.
es: During that time, he convened a second assembly of the main rebel commanders.

en: He found all types: idealists, ambitious people, adventurers, those with social resentments, even common criminals.
vi: He met with everyone: the idealists, the ambitious ones, the adventurers, those with deep personal grudges, and even the thieves.
tr: All kinds of people attended this meeting: idealists, those blinded by ambition, thrill-seekers, social misfits, even common criminals.
es: He found all sorts: idealists, ambitious men, adventurers, social resentfuls, and even common criminals.

en: There was even a former Conservative functionary who had taken refuge in the revolt to escape a judgment for misappropriation of funds.
vi: There was also a Royalist official who had fled the court for embezzling public funds.
tr: Among them was even a former Conservative official who had taken refuge in rebellion to escape trial for embezzlement.
es: There was even a former conservative official who had taken refuge in the revolt to escape a trial for embezzlement.

en: Many of them did not even know why they were fighting in the midst of that motley crowd, whose differences of values were on the verge of causing an internal explosion, one gloomy authority stood out: General Te6filo Vargas.
vi: A lot of people know nothing, including why they are fighting. In the chaotic scene of the crowd, where differences in political views almost caused an internal explosion, a formidable force stood out: General Teófilo Vargas.
tr: Most of them didn't even know why they were fighting. In this colorful group, driven to the brink of internal explosion due to differences in values, one authority stood out: General Teofilo Vargas.
es: Many didn't even know why they were fighting. Amid that motley crowd, whose differences in opinion were on the verge of causing an internal explosion, a sinister authority stood out: General Teófilo Vargas.

en: He was a full-blooded Indian, untamed, illiterate, and endowed with quiet wiles and a messianic vocation that aroused a demented fanaticism in his men.
vi: He was a pure-blooded Indian, rough, illiterate, but possessed a hidden cunning and had the talent to use the magic of Asia Minor to bind his soldiers in a kind of mad fanaticism.
tr: General, an illiterate, uncultured, and unrefined man who blindly convinced his followers, deceiving them into believing that God had given him duties, was a pure-blooded Indian.
es: He was a pure, wild, illiterate Indian, endowed with a taciturn malice and a messianic vocation that incited a mad fanaticism in his men.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía called the meeting with the aim of unifying the rebel command against the maneuvers of the politicians.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía convened a conference with the aim of consolidating the command of the insurgent forces into his own hands to counter the maneuvers of the politicians.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia had gathered the rebel commanders to unite against the maneuvers of the politicians.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía organized the meeting with the purpose of unifying the rebel command against the maneuvers of the politicians.

en: General Teófilo Vargas came forward with his intentions: in a few hours he shattered the coalition of better-qualified commanders and took charge of the main command.
vi: General Theophilo Vachat had anticipated his plans: In a few hours, he managed to break the unity of some of the most famous commanders and jumped to take overall command.
tr: General Teofilo Vargas revealed his own intentions and within a few hours, dismantled the coalition of qualified commanders and took command.
es: General Teófilo Vargas preempted his intentions: in a few hours, he dismantled the coalition of the best-qualified commanders and seized central command.

en: “He’s a wild beast worth watching,” Colonel Aureliano Buendía told his officers.
vi: "That is a fierce beast to be wary of," he told his subordinate officers.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia said to his officers, "This is a wild animal we must never take our eyes off."
es: "He's a beast to be wary of," Colonel Aureliano Buendía told his officers.

en: “That man is more dangerous to us than the Minister of War.”
vi: "For us, that man is even more dangerous than the Minister of Defense."
tr: "This man is more dangerous to us than the Minister of Defense."
es: "For us, that man is more dangerous than the Minister of War."

en: Then a very young captain who had always been outstanding for his timidity raised a cautious index finger.
vi: In the midst of that moment, a young captain, who often stood out from others due to his sentimental nature, cautiously raised his hand.
tr: Upon hearing this, a young captain, known for his timidity, nervously raised his finger.
es: Then a very young captain, who had always been distinguished by his shyness, raised a cautious index finger.

en: “It’s quite simple, colonel,” he proposed.
vi: - Colonel, it's really too easy, - the young captain said probing.
tr: "It's simple, Colonel," he said.
es: —It's very simple, Colonel —he proposed—: we have to kill him.

en: “He has to be killed.”
vi: - Just kill him and be done with it!
tr: "Let's kill this man."
es: —It's very simple, Colonel —he proposed—: we have to kill him.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was not alarmed by the coldness of the proposition but by the way in which, by a fraction of a second, it had anticipated his own thoughts.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was not surprised by the cold nature of the proposal that was made, but rather he was surprised by the manner in which a minor element had anticipated his own thoughts.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia was not surprised by the coldness of the proposal, but he was annoyed that it had been made just a second before he could make it himself.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was not alarmed by the coldness of the proposition, but by the way it anticipated a fraction of a second ahead of his own thought.

en: “Don’t expect me to give an order like that,” he said.
vi: - Don't wait for me to give that order, - he said.
tr: "Don't expect me to give such an order," he said.
es: —Don't expect me to give that order —he said.

en: He did not give it, as a matter of fact.
vi: Indeed, he did not give the order.
tr: To be honest, he didn't give such an order.
es: He did not give it, indeed.

en: But two weeks later General Teófilo Vargas was cut to bits by machetes in an ambush and Colonel Aureliano Buendía assumed the main command.
vi: But fifteen days later, General Teófilo Vargas was hacked to pieces in a sudden ambush, and Colonel Aureliano Buendía took over as the overall commander.
tr: However, two weeks later, General Teofilo Vargas, who had fallen into an ambush, was torn to pieces with machetes, and Colonel Aureliano Buendia assumed the position of commander-in-chief.
es: But fifteen days later, General Teófilo Vargas was hacked to pieces with machetes in an ambush, and Colonel Aureliano Buendía assumed central command.

en: The same night that his authority was recognized by all the rebel commands, he woke up in a fright, calling for a blanket.
vi: It was on the night his new position was acknowledged by all the rebel commanders that he suddenly woke up in a panic, screaming for someone to bring him an overcoat.
tr: The night when all the rebel commanders recognized him as the commander-in-chief, Colonel Aureliano Buendia woke up in fear and asked for a blanket.
es: The same night his authority was recognized by all the rebel commands, he woke up startled, shouting for a blanket.

en: An inner coldness which shattered his bones and tortured him even in the heat of the sun would not let him sleep for several months, until it became a habit.
vi: An internal cold that pierced to the bone made him ache, and even at noon, it did not leave him in peace. This condition lasted for several months until he developed chronic insomnia.
tr: The coldness that enveloped him made his bones shiver, freezing him to the core even under the scorching sun. Because of this chill, he couldn't sleep for several months; then the chill became a habit.
es: An internal cold that reached his bones and tormented him even in broad daylight prevented him from sleeping well for several months, until it became a habit.

en: The intoxication of power began to break apart under waves of discomfort.
vi: The dream of power began to crumble piece by piece.
tr: The intoxication of power began to dissipate with waves of unease.
es: The intoxication of power began to decompose into bursts of unease.

en: Searching for a cure against the chill, he had the young officer who had proposed the murder of General Teófilo Vargas shot.
vi: In an attempt to quell the internal chill, he ordered the execution of the young officer who had suggested killing General Teófilo Vargas.
tr: Aureliano had a young officer who suggested the killing of General Teofilo Vargas executed, thinking it might help with his chill.
es: Seeking a remedy for the cold, he had the young officer who proposed the assassination of General Teófilo Vargas executed by firing squad.

en: His orders were being carried out even before they were given, even before he thought of them, and they always went much beyond what he would have dared have them do.
vi: His orders were carried out before they were issued, often even before he intended them, and frequently exceeded what he dared to wish for.
tr: Aureliano's orders were carried out before they even left his mouth, even before he himself had thought them through, and were taken to extremes he wouldn't dare to reach.
es: His orders were carried out before being given, even before he conceived them, and they always reached much further than he would have dared to send them.

en: Lost in the solitude of his immense power, he began to lose direction.
vi: Lost in the loneliness of boundless power, he began to lose his bearings.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia sank into the solitude of unapproachable power and began to lose awareness of his actions.
es: Lost in the solitude of his immense power, he began to lose his way.

en: He was bothered by the people who cheered him in neighboring villages, and he imagined that they were the same cheers they gave the enemy.
vi: He was irritated by the people in the occupied villages who cheered him, feeling that they were the same people who had cheered his enemies.
tr: He was disturbed by the enthusiastic receptions in neighboring villages, suspecting that the villagers were showing the same enthusiasm to the enemy side.
es: He was annoyed by the people who acclaimed him in the conquered towns, who seemed to him the same people who acclaimed the enemy.

en: Everywhere he met adolescents who looked at him with his own eyes, who spoke to him with his own voice, who greeted him with the same mistrust with which he greeted them, and who said they were his sons.
vi: Everywhere he went, he encountered young men who looked at him with his own eyes, spoke with his own voice, greeted him with the same suspicion with which he had greeted them, and all claimed to be his sons.
tr: Wherever he went, he encountered a multitude of young men who looked at him with his own eyes, spoke with his own voice, shared the distrust he felt towards them, and claimed to be his sons.
es: Everywhere he found adolescents who looked at him with his own eyes, who spoke with his own voice, who greeted him with the same distrust with which he greeted them, and who claimed to be his children.

en: He felt scattered about, multiplied, and more solitary than ever.
vi: He felt fragmented, repeated, and lonelier than ever.
tr: Aureliano found himself scattered and multiplied, sinking into utter loneliness.
es: He felt scattered, repeated, and more solitary than ever.

en: He was convinced that his own officers were lying to him.
vi: He realized that his own officers had deceived him.
tr: He began to believe that even his own officers were lying to him.
es: He was convinced that his own officers were lying to him.

en: He fought with the Duke of Marlborough.
vi: He fought with Duke Marlborough.
tr: He clashed with the Duke of Marlborough.
es: He quarreled with the Duke of Marlborough.

en: “The best friend a person has,” he would say at that time, “is one who has just died.”
vi: "The best friend," he often told himself, "is the one who has just died."
tr: He used to say that a man's best friend is a dead friend.
es: "The best friend," he used to say then, "is the one who has just died."

en: He was weary of the uncertainty, of the vicious circle of that eternal war that always found him in the same place, but always older, wearier, even more in the position of not knowing why, or how, or even when.
vi: He was exhausted by the ambiguous circumstances, by the vicious cycle of that prolonged war in which he always found himself at the same place, only growing older and weaker without knowing why, how, or until when.
tr: He was exhausted and worn out by the endless, futile cycle of war that always caught him in the same place, but each time a little older, a little more tired, and a little less aware of the reasons, the causes, or even the timing of events.
es: He grew tired of the uncertainty, the vicious circle of that eternal war that always found him in the same place, only each time older, more worn out, more without knowing why, or how, or until when.

en: There was always someone outside of the chalk circle.
vi: There was always someone standing outside the white chalk circle.
tr: There was always someone outside the chalk circle.
es: There was always someone outside the chalk circle.

en: Someone who needed money, someone who had a son with whooping cough, or someone who wanted to go off and sleep forever because he could not stand the shit taste of the war in his mouth and who, nevertheless, stood at attention to inform him: “Everything normal, colonel.”
vi: It was the person demanding money from him, the one with a child suffering from whooping cough, or the one who wanted to sleep forever because they could no longer endure the taste of war's filth in their mouth, and yet still tried to stand at attention to report: "Colonel, everything is normal, sir."
tr: It was someone without money, someone whose son had caught whooping cough, or someone who just couldn't stand eating the shit of war anymore and wanted to leave and sleep forever. Moreover, they would stand at attention in front of him as if nothing had happened, saying, "Everything is normal, Colonel."
es: Someone who needed money, who had a child with whooping cough, or who wanted to go to sleep forever because they could no longer bear the taste of war in their mouth, and who, nevertheless, stood at attention with their last reserves of energy to report: "All normal, my colonel."

en: And normality was precisely the most fearful part of that infinite war: nothing ever happened.
vi: And it was precisely that normalcy, which meant nothing was happening, that was the most terrifying aspect of the brutal war.
tr: The most terrifying aspect of that endless war was precisely this normalcy; nothing was happening.
es: And normality was precisely the most horrifying thing about that infinite war: that nothing happened.

en: Alone, abandoned by his premonitions, fleeing the chill that was to accompany him until death, he sought a last refuge in Macondo in the warmth of his oldest memories.
vi: Abandoned by omens and to escape the cold that would chase him to his death, he sought the only refuge in the village of Macondo, in the warmth of those distant memories.
tr: Aureliano, a man who had been abandoned by his premonitions and was trying to escape a chill that would never leave him until his death, sought his last resort in Macondo, in the warmth of old memories.
es: Alone, abandoned by omens, fleeing from the cold that would accompany him until death, he sought a last refuge in Macondo, in the warmth of his oldest memories.

en: His indolence was so serious that when they announced the arrival of a commission from his party that was authorized to discuss the stalemate of the war, he rolled over in his hammock without completely waking up.
vi: His laziness was so extreme that when informed of a party delegation coming to discuss a ceasefire, he merely stirred in his hammock without waking up.
tr: He had become so indifferent that even when he heard that the authorized commission members had arrived for negotiations to stop the war, he merely turned over in his hammock without fully waking up.
es: His apathy was so severe that when he was informed of the arrival of a commission from his party authorized to discuss the crossroads of the war, he turned over in the hammock without fully waking up.

en: “Take them to the whores,” he said.
vi: - Take them to the brothel, - he said.
tr: -Take them to the whores, he said.
es: —Take them to the whores —he said.

en: They were six lawyers in frock coats and top hats who endured the violent November sun with stiff stoicism.
vi: There were six lawyers in tailcoats and felt hats trying to endure the oppressive heat of a scorching November.
tr: The commission members were six lawyers in tailcoats and top hats, enduring the scorching November sun with great indifference and seriousness.
es: They were six lawyers in frock coats and top hats who endured the fierce November sun with hard stoicism.

en: Úrsula put them up in her house.
vi: Ursula let them stay right in her house.
tr: Ursula hosted them in her own home.
es: Úrsula hosted them in the house.

en: They spent the greater part of the day closeted in the bedroom in hermetic conferences and at dusk they asked for an escort and some accordion players and took over Catarino’s store.
vi: Most of the day, they stayed locked in the bedroom to secretly discuss matters. In the evening, they demanded a guard of soldiers and a group of accordion players, then they went to Catarino's store on their own.
tr: Almost all day, they sat in the bedroom and talked secretly; in the late afternoon, they took a woman each and a few accordion players with them and closed down Catarino's shop.
es: They spent most of the day locked in the bedroom in hermetic consultations, and at nightfall, they would ask for an escort and a set of accordions and take over Catarino's store.

en: “Leave them alone,” Colonel Aureliano Buendía ordered.
vi: "Don't bother them," Colonel Aureliano Buendía instructed.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia said, "Don't interfere with their pleasures."
es: "Do not bother them," ordered Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: “After all, I know what they want.”
vi: "I already know what they want."
tr: -You see, I am the one who knows what they want again.
es: "After all, I know what they want."

en: At the beginning of December the long-awaited interview, which many had foreseen as an interminable argument, was resolved in less than an hour.
vi: At the beginning of December, the long-awaited discussion, predicted to be an endless debate, took place in less than an hour.
tr: In early December, the long-awaited meeting, which many thought would lead to intractable debates, concluded in less than an hour.
es: At the beginning of December, the long-awaited interview, which many had predicted would be an endless discussion, was resolved in less than an hour.

en: In the hot parlor, beside the specter of the pianola shrouded in a white sheet, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not sit down that time inside the chalk circle that his aides had drawn.
vi: In the stifling living room, next to the automatic piano covered by a white cloth, this time Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not sit in the center of the white chalk circle drawn by his entourage.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia did not sit inside the chalk circle drawn by his aides, next to the ghost of the lantern covered with white sheets, in the oven-like heated room.
es: In the hot visiting room, next to the specter of the player piano shrouded with a white sheet, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not sit this time within the chalk circle drawn by his aides.

en: He sat in a chair between his political advisers and, wrapped in his woolen blanket, he listened in silence to the brief proposals of the emissaries.
vi: He sat on a chair among his political advisors. Wrapped in a wool coat, he quietly listened to the brief proposals of the special envoys.
tr: Wrapping himself in his wool blanket, he sat on the chair among his political advisors and listened to the proposals of the envoys.
es: He took a seat among his political advisors, and wrapped in the wool blanket, he listened in silence to the brief proposals of the emissaries.

en: They asked first that he renounce the revision of property titles in order to get back the support of the Liberal landowners.
vi: First, they proposed to abandon the inspection of land titles to regain the support of the Liberal landowners.
tr: First, they wanted him to stop tampering with the land registry records to regain the support of the Liberal landowners.
es: They asked, first and foremost, to renounce the review of land ownership titles to regain the support of the liberal landowners.

en: They asked, secondly, that he renounce the fight against clerical influence in order to obtain the support of the Catholic masses.
vi: Then they proposed to give up the fight against the influence of the church to win the favor of the parishioners.
tr: Then, to secure the support of the Catholic masses, they wanted him to stop meddling with the influence of the clergy.
es: They asked, secondly, to renounce the fight against clerical influence to obtain the backing of the Catholic populace.

en: They asked, finally, that he renounce the aim of equal rights for natural and illegitimate children in order to preserve the integrity of the home.
