vi: Finally, they proposed to abandon the ideal of equality of rights between illegitimate and legitimate children to preserve the hierarchy within the family.
tr: Finally, to preserve family integrity, they wanted him to abandon the aim of granting equal rights to children born out of wedlock.
es: They asked, finally, to renounce the aspirations for equal rights between natural and legitimate children to preserve the integrity of households.

en: “That means,” Colonel Aureliano Buendía said, smiling when the reading was over, “that all we’re fighting for is power.”
vi: - It means, - Colonel Aureliano Buendía smiled as the messengers stopped reading, - we are fighting just to seize power.
tr: When the requests were read and finished, Colonel Aureliano Buendia smiled. "So, he said, "we are fighting only for power."
es: —It means —smiled Colonel Aureliano Buendía when he finished reading— that we are only fighting for power.

en: “They’re tactical changes,” one of the delegates replied.
vi: - Those are just temporary reforms, - a delegate retorted.
tr: One of the delegates interjected, -These changes are for tactical reasons.
es: —They are tactical reforms —replied one of the delegates—.

en: “Right now the main thing is to broaden the popular base of the war.
vi: - Now more than ever, the fundamental thing is to expand the popular base of the struggle.
tr: -The important thing right now is to broaden the base of the war that relies on the people.
es: For now, the essential thing is to broaden the popular base of the war.

en: Then we’ll have another look.”
vi: After that, we will review it.
tr: Then, we will revisit these matters.
es: We will see afterwards.

en: One of Colonel Aureliano Buendía’s political advisers hastened to intervene.
vi: A political advisor of Colonel Aureliano Buendía hurriedly joined the debate.
tr: One of Colonel Aureliano Buendía's political advisors couldn't stand it and interrupted the man.
es: One of Colonel Aureliano Buendía's political advisors hurried to intervene.

en: “It’s a contradiction” he said.
vi: A political advisor of Colonel Aureliano Buendía hurriedly joined the debate.
tr: "There is a contradiction here," he said.
es: —It is a contradiction —he said—.

en: “If these changes are good, it means that the Conservative regime is good.
vi: - What nonsense, - he said, - if these reforms are correct, it means that the Monarchy is good.
tr: "If these changes are beneficial and appropriate, then the Conservative regime must also be good."
es: If these reforms are good, it means that the conservative regime is good.

en: If we succeed in broadening the popular base of the war with them, as you people say, it means that the regime his a broad popular base.
vi: If with these reforms we can broaden the popular base of the war, it means that the Monarchy has a broad popular base.
tr: "As you said, if we are going to expand the grassroots base of the war with these changes, it means that the Conservative regime is based on a broad popular foundation."
es: If with them we will manage to broaden the popular base of the war, as you say, it means that the regime has a wide popular base.

en: It means, in short, that for almost twenty years we’ve been fighting against the sentiments of the nation.”
vi: And overall, it means that for nearly twenty years we have been fighting against the conscience of our nation.
tr: "In short, it means that we have been fighting against the feelings of the people for nearly twenty years."
es: It means, in summary, that for almost twenty years we have been fighting against the sentiments of the nation.

en: He was going to go on, but Colonel Aureliano Buendía stopped him with a signal.
vi: He was about to continue speaking, but Colonel Aureliano Buendía signaled him to stop.
tr: He was about to continue speaking, but Colonel Aureliano Buendia silenced him with a gesture.
es: He was going to continue, but Colonel Aureliano Buendía interrupted him with a gesture.

en: “Don’t waste your time, doctor.” he said.
vi: "Please, doctor, don't waste time," he said.
tr: -Don't waste your time, doctor.
es: "Don't waste your time, doctor," he said.

en: “The important thing is that from now on we’ll be fighting only for power.”
vi: "What is of significant importance is that from now on, we fight with the sole purpose of seizing power."
tr: "What matters is that from now on, we will fight to seize power," he said with a smile, took the documents extended by the delegates, and prepared to sign them.
es: "The important thing is that from this moment on, we only fight for power."

en: Still smiling, he took the documents the delegates gave him and made ready to sign them.
vi: He continued to smile, took the papers handed to him by the messengers, and prepared to sign them.
tr: "What matters is that from now on, we will fight to seize power," he said with a smile, took the documents extended by the delegates, and prepared to sign them.
es: Without stopping his smile, he took the documents handed to him by the delegates and prepared to sign.

en: “Since that’s the way it is,” he concluded, “we have no objection to accepting.”
vi: - In times of change, one must adapt, - he concluded, - we completely accept that.
tr: "Since that's the case, we see no harm in accepting it," he concluded.
es: —Since that is the case —he concluded—, we have no objection to accepting.

en: His men looked at one another in consternation.
vi: The people on his side looked at each other in astonishment.
tr: The men looked at each other in astonishment.
es: His men looked at each other in dismay.

en: “Excuse me, colonel,” Colonel Gerineldo Márquez said softly, “but this is a betrayal.”
vi: - Please forgive me, Colonel, - Colonel Herinendo Marquez said softly - Is that a betrayal?
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia held the ink pen in the air and unleashed the full weight of his authority on Colonel Gerinaldo Marquez.
es: —Excuse me, Colonel —said Colonel Gerineldo Márquez softly—, but this is a betrayal.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía held the inked pen in the air and discharged the whole weight of his authority on him.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía paused his ink-dipped pen in mid-air and unleashed the full weight of his authority on Colonel Gerineldo Márquez:
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia held the ink pen in the air and unleashed the full weight of his authority on Colonel Gerinaldo Marquez.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía halted the inked pen in mid-air and unleashed the full weight of his authority upon him.

en: “Surrender your weapons,” he ordered.
vi: - Hand over your weapons to me, - he commanded.
tr: "Surrender your weapons," he commanded.
es: —Hand over your weapons —he ordered.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez stood up and put his sidearms on the table.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía stood up, placing his weapon on the table.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez stood up and placed his weapons on the table.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez stood up and placed the weapons on the table.

en: “Report to the barracks,” Colonel Aureliano Buendía ordered him.
vi: - Report to the barracks, - Colonel Aureliano Buendía ordered him.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia said, "Go to the barracks and stand before the revolutionary court."
es: —Present yourself at the barracks —ordered Colonel Aureliano Buendía—.

en: “Put yourself at the disposition of the revolutionary court.”
vi: - You will be subject to the judgment of the revolutionary court.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia said, "Go to the barracks and stand before the revolutionary court."
es: You are at the disposal of the revolutionary courts.

en: Then he signed the declaration and gave the sheets of paper to the emissaries, saying to them:
vi: Then he signed the declaration, handed the documents to the envoys, and said to them:
tr: Then, he signed the agreement and handed the papers to the envoys.
es: Then he signed the declaration and handed the documents to the emissaries, saying to them:

en: “Here an your papers, gentlemen.
vi: - Gentlemen, you already have all your documents there.
tr: "Here are your papers, gentlemen," he said.
es: —Gentlemen, here are your papers.

en: I hope you can get some advantage out of them.”
vi: Please enjoy them.
tr: "I hope you can achieve something with these."
es: Make good use of them.

en: Two days later, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, accused of high treason, was condemned to death.
vi: Two days later, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez was accused of being a traitor and sentenced to death.
tr: Two days later, Colonel Gerinaldo Marquez, who was being tried for treason, was sentenced to death.
es: Two days later, Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, accused of high treason, was sentenced to death.

en: Lying in his hammock, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was insensible to the pleas for clemency.
vi: Lying in his hammock, Colonel Aureliano Buendía remained indifferent to all pleas for clemency for Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia was lying in his hammock, completely ignoring the pleas for Gerinaldo's pardon.
es: Collapsed in his hammock, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was indifferent to the pleas for clemency.

en: On the eve of the execution, disobeying the order not to bother him, Úrsula visited him in his bedroom.
vi: The night before the execution, despite the order not to disturb him, Úrsula visited him right in his bedroom.
tr: On the night the sentence was to be carried out, Ursula, defying Aureliano's orders not to be disturbed, went to speak with him in his bedroom.
es: The day before the execution, disobeying the order not to disturb him, Úrsula visited him in the bedroom.

en: Encased in black, invested with a rare solemnity, she stood during the three minutes of the interview.
vi: Dressed in a pitch-black outfit from head to toe, with an unusually solemn demeanor, she stood for three minutes while speaking to him.
tr: Dressed in black from head to toe and looking unusually sorrowful as always, Ursula stood throughout the three-minute conversation with her son.
es: Dressed in black, invested with a rare solemnity, she stood for the three minutes of the interview.

en: “I know that you’re going to shoot Gerineldo,” she said calmly, “and that I can’t do anything to stop it.
vi: "I know you will shoot Gerineldo," she said resolutely, "and I cannot do anything to stop this execution.
tr: Calmly, she said, "I know you are going to have Gerineldo shot." "I also know that there is nothing I can do to prevent it."
es: "I know you will execute Gerineldo," she said calmly, "and I can do nothing to prevent it.

en: But I give you one warning: as soon as I see his body I swear to you by the bones of my father and mother, by the memory of José Arcadio Buendía, I swear to you before God that I will drag you out from wherever you’re hiding and kill you with my own two hands.”
vi: But I tell you, right after I see his corpse, I will swear before the remains of my parents, before the spirit of José Arcadio Buendía, I will swear before God that no matter where you flee, I will drag you out and I will kill you with my own hands."
tr: "Still, I came to warn you: The moment I see Gerineldo's dead body, I swear on the bones of my dead father, on the bones of my dead mother, I swear on the memory of Jose Arcadio Buendia, I swear before God, that no matter what hole you crawl into, I will find you and kill you with my own hands."
es: But I warn you of one thing: as soon as I see the corpse, I swear by the bones of my father and mother, by the memory of José Arcadio Buendía, I swear before God, that I will drag you out from wherever you hide and I will kill you with my own hands."

en: Before leaving the room, without waiting for any reply, she concluded:
vi: Before leaving the room, without waiting to hear her son's rebuttal, she concluded:
tr: Without waiting for a response from Aureliano, Ursula turned and, before leaving through the door, concluded her words by saying, "Whether you have become like this or were born with a pig's tail, it's all the same."
es: Before leaving the room, without waiting for any reply, she concluded:

en: “It’s the same as if you’d been born with the tail of a pig.”
vi: - Just like I would kill you if you were born with a pig's tail.
tr: Without waiting for a response from Aureliano, Ursula turned and, before leaving through the door, concluded her words by saying, "Whether you have become like this or were born with a pig's tail, it's all the same."
es: —It's the same thing I would have done if you had been born with a pig's tail.

en: During that interminable night while Colonel Gerineldo Márquez thought about his dead afternoons in Amaranta’s sewing room, Colonel Aureliano Buendía scratched for many hours trying to break the hard shell of his solitude.
vi: In that long, endless night, when Colonel Gerineldo Márquez remembered the beautiful afternoons in Amaranta's sewing room, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was tormented and restless, trying to tear apart the long, interminable night, the tough shell surrounding his loneliness.
tr: Throughout that unending night, on one side, Colonel Gerineldo Marquez thought about the dead days spent in Amaranta's sewing room; on the other side, Colonel Aureliano Buendia struggled for hours to break through the hard shell of his loneliness.
es: That endless night, while Colonel Gerineldo Márquez recalled his dead afternoons in Amaranta's sewing room, Colonel Aureliano Buendía scratched for many hours, trying to break it, the hard shell of his solitude.

en: His only happy moments, since that remote afternoon when his father had taken him to see ice, had taken place in his silver workshop where he passed the time putting little gold fishes together.
vi: The only happy period of his life, since that distant afternoon when his father took him to see the ice, had taken place in the gold workshop, where time passed as he diligently cast little gold fishes.
tr: After that distant day when his father took him to see ice, his only happy moments were the times spent in his silver workshop making tiny fish.
es: His only happy moments, since the distant afternoon when his father took him to see the ice, had passed in the silver workshop, where he spent his time assembling little gold fish.

en: He had had to start thirty-two wars and had had to violate all of his pacts with death and wallow like a hog in the dungheap of glory in order to discover the privileges of simplicity almost forty years late.
vi: He had to ignite thirty-two civil wars, escape death many times, and seek glory like a pig rooting through garbage for food, only to discover nearly ten years later the meaning of the proverb "ignorance is bliss," an inherent trait of gullibility.
tr: It had taken him thirty-two wars, breaking all his pacts with death, wallowing in the filth called fame like a pig, and losing exactly forty years to understand the superiority and privilege of simplicity.
es: He had had to wage thirty-two wars, and had had to break all his pacts with death and wallow like a pig in the mire of glory, to discover almost forty years late the privileges of simplicity.

en: At dawn, worn out by the tormented vigil, he appeared in the cell an hour before the execution.
vi: At dawn, exhausted and weary from a sleepless night, he appeared in the death row cell an hour before the execution.
tr: At dawn, Colonel Aureliano Buendia, weary from a sleepless night spent in self-torment, entered the cell an hour before the execution.
es: At dawn, ravaged by the stormy vigil, he appeared in the stocks room an hour before the execution.

en: “The farce is over, old friend,” he said to Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.
vi: "The charade is over, my friend," he said to Colonel Herinendo Marquez.
tr: He said to Colonel Gerinaldo Marquez, The comedy is over, friend.
es: "The farce is over, compadre," he said to Colonel Gerineldo Márquez.

en: “Let’s get out of here before the mosquitoes in here execute you.”
vi: "We'll be out of here before the mosquitoes get a chance to execute you."
tr: -Let's get out of here before the mosquitoes carry out the death sentence.
es: "Let's get out of here before the mosquitoes finish you off."

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez could not repress the disdain that was inspired in him by that attitude.
vi: Colonel Herinendo Marquez couldn't contain his disdain for such arrogance.
tr: Colonel Gerinaldo Marquez couldn't hide his disgust at this attitude.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez could not repress the contempt that this attitude inspired in him.

en: “No, Aureliano,” he replied.
vi: "Don't go anywhere, Aureliano," he protested.
tr: -No, Aureliano, she replied.
es: —No, Aureliano —he replied—.

en: “I’d rather be dead than see you changed into a bloody tyrant.”
vi: "I would rather die than see you become a blood-stained knife."
tr: -I would rather die than see you become a bloody despot.
es: It's better to be dead than to see you turned into a bully.

en: “You won’t see me,” Colonel Aureliano Buendía said.
vi: - You won't see me anymore, - Colonel Aureliano Buendía said.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia said, "You won't see such a thing."
es: —You won't see me —said Colonel Aureliano Buendía—.

en: “Put on your shoes and help me get this shitty war over with.”
vi: - Put on your shoes and help me end this dirty war.
tr: "Now put on your shoes and help me end this damn war."
es: Put on your shoes and help me finish this shitty war.

en: When he said it he did not know that it was easier to start a war than to end one.
vi: Even while speaking, he still couldn't imagine that starting a war is always much easier than ending it.
tr: When Colonel Aureliano Buendia said these words, he did not know that starting a war was easier than ending one.
es: When he said it, he did not imagine that it was easier to start a war than to end one.

en: It took him almost a year of fierce and bloody effort to force the government to propose conditions of peace favorable to the rebels and another year to convince his own partisans of the convenience of accepting them.
vi: He needed a year of bloody fighting to force the government to make peace proposals beneficial to the insurgents and another year to persuade his own faction to unanimously accept those conditions.
tr: He had to exert a full year of terrible and bloody effort to force the government to propose peace terms that the rebels would accept. He also had to spend another year convincing his own partisans that these terms were acceptable.
es: It took almost a year of bloody rigor to force the government to propose peace conditions favorable to the rebels, and another year to persuade his supporters of the convenience of accepting them.

en: He went to inconceivable extremes of cruelty to put down the rebellion of his own officers, who resisted and called for victory, and he finally relied on enemy forces to make them submit.
vi: He had gone to unwanted extremes of crime to suppress the uprisings of his own officers, who continued to fight stubbornly against the betrayal of the victory of the rebellion, only to end up helping the enemy forces completely dominate them.
tr: He had to resort to unimaginable brutalities to suppress the uprising of his own officers who were unwilling to make peace and were pursuing absolute victory, and in the end, he hoped for help from enemy forces to make them give up.
es: He reached inconceivable extremes of cruelty to quell the rebellions of his own officers, who resisted giving up the victory, and ended up relying on enemy forces to finally subdue them.

en: He was never a greater soldier than at that time.
vi: Never had he been as fierce a warrior as he was then.
tr: He had never attained the stature of a great soldier as he did in those days.
es: Never was there a better warrior than then.

en: The certainty that he was finally fighting for his own liberation and not for abstract ideals, for slogans that politicians could twist left and right according to the circumstances, filled him with an ardent enthusiasm.
vi: The clear realization that he was ultimately fighting for his own liberation and not for abstract ideas or slogans that politicians could manipulate according to specific circumstances, instilled in him a new, exhilarating enthusiasm.
tr: Knowing that he was fighting for his own salvation, rather than for abstract ideals or slogans that politicians would twist to their advantage, filled him with a fiery enthusiasm.
es: The certainty that he was finally fighting for his own liberation, and not for abstract ideals, for slogans that politicians could twist and turn according to circumstances, infused him with a fiery enthusiasm.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, who fought for defeat with as much conviction and loyalty as he had previously fought for victory, reproached him for his useless temerity.
vi: Colonel Hernando Márquez, who fought for defeat with all the zeal and loyalty he had once fought for victory, opposed his useless fear.
tr: Once having fought tirelessly for victory, now Colonel Gerineldo Marquez fought with faith and dedication for defeat, and he scolded Aureliano for recklessly endangering his life and not being cautious.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, who fought for failure with as much conviction and loyalty as he had previously fought for victory, reproached him for his useless recklessness.

en: “Don’t worry,” he would say, smiling.
vi: "Don't worry," he said.
tr: Smiling, Aureliano said, "Don't worry."
es: "Don't worry," he smiled.

en: “Dying is much more difficult than one imagines.”
vi: "Dying isn't as easy as people think."
tr: "Dying is much harder than it seems."
es: "Dying is much harder than one thinks."

en: In his case it was true.
vi: In his case, that was true.
tr: For him, this was true.
es: In his case, it was true.

en: The certainty that his day was assigned gave him a mysterious immunity, an immortality or a fixed period that made him invulnerable to the risks of war and in the end permitted him to win a defeat that was much more difficult, much more bloody and costly than victory.
vi: The firm belief that his death would be foretold endowed him with a strange invulnerability, an immortality so certain that he couldn't be injured in dangerous battles and ultimately allowed him to achieve a defeat far more difficult, bloody, and costly than achieving a victory.
tr: The belief that his death was predetermined gave him a mysterious immunity, a temporary immortality, allowing Aureliano to charge fearlessly into the most dangerous moments of battle. For this reason, he was able to achieve defeat, which was much harder, much bloodier, and much more costly than victory.
es: The certainty that his day was marked endowed him with a mysterious immunity, a fixed-term immortality that made him invulnerable to the risks of war, and finally allowed him to achieve a defeat that was much more difficult, much bloodier, and costlier than victory.

en: In almost twenty years of war, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been at his house many times, but the state of urgency with which he always arrived, the military retinue that accompanied him everywhere, the aura of legend that glowed about his presence and of which even Úrsula was aware, changed him into a stranger in the end.
vi: During nearly twenty years of war, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was often at home, but the hurried state each time he returned, the noisy military apparatus that followed him across the country, as well as the mythical aura that enveloped his image, and even the image of him in that mythical aura, made no one feel close to him, including Úrsula herself. All of these factors turned him into a stranger.
tr: During the war that lasted almost twenty years, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had returned home many times. However, each time he came hurriedly, in between two important tasks, and his soldiers never left his side, creating an aura of legend around Aureliano that even Úrsula noticed. All of this eventually turned Aureliano into a stranger.
es: In almost twenty years of war, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been in the house many times, but the state of urgency in which he always arrived, the military apparatus that accompanied him everywhere, the aura of legend that gilded his presence and to which even Úrsula herself was not insensitive, ended up making him a stranger.

en: The last time that he was in Macondo and took a house for his three concubines, he was seen in his own house only on two or three occasions when he had the time to accept an invitation to dine.
vi: The last time he was in Macondo, he used a house for his three mistresses, and apart from that, he was seen at his own home only two or three times, when he had time to return home for a meal at the family's invitation.
tr: When he opened a house for his three mistresses on his last visit to Macondo, he went to his own home only two or three times, just to call for meals.
es: The last time he was in Macondo, and took a house for his three concubines, he was seen in his own home only two or three times, when he had time to accept invitations to eat.

en: Remedios the Beauty and the twins, born during the middle of the war, scarcely knew him.
vi: Remedios the Beauty and the twin boys, who were born amidst the chaos, hardly knew him.
tr: Beautiful Remedios and the twins, who were born during the war, knew him only from a distance.
es: Remedios, the beautiful, and the twins, born in the midst of the war, barely knew him.

en: Amaranta could not reconcile her image of the brother who had spent his adolescence making little gold fishes with that of the mythical warrior who had placed a distance of ten feet between himself and the rest of humanity.
vi: Amaranta could not find a connection between the image of her brother who had spent his youth in the workshop casting goldfish and the image of a legendary warrior who isolated himself from the rest of humanity by a distance of three meters.
tr: Amaranta, on the other hand, could not reconcile the memory of her brother, who had spent his youth making little goldfish, with this legendary warrior who kept a three-meter distance between himself and all of humanity.
es: Amaranta could not reconcile the image of the brother who spent his adolescence making little gold fishes with that of the mythical warrior who had placed a distance of three meters between himself and the rest of humanity.

en: But when the approach of the armistice became known and they thought that he would return changed back into a human being, delivered at last for the hearts of his own people, the family feelings, dormant for such a long time, were reborn stronger than ever.
vi: But when she knew that a ceasefire was imminent and thought that once again he would return to being an ordinary person, and finally he would be free to reunite with the hearts of his loved ones, the family affection, which had been dormant for quite a while, now revived stronger than ever.
tr: When the news of the ceasefire agreement spread, the household thought that Aureliano would finally be returned to his family, that he would come back to them as a human being once more, and they felt the family bonds that had been in the shadows for so long stronger than ever.
es: But when the proximity of the armistice became known and it was thought that he was returning once again as a human being, finally rescued for the hearts of his own, the family affections dormant for so long were reborn with more strength than ever.

en: “We’ll finally have a man in the house again,” Úrsula said.
vi: - Finally, - Ursula said, - once again we have a man in the house.
tr: Ursula said, "Finally, there will be a man in our house again."
es: —At last —said Úrsula— we will have a man in the house again.

en: Amaranta was the first to suspect that they had lost him forever.
vi: Amaranta was the first to suspect that they had caused him to fail permanently.
tr: Amaranta was the first to sense that they had completely lost Aureliano.
es: Amaranta was the first to suspect that they had lost him forever.

en: One week before the armistice, when he entered the house without an escort, preceded by two barefoot orderlies who deposited on the porch the saddle from the mule and the trunk of poetry, all that was left of his former imperial baggage, she saw him pass by the sewing room and she called to him.
vi: A week before the ceasefire, when he entered the house without a guard, followed by two barefoot soldiers who placed all the rough goods carried by mules in the hallway, and a box of letters, the only remaining item of his once splendid belongings, she saw him pass by the sewing room and called him.
tr: A week before the ceasefire agreement, Aureliano entered the house with two barefoot soldiers, without his officers and aides. The soldiers left the mule saddle and the chest containing the poems, which were all that remained of Aureliano's once-overflowing baggage, on the veranda. Amaranta called out to him as he passed in front of the sewing room.
es: A week before the armistice, when he entered the house without an escort, preceded by two barefoot orderlies who deposited the mule's gear and the trunk of verses, the only remnant of his former imperial baggage, she saw him pass in front of the sewing room and called him.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had trouble recognizing her.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía seemed to barely recognize her.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia did not recognize her.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía seemed to have difficulty recognizing her.

en: “It’s Amaranta,” she said good-humoredly, happy at his return, and she showed him the hand with the black bandage.
vi: - It's me, Amaranta! - she joked, happy that her brother had returned and showing him the black band.
tr: Amaranta, in her joy at Aureliano's return home, said, "I am Amaranta," showing her hand wrapped in a black bandage.
es: —I am Amaranta —she said in good spirits, happy about her return, and showed him the hand with the black bandage—.

en: “Look.”
vi: - Look at this, brother.
tr: "Look."
es: Look.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía smiled at her the same way as when he had first seen her with the bandage on that remote morning when he had come back to Macondo condemned to death.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía flashed a smile identical to the one he had when he saw her bandaging his hand for the first time, that time he returned to Macondo sentenced to death.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia smiled the same way he did that morning when he first saw the bandage on his sister's hand, having come to Macondo once condemned to death.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía gave her the same smile as the first time he saw her with the bandage, that distant morning when he returned to Macondo sentenced to death.

en: “How awful,” he said, “the way time passes!”
vi: - Oh, how terrible, - he said, - time passes so quickly!
tr: "How time flies," he said. "This is a terrible thing!"
es: —What a horror —he said—, how time flies!

en: The regular army had to protect the house.
vi: The standing army has the duty to protect the house.
tr: The soldiers of the state had to protect the house.
es: The regular army had to protect the house.

en: He arrived amid insults, spat upon, accused of having accelerated the war in order to sell it for a better price.
vi: He returned in a state of being escorted, scorned, and accused of reigniting the war with the intention of selling it at a higher price.
tr: The people on the street were cursing and spitting at Aureliano, accusing him of needlessly igniting the war just to sell it at a better price in the end.
es: He arrived harassed, spat upon, accused of having intensified the war only to sell it at a higher price.

en: He was trembling with fever and cold and his armpits were studded with sores again.
vi: He shivered with fever and cold, and once again, his armpits were swollen.
tr: Aureliano was shivering from both the heat and the cold. Wounds had opened up again under his armpits.
es: He was trembling with fever and cold and once again had his armpits full of boils.

en: Six months before, when she had heard talk about the armistice, Úrsula had opened up and swept out the bridal chamber and had burned myrrh in the corners, thinking that he would come back ready to grow old slowly among Remedios’ musty dolls.
vi: Six months before hearing the news of an armistice, Ursula had opened and cleaned the room of the couple, then burned incense in every corner, thinking that he would return to spend his old age beside Remedios' long-unused dolls.
tr: Six months ago, when Ursula first heard the rumors of a ceasefire, she had opened the bridal room, cleaned it thoroughly, burned fragrant myrrh incense in every corner, and started waiting for her son to return home to slowly grow old among Remedios' now moldy dolls.
es: Six months earlier, when she heard about the armistice, Úrsula had opened and swept the bridal chamber, and had burned myrrh in the corners, thinking that he would return ready to grow old slowly among Remedios's moldy dolls.

en: But actually, during the last two years he had paid his final dues to life, including growing old.
vi: But in reality, in the last two years, he had repaid life for what he had enjoyed, including his share of old age.
tr: However, Aureliano had completed all his duties towards life, including aging, in the last two years.
es: But in reality, in the last two years, he had paid his final dues to life, including that of aging.

en: When he passed by the silver shop, which Úrsula had prepared with special diligence, he did not even notice that the keys were in the lock.
vi: As he passed the jewelry workshop that Ursula had meticulously prepared, he did not recognize even the bunch of keys already inserted in the lock.
tr: As he passed by the silver workshop that Ursula had meticulously prepared, Aureliano didn't even notice that the keys were in the lock.
es: As he passed in front of the silver workshop, which Úrsula had prepared with special diligence, he did not even notice that the keys were in the lock.

en: He did not notice the minute, tearing destruction that time had wreaked on the house and that, after such a prolonged absence, would have looked like a disaster to any man who had kept his memories alive.
vi: He felt nothing at all, not even the major or minor damages left by the passage of time in the house, and that after being away for so long, if a person still retains their memories intact, it must be seen as a disaster.
tr: He didn't realize how time had gnawed at the house, made it decrepit, and brought about a situation that could be described as disastrous after so many years for someone who hadn't erased his memories from his mind.
es: He did not perceive the tiny and heartbreaking damages that time had done to the house, and that after such a prolonged absence would have seemed a disaster to any man who kept his memories alive.

en: He was not pained by the peeling of the whitewash on the walls or the dirty, cottony cobwebs in the corners or the dust on the begonias or the veins left on the beams by the termites or the moss on the hinges or any of the insidious traps that nostalgia offered him.
vi: He did not feel the slightest sorrow over the peeling lime on the walls, the cobwebs in every corner, the dust covering the begonias, the termite holes in the beams, or the moss on the windowsills.
tr: Neither the peeling plaster on the walls, nor the dirty, cotton-like cobwebs in the corners, nor the dust on the begonias, nor the worm-eaten beams, nor the rust covering the hinges caused Aureliano any pain; he didn't fall into any of the traps set by his longing for the house.
es: The peeling lime on the walls did not hurt him, nor the dirty cottons of cobwebs in the corners, nor the dust on the begonias, nor the termite veins in the beams, nor the moss on the doorframes, nor any of the insidious traps that nostalgia laid for him.

en: He sat down on the porch, wrapped in his blanket and with his boots still on, as if only waiting for it to clear, and he spent the whole afternoon watching it rain on the begonias.
vi: He sat on the porch, still wearing his boots and wrapped in his coat, as if waiting for the rain to stop, and sat like that all afternoon watching the rain fall on the begonias.
tr: He wrapped himself in his blanket, sat on the veranda, and watched the rain fall on the begonias all day. As if he had come there only to wait for the rain to stop, he hadn't even taken off his boots.
es: He sat in the corridor, wrapped in the blanket and without taking off his boots, as if just waiting for the rain to stop, and spent the whole afternoon watching it rain over the begonias.

en: Úrsula understood then that they would not have him home for long.
vi: At that moment, Ursula realized that it had been a very long time since she had him in this house.
tr: Ursula sensed that he wouldn't stay with them for long.
es: Úrsula then understood that she would not have him in the house for long.

en: “If it’s not the war,” she thought, “it can only be death.”
vi: "If it's not war; - he thought, - then it can only be death."
tr: -If he's not going to war anymore, then it means he will surely die, she thought.
es: "If it's not the war," she thought, "it can only be death."

en: It was a supposition that was so neat, so convincing that she identified it as a premonition.
vi: It was an extremely clear prediction, so convincing that he equated it with an omen.
tr: This assumption was so certain, so convincing that Ursula interpreted it as a prophecy.
es: It was such a clear, convincing supposition that she identified it as a premonition.

en: That night, at dinner, the supposed Aureliano Segundo broke his bread with his right hand and drank his soup with his left.
vi: That night during dinner, the boy impersonating Aureliano Segundo held the bread with his left hand and scooped soup with his right hand.
tr: That evening at dinner, Aureliano Segundo was tearing his bread with his right hand and eating his soup with his left hand.
es: That night, at dinner, the supposed Aureliano Segundo crumbled the bread with his right hand and took the soup with his left.

en: His twin brother, the supposed José Arcadio Segundo, broke his bread with his left hand and drank his soup with his right.
vi: His twin brother, impersonating José Arcadio Segundo, held the bread with his right hand and scooped soup with his left hand.
tr: His twin brother Jose Arcadio Segundo, on the other hand, was tearing his bread with his left hand and eating his soup with his right hand.
es: His twin brother, the supposed José Arcadio Segundo, crumbled the bread with his left hand and took the soup with his right.

en: So precise was their coordination that they did not look like two brothers sitting opposite each other but like a trick with mirrors.
vi: Their movements were so synchronized that it was impossible to think that two people were sitting opposite each other; it seemed like one person looking into a mirror.
tr: Their actions were so harmoniously synchronized that they looked more like someone playing in front of a mirror than two brothers sitting across from each other.
es: The coordination of their movements was so precise that they did not seem like two brothers sitting across from each other, but rather an artifice of mirrors.

en: The spectacle that the twins had invented when they became aware that they were equal was repeated in honor of the new arrival.
vi: The scene of the twin children empathizing with each other since they became aware that they were identical was repeated to welcome the newly returned person.
tr: This game, which they discovered when they realized they were identical twins, was repeated at dinner in honor of Aureliano's arrival.
es: The spectacle that the twins had conceived since they became aware of being identical was repeated in honor of the newcomer.

en: But Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not notice it.
vi: But Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not notice it either.
tr: But Colonel Aureliano Buendia did not even notice.
es: But Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not notice it.

en: He seemed so alien to everything that he did not even notice Remedios the Beauty as she passed by naked on her way to her bedroom.
vi: He seemed estranged from everything, even the sight of Remedios the Beauty walking by naked to the bedroom did not catch his attention.
tr: He was so detached and so disconnected from everything that he did not even see Beautiful Remedios passing by him naked as he went to the bedroom.
es: He seemed so oblivious to everything that he didn't even notice Remedios the Beauty, who walked naked towards the bedroom.

en: Úrsula was the only one who dared disturb his, abstraction.
vi: Úrsula was the only one who dared to disturb his deep contemplation:
tr: Only Ursula dared to break his reverie.
es: Úrsula was the only one who dared to disturb his abstraction.

en: “If you have to go away again,” she said halfway through dinner, “at least try to remember how we were tonight.”
vi: - If you need to leave again, - the old man said to him in the middle of the meal, - at least you should do something so that we can remember how we lived tonight!
tr: Halfway through the meal, -If you have to leave again, at least try not to forget our situation tonight, he said.
es: —If you have to leave again —he told her halfway through dinner—, at least try to remember how we were tonight.

en: Then Colonel Aureliano Buendía realized, without surprise, that Úrsula was the only human being who had succeeded in penetrating his misery, and for the first time in many years he looked her in the face.
vi: So it was no surprise at all that Colonel Aureliano Buendía realized that Úrsula was the only one who had guessed the pain in his heart, and for the first time in many years, he dared to look directly into her eyes.
tr: Then Colonel Aureliano Buendia realized that the only person who could pierce through his pain and loneliness was Ursula. He wasn't surprised by this; for the first time in years, he looked at his mother's face.
es: Then Colonel Aureliano Buendía realized, without surprise, that Úrsula was the only human being who had managed to unravel his misery, and for the first time in many years, he dared to look her in the face.

en: Her skin was leathery, her teeth decayed, her hair faded and colorless, and her look frightened.
vi: Her skin was wrinkled, her teeth were crooked, her hair was withered, and the look in her eyes was full of astonishment.
tr: Ursula's skin had become like leather, her teeth had decayed, and her hair had lost its color. She had a frightening appearance.
es: She had cracked skin, decayed teeth, withered and colorless hair, and an astonished look.

en: He compared her with the oldest memory that he had of her, the afternoon when he had the premonition that a pot of boiling soup was going to fall off the table, and he found her broken to pieces.
vi: He compared her with the old image of her that he still retained, the image of her on the afternoon when he had predicted that the boiling pot of soup would spill off the table, and indeed it had fallen to the ground and shattered into pieces.
tr: Aureliano compared his mother's appearance to his oldest memory of her, from the day she predicted that the boiling soup bowl would fall off the table, and found his mother shattered.
es: He compared her with the oldest memory he had of her, the afternoon when he had the premonition that a pot of boiling broth was going to fall off the table, and he found her shattered.

en: In an instant he discovered the scratches, the welts, the sores, the ulcers, and the scan that had been left on her by more than half a century of daily life, and he saw that those damages did not even arouse a feeling of pity in him.
vi: Immediately, he recognized the wrinkles, the rough patches, the calluses, the scars that had marked her skin over more than half a century of hard work, and he realized that those marks did not stir his heart in the slightest.
tr: He saw in an instant the traces, ulcers, wounds, and cracks that daily troubles over more than half a century had left on his mother, and realized that these did not evoke any feeling of pity in him.
es: In an instant, he discovered the scratches, welts, bruises, ulcers, and scars that more than half a century of daily life had left on her, and he confirmed that these ravages did not even evoke a feeling of pity in him.

en: Then he made one last effort to search in his heart for the place where his affection had rotted away and he could not find it.
vi: Immediately, he tried to find in his heart the place where feelings had rotted away, and he could not find it.
tr: Then he made one last effort to find the place in his heart where emotions had rotted away, but he couldn't find it.
es: He then made one last effort to search in his heart for the place where his affections had rotted away, and he could not find it.

en: On another occasion, he felt at least a confused sense of shame when he found the smell of Úrsula on his own skin, and more than once he felt her thoughts interfering with his.
vi: At least, at other times, he felt ashamed when he suddenly caught Úrsula's scent on his own skin, and many times he felt that her thoughts had intertwined with his own.
tr: On another visit, when he sensed Ursula's scent on his own skin, he felt a feeling akin to shame, at the very least. Later, he noticed many times that Ursula's thoughts were mingling with his own.
es: In another time, at least he experienced a confused feeling of shame when he detected Úrsula's smell on his own skin, and on more than one occasion, he felt his thoughts interfered by hers.

en: But all of that had been wiped out by the war.
vi: But all of that was overshadowed by the war.
tr: But the war had swept away all these feelings.
es: But all that had been swept away by the war.

en: Even Remedios, his wife, at that moment was a hazy image of someone who might have been his daughter.
vi: Even at that moment, Remedios, his wife, was just a faint image of someone who could have been his daughter.
tr: Now even his wife Remedios was nothing more than a faint memory of someone who could be his daughter.
es: Even Remedios, his wife, was at that moment the blurred image of someone who could have been his daughter.

en: The countless women he had known on the desert of love and who had spread his seed all along the coast had left no trace in his feelings.
vi: The girls he had known in the loneliness of love, and who had borne his offspring across the coastal region, left no mark on his feelings.
tr: The countless women he had known in the desert of love, and who had spread his seed throughout the coastal region, had left no trace in Aureliano's heart.
es: The countless women he had known in the desert of love, and who had scattered his seed all along the coast, had left no trace in his feelings.

en: Most of them had come into his room in the dark and had left before dawn, and on the following day they were nothing but a touch of fatigue in his bodily memory.
vi: Most of them had entered his room to sleep when it was dark and had left before dawn, and the next day they were just a vague memory in his mind.
tr: Most of them had entered his room in the dark and left before dawn, leaving behind nothing but the fatigue in his body the next day.
es: Most of them entered the room in the dark and left before dawn, and the next day they were barely a bit of tedium in his bodily memory.

en: The only affection that prevailed against time and the war was that which he had felt for his brother José Arcadio when they both were children, and it was not based on love but on complicity.
vi: The only feeling that remained intact against the ravages of time and war was the memory of his brother José Arcadio when they were both children, not yet knowing love, only mischief.
tr: The only feeling that had endured without succumbing to time and war was the bond he had felt for his brother Jose Arcadio during their childhood. This, too, was a feeling based not on love, but on complicity.
es: The only affection that prevailed against time and war was the one he felt for his brother José Arcadio when they were both children, and it was not founded on love, but on complicity.

en: “I’m sorry,” he excused himself from Úrsula’s request.
vi: - Forgive me, mother, - he said in response to Ursula's request.
tr: Aureliano dismissed Ursula's request not to forget them by saying, "Forgive me, the war erased everything."
es: —Excuse me —he apologized at Úrsula's request—.

en: “It’s just that the war has done away with everything.”
vi: - It's just that this war has destroyed everything.
tr: Aureliano dismissed Ursula's request not to forget them by saying, "Forgive me, the war erased everything."
es: It's just that this war has ended everything.

en: During the following days he busied himself destroying all trace of his passage through the world.
vi: In the days that followed, he busied himself with erasing every trace of his existence from this world.
tr: In the days following that event, Aureliano busied himself with erasing all traces of his passage through the world.
es: In the following days, he occupied himself with destroying every trace of his passage through the world.

en: He stripped the silver shop until all that were left were impersonal objects, he gave his clothes away to the orderlies, and he buried his weapons in the courtyard with the same feeling of penance with which his father had buried the spear that had killed Prudencio Aguilar.
vi: He cleared out the jewelry workshop, leaving only items that did not remind anyone of him, distributed his clothes to the guards, and with the same regretful thought his father had when he buried the spear that killed Prudencio Aguilar, he buried his weapons in the yard.
tr: He distributed everything in the silver workshop until there was nothing left that was uniquely his. He gave his clothes to the soldiers. Feeling a guilt akin to what his father felt when he buried the spear that killed Prudencio Aguilar, he buried all his weapons in the yard.
es: He simplified the silversmith workshop until only impersonal objects were left, gave his clothes to the orderlies, and buried his weapons in the yard with the same sense of penance with which his father buried the spear that killed Prudencio Aguilar.

en: He kept only one pistol with one bullet in it.
vi: He kept only a pistol with a single bullet.
tr: He kept only a pistol with a single bullet in it.
es: He only kept one pistol, and with a single bullet.

en: Úrsula did not intervene.
vi: Úrsula did not dare to interfere with his work.
tr: Ursula did not interfere at all.
es: Úrsula did not intervene.

en: The only time she dissuaded him was when he was about to destroy the daguerreotype of Remedios that was kept in the parlor lighted by an eternal lamp.
vi: Only once did she advise him, and that was when he was about to tear up the carefully preserved photograph of Remedios, which was always illuminated by a lamp.
tr: Only when he attempted to destroy the picture of Remedios, illuminated by a lamp that burned day and night in the living room, did Ursula stop him.
es: The only time she dissuaded him was when he was about to destroy the daguerreotype of Remedios that was kept in the living room, illuminated by an eternal lamp.

en: “That picture stopped belonging to you a long time ago,” she told him.
vi: "This portrait has long ceased to belong to you," she told him.
tr: "This picture ceased to be yours long ago," she said.
es: "That portrait stopped belonging to you a long time ago," she told him.

en: “It’s a family relic.”
vi: "It is a family heirloom."
tr: "It is now a family heirloom."
es: "It is a family relic."

en: On the eve of the armistice, when no single object that would let him be remembered was left in the house, he took the trunk of poetry to the bakery when Santa Sofía de la Piedad was making ready to light the oven.
vi: The night before the armistice agreement was signed, when there was nothing left in the house to remind anyone of him, he took the chest containing five volumes of poetry to the bakery while Santa Sofía de la Piedad was preparing to light the oven.
tr: On the night the armistice agreement came into effect, when there was nothing left in the house to remind anyone of him, Aureliano took the chest where the poems were kept and carried it to the kitchen, where Santa Sofia de la Piedad was preparing to light the oven.
es: On the eve of the armistice, when there was not a single object left in the house that could remind anyone of him, he took the trunk with the verses to the bakery at the moment when Santa Sofía de la Piedad was preparing to light the oven.

en: “Light it with this,” he told her, handing her the first roll of yellowish papers.
vi: - Use this to start the fire, - he said, handing her the roll of yellowed paper. -
tr: Handing over a bundle of yellowed papers, he said, "Burn the oven with these."
es: —Light it with this —he said, handing him the first roll of yellowed papers—.

en: “It will, burn better because they’re very old things.”
vi: The fire will catch quickly because it's all old stuff.
tr: "They will burn better because they are very old."
es: It burns better because they are very old things.

en: Santa Sofía de la Piedad, the silent one, the condescending one, the one who never contradicted anyone, not even her own children, had the impression that it was a forbidden act.
vi: Santa Sophia de la Piedad, the silent woman, the gentle woman, the one who never argued with anyone, not even with her own children, immediately recognized that it was a forbidden act.
tr: Santa Sofia de la Piedad, that silent woman, that gentle, that woman who never conflicted with anyone, not even her own children, sensed that this was something that should not be done.
es: Santa Sofía de la Piedad, the silent one, the accommodating one, the one who never contradicted even her own children, had the impression that this was a forbidden act.

en: “They’re important papers,” she said.
vi: - Those are important documents, - she said.
tr: "These are important papers," he said.
es: —They are important papers —he said.

en: “Nothing of the sort,” the colonel said.
vi: - It's nothing important, - the colonel said.
tr: The Colonel replied, "Not at all."
es: —None of that —said the colonel—.

en: “They’re things that a person writes to himself.”
vi: - Those are completely private pages meant only for the writer to read.
tr: "These are things a person scribbles to themselves."
es: These are things that are written for oneself.

en: “In that case,” she said, “you burn them, colonel.”
vi: - Then, please, uncle, burn it for me, - she said.
tr: -Then, come closer yourself, my colonel.
es: —Then —she said— burn them yourself, Colonel.

en: He not only did that, but he broke up the trunk with a hatchet and threw the pieces into the fire.
vi: Not only did he burn the paper, but he also took an axe to chop the barrel into pieces and put everything into the furnace.
tr: Aureliano not only threw the papers into the furnace with his own hands, but he also broke the chest into pieces with a cane axe and threw it into the fire.
es: Not only did he do it, but he also smashed the trunk with a hatchet and threw the splinters into the fire.

en: Hours before, Pilar Ternera had come to visit him.
vi: A few hours earlier, Pila Tecnêra had come to visit him.
tr: Hours earlier, Pilar Ternera had come to see him.
es: Hours earlier, Pilar Ternera had come to visit him.

en: After so many years of not seeing her, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was startled at how old and fat she had become and how much she had lost of the splendor of her laugh, but he was also startled at the depths she had reached in her reading of the cards.
vi: After many years without seeing her, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was extremely surprised to see that she had aged significantly and gained a lot of weight, that she had lost her loud, ringing laugh, but he was also immensely astonished by her accurate card-reading skills.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, after not seeing her for so many years, was surprised to see how the woman had aged, gained weight, and how her smile had lost its beauty, while at the same time he was astonished at how skillfully she had learned the language of the papers.
es: After so many years of not seeing her, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was astonished at how much she had aged and gained weight, and how much the splendor of her laughter had faded, but he was also amazed at the depth she had achieved in reading the cards.

en: “Watch out for your mouth,” she told him, and he wondered whether the other time she had told him that during the height of his glory it had not been a surprisingly anticipated vision of his fate.
vi: "Keep your mouth shut," she had told him, and he wondered if, at another time during the peak of his glory, if she had told him that, would it have been an unexpected insight that influenced his fate.
tr: Pilar had said to him, "Watch your mouth." Aureliano was pondering whether these words, once again spoken during his brightest days, had determined his fate to an astonishing degree.
es: "Take care of your mouth," she told him, and he wondered if the last time she said it, at the height of his glory, it had been a surprisingly foresighted vision of his destiny.

en: A short time later, when his personal physician finished removing his sores, he asked him, without showing any particular interest, where the exact location of his heart was.
vi: Shortly thereafter, when the doctor responsible for his health had finished cleaning the pus from his two armpits, without any particular interest, he simply asked him where exactly the heart was located.
tr: A short time later, while his private doctor was dressing his wounds, Aureliano, without seeming too interested, asked where exactly his heart was.
es: Shortly after, when his personal doctor finished removing the boils, he asked him without showing particular interest where exactly the heart was located.

en: The doctor listened with his stethoscope and then painted a circle on his cheat with a piece of cotton dipped in iodine.
vi: The doctor pointed to the location of the heart and then used a dirty cotton swab dipped in red medicine to draw a circle on his chest.
tr: The doctor listened with a stethoscope, then drew a circle on Aureliano's chest with a cotton swab dipped in tincture of iodine.
es: The doctor examined him and then drew a circle on his chest with a cotton swab stained with iodine.

en: The Tuesday of the armistice dawned warm and rainy.
vi: On the fourth day, the day the armistice agreement was signed, the scene brightened under the rain and the pleasantly warm weather.
tr: On the Tuesday morning when the weapons were laid down, a hot and rainy day dawned.
es: The armistice Tuesday dawned warm and rainy.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía appeared in the kitchen before five o’clock and had his usual black coffee without sugar.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía appeared in the kitchen before five o'clock and, as usual, drank unsweetened coffee.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia entered the kitchen before five o'clock and drank his usual plain coffee.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía appeared in the kitchen before five and took his usual coffee without sugar.

en: “You came into the world on a day like this,” Úrsula told him.
vi: "You were born on a day just like this," Úrsula told him.
tr: Ursula said, "You were born on a day like this."
es: “A day like this you came into the world,” Úrsula told him.

en: “Everybody was amazed at your open eyes.”
vi: "Everyone was surprised by your wide-open eyes."
tr: "Everyone was astonished when you were born with your eyes open."
es: “Everyone was scared by your open eyes.”

en: He did not pay any attention because he was listening to the forming of the troops, the sound of the comets, and the voices of command that were shattering the dawn.
vi: He didn't pay attention to her words, because he was listening to the soldiers preparing, listening to the sharp bugle calls and the commands that were unsettling the dawn.
tr: Aureliano paid no attention to her stories because he was listening to the bugle sounds tearing through the dawn silence, the soldiers lining up, and the commands being given.
es: He paid no attention to her, because he was focused on the troop preparations, the bugle calls, and the commands that spoiled the dawn.

en: Even though after so many years of war they should have sounded familiar to him this time he felt the same weakness in his knees and the same tingling in his skin that he had felt in his youth in the presence of a naked woman.
vi: Even after many years of war, those sounds seemed familiar to him, but this time they made his knees feel weak and gave him the same shiver he had felt in his youth when standing before a naked woman.
tr: After so many years of fighting, these sounds should not have felt unfamiliar, yet Aureliano felt the same weakness in his knees and the shiver in his skin that he had felt when he saw his first naked woman in his youth.
es: Although after so many years of war they should have seemed familiar to him, this time he experienced the same weakness in his knees and the same tingling of the skin that he had felt in his youth in the presence of a naked woman.

en: He thought confusedly, finally captive in a trap of nostalgia, that perhaps if he had married her he would have been a man without war and without glory, a nameless artisan, a happy animal.
vi: He thought, in a confused way, at the moment he was most trapped in the snare of loneliness, that if he had married that girl, he would have been a man who did not wander through wars and did not carry glory, but a nameless, ordinary craftsman, a happy male.
tr: He felt a strange longing, thinking that if he had married that woman, he would have been a happy, unknown artisan, unaware of war, fame, and glory.
es: He thought confusedly, finally caught in a trap of nostalgia, that perhaps if he had married her he would have been a man without war and without glory, an anonymous craftsman, a happy animal.

en: That tardy shudder which had not figured in his forethought made his breakfast bitter.
vi: It was this late sadness, which did not stand out in his plans, that made his breakfast taste bitter.
tr: This unexpected shiver ruined his breakfast.
es: This late shudder, which was not in his plans, soured his breakfast.

en: At seven in the morning, when Colonel Gerineldo Márquez came to fetch him, in the company of a group of rebel officers, he found him more taciturn than ever, more pensive and solitary.
vi: At seven in the morning, when Colonel Gerineldo Márquez came to find him to go with the group of revolutionary officers, he found him silent, contemplative, lonelier than ever.
tr: At seven in the morning, when Colonel Gerineldo Marquez came to take him with a group of rebel officers, he found Aureliano more lonely, more withdrawn, and more pensive than ever.
es: At seven in the morning, when Colonel Gerineldo Márquez came to fetch him accompanied by a group of rebel officers, he found him more taciturn than ever, more thoughtful and solitary.

en: Úrsula tried to throw a new wrap over his shoulders.
vi: Úrsula intended to drape a new coat over his shoulders.
tr: Ursula tried to throw a new cloak over Aureliano's shoulders.
es: Úrsula tried to throw a new blanket over his shoulders.

en: “What will the government think,” she told him.
vi: "What will the government think," she said to him, "They will think that you surrendered simply because you were so destitute that you couldn't afford a new coat."
tr: "What will the government say then?"
es: “What will the government think,” she said to him.

en: “They’ll figure that you’ve surrendered because you didn’t have anything left to buy a cloak with.”
vi: "What will the government think," she said to him, "They will think that you surrendered simply because you were so destitute that you couldn't afford a new coat."
tr: "They'll think you surrendered because you didn't even have enough money to buy a cloak," she said.
es: “They will imagine that you have surrendered because you no longer had even enough to buy a blanket.”

en: But he would not accept it.
vi: But he still refused to take the coat.
tr: But Aureliano refused.
es: But he did not accept it.

en: When he was at the door, he let her put an old felt hat of José Arcadio Buendía’s on his head.
vi: When he reached the door, seeing that it was still raining, he let her put José Arcadio Buendía's old felt hat on his head.
tr: As he was about to leave through the door, he put on Jose Arcadio Buendia's old felt hat at Ursula's insistence.
es: Already at the door, seeing that the rain continued, he let them put an old felt hat of José Arcadio Buendía on him.

en: “Aureliano,” Úrsula said to him then, “Promise me that if you find that it’s a bad hour for you there that you’ll think of your mother.”
vi: - Aureliano, my son, - at that moment she managed to say to him, - promise your mother that if you encounter any misfortune there, you will think of your mother. Promise me, my son!
tr: Ursula, said Aureliano. If you find yourself in trouble, in a difficult situation, promise me that in the last moment, you will think of your mother.
es: —Aureliano —Úrsula then said to him—, promise me that if you ever encounter a bad moment out there, you will think of your mother.

en: He gave her a distant smile, raising his hand with all his fingers extended, and without saying a word he left the house and faced the shouts, insults, and blasphemies that would follow him until he left the town.
vi: With the elder, he gave a distracted smile, spread his hand with five fingers wide open, then without saying a word, he left his house to face the shouts, curses, and imprecations that followed him all the way to the village gate.
tr: Aureliano raised his hand with fingers spread and smiled absentmindedly. Then, without saying a word, he left the house and plunged into the midst of curses, insults, and imprecations that pursued him until he was out of town.
es: He gave her a distant smile, raised his hand with all his fingers extended, and without saying a word, left the house and faced the shouts, insults, and blasphemies that would pursue him until he left the town.

en: Úrsula put the bar on the door, having decided not to take it down for the rest of her life.
vi: Ursula bolted the door tightly with the intention of never opening it for the rest of her life.
tr: Ursula bolted the door with an iron bar, determined never to open it again until she died.
es: Úrsula bolted the door, determined not to remove it for the rest of her life.

en: “We’ll rot in here,” she thought.
vi: "We will rot to death inside," she thought.
tr: "We will rot here," she thought.
es: “We will rot in here,” she thought.

en: “We’ll turn to ashes in this house without men, but we won’t give this miserable town the pleasure of seeing us weep.”
vi: "We would rather let the ashes cover us in this house without men than let these wretched villagers enjoy watching us cry"...
tr: "We will turn to ashes in this manless house, but we will not give this vile town the pleasure of seeing us cry."
es: “We will turn to ashes in this house without men, but we will not give this miserable town the pleasure of seeing us cry.”

en: She spent the whole morning looking for a memory of her son in the most hidden corners, but she could find none.
vi: That entire morning, she searched every hidden corner to find a keepsake of her son but could not find anything.
tr: Ursula searched the house thoroughly all morning, looking in the most unlikely places, hoping to find a memento of her son. She found nothing.
es: She spent the whole morning looking for a memory of her son in the most secret corners, and she could not find it.

en: The ceremony took place fifteen miles from Macondo in the shade of a gigantic ceiba tree around which the town of Neerlandia would be founded later.
vi: The signing ceremony was held at a location about a few dozen kilometers from Macondo, right under the shade of a giant kapok tree, where the town of Neclandia was later established.
tr: The signing ceremony took place twenty kilometers from Macondo, in the shade of a large tree around which the town of Neerlandia would later be established.
es: The event was held twenty kilometers from Macondo, in the shadow of a gigantic ceiba tree around which the town of Neerlandia would later be founded.

en: The delegates from the government and the party and the commission of the rebels who were laying down their arms were served by a noisy group of novices in white habits who looked like a flock of doves that had been frightened by the rain.
vi: The government representatives, party members, and the army surrendering their weapons were served by a noisy group of nuns in white robes, who looked like a flock of doves startled by the rain.
tr: Young seminarians, dressed in white and resembling a flock of doves startled by the rain, served the rebels who had laid down their arms, as well as the representatives of the government and the party.
es: The government and party delegates, and the rebel commission that surrendered their weapons, were served by a bustling group of novices in white habits, who looked like a flutter of doves frightened by the rain.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía arrived on a muddy mule.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía arrived at the location riding a mud-spattered donkey.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia arrived on a mule mired in mud.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía arrived on a mud-splattered mule.

en: He had not shaved, more tormented by the pain of the sores than by the great failure of his dreams, for he had reached the end of all hope, beyond glory and the nostalgia of glory.
vi: He did not shave, and he was in more pain from the swelling under his arm than from the crushing defeat of his dreams, for he had reached the ultimate point of all belief, which surpassed both glory and the longing for glory.
tr: He had not shaved. He felt more pain from his wounds than from the shattering of his dreams. For he had reached the end of all hopes and had left behind his longing for fame and glory.
es: He was unshaven, more tormented by the pain of his boils than by the immense failure of his dreams, for he had reached the end of all hope, beyond glory and the nostalgia for glory.

en: In accordance with his arrangements there was no music, no fireworks, no pealing bells, no shouts of victory, or any other manifestation that might alter the mournful character of the armistice.
vi: As per his request, the ceremony had no music, no fireworks, no ringing bells, no cheers, and no display of any kind that could disrupt the mournful nature of the armistice signing.
tr: In accordance with Aureliano's wishes, there were no bands playing, no bells ringing, no fireworks, no shouts of victory, nor any other displays that might alter the mournful nature of the truce.
es: In accordance with his own instructions, there was no music, no fireworks, no joyful bells, no cheers, nor any other manifestation that could alter the mournful character of the armistice.

en: An itinerant photographer who took the only picture of him that could have been preserved was forced to smash his plates without developing them.
vi: A traveling photographer, having taken a picture of him—a portrait that could have been preserved—was forced to destroy the entire roll of film without checking each frame.
tr: The glass negatives of the photographer who managed to take the only remaining picture of Aureliano were shattered before the picture could be printed.
es: A traveling photographer, who took the only portrait of him that could have been preserved, was forced to destroy the plates without developing them.

en: The ceremony lasted only the time necessary to sign the documents.
vi: The ceremony almost took just enough time for the ink to dry on the signatures.
tr: The ceremony lasted only as long as it took to sign the documents.
es: The act lasted just long enough for the signatures to be affixed.

en: Around the rustic table placed in the center of a patched circus tent where the delegates sat were the last officers who were faithful to Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: The officers, still loyal to Colonel Aureliano Buendía until the last moment, sat around a rough wooden table placed in the center of the old circus tent, where the delegates were seated.
tr: Around the wooden table in the middle of a patched-up fair tent sat the last officers loyal to Colonel Aureliano Buendia.
es: Around the rustic table placed in the center of a patched circus tent, where the delegates sat, were the last officers who remained loyal to Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: Before taking the signatures, the personal delegate of the president of the republic tried to read the act of surrender aloud, but Colonel Aureliano Buendía was against it.
vi: Before signing the document, the representative of the President of the Republic intended to read aloud the surrender document, but Colonel Aureliano Buendía managed to protest in time.
tr: Before the signatures were affixed, the President's special envoy wanted to read the surrender document aloud. Colonel Aureliano Buendia objected to this.
es: Before taking the signatures, the personal delegate of the president of the republic tried to read the act of surrender aloud, but Colonel Aureliano Buendía objected.

en: “Let’s not waste time on formalities,” he said and prepared to sign the papers without reading them.
vi: "We shouldn't waste time on formalities," he said, then proceeded to sign without reading the documents again.
tr: "Let's not waste time with formalities," he said, and prepared to sign the papers without reading them.
es: "Let's not waste time on formalities," he said, and proceeded to sign the documents without reading them.

en: One of his officers then broke the soporific silence of the tent.
vi: One of his officers then broke the heavy silence that had settled in the circus tent.
tr: Then one of his officers broke the lethargic silence in the tent.
es: One of his officers then broke the soporific silence of the tent.

en: “Colonel,” he said, “please do us the favor of not being the first to sign.”
vi: - Colonel, - the person said, - please, Colonel, could you make sure we are not the first ones to sign?
tr: -Colonel, please, for our sake, don't be the first to sign, he said.
es: —Colonel —he said—, do us the favor of not being the first to sign.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía acceded.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía paused.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia accepted this request.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía agreed.

en: When the documents went all around the table, in the midst of a silence that was so pure that one could have deciphered the signatures from the scratching of the pen on the paper, the first line was still blank.
vi: The document had made a round on the table in such absolute silence that one could read the signatures thanks to the scribbled pen marks on the paper. The first signature spot is still blank.
tr: When the papers circled around the table in an absolute silence where the scratching of the pen on the paper was clear enough to distinguish the letters of the writings one by one, the signature space in the first row was empty.
es: When the document had made a full round of the table, in the midst of a silence so clear that the signatures could have been deciphered by the scratching of the pen on the paper, the first spot was still blank.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía prepared to fill it.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía is ready to sign.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia prepared to fill that empty space.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía prepared to occupy it.

en: “Colonel,” another of his officers said, “there’s still time for everything to come out right.”
vi: - Colonel, - another officer of his said at that moment, - you still have enough time to sign, sir.
tr: Another of his officers interjected, "Colonel, there is still time for everything to be fixed," he said.
es: —Colonel —said then another of his officers—, you still have time to make things right.

en: Without changing his expression, Colonel Aureliano Buendía signed the first copy.
vi: Without losing his composure, Colonel Aureliano Buendía signed the first copy.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, without changing the expression on his face, signed the first copy.
es: Without flinching, Colonel Aureliano Buendía signed the first copy.

en: He had not finished signing the last one when a rebel colonel appeared in the doorway leading a mule carrying two chests.
vi: He had not yet signed the final copy when a young rebel colonel appeared at the door of the tent, holding the reins of a female mule loaded with two chests.
tr: As he was signing the last copy, a rebel colonel appeared at the door, pulling a mule loaded with two crates.
es: He had not finished signing the last one when a rebel colonel appeared at the tent door, leading a mule loaded with two trunks by the halter.

en: In spite of his entire youth he had a dry look and a patient expression.
vi: Despite his youth, he exuded a bitter calmness.
tr: Despite being very young, he had a dry, dull appearance and a patient demeanor.
es: Despite his extreme youth, he had a harsh appearance and a patient expression.

en: He was the treasurer of the revolution in the Macondo region.
vi: He was the treasurer of the revolutionary forces in the Macondo area.
tr: He was the treasurer of the revolutionary organization in the Macondo region.
es: He was the treasurer of the revolution in the Macondo district.

en: He had made a difficult journey of six days, pulling along the mule, who was dying of hunger, in order to arrive at the armistice on time.
vi: This young man had endured six grueling days on the road, dragging the starving mule to arrive in time for the signing of the armistice agreement.
tr: For six days, he had trudged along the road with great difficulty, dragging a nearly dying mule to arrive just in time for the signing ceremony of the ceasefire.
es: He had made a painful six-day journey, dragging the starving mule, to arrive in time for the armistice.

en: With an exasperating parsimony he took down the chests, opened them, and placed on the table, one by one, seventy-two gold bricks, Everyone had forgotten about the existence of that fortune.
vi: With the leisurely manner of someone who is disappointed, the young man unloaded the two chests, opened them wide, and then placed seventy-two gold bricks on the table, one by one. No one remembered that such a vast fortune still existed.
tr: Reluctantly, with a heavy heart, he unloaded the crates, opened them, and laid out seventy-two gold bars one by one on the table. The existence of this fortune had slipped everyone's mind.
es: With exasperating slowness, he unloaded the trunks, opened them, and began placing on the table, one by one, seventy-two gold bricks. No one remembered the existence of that fortune.

en: In the disorder of the past year, when the central command fell apart and the revolution degenerated into a bloody rivalry of leaders, it was impossible to determine any responsibility.
vi: In the tumultuous final years of the war, when the central command was disintegrating and the revolution had degenerated into a bloody brawl among the commanders, it was difficult to assign any responsibility to anyone.
