tr: In the chaos of the last year, when the command center had collapsed and the revolution had degenerated into a bloody power struggle among the leaders, it had become impossible to determine any responsibility.
es: In the disorder of the last year, when the central command fell apart and the revolution degenerated into a bloody rivalry of warlords, it was impossible to determine any responsibility.

en: The gold of the revolution, melted into blocks that were then covered with baked clay, was beyond all control.
vi: The rebels' gold, which had been melted into lumps and then coated with baked mud, was in fact not under anyone's control.
tr: No one had paid attention to the revolutionary gold, which had been melted down, molded, and then covered with baked clay to look like bricks.
es: The gold of the rebellion, melted into blocks that were later covered with baked clay, was beyond any control.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had the seventy-two gold bricks included in the inventory of surrender and closed the ceremony without allowing any speeches.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía ordered the seventy-two gold bricks to be listed among the assets surrendered by the revolutionaries to the government, and concluded the signing ceremony without allowing anyone to deliver a speech.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia wrote down the seventy-two gold bars in the list of transferred items on the surrender document and ended the ceremony without giving anyone a chance to make a speech.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía had the seventy-two gold bricks included in the surrender inventory and closed the act without allowing any speeches.

en: The filthy adolescent stood opposite him, looking into his eyes with his own calm, syrup-colored eyes.
vi: The thin, pale young man continued to stand in front of him, his amber eyes staring directly into his. - And what else, young man?
tr: The young man, dirty and grimy, stood before him, looking at him with his own dull, honey-colored eyes.
es: The scrawny adolescent remained in front of him, looking into his eyes with his serene honey-colored eyes.

en: “Something else?” Colonel Aureliano Buendía asked him.
vi: - Colonel Aureliano Buendía asked.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia asked, "Is there something else?"
es: —Anything else? —Colonel Aureliano Buendía asked him.

en: The young colonel tightened his mouth.
vi: The young colonel gritted his teeth:
tr: The young colonel replied, pursing his lips.
es: The young colonel clenched his teeth.

en: “The receipt,” he said.
vi: - The documents! - the young man said.
tr: -Receipt.
es: —The receipt —he said.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía wrote it out in his own hand.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía handed him the certificate written by his own hand.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia wrote and handed over the receipt himself.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía handed it over in his own handwriting.

en: Then he had a glass of lemonade and a piece of biscuit that the novices were passing around and retired to a field tent which had been prepared for him in case he wished to rest.
vi: After that, he drank a glass of lemonade and ate a biscuit distributed by the nuns; then he went to one of the tents prepared for him in case he wanted to rest.
tr: Then he took a glass of lemonade and a biscuit offered by the young priests and retreated to the field tent prepared for him in case he wanted to rest.
es: Then he took a glass of lemonade and a piece of cake that the novices distributed, and retired to a tent that had been prepared for him in case he wanted to rest.

en: There he took off his shirt, sat on the edge of the cot, and at three-fifteen in the afternoon took his pistol and shot himself in the iodine circle that his personal physician had painted on his chest.
vi: There, he took off his shirt and sat on the edge of a bed. At three fifteen in the afternoon, he pointed the muzzle of the revolver at the circle drawn on his chest with red medicine by the health officer and pulled the trigger.
tr: Upon entering the tent, he took off his shirt, sat on the edge of the cot, and at precisely a quarter past three in the afternoon, he took his pistol and shot himself in the chest, right in the middle of the circle drawn by his personal doctor with iodine.
es: There he took off his shirt, sat on the edge of the cot, and at three fifteen in the afternoon he shot himself with a pistol in the circle of iodine that his personal doctor had painted on his chest.

en: At that moment in Macondo Úrsula took the cover off the pot of milk on the stove, wondering why it was taking so long to boil, and found it full of worms.
vi: At that exact time in Macondo, Úrsula opened the lid of the pot of milk on the stove, surprised at how long it was taking to boil, and found it full of worms.
tr: At that moment in Macondo, Ursula, wondering why the milk on the stove was taking so long to boil, lifted the lid of the pot and saw that it was bubbling with worms.
es: At that hour, in Macondo, Úrsula uncovered the pot of milk on the stove, puzzled that it was taking so long to boil, and found it full of worms.

en: “They’ve killed Aureliano,” she exclaimed.
vi: - They have killed Aureliano, - the old man exclaimed in shock.
tr: -They killed Aureliano! he shouted.
es: —They have killed Aureliano! —he exclaimed.

en: She looked toward the courtyard, obeying a habit of her solitude, and then she saw José Arcadio Buendía, soaking wet and sad in the rain and much older than when he had died.
vi: The old woman looked out into the yard, obediently following her habit of solitude, and immediately she saw José Arcadio Buendía, drenched in rain and looking much older and sadder than when she had last seen him.
tr: Out of a habit born from loneliness, she looked towards the garden and saw Jose Arcadio Buendia, drenched from the rain, looking sorrowful and much older than when he had died.
es: He looked toward the courtyard, following a habit born of his solitude, and then he saw José Arcadio Buendía soaked, sad from the rain, and much older than when he died.

en: “They shot him in the back,” Úrsula said more precisely, “and no one was charitable enough to close his eyes.”
vi: "They killed him for treason," Úrsula judged, "and no one even bothered to close his eyes."
tr: This time, Ursula said more definitively, "They shot him from behind and no one bothered to close his eyes."
es: "They killed him treacherously," Úrsula specified, "and no one did him the kindness of closing his eyes."

en: At dusk through her tears she saw the swift and luminous disks that crossed the sky like an exhalation and she thought that it was a signal of death.
vi: As night fell, through her tears she saw golden round discs glowing orange, whizzing through the sky like lightning bolts, and she thought it was a sign of death.
tr: As the sun was setting, Ursula, through her tears, saw bright circles swiftly passing through the sky like smoke and interpreted this as a harbinger of death.
es: At dusk, through his tears, he saw the swift and luminous orange discs that crossed the sky like a breath, and he thought they were a sign of death.

en: She was still under the chestnut tree, sobbing at her husband’s knees, when they brought in Colonel Aureliano Buendía, wrapped in a blanket that was stiff with dry blood and with his eyes open in rage.
vi: She still sat under the chestnut tree, her head resting on her husband's knee as she sobbed, while they brought her Colonel Aureliano Buendía, his eyes wide open with anger, wrapped in a cloak stained with dried blood.
tr: When they brought Colonel Aureliano Buendia, wrapped in a blanket stiffened with dried blood and with eyes bulging with rage, Ursula was still under the chestnut tree, sobbing as she clung to her husband's knees.
es: He was still under the chestnut tree, sobbing on his husband's knees, when they brought Colonel Aureliano Buendía wrapped in the stiff blanket of dried blood and with eyes wide open in rage.

en: He was out of danger.
vi: He was not in any life-threatening danger.
tr: Aureliano Buendia had escaped the danger.
es: He was out of danger.

en: The bullet had followed such a neat path that the doctor was able to put a cord soaked in iodine in through the chest and withdraw it from the back.
vi: The bullet went straight through his chest to the point where the doctor threaded a medicated string from his chest to his back.
tr: The bullet had followed such a precise path that the doctor, after soaking a cloth in tincture of iodine, inserted it into Aureliano's chest and easily pulled it out from his back.
es: The projectile followed such a clean trajectory that the doctor inserted a cord soaked in iodine through his chest and pulled it out through his back.

en: “That was my masterpiece,” he said with satisfaction.
vi: "This is my masterpiece," he said to him with a pleased expression.
tr: Then, with a self-satisfied air, he said, "This was my masterpiece."
es: “This is my masterpiece,” he said, satisfied.

en: “It was the only point where a bullet could pass through without harming any vital organ.”
vi: It was the only spot where a bullet could pass through without causing any damage to any internal organs.
tr: "That was the only place where the bullet could pass without damaging any vital organs."
es: “It was the only spot where a bullet could pass without harming any vital center.”

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía saw himself surrounded by charitable novices who intoned desperate psalms for the repose of his soul and then he was sorry that he had not shot himself in the roof of the mouth as he had considered doing if only to mock the prediction of Pilar Ternera.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía saw himself surrounded by miserable nuns chanting mournful hymns to pray for his soul to find peace in eternal rest, and he immediately regretted not shooting himself in the mouth as he had planned, and he had refrained from doing so only to mock Pila Tecnéra's prediction.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia saw that he was surrounded by young priests murmuring desperate prayers for the salvation of his soul. It was then that he regretted not having shot the bullet into the roof of his mouth, as he had thought of doing, just to mock Pilar Ternera's prophecy.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía found himself surrounded by merciful nuns who chanted desperate psalms for the eternal rest of his soul, and then he regretted not having shot himself in the palate as he had planned, just to defy Pilar Ternera's prediction.

en: “If I still had the authority,” he told the doctor, “I’d have you shot out of hand.
vi: - If I still had power, - he said to the doctor - I would shoot you without any questioning.
tr: He turned to the doctor, "If I still had the authority, I would have you shot immediately," he said.
es: —If I still had any authority left —he told the doctor—, I would have him shot without a trial.

en: Not for having saved my life but for having made a fool of me.”
vi: Not because you saved my life but because you made me a laughingstock to the world.
tr: "Not for saving my life, but for making a fool of me and making me look ridiculous."
es: Not to save my life, but to make me look ridiculous.

en: The failure of his death brought back his lost prestige in a few hours.
vi: The failed suicide attempt restored his once-faded prestige.
tr: His inability to die restored his lost dignity within a few hours.
es: The failure of death restored his lost prestige in a few hours.

en: The same people who invented the story that he had sold the war for a room with walls made of gold bricks defined the attempt at suicide as an act of honor and proclaimed him a martyr.
vi: Those who had spread rumors that he sold out the war for a house with four walls made entirely of gold bricks affirmed that the suicide attempt was a noble act and thus declared him a martyr.
tr: Those who gossiped that he sold the war for a room with walls built of golden bricks interpreted his suicide attempt as a display of virtue and sanctified him as a martyr.
es: The same people who invented the lie that he had sold the war for a room whose walls were made of gold bricks, defined the suicide attempt as an act of honor, and proclaimed him a martyr.

en: Then, when he rejected the Order of Merit awarded him by the president of the republic, even his most bitter enemies filed through the room asking him to withdraw recognition of the armistice and to start a new war.
vi: Afterward, when he refused the Order of Merit awarded by the President of the Republic, even his mortal enemies came one by one to parade through his bedroom, urging him not to recognize the terms of the armistice agreement and to ignite a new war.
tr: Later, when Aureliano refused the Medal of Merit given by the President, even his arch-enemies crowded into his room, asking him to disregard the ceasefire agreement and start a new war.
es: Later, when he rejected the Order of Merit awarded to him by the president of the republic, even his most bitter rivals paraded through his room asking him to disregard the terms of the armistice and promote a new war.

en: The house was filled with gifts meant as amends.
vi: Moved by the broad support of his old comrades-in-arms, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not dismiss the possibility of fulfilling their wishes.
tr: The house overflowed with gifts from those who wanted to seek forgiveness, wishing him a speedy recovery.
es: The house was filled with gifts of reparation.

en: Impressed finally by the massive support of his former comrades in arms, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not put aside the possibility of pleasing them.
vi: Moved by the broad support of his old comrades-in-arms, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not dismiss the possibility of fulfilling their wishes.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia, influenced by the intense support of his former comrades, did not reject their desires regarding the war.
es: Belatedly impressed by the massive support of his former comrades-in-arms, Colonel Aureliano Buendía did not rule out the possibility of pleasing them.

en: On the contrary, at a certain moment he seemed so enthusiastic with the idea of a new war that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez thought that he was only waiting for a pretext to proclaim it.
vi: On the contrary, there were moments when he seemed so enthusiastic about the idea of a new war that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez thought it would be declared at the slightest provocation.
tr: On the contrary, he became so enthusiastic at the thought of a new war for a moment that Colonel Gerineldo Marquez thought he was waiting for the slightest excuse to declare war. This excuse was not long in coming.
es: On the contrary, at one point he seemed so enthusiastic about the idea of a new war that Colonel Gerineldo Márquez thought he was only waiting for a pretext to proclaim it.

en: The pretext was offered, in fact, when the president of the republic refused to award any military pensions to former combatants, Liberal or Conservative, until each case was examined by a special commission and the award approved by the congress.
vi: Indeed, the provocation came when the President of the Republic refused to grant war pensions to veterans of both the Liberal and Conservative sides until each individual case was reviewed and the war pension law was passed by Congress.
tr: The President said that no pensions would be granted to any of the former warriors, whether Liberal or Conservative, until everyone's situation had been examined by a special commission and approved by the parliament.
es: The pretext was indeed offered to him when the president of the republic refused to assign war pensions to former combatants, whether liberal or conservative, unless each file was reviewed by a special commission and the allocation law approved by congress."This is an outrage," thundered Colonel Aureliano Buendía.

en: “That’s an outrage,” thundered Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: "This is an abuse," Colonel Aureliano Buendía fumed, "People will die of old age while waiting for a response."
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia roared, "This is an outrage!"

en: “They’ll die of old age waiting for the mail to come.”
vi: "This is an abuse," Colonel Aureliano Buendía fumed, "People will die of old age while waiting for a response."
tr: "They will grow old and die waiting for news from the mail," he said.
es: They will die of old age waiting for the mail. "

en: For the first time he left the rocker that Úrsula had bought for his convalescence, and, walking about the bedroom, he dictated a strong message to the president of the republic.
vi: For the first time, he left the rocking chair that Úrsula had bought for his convalescence and paced the room, reading a decisive telegram addressed to the President of the Republic.
tr: For the first time, he got up from the rocking chair that Ursula had bought for him to sit and rest until he recovered, and pacing up and down the bedroom, he dictated a harsh message to the president.
es: For the first time, he abandoned the rocking chair that Úrsula had bought for his convalescence, and pacing around the room, he dictated a decisive message to the president of the republic.

en: In that telegram which was never made public, he denounced the first violation of the Treaty of Neerlandia and threatened to proclaim war to the death if the assignment of pensions was not resolved within two weeks.
vi: In this telegram, he denounced the government's initial violations of the Neclandia armistice agreement and threatened to declare war if the pensions were not resolved within fifteen days.
tr: In this telegram, which was never made public, he condemned the violation of the Neerlandia Agreement and threatened to fight until death if the pensions were not resolved within two weeks.
es: In that telegram, which was never published, he denounced the first violation of the Treaty of Neerlandia and threatened to proclaim a war to the death if the allocation of pensions was not resolved within fifteen days.

en: His attitude was so just that it allowed him to hope even for the support of former Conservative combatants.
vi: His stance was so correct that it garnered the support of everyone, even the approval of the Conservative veterans.
tr: He was so justified that he hoped even the former Conservative warriors would support him.
es: His stance was so just that it even allowed for the expectation of support from former conservative combatants.

en: But the only reply from the government was the reinforcement of the military guard that had been placed at the door of his house with the pretext of protecting him, and the prohibition of all types of visits, Similar methods were adopted all through the country with other leaders who bore watching.
vi: But the government's only response was to increase the number of guards at his door, ostensibly to protect the house and strictly prohibit all visits. Similar measures were applied nationwide to generals under house arrest.
tr: However, the only response from the government was to increase the number of soldiers stationed at the door, supposedly to protect Aureliano, and to prohibit entry to the house for any reason. The same method was applied to other leaders held in custody across the country.
es: But the only response from the government was the reinforcement of the military guard that had been placed at the door of the house, under the pretext of protecting it, and the prohibition of all kinds of visits. Similar measures were adopted throughout the country with other troublesome leaders.

en: It was an operation that was so timely, drastic, and effective that two months after the armistice, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía had recovered, his most dedicated conspirators were dead or exiled or had been assimilated forever into public administration.
vi: It was a timely, brutal, and effective campaign, so much so that two months after the armistice, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía had fully recovered, his closest comrades-in-arms were either dead, exiled, or had completely submitted to the public house arrest.
tr: This was such a timely, comprehensive, and effective operation that, two months after the signing of the ceasefire agreement, when Colonel Aureliano Buendia recovered and got back on his feet, the most passionate and enthusiastic organizers were either dead, exiled, or had adapted to the administrative cadres.
es: It was such a timely, drastic, and effective operation that two months after the armistice, when Colonel Aureliano Buendía was discharged, his most determined instigators were either dead, exiled, or had been permanently assimilated into the public administration.

en: Colonel Aureliano Buendía left his room in December and it was sufficient for him to look at the porch in order not to think about war again.
vi: In December, Colonel Aureliano Buendía stepped out of the bedroom and just a glance at the hallway was enough for him to stop thinking about the war.
tr: Colonel Aureliano Buendia stepped out of his room in December, and a glance at the veranda was enough to erase the war from his mind.
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía left the room in December, and it only took a glance at the corridor for him to never think about the war again.

en: With a vitality that seemed impossible at her age, Úrsula had rejuvenated the house again.
vi: With a vitality seemingly impossible for her age, Úrsula did everything to rejuvenate the house.
tr: Ursula, with incredible vitality at her age, had rejuvenated the house.
es: With a vitality that seemed impossible for her age, Úrsula had rejuvenated the house once more.

en: “Now they’re going to see who I am,” she said when she saw that her son was going to live.
vi: "Now they will know who I am," she said when she was certain her son would live.
tr: When she realized that her son would live, she said, "They will see who I am."
es: “Now you will see who I am,” she said when she learned that her son would live.

en: “There won’t be a better, more open house in all the world than this madhouse.”
vi: "In this town, there will be no house more luxurious, more open to the four winds than this house of mad people."
tr: "There will be no house in the world better, more beautiful, and with doors open to everyone than this madhouse."
es: “There won't be a better house, nor one more open to everyone, than this house of crazies.”

en: She had it washed and painted, changed the furniture, restored the garden and planted new flowers, and opened doors and windows so that the dazzling light of summer would penetrate even into the bedrooms.
vi: She ordered the house to be cleaned, whitewashed, replaced the furniture, refurbished the garden, planted new flowers, and opened all the doors: the main door and the windows, to let the brilliant summer light flood into the bedrooms.
tr: She had the house plastered from top to bottom, painted, changed the furniture, rearranged the garden, planted new flowers, and opened all the doors and windows wide so that the dazzling summer sun could even enter the bedrooms.
es: She had it washed and painted, changed the furniture, restored the garden and planted new flowers, and opened doors and windows so that the dazzling summer light would reach even the bedrooms.

en: She decreed an end to the numerous superimposed periods of mourning and she herself exchanged her rigorous old gowns for youthful clothing.
vi: She decided to stop mourning the successive deaths of her loved ones, and she herself began to wear colorful, youthful dresses instead of the old, shabby ones.
tr: She put an end to the years of accumulated mourning and she herself took off her old clothes and wore colorful garments suitable for the young.
es: She decreed the end of the numerous overlapping mourning periods, and she herself changed the old strict outfits for youthful clothes.

en: The music of the pianola again made the house merry.
vi: Music once again emanated from the automatic piano, making the house more lively.
tr: The music of the lantern once again filled the house with joy.
es: The music of the player piano once again brought joy to the house.

en: When she heard it, Amaranta thought of Pietro Crespi, his evening gardenia, and his smell of lavender, and in the depths of her withered heart a clean rancor flourished, purified by time.
vi: Upon hearing that music, Amaranta deeply missed Pietro Crespi, remembered the ivory-yellow gardenia on his lapel, and the lavender scent that emanated from him. And within her withered heart blossomed a pure feeling, cleansed by time.
tr: When Amaranta heard the sound of the lantern, she remembered Pietro Crespi, his evening arrivals with gardenias in hand, the scent of lavender, and deep within her pale heart, a pure hatred, cleansed by time, was born.
es: Upon hearing it, Amaranta remembered Pietro Crespi, his twilight gardenia and lavender scent, and in the depths of her withered heart, a clean resentment, purified by time, blossomed.

en: One afternoon when she was trying to put the parlor in order, Úrsula asked for the help of the soldiers who were guarding the house.
vi: One afternoon, while tidying up the living room, Úrsula asked the house guards to lend a hand.
tr: One day, while Ursula was tidying up the living room, she asked for the help of the soldiers guarding the house.
es: One afternoon, while trying to bring order to the living room, Úrsula asked the soldiers guarding the house for help.

en: The young commander of the guard gave them permission.
vi: The young commander of the guard allowed it.
tr: The young commander of the guards allowed the soldiers to help.
es: The young commander of the guard granted them permission.

en: Little by little, Úrsula began assigning them new chores.
vi: Gradually, Úrsula asked them to help with other tasks as well.
tr: Gradually, Ursula assigned them new tasks.
es: Little by little, Úrsula assigned them new tasks.

en: She invited them to eat, gave them clothing and shoes, and taught them how to read and write.
vi: She invited them to meals, gave them clothes and shoes, and taught them to read and write.
tr: She fed them, gave them clothes and shoes, and taught them to read and write.
es: She invited them to eat, gave them clothes and shoes, and taught them to read and write.

en: When the government withdrew the guard, one of them continued living in the house and was in her service for many years.
vi: When the government ceased the guard duty, one of those soldiers stayed to serve her for many years.
tr: After the government removed the guards, one of the soldiers stayed at home and served Ursula for many years.
es: When the government suspended the surveillance, one of them stayed living in the house and served her for many years.

en: On New Year’s Day, driven mad by rebuffs from Remedios the Beauty, the young commander of the guard was found dead under her window.
vi: The New Year's festival dawned brightly with the young commander of the guard, driven mad by the reckless behavior of Remedios the Beauty, dying of love right next to her window.
tr: The young commander of the guards, however, went mad because Beautiful Remedios scorned and rejected him, and on New Year's Day, he was found dead under her window.
es: On New Year's Day, driven mad by the slights of Remedios the Beauty, the young commander of the guard was found dead from love by her window at dawn.

en: Chapter 10
vi: Chapter 10
tr: Years later, Aureliano Segundo, on his deathbed, would remember that rainy June day when he entered the bedroom to see his first son.
es: Years later, on his deathbed, Aureliano Segundo would remember the rainy June afternoon when he entered the bedroom to meet his first child.

en: YEARS LATER on his deathbed Aureliano Segundo would remember the rainy afternoon in June when he went into the bedroom to meet his first son.
vi: In his later years, lying on his deathbed, Aureliano Segundo remembered the rainy June afternoon when he walked into the bedroom to see his firstborn son for the first time.
tr: Years later, Aureliano Segundo, on his deathbed, would remember that rainy June day when he entered the bedroom to see his first son.
es: Years later, on his deathbed, Aureliano Segundo would remember the rainy June afternoon when he entered the bedroom to meet his first child.

en: Even though the child was languid and weepy, with no mark of a Buendía, he did not have to think twice about naming him.
vi: Although the child was weak and often cried, bearing no resemblance to anyone in the Buendía family, he did not have to think hard to come up with a name for him.
tr: Even though the child was screaming, lying limp like an empty sack, and bore none of the characteristics typical of the Buendias, Aureliano Segundo decided without hesitation what name to give him.
es: Although he was languid and crying, without any features of a Buendía, he did not have to think twice to name him.

en: “We’ll call him José Arcadio,” he said.
vi: - We will call him José Arcadio, - he said.
tr: "His name will be Jose Arcadio," he said.
es: —He will be called José Arcadio —he said.

en: Fernanda del Carpio, the beautiful woman he had married the year before, agreed.
vi: Fernanda del Carpio, the beautiful wife he married last year, agreed to name the baby that way.
tr: Fernanda del Carpio, the beautiful woman Aureliano had married a year ago, accepted what her husband said.
es: Fernanda del Carpio, the beautiful woman he had married the previous year, agreed.

en: Úrsula, on the other hand, could not conceal a vague feeling of doubt.
vi: As for herself, Úrsula could not hide her vague pain.
tr: On the other hand, Ursula did not hide her vague suspicion.
es: On the other hand, Úrsula could not hide a vague feeling of unease.

en: Throughout the long history of the family the insistent repetition of names had made her draw some conclusions that seemed to be certain.
vi: In the long history of the family, the practice of naming children the same from generation to generation allowed her to draw conclusions that were almost confirmed.
tr: According to Ursula, the repeated use of names throughout the family's long history had yielded almost certain results.
es: In the long history of the family, the persistent repetition of names had allowed her to draw conclusions that seemed definitive to her.

en: While the Aurelianos were withdrawn, but with lucid minds, the José Arcadios were impulsive and enterprising, but they were marked with a tragic sign.
vi: While those named Aureliano were melancholic yet very intelligent, those named José Arcadio were impulsive and bold; but all bore the mark of a tragic fate.
tr: While all the Aurelianos were introverted and sensible, the Jose Arcadios were bold and enterprising, but inevitably ran into trouble.
es: While the Aurelianos were withdrawn but of clear mind, the José Arcadios were impulsive and enterprising, but they were marked by a tragic sign.

en: The only cases that were impossible to classify were those of José Arcadio Segundo and Aureliano Segundo.
vi: The only cases that were difficult to distinguish were those of José Arcadio Segundo and Aureliano Segundo.
tr: The only case that couldn't be classified was the situation of Jose Arcadio Segundo and Aureliano Segundo.
es: The only cases of impossible classification were those of José Arcadio Segundo and Aureliano Segundo.

en: They were so much alike and so mischievous during childhood that not even Santa Sofía de la Piedad could tell them apart.
vi: In their childhood, both were so alike and mischievous that even Santa Sofía de la Piedad could not tell the twin brothers apart.
tr: In their childhood, they were so identical and so mischievous that even Santa Sofia de la Piedad could not tell them apart.
es: They were so similar and mischievous during childhood that not even Santa Sofía de la Piedad herself could distinguish them.

en: On the day of their christening Amaranta put bracelets on them with their respective names and dressed them in different colored clothing marked with each one’s initials, but when they began to go to school they decided to exchange clothing and bracelets and call each other by opposite names.
vi: On the day of the naming ceremony, Amaranta put a saint medallion with their names engraved on each and dressed them in different colored clothes marked with their initials; but when they went to class, they swapped names, clothes, and medallions.
tr: On the day they were baptized, Amaranta put a tag on each of the children's arms and always dressed them in clothes of different colors with their initials embroidered on them. However, after the children started school, they began changing their clothes and name tags, calling each other by the wrong names.
es: On the day of the baptism, Amaranta put bracelets on them with their respective names and dressed them in different colored clothes marked with each one's initials, but when they started attending school, they opted to switch clothes and bracelets and call themselves by the crossed names.

en: The teacher, Melchor Escalona, used to knowing José Arcadio Segundo by his green shirt, went out of his mind when he discovered that the latter was wearing Aureliano Segundo’s bracelet and that the other one said, nevertheless, that his name was Aureliano Segundo in spite of the fact that he was wearing the white shirt and the bracelet with José Arcadio Segundo’s name.
vi: The teacher, Mencho Escalona, who had gotten used to identifying José Arcadio Segundo by his blue shirt, was suddenly confused when he discovered that this boy wore a medallion with the name Aureliano Segundo and that although the other boy claimed to be Aureliano Segundo, he wore a white shirt and a medallion with the name José Arcadio Segundo.
tr: The teachers, including Melchor Escalona, who distinguished Jose Arcadio Segundo by his green shirt, were bewildered when they discovered that Jose Arcadio Segundo was wearing the name tag of the other, who, in turn, wore a white shirt and the name tag of Aureliano Segundo.
es: Teacher Melchor Escalona, accustomed to knowing José Arcadio Segundo by his green shirt, lost his temper when he discovered that this one had Aureliano Segundo's bracelet, and that the other claimed to be Aureliano Segundo despite wearing the white shirt and the bracelet marked with the name José Arcadio Segundo.

en: From then on he was never sure who was who.
vi: From then on, it was impossible to know exactly who was who.
tr: From then on, they could never be sure which one was which.
es: From then on, it was not known for certain who was who.

en: Even when they grew up and life made them different.
vi: Even when they had grown up and life had made them different, Úrsula continued to wonder if at some point they had made a mistake in their confusing game, they would have changed a lot.
tr: Even when the children grew up and life differentiated them, Ursula always wondered if, during that game of deception, the children had mistakenly switched identities permanently.
es: Even when they grew up and life made them different, Úrsula kept wondering if they themselves had made a mistake at some point in their intricate game of confusions and had remained switched forever.

en: Úrsula still wondered if they themselves might not have made a mistake in some moment of their intricate game of confusion and had become changed forever.
vi: Even when they had grown up and life had made them different, Úrsula continued to wonder if at some point they had made a mistake in their confusing game, they would have changed a lot.
tr: Even when the children grew up and life differentiated them, Ursula always wondered if, during that game of deception, the children had mistakenly switched identities permanently.
es: Even when they grew up and life made them different, Úrsula kept wondering if they themselves had made a mistake at some point in their intricate game of confusions and had remained switched forever.

en: Until the beginning of adolescence they were two synchronized machines.
vi: Even in their youth, they were like two synchronized machines.
tr: Until they reached adolescence, they were like two machines operating in perfect harmony.
es: Until the beginning of adolescence, they were two synchronous mechanisms.

en: They would wake up at the same time, have the urge to go to the bathroom at the same time, suffer the same upsets in health, and they even dreamed about the same things.
vi: They woke up at the same time, felt the need to go to the bathroom at the same hour, suffered from the same ailments, and had identical dreams.
tr: They woke up at the same time, rushed to the bathroom at the same time, caught the same illnesses, and even had the same dreams.
es: They woke up at the same time, felt the need to go to the bathroom at the same hour, suffered the same health disorders, and even dreamed the same things.

en: In the house, where it was thought that they coordinated their actions with a simple desire to confuse, no one realized what really was happening until one day when Santa Sofía de la Piedad gave one of them a glass of lemonade and as soon as he tasted it the other one said that it needed sugar.
vi: At home, everyone believed that their synchronized actions were a deliberate attempt to confuse people, but no one understood their true nature until one day Santa Sofía de la Piedad gave one of them a glass of lemonade, and later the other one said it lacked sugar.
tr: The people at home thought they were acting this way to deceive everyone. However, one day Santa Sofia de la Piedad gave one of the twins a glass of lemonade. As soon as the child brought the glass to his mouth, the other one jumped in and said that the lemonade was unsweetened.
es: In the house, where it was believed they coordinated their actions simply to confuse, no one realized the reality until one day when Santa Sofía de la Piedad gave one a glass of lemonade, and he no sooner tasted it than the other said it lacked sugar.

en: Santa Sofía de la Piedad, who had indeed forgotten to put sugar in the lemonade, told Úrsula about it.
vi: Indeed, she had forgotten to put sugar in the lemonade. Santa Sofía de la Piedad recounted this to Úrsula.
tr: Santa Sofia de la Piedad, who had indeed forgotten to put sugar in the lemonade, told this incident to Ursula.
es: Santa Sofía de la Piedad, who had indeed forgotten to put sugar in the lemonade, told Úrsula about it.

en: “That’s what they’re all like,” she said without surprise.
vi: "All the children in this family are like that," she said, not at all surprised. "
tr: Ursula was not surprised at all, "They're all like this," she said.
es: “That's how they all are,” she said, without surprise.

en: “crazy from birth.”
vi: They are crazy from birth. "
tr: "Crazy from birth."
es: “Crazy from birth.”

en: In time things became less disordered.
vi: Time passed and eventually ended the confusion of identities.
tr: Over time, the confusion lessened.
es: Time finished disorganizing things.

en: The one who came out of the game of confusion with the name of Aureliano Segundo grew to monumental size like his grandfathers, and the one who kept the name of José Arcadio Segundo grew to be bony like the colonel, and the only thing they had in common was the family’s solitary air.
vi: The boy in the confusing games, still called Aureliano Segundo, had the robust body of his grandfather, while the other, still called José Arcadio Segundo, had the slender build of the colonel, and the only thing they shared was the family's characteristic loneliness.
tr: At the end of the deception game, the one known as Aureliano Segundo became a broad-shouldered young man like his ancestors, while the one named Jose Arcadio Segundo turned into a thin, bony young man like the colonel. The only common trait they shared was the air of loneliness unique to the family.
es: The one who, in the games of confusion, kept the name Aureliano Segundo became monumental like the grandfather, and the one who kept the name José Arcadio Segundo became bony like the colonel, and the only thing they retained in common was the solitary air of the family.

en: Perhaps it was that crossing of stature, names, and character that made Úrsula suspect that they had been shuffled like a deck of cards since childhood.
vi: Perhaps the swapping of appearances, names, and characteristics was what made Úrsula suspect that from their childhood, they had been shuffled like a deck of cards.
tr: Perhaps it was this contrast in their stature, names, and personalities that gave Ursula the suspicion that the children had been shuffled like a deck of cards since they were born.
es: Perhaps it was this crossing of statures, names, and characters that made Úrsula suspect they had been switched since childhood.

en: The decisive difference was revealed in the midst of the war, when José Arcadio Segundo asked Colonel Gerineldo Márquez to let him see an execution.
vi: The clear difference between the two was evident during the most intense period of the war when José Arcadio Segundo asked Colonel Gerineldo Márquez to take him to watch the executions.
tr: During the most intense days of the war, when Jose Arcadio Segundo told Colonel Gerineldo Marquez that he wanted to watch someone being executed by firing squad, a clear distinction emerged among the children.
es: The decisive difference was revealed in the midst of the war when José Arcadio Segundo asked Colonel Gerineldo Márquez to take him to see the executions.

en: Against Úrsula’s better judgment his wishes were satisfied.
vi: Contrary to Ucsula's thoughts, his wish was fulfilled.
tr: Ursula's opposition was in vain, and Jose Arcadio Segundo got his way.
es: Against Úrsula's opinion, his wishes were granted.

en: Aureliano Segundo, on the other hand, shuddered at the mere idea of witnessing an execution.
vi: On the contrary, Aureliano Segundo felt weak at the thought of being present at the execution.
tr: On the other hand, Aureliano Segundo shuddered from head to toe at the mere thought of watching someone being executed by firing squad.
es: Aureliano Segundo, on the other hand, shuddered at the mere idea of witnessing an execution.

en: He preferred to stay home.
vi: The boy only liked staying at home.
tr: He preferred to stay at home.
es: He preferred the house.

en: At the age of twelve he asked Úrsula what was in the locked room.
vi: At the age of twelve, he asked Ucsula what was in the closed room.
tr: When he was twelve years old, he asked Ursula what was in the locked room.
es: At twelve years old, he asked Úrsula what was in the locked room.

en: “Papers,” she answered.
vi: "Just papers," she replied, "those are Melquíades' books and the strange things he wrote in his later years."
tr: Ursula replied, "Papers." "Melquiades' books and the strange things he wrote in his final years."
es: "Papers," she replied.

en: “Melquíades’ books and the strange things that he wrote in his last years.”
vi: "Just papers," she replied, "those are Melquíades' books and the strange things he wrote in his later years."
tr: Ursula replied, "Papers." "Melquiades' books and the strange things he wrote in his final years."
es: "They are Melquíades' books and the strange things he wrote in his later years."

en: Instead of calming him, the answer increased his curiosity.
vi: The answer that should have reassured him only further stimulated his curiosity.
tr: This answer only fueled Aureliano Segundo's curiosity instead of quenching it.
es: The answer, instead of calming him, increased his curiosity.

en: He demanded so much, promised with such insistence that he would not mistreat the things, that Úrsula, gave him the keys.
vi: He earnestly begged to be allowed to see, passionately promising her that he would not damage anything in there, to the point that Ucsula couldn't resist and had to give him the key.
tr: He insisted so much on entering the room and promised so fervently that he wouldn't damage anything that Ursula finally handed him the keys.
es: He insisted so much, promised so earnestly not to damage anything, that Úrsula gave him the keys.

en: No one had gone into the room again since they had taken Melquíades’ body out and had put on the door a padlock whose parts had become fused together with rust.
vi: No one had entered the room since they carried Melquíades' corpse away; and a rusty iron lock that had long since seized up had been installed on the door.
tr: No one had entered the room since Melquiades' body had been removed. The padlock on the door had rusted and corroded from the inside.
es: No one had entered the room again since they had taken out Melquíades' corpse and put a lock on the door whose pieces had fused with rust.

en: But when Aureliano Segundo opened the windows a familiar light entered that seemed accustomed to lighting the room every day and there was not the slightest trace of dust or cobwebs, with everything swept and clean, better swept and cleaner than on the day of the burial, and the ink had not dried up in the inkwell nor had oxidation diminished the shine of the metals nor had the embers gone out under the water pipe where José Arcadio Buendía had vaporized mercury.
vi: However, when Aureliano Segundo flung the windows open, a familiar beam of light seemed to illuminate the room as it always had; the room was not covered in dust, there were no cobwebs, but on the contrary, everything was clean, perhaps even more meticulously swept and polished than on the day of the funeral, the ink in the bottle was not dry, rust had not dulled the shine of the metal tools; even the embers in the stove where José Arcadio Buendía boiled mercury were still glowing.
tr: Despite all this, when Aureliano Segundo opened the windows, a light entered the room as if it were accustomed to illuminating it every day. There was no dust or cobwebs to be seen anywhere. Everywhere had been swept and cleaned, it was even shinier than the day Melquiades was buried. The ink in the inkwell had not dried, the metal objects had not rusted or tarnished, and the embers under the still where Jose Arcadio Buendia boiled mercury had not yet gone out.
es: But when Aureliano Segundo opened the windows, a familiar light entered that seemed accustomed to illuminating the room every day, and there was not the slightest trace of dust or cobwebs; everything was swept and clean, better swept and cleaner than on the day of the burial, and the ink had not dried in the inkwell, nor had rust altered the shine of the metals, nor had the embers of the furnace where José Arcadio Buendía vaporized mercury extinguished.

en: On the shelves were the books bound in a cardboard-like material, pale, like tanned human skin, and the manuscripts were intact.
vi: On the shelves were books bound in light brown cardboard resembling tanned human skin and even handwritten pages with fresh ink.
tr: On the shelves were books covered with something resembling cardboard, yellowed, and tanned, reminiscent of human skin. The manuscripts had also remained as they were.
es: On the shelves were books bound in a cardboard-like material, pale like tanned human skin, and the manuscripts were intact.

en: In spite of the room’s having been shut up for many years, the air seemed fresher than in the rest of the house.
vi: Although the room had been closed for many years, the air there seemed cleaner than in other parts of the house.
tr: Despite being closed for years, the air in the room was cleaner than that of the other rooms in the house.
es: Despite the many years of confinement, the air seemed purer than in the rest of the house.

en: Everything was so recent that several weeks later, when Úrsula went into the room with a pail of water and a brush to wash the floor, there was nothing for her to do.
vi: Everything was so new that a few weeks later when Ucsula brought in a bucket of water and a broom to sweep the floor, she found she didn't need to do anything.
tr: Everything was so clean that a few weeks later, when Ursula entered the room with a bucket and a brush to scrub the boards, she found nothing to do.
es: Everything was so recent that several weeks later, when Úrsula entered the room with a bucket of water and a broom to wash the floors, she had nothing to do.

en: Aureliano Segundo was deep in the reading of a book.
vi: Aureliano Segundo was engrossed in reading a book.
tr: Aureliano Segundo was dozing, reading a book.
es: Aureliano Segundo was absorbed in reading a book.

en: Although it had no cover and the title did not appear anywhere, the boy enjoyed the story of a woman who sat at a table and ate nothing but kernels of rice, which she picked up with a pin, and the story of the fisherman who borrowed a weight for his net from a neighbor and when he gave him a fish in payment later it had a diamond in its stomach, and the one about the lamp that fulfilled wishes and about flying carpets.
vi: Although the book had lost its cover and had no title, the boy enjoyed the story of a woman sitting at a table picking up each grain of rice with chopsticks; the story of a fisherman borrowing a lead weight from his neighbor to fasten to his fishing net and the fish he later returned to the neighbor carrying a pearl in its belly; the story of a magic lamp that granted all wishes and flying carpets.
tr: Even though the book had no cover and its name was written nowhere, the child still enjoyed what he was reading. He was reading the story of a woman who sat at a table and put nothing in her mouth except rice paste which she ate with a stick, the story of a fisherman who borrowed weights from his neighbor to catch fish and in return gifted a fish from whose belly a diamond emerged, the story of a magic lamp that granted wishes, and flying carpets.
es: Although it lacked covers and the title did not appear anywhere, the boy enjoyed the story of a woman who sat at the table and only ate grains of rice that she picked up with pins, and the story of the fisherman who borrowed a lead weight for his net from his neighbor and the fish with which he later repaid him had a diamond in its stomach, and the lamp that granted wishes and the flying carpets.

en: Surprised, he asked Úrsula if all that was true and she answered him that it was, that many years ago the gypsies had brought magic lamps and flying mats to Macondo.
vi: With an excited look, the boy asked Ursula if these stories were true, and she replied that they were, that a long time ago, the gypsies brought magic lamps and flying carpets to the village of Macondo.
tr: Aureliano Segundo, in astonishment, asked Ursula if these were real. Ursula also said they were true and told him that years ago, gypsies had brought magic lamps and flying carpets to Macondo.
es: Astonished, he asked Úrsula if all that was true, and she replied that yes, many years ago the gypsies brought wonderful lamps and flying rugs to Macondo.

en: “What’s happening,” she sighed, “is that the world is slowly coming to an end and those things don’t come here any more.”
vi: - The thing is, - he sighed, - the world is becoming increasingly impoverished, and therefore, those things are no longer seen.
tr: Then he sighed, "Slowly, the end of the world is coming, such people no longer visit these places," he said.
es: —What happens —he sighed— is that the world is gradually ending and those things no longer come.

en: When he finished the book, in which many of the stories had no endings because there were pages missing, Aureliano Segundo set about deciphering the manuscripts.
vi: After finishing the book with many stories left incomplete due to missing pages, Aureliano Segundo turned to translating the handwritten manuscripts.
tr: After finishing the book, most of whose stories were incomplete due to missing pages, Aureliano Segundo started to dismantle the manuscripts.
es: When he finished the book, many of whose stories were incomplete because pages were missing, Aureliano Segundo set about deciphering the manuscripts.

en: It was impossible.
vi: It was an impossible task.
tr: Deciphering the writings was impossible.
es: It was impossible.

en: The letters looked like clothes hung out to dry on a line and they looked more like musical notation than writing.
vi: The letters looked like clothes hanging on a wire, and overall it resembled sheet music more than a piece of literature.
tr: The letters resembled clothes hanging on a line, looking more like musical notes than writing.
es: The letters looked like clothes hung out to dry on a wire, and they resembled musical notation more than literary writing.

en: One hot noontime, while he was poring over the, manuscripts, he sensed that he was not alone in the room.
vi: One scorching afternoon, while deciphering the manuscripts, the boy felt he was not alone in the room.
tr: One hot afternoon, while Aureliano Segundo was working hunched over the manuscripts, he suddenly sensed he was not alone in the room.
es: One scorching midday, while he was scrutinizing the manuscripts, he felt he was not alone in the room.

en: Against the light from the window, sitting with his hands on his knees, was Melquíades.
vi: Melquiades was sitting there, with his back to the window, hands resting on his knees.
tr: In the light coming through the window, with his hands resting on his knees, Melquiades was sitting.
es: Against the glare of the window, sitting with his hands on his knees, was Melquíades.

en: He was under forty years of age.
vi: Melquiades was sitting there, with his back to the window, hands resting on his knees.
tr: He was not yet forty years old.
es: He was no more than forty years old.

en: He was wearing the same old-fashioned vest and the hat that looked like a raven’s wings, and across his pale temples there flowed the grease from his hair that had been melted by the heat, just as Aureliano and José Arcadio had seen him when they were children.
vi: He still wore the bizarre overcoat and the wide-brimmed hat, sweat dripping from his hair down his temples, exactly as he had appeared to Aureliano and José Arcadio when they were young.
tr: He wore that outdated vest and a hat resembling a crow's wing. The oil he had applied to his hair had melted in the heat and dripped down his pale temples. He looked exactly as he had when Aureliano and Jose Arcadio first saw him in their childhood.
es: He wore the same anachronistic vest and the raven-winged hat, and the grease from his hair, melted by the heat, dripped down his pale temples, just as Aureliano and José Arcadio had seen when they were children.

en: Aureliano Segundo recognized him at once, because that hereditary memory had been transmitted from generation to generation and had come to him through the memory of his grandfather.
vi: Aureliano Segundo recognized him immediately, because that hereditary memory had been passed down from generation to generation, and it came to him from his grandfather's recollection.
tr: Aureliano Segundo recognized him at first glance. Because memories had passed from generation to generation, and his grandfather's memories had been transmitted to him through heredity.
es: Aureliano Segundo recognized him immediately, because that hereditary memory had been passed down from generation to generation, and had reached him from his grandfather's memory.

en: “Hello,” Aureliano Segundo said.
vi: - Hello, sir, - Aureliano Segundo said.
tr: Aureliano Segundo said, "Hello."
es: —Cheers —said Aureliano Segundo.

en: “Hello, young man,” said Melquíades.
vi: - Hello, young friend, - Menkyadet replied.
tr: Melquides replied, "Hello young man."
es: —Greetings, young man —said Melquíades.

en: From then on, for several years, they saw each other almost every afternoon.
vi: Since that time, for a few years, they met almost every afternoon.
tr: After that, they met every day for several years.
es: Since then, for several years, they saw each other almost every afternoon.

en: Melquíades talked to him about the world, tried to infuse him with his old wisdom, but he refused to translate the manuscripts.
vi: Melquiades talked to the boy about the world, trying to pass on his ancient knowledge, but he refused to translate the handwritten pages.
tr: Melquiades would tell him about the world, trying to impart his knowledge to him, but he refused to translate the manuscripts.
es: Melquíades spoke to him about the world, tried to instill his old wisdom in him, but refused to translate the manuscripts.

en: “No one must know their meaning until he has reached one hundred years of age,” he explained.
vi: "No one should know the meaning until a hundred years have passed," the old man explained.
tr: "No one should know what is written there before reaching the age of one hundred," he would say.
es: “No one should know their meaning until a hundred years have passed,” he explained.

en: Aureliano kept those meetings secret forever.
vi: Aureliano Segundo kept these meetings a secret forever.
tr: Aureliano kept his meetings with Melquiades a secret from everyone.
es: Aureliano Segundo kept the secret of those meetings forever.

en: On one occasion he felt that his private world had fallen apart because Úrsula came in when Melquíades was in the room.
vi: There were times when the boy felt his private world was being shattered, because Úrsula had entered the room just as Melquíades was present.
tr: Once, when Melquiades was in the room and Ursula suddenly walked in, Aureliano Segundo thought his private world had been shattered.
es: On one occasion he felt that his private world was collapsing, because Úrsula entered just as Melquíades was in the room.

en: But she did not see him.
vi: But she did not see him.
tr: However, Ursula did not see Melquiades.
es: But she did not see him.

en: “Who were you talking to?” she asked him.
vi: - Who are you talking to? - the old man asked.
tr: -Who were you talking to? he asked.
es: —Who are you talking to? —he asked her.

en: “Nobody,” Aureliano Segundo said.
vi: - Not telling anyone, right? - Aureliano Segundo replied.
tr: -With no one, said Aureliano Segundo.
es: —With no one —said Aureliano Segundo.

en: “That’s what your great-grandfather did,” Úrsula, said.
vi: - Your great-grandfather was the same way, - Ursula said, - He would just talk to himself.
tr: "Your great-grandfather used to do the same, he would talk to himself too," said Ursula.
es: —That was your great-grandfather —said Úrsula—.

en: “He used to talk to himself too.”
vi: - Your great-grandfather was the same way, - Ursula said, - He would just talk to himself.
tr: "Your great-grandfather used to do the same, he would talk to himself too," said Ursula.
es: He also talked to himself.

en: José Arcadio Segundo, in the meantime, had satisfied his wish to see a shooting.
vi: Meanwhile, José Arcadio Segundo found satisfaction in watching an execution.
tr: Meanwhile, Jose Arcadio Segundo had satisfied his curiosity by watching someone being executed by firing squad.
es: José Arcadio Segundo, meanwhile, had fulfilled the illusion of witnessing an execution.

en: For the rest of his life he would remember the livid flash of the six simultaneous shots-and the echo of the discharge as it broke against the hills and the sad smile and perplexed eyes of the man being shot, who stood erect while his shirt became soaked with blood, and who was still smiling even when they untied him from the post and put him in a box filled with quicklime.
vi: All his life, he would forever remember the flash of the six bullets fired simultaneously and the echo of the gunshots reverberating from the surrounding mountains, then recall the sad smile and the startled eyes of the man being shot, who stood proudly as the blood soaked his shirt, who kept smiling even as they untied him from the execution post and placed him in a coffin filled with lime powder.
tr: He would never forget the purple glow of the bullets fired simultaneously, the echoing sound hitting the hills, and the surprised eyes and sad smile of the man being executed for the rest of his life. The man stood upright even when his shirt was soaked in blood, and he was still smiling when they untied him from the post and placed him in a lime-filled coffin.
es: For the rest of his life, he would remember the livid flash of the six simultaneous shots and the echo of the blast that shattered through the mountains, and the sad smile and perplexed eyes of the executed man, who remained upright while his shirt was soaked with blood, and who continued smiling even when they untied him from the post and put him in a box full of lime.

en: “He’s alive,” he thought.
vi: "Still alive," he thought.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo thought, "He's alive."
es: “He is alive,” he thought.

en: “They’re going to bury him alive.”
vi: "They are going to bury him alive."
tr: "They're going to bury him alive."
es: “They are going to bury him alive.”

en: It made such an impression on him that from then on he detested military practices and war, not because of the executions but because of the horrifying custom of burying the victims alive.
vi: He was so terrified, so much so that from that moment on he cursed the military profession and war, not just because of the executions but mainly because of the disgusting habit of burying the executed alive.
tr: This affected him so deeply that from that day on, he hated the military and war, not because of the executions but because the executed were buried alive.
es: He was so impressed that from then on he detested military practices and war, not because of the executions but because of the dreadful habit of burying the executed alive.

en: No one knew then exactly when he began to ring the bells in the church tower and assist Father Antonio Isabel, the successor to “The Pup,” at mass, and take can of the fighting cocks in the courtyard of the parish house.
vi: Thus, no one knew when he started ringing the church bells, began assisting Father Antonio Isabel, who was nicknamed El Cachorro and had replaced the parish priest, and started taking care of the fighting cocks raised in the monastery yard.
tr: No one understood when Jose Segundo began ringing the church bell, assisting Peter Antonia Isabel, who replaced the Hippopotamus, during masses, and taking care of the fighting cocks in the priest's house garden.
es: No one knew then at what moment he began to ring the bells in the tower, to assist Father Antonio Isabel, successor of El Cachorro, at mass, and to care for fighting cocks in the courtyard of the parish house.

en: When Colonel Gerineldo Márquez found out he scolded him strongly for learning occupations repudiated by the Liberals.
vi: When Colonel Gerineldo Márquez found out, he scolded the boy for a long time for learning trades that were condemned by the Liberals.
tr: When Colonel Gerineldo Marquez learned of this, he scolded the young man for engaging in activities opposed and disapproved of by the Liberals.
es: When Colonel Gerineldo Márquez found out, he harshly reprimanded him for learning trades despised by the liberals.

en: “The fact is,” he answered, “I think I’ve turned out to be a Conservative.”
vi: - The problem is, - the boy answered, - it seems I have become a Royalist.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo replied, "To tell you the truth, I think I have become a Conservative."
es: “The thing is,” he replied, “it seems to me that I have turned out to be a conservative.”

en: He believed it as if it had been determined by fate.
vi: You believe that as if it were an affirmation of misfortune.
tr: He said this with a belief as if it were his destiny.
es: He believed it as if it were a determination of fate.

en: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, scandalized, told Úrsula about it.
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía, annoyed, recounted the story to Úrsula.
tr: Colonel Gerineldo Marquez became very angry, very anxious, and explained the situation to Ursula.
es: Colonel Gerineldo Márquez, scandalized, told Úrsula about it.

en: “It’s better that way,” she approved.
vi: - The better, - the old man praised.
tr: Ursula said, "It's better this way."
es: —Better —she approved—.

en: “Let’s hope that he becomes a priest so that God will finally come into this house.”
vi: - Oh Lord, he will become a monk so that finally God will come to this house.
tr: "I wish he were a priest so that God would finally enter through the door of this house."
es: I hope he becomes a priest, so that God finally enters this house.

en: It was soon discovered that Father Antonio Isabel was preparing him for his first communion.
vi: Immediately, everyone knew that Father Antonio Isabel was preparing to conduct the first Holy Communion for the boy.
tr: It soon became clear that Father Antonio Isabel was preparing Jose Arcadio Segundo for his first communion.
es: Very soon it was known that Father Antonio Isabel was preparing him for his first communion.

en: He was teaching him the catechism as he shaved the necks of his roosters.
vi: Father taught him catechism while plucking the neck feathers of fighting cocks.
tr: While they were shaving the necks of their roosters and preparing them for fights, the priest was teaching Jose Arcadio Segundo the necessary knowledge through 'catechism'; as they placed the hens ready to brood into the nests, he explained with simple examples how on the second day of creation, God thought that chicks should hatch from eggs.
es: He taught him the catechism while shaving the necks of the roosters.

en: He explained to him with simple examples, as he put the brooding hens into their nests, how it had occurred to God on the second day of creation that chickens would be formed inside of an egg.
vi: Father used simple, easy-to-understand examples to explain to him while placing the hens in their nests, just as it happened with God on the second day of Creation, the day the chicks were formed in the eggs.
tr: While they were shaving the necks of their roosters and preparing them for fights, the priest was teaching Jose Arcadio Segundo the necessary knowledge through 'catechism'; as they placed the hens ready to brood into the nests, he explained with simple examples how on the second day of creation, God thought that chicks should hatch from eggs.
es: He explained with simple examples, while placing the broody hens in their nests, how God thought on the second day of creation that chicks should form inside the egg.

en: From that time on the parish priest began to show the signs of senility that would lead him to say years later that the devil had probably won his rebellion against God, and that he was the one who sat on the heavenly throne, without revealing his true identity in order to trap the unwary.
vi: From that time, the pastor showed the first signs of senility, which many years later led him to say that perhaps the devil had won the rebellion against God's will, who sits on the heavenly throne, not revealing his form before the eyes of the foolish.
tr: The priest had begun to show signs of senility at that time. This senility would gradually increase, and years later, the priest would claim that perhaps the devil's rebellion against God had ended in victory and that, to deceive the unwary, the devil had hidden his true identity and sat on the throne in the heavens.
es: Since then, the parish priest showed the first symptoms of the senile delirium that led him to say, years later, that probably the devil had won the rebellion against God, and that it was he who was sitting on the heavenly throne, without revealing his true identity to trap the unwary.

en: Warmed up by the persistence of his mentor, in a few months José Arcadio Segundo came to be as adept in theological tricks used to confuse the devil as he was skilled in the tricks of the cockpit.
vi: Forged by the courage of his teacher, a few months later, José Arcadio Segundo had become very knowledgeable in religious tricks to deceive the devil and also experienced in raising chickens.
tr: With the guidance and persistence of his teacher, Jose Arcadio Segundo mastered the theological tricks used to outwit the devil within a few months, just as he had mastered the tricks of cockfighting.
es: Fired up by the boldness of his preceptor, José Arcadio Segundo became in a few months as skilled in theological tricks to confuse the devil as he was in the tricks of the cockpit.

en: Amaranta made him a linen suit with a collar and tie, bought him a pair of white shoes, and engraved his name in gilt letters on the ribbon of the candle.
vi: Amaranta sewed him a linen suit with a collar and tie, bought him a pair of white shoes, and gilded his name on the ribbons tied to the candle.
tr: Amaranta sewed a linen garment with a collar and tie. She bought white shoes. She embroidered the initials of her name in gold on the ribbon that would be tied to the candle.
es: Amaranta made him a linen suit with a collar and tie, bought him a pair of white shoes, and engraved his name in gold letters on the ribbon of the candle.

en: Two nights before the first communion, Father Antonio Isabel closeted himself with him in the sacristy to hear his confession with the help of a dictionary of sins.
vi: Two nights before his first Holy Communion, Father Antonio Isabel closed the holy storeroom to conduct a confession ceremony with him, aided by a book listing sins.
tr: Two nights before the first communion, Father Antonio Isabel locked himself in the room where the church's valuable items were kept with Jose Arcadio Segundo to hear his confession. They had also brought a dictionary of sins with them.
es: Two nights before the first communion, Father Antonio Isabel locked himself up with him in the sacristy to confess him, with the help of a dictionary of sins.

en: It was such a long list that the aged priest, used to going to bed at six o’clock, fell asleep in his chair before it was over.
vi: It was such a long list that the old pastor, who was used to going to bed at six o'clock, fell asleep in the rocking chair before finishing.
tr: The list of sins was so long that the old priest, who was used to going to bed at six, couldn't stay awake until the end and fell asleep in his chair.
es: It was such a long list that the elderly parish priest, used to going to bed at six, fell asleep in the chair before finishing.

en: The interrogation was a revelation for José Arcadio Segundo.
vi: The questions were a revelation to José Arcadio Segundo.
tr: The priest's questions opened up a new world for Jose Arcadio Segundo.
es: The interrogation was a revelation for José Arcadio Segundo.

en: It did not surprise him that the priest asked him if he had done bad things with women, and he honestly answered no, but he was upset with the question as to whether he had done them with animals.
vi: He was not surprised to see the priest ask him if he had been with a woman, and he proudly answered no, but he was bewildered when the priest asked if he had been with animals.
tr: He wasn't surprised when the priest asked if he had done indecent things with women and honestly answered no. But when he was asked if he had done the same with animals, he was confused.
es: He was not surprised that the father asked him if he had done bad things with women, and he honestly answered no, but he was puzzled by the question of whether he had done them with animals.

en: The first Friday in May he received communion, tortured by curiosity.
vi: In May, on the first Friday, he took communion with a heart aching from curiosity.
tr: On the first Friday of May, the communion was held, but his mind was still on the priest's question.
es: On the first Friday of May, he took communion tortured by curiosity.

en: Later on he asked Petronio, the sickly sexton who lived in the belfry and who, according to what they said, fed himself on bats, about it, and Petronio, answered him: “There are some corrupt Christians who do their business with female donkeys.”
vi: Afterward, he asked Petronio, the sickly monk who kept the holy relics, lived in the bell tower, and who, according to rumors, ate fireflies to survive, and Petronio answered him: "It's because there was a vile brother who slept with a female donkey."
tr: He immediately ran to Petronio. Petronio was the church's sickly caretaker. He lived in the bell tower. It was said that he ate bats.
es: Later he asked the question to Petronio, the sick sacristan who lived in the tower and who, according to rumors, fed on bats, and Petronio answered him: "It’s because there are corrupted Christians who do their things with donkeys."

en: José Arcadio Segundo still showed so much curiosity and asked so many questions that Petronio lost his patience.
vi: José Arcadio Segundo was more astonished than ever, demanding further explanations to the point that Petronio lost his patience.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo asked him the question that was troubling his mind. Petronio replied, "There are immoral Christians who do their business with female donkeys." Jose Arcadio Segundo wasn't satisfied with this answer, his curiosity was tormenting him, and he asked so many questions in succession that Petronio finally lost his patience.
es: José Arcadio Segundo continued to show so much curiosity, asked so many questions, that Petronio lost his patience.

en: “I go Tuesday nights,” he confessed.
vi: - I go on Tuesday evenings every week, - he confessed.
tr: "I go on Tuesday nights," he confessed.
es: —I go on Tuesday nights —he confessed—.

en: “if you promise not to tell anyone I’ll take you next Tuesday.”
vi: - If you promise not to tell anyone, next Tuesday I'll take you with me.
tr: "If you promise not to tell anyone, I'll take you next Tuesday."
es: If you promise not to tell anyone, I'll take you next Tuesday.

en: Indeed, on the following Tuesday Petronio came down out of the tower with a wooden stool which until then no one had known the use of, and he took José Arcadio Segundo to a nearby pasture.
vi: Indeed, on the third day, Petronio carried a wooden chair that no one knew what it was used for until now, down from the bell tower, and led Jose Arcadio Segundo to a nearby garden.
tr: Indeed, the following Tuesday, Petronio came out of the bell tower with a wooden stool that no one had known the purpose of until that day and took Jose Arcadio Segundo to a nearby pasture.
es: On the following Tuesday, indeed, Petronio came down from the tower with a small wooden bench that no one had known what it was for until then, and took José Arcadio Segundo to a nearby orchard.

en: The boy became so taken with those nocturnal raids that it was a long time before he was seen at Catarino’s.
vi: The boy was so passionate about those adventurous nights that it was a long time before people saw him appear at Catarino's dance hall again.
tr: The young man became so engrossed in his nightly outings that he didn't appear at Catarino's shop for a very long time.
es: The boy became so fond of those nocturnal excursions that a long time passed before he was seen again in Catarino's store.

en: He became a cockfight man.
vi: He became a cockfighter.
tr: He became a passionate cockfighter.
es: He became a rooster man.

en: “Take those creatures somewhere else,” Úrsula ordered him the first time she saw him come in with his fine fighting birds.
vi: "Take those animals somewhere else," Ursula said when she first saw him bring the beautiful fighting cocks home. "
tr: The first day he came home with fighting cocks, Ursula scolded him, saying, "Take these damn things out of here."
es: "Take those animals somewhere else," Úrsula ordered him the first time she saw him enter with his fine fighting animals.

en: “Roosters have already brought too much bitterness to this house for you to bring us any more.”
vi: Those chickens have brought so much bitterness to this house, and now you want to bring more suffering to us? "
tr: "Cocks have already brought too much sorrow to this house; there's no need for you to add to it."
es: "Roosters have already brought too much bitterness to this house for you to bring us more now."

en: José Arcadio Segundo took them away without any argument, but he continued breeding them at the house of Pilar Ternera, his grandmother, who gave him everything he needed in exchange for having him in her house.
vi: Jose Arcadio Segundo did not argue with his great-grandmother; he quietly took the fighting cocks to be raised at the house of his grandmother, Pilar Ternera, who was willing to indulge him so he could be present at her home.
tr: Without any resistance, Jose Arcadio Segundo took the cocks out of the house, but he continued to keep them at the house of his grandmother Pilar Ternera, who did anything to have him visit her.
es: José Arcadio Segundo took them away without argument, but continued raising them at Pilar Ternera's, his grandmother, who provided him with everything he needed in exchange for having him in the house.

en: He soon displayed in the cockpit the wisdom that Father Antonio Isabel had given him, and he made enough money not only to enrich his brood but also to look for a man’s satisfactions.
vi: Immediately, he demonstrated the knowledge of Father Antonio Isabel at the cockfighting ring, preparing enough money not only to enrich the chickens he raised but also to satisfy his adventurous spirit.
tr: Soon enough, in the cockfighting arena, applying the tricks he had learned from Father Antonio Isabel, he not only increased the number of cocks but also made enough money to consider having some fun.
es: Soon he demonstrated in the cockfighting ring the wisdom that Father Antonio Isabel had instilled in him, and had enough money not only to enrich his breeds but also to procure himself the satisfactions of a man.

en: Úrsula compared him with his brother at that time and could not understand how the twins, who looked like the same person in childhood, had ended up so differently.
vi: At this time, Ursula compared him to his brother and could not understand how two twins who were identical in childhood could now be so completely different.
tr: Ursula compared him to his brother and couldn't understand how the twins, who had been like one person in their childhood, had ended up so differently.
es: At that time, Úrsula compared him to his brother and could not understand how the two twins, who had seemed like one person in their childhood, had ended up being so different.

en: Her perplexity did not last very long, for quite soon Aureliano Segundo began to show signs of laziness and dissipation.
vi: She did not have to ponder this thought for long because Aureliano Segundo soon began to show signs of laziness.
tr: Ursula's astonishment did not last long. Because very soon, Aureliano Segundo began to show signs of laziness and disarray.
es: The perplexity did not last long, because very soon Aureliano Segundo began to show signs of laziness and dissipation.

en: While he was shut up in Melquíades’ room he was drawn into himself the way Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been in his youth.
vi: When sitting in Melquiades' room, he was as contemplative as Colonel Aureliano Buendia in his youth.
tr: When he locked himself in Melquiades' room, Aureliano Segundo, like Colonel Aureliano Buendia in his youth, would withdraw into himself.
es: While he was locked up in Melquíades' room, he was a self-absorbed man, as Colonel Aureliano Buendía had been in his youth.

en: But a short time after the Treaty of Neerlandia, a piece of chance took him out of his withdrawn self and made him face the reality of the world.
vi: But shortly before the Treaty of Neclandia, a chance encounter pulled him out of his inner world, forcing him to face real life.
