es: Trying to escape the nightmare, José Arcadio Segundo crawled from one wagon to another, in the direction the train was moving, and in the flashes that burst through the wooden slats as they passed through the sleeping towns, he saw the dead men, the dead women, the dead children, who were going to be thrown into the sea like rejected bananas.

en: He recognized only a woman who sold drinks in the square and Colonel Gavilán, who still held wrapped in his hand the belt with a buckle of Morelia silver with which he had tried to open his way through the panic.
vi: He only recognized a woman who sold refreshments at the station and Colonel Gavilan, who was still holding the silver-buckled belt from Morelia that he used to carve his way through the horror.
tr: Among the corpses, he could only recognize a woman who sold lemonade in the square and General Gavilan, who still held the belt with a Marelya silver buckle that he had swung to clear a path through the panic.
es: He only recognized one woman who sold refreshments in the square and Colonel Gavilán, who still had the belt with the Morelian silver buckle with which he had tried to make his way through the panic rolled up in his hand.

en: When he got to the first car he jumped into the darkness and lay beside the tracks until the train had passed.
vi: When he reached the first car, he jumped off the train, hid in the darkness, and lay still for a long time in a ditch waiting for the train to pass.
tr: When he reached the frontmost car, he threw himself into the dark void and lay down beside the tracks, waiting for the train to pass.
es: When he reached the first wagon, he jumped into the darkness and lay in the ditch until the train finished passing.

en: It was the longest one he had ever seen, with almost two hundred freight cars and a locomotive at either end and a third one in the middle.
vi: It was an unprecedentedly long train of about two hundred freight cars, each end hooked to a locomotive and another one in the middle.
tr: This was the longest train Jose Arcadio Segundo had ever seen. It had nearly two hundred freight cars and three locomotives: one in the front, one in the back, and one in the middle.
es: It was the longest he had ever seen, with almost two hundred freight wagons, and a locomotive at each end and a third in the center.

en: It had no lights, not even the red and green running lights, and it slipped off with a nocturnal and stealthy velocity.
vi: It had no lights, not even the green and red signal lights, and it sped through the silent night.
tr: The train was pitch dark, it hadn't even turned on its red and green lights. It was moving rapidly.
es: It carried no lights, not even the red and green position lamps, and it slid along at a nocturnal and stealthy speed.

en: On top of the cars there could be seen the dark shapes of the soldiers with their emplaced machine guns.
vi: On the roof of the cars, the dark shapes of soldiers with machine guns ready to fire stood out.
tr: The dark silhouettes of soldiers with machine guns could be seen on the carriages.
es: On top of the wagons, the dark shapes of soldiers with mounted machine guns could be seen.

en: After midnight a torrential cloudburst came up.
vi: In the middle of the night towards dawn, a heavy rain shower poured down.
tr: After midnight, it started raining cats and dogs.
es: After midnight, a torrential downpour broke out.

en: José Arcadio Segundo did not know where it was that he had jumped off, but he knew that by going in the opposite direction to that of the train he would reach Macondo.
vi: José Arcadio Segundo didn't know where he had jumped off, but he was certain that by walking in the opposite direction of the train, he would reach Macondo.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo didn't know where he jumped off the train, but he figured that if he headed in the opposite direction of the train's path, he would reach Macondo.
es: José Arcadio Segundo did not know where he had jumped off, but he knew that by walking in the opposite direction of the train, he would reach Macondo.

en: After walking for more than three hours, soaked to the skin, with a terrible headache, he was able to make out the first houses in the light of dawn.
vi: After more than three hours of walking, thanks to the dawn light, he recognized the first roofs; by then, he was soaked to the bone and had a terrible headache.
tr: After walking for more than three hours with a headache and soaked to the bone, he could make out the first houses of the town as dawn broke.
es: After more than three hours of walking, soaked to the bone, with a terrible headache, he saw the first houses in the light of dawn.

en: Attracted by the smell of coffee, he went into a kitchen where a woman with a child in her arms was leaning over the stove.
vi: Drawn by the aroma of coffee, he stepped into a kitchen; he saw a woman holding a child, bending over the fire.
tr: Unable to resist the smell of coffee, he entered a kitchen where a woman with a child in her lap was sitting by the stove.
es: Attracted by the smell of coffee, he entered a kitchen where a woman with a child in her arms was leaning over the stove.

en: “Hello,” he said, exhausted.
vi: - Hello, ma'am, - he said.
tr: In a weary voice, "Hello," he said.
es: —Good —he said exhaustedly—.

en: “I’m José Arcadio Segundo Buendía.”
vi: - I am José Arcadio Segundo Buendía, right?
tr: "I am Jose Arcadio Segundo Buendia."
es: I am José Arcadio Segundo Buendía.

en: He pronounced his whole name, letter by letter, in order to convince her that he was alive.
vi: He stated his full name, clearly enunciating each word so that the listener would recognize that he was still alive.
tr: To convince the woman that he was alive, he had spelled out his name by pressing each letter individually.
es: He pronounced the full name, letter by letter, to convince himself that he was alive.

en: He was wise in doing so, because the woman had thought that he was an apparition as she saw the dirty, shadowy figure with his head and clothing dirty with blood and touched with the solemnity of death come through the door.
vi: He did something very timely because his mother almost thought he was a ghost when she saw a haggard figure at her doorstep, with hair and clothes matted with blood, and was certain that this figure had just brushed against the might of death.
tr: It was a good thing he did, because when the woman saw this dirty and dark shadow covered in blood, she thought she had seen a ghost and froze as if death had stepped inside the door.
es: He did well, because the woman had thought it was an apparition upon seeing the gaunt, somber figure at the door, with his head and clothes dirty with blood, touched by the solemnity of death.

en: She recognized him.
vi: His mother recognized him and brought him a cloak to wear temporarily while waiting for his wet clothes to dry completely by the stove.
tr: Then she recognized him.
es: She knew him.

en: She brought him a blanket so that he could wrap himself up while his clothes dried by the fire, she warmed some water to wash his wound, which was only a flesh wound, and she gave him a clean diaper to bandage his head.
vi: Then she gave him hot water to clean his wound, which was actually just a superficial scratch, and also gave him a piece of cloth to bandage his head.
tr: She brought a blanket for him to wrap himself in until his clothes dried by the fire; she heated water to clean his wound, which was just a minor scratch, and gave him a clean cloth to wrap his head.
es: She brought a blanket for him to wrap himself in while his clothes dried by the stove, heated water for him to wash his wound, which was only a skin tear, and gave him a clean cloth to bandage his head.

en: Then she gave him a mug of coffee without sugar as she had been told the Buendías drank it, and she spread his clothing out near the fire.
vi: After that, she gave him a cup of black coffee without sugar, as people often told her: those of the Buendía family only drank that kind of coffee.
tr: Then, because she had heard that the Buendias drank it that way, she offered him a cup of black coffee and laid his clothes out in front of the fire.
es: Then she served him a cup of coffee, without sugar, as she had been told the Buendías drank it, and opened his clothes near the fire.

en: José Arcadio Segundo did not speak until he had finished drinking his coffee.
vi: José Acadio Segundo quietly drank all the coffee.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo did not speak until he finished his coffee.
es: José Arcadio Segundo did not speak until he finished drinking his coffee.

en: “There must have been three thousand of them” he murmured.
vi: - Perhaps up to three thousand people, no less, - he muttered.
tr: "There were about three thousand," he murmured.
es: —There must have been around three thousand —he murmured.

en: “What?”
vi: - What is that?
tr: "There were about three thousand," he murmured.
es: —What?

en: “The dead,” he clarified.
vi: - The dead people, - he said.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo said, "The dead."
es: —The dead —he clarified—.

en: “It must have been an of the people who were at the station.”
vi: - Perhaps everyone present at the station was shot dead.
tr: "Everyone at the station must be dead."
es: They must have been all the ones who were at the station.

en: The woman measured him with a pitying look.
vi: With a look of pity, the mother looked at him questioningly.
tr: The woman looked at him as if she pitied him.
es: The woman measured him with a look of pity.

en: “There haven’t been any dead here,” she said.
vi: "Here, not that many people died," she said, "Since the time of the late Colonel, that young man of his, nothing has happened in Macondo."
tr: "No one has ever died here," she said.
es: “There have been no deaths here,” she said.

en: “Since the time of your uncle, the colonel, nothing has happened in Macondo.”
vi: "Here, not that many people died," she said, "Since the time of the late Colonel, that young man of his, nothing has happened in Macondo."
tr: "Since the time of your great uncle the colonel, nothing has happened in Macondo."
es: “Since the times of your uncle, the colonel, nothing has happened in Macondo.”

en: In the three kitchens where José Arcadio Segundo stopped before reaching home they told him the same thing.
vi: Before returning to his own home, José Arcadio Segundo visited three families, and each one told him the same thing: "Not that many people died."
tr: In the kitchens of the other three houses Jose Arcadio Segundo visited before reaching his own, they said the same thing: "No one has ever died." Jose Arcadio Segundo stepped out into the small area in front of the station.
es: In three kitchens where José Arcadio Segundo stopped before reaching the house, they told him the same thing: “There were no deaths.”

en: “There weren’t any dead.
vi: Before returning to his own home, José Arcadio Segundo visited three families, and each one told him the same thing: "Not that many people died."
tr: The trays of the pie vendors were stacked on top of each other.
es: In three kitchens where José Arcadio Segundo stopped before reaching the house, they told him the same thing: “There were no deaths.”

en: He went through the small square by the station and he saw the fritter stands piled one on top of the other and he could find no trace of the massacre.
vi: He crossed the platform, saw the food stalls piled up on each other, and right here he also did not see any trace of the massacre.
tr: There was no trace of the massacre.
es: He passed by the station square and saw the tables of fried foods piled on top of each other, and there too he found no trace of the massacre.

en: The streets were deserted under the persistent rain and the houses locked up with no trace of life inside.
vi: Under the heavy rain, the streets were silent and deserted, all the houses were tightly closed, with no sign of life inside.
tr: The streets were completely empty under the constant rain. It seemed as if there was no one behind the closed doors and windows of the houses.
es: The streets were deserted under the relentless rain and the houses were closed, with no signs of life inside.

en: The only human note was the first tolling of the bells for mass.
vi: Only the church bell calling the faithful to mass was the sole human activity.
tr: The only thing indicating the presence of life in the town was the sound of the church bells calling for mass.
es: The only human news was the first bell for mass.

en: He knocked at the door at Colonel Gavilán’s house.
vi: Stopping right at Colonel Gavilan's door, he called out.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo stopped by Colonel Gavilan's house.
es: He knocked on the door of Colonel Gavilán's house.

en: A pregnant woman whom he had seen several times closed the door in his face.
vi: A pregnant woman, whom he had met many times, upon seeing him, immediately slammed the door shut.
tr: A pregnant woman he had seen a few times before slammed the door in his face.
es: A pregnant woman, whom he had seen many times, shut the door in his face.

en: “He left,” she said, frightened.
vi: "Not here," she replied with a look of fear: "gone back to the countryside."
tr: In a fearful voice, she said, "Gavilan is gone."
es: “He’s gone,” she said, frightened.

en: “He went back to his own country.”
vi: "Not here," she replied with a look of fear: "gone back to the countryside."
tr: "He returned to his homeland."
es: “He went back to his homeland.”

en: The main entrance to the wire chicken coop was guarded as always by two local policemen who looked as if they were made of stone under the rain, with raincoats and rubber boots.
vi: The main gate leading into the compound, surrounded by barbed wire as usual, was guarded by militiamen in raincoats and pith helmets, standing like stone statues in the rain.
tr: The local police were on guard at the main entrance of the chicken wire fence, as usual.
es: The main entrance of the fenced chicken coop was guarded, as always, by two local policemen who seemed like stone under the rain, with raincoats and rubber helmets.

en: On their marginal street the West Indian Negroes were singing Saturday psalms.
vi: On their small streets, the black people from Antidat were singing hymns in unison.
tr: They stood like stones in the rain with their rubber boots and oilskins.
es: In their marginal street, the Antillean blacks sang the Saturday psalms in chorus.

en: José Arcadio Segundo jumped over the courtyard wall and entered the house through the kitchen.
vi: José Arcadio Segundo jumped over the fence in front of the house and entered through the kitchen.
tr: When Jose Arcadio Segundo came home, he jumped over the garden wall and entered through the kitchen.
es: José Arcadio Segundo jumped over the backyard fence and entered the house through the kitchen.

en: Santa Sofía de la Piedad barely raised her voice.
vi: Santa Sofía de la Piedad could only exclaim, "Don't let Fernanda see you."She said, "She just got up."
tr: Santa Sofia de la Piedad, afraid to raise her voice, said, "Don't let Señora Fernanda see you."
es: Santa Sofía de la Piedad barely raised her voice.

en: “Don’t let Fernanda see you,” she said.
vi: Santa Sofía de la Piedad could only exclaim, "Don't let Fernanda see you."She said, "She just got up."
tr: Santa Sofia de la Piedad, afraid to raise her voice, said, "Don't let Señora Fernanda see you."
es: “Don’t let Fernanda see you,” she said.

en: “She’s just getting up.”
vi: Santa Sofía de la Piedad could only exclaim, "Don't let Fernanda see you."She said, "She just got up."
tr: "She will wake up soon," Santa Sofia de la Piedad, as if adhering to a secret agreement, led her son to the 'sitting room'
es: “She was getting up a while ago.”

en: As if she were fulfilling an implicit pact, she took her son to the “chamberpot room.” arranged Melquíades’ broken-down cot for him and at two in the afternoon, while Fernanda was taking her siesta, she passed a plate of food in to him through the window.
vi: As if by an unspoken agreement, she took her son to the room with the chamber pots, fixed the wobbly bed of old Melquíades for him to use, and at two in the afternoon, while Fernanda was taking her nap, she handed her son a plate of rice through the window.
tr: he took it, fixed Melquiades' broken bed, and when Fernanda went to sleep at two in the afternoon, he put his son's meal on a plate and handed it out the window.
es: As if fulfilling an implicit pact, she took the son to the chamber pot room, fixed Melquíades' rickety cot for him, and at two in the afternoon, while Fernanda was taking a nap, she passed him a plate of food through the window.

en: Aureliano Segundo had slept at home because the rain had caught him time and at three in the afternoon he was still waiting for it to clear.
vi: Aureliano Segundo stayed at home because an unexpected downpour kept him there, and until three in the afternoon, he was still waiting for the rain to stop.
tr: Aureliano Segundo had stayed overnight because he was at home when the rain started. Even though it was three o'clock, he was still waiting for the weather to clear up.
es: Aureliano Segundo had slept at home because the rain caught him there, and at three in the afternoon he was still waiting for it to stop.

en: Informed in secret by Santa Sofía de la Piedad, he visited his brother in Melquíades’ room at that time.
vi: Because he was secretly informed by Santa Sofía de la Piedad, he visited his twin brother in the room of Melquíades at this hour.
tr: When Santa Sofia de la Piedad secretly told him that his brother had arrived, Aureliano Segundo went into Melquiades' room to see him.
es: Informed secretly by Santa Sofía de la Piedad, at that hour he visited his brother in Melquíades' room.

en: He did not believe the version of the massacre or the nightmare trip of the train loaded with corpses traveling toward the sea either.
vi: He also did not believe the story about the massacre or the heavy-laden ship carrying the dead towards the sea.
tr: Aureliano Segundo also did not believe the massacre story that Jose Arcadio Segundo told and the nightmarish journey of the corpse-filled train heading towards the sea.
es: He also did not believe the version of the massacre nor the nightmare of the train loaded with the dead traveling towards the sea.

en: The night before he had read an extraordinary proclamation to the nation which said that the workers had left the station and had returned home in peaceful groups.
vi: The night before, a special bulletin had been read to inform everyone that the workers had obeyed the order to disperse from the station and had formed peaceful groups to return to their homes.
tr: The previous evening, he had read in an extraordinary bulletin addressed to the nation that the workers had left the station and quietly dispersed in small groups to return to their homes.
es: The previous night they had read an extraordinary national decree, informing that the workers had obeyed the order to evacuate the station and were heading to their homes in peaceful caravans.

en: The proclamation also stated that the union leaders, with great patriotic spirit, had reduced their demands to two points: a reform of medical services and the building of latrines in the living quarters.
vi: The bulletin also stated that the union leaders, with a high spirit of patriotism, had reduced their demands to two points: improving medical services and constructing latrines in the workers' camps.
tr: The bulletin also mentioned that the patriotic union leaders had reduced their demands to two points: they wanted nothing more than a reform in health services and the construction of toilets in the houses.
es: The decree also informed that the union leaders, with a high patriotic spirit, had reduced their demands to two points: reform of medical services and construction of latrines in the homes.

en: It was stated later that when the military authorities obtained the agreement with the workers, they hastened to tell mr Brown and he not only accepted the new conditions but offered to pay for three days of public festivities to celebrate the end of the conflict.
vi: It was further announced that when the military officials received the workers' petition, they urgently informed Mr. Brown, and that he not only approved the new demands but also allocated funds for a three-day celebration to mark the resolution of the conflict...
tr: In a later statement, it was mentioned that when the military authorities reached an agreement with the workers, they informed Mister Brown, who not only responded positively to these demands but also announced that he would hold a three-day and three-night celebration to mark the end of the dispute and would pay for the festivities out of his own pocket.
es: It was later reported that when the military authorities obtained the workers' agreement, they hurried to communicate it to Mr. Brown, and that he not only accepted the new conditions but also offered to pay for three days of public festivities to celebrate the end of the conflict.

en: Except that when the military asked him on what date they could announce the signing of the agreement, he looked out the window at the sky crossed with lightning flashes and made a profound gesture of doubt.
vi: The only trouble was that when the soldiers asked him when they could announce that the petition had been signed, he looked at the sky streaked with lightning through the window and made an indecisive gesture:
tr: The only event not mentioned in the report was when the soldiers asked when the agreement would be signed, Mister Brown looked at the sky illuminated by lightning and shrugged as if to say, "How should I know?" and said, "When the rain stops."
es: Only when the military asked him for a date to announce the signing of the agreement, he looked through the window at the sky streaked with lightning and made a deep gesture of uncertainty.

en: “When the rain stops,” he said.
vi: - When the rain stops, - he said.
tr: "As long as it rains, we are halting all activities."
es: —It will be when it stops raining —he said—.

en: “As long as the rain lasts we’re suspending all activities.”
vi: - We will suspend all activities while it is still raining.
tr: "As long as it rains, we are halting all activities."
es: While the rain lasts, we suspend all kinds of activities.

en: It had not rained for three months and there had been a drought.
vi: It had been three months without rain and it was now the dry season.
tr: It hadn't rained for three months, and there was a drought.
es: It hadn't rained for three months and it was a time of drought.

en: But when mr Brown announced his decision a torrential downpour spread over the whole banana region.
vi: But when Mr. Brao announced his decision, a downpour spread across the Banana Company region, and José Arcadio Segundo was caught in the rain on his way back to Macondo.
tr: But as soon as Mister Brown announced his decision, rain started pouring down in the banana region as if from buckets.
es: But when Mr. Brown announced his decision, a torrential downpour fell across the entire banana zone, surprising José Arcadio Segundo on the road to Macondo.

en: It was the one that caught José Arcadio Segundo on his way to Macondo.
vi: But when Mr. Brao announced his decision, a downpour spread across the Banana Company region, and José Arcadio Segundo was caught in the rain on his way back to Macondo.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo got caught in this rain while returning to Macondo.
es: But when Mr. Brown announced his decision, a torrential downpour fell across the entire banana zone, surprising José Arcadio Segundo on the road to Macondo.

en: A week later it was still raining.
vi: A week later, it was still raining.
tr: A week later, it was still raining.
es: A week later, it was still raining.

en: The official version, repeated a thousand times and mangled out all over the country by every means of communication the government found at hand, was finally accepted: there were no dead, the satisfied workers had gone back to their families, and the banana company was suspending all activity until the rains stopped.
vi: The official explanation, repeated thousands of times and spread by the government, made everyone believe that no one had died, the workers had contentedly returned to their families, and the Banana Company had ceased all operations during the rain.
tr: The official account of the event had been repeated perhaps a thousand times, spread to every corner of the country through all the communication tools at the government's disposal, and eventually accepted. According to the authorities, there were no casualties; the workers, whose demands were met, had returned to their families, and the Banana Company had suspended its operations until the rains stopped.
es: The official version, repeated and hammered a thousand times throughout the country by every means of dissemination the government could find, eventually prevailed: there were no deaths, the satisfied workers had returned to their families, and the banana company was suspending activities until the rain passed.

en: Martial law continued with an eye to the necessity of taking emergency measures for the public disaster of the endless downpour, but the troops were confined to quarters.
vi: The curfew law continued to be enforced to prepare for the need to implement emergency measures to prevent general damage caused by the relentless rain, and the army remained stationed in Macondo.
tr: Although martial law was maintained to take necessary precautions against a potential disaster caused by the incessant rain, the soldiers withdrew to their barracks.
es: Martial law continued, in anticipation that emergency measures might be necessary for the public calamity of the endless downpour, but the troops were quartered.

en: During the day the soldiers walked through the torrents in the streets with their pant legs rolled up, playing with boats with the children.
vi: During the day, the soldiers, with their pants rolled up to their thighs, walked through the streets where water flowed like a torrent, playing a game of rescuing drowning people with the children.
tr: During the day, the soldiers roamed the waterlogged streets with their pant legs rolled up, floating paper boats in puddles along with the children.
es: During the day, the soldiers walked through the torrents in the streets, with their pants rolled up to mid-calf, playing shipwrecks with the children.

en: At night after taps, they knocked doors down with their rifle butts, hauled suspects out of their beds, and took them off on trips from which there was no return.
vi: At night, after the curfew signal sounded, they searched every house, using rifle butts to break down doors, arresting suspects in their beds and making them disappear.
tr: At night, after getting drunk, they would pound on doors with the butts of their rifles, rouse suspicious individuals from their beds, and take them on journeys of no return.
es: At night, after the curfew, they would break down doors with rifle butts, drag suspects out of their beds, and take them on a one-way trip.

en: The search for and extermination of the hoodlums, murderers, arsonists, and rebels of Decree No. 4 was still going on, but the military denied it even to the relatives of the victims who crowded the commandant’s offices in search of news.
vi: That was the period of hunting down and eliminating the remaining "troublemakers," "murderers, arsonists," punished by Decree No. 4, but the soldiers denied their own acts of arrest and killing to the relatives of the victims when they came to the command offices for information.
tr: The process of hunting down and eradicating the ruffians, subversives, arsonists, murderers, and rebels mentioned in the 4th proclamation continued unabated.
es: It was still the search and extermination of the criminals, murderers, arsonists, and rebels of Decree Number Four, but the soldiers denied it even to the relatives of their victims, who crowded the commanders' office in search of news.

en: “You must have been dreaming,” the officers insisted.
vi: "It must have been just a dream," the officers said.
tr: However, the military authorities denied this situation, telling the relatives of the victims who filled the commanders' rooms to get some news, "You must have been dreaming."
es: “It must have been a dream,” the officers insisted.

en: “Nothing has happened in Macondo, nothing has ever happened, and nothing ever will happen.
vi: "Nothing terrible like arrests and killings has happened, is happening, or will ever happen in Macondo.
tr: "Nothing happened in Macondo." "Just as nothing has happened until today, nothing will happen in the future."
es: “Nothing has happened in Macondo, nothing is happening, and nothing will ever happen.

en: “This is a happy town.”
vi: This is a happy town. "
tr: "How fortunate for this town," they said.
es: This is a happy town.”

en: In that way they were finally able to wipe out the union leaders.
vi: That was how they finished off the union leaders.
tr: By saying this over and over, they eventually swept away the union leaders.
es: Thus they consummated the extermination of the union leaders.

en: The only survivor was José Arcadio Segundo.
vi: The sole survivor was José Arcadio Segundo.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo was the only one who survived.
es: The only survivor was José Arcadio Segundo.

en: One February night the unmistakable blows of rifle butts were heard at the door.
vi: One February night, the unmistakable sound of rifle butts banging on the door suddenly echoed on the porch.
tr: One February night, the door began to shake with the well-known blows of a rifle butt.
es: One February night, the unmistakable knocks of rifle butts were heard at the door.

en: Aureliano Segundo, who was still waiting for it to clear, opened the door to six soldiers under the command of an officer.
vi: Aureliano Segundo, who had been waiting for the rain to stop to leave, opened the door to six soldiers under the command of an officer.
tr: Aureliano Segundo, who was still waiting for the weather to clear, opened the door to the officer and six soldiers. The soldiers were drenched to the bone.
es: Aureliano Segundo, who was still waiting for the rain to stop so he could go out, opened the door to six soldiers led by an officer.

en: Soaking from the rain, without saying a word, they searched the house room by room, closet by closet, from parlor to pantry.
vi: Soaked with rain, silently, they thoroughly searched the house: room by room, cabinet by cabinet, from the living rooms to the pantry.
tr: Without saying a word, they ransacked the house from the living room to the granary; they searched room by room, cupboard by cupboard.
es: Soaked from the rain, without saying a word, they searched the house room by room, wardrobe by wardrobe, from the living rooms to the barn.

en: Úrsula woke up when they turned on the light in her room and she did not breathe while the march went on but held her fingers in the shape of a cross, pointing them to where the soldiers were moving about.
vi: Úrsula woke up when the room lights were turned on, and she did not sigh mournfully while the soldiers searched, but she kept her fingers making the sign of the cross directed towards the soldiers at work.
tr: Ursula woke up when they turned on the light in her room. But she didn't even take a breath until the search was completed. She only crossed her fingers in the shape of a cross and lay there, turning her fingers in the direction the soldiers moved around the room.
es: Úrsula woke up when they turned on the light in the bedroom, and she did not let out a sigh during the search, but she kept her fingers crossed, moving them towards where the soldiers moved.

en: Santa Sofía de la Piedad managed to warn José Arcadio Segundo, who was sleeping in Melquíades’ room, but he could see that it was too late to try to escape.
vi: Santa Sofía de la Piedad had managed to warn José Aureliano Segundo, who was sleeping in Melquíades' room, but he understood that it was too late to escape now.
tr: Santa Sofia de la Piedad found an opportunity to inform Jose Arcadio Segundo, who was sleeping in Melquiades' room. However, he also knew it was too late to escape.
es: Santa Sofía de la Piedad managed to warn José Arcadio Segundo, who was sleeping in Melquíades' room, but he understood that it was too late to attempt an escape.

en: So Santa Sofía de la Piedad locked the door again and he put on his shirt and his shoes and sat down on the cot to wait for them.
vi: So Santa Sofía de la Piedad locked the room door again, and he dressed, put on his shoes, and sat on the bed waiting for them to come.
tr: Santa Sofia de la Piedad locked the door again. Jose Arcadio Segundo put on his shirt and shoes and began to wait for the soldiers.
es: So Santa Sofía de la Piedad closed the door again, and he put on his shirt and shoes, and sat on the cot to wait for them to arrive.

en: At that moment they were searching the gold workshop.
vi: Meanwhile, the soldiers were searching the jewelry workshop.
tr: The soldiers were searching the workshop at that moment.
es: At that moment, they were searching the goldsmith's workshop.

en: The officer made them open the padlock and with a quick sweep of his lantern he saw the workbench and the glass cupboard with bottles of acid and instruments that were still where their owner had left them and he seemed to understand that no one lived in that room.
vi: The officer ordered the latch to be opened and, with the beam of his flashlight swiftly scanning the room, he saw the worktable, the glass cabinet with bottles of acid and the tools still in place as their owner had arranged them, and it seemed he understood that no one was in that room.
tr: The officer told the soldiers to unlock it, then he shone his flashlight around the room, and upon seeing the workbench and the glass cabinet filled with tools and acid bottles left by its owner, he concluded that no one was in the room.
es: The officer had the padlock opened, and with a quick sweep of the flashlight, he saw the workbench and the glass cabinet with the acid bottles and instruments that were still in the same place where their owner had left them, and he seemed to understand that no one lived in that room.

en: He wisely asked Aureliano Segundo if he was a silversmith, however, and the latter explained to him that it had been Colonel Aureliano Buendía’s workshop.
vi: However, cunningly, he asked Aureliano Segundo if he was a jeweler, and he replied that the room used to be Colonel Aureliano Buendía's jewelry workshop.
tr: Still, not letting his guard down, he asked Aureliano Segundo if he was a silversmith. When he learned that it was Colonel Aureliano Buendia's workshop, the officer let out an "Ohoo!" and then ordered the lights to be turned on and the room to be thoroughly searched.
es: However, he cunningly asked Aureliano Segundo if he was a silversmith, and he explained that it had been Colonel Aureliano Buendía's workshop.

en: “Oho,” the officer said, turned on the lights, and ordered such a minute search that they did not miss the eighteen little gold fishes that had not been melted down and that were hidden behind the bottles
vi: "Ah ha," the officer cleared his throat, then he turned on the light and ordered a thorough search of the room, so meticulous that the eighteen unfinished goldfish stored in a tin box hidden behind the acid bottles could not escape their notice.
tr: The soldiers searched so thoroughly that they even found the eighteen fish that had not been melted down, hidden in a tin behind the flowers.
es: "Aha," said the officer, and he turned on the light and ordered such a thorough search that they did not miss the eighteen little gold fishes that had not been melted down and were hidden behind the bottles in the tin can.

en: Is their tin can.
vi: "Ah ha," the officer cleared his throat, then he turned on the light and ordered a thorough search of the room, so meticulous that the eighteen unfinished goldfish stored in a tin box hidden behind the acid bottles could not escape their notice.
tr: The soldiers searched so thoroughly that they even found the eighteen fish that had not been melted down, hidden in a tin behind the flowers.
es: "Aha," said the officer, and he turned on the light and ordered such a thorough search that they did not miss the eighteen little gold fishes that had not been melted down and were hidden behind the bottles in the tin can.

en: The officer examined them one by one on the workbench and then he turned human.
vi: The officer carefully inspected each one on the worktable, and at this point, he was entirely benevolent.
tr: The officer lined up the fish on the workbench, examined them one by one, and then his humane side surfaced.
es: The officer examined them one by one on the workbench and then became completely humanized.

en: “I’d like to take one, if I may,” he said.
vi: "I would like to take one if you agree," he said.
tr: "If you permit, I would like to take one," he said. "
es: "I would like to take one, if you permit me," he said.

en: “At one time they were a mark of subversion, but now they’re relics.”
vi: "There was a time when these goldfish were a symbol of the rebels, but now they are a relic."
tr: Once, these were a sign of death, but now they are considered antiques. "
es: "At one time they were a symbol of subversion, but now they are a relic."

en: He was young, almost an adolescent, with no sign of timidity and with a natural pleasant manner that had not shown itself until then.
vi: He was very young, almost still in his teens, with a natural friendliness that only now became apparent.
tr: The officer was a very young man. He was brave and had a natural courtesy that had not emerged until that moment.
es: He was young, almost an adolescent, without any sign of shyness, and with a natural charm that had not been noticed until then.

en: Aureliano Segundo gave him the little fish.
vi: Aureliano Segundo gave him a goldfish.
tr: Aureliano Segundo gave him one of the fish.
es: Aureliano Segundo gave him the little fish.

en: The officer put it in his shirt pocket with a childlike glow in his eyes and he put the others back in the can and set it back where it had been.
vi: The officer put it in his shirt pocket, and the others he placed back in the tin box and returned the box to its original place.
tr: With eyes shining with childlike joy, the officer put the fish in his shirt pocket. He then refilled the tin with the remaining fish and put it back in its original place.
es: The officer put it in his shirt pocket, with a childlike gleam in his eyes, and threw the others back in the can to put them where they were.

en: “It’s a wonderful memento,” he said.
vi: - That is a priceless memento, - he said.
tr: "I will keep this as a very precious memory," he said.
es: —It is an invaluable memory —he said—.

en: “Colonel Aureliano Buendía was one of our greatest men.”
vi: Colonel Aureliano Buendía is one of our great men.
tr: "Colonel Aureliano Buendia was one of our greatest men."
es: Colonel Aureliano Buendía was one of our greatest men.

en: Nevertheless, that surge of humanity did not alter his professional conduct.
vi: However, that fleeting moment of humanity did not change his usual behavior.
tr: However, this humane sentiment did not prevent the officer from carrying out his duties.
es: However, the blow of humanization did not modify his professional conduct.

en: At Melquíades’ room, which was locked up again with the padlock, Santa Sofía de la Piedad tried one last hope.
vi: In front of the room of old Melquiades, which had just been locked again, Santa Sofía de la Piedad turned to her last hope.
tr: When they arrived at Melquiades' room, which had been locked up again, Santa Sofia de la Piedad murmured with a last glimmer of hope, "No one has sat in this room for a hundred years."
es: In front of Melquíades' room, which was once again locked, Santa Sofía de la Piedad turned to a last hope.

en: “No one has lived in that room for a century,” she said.
vi: "Sir, for nearly a century, no one has lived in this room," she said.
tr: When they arrived at Melquiades' room, which had been locked up again, Santa Sofia de la Piedad murmured with a last glimmer of hope, "No one has sat in this room for a hundred years."
es: “It’s been like a century since anyone lived in that room,” she said.

en: The officer had it opened and flashed the beam of the lantern over it, and Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofía de la Piedad saw the Arab eyes of José Arcadio Segundo at the moment when the ray of light passed over his face and they understood that it was the end of one anxiety and the beginning of another which would find relief only in resignation.
vi: The officer still ordered the door to be opened, he shone his flashlight around the room, Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofía de la Piedad saw the Arab eyes of José Arcadio Segundo when the flashlight beam hit his face, and they understood that it marked the end of one suffering and the beginning of another, which could only be consoled by patient endurance.
tr: The officer had the door opened and shone the lantern's light around the room. Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofia de la Piedad saw the dark eyes of Jose Arcadio Segundo, which were similar to those of Arabs, glinting in the light, and at that moment, they realized that a period of sorrow had ended, but a new period of sorrow, one that could only be endured by submitting and accepting it, had begun.
es: The officer had it opened, scanned it with the beam of his flashlight, and Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofía de la Piedad saw the Arab eyes of José Arcadio Segundo at the moment when the beam of light passed over his face, and they understood that this was the end of one anxiety and the beginning of another that would only find relief in resignation.

en: But the officer continued examining the room with the lantern and showed no sign of interest until he discovered the seventy-two chamberpots piled up in the cupboards.
vi: But the officer continued to search the room with his flashlight, showing no sign of interest until he saw the seventy-two chamber pots on the shelves.
tr: However, the officer continued to move the light of the lantern around the room and did not pay attention to anything until he saw the seventy-two seats piled in the cupboards.
es: But the officer continued examining the room with the flashlight and showed no sign of interest until he discovered the seventy-two chamber pots piled up in the closets.

en: Then he turned on the light.
vi: Then he turned on the light.
tr: Then he turned on the light.
es: Then he turned on the light.

en: José Arcadio Segundo was sitting on the edge of the cot, ready to go, more solemn and pensive than ever.
vi: José Arcadio Segundo was sitting on the edge of the bed, ready to leave, more solemn and thoughtful than ever.
tr: Jose Arcadio, more pensive and thoughtful than ever, was sitting at the edge of the bed, ready to leave.
es: José Arcadio Segundo was sitting on the edge of the cot, ready to leave, more solemn and thoughtful than ever.

en: In the background were the shelves with the shredded books, the rolls of parchment, and the clean and orderly worktable with the ink still fresh in the inkwells.
vi: Further inside were the bookshelves with books whose spines were peeling, rolls of parchment, and the writing desk that was still tidy and clean, with fresh ink in the inkwell.
tr: On the wall behind, there were shelves filled with old books, scrolls of manuscripts, and neatly arranged desks with ink in the inkwells that had not yet dried.
es: At the back were the shelves with the unstitched books, the rolls of parchment, and the clean and orderly work table, with the ink in the inkwells still fresh.

en: There was the same pureness in the air, the same clarity, the same respite from dust and destruction that Aureliano Segundo had known in childhood and that only Colonel Aureliano Buendía could not perceive.
vi: The room retained its fresh and airy atmosphere, maintaining its honor against dust and decay, as Aureliano Segundo had seen in his youth and which only Colonel Aureliano Buendía could not see.
tr: As Aureliano Segundo knew from his childhood and everyone in the house except Colonel Aureliano Buendia noticed, the air in the room was clean, there was no dust anywhere, and nothing was worn out.
es: There was the same purity in the air, the same clarity, the same privilege against dust and destruction that Aureliano Segundo had known in his childhood, and that only Colonel Aureliano Buendía could not perceive.

en: But the officer was only interested in the chamberpots.
vi: But the officer only paid attention to the chamber pots.
tr: The officer was only concerned with the chairs.
es: But the officer was only interested in the chamber pots.

en: “How many people live in this house?’ he asked.
vi: - How many people live in this house? - he asked.
tr: The officer asked, "How many people are there in the house?"
es: —How many people live in this house? —he asked.

en: “Five.”
vi: - Five people.
tr: -Five.
es: —Five.

en: The officer obviously did not understand.
vi: Clearly, the officer did not understand.
tr: The officer probably didn't understand.
es: The officer, evidently, did not understand.

en: He paused with his glance on the space where Aureliano Segundo and Santa Soft de la Piedad were still seeing José Arcadio Segundo and the latter also realized that the soldier was looking at him without seeing him.
vi: He stopped his gaze at the place where Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofía de la Piedad were intently looking at. It was the place where José Arcadio Segundo was sitting, and he also understood that the officer was looking at him without seeing him.
tr: He looked at the void where Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofia de la Piedad were seeing Jose Arcadio Segundo. Jose Arcadio Segundo sensed that the officer was looking at him, but not seeing him.
es: He fixed his gaze on the space where Aureliano Segundo and Santa Sofía de la Piedad were still watching José Arcadio Segundo, and he too realized that the soldier was looking at him without seeing him.

en: Then he turned out the light and closed the door.
vi: Then he turned off the light and closed the room door.
tr: Then the officer turned off the light and closed the door.
es: Then he turned off the light and adjusted the door.

en: When he spoke to the soldiers, Aureliano, Segundo understood that the young officer had seen the room with the same eyes as Colonel Aureliano Buendía.
vi: When he talked to the soldiers, Aureliano Segundo understood that the officer had looked at the room with the same eyes that Colonel Aureliano Buendía once had.
tr: Hearing what the officer told the soldiers, Aureliano Segundo realized that he too saw the room through Colonel Aureliano Buendia's eyes.
es: When he spoke to the soldiers, Aureliano Segundo understood that the young officer had seen the room with the same eyes with which Colonel Aureliano Buendía had seen it.

en: “It’s obvious that no one has been in that room for at least a hundred years.” the officer said to the soldiers.
vi: - Indeed, no one has lived in that room for at least a century - the officer said to the soldiers.
tr: "It is clear that no one has set foot in this room for at least a hundred years," said the officer.
es: —It is true that no one has been in that room for at least a century —said the officer to the soldiers—.

en: “There must even be snakes in there.”
vi: - There are probably only venomous snakes in there.
tr: "God knows, there might even be snakes."
es: There must even be snakes in there.

en: When the door closed, José Arcadio Segundo was sure that the war was over.
vi: As the door of the room closed, José Arcadio Segundo clearly realized that his war was over.
tr: When the door closed, Jose Arcadio Segundo believed that the war had ended.
es: When the door closed, José Arcadio Segundo was certain that his war had ended.

en: Years before Colonel Aureliano Buendía had spoken to him about the fascination of war and had tried to show it to him with countless examples drawn from his own experience.
vi: Years before, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had spoken to him about the joy of war and had intended to prove it with countless examples drawn from his own life experiences.
tr: Years ago, Colonel Aureliano Buendia had told him how war had a fascinating aspect, showing countless examples from his own experiences.
es: Years before, Colonel Aureliano Buendía had spoken to him about the fascination of war and had tried to demonstrate it with countless examples drawn from his own experience.

en: He had believed him.
vi: He had believed him.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo had believed him.
es: He had believed him.

en: But the night when the soldiers looked at him without seeing him while he thought about the tension of the past few months, the misery of jail, the panic at the station, and the train loaded with dead people, José Arcadio Segundo reached the conclusion that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was nothing but a faker or an imbecile.
vi: But that night, when the soldiers looked at him without seeing him, thinking about the tense situation of the recent months, the hardships in prison, the horrors at the train station, and the train carrying the dead, José Arcadio Segundo concluded that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was nothing more than a clown or a coward.
tr: On the night when the soldiers looked at his face without seeing him, Jose Arcadio Segundo, thinking about the tension of the past few months, the misery in prison, the panic at the station, and the train full of dead bodies, concluded that Colonel Aureliano Buendia was either a fraud or an idiot.
es: But the night the soldiers looked at him without seeing him, while he thought about the tension of the past few months, the misery of the prison, the panic at the station, and the train loaded with dead bodies, José Arcadio Segundo concluded that Colonel Aureliano Buendía was nothing more than a fraud or an idiot.

en: He could not understand why he had needed so many words to explain what he felt in war because one was enough: fear.
vi: He did not understand that he had to use too many words to describe what he felt in the war, not knowing that just one word was enough to express it. That word was fear.
tr: He couldn't understand why the Colonel had spoken at such length to describe what he had heard in the war.
es: He couldn't understand why so many words were needed to explain what one felt in war, when a single word sufficed: fear.

en: In Melquíades’ room, on the other hand, protected by the supernatural light, by the sound of the rain, by the feeling of being invisible, he found the repose that he had not had for one single instant during his previous life, and the only fear that remained was that they would bury him alive.
vi: In contrast, in Melquíades' room, protected by supernatural light, by the sound of the rain, and by the feeling of being invisible, José Arcadio Segundo lived in a rest he had never had before, with a lingering fear that he would be buried alive.
tr: Because a single word was enough: Fear, yet in Melquiades' room, with the supernatural light, the sound of rain, and the sense of being invisible, he felt a peace he had never experienced for even a moment in his entire life until that day. Now he was only afraid of being buried alive.
es: In Melquíades' room, however, protected by the supernatural light, the sound of the rain, and the sensation of being invisible, he found the rest he had never had for a single moment in his previous life, and the only fear that persisted was that of being buried alive.

en: He told Santa Sofía de la Piedad about it when she brought him his daily meals and she promised to struggle to stay alive even beyond her natural forces in order to make sure that they would bury him dead.
vi: He shared this with Santa Sofía de la Piedad, who brought him food twice a day, and she promised him that she would live until her strength gave out to ensure that he would be buried only when he was truly dead.
tr: He told Santa Sofia de la Piedad, who brought him his food, about this fear. His mother also promised to outlive him, defying natural forces, to ensure he would be buried after he died.
es: He told this to Santa Sofía de la Piedad, who brought him his daily meals, and she promised to fight to stay alive beyond her strength to ensure that he would be buried dead.

en: Free from all fear, José Arcadio Segundo dedicated himself then to peruse the manuscripts of Melquíades many times, and with so much more pleasure when he could not understand them.
vi: Freed from all fears, José Arcadio Segundo buried himself in reading Melquíades' parchments, and the more enthusiastically he read, the less he understood them.
tr: Free from all fears, Jose Arcadio Segundo devoted himself to reading Melquiades' manuscripts. When he couldn't decipher the writings, he would tackle the task with even more enthusiasm.
es: Free from all fear, José Arcadio Segundo then dedicated himself to reviewing Melquíades' parchments many times, and all the more content the less he understood them.

en: He became accustomed to the sound of the rain, which after two months had become another form of silence, and the only thing that disturbed his solitude was the coming and going of Santa Sofía de la Piedad.
vi: Having become accustomed to the constant rain, which after two months had become a new form of tranquility, the only thing that disturbed his solitude was the comings and goings of Santa Sofía de la Piedad.
tr: He got used to the sound of the rain, which had been falling incessantly for two months and had become another form of silence. The only thing that disturbed his solitude was the comings and goings of Santa Sofia de la Piedad.
es: Accustomed to the sound of the rain, which after two months became a new form of silence, the only thing that disturbed his solitude were the comings and goings of Santa Sofía de la Piedad.

en: He asked her, therefore, to leave the meals on the windowsill and padlock the door.
vi: So he asked her to leave his food on the window sill and lock the door from the outside.
tr: Therefore, he told his mother to leave the food by the window and to put a padlock on the door.
es: That is why he begged her to leave the food on the windowsill and lock the door.

en: The rest of the family forgot about him including Fernanda, who did not mind leaving him there when she found that the soldiers had seen him without recognizing him.
vi: The others in the family had forgotten him, including Fernanda, who disapproved of him living there when she knew that the soldiers had looked at him without seeing him.
tr: After hearing that the soldiers did not see him even though they looked at him, the household, including Fernanda who did not object to her brother-in-law staying there, forgot about him.
es: The rest of the family forgot about him, including Fernanda, who had no problem leaving him there when she learned that the soldiers had seen him without recognizing him.

en: After six months of enclosure, since the soldiers had left Macondo Aureliano Segundo removed the padlock, looking for someone he could talk to until the rain stopped.
vi: When José Arcadio Segundo had been locked in the room for six months, and now that the soldiers had withdrawn from Macondo, Aureliano Segundo unlatched the door to find someone to talk to while waiting for the rain to stop.
tr: Six months after the soldiers left Macondo, Aureliano Segundo unlocked the door because he was looking for someone to chat with until the rains stopped.
es: After six months of confinement, seeing that the soldiers had left Macondo, Aureliano Segundo removed the lock looking for someone to talk to while the rain passed.

en: As soon as he opened the door he felt the pestilential attack of the chamberpots, which were placed on the floor and all of which had been used several times.
vi: Upon opening the door, he was overwhelmed by the stench from the chamber pots full of excrement and urine placed on the floor.
tr: As soon as he opened the door, he was confronted with the nauseating smell of chamber pots. All the chamber pots were lined up on the floor, and all had been used several times.
es: From the moment he opened the door, he felt assaulted by the stench of the chamber pots that were placed on the floor, all of them often used.

en: José Arcadio Segundo, devoured by baldness, indifferent to the air that had been sharpened by the nauseating vapors, was still reading and rereading the unintelligible parchments.
vi: José Arcadio Segundo, suffering from skin sores, unaware of the gloomy scene caused by the rain, was still engrossed in reading the incomprehensible writings on the parchments.
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo, whose hair had almost completely fallen out, was reading and rereading the writings that could not be erased, without paying attention to the nauseating smells.
es: José Arcadio Segundo, devoured by hair, indifferent to the air thickened by nauseating vapors, continued reading and rereading the unintelligible parchments.

en: He was illuminated by a seraphic glow.
vi: He was illuminated by a beam of angelic light.
tr: He was illuminated by a light similar to a halo surrounding angels.
es: He was illuminated by a seraphic glow.

en: He scarcely raised his eyes when he heard the door open, but that look was enough for his brother to see repeated in it the irreparable fate of his great-grandfather.
vi: It seemed that as soon as he looked up when he heard the door open, that glance was enough for his twin brother to see the inherent fate of their great-great-grandfather repeated in him.
tr: When he heard the door open, he only lifted his head and looked. But this look was enough for his brother to see the incurable fate of their great-grandfather in his eyes.
es: He barely looked up when he felt the door open, but his brother needed only that glance to see the irreparable destiny of their great-grandfather repeated in it.

en: “There were more than three thousand of them,” was all that José Arcadio Segundo said.
vi: - More than three thousand people, - that is all Hôsê Accađiô Sêgunđô said. -
tr: Jose Arcadio Segundo, "There were more than three thousand," he says, and he would say no more.
es: —There were more than three thousand —was all that José Arcadio Segundo said—.

en: “I’m sure now that they were everybody who had been at the station.”
vi: Now I am absolutely certain that those were all the people present outside the station.
tr: "I now know for certain that everyone at the station is dead."
es: Now I am sure that they were all the ones who were at the station.

en: Chapter 16
vi: Chapter 16
tr: "I now know for certain that everyone at the station is dead."
es: Now I am sure that they were all the ones who were at the station.

en: IT RAINED FOR four years, eleven months, and two days.
vi: Rain for four years, eleven months, and two days.
tr: The rain lasted exactly four years, eleven months, and two days.
es: It rained for four years, eleven months, and two days.

en: There were periods of drizzle during which everyone put on his full dress and a convalescent look to celebrate the clearing, but the people soon grew accustomed to interpret the pauses as a sign of redoubled rain.
vi: There were times when the drizzle was so persistent that everyone wore ceremonial clothes and put on a solemn face to pray for the rain to stop, but soon people got used to the brief dry spells that foretold even more prolonged rains to come.
tr: At times it would lighten, turning into a drizzle, and then everyone would dress up, preparing to celebrate the improvement in the weather. But it was soon learned that these drizzly pauses were harbingers of a rain a thousand times worse than before.
es: There were periods of drizzle when everyone put on their Sunday best and wore a convalescent face to celebrate the clearing, but soon they got used to interpreting the pauses as announcements of a resurgence.

en: The sky crumbled into a set of destructive storms and out of the north came hurricanes that scattered roofs about and knocked down walls and uprooted every last plant of the banana groves.
vi: The sky seemed to break open in a thunderous storm, and from the north, gales came, tearing off roofs, toppling walls, and sweeping away the last remaining vines in the fields.
tr: The air was filling and darkening with storms that destroyed everything they touched, and the face of the sky was wrinkling. The hurricane coming from the north was blowing off roofs, tearing down walls, and uprooting and toppling all the banana trees in the orchards without leaving a single one standing.
es: The sky was unpaved in storms of destruction, and the north sent hurricanes that chipped roofs and knocked down walls, and uprooted the last vines of the plantations.

en: Just as during the insomnia plague, as Úrsula came to remember during those days, the calamity itself inspired defenses against boredom.
vi: Just like during the insomnia plague that Ursula now recalled, it seemed this calamity had come to punish them with a monotonous life.
tr: Ursula remembered the insomnia epidemic. Because during the rain, just like during the insomnia epidemic, the disaster forced people to resist boredom.
es: As happened during the insomnia plague, which Úrsula remembered during those days, the calamity itself inspired defenses against boredom.

en: Aureliano Segundo was one of those who worked hardest not to be conquered by idleness.
vi: Aureliano Segundo was one of those who worked the hardest to avoid falling into idleness.
tr: One of those who worked the hardest to avoid idleness was Aureliano Segundo. On the night Mister Brown started the storm, Aureliano Segundo had stopped by the house for something trivial.
es: Aureliano Segundo was one of those who did the most to not succumb to idleness.

en: He had gone home for some minor matter on the night that mr Brown unleashed the storm, and Fernanda tried to help him with a half-blown-out umbrella that she found in a closet.
vi: He returned home to take on some chores on the night when Mr. Brown summoned the storm that caused the rain and wind, and Fernanda found him an old umbrella in a cupboard.
tr: When the rain started, Fernanda took out an umbrella with half of its wires broken, which she found at the bottom of a cupboard, and brought it to her husband, who said, "I don't need it."
es: He had gone to the house for some casual matter the night Mr. Brown summoned the storm, and Fernanda tried to help him with a half-broken umbrella she found in a closet.

en: “I don’t need it,” he said.
vi: "No need," he said, "I'll stay here until the rain stops.
tr: "I'll stay until the weather clears up," he said.
es: “No need,” he said.

en: “I’ll stay until it clears.”
vi: "No need," he said, "I'll stay here until the rain stops.
tr: "I'll stay until the weather clears up," he said.
es: “I’ll stay here until it clears up.”

en: That was not, of course, an ironclad promise, but he would accomplish it literally.
vi: "Of course, it wasn't a promise set in stone, but he did exactly that.
tr: Undoubtedly, it was not a binding promise, but even so, Aureliano Segundo felt the need to keep his word.
es: It was not, of course, an unavoidable commitment, but he almost fulfilled it to the letter.

en: Since his clothes were at Petra Cotes’s, every three days he would take off what he had on and wait in his shorts until they washed.
vi: Since his clothes were all at Petra Cotes' house, he changed his outer clothes every three days and wore shorts until his laundry dried.
tr: Since his clothes were at Petra Cotes' house, every three days he would take off what he was wearing and wait in his underwear until they were washed and dried.
es: Since his clothes were at Petra Cotes's house, he took off the ones he was wearing every three days and waited in his underwear while they were washed.

en: In order not to become bored, he dedicated himself to the task of repairing the many things that needed fixing in the house.
vi: To avoid boredom, he threw himself into repairing countless broken things around the house: sometimes fixing a hinge, oiling a lock, tightening screws, or straightening nails.
tr: To keep himself from getting bored, he got involved in a bunch of repair jobs around the house.
es: To avoid getting bored, he devoted himself to fixing the numerous defects in the house.

en: He adjusted hinges, oiled locks, screwed knockers tight, and planed doorjambs.
vi: To avoid boredom, he threw himself into repairing countless broken things around the house: sometimes fixing a hinge, oiling a lock, tightening screws, or straightening nails.
tr: He fixed the hinges, oiled the locks, tightened the loose doorknobs, and planed the swollen doors.
es: He adjusted hinges, oiled locks, screwed bolts, and leveled latches.

en: For several months he was seen wandering about with a toolbox that the gypsies must have left behind in José Arcadio Buendía’s days, and no one knew whether because of the involuntary exercise, the winter tedium or the imposed abstinence, but his belly was deflating little by little like a wineskin and his face of a beatific tortoise was becoming less bloodshot and his double chin less prominent until he became less pachydermic all over and was able to tie his own shoes again.
vi: For several months, he was seen wandering around the house with a set of tools left behind by the gypsies since the time of old José Arcadio Buendía, and no one knew if he did it out of a reluctant need to stay active, because the winter made him bored, or because he forced himself to indulge in moderate play. He became so passionate about working that his once-bulging belly shrank, wrinkling like a piece of leather, and his once-handsome, turtle-like face lost its charm, his sagging chin firmed up until he was less obese and could bend down to tie his shoes again.
tr: The toolbox from the time of Jose Arcadio Buendia, acquired from the gypsies, did not leave Aureliano Segundo's hands for several months. Whether it was from moving around a lot to fix this and that, from the boredom brought by winter, or from the mandatory diet, it is unknown, but his belly started to shrink little by little, the purpleness of his face, which resembled a turtle's back, began to fade, his double chin started to melt away, and he stopped resembling an elephant and reached the point where he could tie his own shoes.
es: For several months he was seen wandering with a toolbox that the gypsies must have forgotten in the times of José Arcadio Buendía, and no one knew if it was due to the involuntary exercise, the winter boredom, or the enforced abstinence, but his belly gradually deflated like a wineskin, and his beatific turtle face became less sanguine and his double chin less protuberant, until he ended up being less pachydermic and could tie his shoelaces again.

en: Watching him putting in latches and repairing clocks, Fernanda wondered whether or not he too might be falling into the vice of building so that he could take apart like Colonel Aureliano Buendía and his little gold fishes, Amaranta and her shroud and her buttons, José Arcadio and the parchments, and Úrsula and her memories.
vi: As she watched him fix hinges and dismantle clocks, Fernanda wondered if her husband was also afflicted with the compulsion to create and destroy, like Colonel Aureliano Buendía making goldfish, like Amaranta sewing buttons and weaving shrouds, like José Arcadio Segundo reading the inscriptions on parchment, and like Ursula reminiscing about her life.
tr: As Fernanda watched him install latches on doors and repair clocks, she wondered if her husband would enter into a similar cycle of endless tinkering with home repairs, just like Colonel Aureliano Buendia with his fish that he melted and remade, Amaranta with her never-ending shroud and the buttons she endlessly sewed and resewed, Jose Arcadio with the manuscripts he tried to decipher, and Ursula with her memories.
es: Seeing him install doorknobs and disconnect clocks, Fernanda wondered if he was also falling into the vice of doing to undo, like Colonel Aureliano Buendía with his goldfish, Amaranta with the buttons and the shroud, José Arcadio Segundo with the parchments, and Úrsula with her memories.

en: But that was not the case.
vi: But it wasn't quite like that.
tr: The worst part is that the rain damages everything and made this repair necessary.
es: But it wasn’t true.

en: The worst part was that the rain was affecting everything and the driest of machines would have flowers popping out among their gears if they were not oiled every three days, and the threads in brocades rusted, and wet clothing would break out in a rash of saffron-colored moss.
vi: The worst part was that the rain changed everything; even the driest machines grew moldy if left unoiled for three days, steel wires and copper nets rusted, and wet clothes grew green moss.
tr: If it wasn't oiled every three days, it seemed like buds would sprout between the gears of the driest machines, rust stains would form on embroidery threads, and wet clothes would quickly develop saffron-colored mold.
es: The problem was that the rain disrupted everything, and the driest machines sprouted flowers among the gears if they weren’t oiled every three days, and the threads of the brocades rusted and saffron algae grew on the wet clothes.

en: The air was so damp that fish could have come in through the doors and swum out the windows, floating through the atmosphere in the rooms.
vi: The air was so damp that fish could swim through it to enter the house through the front door and exit through the windows.
tr: The air was so humid that fish would almost swim in through the doors, float in the room's air, and exit through the windows.
es: The atmosphere was so humid that fish could have entered through the doors and exited through the windows, navigating through the air of the rooms.

en: One morning Úrsula woke up feeling that she was reaching her end in a placid swoon and she had already asked them to take her to Father Antonio Isabel, even if it had to be on a stretcher, when Santa Sofía de la Piedad discovered that her back was paved with leeches.
vi: One morning, Ursula woke up feeling faint and demanded to be taken to Father Antonio Isabel even if she had to be carried on a stretcher, and at that moment, Santa Sofía de la Piedad saw leeches all over her back.
tr: One morning, when Ursula woke up, she felt that her end had come, that she would faint quietly and never wake up again, and she told them to take her to Father Antonio Isabel even if she had to be carried on a stretcher. When Santa Sofia de la Piedad propped her up slightly, she saw that leeches had covered her back from top to bottom.
es: One morning Úrsula woke up feeling she was ending in a swoon of placidity, and she had already asked for Father Antonio Isabel to be brought to her, even if on a stretcher, when Santa Sofía de la Piedad discovered that her back was paved with leeches.

en: She took them off one by one, crushing them with a firebrand before they bled her to death.
vi: They had to use red-hot embers to detach each leech before they sucked all her blood.
tr: She removed the leeches one by one so they wouldn't drain the woman's blood, crushed them with tongs, and killed them.
es: They removed them one by one, burning them with embers, before they finished draining her blood.

en: It was necessary to dig canals to get the water out of the house and rid it of the frogs and snails so that they could dry the floors and take the bricks from under the bedposts and walk in shoes once more.
vi: They had to dig many trenches to drain the water from the house and sweep away the toads and snails to dry the floors, remove the bricks under the bed legs, and once again wear shoes indoors.
tr: To drain the water, it was necessary to dig channels, dry the boards, remove the bricks from under the beds, and to be able to walk around in shoes again, it was also necessary to get the snails and frogs out.
es: It was necessary to dig channels to drain the house, and to clear it of toads and snails, so that the floors could dry, the bricks could be removed from the bed legs, and they could walk with shoes again.

en: Occupied with the many small details that called for his attention, Aureliano Segundo did not realize that he was getting old until one afternoon when he found himself contemplating the premature dusk from a rocking chair and thinking about Petra Cotes without quivering.
vi: Absorbed in the many small tasks that fascinated him, Aureliano Segundo didn't realize he was aging until one afternoon when he found himself sitting in a rocking chair, watching the early evening with indifference, thinking of Petra Cotes.
tr: Aureliano Segundo, who had plunged into a heap of trivial tasks he needed to do, did not realize he had aged until one evening while watching the sunset, he thought of Petra Cotes without his heart and flesh stirring.
es: Busy with the numerous minutiae that demanded his attention, Aureliano Segundo didn’t realize he was getting old until one afternoon when he found himself contemplating the early sunset from a rocking chair, and thinking of Petra Cotes without shuddering.

en: There would have been no problem in going back to Fernanda’s insipid love, because her beauty had become solemn with age, but the rain had spared him from all emergencies of passion and had filled him with the spongy serenity of a lack of appetite.
vi: Nothing prevented him from returning to the tepid love of Fernanda, whose beauty had now faded behind the maturity of age, but the rain had freed him from all sudden passions and instilled in him a calm, unexcited love.
tr: Returning to the broad love of Fernanda, whose beauty had faded as she aged, was not difficult. However, the rain had dried Aureliano Segundo to the bone, detached him from passion, and dragged him into a solemnity born of indifference.
es: He would have had no problem returning to the insipid love of Fernanda, whose beauty had settled with maturity, but the rain had saved him from any passionate emergency, and had infused him with the spongy serenity of lack of appetite.

en: He amused himself thinking about the things that he could have done in other times with that rain which had already lasted a year.
vi: He enjoyed the incessant rain that had lasted almost a handful of years, thinking about the things he could have done in the past when he was one of the first to bring corrugated iron to Macondo, before the banana company made it fashionable, and he used it only to roof Petra Cotes' bedroom, relishing the intimate feeling it gave him as the rain pattered on it.
tr: He was thinking about the rain that had been falling for a year now, and at other times he would have enjoyed imagining the things he could do with this rain.
es: He amused himself thinking about the things he could have done in another time with that rain that was already going on for a year.

en: He had been one of the first to bring zinc sheets to Macondo, much earlier than their popularization by the banana company, simply to roof Petra Cotes’s bedroom with them and to take pleasure in the feeling of deep intimacy that the sprinkling of the rain produced at that time.
vi: He enjoyed the incessant rain that had lasted almost a handful of years, thinking about the things he could have done in the past when he was one of the first to bring corrugated iron to Macondo, before the banana company made it fashionable, and he used it only to roof Petra Cotes' bedroom, relishing the intimate feeling it gave him as the rain pattered on it.
tr: Long before the Banana Company came and zinc roofs became widespread, Aureliano Segundo was one of the first to bring zinc sheets to Macondo. And he had them brought solely to lay on the roof of Petra Cotes' bedroom and to hold his mistress more tightly while listening to the rain hitting the zinc.
es: He had been one of the first to bring zinc sheets to Macondo, long before the banana company made them fashionable, just to roof Petra Cotes's bedroom with them and enjoy the deep intimacy that the rain’s crepitation produced in him at that time.

en: But even those wild memories of his mad youth left him unmoved, just as during his last debauch he had exhausted his quota of salaciousness and all he had left was the marvelous gift of being able to remember it without bitterness or repentance.
vi: But even the wild memories of his youthful debauchery couldn't cheer him up. In his most recent binge, he had lost his lustful enthusiasm. All that remained was the indifferent joy of organizing feasts.
tr: However, now even the memory of those wild youthful days no longer excited him. In the midst of the last revelry he embarked on, he had exhausted his reservoir of lust and was left breathless halfway through. Fortunately, he possessed the virtue of being able to recall all these without feeling a pang in his heart or any regret.
es: But even those crazy memories of his extravagant youth left him impassive, as if in the last party he had exhausted his quotas of salaciousness, and only the wonderful prize of being able to recall them without bitterness or regrets remained.

en: It might have been thought that the deluge had given him the opportunity to sit and reflect and that the business of the pliers and the oilcan had awakened in him the tardy yearning of so many useful trades that he might have followed in his life and did not; but neither case was true, because the temptation of a sedentary domesticity that was besieging him was not the result of any rediscovery or moral lesion.
vi: One might think that the flood had given him time to reflect, and the small tasks with pliers and oil cans had awakened in him a late regret for the practical trades he could have pursued but never did in his life, regretting that none of them were concrete, because the desire to sit still and the household chores that once stimulated him were not the result of thoughtful contemplation nor a learned lesson.
tr: Those who saw him in this state might think that he was taking advantage of the opportunity created by the storm to reflect deeply or that he longed for a multitude of useful tasks he could have done throughout his life but never did, while fiddling with pliers and an oil can. However, the domesticity that began to envelop Aureliano Segundo had nothing to do with regret or a sudden onset of wisdom.
es: One might have thought that the deluge had given him the opportunity to sit and reflect, and that the hustle of pliers and oil cans had awakened in him a late longing for so many useful trades he could have done and didn’t do in life, but neither was true, because the temptation of sedentariness and domesticity that was haunting him was not the result of reflection or lesson learned.

en: it came from much farther off, unearthed by the rain’s pitchfork from the days when in Melquíades’ room he would read the prodigious fables about flying carpets and whales that fed on entire ships and their crews.
vi: That nostalgia was unearthed by the rainy season, coming to him from far away, from the days he sat reading in Melquíades' room about the legendary tales of flying carpets and giant whales swallowing ships.
